HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Senate Race;
Republican Imperils Tide Of Democrats in California

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23

 BODY:
In the volatile 1992 election year, at least this has seemed certain: Gov. Bill Clinton will win California big, and he will bring with him two female Democratic Senators, Barbara Boxer and Dianne Feinstein.
But an upset could be in the making. By painting the liberal Ms. Boxer as a free-spending Washington insider, a 60-year-old conservative Republican who has never held elective office before is swimming against the rushing Democratic tide. Poll takers say he has surged in recent days, shaking the Boxer camp and feminists nationally. 
 He is Bruce Herschensohn, a former Government film maker, aide to Richard M. Nixon and television commentator who resembles few other politicians. To him, a fine meal consists of two pieces of American cheese between slices of white bread, served on a paper plate. His one-bedroom apartment in Hollywood, which lacks even plates and glasses, makes a college dormitory room seem luxurious. The only possessions the divorced Mr. Herschensohn values are his ideas, deeply conservative notions about driving the Federal Government out of people's lives.
He advocates abolishing or cutting back nearly every Federal agency except the Department of Defense. Mr. Herschensohn would repeal the Endangered Species Act, ban abortion except when the mother's life is threatened or in cases of rape and incest, replace the graduated income tax with a flat tax, and provide no Federal aid to rebuild after hurricanes, riots and other disasters. He favors free international trade and a strong military presence abroad.
All of this is based on a strict interpretation of the Constitution, leaving most authority with the states. "I am a constitutionalist more than I am anything else," he said in an interview on Wednesday. "If I were to label myself, that would be the label."
Although the Boxer campaign has tried, it has been difficult for it to paint Mr. Herschensohn as a wild-eyed extremist, given that his avuncular face and mellifluous baritone are familiar to millions of Southern Californians from his nightly commentaries on KABC-TV here over 13 years. While supported by the religious right, his conservatism seems less emotional.
"He comes off as reasonable and rational," said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a political analyst at the Claremont Graduate School. "He reminds me of Ronald Reagan. You might hate what he stands for, but he's a decent human being. He's very media friendly, while Boxer comes off as overly shrill."
 
'Down to Earth'
 Indeed, if Sandra Martinez is typical, Ms. Boxer, a Representative since 1982, is in trouble. Even though Ms. Martinez, a saleswoman for a medical clinic, strongly favors abortion rights, she is undecided. After hearing Mr. Herschensohn speak at a lunch this week, she found his manner "down to earth," while saying she found reports of Ms. Boxer's writing 143 uncovered checks on the House bank "a little bit scary."
Ms. Boxer's early lead has been halved, according to the latest Field Poll, from 22 points in mid-September to 11 points in a poll taken Oct. 3-10. The polls of 900 registered voters had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points. Ms. Feinstein still holds a sizable lead in her race against Senator John Seymour.
More recent private polls show the Boxer-Herschnesohn race even closer, though the Republican's own poll taker, Arnold Steinberg, said he remains the underdog because Governor Clinton leads President Bush in California by a staggering margin of 22 points. A rattled Boxer campaign called on Mr. Clinton for help, and he barnstormed with her on Thursday.
California has a history of vote splitting. In 1964, for example, California voted overwhelmingly for Lyndon B. Johnson for President over the conservative Barry Goldwater but elected a conservative Republican, George Murphy, to the Senate over Pierre Salinger.
In an interview, Ms. Boxer attributed her troubles to the fact that the Republican, with $2.5 million from the National Republican Senatorial Committee, had been able to go on television two weeks ahead of her. His slashing advertisements attacked her overdrafts, recent absenteeism and support for a Congressional pay raise.
 
'I've Been Brutally Attacked'
 "It's been as tough as I thought it would be," she said. "I've been brutally attacked day after day. These are negative attacks meant to cover up the differences. He's trying to cover up his own record and the issues."
In recent days, Ms. Boxer's advertisements have avoided direct attacks. Her latest advertisement extols her commitment to education. The Republican's new commercial attempts to smooth the hard edges, saying he wants to protect the environment "not the bureaucrats who give us absurd regulations."
On the campaign trail, Mr. Herschensohn, who never attended college, articulates his principles with bluntness.
On environmental protection: "Now we have the gnat-catcher and the Stevens kangaroo rat and a possible loss of 100,000 to 200,000 jobs. The rat isn't worth one Californian's job to me. Do you even know what they look like?" (In an exception that is perhaps particularly appropriate for a candidate who portrays himself as a superpatriot, Mr. Herschensohn does advocate Federal protection to save the bald eagle.)
 
Odd Political Career
 On the Los Angeles riots: "It isn't economic deprivation that causes people to do that. It is a terribly bad character."
Mr. Herschensohn's is one of the odder political careers in America. The son of a doctor who migrated to Los Angeles from Milwaukee when he was 8 years old, Mr. Herschensohn eschewed college, taking a job as a messenger with RKO Pictures and ultimately becoming a documentary film maker, joining the United States Information Agency in 1968.
There he made admiring films on John F. Kennedy, Vice President Spiro Agnew and Mr. Nixon, but ultimately had to resign in 1972 after he publicly called Senator J. W. Fulbright, who was then chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, "very naive and stupid." But he soon turned up as deputy special assistant to President Nixon at the White House. According to Nixon archive documents distributed by the Boxer campaign, he tried to defend the President against impeachment and argued against resignation until the very end.
He returned to Los Angeles and joined KABC, taking time out to make a losing primary bid for the Senate in 1986 and then ran again this year, when he beat Representative Tom Campbell, a more moderate Republican, in a three-way race.
 
'I Will Not Compromise'
 "After talking about issues, national and international, for the past 13 years, you feel frustrated in not being able to do something about them," he said in the interview. "You do reach a point of saying, 'I don't only want to try to influence, I want to actually do these things.' "
But just how much he could accomplish is a big question. He would not be a deal maker. "I will not compromise on matters of principle," he said. "I am not one for pork. I want the Federal Government out of the act."
His views on environmental protection illustrate his philosophy: "I have no problem with the Federal Government giving guidance. But I have great difficulty with its doing the kinds of things it has done, like the Endangered Species Act, like the idea of going on private property and saying there's a puddle and it's a wetland and you cannot do what you want with this land any more. That Endangered Species Act has got to have a prologue that the human species takes precedence over any other species." He said he would leave environmental rules up to individual states.

HEADLINE: E. F. Denison, Economist, 76; Devised G.N.P.

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Edward F. Denison, an economist who was an expert on national income and production, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 76 years old.
The cause of death was not determined, but he had suffered from heart disease, his family said. 
 Mr. Denison served for 18 years as an official in the United States Commerce Department, working at various times in the Roosevelt, Truman, Eisenhower, Carter and Reagan Administrations. For 30 years he also worked for the Brookings Institution, a nonpartisan economics and public policy research organization.
In the 1940's and 50's, Mr. Denison was credited with developing the measurement of the United States gross national product, which in turn became the basis for similar calculations in other nations. His colleagues in that project included Milton Gilbert, George Jaszi and Charles F. Schwartz.
 
Impacts on Productivity
 Expanding on his work at Brookings in the 1960's, he developed new studies on the causes of economic growth, including increased capital, improved education of workers and scientific and technological advances. His methods and analyses were adopted by scholars around the world. His later research looked at the effect on productivity of factors like dishonesty, tax law revisions, energy costs and government regulations like pollution control and worker safety.
Despite his detailed findings, he also acknowledged that some causes of economic trends remained "a mystery."
Mr. Denison was a former vice president of the American Economic Association, executive committee chairman of the Conference on Research in Income and Wealth and member of the governing board of the National Economists Club. He wrote several books and numerous articles.
Born in Omaha, he grew up in Oak Park, Ill. After graduating from Oberlin College in 1936, he earned a master's degree in economics in 1938 and a doctorate in 1941, both at Brown University.
At the Commerce Department he was an economist and the acting chief of the National Income Division from 1941 to 1948, assistant director of the Business Economics Office from 1949 to 1956 and associate director of National Economic Accounts from 1979 to 1982. At Brookings he was a research fellow in 1939 and 1940, a senior fellow from 1962 to 1978 and an active senior fellow emeritus since 1982.
At the end of World War II, he studied the effects of Allied bombing on Germany. In 1951 he graduated from the National War College.
Surviving are his wife of 51 years, the former Elsie Lightbown; a son, Edward B. Denison of Palatine, Ill.; a daughter, State Senator Janet Howell of Reston, Va.; two sisters, Edna Ferguson and Miriam Burton, both of Seattle, and four grandchildren.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 9; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Where Are All the Happy Endings?

BYLINE: By Walter Goodman; Walter Goodman is a television critic for The New York Times.

 BODY:

HOLLYWOOD VS. AMERICA
Popular Culture and the War on Traditional Values.
By Michael Medved.
386 pp. New York:
HarperCollins Publishers. $20. 
 MICHAEL MEDVED, a movie reviewer seen on public television, writes as though to the blurb born. His style is shrill and sanctimonious, and his book reeks of the us-vs.-them (and sometimes the me-vs.-them) spirit that resounded through the Republican National Convention. Still, the man is on to something, although he manages to muddle what it is.
To begin with the familiar, "Hollywood vs. America" takes the perpetrators of movies, television shows and rap music to task for churning out ever more violence, sex and profanity. Although the studies he cites can be silly -- it is reported that violent acts occurred on television "some 55 times more frequently than they did in the real world" -- viewers can attest that big screens and small are generously besplattered.
Mr. Medved, who is not too particular when casting about for evidence to support a position, also cites a few studies that suggest that watching violence may lead to its commission. That remains highly problematic. But his assumption that relentless exposure to on-screen violence, sex and profanity must have some effect, and not a salubrious one, is more plausible than the denials of their marketers that anything they turn out could possibly influence anybody.
The fresher part of "Hollywood vs. America" has to do with those good old values. Mr. Medved decries what he calls "The Assault on the Family." The chapter headings make up his bill of indictment: "Promoting Promiscuity," "Maligning Marriage," "Encouraging Illegitimacy," "Kids Know Best." An entire section of the book is given to "The Attack on Religion."
Mr. Medved says he is against censorship and wants only balance: more movies with heroes -- especially American heroes -- happy families, happy endings and religion. (He does not fail to mention, more than once, that he and his family are observant Jews.) He looks back fondly to the era when the big studios followed "eminently reasonable guidelines" that forbade treating any religious faith, ceremony, minister, priest, rabbi or mullah disrespectfully, and leaves the impression that "Going My Way" is a better movie than "True Confessions."
For a professional reviewer, he shows little interest in esthetic distinctions. By his accounting, for instance, violence -- whether in "Silence of the Lambs" or "Goodfellas" or in all the "Terminators" and their ilk -- is violence. He acknowledges that "Silence of the Lambs" was exceedingly well acted and directed, but his bottom line in this case is moral uplift.
The book's running theme is that Hollywood's view of America is very different from the views of most Americans. For one thing, it is skewed emphatically to what Mr. Medved calls the loony left. Who besides studio press agents can dispute that?
But he goes farther, offering figures to demonstrate that movies that run contrary to strongly held values do not make so much money as those that carry a more conventional message, and that violence, sex and profanity are keeping people away from the box office and the tube. His essential measure of success is an accountant's: the box-office failure of "The Last Temptation of Christ" is treated as a moral judgment. But he glides over the millions raked in by all those "Terminators," "Die Hards," "Rambos" and "Robocops" as well as hit shows like "The Simpsons" and "Married . . . With Children." He has trouble deciding whether Hollywood is too successful at corrupting America or not successful enough.
As Mr. Medved keeps pointing out, studio heads and producers do live in a very special world: Woody Allen's jokes, which seem so funny in New York and Los Angeles, fall flat in most other places. But laying Hollywood's economic problems so heavily to bicoastal provincialism omits too much. The industry is grappling with profound changes in its role, in the sources of entertainment and in the mass audience. Today, movies and television have to grab the attention of sizable groups deeply divided by age, education, income and other factors. The job is more complicated than in Mr. Medved's philosophy.
Instead of addressing such matters, Mr. Medved goes in for anecdotes, alliteration ("a preference for the perverse," "a bias for the bizarre," "counterculture's comprehensive conquest") and quotations from congenial critics to cook up this couscous.
The book's spirit is expressed in its epigraph from Frank Capra's self-celebrating and untrustworthy autobiography, "The Name Above the Title": "Only the morally courageous are worthy of speaking to their fellow men for two hours in the dark. And only the artistically incorrupt will earn and keep the people's trust." This is not only blather; it also makes nonsense of Capra's own work, which was chronically compromised by deferring to what the audience was willing to take. But that is exactly what Mr. Medved seems to admire.
His contention that Hollywood is self-destructing is startling. By that assessment, the moguls who have been pilloried for decades for producing for profit, pandering to the lowest common denominator and so forth are in fact willing to lose money to advance their preferred causes and to liberate the creative energies of directors and writers, which is what most critics have been demanding since movies began.
But not Mr. Medved. He instructs the producers that it "makes little sense to give needless offense to any significant segment of the moviegoing public." Thanks. His lamentation that "the old struggle between art and commerce has tilted decisively in the direction of art" is not meant sarcastically.
I don't know that there is much to choose between the puerile populism of Mr. Medved and that of the Hollywoodniks he challenges here. It would be like taking sides when Gorgo the Dinosaur meets Mothra the Giant Moth. I'll settle for a good movie.

HEADLINE: FILM;
A Director Crosses the Line Into a Reality of . . . More Lines

BYLINE: By KAREN SCHOEMER

 BODY:
Anthony Drazan has come home again. On a bright October afternoon, the director and writer of "Zebrahead" is taking a tour of his old neighborhood in Cedarhurst, L. I., just a few miles over the border from Queens. He is going back to visit some of the scenes that inspired the film, giving a tour of the divergent black and white neighborhoods.
"Zebrahead," which opened in Manhattan on Friday, is the story of a white Jewish teen-ager named Zack whose best friend is black and who winds up dating Nikki, a black girl, in high school. The film played for two nights at this year's New York Film Festival. There, it received some mixed reviews, and a great deal of attention: for Mr. Drazan's enormous good fortune with this, his first movie, and for its exploration of racial issues.Because Mr. Drazan, a white man, has made a film about black-and-white relationships. 
 Much of the $2 million movie is autobiographical, and Mr. Drazan, who is 37 years old, had been working on the script for several years. In 1990 the story came to the attention of the director Oliver Stone, who agreed to serve as executive producer. "Zebrahead" eventually won the Film maker's Award at the 1992 Sundance Film Festival, and Mr. Drazan is now involved in a deal to direct two pictures for Steven Spielberg's production company.
On today's tour through Cedarhurst, the car is being driven by Chuck Mitchell, who served as one of the producers on "Zebrahead" and who at the moment is taking Mr. Drazan's soft-spoken but very specific directions on where and when to turn. Mr. Drazan narrates: "This is Rockaway Boulevard. This is a very commercial sector. You can see there's a row of gas stations on the left-hand side, tanks over on the right."
The car turns off the boulevard and the neighborhood abruptly changes. "What you have here is single-family homes," Mr. Drazan says. "You can get a little flavor of the kind of suburb we're talking about: one block off the commercial district, 20 minutes from the inner city."
"Zebrahead" is similarly set in the no man's land between urban and suburban. The teen-age Zack, played by Michael Rapaport, identifies strongly with black music and culture. He listens to hip-hop and his speech has a pronounced urban lilt, although the film does not use hip-hop music as an engine for its plot. "I didn't want to make a hip-hop film," Mr. Drazan says. "As a film maker I felt the choice was clear: to deromanticize elements, and keep it simple and stark."
Zack's best friend, Dee, is black; both Zack and Dee are from middle-class families. The high school the boys attend in "Zebrahead" includes students from a variety of social and ethnic backgrounds. The director videotaped hours of conversations between students in the lunch room of a Yonkers high school and translated some of those conversations directly into the film -- specifically a conversation among black teen-age girls on the subject of dating white boys. Black and white, male and female, upper middle class and lower middle class -- "Zebrahead" is about crossing the lines.
When Mr. Drazan was growing up in Cedarhurst, his best childhood friend, Douglas, was black. At the time, Mr. Drazan's neighborhood was not integrated. For the most part, two decades later, that line of demarcation remains sharply drawn. Mr. Drazan directs the car back across Rockaway Boulevard, to the other side of the commercial zone. The car literally crosses a set of railroad tracks, and the neighborhood shifts again. The economic conditions noticeably deteriorate.
When he was in his teens, Mr. Drazan moved away from Cedarhurst. He graduated from the New York University film school in 1985, and in 1987 brought the script of "Zebrahead" to a workshop at Robert Redford's Sundance Institute. Soon afterward, he met Mr. Mitchell. At one point, Mr. Drazan took Mr. Mitchell on the Cedarhurst tour. "I thought, 'This guy's got a movie,' " Mr. Mitchell says. "Because what you always look for is that sense of place that defines a whole set of characters."
An early version of the script was set on Long Island, but air traffic from nearby John F. Kennedy Airport would have interfered with shooting, so Mr. Drazan scouted dozens of Northeastern and Midwestern areas looking for his hometown's critical, semi-urban, cross-racial mix. (He found it in Detroit, where the film was shot.)
In casting "Zebrahead," Mr. Drazan chose unknowns for all the teen-age roles. DeShonn Castle, a rapper who plays Dee, was discovered at the Yonkers high school where Mr. Drazan was doing research. N'Bushe Wright, who plays Nikki, is a dancer from the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. Ron Johnson, who plays Nut, the volatile young character who vies for Nikki's affections, is a rapper from South-Central Los Angeles. The naturalistic performances have earned good notices.
Mr. Johnson says that at the film festival "people would walk up to me and congratulate me, saying, 'That was good how you brought that across.' But that's how I felt." As Mr. Rapaport says, "If you look at Ron, look at me or look at DeShonn, we're all close to our characters."
Mr. Drazan directs the car down a narrow street in the black neighborhood. "My friend Douglas lived in the second house in, over there," he says. "I would imagine that Doug and I hit it off because he sat in the back left corner of the classroom and that's where I felt comfortable sitting too. I lost my mother when I was young, so I had a strong feeling of alienation from the mainstream. Anybody who's gone through something like that feels just completely different and outside. It's hard to fit in."
In "Zebrahead," issues of race and identity ultimately shatter the fragile balance within the high school community. But ultimately Mr. Drazan believes that the bonds of friendship are much harder to break. "Zack and Dee have a true friendship that's built on a lot of things," he says, "and not just identification of a cultural sort."
In Cedarhurst, a few places are vacated or boarded up. Although it is the middle of a weekday afternoon, many people are on the street, hanging out in front yards or sitting on porches. "This is Nassau County," says Mr. Drazan. "This is the suburbs. This is a stone's throw away from New York. This," he adds with calculated irony, "is the Deep South."

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
Reading the Candidates' Family Portraits

BYLINE: By Charles Hagen; Charles Hagen writes frequently about photography and art.

 BODY:
IN THE MIX OF ACTIONS, IDEAS AND pageantry that makes up a Presidential race, two parallel campaigns vie for voters' attention. One is the explicit campaign of issues, while the other, equally important, deals with images and symbols. This year, candidates' families have played a central role in this other campaign of symbols. Using a complex mix of media, including official portraits, staged photo opportunities and elaborate video biographies, candidates have presented themselves and their families, in an effort to convince voters of their character, and their ordinariness.
The official start of the campaign of images, like that of issues, comes at the conventions. It is here, in a now traditional moment at such gatherings, that the theme of family is first made explicit. The candidates stand on the podium in a blaze of television lights, flanked by their wives, children, grandchildren, parents, even brothers and sisters. Lined up like the cast of an opera taking a curtain call, they offer themselves as an admirable example of the American family, given vivid and dramatic form. 
 In the weeks since the conventions, the candidates and their families have been shown in innumerable photographs and on television, engaged in symbolic activities designed to signal their adherence to middle-class values and win voter approval. Following a familiar strategy, the campaigns have linked the candidates to appealing stereotypes of family life, in effect trying to convince voters that the candidates are just like them -- only more so.
As the French critic Roland Barthes wrote in "Mythologies," his classic study of popular culture, photographs of candidates "offer to the voter his own likeness, but clarified, exalted, superbly elevated into a type." As a result, these images often end up saying less about the candidates and their families than about the voters themselves.
The public perception of President and Mrs. Bush as surrogate grandparents to the nation -- what Newsweek called the President's "gampy mode" -- is strikingly reinforced by the official White House portrait of the first family. In it the Bushes appear surrounded by no fewer than 22 children and grandchildren, all neatly lined up and dressed in their Sunday best.
But it is in photographic coverage of Mrs. Bush that the gampy (or gammy) mode shifts into high gear. With her matronly bearing, famous white hair and beaming smile, she seems like a wise and caring Sunday school teacher, and she is often photographed reading to groups of children. These pictures serve the practical purpose of promoting literacy programs, but they also reinforce her motherly image.
In combining marriage, motherhood and a career, Hillary Clinton's life is not all that unusual today. Despite this, she -- or her handlers -- still feels the need to project something of the image of a traditional housewife. Throughout the campaign she, too, has often been photographed in "caring" roles, whether speaking with young cancer patients, showing off her chocolate chip cookies or gazing adoringly at her husband.
Given Mrs. Clinton's reputation for independence, it is not surprising that she and her husband are often depicted in echoing poses. When Time magazine ran a cover article about the "Hillary Factor," it featured a large close-up of the Clintons standing together, seen in profile. With their matching expressions of serious concern, the two look a little as if they're about to be carved onto a coin.
Another picture in the Time story probably reflected many people's misgivings about Mrs. Clinton's personality. It showed her wearing a black cowboy hat and dark glasses, scowling into the camera.
The portentously titled video biography of her husband, "The Man From Hope," produced for the convention by the Clinton campaign, betrays no such ambivalence in its celebration of Clinton family life. Productions of this sort have almost become a campaign requirement. A similar video self-portrait of Vice President Quayle was shown at the Republican convention, as part of his announced attempt to redefine his image.
Both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Quayle feature their families prominently in these video self-portraits. The two works are drenched in nostalgia and use similar techniques. Blurry home movies of the candidates as children are mixed with black-and-white snapshots and interviews in which the candidates, their wives and other family members offer anecdotes to emphasize how ordinary their childhoods were -- even if they weren't.
Thus Mr. Quayle's video makes no mention of his family's wealth but includes home movies showing him learning to roller skate and a snapshot of his father standing in front of their unassuming ranch-style house, holding him as a baby.
It comes as no surprise that in Mr. Clinton's video a host of family members testify to his good character. The tape emphasizes his small-town roots through the use of old photographs and home movies. In a nice touch, the tape also incorporates shots from home videos that show Mr. Clinton dancing with his 12-year-old daughter, Chelsea, the two of them throwing stones into a pond, and Chelsea, in a long white dress, curtsying in shy delight for the camera.
These sentimental images, which could have been lifted from a commercial for camcorders, serve to blunt questions viewers may have about the effect Mr. Clinton's rumored infidelity has had on his daughter. At the same time, they show the Clintons engaging in a common ritual of contemporary middle-class life.
Even Ross Perot, despite his announced refusal to play the game of images, apparently felt the need to let the country in on his (humble) family background. In the closing weeks of the campaign, he aired a half-hour television show about himself and his family. Like his charts-and-pointer talks on the economy, this was short on production values and long on folksiness.
While Mr. Perot reminisced about his childhood in Texarkana, Tex., his service in the Navy and his early career working for I.B.M., snapshots flashed on the screen. Mr. Perot appeared as a boy, standing with his parents or on a seesaw or a horse. Other pictures showed him as a cadet at the Naval Academy, and with his wife shortly after their marriage. In all, the experience was much like that of looking through a family album with a cantankerous uncle telling anecdotes about each shot.
When Mr. Clinton selected Senator Al Gore as his running mate, he added a curious twist to the usual campaign scenario. Because the Clintons and the Gores are in many ways similar, they give the impression they could be neighbors. This sense of closeness was furthered by the now-famous bus tour of the Midwest the candidates and their wives took just after the convention.
On this trip the Clintons and the Gores seemed almost like two couples off on vacation, journeying in their mobile home into the heart of America. News photographs of them sipping sodas on the bus or appearing on stages together, passing the microphone back and forth, were like slides of a neighbor's trip to Disney World. The tour underscored the conceit that candidates and their families are just regular folks.
Perhaps because of the appeal of the resulting images, the bus tour has become one of the central symbolic events of the campaign, and has spawned imitators. Several members of the Bush family, including Barbara Bush, her daughter, Doro Bush Koch, and others, recently toured Wisconsin on a bus, while Senator Gore's parents, along with Hillary Clinton's mother, embarked on what the Democrats billed as the "Senior Bus Tour" through New Jersey.
WHILE THE BUS TOUR provides an updated version of the time-honored whistle-stop campaign, the use of candidates' families for symbolic purposes is by no means a recent development. One of the most popular images of Abraham Lincoln, taken at Mathew Brady's studio in 1864, showed him seated in an armchair, a large book in his hands, with his young son Tad leaning on a nearby table.
James D. Horan, in his biography "Mathew Brady: Historian With a Camera," quotes a journalist of the time who reported that Lincoln worried about the fact that the scene was a setup. People might think that he was "making believe reading the Bible to Tad," Lincoln said, when in fact he was holding a photographic album. Despite Lincoln's reservations, an engraving of the photograph was featured in Harper's Weekly shortly after his assassination and the picture was later widely reproduced as a lithograph.
In ensuing years, families assumed an increasingly important role in the public image of Presidential candidates. With the rise of mass media and the growing popularity of behind-the-scenes views of candidates and their families, voters were offered increasingly detailed, if not always accurate, reports about Presidents' families. First Ladies in particular, from Eleanor Roosevelt to Mamie Eisenhower to Rosalynn Carter and Nancy Reagan, were all assigned distinctive characters in the public mind, with the press supplying photographic evidence to support those impressions.
Enlisting a President's family to boost his public image reached a new intensity with the election of John F. Kennedy. The Kennedys provided the country with a ready-made soap opera, complete with attractive main characters, an extensive and colorful supporting cast, and the real-life drama of national affairs. In many ways, the most enduring images of the Kennedy years have been of family scenes, whether of John John running to greet his father or peeking out from beneath his desk in the Oval Office or of the President sailing with his daughter, Caroline. Featured in such mass-market picture magazines as Life and Look, these photographs provided an especially intimate view of the First Family.
Presidents since then have tended to submit to the public's hunger for images reflecting their family life. These days, though, candidates have begun to place limits on the use of their families for publicity purposes. The Clintons have largely shielded their daughter from media attention, refusing to allow her to be interviewed. Even when People magazine ran a photograph of Chelsea on its cover this summer, the accompanying story included no quotes from her. Mr. Perot's wife and children, too, have for the most part stayed out of the limelight.
Despite these hints of change, images of the candidates' families remain a staple in media coverage of the campaigns. Like much else in a Presidential race, these pictures offer a blend of reality and symbolism. Images of this sort serve mainly to confirm voters' preconceptions -- to tell them what they think they already know.
This is true even for news photographs, which might be expected to provide another view. The news photographs that stick most firmly in the public mind are those that confirm pre-existing opinions, and in classic chicken-and-egg fashion, it is these very pictures that photographers tend to take, and editors to publish.
As a result, coverage of the candidates' families, whether photographic or on television, more often than not is conservative and simplistic, both reflecting and reinforcing public attitudes. In the intricate game of images and reality that is at the heart of any campaign, everyone -- candidates, editors and the public -- tends to reach for the reassuringly familiar.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION VIEW;
On 'Roseanne,' The Recession Is a Laugh Riot

BYLINE: By Walter Goodman

 BODY:
With gloomy news about the economy filling the nightly news, the talk shows and the campaign documentaries, it is a pleasure to announce that the Conners are having a good recession. Yes, Dan's motorcycle shop conked out to begin the season, which sent Mark, his young helper, and daughter Becky eloping to Minneapolis, where a job awaits. Roseanne can't get work of her own; there are squabbles over money, problems with mortgage payments and worries about the electricity bill. (The telephone still operates, or how would a sitcom get along?) But the main thing is that the wisecracks keep coming and ratings stay high.
Making jokes out of dire circumstances is a treasured American characteristic, a way to cope and no doubt a sign of mental health. Probably that is how Roseanne's nearest and dearest, punchy from punchlines, manage to stay on this side of neurosis. "I knew we shouldn't have gone into business for ourselves," Roseanne says to Dan by way of commiseration. "There's no one to steal from." 
 But whereas in life, gags may be a cushion against hard knocks, in a sitcom the knocks are merely occasions for the gags. You can be sure that nothing too drastic will happen to the Conners; that's the difference between a sitcom and a soap opera. When, a few weeks ago, Becky, that good girl, became upset enough to attack dear old Dad for ruining her life by his incompetence, it struck a shrill and false note, and in a moment the show went back to snappier tunes.
Be assured that Dan and Roseanne Conner will survive the tough times without losing too much sleep or a single pound. (I imagine Roseanne Arnold and John Goodman are contractually obligated by ABC to maintain a certain heft.) Even if they have to go through their savings, they will be yakking it up all the way from the bank. "I like the kids poor," cracks Roseanne. "That way they don't fight to be the favorite."
The reality quotient in "Roseanne" seems high: the house at Third and Delaware, Lanford, Ill., Middle America, is busy and crowded; the inmates can hardly stay out of one another's way. Somebody is always doing the laundry or fixing a meal or gobbling junk food while staring at the tube. But this is camouflage. The world is not allowed to strike too deep. Spirits never flag, even when the cable service is in jeopardy. Roseanne is able to joke about not getting hired after waiting around for hours for an interview for a job that requires no skill or experience. The show is brilliant at coaxing audience empathy without risk of making anyone too depressed to watch.
Anyhow, just in case anybody out there was brooding over the Conners' prospects as the recession slogs along, who should show up but Roseanne's take-charge mom. Not only is she a great target for mother and mother-in-law jokes, but she also brings with her two checks for $10,000 each, for Roseanne and her sister, Jackie. Talk about points of light! And President Bush would be overjoyed to learn that the family is investing in a loose-meat restaurant, whatever that is. Small business may yet save the country.
For a moment, when the gift was handed over, Roseanne seemed downright earnest: "Mom, you have no idea how much this means to us now." But a breath later, she was back in form. Grabbing the check from her daughter Darlene, everybody's favorite awful teen-ager, she said: "Give me that check. You're drooling the zeros off it."
So the crisis, if it was a crisis, seems to be ebbing. As Roseanne has put it, "Poverty is grand, but we've tried that." Although she could not obtain a bank loan for the restaurant last Tuesday, the deus ex mamma came through with more money. But now she wants to be a full partner, which means -- and this is the important point -- that Roseanne will have Mom to kick around for a while longer.
Has the experience affected the Conners' political inclinations, as it seems to have affected those of millions of their fellow citizens? Well, you can't tell. Roseanne is no blue-collar Murphy Brown. Politics is not much discussed at the Conners' dinner table, even though it lends itself to the put-downs that are the family's favorite dish. The Conners didn't even seem to notice that some of their usual television shows were pre-empted by the campaign debates. The Simpsons are more politically aware.
Can it be that indifference to public issues is one of the elements, along with the dependable one-liners and the cluttered ambiance, that keeps fans coming back to "Roseanne"? In the throes of a tube-saturating Presidential campaign, even people who vote may take comfort in the weekly visit to one household where George Bush and Bill Clinton will never be household words.

HEADLINE: Recession Dictates Renovation

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
ADDITIONS to Manhattan's skyline may have all but stopped, evidence of the severe recession ravaging the world of commercial real estate these days. But scores of office buildings are being repaired, renovated and reconfigured as landlords, faced with an increasingly competitive market, strive to make their properties as attractive as possible.
The capital improvements -- which, in many cases, are designed to keep old tenants as much as lure new ones -- are esthetic (installing new floors, facades, walls and windows), efficient (improving access for the disabled and replacing old elevators, bathrooms, electrical and telecommunications systems) and environmentally conscious (installing new heating, air-conditioning and security systems and removing asbestos). 
 The renovations themselves are just as varied. They include a $12 million overhaul of the security system at Rockefeller Center and a $30 million modernizing of the 60-story One Chase Manhattan Plaza at Liberty, Pine, Williams and Nassau Streets in lower Manhattan.
And then there are the smaller buildings, such as the 24-story, 350,000-square-foot structure at 90 West Street in the heart of the financial district in lower Manhattan and the 21-story Art Deco office tower across the street from the empty former B. Altman department store near the Empire State Building at 16 East 34th Street.
"Basically, our building was in a state of disrepair and neglect when we acquired it," said Nancy Ann Peck, the president of S.L. Green Real Estate, of Manhattan, which in a joint venture with clients of Loeb Partners Realty, also of Manhattan, bought the 360,000 square-foot building at 16 East 34th Street late last year. "So, to change the image and create new interest in the project, we launched a major rejuvenation program."
CAPITAL improvements have become particularly commonplace in the financial district, where vacancy rates are high because banks, financial houses and brokerage firms, feeling the effects of the recession and the aftermath of the 1987 stock market crash, have cut their staffs and office-space needs.
According to Cushman & Wakefield, the vacancy rate for office buildings in downtown Manhattan in the third quarter of 1992 was 20.1 percent, up from 18.7 percent in 1991 For mid-Manhattan, it was 17.2 percent, virtually unchanged from the 17.3 percent vacancy rate last year. By comparison, the vacancy rates for both mid-Manhattan and downtown in 1986 were 9.8 percent.
At One Chase Manhattan Plaza, renovations began last year when the entire exterior of the structure was cleaned. And three months ago, the building began removing asbestos. Future plans call for upgrading elevators, installing new bathrooms, floors, ceilings, lighting, heating and cooling systems and turning the lobby into a more dramatic two-story area. The building was built in 1960 and designed by the New York office of Skidmore Owings & Merrill, which is also handling the renovations.
"We wanted to keep our building in a class A category, and in order to do that we realized we had to look at the lobby and renovate it, not only for our tenants, but for us," said Edward A. Rytter, vice president and director of facilities for Chase Manhattan Bank. "There is no question that having a lobby that is current and attractive is an enhancement to the tenants that are there and well as any prospective tenants."
On a smaller scale in lower Manhattan, the Galbreath Company, of Manhattan, is spending $7 million to renovate the 37-story, 950,000 square-foot building at 14 Wall Street. Plans include a new design for the main entrance, a new main lobby, new common corridors with marble, brass and custom lighting fixtures and the restoration of an 8,000 square-foot penthouse restaurant in a former apartment of J.P. Morgan. The company, which is managing the building for its owner, General Electric Investments, is also replacing the building's windows and elevator cabs and upgrading its electrical system. The work is scheduled to be completed early next year.
"Our belief is that if we make the property somewhat more distinctive, we would draw more tenants," said John Wheeler, a managing director of Galbreath.
Nearby, a Dutch partnership called FGP 90 West Street, is spending $4 million to renovate 90 West Street, a historic 24-story, 350,000 square-foot office building. The project includes a refurbishing of the lobby, new elevator systems and upgraded common space and bathrooms, as well as a new copper mansard roof with gold-painted highlights.
The property, which is directly south of the World Trade Center and was built in 1905 by Cass Gilbert, the designer of the Woolworth building, had been in foreclosure and receivership for two years before being acquired by the partnership last year. It is also managed by Galbreath.
Since the takeover, the vacancy rate of the building has dropped from 40 to 30 percent. "Tenants in the building that have lived through the receivership and the foreclosure are extremely happy," said Karla Beth Kudatsky, associate director of leasing for Galbreath. "We have leased since last November in excess of 80,000 square feet, which is a remarkable figure because of the market."
At 55 Broad Street, near Wall Street, which was left nearly vacant last year after the anchor tenant, Drexel Burnham Lambert, filed for bankruptcy protection, the lobbies have been renovated, the elevators upgraded and all the asbestos from the building has been removed.
The building is owned by the Rudin Management Company, which has further renovation plans but won't begin them until a major commitment is made by a new tenant. "But in marketing the building, we show the prospective tenants the drawings and the plans," said William C. Rudin, executive vice president of Rudin.
Capital improvements are also taking place in the suburbs, where the vacancy rates in office buildings are often even higher than they are in New York. In Fairfield County, Conn., for instance, the vacancy rate, according to Cushman & Wakefield, was 28.1 percent for the third quarter. In Westchester County, it was 27.3 percent.
BECAUSE credit is tight, though, much of the renovation, both in the city and the outlying region, is being undertaking by companies, usually larger ones, that can finance the work themselves. "They're not going outside for financing," said Bruce Fehey, president of McCann Inc., a Manhattan construction company.
Older buildings have the greatest need for remodeling because of their often awkward layouts and dated wiring systems. The higher levels of asbestos found in older buildings also makes them less competitive with newer properties. "The cost of removal is down 60 percent of what it used to be, and building owners are taking advantage of that," said Daniel J. Sitomir, a environmental lawyer in Manhattan. "It was $50 a square foot in 1985-86, now it's $13."
At 16 East 34th Street, which was built in 1929, recent renovation cost $7 million and included creating a new entrance on 34th Street, cleaning and painting the building's facade, replacing the windows, installing new bathrooms, repairing and restoring the lobby, installing a new concierge desk and new elevator cabs, laying a new roof on top of the older leaky, often-patched roof and upgrading the air-conditioning systems.
Ms. Peck said that since the renovation began 10 months ago, the vacancy rate in the building, whose tenants are mostly law firms, publishing houses and apparel makers, has dropped from 50 to 20 percent. Four floors are still vacant, as well as a small space facing the 33d Street entrance.
SHE added that a key part of the renovation was improving the electrical system. "The building didn't have adequate power for the current demand of office needs," Ms. Peck said. "We brought in 1,200 more amps; the prior service was about 5,000."
Indeed, not all the capital improvements being made these days are of the brick-and-mortar nature. A major consideration is customized communications systems that can accommodate the latest generation of telephones and computers. Some buildings require extensive alterations to accommodate the necessary wiring. Most buildings older than 10 years need some updating.
"Renovated exteriors and lobbies get prospective tenants in the door, but today's sophisticated users are delving below the surface for the technology their businesses increasingly require," said Harvey Brickman, senior vice president of Tishman Construction Corporation.
"It is a much more complex task to install new and integrated security, communications, life safety and environmental control systems in an existing building not designed for these systems than to include them in the design of a new structure," he added.
SECURITY, in particular, is a top priority for tenants these days, and the state-of-the-art system Tishman is installing in the Rockefeller Center buildings incorporates a broad range of features including identification card readers, infrared sensors, alarms, closed-circuit television cameras and monitors. It also has a computerization system that records all entries and alarms.
Tishman was also involved with renovating 575 Lexington Avenue, at 51st Street, a 34-year-old, 36-story, 589,000 square-foot office tower. The renovation's most dramatic aspect, which was completed in 1990, was the installation of a new curtain-wall system of sleek black heat-processed aluminum and glass over the outdated gold anodized aluminum facade. The building, which was renovated by the architect, Der Scutt, also features a new granite-and-glass entry with bronze trim and a state-of-the-art elevator system.
"You have to do this to be able to compete in a very tight market, to keep tenants and also to compete with getting any new tenants," said Vince Piscopo, a senior vice president at Tishman.
For companies like Tishman and McCann, renovation has helped them during a time when there is very little new construction. Mr. Fehey said his company was currently working on over a dozen commercial capital improvement projects in Manhattan, including a long-term project to upgrade the underground concourse at Rockefeller Center, between 47th and 51st Streets. The work began three years ago and will continue for several more years.
"It's work," Mr. Fehey said. "It's not enough to give us an upswing, but this kind of work would not be going on if our building needs outstripped our supply."

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Industrial Space in Queens;
A Pleasant Time for Tenants on the Move

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
"MY pet peeve is the occupancy tax," said Richard Zirinsky in the hearty voice of a man happy to describe himself as a salesman. "To pay 6 or 7 percent for the privilege of renting industrial or commercial space is silly."
With little prompting, this 77-year-old developer and owner of industrial and commercial space in Queens will take a swipe at electricity costs and taxes in New York City as well. They have pushed industrial tenants out of the city, he said. 
 But Mr. Zirinsky himself, chairman of Richard Zirinsky Associates, at 60 East 56th Street in Manhattan, has stayed. He and his late cousin Lawrence Zirinsky started buying industrial properties in the 40's, and now the Zirinskys own 12 buildings with over two million square feet in Long Island City, plus a handful elsewhere. They built properties for major corporations, selling some but keeping most, and they upgraded older buildings for distribution, light assembly and office space.
"You tend to do what you're used to doing," said Mr. Zirinsky. His son Richard Jr., 29, who is president of the firm, seems to like the approach. "When the city comes back, western Queens will follow," he said. "The key is patience right now."
What the Zirinskys have done over the years is to produce new or upgraded space at low cost for corporate users, among them Pfizer, DuPont and American Can. While that business is at bay, leasing activity grinds onward as companies merge or fold or merely move. Since recession causes contraction, availability expands and prices fall. The beneficiaries are the tenants who happen to be expanding.
"The market is terrible and that helped me tremendously because I'm in a very good building," said Randy Greenberg, manager of Crystal Art Gallery, which moved three weeks ago into two 50,000-square-foot floors at 58-30 Grand Avenue in Maspeth, just east of Long Island City. The company frames and distributes posters. It brought its 30 employees from 35,000 square feet "around the corner," Mr. Greenberg said.
Another company that marched into a favorable situation is Cowboy Brothers Trading. It leased the former Capitol Liquors warehouse building at 55-60 58th Street in Maspeth, taking a net lease for a 190,000-square-foot building with a ceiling 20 feet high and 17 loading platforms. The warehouse area is a supermarket for retailers of electronic and home appliances.
"The building was vacant almost two years while the owner was trying to lease it, but he kept seeking an above-market price as the market fell," said Richard Maltz, principal in Greiner-Maltz Company, a 39-year-old commercial and industrial brokerage in Long Island City. "He didn't recognize that the market was slipping away."
The leasing market for buildings of its quality was about $6.25 a square foot per year when it went on the market. That included about $1.25 a foot for real-estate taxes. Now the market for such a building is about $4.50 a square foot including taxes, Mr. Maltz said.
At that figure, the tenant leasing 100,000 square feet would be paying $37,500 a month in rent, of which property taxes of $1.25 a square foot would take $10,400, or 27 percent of the gross rent unless the owner succeeded in getting a reduction.
The Long Island City tenant pays an an occupancy tax of 4.2 percent of gross rent. With a gross rent of $4.50 a square foot, the tax is $18,900 a year for 100,000 square feet. The occupancy tax for commercial tenants used to be 6 percent citywide, but it was reduced by 30 percent for properties outside Manhattan, or north of 96th Street, in June 1989. "You have no idea how that tax sticks in people's craw," the elder Mr. Zirinsky said.
DEPENDING on quality and location, most one-story warehouse buildings can currently be leased at a rent between $2 to $3.50 a square foot per year, excluding taxes, according to Mr. Maltz. This is a drop of 25 to 35 percent from three years ago, he said. Real-estate taxes can add 75 cents to $1.50 a square foot to the base rent.
Greiner-Maltz's figures show that the vacancy rate for factory and warehouse space in western Queens was 12.77 percent in the third quarter of this year. Two years ago it was 11.4 percent. The total inventory of this space is 105.2 million square feet. The area embraces Long Island City, Maspeth, Astoria, College Point, Jackson Heights and Elmhurst.
In both Queens and Brooklyn, Greiner-Maltz finds a somewhat improved market this year. In Queens, for example, the 1.14 million square feet of sales and leasing in the third quarter represented the first time in over four years that activity exceeded one million square feet in back-to-back quarters.
"We're leasing at about the same rate that space is becoming available," Mr. Maltz said, "whereas in the past more space was becoming available that was being leased."
Mr. Zirinsky gave an account of where he stood as a developer of commercial space in Queens when the music stopped in the late 80's.
Encouraged by the growth of showrooms and large stores on Northern Boulevard in Sunnyside, he had bought the former Naarden Fragrance building at 43-23 37th Avenue. The purchase included 5.5 acres of vacant land, a potential construction site.
Encouraged as well by the 48-story Citicorp building at Court Square in Long Island City, he bought the nearby six-story 45-18 Court Square, formerly a Contadina tomato-paste plant, and renovated it for office use.
The office space is still on the market and no user has emerged for the Sunnyside site. But the marketing continues.
Zirinsky Associates has probably been the largest private investor in development property in Long Island City over the last 30 years. Many projects have been successes. In one case the company bought the 50,000-square-foot building at 30-10 41st Avenue and resold it to the Mainco Company, a maintenance firm. In another instance it bought the Volunteers of America building, at 23-10 43d Avenue, rehabilitated it and sold it to the Landes Bank, later bought by the Bank of Austria.
Other investors have taken the same approach, normally with smaller properties. Among these were John Werwaiss, the owner of many buildings in the 2,500-to-25,000-square-foot range. He bought, upgraded and rented out successfully, but stopped the process in the late 80's.
"He was smart," Mr. Maltz said.
Seymour Schuman, principal of Propper Manufacturing, a maker of medical instruments in Long Island City, also started buying in 70's. He upgraded lesser properties and has wound up with a sizable inventory.
Rents have to start approaching $7 or $8 a square foot -- excluding real estate taxes -- for developers to produce new space speculatively. That type of revival is also necessary for a renewal of hopes for more office or store development along the so-called Jackson Avenue corridor, south of Queens Plaza. It is probably a long way off. Right now tenants, often in service businesses, are starting to buy their own buildings, Mr. Maltz said, because for some owners lower rents and high taxes have made ownership too unattractive. Among the sellers are older people getting close to retirement.
The sellers have not included the Zirinskys. The prices have not been right, Mr. Zirinsky said.
"After paying the taxes, there would be very little left," he said.
But vacant buildings are worth more than occupied buildings.
"Users can get financing," he said, "but real estate people can't."

HEADLINE: Talking: Budget Time;
For Co-ops, Rising Fees And Taxes

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
RISING fuel, insurance and water costs will need special attention during the 1993 budget preparation process now in full swing at most New York City co-ops.
Also needing study will be the impact of revenue shortfalls because of increasing delinquencies among shareholders and the decline of flip-tax revenue because of slower sales. Co-ops may also have to set aside funds for taxes that could be due under Section 277 of the Internal Revenue Code. 
 Also new to the budgetary process will be compliance with recent guidelines from the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. They require, at the least, a footnote explaining how future reserves are to be paid for. Although promulgated in August 1991, accountants say the guidelines took time to percolate through the system. Many co-ops did not modify their 1992 budgets and will be doing so for the first time this fall.
The item in greatest danger of gushing out of control is water costs. In 1988, New York City mandated a shift from a flat-rate system to metering. Since then, meters have slowly been installed around the city and dozens of buildings are likely to feel the full brunt of the changeover in 1993.
Managers are recommending a line item increase for water costs of 20 percent on top of the customary 10 percent increase normally allocated, unless more accurate estimates of the effect of metering have already been made. If meters have already been installed, an increase of 3 percent over last year's total should be sufficient, said Anthony Colella, managing director of Tudor City Realty Services Corporation, which handles 23 buildings.
Insurance costs may also rise unexpectedly. Insurance agents warn that the downward slide in the cost of premiums over the last few years may be coming to an end.
Carla Vel, a vice president at Kaye Insurance Associates of Manhattan who specializes in co-op coverage, said insurance companies had taken a triple hit in the last year: first, mounting losses from real estate investments, then a decline in anticipated revenues caused by unusually low interest rates and finally the losses from Hurricane Andrew.
All this, she said, has created a drain on funds that will have to be reversed somehow. The most probable result, she predicts, will be renewed pressure on premium income. Co-ops that have recently joined large group pools hoping that escalating premiums were a thing of the past could also be affected. "Even a pool policy can go up," she said.
She suggests estimating 10 percent more than was paid last year, for everything -- insurance costs on the structure itself, liability and employee coverage.
Fuel oil and natural gas prices are also expected to rise. Oskar Brecher, president of Landmark Management Corporation, which manages 45 buildings, warned that fuel costs, like insurance premiums, had been exceptionally low in recent years. And together with a string of mild winters, they may have now created artificially low expectations.
He warned that recent predictions for an icy winter in 1993 plus a sudden spurt in the price of natural gas earlier in 1992 should serve as a signal that preliminary estimates for the coming winter may need to be raised. He recommended a rise of 15 percent over last year's usage unless major conservation efforts -- such as installing thermal windows or upgrading a burner system -- had been made in the interim.
The potential impact of I.R.S. Section 277 taxes, although not necessarily a new cost, should also be addressed. Section 277 was originally created to tax the income of industrial co-ops and membership organizations. But in the last few years the I.R.S. has begun applying it to residential co-ops, too. The Federal tax has led to state and city levies, all three totaling around 30 percent of any revenues generated from interest income or commercial rents.
HOWEVER, lawyers hope that current court challenges plus proposed modifications to the legislation will eventually make it clear that the tax is not applicable. Meanwhile, there has been mixed opinion on whether a co-op should pay only if required as a result of an audit.
Martin Marin, a partner with Marin & Montanye, accountants of Port Washington, L.I., who handle about 350 buildings, said most co-ops had simply been ignoring the issue. "They aren't even putting aside the money in case they're audited," he said, which may be a mistake, since the tax can be significant -- $16,000 on $50,000 worth of income.
He suggests temporarily setting aside a third of any taxable interest or rental income in a special fund to cover any possible demand. This way, in the event of an audit, reserves will not have to be raided.
Dennis Greenstein, a Manhattan lawyer who represents some 225 buildings, warned against including in the revenue column any income from flip taxes. In the last few years, he noted, many of his client buildings found this source to be increasingly unreliable.
Even using the average generated over the last three years, a favored method of late, may be overly optimistic. It's better, he said, to clear the item entirely from the budget and consider any flip-tax revenues a bonus, at least till the market picks up.
Mr. Greenstein also sounded the alarm on potential shortfalls resulting from the rise in shareholder delinquencies.
In the last few years more and more shareholders have been falling behind on monthly charges, and the resulting loss of anticipated maintenance fees, coupled with elevated collection costs, is now making a significant dent in income.
He recommends using the average size of the losses and the costs of debt collection over the last three years and make the appropriate adjustments for 1993 before they create havoc with cash flow.
Finally, the good news. Most experts are not expecting significant increases in real estate taxes in 1993, since the co-op community is increasingly being recognized as a large and sophisticated voting block.
Moreover, the added competition among certiorari lawyers -- who specialize in real estate tax disputes -- to challenge any change in a co-op's assessments has had a downward effect even on fees.
The standard legal fees for certiorari work traditionally stood at around 30 percent of any savings generated; these fees have now fallen to 20 percent. "So negotiate to the hilt even if you're using your usual lawyer," said Mr. Brecher.

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM: NIANTIC;
Children's Museum Born of Teamwork

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA

 BODY:
SO FAR, volunteers working to establish the Children's Museum of Southeastern Connecticut have dealt with, among other things, fund raising, trench digging, poison ivy, painting, the delivery of hundreds of pounds of fossils and, yes, the delivery of a baby. With the museum scheduled to open next Sunday, they are still working.
"We're getting in there, getting dirty, and making it happen," said Andrew Pappas, vice president of the museum's board of trustees. 
 The museum, in the Niantic section of East Lyme, will have about 25 exhibits, mostly of the hands-on variety. Young visitors will get to use an old printing press, make dinosaur footprints in plaster, tour a play village, climb around in a rowboat and see how electricity travels. They will handle magnets and minerals in the Discovery Room and perform, with props, in the Shadow Room. Very young children will find an area with soft sculptures to climb; nursing mothers will find a room with a rocking chair, and handicapped people will find accessible restrooms. "This is a family event where everybody gets to participate," said Jay Gionet, president of the board.
Mr. Pappas, who has a daughter, and Mr. Gionet, who has three children, were inspired last fall by a newspaper story about a children's museum in Holyoke, Mass. Started in a storefront by local residents, the museum grew, won wide acclaim and boosted the local economy. The two men figured that such a project would be ideal for their area, where the economy was faltering and families were finding too few places where they could spend time together without spending too much money. In addition, there was a building on Niantic's Main Street that was left vacant when the town library moved to bigger quarters.
The two men rounded up other supporters, and last December they asked the East Lyme Board of Selectmen to lease the old library building for three years, at a dollar a year, to house a children's museum. The board agreed, and Mr. Gionet rushed home to tell his wife.
 
Another Patron Is Born
 "She said, 'That's really good news. Now, I've got some news,' " he recalled. Mrs. Gionet was about to have a baby.
By the next day, the Gionets had a new son, and Mr. Gionet had persuaded the delivery-room nurse to serve on the museum's board of trustees.
By the next month, the nurse, Mary Anne Diamond, and her husband, John Diamond, were serving as chairmen of the museum's exhibits and education committee. "Our committee has met every Thursday night since January," Mr. Diamond said. "It's been an interesting hammer-and-anvil process."
The organizers sought advice from other museums and help from everyone they could think of. "We looked for community support," Mr. Pappas said, adding that people from more than a dozen area towns responded. A lawyer helped the group incorporate as a nonprofit organization and an accountant agreed to serve as treasurer. Northeast Utilities, where Mr. Gionet and Mr. Diamond are employed as engineers, provided a $30,000 grant to be used over three years. Assorted businesses, groups and individuals also made financial contributions. This year the museum budget was $30,000; next year it will be $100,000.
Many lent equipment (like a cement mixer) or offered services. "One plumber came to take a look and never left," Mr. Pappas said. Others donated items like shells, rocks and birds' nests. A man who builds pipe organs made a child-size one for the museum. A fossils dealer sent a truckload of fossils ("hundreds of pounds," Mr. Gionet said). A man whose wooden rowboat was washed up on the town beach during a storm let the museum have the boat. "It's going to become a play-scape," Mr. Gionet explained.
Mr. Pappas, who runs a restaurant, described how he has been approaching his customers ever since work got under way to prepare the building and the exhibits: "When people come in and eat, I say, 'Hi, do you know how to bang a nail?' "
Although the old library building was mostly vacant for several years, a school used part of it during the last school year. The museum's lease took effect July 1, after the school moved out. Then scores of volunteers plunged into such tasks as clearing brush (including poison ivy) from the side yard, cleaning mud from gutters, repairing areas where wood had rotted, digging a trench for new bathroom plumbing, installing new doors to meet current fire codes, painting murals on walls and setting up exhibits.
They built a child-size village, complete with firehouse and bank. They installed a structure that shows how a house is built -- a structure where youngsters can see how plumbing works, watch lights flash as electricity goes through glassed-in wires and use a pulley to haul cardboard bricks. They built the Shadow Room, with walls that will be coated with light-sensitive material. Youngsters can stand before a light, pose with selected props, then step away to see their shadow.
 
Children Make Dry Runs
 As opening day drew near, Mr. Gionet spent his weeklong vacation at the museum. "We're moving at an extremely fast clip now," he said. "People are driving by and looking in; we're the talk of the town," he said, as volunteers swarmed around with saws, paint brushes and a vacuum cleaner. "I know how to screw in sheetrock now," Robin Soule said. Laura Balantic reported, "We just ordered some life-like snakes and lizards." As usual, many workers brought their children. "They're the testers," Mr. Diamond said.
The organizers say that opening is only the beginning. They are already considering such future changes as having the village represent different countries and different eras. They also hope to offer educational programs and perhaps involve teen-agers as museum guides. At first, the only paid employee will be a part-time operations manager; volunteers will staff the museum. Eventually, a full-time director may be hired.
"We're establishing a base we can grow from," Mr. Diamond said.
 Starting next Sunday, the Children's Museum of Southeastern Connecticut (409 Main St., Niantic, 691-1255) will be open Thursday 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.,Friday 10 to 8, Saturday 11 to 5 and Sunday 1 to 5. Admission is $3, $1.50 for children; annual memberships available.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Volunteers, above, painting around windows in one of the exhibition areas at the Children's Museum of Southeastern Connecticut, while other, younger "volunteers," right, played make-believe water games as their parents worked.
(Photographs by Ernie Hearion for The New York Times)
