HEADLINE: Safety Net for the Hungry Is Collapsing

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
FROM one end of the state to the other, in church basements and bingo halls, in soup kitchens and shelters for the homeless, thousands of volunteers have woven a vast grass-roots safety net to feed hundreds of thousands of hungry men, women and children.
But now, the leaders of this unprecedented movement say, the rapid growth in the ranks of the hungry is outstripping their ability to meet the demand. These are some of the developments they cite: 
 *A new tide of the "working poor"-- once self-sufficient families laid low by the recession and unemployment -- has inundated the food pantries and soup kitchens. "The people coming to us now for basic needs," said Patricia Espy, director of the Center for Food Action, a nonprofit organization in Englewood, "are the same people who were providing donations two years ago."
*Thousands of elderly residents living on fixed incomes and interest on savings have been forced to line up for food as prices have risen and interest rates have tumbled. Even more troubling, said Patricia Danielak, senior citizen coordinator for the Ironbound Community Corporation, a Newark-based social service agency, are those too proud to seek help. "We're the richest country in the world," she said, "and we have senior citizens who are eating cat food or hardly eating at all."
*About 500,000 residents in the Federal food stamp program have watched the buying power of their food stamps dwindle. "What we're seeing," said Monica Ward, an assistant administrative supervisor with the Camden County Board of Social Services, "is more and more of them running out of stamps earlier and earlier in the month and being forced to go to the soup kitchens."
*As many as 14,000 recipients of municipal welfare payments will be removed from the rolls on Dec. 31. "This is going to push a lot of people over the edge," said Anne Miller Christensen, a coordinator for Let's Celebrate, a Jersey City-based coalition of religious congregations that operates a network of 17 emergency food pantries in Hudson County. "From a soup kitchen standpoint, I assume our numbers will double."
The Statewide Emergency Food and Anti-Hunger Network is a coalition of more than 800 food providers that was created by Ms. Espy's center in Englewood. "We are the safety net," she said, "and at this point the net is collapsing."
Last year, she said, the center in Englewood provided three-day emergency food packages to more than 14,000 people in Bergen and Passaic Counties. "This year, we're up 38 percent over the same time period as last year," she said. "And most of the new population that has come to us are people who have worked all their lives."
Adele La Tourette, director of the anti-hunger network, said its members were finding themselves unable to cope with the increasing demands. "They don't have the resources, they don't have the time, they don't have the person-power and they don't have the food," she said. "The fact is, the volunteer agencies simply can't handle it anymore."
 
10% of Residents Face Hunger
 There are no official statistics on the number of hungry people in the state. But Lauren Tucker, a coordinator with the Community Foodbank of New Jersey in Newark, said, "At this point, we're estimating that one in 10 New Jerseyans currently face hunger and that half of those are children and the elderly, and even that estimate might be on the low side." As of 1990, the state population was about 7.7 million.
Many private social services agencies doubt their ability to cope with these growing numbers of hungry residents.
"It's frustrating and it's frightening," said Kathleen Steele, executive director of the Food Bank of South Jersey in Camden, a nonprofit organization that distributes more than 3.2 million pounds of food a year to more than 200 soup kitchens, food pantries and charitable organizations in Camden, Gloucester, Salem and Burlington Counties.
"Some of our agencies have reported increases of up to 50 percent in people coming for help," Ms. Steele said.
Kathleen DiChiara, executive director of the Community Foodbank of New Jersey, said the demands being placed on the agencies her organization serves were "overwhelming."
"Every emergency food pantry we deal with is showing an increase in the number of people coming for help," said Ms. DiChiara, whose organization covers the state's 17 central and northern counties. "We distribute more than 50,000 pounds of food a day to more than 1,000 charities, and it's just a drop in the bucket."
Public assistance programs to combat hunger consist mainly of the Federal food stamp program; the Women, Infants and Children Supplemental Feeding Program, known as the W.I.C. program, and school breakfast and lunch programs.
The W.I.C. program, which provides vouchers for meals for pregnant and nursing women and their children under 5 years old, now reaches only half of the potentially eligible participants, said Ms. Espy, of the Center for Food Action. And while school lunch programs are common, breakfast programs are currently not available in 70 percent of the state's school districts.
The quantity of food stamps a family receives, said Ms. Ward, of the Camden County Board of Social Services, depends upon the gross income and number of people in the family. For example, a family of four with $1,512 in gross monthly income is eligible for $370 a month in food stamps.
 
'It's Not Enough'
 "The food stamp program is designed to supply the basic nutritional needs for people," Ms. Ward said. "I can tell you it's not enough."
At Lighthouse Community Services in Newark, said the Rev. Steven Parrot, the executive director, "the first two weeks of the month we average about 400 people; the following two weeks, we're up to around 700." The increase, he said, is due to the fact that welfare payments and food stamps run out long before the end of the month.
Donna Ross Cohen, director of Invest in Children, a coalition of business leaders and children's advocates, said, "It is well documented that the food stamp allotment is not enough to feed a family."
A large and growing segment of the hungry population, Ms. Steele of the Camden food bank said, is made up of elderly people on fixed incomes. "With interest rates on their savings dropping," she said, "they're strapped each month for money to pay for food."
Ms. Danielak, of the Ironbound Community Corporation, said a large number of elderly people who need help do not seek it. "Their pride tells them they have to do it on their own," she said. "Sometimes it's 'heat or eat' -- you either pay your gas and electric bill or buy food." Far too often, Ms. Danielak said, elderly residents opt for the former choice.
 
Surge in 'Working Poor'
 At the Hoboken Shelter for the Homeless recently, 25-year-old Tracy Fletcher wiped spaghetti sauce from the face of her 2-year-old daughter, Shaheeda. She, her husband, Benjamin, and their two other daughters, 4 and 6, were having dinner at the shelter.
The Fletchers are part of a new surge in the number of "working poor" who are crowding soup kitchens and shelters. Mr. Fletcher has a minimum-wage job, and the rent on the couple's Jersey City apartment, plus the utility bills, leave the family with little money for food. That led them to the shelter for meals.
"We're trying to do the right thing for our children," Mrs. Fletcher said, adding, "That was a wonderful meal."
The working poor are among the "most neglected" in the population in general said Ms. DiChiara, of the Community Foodbank of New Jersey. "The cost of housing has gone up, and the minimum wage is just not covering the bills," she said. "If they have to make the choice 'Do I pay my rent or buy food?,' they pay the rent so they have a roof over their heads."
Ms. Espy, of the Center for Food Action in Englewood, said the fastest growing segment of families needing emergency food she has seen has been two-wage-earner households in which one spouse has lost a job.
"These are people who are embarrassed to go and apply for food stamps," she said. "By the time they come to us, they're absolutely desperate."
 
A Date Viewed With Dread
 The food providers look toward Dec. 31 with dread. That is the day when an estimated total of 10,000 to 14,000 municipal welfare recipients will have their $140 monthly welfare allotment cut to zero. The cut is the result of a legislative determination that single employable adults on municipal welfare should lose their benefits after six months. The clock started ticking last July 1.
State Department of Human Services records indicate that 30,939 people are currently on municipal welfare. Nearly 20,000 of those are classified as being able to work.
"Things look bleak now, and they're going to get a whole lot worse," said Ms. Christensen, of Let's Celebrate. "It seems as if someone is saying, 'These lazy, good-for-nothing people just don't want to work,' but with unemployment around 9 percent, where are they going to find jobs?"
Most of the food distributed by the the Center for Food Action comes from donations from residents and businesses in the area, Ms. Espy said.For example, a food drive sponsored by The Record of Hackensack that ended last week resulted in the collection of about 55,000 cans of food and $15,000 in cash.
 
Other Sources of Donations

 Other emergency food providers stock their shelves from a variety of sources, including hunger marches, neighborhood food drives and food contributions through churches and synagogues.
Many soup kitchens and food pantries that receive cash donations instead of actual food, however, use that cash to buy food from the Newark or Camden food banks.
The food banks receive large quantities of food, toiletries and other necessities from manufacturers. Often, the packaging is crushed or soiled, but the product itself is undamaged.
For the food banks, as for most other emergency food providers, their volunteers are at the heart of the enterprise.
Vera Davis, for example, has been working at the Newark food bank since it opened 10 years ago. She is 78 years old and takes two buses from her home in Newark to the food bank.
"I do this," Mrs. Davis said, "because I know it's going to help someone who lives in a poor neighborhood like the one I live in."
 
 
 
HOW MANY? AN ESTIMATE
 Most experts acknowledge that it is difficult to estimate the number of people in the state who are suffering from hunger at any specific time.
Last year, the Food Research and Action Center, a research organization based in Washington, released state-by-state hunger estimates based upon studies completed in seven demographically varied states.
Christin Driscoll, a spokeswoman for the organization, said projections from that survey indicated that at the time the survey was taken, more than 23 percent of New Jersey families with children under 12 were "at risk" of being hungry. More than 10 percent of those families, Ms. Driscoll said, were actually experiencing hunger on a recurring basis.
The survey was conducted over an 18-month period, from February 1989 to August 1990. More recent figures are not available.
By way of comparison, however, the number of food-stamp recipients in the state in May of 1990 was 384,042. By May of 1992, that number had increased to 502,170.
 
 
 
Volunteer's Evolution
 The development of the anti-hunger network in the state has changed the lives of many of its thousands of volunteers. "Some organizations that began as small volunteer organizations out of the goodness of people's hearts," said Adele la Tourette, director of the Statewide Emergency Food and Anti-hunger Network in Englewood, "have evolved into full-scale social service agencies."
An example of that metamorphosis can be found in the person of Kathleen DiChiara, director of the Community Foodbank of New Jersey.
"In 1975 I was a typical suburban housewife," said Mrs. DiChiara, who lives in Summit and has two children. "I started collecting canned goods at church. Then I gave my telephone number to the welfare department and told them to call me if they knew anybody who needed food."
From the back of her station wagon, Mrs. DiChiara began delivering food to people she had been referred to by the department. Over the years, her station-wagon-based food distribution network grew into the largest nonprofit food bank in the state.
"In 1991 alone we distributed $20 million worth of food to more than 1000 member agencies," Mrs. DiChiara said. "We will exceed that number considerably in 1992."
The food bank is now situated in an industrial section of Newark. A steady stream of trucks, vans and cars arrives at the platform of the 43,000-square-foot warehouse, some delivering, some picking up cartons of food, toiletries, soap and other necessities.
Inside, pallets of goods are stacked 15 feet high or stored in one of the food bank's two 32,000- cubic-foot refrigerated rooms. Volunteers are busy sorting, cleaning and repacking items that arrive from corporate contributors in large cardboard boxes.
To cover operating costs, the food bank charges member agencies 12 cents a pound for the more than 50,000 pounds of goods that leave the warehouse each day. Next month, the food bank will move to a new warehouse in Newark that is seven times the size of its current quarters.

HEADLINE: Behind Congress Races, The Presidential Factor

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
AS if the redrawing of Congressional districts, the loss of a Congressional seat and the retirement of four incumbents aren't enough, candidates for New Jersey's 13 seats in the House of Representatives this year find themselves in the middle of a role reversal.
Usually the Republican Presidential candidate has held the lead in the closing weeks of the campaign while Democratic candidates for Congress tried to come up with strategies to divorce their campaigns from what was happening at the top of the ballot. 
 The last time a Democratic Presidential candidate carried New Jersey was in 1964, when Lyndon B. Johnson won in a landslide and helped turn an 8-to-7 Republican majority in the state's Congressional delegation to an 11-to-4 majority for the Democrats. Succeeding elections and census counts have whittled the delegation down to its new level of 13 seats, leaving the Democrats with a 7-to-6 margin over Republicans.
 
In Search of Local Issues
 Last week, with Gov. Bill Clinton holding a double-digit lead over President Bush, the only signs of divorce were in the Republican camp.
Robert C. Janiszewski, the Hudson County Executive and chairman of the Clinton-Gore campaign in New Jersey, said he found it refreshing to see some Republican candidates for Congress "trying to significantly increase their name recognition and find local issues to run on" while keeping their distance from the head of the ticket.
He predicted that a close result in the Presidential race would probably leave the state's Congressional races unaffected. "But if Clinton wins by 8 or 10 or 12 points," Mr. Janiszewski added, "it could make a difference" for Democratic candidates.
William J. Palatucci, the executive director of the Bush-Quayle campaign, said President Bush's good showing in the final televised debate last week could make a big difference in the Congressional races. "He saved the best for last, and we expect to see a little bump," Mr. Palatucci said. "If it gets Clinton's lead down to single digits, we'll take it from there."
 
Findings of Poll
 In mid-September, the Star-Ledger/Eagleton poll at Rutgers University said that Mr. Clinton had a 13-point lead over Mr. Bush and that the New Jersey electorate was leaning further toward the Democratic Party in Congressional races than it had in recent elections.
Ken Dautrich, associate director of the poll, said 44 percent of the 670 registered voters surveyed said they favored Democrats for Congress, compared with 31 percent who said they leaned toward the Republican Party. The rest were undecided. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus four percentage points.
In a similar poll in 1988, Mr. Dautrich said, registered voters favored Democrats in Congress by just a four-percentage-point margin.
Last week, incumbents appeared to be running ahead in their bids for re-election. Most of the attention was focused on districts where incumbents had retired, particularly in the Sixth and Eighth Districts.
These two contests were cited by Neil Upmeyer, director of the Center for the Analysis of Public Issues, an independent public issues organization in Princeton, as "the only two real Congressional races." He said the Presidential election "could have a coattail effect" in these contests, and any others that might tighten up in the closing days of the campaign.
The new Sixth District is made up of parts of the old Third District in Monmouth and Ocean Counties and the old Sixth District, mainly in Middlesex County. The redistricting put most of the balance of the old Third District, which had been represented by Frank Pallone Jr. of Long Branch, into a new Fourth District to the south.
That left Mr. Pallone virtually a man without a country. It also meant that, to remain in office, he would have to run in one of the two new districts, where strong incumbents were in place.
His problem was resolved when Bernard J. Dwyer, a Democrat who had represented the old Sixth for 12 years, suddenly retired. Mr. Pallone won a hard-fought primary against four candidates from Middlesex, which has 58 percent of the new district. His opponent, State Senator Joseph Kyrillos of Middletown, did the same in the Republican primary despite the fact that he, too, is from the smaller Monmouth portion of the district.
 
Frustration Over Economy
 Mr. Kyrillos recognizes that voter frustration over the sluggish economy is the overriding issue in the race and that the President is the target of much of that frustration. He hopes that enough of those venting their anger in the voting booth will also want to turn out Democratic Congressional incumbents, including Mr. Pallone.
Mr. Pallone, in turn, has continued the campaign strategy he began in the June primary, picturing himself as a "maverick" who has charted an independent course, and angered members of both parties in the process. He reminds listeners that he was the only member of the New Jersey delegation who voted against the $40,000 raise that Congress voted itself in 1989.
Mr. Kyrillos says Mr. Pallone accepted the raise and pocketed most of the money, despite Mr. Pallone's assertion that he gives $10,000 to charity and that most of the rest, aside from cost of living increases, is eaten up by taxes. Mr. Kyrillos says that if he is elected and another raise comes up for a vote, he will vote against it and return the money to the Treasury. He favors term limits on Congressional service; Mr. Pallone does not.
 
A Surprise Resignation
 One of the goals of the bipartisan commission that drafted the new Congressional map was to preserve the seat of Representative Robert A. Roe of Wayne, the Democratic dean of the state's delegation with enough seniority to be chairman of the powerful Public Works and Transportation Committee. But then Mr. Roe suprised everyone by retiring after 22 years in Washington.
Mr. Roe's Eighth District seat is being sought by State Senator Joseph L. Bubba, Republican of Wayne, and Herbert C. Klein of Clifton, a Democrat and former member of the State Assembly. Mr. Bubba was viewed as the early favorite in the race, but Mr. Janiszewski said the district was one in which a strong showing by Mr. Clinton could give Mr. Klein the victory.
The campaign has been marked by strong personal attacks from both candidates. Mr. Bubba charges that Mr. Klein bragged in a letter that his law firm had helped change state environmental rules to allow developers to build in protected wetlands and that the firm solicited business based on that claim.
Mr. Klein counters that Mr. Bubba accepted $10,000 from the National Rifle Association and later opposed a seven-day waiting period for handgun purchases and that Mr. Bubba supports "the open sale of military-style assault weapons."
Mr. Bubba is highlighting his votes to make welfare fraud a crime, impose stiffer penalties for hate crimes and establish a crime victim's "Bill of Rights" and his sponsorship of a proposed constitutional amendment to prevent the New Jersey Supreme Court from overturning death sentences imposed by juries.
 
Budget Deficit an Issue
 Mr. Klein, who has not held public office since he served in the Assembly from 1972 to 1976, says he is "not a career politician who has lost touch with the concerns of ordinary people." With the end of the cold war, Mr. Klein says, the $140 billion the Government spends annually "defending Germany and Japan" should be used to reduce the Federal budget deficit.
Another vacancy occurred in the redrawn Seventh District in Union County when Matthew J. Rinaldo, a Republican, retired after 10 terms in Congress. Although the district is competitive, State Assemblyman Robert D. Franks of New Providence, the New Jersey Republican chairman, is considered the front-runner, in part because he has represented some of the same territory in the Legislature.
His opponent, who is making his first run for public office, is Leonard R. Sendelsky of Colonia, a wealthy builder and Democratic fund-raiser..
The redrawn 13th District, part of which was represented for 14 years by another retiree, Frank J. Guarini, Democrat of Jersey City, is expected to be filled by Robert Menendez of Union City, a Cuban-American who is the city's Mayor and a State Senator. His Republican opponent is Fred Theemling of Weehawken, who was defeated twice in prior elections by Mr. Guarini.

HEADLINE: The Lowey-DioGuardi Rematch

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

 BODY:
LIKE a quarreling couple reworking old disputes at a dinner party, Joseph J. DioGuardi and Nita M. Lowey are moving from political debate to political debate these days, puzzling and annoying their audiences while trying to inform and sway them.
Both candidates are seeking re-election. Mr. DioGuardi, a Republican-Conservative, won Westchester's 20th Congressional District seat in 1984 in his first run for public office. He held on to the seat in 1986, but then lost it two years later to Mrs. Lowey, a Democrat, in her first election bid. She was the only woman in the United States that year to beat an incumbent Congressman. 
 Now they are at it again, struggling against a familiar backdrop. Mr. DioGuardi, the challenger, has been taking the fight to his opponent, often devoting his entire opening statement to attacking Mrs. Lowey. She then spends most of the time allotted to her initial remarks to answering him.
The negative campaigning technique pursued by Mr. DioGuardi is evident even in the voters guide published by the League of Women Voters. Asked to respond to three questions, Mr. DioGuardi devotes his entire 90-word statement to characterizing and criticizing Mrs. Lowey's record.
Their positions on issues emerge, but often indistinctly or in enigmatic shorthand. Mr. DioGuardi makes no excuses for the attack mode he has employed. "She started it in 1988 when she stole the election by smearing me in the final days," he said. "It won't happen again. This time I'm not going to wait to respond. I have to be responding before she attacks."
He was referring to an incident that surfaced just before the 1988 election when Joseph Crabtree, a member of Mr. DioGuardi's campaign finance committee, funneled more than $50,000 in illegal contributions through his automobile dealership by reimbursing employee contributions. Mr. Crabtree paid a $10,000 fine and testified that Mr. DioGuardi masterminded the plan; the candidate has denied it.
 
No More Bullhorns
 Mrs. Lowey capitalized on the disclosure with radio and television advertisements, paying for them with $250,000 of her own money, which she lent her campaign but failed to report within 48 hours as required by law. She later paid a $3,500 civil penalty for failure to disclose it properly.
References to these incidents serve as a contrapuntal melody in the current campaign, frustrating audiences seeking more up-to-date information. At one recent debate, Mr. DioGuardi was booed by an exasperated audience when he answered a question on the Clean Air Act by observing first that Mrs. Lowey "is owned by the unions and the trial attorneys."
The campaign is punctuated by charges of "liar" and "hypocrite." An early practice -- DioGuardi supporters using bullhorns to interrupt Lowey speeches -- has been halted, presumably as excessive even for this campaign.
A candidates' lunch forum sponsored by the Woman's Club of White Plains on Oct. 14 also was typical. Mr. DioGuardi began in disarming fashion by saying that "this is one of the most exciting races in America because Congresswoman Lowey and I disagree on every issue of substance."
He then spent all but a few moments of his opening remarks characterizing Mrs. Lowey's positions in his own terms, leaving only a few sentences at the end for his own political agenda. A woman in the audience leaned over and complained to another woman: "He really shouldn't be doing this."
The second woman said, "He's the challenger. He has to do it."
"But not like that," the first woman replied.
Mr. DioGuardi said his opponent's "approach to life is bigger government; that's why she voted nine times to raise your taxes."
"She supports the Clinton plan to raise taxes on everybody earning more than $36,000," he continued. "She thinks that's the way to create jobs, using your tax dollars for make-work jobs, not real jobs.
"She was given a 100 percent rating by the Americans for Democratic Action; that's 5 percent higher than the 95 percent they gave Barney Sanders of New Hampshire, the only elected Socialist in the House. She's a perfect liberal. You're going to hear lies that she is a fiscal conservative. But that's part of the disinformation she creates, using money from her husband's law firm.
"How do you get 100 percent from the A.D.A.? By voting for fish farms in Arkansas and voting against sending troops to the Gulf. By saying you express your First Amendment rights by burning the flag, by putting $45,000 into the National Endowment for the Arts for exhibits that are so obscene I wouldn't discuss them here. She votes against the police, votes to release guilty people because they're picked up on some technicality where it's clear they're guilty."
He then offered his own agenda:
"The bottom line is I'm a certified public accountant. I have a three-point plan. It starts with reducing the capital gains tax to 10 percent to loosen up capital. I'm for a line-item veto, a balanced budget amendment, and I'm not going to even think about raising your taxes until we get spending in Washington under control."
Mrs. Lowey, responding to the "flawed, failed former Congressman," a phrase she uses as often as he tags her as a "tax-and-spend liberal," challenged her audience to "ask him how he spent his last four years," asserting that he is simply "looking for a job in Washington because he never went back to his accounting firm."
 
Mrs. Lowey's Agenda
 As for her own legislative agenda, she summarized it this way:
"We should be investing in our crumbling roads and highways. In Westchester, 50 percent of construction workers have no jobs. I support investment tax credits for small businesses, because that's where jobs are created, as well as investments in research and technology so we can get the private sector moving again."
Mrs. Lowey speaks of being instrumental in obtaining an export contract for a Yonkers company to build subway cars for Taiwan and in building a new Federal courthouse in White Plains. Mr. DioGuardi claims a role in both achievements. Both claim credit for initiating the idea of a Long Island Sound office to orchestrate the cleanup of the Sound.
She said her 100 percent A.D.A. rating came from the fact that she favors reducing the scope of the Strategic Defense Initiative, cutting further the number of troops overseas, opposing the financing of a space station, banning assault weapons, increasing financing for Head Start and other children's support measures and supporting the Brady bill on gun control.
Mrs. Lowey said her opponent "voted against almost every budget plan proposed during his tenure in Congress." As for the National Endowment for the Arts, "the grants that prompted the furor were approved by Reagan-Bush appointees." On the subject of crime, Mrs. Lowey opposes the death penalty; Mr. DioGuardi favors it. She says she backed a major crime bill that died in the Senate "because the President and his friends did not want to offend the National Rifle Association." She would create boot camps for first-time offenders, she says.
Mr. DioGuardi claims that Mrs. Lowey is among Congress's leading recipients of contributions from lawyers, "getting $100,000 from law firms in New York City." The money, he says, "comes from law firms who are under pressure to contribute."
Scott Fleming, an aide to Mrs. Lowey, said, "We never added it up, but there's no pressure and the vast majority of her contributions come from her constituents."
Mrs. Lowey opposes both a line-item veto and a balanced budget amendment, while Mr. DioGuardi favors both. She would reduce capital gains by indexing them for inflation; he says "indexing is a good idea, but it's not enough. In addition, the capital gains tax rate should be dropped to 10 percent."
 
Different Views on Health Care
 He favors a health-care plan "that has a national orientation but is managed by the private sector." She says health-care reform should include the right to choose health-care providers combined with effective cost-control mechanisms as well as addressing the need for affordable long-term care for the elderly and the disabled.
Mrs. Lowey favors a woman's right to have an abortion; Mr. DioGuardi, who has Right to Life Party endorsement, is against it.
She says, "He keeps talking about his 22 years as a C.P.A., but the best example of how he used his C.P.A. skills was in putting together a scheme for himself and cronies in the Congress to shelter income from speaking fees." He says the charge is "baseless," that the so-called cronies included Democrats "who asked me to help set up retirement plans."
 
An Oddly Shaped District
 The candidates are running in a district that extends south through the east Bronx into central Queens. Mr. DioGuardi claims that redistricting, which created the oddly shaped district, "is good for my campaign" because it eliminated parts of the old district where Mrs. Lowey outpolled him 56 percent to 44 percent.
The 1988 Lowey-DioGuardi contest was among the nation's most expensive, with each candidate spending more than $1 million. This year's race could be equally expensive. Mr. DioGuardi began using television ads nearly two weeks ago.
Westchester communities are included in three other Congressional Districts. The 19th, which covers all of northern Westchester as far south as Mount Pleasant, North Castle and White Plains as well as Putnam County and parts of Dutchess and Orange Counties, is represented by a 12-term Republican-Conservative, Hamilton Fish Jr. of Fishkill.
His challenger, Neil McCarthy of Waccabuc, a lawyer, says Mr. Fish, is "a rubber stamp" for the White House and seeks to use Mr. Fish's long service against him. "For two-thirds of my adult life Mr. Fish has been the Congressman from my district; I think it's time for a change," Mr. McCarthy said.
 
Comfortable Margins in the Past
 Mr. Fish, who has won previous elections by comfortable margins, said he was seeking "a $5,000 tax credit and penalty-free IRA withdrawals for first-time-home purchases, a permanent extension of the low-income housing tax credit and a cut in the capital gains tax rate." There is no Right to Life candidate in the 19th Congressional District.
Another longtime incumbent, Benjamin A. Gilman of Middletown, a Republican who has served in Congress for 20 years, represents the town of Greenburgh as well as Rockland and parts of Orange and Sullivan Counties in the 20th Congressional District. His principal challenger is Jonathan L. Levine of Clarkstown, a lawyer and former assistant public defender in Rockland County.
Mr. Levine has said he would free the nation from its "addiction" to foreign oil by relying on domestic sources. He said "the cost of oil from abroad is low until you add the cost of protecting it." The Right to Life candidate is Robert F. Garrison.
Another strong incumbent, although in this case a Democrat, is Eliot L. Engel, the two-term Bronx Congressman whose redrawn 17th District includes southwest Yonkers, most of Mount Vernon and parts of New Rochelle and Pelham.
Mr. Engel's main opponent, Martin Richman, is a Republican and former special assistant to the United States Attorney General prosecuting Government corruption. Kevin Brawley is the Conservative candidate and Martin J. O'Grady is the Right to Life candidate in the 17th District.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Jane Moos, David Cohen

 BODY:
Jane Moos, an architect at Skidmore, Owings & Merrill in New York, was married in Chicago last evening to David Cohen, a business consultant with the Hampton Consulting Group, a financial-consulting concern in New York. Rabbi Herbert Bronstein officiated at the Standard Club.
Mrs. Cohen, 40 years old, graduated from Tulane University and received a master's degree in architecture from Pratt Institute. She is a daughter of Clifford Moos of Highland Park, Ill., and the late Naomi Moos. The bride's father is the president of the Economy Folding Box Corporation, a packaging concern in Chicago. 
 Mr. Cohen, 45, graduated from Yale University and received an M.B.A. from Boston University. He is a son of Harry Cohen of Woodbury, Conn., and the late Frances Cohen. His father is a partner in Cohen & Kessler, a law firm in New Milford, Conn.

HEADLINE: Signs of Life at Sears, Roebuck

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Floors laid with carpet or tile instead of linoleum? Women's dresses displayed in their own section instead of across the aisle from laundry detergents and kitchen gadgets? Brand-name appliances and attractively priced knockoffs of trendy dresses and blouses sold at Saks and Neiman Marcus?
Just what is going on at Sears, Roebuck & Company? 
 The retailer that many shoppers, competing merchants and Wall Street analysts have written off as a hopeless has-been, the maligned merchant that raised unresponsiveness to an art, is exhibiting some astonishing signs that it can indeed change. It has begun to recast itself in a more modern, more sophisticated way. It has moved to stop selling everything and instead focused on seven kinds of merchandise. It has pared expenses by dismantling the way it did things for decades.
As part of the makeover, Sears is for the first time reaching outside to recruit talent, turning the merchandising group over to department- and specialty-store veterans like Arthur C. Martinez, who became head of retail operations less than two months ago, and Dorrit Bern, national merchandise manager for women's apparel. And the talents of Sears veterans like Janice E. Page, also a merchandise manager, are starting to shine.
Sears, which a year ago slipped from being the nation's largest retailer to third-largest behind Wal-Mart and Kmart, is already enjoying some gains in market share -- no small relief to the 362,400 merchandising-group employees and almost 350,000 shareholders who count on the company. It has regained almost 5 market-share points in the appliances business, claiming more than 30 percent of the market. At a time when most retailers have reported declining or flat sales of apparel, sales of women's clothing, Sears's most profitable business, have increased as much as 5 percent in stores open at least one year. And Sears has gained in the home furnishings business, although by how much is uncertain.
 
Wall Street Thinks Again
 "For the last 10 years, I've had a standing sell recommendation on Sears," said Peter J. Siris, a retail analyst at UBS Securities. "I said this was the worst company in the world and these guys should be put out of their misery one way or the other. But I have come to believe over the last year or so -- and I never thought I would -- that, while they once were without a doubt complete idiots, they may in fact have finally gotten smart."
He thinks Sears's sales gains in areas like women's apparel are translating into market share improvements and points to the elimination of almost $1 billion, or roughly 11 percent, of expenses. He also cites better merchandise distribution to insure that stores are in stock with best-selling goods, and a program that has tamed an infamous bureaucracy by eliminating a layer of management.
Margaret A. Gilliam, a retail analyst at the First Boston Corporation who is closely read by the industry, wrote of Sears this month: "We do believe that with all the cost cutting that Sears has been undertaking, and the improvement efforts that have been going on in the merchandising areas, that better earnings are in store with any type of economic recovery." She said the company's dominant locations in good shopping malls, many loyal credit-card holders and the clout of $32 billion in sales give it a solid foundation.
That is not to say that Sears will make it. Ms. Gilliam and Mr. Siris are among a small band of guarded optimists. Others who predicted a Sears recovery in the past have been disappointed. Stingy consumers, a weak economy and extreme competition that has eaten away at profit margins are still large obstacles. More than half of Sears's 860 stores still must be spiffed up, and millions of Americans remain unconvinced that Sears is a place to shop. It hasn't helped that a scandal last summer in Sears's automotive business, in which salespeople were accused of recommending unneeded repairs, has cut revenue in that department by 10 to 15 percent.
"I think our biggest challenge has been and will be how well we execute," Mr. Martinez said.
Indeed, many believe an inability to execute is Sears's fatal flaw. "You're talking about something that has to be rebuilt from the bottom up, and it's 20 years too late to do that," said Philip Johnson, president of Leo J. Shapiro & Associates, a consumer marketing and retail firm in Chicago.
Sears, whose sales have not even outpaced inflation for a decade, has a rich history of initiatives that never lived up to their promises, mostly because of half-hearted implementation, analysts say. Count among them "everyday low pricing" and the "Store of the Future."
 
The Action Plan
 Contrary to its image, Sears is now reacting decisively not only to shoppers but also to shareholders and Wall Street.
On Sept. 29, the corporation announced plans to uncobble its group of disparate businesses, spinning off its financial-services arm, Dean Witter Reynolds, and its real estate interest, Coldwell Banker, and offering to the public a 20 percent piece of its Allstate insurance subsidiary.
Sears decided to unleash these businesses because the merchandising group's lousy performance caused the market to devalue them. Between 1987 and 1991, merchandise-group sales grew only 12 percent and profits dropped 22 percent. Last Thursday, Sears issued a dismal third-quarter report on its merchandising business, which lost $36.4 million.
Sears's stock closed Friday at $41.75, a little under book value. Edward A. Brennan, chairman and chief executive, has never achieved his goal of reaching a 15 percent return on equity, and the retail division hasn't even come close.
Mr. Martinez says his merchandising group will achieve that goal within five years, and then he wants to push it further. "How high is up for us? I don't know yet," he said, "but 15 percent is kind of the minimum relatively short-term standard I'm working toward."
Sears has moved to cut its costs, which are still far higher than many of its competitors', and Mr. Martinez says he will cut more. Last year, Sears spent 29.2 percent of its revenues on operating expenses like salaries, advertising and utility bills, while Kmart spent 21.2 percent and the Gap spent 22.85 percent. On the other hand, J. C. Penney, which Sears regards as a tough competitor, spent 30.4 percent.
About 48,050 positions have been eliminated, although the number of people employed in the merchandising group has dropped less significantly, to 362,400 at the end of last year from 370,400 a year earlier.
"We have never seen a retailer cut costs as aggressively or as consistently as has Sears," Mr. Siris wrote in a report last summer.
 
The New Look
 It is in the roughly 35 percent of Sears's 860 stores that have been renovated where the company's new direction becomes most apparent.
Take the Woodfield Mall Sears store in Schaumburg, Ill., with its spacious tiled aisles and carpeted sales floors, wood moldings along the walls, bright lights and eye-catching displays. The store is clearly arranged into the seven core businesses on which Sears has chosen to focus -- men's, women's and children's clothing, home furnishings, home improvement, automotive services and supplies, and appliances and consumer electronics. It has a genteel department-store ambiance, as do Sears stores in Hicksville, L.I., and King of Prussia, Pa., among other places.
Contrast these with the cluttered, down-at-the-heels feel of the Sears store on Lawrence Avenue in Chicago, among others. Too much merchandise is crammed into too little space. Sears's effort to sell everything from greeting cards, eyeglasses and popcorn to drills and furniture creates a kind of three-ring circus. A brass light fixture and an extension cord encased in orange plastic can be bought without taking a step. Office clothes, including a lovely red-and-black houndstooth sweater suit, are displayed right across the aisle from appliances and detergent. Economical uses of space, perhaps, but presentations unlikely to entice someone shopping for a chandelier or Wall Street suit.
Upgrading stores like Lawrence Avenue means money. Last year, Sears invested about $650 million in capital expenditures; then again, Wal-Mart and Kmart each spent more than $1 billion to spruce up their stores.
"We have slipped behind the pack in that regard so we have some catchup to do," Mr. Martinez said.
Less visible but no less important than the improvements on the sales floor is what has happened out of sight of the customer.
In narrowing its focus to seven businesses, Sears has made each business responsible for itself -- accountable for its own profits and losses and for keeping track of the competition.
In the past, Sears divided its merchandising into two parts, "hard lines" like washing machines and "soft lines" like clothing. Regional managers (now eliminated) decided where merchandise would go and store managers decided how much effort to devote to selling different goods. Now the buyers ordering hot pants also oversee their distribution to the stores and insure that there is always someone there to sell them.
"We have been taking apart processes, looking at everything that goes into what we do and asking if we really need it," said Jane J. Thompson, vice president for planning.
Take the typical Sears sales manager. Today she is spending 80 percent of her time on the floor with customers, up from 40 percent. She is no longer responsible for restocking shelves or making price changes.
Technology has helped too. Point-of-sale computer terminals in all Sears stores allow sales clerks to issue credits for returned merchandise, begin layaway plans and arrange for deliveries -- and to track customer preferences.
 
Plans for Tomorrow
 Mr. Martinez has much more in mind. In an interview at the merchandising group's new headquarters in the northwest Chicago suburb of Hoffman Estates, Ill., the veteran of Saks Fifth Avenue and Marshall Field mentioned several possibilities for streamlining Sears, including closing some weaker stores, freeing up more selling space in stores and perhaps even closing the catalogue operation, which lost about $200 million last year.
He also vowed to make his managers stop speaking in the numbers that designate various departments and districts within the company. Riding in the elevators at Sears, it is not unusual to overhear one employee ask another something like, "Did you know that Division 22 and Division 26 of 700-1 are doing real well in District 260?" (Translation: "Did you know that cooking and laundry appliances are doing real well in Chicago?")
The numerical jargon is a telling indication of the unnecessarily complicated quality of Sears's business in the past. "I have a little policy now," Mr. Martinez said. "Anytime anyone uses a number instead of a noun, they have to put $1 in the kitty."
For all the changes, visible and invisible, Sears's bottom line in merchandising hasn't improved. Last year, bicycles, winter coats, dishwashers, garden hoses and the myriad other items Sears sells earned just 7 percent of the retail group's profits. Sears's own credit card earned the rest (its Discover card's earnings fall under Dean Witter). And Sears executives don't expect much improvement this year.
The reason: cutthroat competition has forced Sears and its competitors to drop prices. Even though it has gained market share, the company has been unable to raise revenues, and profit margins throughout the retail industry keep shrinking, particularly in areas like home appliances and consumer electronics.
If its plan is to work, Sears must raise sales, especially of clothing, with its higher margins. Among the prime targets: women with household incomes of $35,000 to $55,000 a year, who prize value but have learned from stores like The Limited that it doesn't have to come at the expense of fashion. Sears has also retained the loyalty of older people and inner-city Hispanic customers.
Sears is trying to attract new shoppers with promotions on basic items, like two-for-one sales on T-shirts and jeans. Once in a Sears store like that in Schaumburg, they may then be attracted to a beaded blue evening dress that looks like one in a Saks catalogue but at $140 is half the price.
 
And Here's Fashion
 That dress is evidence that fashion has finally arrived at Sears, and not a moment too soon. Margins on the goods for which the retailer is famous -- tools, appliances and car batteries -- are shrinking as competitors like Home Depot, Circuit City and Trak Auto reach for business. Apparel, accessories and cosmetics offer retailers a higher gross margin -- 30 to 40 percent, compared with 20 to 30 percent for goods like lawn mowers.
Already, sales of women's apparel account for 22 percent of Sears's business and are the most profitable of its seven businesses.
Sears has an enviable position as one of the only large retailers that did not abandon Middle America in search of shoppers with more disposable income. "Moderate America has been walking around the malls saying, 'Excuse me, but where am I going to shop?' " said Ms. Bern, a former Federated Department Stores buyer who has forced a sense of fashion into the women's clothing business at Sears. "My competitors brag about having $100 dresses. I hate to tell them, but Moderate America doesn't have $100 to spend."
She and her colleagues, many of them department-store refugees, steal concepts about colors, fabrics and styles from suppliers who wouldn't dream of selling their goods in a Sears store. For example, there is the $26 version of a $300 sweater bought at a boutique in London on one of Ms. Bern's European scouting trips. The difference? The Sears sweater may feel like angora but is made in an acrylic that washes like polyester. Or take the $95 studded, fur-trimmed ski jacket that looks suspiciously like a Bogner parka retailing for $895. And Mainframe, Sears's juniors department, is selling several funky fake furs for $120.
In some cases, Sears's women's clothing comes off the same production line as branded merchandise the company can't stock. You can buy an $80 brushed-flannel nightie at Saks, or spend $16.99 at Sears for the same thing in a slightly different print.
"Granted, Vanity Fair, Bali and Maidenform aren't beating down our door to sell to us," said Ms. Page, merchandise manager for intimate apparel. "But we have the same products with the same quality for a much better price without their names."
Now, if only Sears could persuade more people of that.
 
 
 
A MATTER OF CUSTOMER PERCEPTIONS
 Sears is throwing a big party in its Hicksville, L.I., store next month for the top brass at prestigious potential suppliers like Liz Claiborne, Leslie Fay and Gitano. Its goal: to show a Sears reincarnate and coax suppliers into selling at Sears.
Such self-promotion is rare for Sears. In an industry where tooting one's horn is a big part of business, Sears is reticent.
Its advertising focuses on promotional items instead of creating an image. By contrast, J. C. Penney's new commercials use bright shots of fashionable apparel and accessories and the tagline "We've changed" to announce the chain is not the frumpy general merchant it was 10 years ago. The Gap used celebrities to give its T-shirts and jean jackets panache.
Sears has only recently begun to harvest the shopping records of the 27 million people who use Sears credit cards, targeting customers with slick direct-mail brochures and invitations for special shopping nights.
And while Sears needs to get its message out, it has hesitated to make noise until sure its store renovations and improved merchandise are in place, said Matthew A. Howard, senior vice president for marketing.
There's still a big gap to be bridged in convincing customers that Sears merits their attention. In a 1990 survey to measure recognition of 2,000 brand names by the image consulting firm Landor Associates, Sears placed fifth, ahead of such All-American staples as Betty Crocker, Kleenex, Hallmark and Kraft. But when the study turned to the esteem with which consumers regard certain brands, Sears's ranking plummeted to 79.
"A big gap between those two numbers, recognition and esteem, means there's something out of balance in the marketing strategy," said Edwin D. Rice, executive marketing director at Landor. "They need to manage their message. They have the same price-value message as The Gap, but who knows about it?"

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Thirties Redux: The Return of Trade Wars

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
As the world has stumbled into what President Bush calls a global recession, the economic optimists have been comforted by one fact. The leading industrial nations, they said, had learned from the 1930's, when the Smoot-Hawley tariff sparked trade wars and "beggar thy neighbor" policies deepened and prolonged the Depression.
Perhaps the optimists spoke too soon. 
 Mr. Bush's "new world order," so happily proclaimed after the collapse of Communism, is beginning to look like a case of every country for itself. In Western Europe, the Maastricht dreams of unity lie in tatters, and last week the Bush Administration said the talks on a new world trade agreement had ended in failure.
The current round of world trade talks has been going on for seven years, in large part because no one wants to be blamed for their failure, and efforts are now under way to prevent them from appearing dead. But the French Government, fearful of its angry farmers as legislative elections approach in the spring, is unwilling to accept any deal the American Government could sell to its farmers. The big question now is whether a tit-for-tat round of trade retaliation will soon begin.
So far, the prospect of such battles does not seem to have troubled investors. Stock prices were generally strong last week, especially in Europe, where hopes are again rising that Germany will lower interest rates. "It's kind of like the Cuban missile crisis," said Hugh Johnson, the strategist at First Albany. "I get the feeling we will get to the brink, but then everyone will back down, recognizing the danger."
Maybe so, but some battles are already under way. The British Government may not have wanted to be forced out of Europe's system of managed exchange rates, but it now seems to be following a cheap pound policy to stimulate exports. Mexico, under pressure from its own exporters, agreed last week to more rapid devaluation of the peso. There is grumbling in Europe about the artificially depressed yen, but the Japanese Government is hesitant to curb the country's rising trade surplus when its economy is so weak that the country's money supply is falling.
"Everyone is looking for exports, but nobody can see where growth is coming from," says Steven Nagourney, Lehman Brothers' international strategist.
Sixty years ago, the battles were over tariffs. Now the issue is subsidized exports. Soon it could be taxes. Bill Clinton wants to close "loopholes" for foreign companies. If he does, don't be surprised if there is retaliation against American multinationals abroad.
There is no question that economic war would be bad news for all participants and for the world economy. But domestic pressures to stand up for the local industry in the face of "unfair" foreign competition can be especially strong when economies and governments are both weak. That is the case in country after country.
Cooperation for growth is certainly needed. But it may not be forthcoming.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/October 18-23

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
It May Be a Matter of the Right C.E.O., Wrong Decade 

Just as G.M. was releasing plans to further restructure -- it will consolidate its six North American design and engineering staffs into four groups -- rumors were circulating among Motown's cognoscenti that Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, would be swept out of office before the board of directors meets Nov. 2. G.M.-watchers were abuzz with talk that his replacement would be John G. Smale, a retired chairman of Procter & Gamble Inc. and a G.M. director who would serve on an interim basis. The job would then go to Jack Smith, the hard-charging executive who turned G.M.'s European operations around. The changes are "about redefining what G.M. will be," said James Womack, a manufacturing consultant in Cambridge, Mass. "Stempel is the perfect person for the G.M. of the 1950's. But he had the misfortune of wandering into the G.M. of the 90's."

Dial-a-Video Is on the Way
 
Tired of hoofing it to the nearest video store to pick up a copy of your favorite spaghetti Western? Last week, the Bell Atlantic Corporation, the regional phone company serving the mid-Atlantic states, said it would begin offering TV service to its customers in 1994, through the phone lines. Most experts assumed that telephone companies needed to replace their old lines with fiber-optic cable to transmit TV signals -- at a national cost of $100 billion to $400 billion. But Bell Atlantic will use existing copper wires with new technology developed by Bellcore, a research consortium of the seven regional Bell companies. The service takes advantage of the Federal Communications Commission's decision to let phone companies offer "video dial tones." Most analysts are cautious -- for now. "This is a long process," said Daniel P. Reingold at Morgan Stanley & Company. "It's not going to happen overnight."

A Pilot Squeeze Play at Delta?
 
Even the strongest airlines have felt the pinch from this year's fare wars. Delta Airlines lost $502 million in fiscal 1992, which ended June 30, and $106.7 million in the first quarter of fiscal 1993, which ended Sept. 30. Last week, Delta said it would lay off up to 200 pilots beginning in December and reduce its purchases of new planes. It is the first time Delta has laid off pilots since the mid-1950's. Though Delta said it hopes to recall the pilots, the Airline Pilots Association thinks the layoffs may be a ploy to wring wage concessions from the company's remaining 9,400 pilots when a new contract is negotiated. "It sure sounds like that to us," said Rhea Nichols, a spokesman for the Delta branch of the union.

McDonnell Douglas's Sour Year
 
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation has had its troubles this year. When it tried to take in a Taiwanese investor group that included the government, not only did McDonnell's unions disapprove, but so did several members of Congress. Then the Taiwanese said they didn't want to invest in the company after all -- just buy planes. In July, cash-starved McDonnell said it would lay off 4,000 to 5,000 workers and put off development of a passenger plane. Last week, analysts said orders for the company's MD-11 wide-body jets have slowed so much McDonnell might have to cut production by 40 percent in 1994. Those cutbacks could result in the elimination of an additional 3,000 jobs at McDonnell Douglas and its suppliers. The "market for these aircraft is soft," said a spokesman for the company.

No More Math Phobia for Barbie
 
For decades Barbie dressed her way into the top of the toy world. Then Mattel Inc. taught her to talk. Among other things, Mattel had Barbie lament that "math class is tough." That phrase -- one of 270 the doll can utter -- caught the ire of the American Association of University Women. Barbie's complaint, the association said, could undermine confidence among girls in their mathematical abilities. "The last thing we would intentionally do would be to have Barbie convey anything but the most aspirational of messages," said Jill E. Barad, Mattel's president. Mattel said last week it would remove the phrase from Barbie's microchip.

The Making of a Talent Empire
 
As agents go, those at the William Morris Agency are the blue-suited Brooks Brothers variety -- conservative, businesslike, a bit stodgy. But they have a huge client list that includes Bill Cosby, the nation's highest-paid entertainer, Candice Bergen and Clint Eastwood. Mid-sized Triad Artists, on the other hand, is more Armani, high class but loose. Not only is Triad solid in Tinseltown -- its clients include Bruce Willis -- but it's big in Nashville, too, where it represents Merle Haggard, Tanya Tucker and others. Last week, after four months of secret negotiations, William Morris bought Triad for an undisclosed sum. The deal "makes us a major player in the motion-picture world and for our music business, it's just incredible," said Jerry Katzman, president of William Morris.

 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Back to Home-Building
 
For the second month in a row, housing starts rose, the Commerce Department said last week. Housing starts in September increased by 1.4 percent after jumping by 12.6 percent in August. But along with the rise in housing starts, there was more good news: The department reported a 3.7 percent increase in building permits issued, an indicator of future construction. Together the figures represent "the first signal we've gotten in a long time that the beleaguered economy might poke its nose out of its recessionary hole," said Jack M. Albertine, who heads a forecasting firm in Washington.

Improving Jobless Numbers
 
In another upbeat note, the Labor Department reported that new jobless claims for the week ended Oct. 10 fell by 15,000, to 368,000, their lowest level in more than two years. It was the third decrease in new jobless claims in a row.
 
The Mileage Debate
 
In last week's Presidential debate, President Bush said he opposed raising gasoline mileage standards above the current fleet average of 27.5 miles a gallon. Mr. Bush said raising the standards would result in lost jobs -- and Detroit's trade association agrees. But environmental advocates dispute those findings. The American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy, a Washington-based environmental study and lobbying group, recently predicted higher-mileage cars would actually create jobs by allowing consumers to spend less on gas and more on other things. Retooling Detroit would also result in more "engineers, more assemblers, more parts suppliers, and more revenue and economic activity for auto producers," said Howard Geller, the group's executive director.

 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Britain's Miners Win One
 
Britain's coal industry has been dying a slow death. Demand is down as industry converts to natural gas and the utilities go nuclear. And Britain's deep pit mines can't compete with the strip mines of America. But the Government -- which owns the mines -- still employs 40,000 politically powerful miners and spends $163 million a month subsidizing the industry. That burden prompted Prime Minister John Major to say his Government would dismiss 30,000 miners and close almost all of the mines. But last week -- under severe pressure even within his own Conservative Party -- Mr. Major backed down. Not only were reprieves granted to 23,000 miners, but 21 mines will now remain. That's still too much coal for Britain. The Government said last week it would seek export markets for the surplus.

Mired in the Trade Bog
 
Europe says it wants to negotiate a new trade agreement with the United States and other countries under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. But even after months of on-again-off-again talks, the European Community has refused to give up subsidizing its agriculture, something the United States has been pressing for. Last week, France huffed that further discussions with the United States were pointless until after the Presidential election. "I don't feel that today the Americans have the capacity to make useful proposals in this area," said Michel Sapin, France's Finance Minister. But France itself faces elections in six months, and with the farmer's vote crucial, Paris is unlikely to make concessions on subsidies. With the talks off, Washington is making plans to retaliate against Europe for subsidizing its exports and barring American agriculture imports.
 
The Bundesbank Obliges
 
Germany's Bundesbank, headed by Helmut Schlesinger, is Europe's sternest taskmaster. It's anti-inflation, high-interest policies have kept prices more or less stable as Germany integrates its eastern states into the West. But it has also created havoc in the European monetary system -- Britain "temporarily" left the system -- and angered the White House, which wants Europe to grow faster. Last week, the Bundesbank let its monocle drop. After injecting money into the economy for a month, it said it would lend money to banks at variable rates. Those actions put downward pressure on interest rates. In a month, German money market rates have fallen to 8.90 percent, from 9.75 percent. They could go lower. "The Bundesbank's intention is to lower money market interest rates in the coming weeks to around 8.50 percent," said Peter Pietsch, an economist with Commerzbank A. G. in Frankfurt.

Pizza and Pepsi for the Steppes
 
Last week Pepsico Inc. signed a complicated barter agreement with Ukraine that will take pizza and Pepsi to the steppes. The agreement calls for Pepsi to use the proceeds from selling $1 billion worth of Ukrainian-built double-hull tankers to build 100 Pizza Huts and five new Pepsi bottling plants. The deal triples Pepsico's investment in Ukraine, and replaces other deals that dissolved along with the Evil Empire.

HEADLINE: At Work;
The Missing Issue in Campaign '92

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
It may be the year of the woman, but women's issues have been curiously inconspicuous during the Presidential campaign. True, when pressed in the final debate last week, George Bush cited his appointments; Bill Clinton cited his appointments and his award from the National Women's Political Caucus; Ross Perot cited one appointment and his wife and four "beautiful daughters."
But the income issues women's groups used to filter into campaigns, in the last few years via the hapless Democrats, have been obscured this year. The Presidential tickets have been too busy lobbing family-value bombs back and forth, and women themselves have been busy running for office in record numbers. "Women are focused on getting women elected," said Heidi Hartmann, director of the Institute for Women's Policy Research, a Washington economic research group. "There's less energy for the national campaign." 
 The lack of debate on women's issues inspired Ms. Hartmann and several colleagues, all economists and all removed enough from the immediate fray to have a little scholarly perspective, to form the Economists' Policy Group on Women's Issues. Earlier this month the group issued a "women's policy agenda" and rated the two major-party candidates on issues the group regards as crucial to women. The agenda has been endorsed by a two-and-a-half page list of economists, including Nobel prize winners James Tobin, Franco Modigliani and Robert Solow.
The group is concerned almost entirely with classic liberal bread-and-butter issues. The agenda calls for:
* Changes in the welfare system that would make it easier for single mothers -- 40 percent of whom are poor -- to climb out of poverty.
* Renewed efforts to promote "equality of opportunity" in hiring, promotion and wages, by race and gender.
* Federal support of child-care and family-leave initiatives.
* Universal access to health care.
Though the wage gap between men and women has narrowed -- women now make roughly 70 percent of what men make, up from 59 percent in 1968 -- women unattached to men continue to be vulnerable. According to research done by Barbara Bergmann, an American University economist who leads the policy group with Ms. Hartmann, a single mother in the United States needs to make at least $19,000 year to escape poverty, well above the Government's official standard of $10,973 for a family of three.
In France, a single mother can have the equivalent -- or better -- standard of living earning only $13,000 because of Government cash and transfer payments, state-supported day care and a national health program. One consequence of the sievish American welfare system, research indicates, is that women may feel forced to stay in abusive relationships to keep the support of a second wage earner.

THE pay-gap gains of the 80's made it possible for white-collar and professional women to support themselves. But Ms. Hartmann says women remain vulnerable, pointing to less-than-enthusiastic enforcement of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in the Reagan-Bush years. "More depends on particular employers and whether they are compliant," she said.
If the agenda seems weighted heavily toward damage repair after 12 years of a free-market approach to inequality, the economists' group also proposes several policy and legislative moves.
It would, for example, like the Labor Department to establish guidelines for pay equity -- an issue once known by the phrase "comparable worth" -- that would equalize the wage differences between "women's work" and "men's work." It would push Congress to devise a national health-care plan and a child-care system. It would also urge Congress to pass a version of the family-leave legislation recently vetoed by President Bush, less because of the leave itself -- many companies already offer more than the measure calls for -- than because it would confer the right to return to a job. "People underestimate the importance of a job guarantee," Ms. Hartmann said.
The group doesn't apologize for its agenda's $100 billion price tag. Ms. Hartmann theorizes that Mr. Clinton is pedaling softly on issues he basically supports because of the money stigma. But, she says, the group is proposing nothing that virtually every other industrialized country doesn't already provide as a matter of course to its citizens. And nothing that couldn't come about by paring the military budget and raising taxes. Would they -- quick intake of breath -- tax and spend? A big public sector can account for the failure of the market system to provide the "goods" women need, Ms. Hartmann argues: "Women should want big government."
 
 
 
HOW THE CANDIDATES RATED
 Given that the agenda of the Economists' Policy Group on Women's Issues has what some Republicans might call a parlor-pinkish slant, it is no surprise that Gov. Bill Clinton gets a higher grade from the group than President Bush. Mr. Clinton's support of a ban on gender discrimination in Federal hiring, promotion and contracts and uncapping the damage awards available to women who have experienced discrimination helped win him an overall grade of B-. Mr. Bush paid for twice vetoing the Family and Medical Leave Act and a laissez-faire attitude toward affirmative action with a grade of D.
The policy group was unimpressed with the records of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush on welfare reform -- they get a C+ and C, respectively -- and health insurance, for which both receive C's. The Administration's four-year failure to introduce a health-care plan incites skepticism, as does the vagueness of Mr. Clinton's proposed cap on health-care expenditures.
Ross Perot was out of the race when the candidates were rated.

HEADLINE: ON THE STREET;
Love Your Jacket!

 BODY:
There is a cookie-cutter look dominating the autumn fashion scene in Paris. It's a black Chanel jacket with an off-center gold zipper and four nonfunctioning gold buttons. Seven women wearing the jacket, most of whom were strangers to each other, were seated in the same small section of the audience at last Monday's Chanel opening. At least 18 others there were in the same jacket, and all but two were in black. What is the special appeal of the jacket, which retails for $2,480?
Especially in a time of economic strain, this jacket's advantage is that it works with both day and evening wear. At 11 A.M., women were wearing the jacket with both above-the-knee and mid-calf skirts. Others were wearing it with trousers and leggings. At a cocktail party, it was seen with a chiffon skirt, and over satin-finished tights. The zipper allows the wearer to have a lower neckline for the dinner table without sacrificing the jacket's smooth-body shape, and the comfort of a higher neckline for cool autumn days. 
 Last year, the American designer Louis Dell'Olio had similar success with a black jacket with an off-center gold zipper and a double row of nonfunctioning gold buttons. Could Paris now be sampling from New York?

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Chrysler Tries to Build Traffic With Its New LH Sedans

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
IT was a perfect New York scene, with a neatly turned-out pedestrian threading his way through the automobiles and talking into his black cellular phone. Hollering, actually, trying to make himself heard above the blaring horns and general mess of well-jammed traffic.
I caught part of what he said because the street was narrow and I was part of the problem. 
 It was rush hour, and I was at the wheel of a new LH sedan, one of the 40 cars that Chrysler Corporation's minions were trying to jam -- more or less simultaneously -- into a crowded underground garage.
The cars, marketed as Chrysler Concordes, Dodge Intrepids and Eagle Visions, had come to New York for their debut with the press and with their dealers, and the event had gone on all day, doing its small bit here and there for the gridlock that is the city's state of being.
First, there was Kennedy Airport, where British Airways had trotted out its quickest plane (Concorde, get it?). Then there was the Intrepid museum for a Dodge lineup down at the docks. And, finally, the parking garage at the Hotel Millenium, a sort of farfetched backdrop for the Eagle Vision.
And, yeah, the guy with the phone. He was yelling at his caller: "It's Chrysler Corporation that's tying things up, and I'm selling my damn stock!"
I don't think he was serious. But if he were, he'd better rethink the notion, because the new sedans are classy cars, and they have a better chance than anything else in a very long time of saving America's No. 3 automaker, which thus far has been kept afloat almost solely by its popular minivans and Jeeps.
At heart and in basic anatomy, the Chrysler, Dodge and Eagle are the same car -- but one with a lot going for it. The company has said that the LH models are "the finest handling four-door sedans America has ever produced" for the mid-size, medium-price market. And, hyperbole aside, their "cab-forward" design does make them immensely roomy and rock-solid on the road.
Cab-forward design is something relatively new, but you will be hearing a lot about it in coming months as a result of Chrysler's $80 million campaign to launch the cars. What it refers to, basically, is a structure that puts the wheels closer to the corners of the car and extends the base of the windshield out to the axis of the front wheels.
That makes the car more stable and creates more room for passengers. In the Concorde, Intrepid and Vision, it is particularly noticeable in the rear compartment, which has the leg- and headroom of a much larger automobile. Interior space, in fact, measures 121 cubic feet, which compares to the likes of Ford Taurus, 118 feet, and Acura Legend, 110 feet.
The more expensive Legend does indeed come up when Chrysler officials talk about their new cars, and it was one of the benchmarks that the company used as a target. In particular, the Legend's handling set the parameters for the LH sedans' Touring suspension, one of three levels of stiffness that can be ordered on the cars.
But the competition is legion, and it includes the Taurus, the BMW 5-series, the Honda Accord, Toyota Camry, Nissan Maxima, Buick Regal and Pontiac Bonneville. The LH's are better or worse than the others in various regards, and some of the other cars are faster and better equipped. But few, if any, are as roomy or as inexpensive.
The Dodge is an "entry-level" vehicle for the line, with prices starting at $15,930. The base Eagle Vision carries a sticker of $17,387, and the least expensive Chrysler Concorde is $18,341. Options abound, however, and those prices escalate quickly into the low- to mid-$20,000 range.
Chrysler's emphasis in its ad campaign is that the company has reinvented itself. But it also is taking steps to differentiate the three lines.
For '93, Dodge gets a new corporate logo in the form of a stylized ram's head, and commercials for the Intrepid proclaim that "This changes everything!" Chrysler's marketing people say that Jeep-Eagle division customers go their own way, and the Vision is being sold as the sportiest of the LH's. Ads for the Vision carry the tagline: "Not intended for the general public."
Chrysler itself has always appealed to older and more conservative buyers, and the sleek shape of the Concorde is a bold step whose success with those customers remains to be seen.
Even more daring will be the introduction next March of the Chrysler New Yorker, a car that was presented at this year's auto shows as a concept vehicle.
The New Yorker will have a seven-inch longer body on the LH platform, with a roof whose beautifully rounded rear profile is a direct steal from the classic Jaguar sedans of old. The design is dashing, and a wide grille makes it look even wider than its sisters.
Under the skin, though, the cars are the same, with two engines available. Both are V6's, mounted fore-to-aft but driving the front wheels. The base engine, which bowed in the minivan three years ago, displaces 3.3 liters and produces 153 horsepower. The optional 3.5-liter powerplant is new this year, has 24 valves and yields a healthy 214 horses. Both are Chrysler designs and are produced in America.
An electronically controlled four-speed automatic is the only transmission available, although five- and six-speed manuals reportedly are under consideration. Also -- and depending on future fuel-economy regulations -- a V8 could be in the works. The longitudinal mounting would lend itself rear-drive configuration, and the engineers say a V8 will fit.
Oddly, both of the V6's feel much the same, and the smaller engine makes the car quick enough for conservative drivers. It is also thriftier, with a city-highway economy rating of 20 and 28 miles per gallon. The bigger engine is naturally thirstier and the rating is 18 and 26.
Whichever engine a buyer chooses, it will live under a sharply sloping hood. And, at the wheel, a driver looks down at the road with the hood barely in the line of sight. Visibility is, in fact, very good all round, and the cars handle and drive like much smaller vehicles.
Front and rear treatments are different on all three, and it is tempting to say that some of the sheetmetal is unique to each. In fact, though, the front fenders are plastic rather than metal, which makes them lighter and resistant to dents.
The test car was a Dodge Intrepid, metallic bronze with a tan leather interior, an option that adds $966 to the price and a bit of stiffness to the ride. It also carried the 3.5-liter engine, costing an additional $625, and a "Customer Preferred Group" that included the performance suspension and added $5,230 to the sticker. What with all that, the bottom line was $23,760.
While the Eagle and Concorde share instrument panels, the Dodge has its own look, with large white gauges. Happily, all three cars use easy-to-read analog instruments, and the digital variation is not even offered as an option.
All three offer standard air bags for both driver and front-seat passenger, a major advance in a medium-priced vehicle. Antilock brakes also are standard in the Chrysler and optional on the Dodge and Eagle. And Chrysler's built-in child safety seats are a welcome option for the rear bench.
The tester had buckets in front, although the base car comes with a split bench in front. With the more expensive interior, you get a shifter and cupholders in the console between the seats; in the cheaper version, the shift lever is on the column.
There are some things not to like, in particular the fact that the rear windows go down only halfway, despite the generous width of the doors that could easily accommodate the glass. Then, too, there is a door-pull sunk into the front armrests that falls directly below the elbow of an average-size occupant. It is uncomfortable and surprising in a car whose interior is otherwise so friendly.
Also lacking is an automatic "down" function for the driver's power window, a feature present in much of the competition. But those are mostly minor quibbles in a domestic automobile that is as competent and neatly done as many of the pricier entries from Europe and Japan.
The cars are relatively easy on the pocketbook. They are good on the highway, good in traffic. Just don't try to put 40 of them into the garage at the same time.
