HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
The Recording Industry Hedges Its Bets and the Superstars Sign On

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
CYNDI LAUPER clearly understood rock singers when she recorded her hit "Money Changes Everything." In the past months, Prince, Madonna and ZZ Top have announced huge record contracts. Will the economics of those deals affect the choices available to music fans?
It's not immediately clear that they will. Interestingly, politics could play a stronger role in what is heard. In the wake of Warner Brothers rapper Ice-T's "Cop Killer" -- which angered many policemen enough to stage a boycott -- a number of record companies have become more stringent in evaluating the songs they release. 
 Michael Jackson was one of the first to announce a megadeal: a $1 billion package with Sony Music that included his own record label. Then Madonna said she had a $60 million arrangement from Warner and her own label. Most recently Prince announced that he had a $100 million deal with Warner Brothers Records, including financing for his Paisley Park label and a position as a vice president at Warner.
These deals are not exactly what they seem. The biggest stars have always called the tune, and today, as decades ago, a few can command their own labels. Frank Sinatra had the Reprise label, the Beatles, Apple.
Certainly, the stars today are making more money than ever, but the major record companies that remained after the merger mania of the 1980's wield greater clout than those individuals. Despite the hyperbole of their press releases, the singers are getting less than the extraordinary numbers being bandied about.
 
The 'Mini-Maxi' Deal
 The contracts, called "mini-maxi" deals, primarily protect the company. Prince, for example, may make $100 million, and then again he may not. His arrangement with Warner Records is "self correcting," as one record industry executive described it. Prince will get a $10 million advance for the first album, but his advance on each new album will depend on the success of the previous release. If the record is a hit, he will get a $10 million advance on his second album. If it flops, he could get only a $2 million advance on the second. Such a deal does not involve paltry sums, but it protects Warner from owing Prince a fortune should his career wane.
The big stars, however, are crucial for multibillion-dollar businesses like Warner, Sony, MCA Records, RCA and Polygram, which as a result of consolidation are distributing an increasingly high percentage of tapes and discs in the United States and abroad, where English language singers still account for 60 percent of sales.
But the deals do have their risks. RCA Records is now owned by the German conglomerate, Bertelsmann A.G. Once a great label, RCA has fallen on hard times. Its recent contract with ZZ Top, rumored at $35 million, is viewed by some music industry executives as yet another example of poor judgment from a company that has paid too much for a group that is already passe. The critics say the sole justification for the deal was to show Bertelsmann's commitment to RCA.
If the prices for superstars are not likely to affect the choice of music available to the consumer, the politics of the business could. Caught between the principles of the First Amendment and the pressures of public accountability, some record companies are nervously taking a stronger stand with performers. However, the performers involved are not necessarily the highest paid in the industry.
And a few of the groups have indicated a willingness to go along with their distributors. For example, MCA Records, which distributes for JDK Records, recently pulled from release an album by JDK's rap group, FU2. The group's lyrics to "One Head, One Backstage Pass" offended a number of MCA employees, including some women staff members. Tragedy, another rap group, was asked to remove from its album "Black Rage," a particularly violent song that talked about a police shooting. The album is distributed by A & M Records, which is owned by Polygram.
Though rap accounts for only 10 percent of music sales, a $7.8 billion market, no company wants to antagonize its talent publicly. So negotiations become a tense balancing act between distributors and artists.
 
Company Clout
 Most artists, by signing with big companies like Warner, acknowledge that the companies can provide more clout at the record stores and more exposure than an independent might. Ice-T, rather than fight the police-led boycott, asked that Warner recall his album. In turn, the giant record companies can exert some leverage of their own with singers -- both over lyrics and contracts.
Today's high-flying mini-maxi deals should not stop companies from supporting new groups and new music formats. Unlike the film business, where the capital costs of producing even a moderate budget film are great, a new record costs less than $1 million to put out. And even today, on the top 200 chart, released each week by Billboard, the trade publication, at least three of the top 10 hits are from relative unknowns.
"If the companies lose on the superstars, they may cut back on new acts," said Irving Azoff, who runs Giant Records, a joint venture with Time Warner's record group, "but on most of these deals it is far too early to gauge the results." In the end, industry analysts say, the economy, one of the records market's most brutal critics, will determine the course of careers.
Correction
An article last Sunday about a hypothetical 50-cent-a-gallon increase in the gasoline tax misstated the difference between the revenue that it might raise and the spending projected for electric car research by a Federal-private entity, the Advanced Battery Consortium. The consortium's research-cost figure, $100 million a year, is only one five-hundredths as much as the $50 billion in potential gas-tax income.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Campuses Buck Clinton On Welfare

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

 BODY:
THEY canceled classes. They sang "Blowin' in the Wind." They carried placards that read, "Willie Horton was an abused/neglected child."
Teach-ins were back last week at the School of Social Work at Columbia University and about 200 other graduate programs around the country. The events, which at Columbia included lectures and a march around campus, were meant to protest cuts in welfare benefits, as well as what the organizers called the demonization of people on welfare . 
 The Columbia event offered a look at the gulf between old-style liberals, who dominated the campus teach-in, and Democrats like Gov. Bill Clinton, whose view of the welfare system forms part of his claim to breaking with his party's past. Traditional liberals have argued that what welfare families lack is economic opportunity and that what they need, most of all, is money. Democrats like Mr. Clinton say the system should enforce certain kinds of behavior, requiring that recipients work or study as a condition of aid. Mr. Clinton has said that if he is elected he will reduce benefits to mothers after two years if they do not get a job or perform community service.
David Fanshel, the Columbia professor who organized the teach-in, said that Mr. Clinton should expect a fight, because "We have a different agenda." While professors of social work control no voting bloc in Congress, they do train many of the workers who staff the bureaucracy that would have to enact the new policies.
Mr. Fanshel and others contended that the main problem for welfare families is poverty, not dependency. They suggested that the Government set a uniform national payment that, along with food stamps, lifts every family above the poverty line, as only two states now do. The benefits for a mother with two children range from $412 in Mississippi to $1,184 in Alaska.
The organizers also called for other income support policies, based on Western European models. These include a $1,000 child allowance, given to every family regardless of income, and a program that pays child support to single mothers when the government fails to collect it from absent fathers.
A record number of Americans are on welfare. There are 4.8 million families -- or more than 13 million people -- relying on Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the main Federal program.
The country reacts to them with a split personality. It frets that almost one American child in four now lives in poverty. But it also frets over the perception that their mothers, or at least some of them, are behaving in unacceptable ways -- not working, not studying, having children when they are too young and poor to support them.
Wisconsin has begun cutting grants to mothers whose children do not attend school. New Jersey plans to stop giving mothers additional benefits for additional children. California will vote on Nov. 3 whether to cut benefits by 25 percent.
 
Jobs for Millions of Mothers
 Past experiments suggest that the cuts and restrictions are unlikely to bring big behavioral changes. And in an economy that is laying off people with solid resumes, the social workers ask where 4.8 million welfare mothers will find work. When Michigan eliminated 80,000 adults from its welfare rolls earlier this year, some found jobs, but others resorted to selling blood and sleeping in homeless shelters.
A mother with two children and no outside income is expected to pay rent and feed and clothe her children on an average of $644 a month in welfare and food stamps, a decline of 27 percent in the past two decades. It is no wonder, then, that researchers have found that virtually all welfare mothers cheat by not reporting outside income.
Mr. Clinton has proposed spending an additional $6 billion a year on tax credits and training to help people on welfare. But if they do not find jobs within two years, he has pledged to make them work off their grants. The teach-in critics noted that this leaves welfare mothers no less poor, just busier. Several professors argued that the Government should guarantee public-works jobs for women now on welfare at a wage that would lift them from poverty -- the kind of program that succeeded during the Great Depression. But it would cost tens of billions of dollars today.
Those wishing to reverse the fortunes of the poor will need savvy not just in policy but politics as well. Among the impressions left by the teach-in is the gap between the way most Americans view social deprivation and the way professors of social work do: It is hard to imagine anyone outside a school of social work who would rally around Willie Horton.
Part of the day's activities involved watching a videotaped panel discussion that included two conservative scholars. Charles Murray of the American Enterprise Institute argued that the predominance of single-parent families was having calamitous effects on the black inner-city and that the welfare system "seduces" women to have children. Lawrence Mead, a political scientist at New York University, argued that the main reason for chronic poverty was the inability of the underclass to capitalize on opportunity. Both comments drew hisses and cackles from the crowd.
"At a forum here, you have to be careful what you say," remarked one student, concerned about what she called the conformity of thought.
The student had just returned from five years of anti-poverty work in Africa and South America, and was perplexed about the mix of external oppression and self-defeat that shapes the American inner city.
"The public thinks poor people are totally respsonsible for their situation," she said. "I think we as social workers tend to go too far the other way, that people aren't responsible at all."
"I'm struggling in terms of what the reality is," she said.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
U.S. Lead in Software Faces a Rising Threat

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
ON a tour of Russia last summer John Morrison, a software designer for the Star Wars anti-missile defense system, was startled to find dozens of small companies using the most advanced American software tools to write programs that rival America's best efforts from electronic spreadsheets to video games. "The surprising thing," he said, "was that Russians are doing more with our best technology than we are. You have world-class programmers who were willing to work for $200 a month."
Low labor costs in foreign countries and dramatic changes in computer technology have led Mr. Morrison and some other software experts to believe that the United States' dominant position in this crucial high-technology sector may soon be challenged. Until now this country's lead in software has appeared unassailable, and the outlook for computer programmers has been one of the few bright spots on the American economic scene. The Bureau of Labor Statistics' projections through 2005 anticipated a need for 613,000 programmers and systems analysts, one of the country's five largest growth categories. Today, however, Russia, India, Brazil and Singapore, among other countries, are making the development of an indigenous software industry a top priority. These countries and others are eagerly offering their brightest technical workers to United States companies, frequently to do the most boring and repetitive programming tasks for low wages. American companies may well find it compelling to export such jobs. 
 In a controversial book published this year, Edward Yourdon, a software consultant, argues that the Government's job predictions are likely to be a mirage. In "The Decline and Fall of the American Programmer," he contends that there will be massive unemployment among American programmers, systems analysts and software engineers before the end of the decade. "We assume that our supposed edge in creativity and innovation will continue to make us dominant," he said. "But a huge part of the software industry involves mature technologies and that's an area in which the United States will be vulnerable."
Maturation means, for one thing, that many applications that once required customized programs can now be done with standardized modules, much as pre-fabricated units simplify the construction of a house that had to be built laboriously by a master carpenter. Different modules encompass a variety of functions so that a programmer sometimes merely links pre-existing modules. And assembling modules requires fewer programmers than creating a program from scratch.
 
Easy Does It
 For another thing, some modules require only the level of programming that a user with little background in computers can provide. Lotus 1-2-3, for example, turns every accountant into a programmer and displaces the job of someone once required to accomplish the same result. Such easy-to-master, off-the-shelf software is increasingly the norm as the cost of hardware, especially the personal computer, declines. In fact, at $20.7 billion this year, the off-the-shelf market almost matches the $21.4 billion market for custom software.
While attention is still given to the young hotshot programmers of Silicon Valley and Route 128 around Boston, the vast majority of American programmers now work for large corporations, mostly maintaining the programs that run everything from airline reservation systems to inventory and accounting processes. With $120 billion a year at stake in the global software business, it is no wonder that America's industry is a prime target for foreign competitors. Mr. Yourdon predicts computer programmers will meet the same fate that befell American autoworkers in the 1970's and 1980's at the hands of the Japanese.
Already Texas Instruments and Citicorp have established software development operations in India. Borland International, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., developed its popular Quattro spreadsheet in Hungary. Earlier this year, Sun Microsystems hired a group of crack Russian computer designers to develop future Sun systems. "Anywhere in the world that has a lower standard of living and has a structure with programming talent is a potential source of competition with the United States," said Capers Jones, chairman of Software Productivity Research. Also, as with automobiles, American pre-eminence seems vulnerable on another troublesome front: quality. A survey this year by Software Productivity Research Inc., a consulting firm, found that United States software quality ranked seventh behind Japan, England, Sweden, Norway, Canada and the Netherlands.
Still, Government economists counter that there is little reason to expect dramatic changes in the growth outlook for software employment between now and the end of the decade. Megan Barkume, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics who tracks programming and other high technology jobs, said, "I believe that growth in information technologies will continue at its current pace although the growth in the need for programmers will slow in the future."
For the American computer programmer, that is scant reassurance. Already there are fewer programmers in Los Angeles and New York then there are in Tokyo and London.
"I don't think that anyone in the software industry has any reason to feel comfortable," said Jim Davis, an independent Silicon Valley programmer who was unemployed for half of 1992. "There is a general pressure to push down wages in the industry. How can you compete with people who are willing to work for $800 a year?"

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Why the Candidates Resist Saying 'Prime the Pump'

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
EVER since President Franklin D. Roosevelt launched the Works Progress Administration and other New Deal ventures to help the one in four Americans out of work during the Great Depression, policymakers have looked to fiscal stimulus as a life raft to rescue the nation from recession. Though the success of the New Deal is debated -- it took World War II to end the Depression -- the vast job creation program, based on the precepts of John Maynard Keynes, the British economist, put almost four million Americans to work building the Hoover Dam, LaGuardia Airport and other public projects. Some economists say it laid the basis for more equitable distribution of wealth when recovery occurred.
This year, even though the economy remains stalled, all three Presidential candidates are looking askance at fiscal stimulus, the use of deficit spending to create jobs and consequent growth. 
 President Bush, Gov. Bill Clinton and Ross Perot are all pushing plans to strengthen the economy in the long term, but they are loath to try short-term stimulus because increasing the deficit would open them to charges of fiscal irresponsibility.
This reticence could disappear around Inauguration Day. Whoever is elected will want to get off to a strong start and may turn to fiscal stimulus because nothing else seems likely to jolt the economy.
"If Clinton is elected and the economy is flat or negative into February, you don't have to be a rocket scientist to see that he will call his advisers together and say, 'I want a plan to get this economy moving again,' " said Robert F. Westcott, an economist with the WEFA Group, a consulting firm in Bala Cynwyd, Pa.
In Mr. Clinton's plan, he proposes to spend $20 billion a year on highways, high-speed rail and other public investment projects. Few economists view his approach as fiscal stimulus, however, because spending would be offset by measures to simultaneously reduce the deficit, like increasing taxes on the wealthy and trimming numerous government programs, including defense. (His plan would not, however, reduce the deficit by nearly as much as Mr. Clinton promises, most economists say.)
President Bush's plan relies on lower taxes, spending cuts and deregulation, but Administration officials admit it is not a plan to spur short-term growth.
Mr. Perot's plan to eliminate the deficit over four years is the opposite of fiscal stimulus. By increasing taxes and cutting spending, it would slow growth for several years before leading to faster growth late this decade. Many economists feel most Americans, weary from years of stagnating income, may not want to wait that long.
Indeed, with the economy sliding sideways like a lethargic lobster, more and more economists want the candidates to promote stimulus plans. The opposing view is that this kind of pump-priming often does more harm than good, raising fears of higher inflation and pushing long-term interest rates higher, which undermines housing construction and business investment. Besides, some economists say, the economy is slowly picking up steam and by the time fiscal stimulus has road builders hiring workers, growth will be so strong that the stimulus will no longer be needed.
Every billion dollars spent on public works yields about 25,000 jobs directly, and by creating orders for cement or new tractors, another 15,000 jobs indirectly, according to DRI/McGraw-Hill, a consulting firm in Lexington, Mass. But a stimulus plan would not put people back to work in days or weeks. If the next President pushed a program through Congress in February, it might take a month for Maine or Mississippi to bid a highway re-paving contract, and another month for the winning company to buy asphalt and hire workers. Plans to rebuild bridges or construct new airports or high-speed railroads could take much longer. Not before mid-1993 or later might there would be a measurable impact on jobs, said Francis B. Francois, executive director of the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials.
The 50 states say they have $1.8 billion of highway plans that could be begun within 30 days. The Federal Highway Administration says $45 billion more is needed each year to bring the nation's decaying roads back to satisfactory condition. It also says 134,000 of the 555,000 bridges need to be repaired or rebuilt.
All this spending could run into bumps along the way. Cash-strapped states could find it hard to ante up their share to match the Federal money -- roughly $1 for every four Federal dollars. And northern states, because of their colder climates, might take longer than southern states to start programs.
DRI/McGraw-Hill estimates that a $40 billion public investment program would create 640,000 jobs in 1993 and 1.25 million in 1994. This would reduce the jobless rate, currently 7.5 percent, by one percentage point. And the hard-core unemployed might be missed: "These programs don't do much for those who need the jobs most," said Eli Ginzberg, a professor emeritus at Columbia University. "Unions usually have a big say in these programs, and blacks don't get the jobs." He suggested a program of "public service," not just public investment, like using Federal money to hire more security guards for city schools. Other suggestions include giving states and municipalities money to hire welfare recipients or the long-term unemployed to be clerks or mechanics.
This approach leads many conservatives to grouse about make-work programs, like hiring receptionists for offices where the phone rings once a day. Liberals have gripes, too. When President Carter launched a public employment program involving 750,000 workers, many unions complained that cities fired experienced workers and used the Federal money to hire lower-paid replacements.
In theory, anyway, a stimulus program tilted heavily toward investment, not public service, would do most to create jobs and build a more efficient America, experts say. It should help allay fears of inflation.
Long-term interest rates have risen recently in part because investors believe that a Clinton Presidency would mean more economic activism than under President Bush. To investors, such activism signals faster growth and higher inflation. Although today's economy is underheated, Wall Streeters fear stimulus could lead to overheating in several years. But advocates of such programs say it's foolish to think pump-priming will cause prices to ramp upward.
"The costs of not acting, I think, are much greater than the costs of acting," said Robert Eisner, an economist at Northwestern University. "We have almost no inflation now. The inflation hawks are fighting the last war."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 948 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Lily-Livered Neo-Wilsonian! The New Political Tag Game

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS the saying goes, you can't tell the players without a scorecard, but what if the game changes and the scorecard stays the same? That is the situation this political season, when the labels "conservative" and "liberal" no longer seem to fit the players, but no one has quite come up with new ones.
"These labels now disinform rather than inform," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a veteran of many political wars. "We are headed for a new political language to describe a new political terrain -- one in which we are not the economic colossus of the world, which we have been for a century, and one in which we are not locked in a struggle with totalitarianism, which we have been for half a century." 
 Fear not. Ideologues and pundits are already busy sewing new uniforms, and it may not be long before you hear about "neo-Wilsonians" taking the field against "realists" and "Trumanites" in Democratic foreign policy debates, while "Murphy Brown traditionalists" and "libertarians" slug it out on the Republican side.
Don't like those labels? Then wait five minutes. White House wags have just labeled the young Republican interns in the Bush campaign as "mini-cons," and Pat Buchanan as a "neo-Calhounist," a reference to Mr. Buchanan's isolationist, state's-rights agenda evocative of John C. Calhoun's.
 
From 'Kook' to 'Nut'
 The New Republic coined "homo-cons" to describe gay conservatives, and its editor in chief, Martin Peretz, came up with "paleo-liberals" to describe those diehard, pro-quota, shun-the-use-of-force Democrats who he fears will try a comeback in a Clinton Administration.
Spy magazine topped everyone, though. It has just presented its own political spectrum for the 1990's, describing the players from far left to far right as follows: "kook," "progressive," "concerned," "moderate," "right-thinking," "patriot," "nut."
The political agenda that made sense of the terms "conservative" and "liberal" was set in stone by the New Deal. The question then was what roles should a market economy and the welfare state play in providing every American a decent standard of living and in moderating cyclical economic downturns. Liberals favored more government, conservatives less.
Today some new questions are on the table. In domestic policy the question is: what is the proper role of government in dealing with an American economy that no longer seems structurally equipped to remain competitive in a globally intertwined world?
In foreign policy, the old question was how best to respond to the Soviet Union. Today the new question is how best to respond to a world in which nations are simultaneously fragmenting ethnically and politically while consolidating economically. That is, how best to respond to a world in which ethnic-cleansing zones and free-trade zones exist side-by-side?
For these questions, several Democratic schools of thought are now in session. In foreign policy, the most prominent group in the Clinton campaign is the "neo-Wilsonians." This term applies to Democrats who want foreign policy focused more on values and spreading democracy, but who also believe that it can't be overly moralistic or averse to the use of force to resolve complex crises like Bosnia. Also in the Clinton camp are "neo-Trumanites," who share the neo-Wilsonians' sober internationalism, but are a little bit more hard-headed.
 
That Annoying 'Label Lag'
 Anthony Lake, Mr. Clinton's top foreign policy adviser, who years ago got tabbed as a dove for opposing the Vietnam war, argues that the labels "dove" and "hawk" are meaningless today, when the issues are totally different and a neo-Wilsonian like himself advocates a limited use of force to deal with situations like the Balkans. Mr. Lake may be experiencing what will be the most common political malady of the 1990's: "label lag." As he put it: "The world has changed and to carry a label that contradicts your views is very irritating."
In both parties there also are "realists," who think America should be involved only in foreign policy problems that touch on immediate strategic interests, and "isolationists," who don't believe in foreign policy at all.
In domestic affairs, there is a "libertarian school" among Republicans, led by Jack Kemp, that argues for individual choice on personal questions, like abortion and schools, and for laissez-faire economics. Its adherents should find themselves opposed by cultural "traditionalists," prominent among them Pat Robertson, who say Government should have a role in shaping family values and moral choices. In between will be the "problem solvers" -- a Jim Baker-Gerald Ford group of Republican pragmatists who favor limited tax increases, limited welfare and limited family values, but are motivated by solving problems, not reaching ideological goals.
On economic issues, Mr. Clinton is straddling two Democratic camps. One is the "Wall Street liberals," who argue that the economy is not merely in a cyclical trough but a structural decline that can be reversed only by improving productivity and competitiveness. They want to use market forces to carry out this agenda, while also focusing keenly on longer-term deficit reduction. The other school, which might be called the "Japan liberals," favors Government-directed industrial policies like those that have made Japan such a competitive dragon, and is willing to be slightly less aggressive about the deficit to protect social programs and growth.
Still don't like those labels? You may not be alone.
Senator Moynihan, referring to the Republicans who in 1884 deserted their candidate to vote for Grover Cleveland, said, "Put me down as a mugwump."

HEADLINE: Prerequisite for College: Banking 101

 BODY:
A finance quiz: If the American economy is adversely affected by its hugh debt and one prescription to improve the economy is to create a better, college-educated work force, how do people pay for a college education?
 Increasingly, the answer is debt. 
 As college costs continue to outpace increases in income, record numbers of families are turning to loans to pay for college. Fifteen years ago, loans accounted for 17 percent of all student aid; now they are 50 percent.
 And as the number of loans increased, defaults on student loans increased faster. The Federal Government had almost $3 billion in default costs in fiscal 1992.
 Gov. Bill Clinton cited the default figures in the second televised Presidential debate when he was asked how he would finance his education plan - a guarantee to every eligible student, a college education, in exchange for a few years of government service or a surcharge on the student's future income taxes.
 Governor Clinton says his plan would cost $8 billion a year above the current costs of $3 billion in loan defaults and $1 billion in bank fees.
 Neither President Bush nor Ross Perot has proposed dramatic changes in the current system.
 Campaign promises focus on the figure. At right are snapshots from college financing's recent past.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Less Than Full Equivalency

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
FOR decades, the General Educational Development test, or G.E.D., has been regarded as a respectable alternative to a four-year high school diploma, one that a growing proportion of high school dropouts have taken as a way to resume their education or enter training programs.
Now evidence is emerging, part academic, part empirical, that the people who have G.E.D. certificates remain well behind regular high school graduates in earning power as well as in other, more subtle qualities . 
 A University of Chicago economist, James J. Heckman, published a paper this spring that has stunned the G.E.D. Testing Center, which is part of the non-profit American Council on Education. Using Census Bureau figures, Dr. Heckman demonstrated that in his sample of men, 25 and 28 years old, G.E.D. holders earn little more than dropouts with no certification, and far less than people with high school diplomas.
"Exam-certified high school equivalents are statistically indistinguishable from high school dropouts," he reported. "There is no cheap substitute for schooling."
Some G.E.D. graduates do very well. Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, Waylon Jennings, the country singer, and the comedian Bill Cosby are some of the better-known holders of the certificate. (Mr. Cosby later graduated from Temple University and earned a Ph.D. in education from the University of Massachusetts.)
Last week, it came out that the Army has quietly stopped accepting the G.E.D. holders into the service on the same basis as high school graduates, because recruits with G.E.D.'s fail basic training and are kicked out of the service at nearly twice the rate of those with high school diplomas.
 
Key to State Jobs
 The G.E.D. Testing Service maintains that Dr. Heckman's sample of G.E.D. holders was too small to be meaningful. As for the Army's decision, the service concedes that the certificate only measures academic skills, not the more elusive quality of tenacity.
G.E.D.'s continue to account for a growing share of all high school diplomas, amounting to 14 percent of the total last year, compared to five percent 20 years ago. Dr. Heckman credits the increase to the expansion of Federal and state job training programs that require a G.E.D., a benefit of obtaining the certificate.
Defenders of the G.E.D. also make a muted social argument for accepting the G.E.D. on the same basis as the high school diploma. G.E.D.-takers are poorer, more likely to be black or Hispanic and possess fewer family advantages than those who complete high school, they observe. To begin discounting the value of the G.E.D. now, just as more and more disadvantaged people seize a chance to improve their lives, only adds to the difficulties of people who deserve credit for what they have achieved, and encouragement to go on.

HEADLINE: INSURERS PREPARE TO SEEK RATE RISES AFTER DISASTERS

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Insurance for homes and automobiles is expected to rise in cost 10 percent or more in some states, and perhaps become harder to obtain, after the staggeringly high losses to insurers from Hurricane Andrew and other recent disasters.
The losses this year, estimated at more than $10 billion, come after a number of difficult years for the property-casualty industry. And they come while lower interest rates are reducing the return on insurance companies' investments. As a result, analysts and industry executives say, many companies will experience cash shortages in the next 12 months and will be under pressure to raise rates.
 
An Excuse to Gouge?
 Nonetheless, consumer advocates say many insurance companies are far healthier than they would have the public believe and are trying to use the catastrophes as an excuse to gouge the public. 
 The conflict was stoked when an internal memo from the American International Group, a major property-casualty insurer, was published in The Washington Post. In it, J. W. Greenberg, executive vice president, wrote that Hurricane Andrew was "an opportunity to get price increases now." Maurice R. Greenberg, A.I.G.'s chairman and J. W. Greenberg's father, said the memo's meaning had been taken out of context. Last month, the insurance commissioners of Florida and Louisiana took the unusual step of freezing A.I.G.'s premiums.
 The debate over how consumers will be affected by the year's disasters -- the greatest run of insured losses in this century -- goes beyond a disagreement over the reams of numbers pouring in from disaster areas in Florida, Hawaii and other states. It is part of a continuing war between consumer advocates and the industry over how America should distribute the costs of big risks and whether insurers are treating consumers fairly.
At the heart of their conflict is the debate between consumer advocates on the one hand and many economists and analysts on the other over how the financial health of the insurance industry should be judged.
Some companies say moderate price increases on personal lines of insurance may take place in coastal states from Texas to Florida and up the East Coast, possibly as far north as New Jersey. Prices may also be affected in California, where insurers pay for catastrophe reinsurance for earthquakes. No one is certain how much rates might go up in each state; industry analysts say perhaps 5 to 15 percent.
One thing that could prevent price rises, analysts say, would be a strong reaction by the public and regulators.
"Hurricane Andrew was a fundamental shock to the system," said an executive of one big insurance company who insisted on anonymity. "Either prices are going to have to go up somewhat in disaster-prone states, or companies are going to have to back out of the business."
He added, "But insurance commissioners like John Garamendi in California will be saying, 'By golly, I am not going to let the people suffer.' " Mr. Garamendi, an elected official, has enraged the industry with policies that he calls pro-consumer but that many companies say are a way to further his political ambitions.
 
 
Costliest Disaster Ever
 After an original estimate of $7.3 billion of losses in Florida, industry experts last week revised their estimates to $10.2 billion in Florida plus another $500 million in Louisiana. Those losses are more than twice the $4.2 billion insurers lost in what had been the nation's most expensive storm, Hurricane Hugo in 1989.
While insurers were still catching their breath after Andrew, Hurricane Iniki hit Hawaii and cost an additional $1.6 billion, making it the nation's third-costliest storm. And all of that followed losses from the Los Angeles riots and a flood in downtown Chicago, as well as severe hailstorms and other disasters.
Altogether, the industry is expected to pay at least $16 billion in claims on disasters this year, according to the American Insurance Services Group, which estimates industrywide damages from disasters. Most insurers will be able to recoup about a third of those losses after taxes. The last four years, which have included other losses like the collapse of oil platforms and the San Francisco earthquake, have become the most costly of this century to the property-casualty industry.
But it is not those losses alone that will create pressures to increase prices, some analysts say, but long-term trends in the industry.
"Hurricane Andrew will not in itself raise rates," said Orin Kramer, an analyst and industry consultant in Fort Lee, N.J. "But the largest catastrophe losses in insurance history follow five years of overall deteriorating financial performance and growing cash-flow problems."
 
 
Losses From Underwriting
 Mr. Kramer pointed to the extent of the industry's losses on underwriting -- the fact that together the industry has paid out more than it has taken in through premiums on all types of property casualty insurance. A. M. Best, the insurance-company rating concern in Oldwick, N.J., says the industry has lost an average of nearly 10 cents on the dollar on underwriting in the last decade.
In good years, companies more than make up those losses with income from investments. Since 1986, investment income has covered those losses but left the industry only modest profit margins of 5 to 8 percent.
John Snyder, a senior vice president of A. M. Best, said that with lower interest rates, property-casualty insurers are expected to realize investment income of only 3 to 4 percent this year. Together with this year's heavy losses, profits will be far harder to achieve, he said.
In recent weeks, Wall Street has speculated intensely on whether the storm losses will lead to a rise in commercial insurance rates, the premiums charged to businesses. The impact on commercial prices remains unclear, many analysts say, because the losses are spread across an industry with $160 billion in capital.
But Bruce Ballantine, a senior analyst with Moody's Investors Service in New York, says a point often missed in such discussions is that the losses from Hurricane Andrew were not distributed equally among insurers. They fell disproportionately on the segment of the industry that specializes in personal lines of insurance and has perhaps a third of the industry's total capital.
 
An Eye on Capital
 Allstate and State Farm, for example, together write about a third of the nation's auto and homeowners policies. Allstate's after-tax losses of $1.1 billion equal about 20 percent of the company's capital. State Farm's $1.4 billion in losses equal about 8 percent of capital.
The amount of capital is crucial to an insurance company because it serves as a buffer against unexpected losses. It also limits the amount of insurance the company can write. Generally, state regulators prefer that insurers write policies whose premiums do not add up to much more than twice the insurers' capital, or net worth.
Still another factor that may affect prices for individuals, analysts say, is the extreme tightening in the market for disaster reinsurance, which is insurance that insurance companies buy so that when a large disaster hits, they share the costs with others.
Even before Andrew, losses from the last three years had already drastically reduced the amount of reinsurance being written by Lloyd's of London and other British reinsurers. Continental Insurance of the United States, which wrote $250 million in reinsurance premiums annually, said that after heavy losses from Andrew, it was leaving the field.
 
View of Consumer Groups

 Michael Frinquelli, an analyst for Salomon Brothers, who expects average rate increases of as much as 10 percent for personal types of insurance, points out that the question of how well property-casualty insurers have done in recent years depends on what numbers you look at.
If one looks at only underwriting results and investment income in the last decade, returns for the industry were poor -- about 11 percent for those who have invested in the insurance industry, compared with 15 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500. But if one counts the gains insurers made on their stock and bond portfolios, the number rises to a much healthier 17 percent since 1981.
Robert Hunter, president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization in Alexandria, Va., says regulators must take into account the fact that the property-casualty industry increased its capital $20 billion in 1991 alone, much of which came as a result of dropping interest rates that pushed up the value of insurers' bonds. Those capital increases, Mr. Hunter said, more than make up for this year's losses.
In addition, Mr. Hunter said, insurers received some good news recently in results from the private passenger-car market. In the last 18 months, underwriting results there actually improved sharply, according to data gathered by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, he said. In 1991, returns for insurance companies jumped 10 percent, largely because people were driving less and having fewer accidents during the recession.
Most important, Mr. Hunter said, companies should not be allowed to charge the public for past losses. The theory behind insurance regulation, he said, is that prices should be based on predictions of losses in the future. A large storm like Andrew, Mr. Hunter said, should have a small impact on the cost of personal lines of insurance in some coastal areas. Price increases as a result of Hurricane Hugo, for example, were limited to 3 to 4 percent for homeowners and other property insurance in South Carolina.
Mr. Hunter said he expected the companies to try to use the hurricanes as an excuse to raise prices even more in insurance for businesses, a move he and other opponents of the industry would likely dispute.

HEADLINE: Baker, Informing Iraqis of Credits, Asked for Help With Palestinians

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d sent a message to Iraq in November 1989 telling the Iraqis that the United States had just approved new grain credits and seeking Baghdad's influence in persuading Palestinians to take part in peace talks with Israel, a newly declassified document shows.
Although the message from Mr. Baker, now the White House chief of staff, does not explicitly link the farm loan credits to Iraq's intervention with the Palestinians, it provides the clearest evidence to date that the United States wanted something in return for the guarantees. 
 The message was sent to Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, on Nov. 9, 1989, nine months before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. A copy of the message was released along with numerous other documents Friday night by the Senate Agriculture Committee, which is investigating reported abuses in the farm credit program.
Some members of Congress have charged that the Iraqis diverted the grain for money and weapons, and that the Bush Administration generally sought to curry favor with President Saddam Hussein before Iraq invaded Kuwait. The question has become an issue in the Presidential election.
The Bush Administration has repeatedly denied that there was any evidence of such a grain diversion and justified its decision to extend the farm credits as a way to try to moderate President Hussein's behavior through economic and political incentives.
The decision to proceed with the farm credits was made despite opposition from the Treasury Department, the Federal Reserve, the Office of Management and Budget and Federal prosecutors in Atlanta who were investigating a multibillion-dollar loan fraud involving the Atlanta branch of an Italian bank and Iraq.
In another document released by the committee, the Federal prosecutor in charge of the bank case wrote in an internal memo last July stating that Iraq had misused the farm program and that the Agriculture Department knew it but chose to ignore it.
The July 16, 1992 memo by the prosecutor, Gail McKenzie, sharply criticizes the Department for ignoring evidence of the abuses in a meeting with other Government agencies held just before the Administration agreed to proceed with the first $500 million of the $1 billion in credits to Iraq.
Mr. Baker's request to the Iraqis for help with the Palestinians partly explains why he became personally involved in lobbying for the farm program. Determined to make progress on his peace plan, Mr. Baker at one point, according to previous press reports, telephoned Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter to press the case for the grain credits.
 
Delivered by Ambassador
 In the message to Iraq, which was sent by Mr. Baker for delivery by the United States Ambassador in Baghdad, April C. Glaspie, Mr. Baker said he was "pleased to be able to inform" Mr. Aziz that an Agriculture Department team would soon arrive in Baghdad to negotiate new credits under terms that "we believe will be acceptable to you."
The message, sent a month after Mr. Aziz and Mr. Baker had met in Washington, said the decision on the grain credits "reflects the importance we attach to our relationship with Iraq."
Then Mr. Baker quickly turned to the peace talks. "We are at a critical point in our diplomacy," Mr. Baker said. "The Government of Egypt is working closely with Palestinians to respond positively to our five-point framework, enabling us to get an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue launched. It would be useful if you could weigh in with them and urge them to give a positive response to Egypt's suggestions."
Mr. Baker had broached the subject of Iraqi support for the Egyptian peace plan at his meeting with Mr. Aziz on Oct. 6. But at that meeting, according to the minutes, Mr. Aziz remained noncommittal, telling Mr. Baker, it was "Iraqi policy to refrain from public statements on the peace process."
Ms. McKenzie's memo gives a detailed description of her concerns about the grain program, which she had voiced in a conversation with two senior Agriculture Department officials on Oct. 11, 1989. Other documents indicate that Ms. McKenzie and other members of her team had warned against giving Iraq new credits.
Ms. McKenzie wrote in the memo that she told the two officials that there were strong indications that Iraq was bartering or diverting food bought through the credit program, because the country was buying more food than "could reasonably be consumed in Iraq." She noted that the Agriculture Department's monitoring system traced food shipments only as far as Jordan and Turkey, not as far as Iraq.
At the time of her meeting, Federal prosecutors in Atlanta and other United States Government officials were suspicious that Iraq was diverting either the loan money or the food into weapons purchases, although the allegations have never been proven.
Ms. McKenzie's memo was apparently written as a protective measure to exonerate her and her team of any wrongdoing in their handling of the bank fraud. Ms. McKenzie said in the memo that it was written after she learned that Congress was investigating her briefings to Agriculture Department officials.
 
Iraq Demanded Bribes
 The prosecutors had also uncovered evidence that Iraq had demanded bribes from American exporters participating in the program. In her memo, Ms. McKenzie described how the Iraqis paid inflated prices for goods backed by the American program in order to include kickbacks and freight charges in violation of the program's regulations. Even after the Agriculture Department "advised Iraq to cease such demands for payments," she wrote, the Iraqis continued to demand kickbacks.
Many of the loans guaranteed by the United States grain program were extended by the Atlanta branch of the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, an Italian bank that Ms. McKenzie's office was investigating. She noted that Iraq was using other loans from the bank to buy militarily useful equipment, including machines useful in both ballistic missile and nuclear wepaons programs.
She also said that the Iraqis "may be" using profits from the bank fraud scheme and from kickbacks in military projects.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Overview;
CONTEST TIGHTENS AS PEROT RESURGES AND CLINTON SLIPS

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
The 1992 Presidential campaign is entering its home stretch with Ross Perot newly energized and Gov. Bill Clinton still in the lead but facing a tightening contest with President Bush, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
The new poll, conducted Tuesday through Friday, suggests that Mr. Perot received a considerable boost from his performance in the Presidential debates and his weeks of heavy advertising. It indicates that Mr. Clinton's support has dropped since early October and that Republican attacks on his trustworthiness may be taking a toll. Mr. Bush's support, however, was not growing, according to the poll. 
 The upshot is a tighter race. Among the probable electorate, which reflects the likelihood of each respondent's voting on Nov. 3, Mr. Clinton now has the support of 40 percent, Mr. Bush of 35 percent and Mr. Perot of 15 percent, the poll shows. In early October, before the debates, Mr. Clinton stood at 46 percent, Mr. Bush at 38 percent and Mr. Perot at 7 percent.
 
Elation in Bush Camp
 Bush campaign officials, elated over signs in this and other polls that Mr. Clinton's substantial lead was eroding, predicted that voters were entering a new phase of decision-making that would put a premium on trust. "It's moving our way," said Charles Black, senior adviser to the Bush campaign.
But Clinton strategists disputed the Times/CBS poll, noting that other independent surveys, while showing a closer race, did not show the gap as small as five percentage points. "I never question somebody's polls," said James Carville, senior strategist for Clinton. "But this is the first private or public poll with a margin like this."
Mr. Carville added: "The race is going to tighten. I don't think there's any question about that. I just think we've got to work hard coming down the stretch."
 
Election Seen as Over
 A Washington Post poll published today showed an eight-point Clinton lead, while the Time Magazine/CNN poll released this weekend showed a seven-point gap. The Times/CBS poll, based on interviews with 1,854 adults nationwide, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, which means that statistically it is in the range of the other polls.
But as the national polls tighten, Mr. Clinton retains strong leads in some of the biggest states and thus a commanding hold on the electoral map, which Republicans acknowledge will be very hard to break.
The registered voters seem to be operating under the assumption that the election is over, with 6 in 10 expecting a Clinton victory on Election Day, according to the Times/CBS poll. To some analysts, this suggests that some recent supporters of Mr. Perot may be exercising a "free vote," sending a message by backing him because they feel that neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Clinton need their vote.
Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker, argued, "Once there was this sense of inevitability associated with Clinton's election, voters could start to be for Perot without any sense of risk to it. You could be for Perot without having to worry about electing a President, or without having to worry about electing George Bush President."
Still, Mr. Perot has undergone a remarkable image-building since he re-entered the race. Twenty-nine percent now say they view Mr. Perot favorably, while 32 percent see him unfavorably. In early October, only 7 percent viewed him favorably, while 59 percent held unfavorable views.
 
Debates Aid Perot
 The debates were a clear lift to Mr. Perot, many analysts said, operating as a kind of mini-convention re-introducing him to the American electorate. Thirty-nine percent said Mr. Clinton won the three Presidential debates, but 31 percent said Mr. Perot did. Only 15 percent said Mr. Bush won.
Mr. Bush, for his part, continues to have many vulnerabilities. His job approval rating stands at 40 percent among all adults, and 77 percent continued to rate the economy as bad or very bad, findings that showed little change during the fall campaign. But his favorability ratings improved slightly among registered voters this month, now standing at 35 percent favorable, 45 percent unfavorable.
Mr. Clinton was acquiring a more negative image, reflecting Republican attempts to raise doubts about his character and suitability as a potential President: 33 percent now view him favorably, 39 percent unfavorably. And the proportion who say he is not telling the truth about the draft is rising.
Mr. Bush retains and has even enlarged his advantage in being seen as able to "handle all the problems a President has to deal with," a major theme of his campaign. But Mr. Clinton retains strong advantages in other areas, such as "caring about the needs and problems of people like you," which 65 percent said he did, while 48 percent said Mr. Bush did.
Still, the most intriguing variable in this race, nine days before the election, is Mr. Perot. Both campaigns are paying less attention to Mr. Perot's standing nationally than to his impact in specific states. He is considered a help to the Democrats in the South and a problem for them in the industrial Midwest.
Stan Greenberg, the poll taker for Mr. Clinton, said that while Mr. Perot may be "taking a little more from us nationally," he may actually be helping the Democrats in the Electoral College. Mr. Greenberg argued that Mr. Clinton's leads in the states where Mr. Perot was dipping into the Democrat's support were big enough to withstand it.
Republicans acknowledge their daunting challenge in assembling a majority in the Electoral College, given Mr. Clinton's present strength. "Sure he's got a big advantage there," said Bob Teeter, chairman of the Bush campaign. "We've got to have a lot of things change." But they were clearly heartened by signs of movement in the national polls.
The latest Times/CBS poll showed an unusually close race between Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton in the Northeast, in opposition to a round of recent state polls that showed solid margins for the Democrat. When the results were re-calculated to reflect the relationship of the Northeast to the rest of the country in typical polls this fall, Mr. Clinton's national lead rose to six from five percentage points.
Totally separate from The New York Times/CBS News Poll, The Times interviewed political professionals and analysts across the country this week for their assessments of the race. What follows is a regional perspective, based on their impressions.
 
The South
Democrats Gain By Being Neighbors
 The political scientist V. O. Key Jr. wrote about the "friends and neighbors" factor in Southern politics, the predilection to vote for the hometown ticket. This campaign has proven that theory to be alive and well. Not since the last friend-and-neighbor Democratic nominee in 1976 has the South been so competitive.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore have offered themselves as "different" Democrats, culturally and ideologically in tune with their native South, largely defusing such reliable Republican campaign points as the death penalty (which Mr. Clinton supports, a fact noted in his television advertising). Coupled with the ailing economy, this helps explain why Mr. Bush is still campaigning hard in a region he once considered his "firewall."
Mr. Bush is considered strongest in Mississippi, South Carolina and Alabama, but he is still scrambling in the biggest states, North Carolina, Georgia, Florida and Texas. Florida is a striking example of Mr. Bush's vulnerability: a state that he carried with 61 percent of the vote in 1988 is now widely considered too close to call.
Texas, Mr. Bush's adopted state, is still very uncertain too, with Mr. Perot a major factor. A new poll by The Houston Chronicle, released today, showed Mr. Clinton in the lead, with 39 percent of the vote, followed by Mr. Bush with 31 percent and Mr. Perot with 15 percent. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points
 
The Midwest
Clinton Is Trying To Hold Lead
 The Midwest is the traditional battleground in competitive Presidential campaigns, the home of the Reagan Democrats. Fueled by the ailing economy, Mr. Clinton built a formidable lead in this region in the two months after the Democratic convention. Now, his challenge is to hold onto it, against Mr. Bush and a newly energized Mr. Perot.
Illinois, with its 22 electoral votes, has become a Clinton stronghold, with the Democratic nominee holding consistent double-digit leads in polls throughout the fall. But Michigan, with 18 electoral votes, is considered to be more competitive, a state where Democrats will have to watch closely for Mr. Perot's impact. This region shows the quirkiness of Mr. Perot's political impact. While he seems to work to the advantage of the Democrats in the South, he is a worry to them here.
A poll of Michigan for The Detroit Free Press and WXYZ-TV, conducted on Tuesday and Wednesday showed Mr. Perot cutting Mr. Clinton's lead in half. Mr. Clinton had the support of 41 percent of the voters, Mr. Bush of 31 percent and Mr. Perot of 19 percent. Before the debates, Mr. Clinton led by nearly 20 percentage points. The latest poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
Analysts in Ohio also report a bump for Mr. Perot, although Mr. Clinton continued to lead. The Democrats seem confident of Missouri, but Wisconsin remains competitive. "Clinton's ahead, but his lead is marginal," asserted Brian Christenson, political director of the Republican Party in Wisconsin. Jonathan Sender, executive director of the Democratic Party in Wisconsin, agreed that despite Mr. Clinton's lead, "this is a very competitive battleground state."
 
The West
California Becomes Clinton Stronghold
 The Pacific West has become an anchor for the Democrats. Mr. Clinton acquired a big lead in California after Mr. Perot withdrew from the race in July and held onto it throughout the fall. Clinton strategists say they believe their candidate is strong enough in the state -- which alone provides one-fifth of the 270 electoral votes necessary to win -- to withstand a boomlet for Mr. Perot.
Economic concerns are particularly strong in California, where the unemployment rate was 9.4 percent in September, and Mr. Bush has felt the full measure of the voters' discontent, with his disapproval ratings here being among the highest in the country. Democrats are also counting on an increase in voter registration to help them.
The Rocky Mountain West is far more complicated. Mr. Clinton has done some hard campaigning in this region, once reliable for the Republicans. The Bush camp is hoping that most of these states will return to the fold as the election nears. But the post-debate gain by Mr. Perot may be coming with a vengeance here and complicating their task.
Mr. Perot had some of his strongest support in the Mountain West before July, and a new poll for the Denver Post suggests that much of it is returning.
The poll for The Denver Post and KCNC-TV in Denver, conducted among 400 registered voters the evenings of Oct. 20 through Oct. 23, showed Mr. Clinton at 37 percent, Mr. Bush at 28 percent and Mr. Perot at 25 percent. The poll had a sampling error of plus or minus 4.9 percentage points.
 
The East
Democrats Look To 1964 Landslide

New York, with its 33 electoral votes, is widely considered to be solid for Mr. Clinton. Democrats, hoping for a repeat of the tidal wave for Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964, say they are guarding against complacency with a vast get-out-the-vote drive following major gains in registration earlier this year.
To that, the Clinton campaign is hoping to add a victory in Pennsylvania, with 23 electoral votes, and an unusually strong showing in New England. But a poll in Friday's Hartford Courant showed a jump in support for Mr. Perot and suggested a narrowing lead for Mr. Clinton. Republicans there said they now believed that Mr. Bush could win the state, although the chairman of the Democratic Party, Edward L. Marcus, said he still expected a double-digit win for Mr. Clinton.
New Jersey, which has not voted Democratic in a Presidential race since 1964, has become a major battleground as one of the belt of industrial states that the Bush forces consider critical. Mr. Bush campaigned hard there this week, declaring: "Something is happening. We're moving up on this guy."
A new poll conducted by the Eagleton Institute, to be published Sunday in The Star-Ledger of Newark, showed Mr. Clinton at 44 percent, Mr. Bush at 31 percent, and Mr. Perot at 17 percent of the likely voters. But the poll, which had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points, also showed Mr. Perot cutting into Mr. Clinton's lead as the week went on.
 
 
 
HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Tuesday through Friday with 1,854 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, of whom 1,467 said they were registered voters.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus providing access to both listed and unlisted numbers. In each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
Some findings related to voting are reported in terms of an overall "probable electorate," which uses responses to questions dealing with voter registration, past voting history and the likelihood of voting in 1992 as a measure of the probability of particular respondents' voting in November.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adults in the country.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for results based on registered black voters, it is plus or minus ten percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.

HEADLINE: Blacks Say G.O.P. Ballot Challenges Are Tactic to Harass Minority Voters

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HELENA, Ark.

 BODY:
A two-year Federal investigation that will culminate in a trial on the eve of Election Day is likely to have greater impact on voter turnout in this small Mississippi River delta town than the Presidential debates or any last-minute blitzes of campaign advertising.
The case involves accusations that several black candidates and their campaign workers forged signatures and falsified absentee ballots in the 1990 elections. But black politicians find both the timing and the charges suspicious, and they maintain that local Republican officials pushed for the investigation and subsequent indictments hoping to discourage blacks from participating in politics. 
 Democrats and some experts on minority voting say that local ballot challenges like these appear to be emerging as a nationwide Republican strategy of harassing minority voters.
 
Teacher's Aide Indicted
 The 1990 elections saw greatly increased levels of minority voter participation here, in large part because a Federal court had recently settled a Voting Rights Act lawsuit by creating 10 black-majority state legislative districts.
Among those charged by Federal prosecutors is Brenda Sue Steele, a 26-year-old political novice and teacher's aide in the local school district who worked as a campaign volunteer for her cousin, a candidate for the State Legislature.
Ms. Steele and another volunteer, Regener Levon Boards, have pleaded not guilty to six counts of forgery and conspiracy. If convicted, each faces up to 10 years in prison.
Their trial, scheduled to begin Nov. 2, will be the second in three months involving alleged voter fraud in this city of 6,000 residents. In a mixed verdict last month, two other black Helena residents were acquitted of 18 counts of vote fraud but were found guilty of conspiring to commit vote fraud.
 
Widespread Interrogations
 Both cases have touched many lives in this small community. Dozens of people have been interrogated over the last year by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents, and many black leaders fear that all the questioning has had a chilling effect on poor, often illiterate black voters.
"We had people who refused to sign petitions for black candidates to get on the ballot this time around because of these charges from two years ago," said Linda Whitfield, who worked with black candidates in 1990 and is running for circuit court clerk this year. "They have the impression that we led them to do something illegal, and that's going to hurt turnout."
Ms. Whitfield and others assert that a chilling effect was precisely what Arkansas Republicans had in mind when they pushed for the investigations and for prosecutions by the United States Justice Department after state prosecutors and the United States Attorney for Eastern Arkansas had found insufficient evidence to prosecute.
 
Aura of Criminality
 State Representative Jimmie Wilson, who is black, said the indictments had unfairly cloaked legitimate political activism, especially efforts to promote absentee voting, in an aura of criminality.
The Arkansas prosecutions and the suspicions voiced by local black organizations here echo cases in Alabama, Louisiana, New Jersey, North Carolina and Texas in which Republican Party officials challenged ballots and voter drives between 1982 and 1992, almost always in areas with large minority populations.
In New Jersey and North Carolina, Democrats counterattacked in court, obtaining consent decrees in which judges admonished the Republicans to refrain from ballot challenges "where the racial or ethnic composition of such districts is a factor."
Dean St. Dennis, a spokesman for the the Public Integrity Section of the Justice Department, which is prosecuting the cases here, denied any political or racial motivation. Most of the prosecution witnesses are black voters who contend that they were defrauded of their ballots, Mr. St. Dennis said. He also noted that among those indicted were workers for a Republican candidate. That candidate, however, was Ms. Steele's cousin, Arnell Willis, a maverick black candidate who had neither the support nor the endorsement of the Republican party.
 
More Candidates, More Scrutiny
 Dayna Cunningham, a lawyer with the NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund, said that in many ways the 1990 elections from which the charges arose marked the beginning of a change in the electoral problems that had plagued rural Eastern Arkansas.
The Federal court's creation of 10 new black-majority state legislative districts buoyed blacks in the city, which is nearly 70 percent black, and in surrounding Phillips County, which is 55 percent black. Republicans and Democrats alike set out to sign up black absentee voters, in many cases using tactics that were legal and that had proved successful with white voters in the past.
Groups of volunteers first identified likely absentee voters, then solicited their support and helped them request absentee ballots. In many cases they had the voters request that their ballots be sent to a central location where campaign workers received them.
The campaign workers delivered the ballots to the absentee voters, made sure the forms accompanying the sealed ballot were properly dated and signed, then delivered the ballots to the county clerk.
Under Arkansas law, all these practices are legal. In the 1990 race they were employed by Helena's white and black candidates alike, resulting in 1,436 absentee ballot requests, nearly double the usual number among Phillips County's nearly 15,000 registered voters.
Ms. Whitfield's group collected 307 absentee ballots, while Ms. Steele's group collected about 60. But the indictments accuse Ms. Steele and Mr. Boards of forging voter signatures and illegally casting ballots.
Mr. St. Dennis said the case had come to the unit's attention after F.B.I. agents in Little Rock passed on news reports of complaints about alleged absentee ballot fraud.
Asa Hutchinson, chairman of the Arkansas Republican Party, acknowledged that many of the complaints had come from state Republican officials who had sent poll watchers into Helena in response to concerns from local Republicans. Mr. St. Dennis said that by the time the case went to trial in September, the investigation had produced 16 witnesses who said they had been defrauded of their absentee votes. Fifteen were black.
"I had no reason to request an absentee ballot, and I went to the polls that day to vote," said said one of the witnesses, 32-year-old Alberta Robinson, who was allowed to vote even though the records indicated that she had requested an absentee ballot. "My name was just forged on all of that. That's all I know."
Defense lawyers do not dispute those and similar claims by other witnesses, but they maintain that their clients were not the ones who committed the fraud.
Many elderly Helena residents said they had benefited from absentee voter drives.
 
Emerging Tactic Nationwide
 For example, 83-year-old Irene Jackson, who suffers from arthritis and high blood pressure and is confined to her home, said that when the volunteers arrive, "I just do what I'm supposed to do, and if there is someone I really want to vote for, I mark it."
"If I don't know about a candidate I ask them questions," she went on. "And I usually ask them who they like, and they tell me. But they always say vote for whoever you want to, and they don't pressure me at all."
Whatever the merits of the charges, it is clear that Republicans have adopted a tactic of alleging vote fraud in black areas, on the presumption that high minority voter turnout will overwhelmingly benefit Democrats, said David Bositis, a senior researcher with the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington-based research center that specializes in black political issues.
"The Republicans have a tremendous incentive to go after cases in these areas and in areas like the one in Arkansas," Mr. Bositis said. "There is no down side for them, because they don't anger their potential supporters if they win a conviction. And they have the effect of depressing turnout even if there isn't a conviction."
Those sentiments were echoed by Mary Lee Orr, who is white and the chairman of the local Democratic Party in Longview, Tex., where scores of black residents were interrogated by the F.B.I. after Republican ballot challenges in 1990.
Although no indictments resulted, she said, "Black voter turnout was way down in the primaries last spring, and many black people told us that they wouldn't ever vote again because they didn't want to be harassed like they were in 1990."
