HEADLINE: Pentagon Objected to Bush's Message to Iraq

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Days before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, senior Pentagon officials sought to block a message from President Bush to Saddam Hussein they feared was so weakly worded that it would send a signal that the United States was not determined to stand up to Iraqi aggression.
The previously undisclosed dispute in late July 1990 within the Bush Administration about how to deal with the Iraqi leader occurred as Mr. Hussein's troops massed on the Kuwaiti border. 
 Although the Pentagon's effort to draft a sterner message did not succeed, senior Administration officials later became concerned that their diplomacy had not worked and on the eve of the invasion discussed sending a second, stronger Presidential statement to President Hussein. Before they could so do, Iraq had launched its attack on Aug. 2.
The disclosures bear on the election-year debate over whether the Bush Administration did all it could to deter the Iraqis from invading Kuwait.
The Administration's policy toward Iraq had been based on a directive issued by President Bush in October 1989, to use economic and political incentives to moderate Mr. Hussein's behavior. The extent of the Administration's conciliatory approach emerged only after the war, leading to accusations that the war might have been avoided had Mr. Bush pursued a tougher approach.
Mr. Bush, who has portrayed himself as the candidate best capable of dealing with international crises, has vigorously defended his diplomacy, saying that his aim was to "bring Saddam Hussein into the family of nations.
But a reconstruction of events in the weeks leading up to Iraq's invasion, based on interviews with former and current administration officials, shows that some senior Administration officials had grave reservations at the time about the White House's diplomatic efforts, believing they failed to take seriously Mr. Hussein's threats and to respond effectively.
"We were already seeing troops moving," said Henry S. Rowen, who was then Assistant Defense Secretary for International Security Affairs. "We were getting worried, and we were putting up this piece of pap. It was just very weak. We should have been much more threatening."
Mr. Rowen is now a professor at the Stanford University Graduate School of Business and a senior fellow at the Hoover Institution.
Bluntly describing American diplomacy toward Baghdad as "a substantial policy and intelligence failure," Mr. Rowen, a Republican, said in an interview that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait might have been averted had Washington taken a tougher line.
 
Assuring Messages And 'Reservations'
 A senior White House official disputed Mr. Rowen's analysis, arguing that Mr. Bush's message followed Iraqi statements that Baghdad was interested in negotiating a settlement of its disputes with the Kuwaitis. The official said the communication was consistent with advice that Washington was receiving from its Arab allies.
"We were being told by Mubarak and by King Hussein, 'Hey, don't worry about it,' " the senior White House official said, referring to President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Hussein of Jordan. He said they advised that "it is a tempest in a teapot, that all Saddam was trying to do was achieve leadership in the Arab world."
But senior Pentagon officials, including Paul D. Wolfowitz, Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, reportedly shared Mr. Rowen's concerns. Mr. Rowen instructed Arthur G. Hughes, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Near East and South Asian Affairs, to request that the transmittal of the Presidential message be delayed so that the Pentagon could propose a sterner warning, Mr. Rowen said.
Mr. Hughes made the request to a senior aide to John H. Kelly, Assistant Secretary of State for Near East Affairs. The Pentagon believed that it blocked the message, Mr. Rowen said. But the next day, Pentagon officials were informed by the White House that the original message had been sent.
A spokesman for the State Department confirmed that Defense Department officials expressed "reservations" about the Presidential communication to the State Department's Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs. But heasserted that "by the time we learned of their views it was too late."
 
Iraq's Buildup And U.S. Response
 Leading up to Mr. Bush's message was increasingly bellicose behavior by Iraq, which crossed a new threshold in mid-July 1990 with a letter from Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to the Arab League. The letter asserted that Kuwait's refusal to yield on disputes over the border, oil production and pricing policy and Iraq's multibillion-dollar debt to Kuwait, was tantamount to military aggression. On July 17, Mr. Hussein warned in a speech that Baghdad was prepared to use military force to attain its objectives.
The first American complaint about Iraqi threats came not from the President or the Secretary of State, but from a mid-level State Department official, David Mack, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs. He used a regularly scheduled luncheon with Iraq's Ambassador to Washington to express American concern.
Later that day, Mr. Mack drafted a cable for Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to send to American embassies in the Middle East, recounting the exchange. The cable, transmitted that day, instructed American diplomats in Baghdad to press for a clarification of Iraq's intentions toward Kuwait.
During that period, American intelligence noted that Iraqi troops were taking up positions near the Kuwaiti border and that the buildup was continuing. Despite Baghdad's threats, only the United Arab Emirates, which Iraq had also threatened because it was exceeding OPEC's oil-production quotas, asked for American assistance: the dispatch of two American KC-135 refueling planes. No additional military steps were taken.
 
Glaspie and Hussein: Gauging Intentions
 As the Administration's concerns grew, Mr. Baker sent a July 24 cable instructing April C. Glaspie, the American Ambassador in Baghdad, and American ambassadors in other Arab capitals, to reiterate the Bush Administration's views.
Mr. Baker's cable said, "While we take no position on the border delineation raised by Iraq with respect to Kuwait, or on other bilateral disputes, Iraqi statements suggest an intention to resolve outstanding disagreements by the use of force, an approach which is contrary to U.N. charter principles."
After conveying that message to Iraqi officials, Ms. Glaspie was summoned to an impromptu noon meeting on July 25 with Saddam Hussein. According to her diplomatic cables on the meeting, which has been characterized in published accounts but not declassified, Ms. Glaspie said in reference to the Iraqi troops on Kuwait's border: "Is it not reasonable for us to ask, in the spirit of friendship, not confrontation, the simple question: What are your intentions?"
The Iraqi leader said it was a reasonable question but complained that Iraq was in such difficult financial condition that pensions for widows and orphans would have to be cut. He also told her that he had agreed to negotiate with the Kuwaitis on their disputes.
After the meeting, Ms. Glaspie cabled that the Iraqi leader had said "some circles of the U.S.G. continue to work to undermine his Government and his policies" but described Mr. Baker and Mr. Bush as "fine and honorable men," then asked Ms. Glaspie to explain Iraq's concerns to the President, she related in her cable.
Then, Ms. Glaspie wrote: "Saddam, who in the memory of the current diplomatic corps, has never summoned an ambassador, is worried. He does not want to further antagonize us. With the U.A.E. maneuvers, we have fully caught his attention, and that is good. I believe we would now be well-advised to ease off on public criticism of Iraq until we see how the negotiations develop."
 
Split in Washington On Message's Tone
 Mr. Bush's message was drafted in response to Mr. Hussein's statements. Middle East specialists at the National Security Council and State Department were primarily responsible for drafting the message, which was to be sent in Mr. Bush's name. But there were disagreements among the council staff, State Department officials and Defense Department officials.
The National Security Council and State specialists on the Middle East gave credence to Iraq's statements that it was interested in negotiating a resolution of its differences with Kuwait. Further, officials were making the assumption that the Arab states in the region who were playing down the Iraqi threat were in a better position to discern Iraq's intentions.
"For the first time, Saddam was showing a little bit of conciliation," said Sandra Charles, a National Security Council specialist on the Middle East, who is now a private consultant. "You do not go back and say: 'We will believe that when we see it. You better negotiate or we will blow you off the face of the earth.' "
But civilian Pentagon officials favored taking a harder line. They thought Ms. Glaspie had come off weak in her meeting with Mr. Hussein.
"We objected to the language," Mr. Rowen said.
The Presidential response that was drafted was only three paragraphs long. It read:
"I was pleased to learn of the agreement between Iraq and Kuwait to begin negotiations in Jedda to find a peaceful solution to the current tensions between you. The United States and Iraq both have a strong interest in preserving the peace and stability of the Middle East. For this reason, we believe that differences are best resolved by peaceful means and not by threats involving military force or conflict.
"I also welcome your statement that Iraq desires friendship, rather than confrontation with the United States. Let me reassure you, as my Ambassador, Senator Dole and others have done, that my Administration continues to desire better relations with Iraq. We will also continue to support our other friends in the region with whom we have had longstanding ties. We see no necessary inconsistency between these two objectives.
"As you know, we still have fundamental concerns about certain Iraqi policies and activities, and we will continue to raise these concerns with you in a spirit of friendship and candor, as we have in the past both to gain a better understanding of your interests and intentions and to ensure that you understand our concerns. I completely agree that both our Governments must maintain open channels of communication to avoid misunderstanding and in order to build a more durable foundation for improving our relations."
Then Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, who was overseeing the State Department while Mr. Baker was in the Soviet Union, instructed Ms. Glaspie in a cable to deliver the message orally before she departed Iraq for consultations and then home leave on July 30. If that could not be done, she was to deliver its main points in a "non-paper," a unofficial diplomatic communication.
On Aug. 1, 1990, Robert M. Kimmitt, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, convened a meeting of top officials. The officials were nervous. The Iraqis had broken off negotiation with the Kuwaitis in Jedda. The Iraqi buildup had continued and exceeded 100,000 troops, far more than Iraq would need for mere intimidation.
The officials recommended that a second, stronger Presidential message be considered. Richard N. Haass, the top Middle East deputy on the National Security Council, was to meet with Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, to discuss its contents.
But before that could be done, the officials learned that Iraqi forces had invaded Kuwait.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Attacks News Media, And Crowds Cheer Him On

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAFAYETTE, La., Oct. 24

 BODY:
President Bush regaled crowds in two states today with his standard attacks on Bill Clinton's credibility and tax proposals, but the day's best red-meat lines had nothing to do with the Arkansas governor. What roused the crowds -- what rouses many Bush crowds lately -- were Presidential jabs at the press.
"Annoy the media," Mr. Bush cried with evident delight at a Montgomery, Ala., rally this morning that drew 10,000. He had spotted a banner sporting that slogan with the tag line "Re-elect Bush," prompting him to add, "They wouldn't know good news if it hit them in the face." 
 Later, at a rally of 1,700 backers in a high-school gym here, Mr. Bush did not hesitate when a young journalism student asked him for advice. "Be objective," he shot back.
Both remarks drew roars of approval, as have similar barbs in recent Bush speeches. But as his effort to overtake Mr. Clinton nears its final week, they have become more than just applause lines.
With some opinion polls now suggesting that Mr. Bush's attacks are shaking voter confidence in Mr. Clinton, the campaign is tackling an even tougher task: telling voters why they should back Mr. Bush instead.
 
Getting Message Past Media
 The White House argues that the news media are not allowing that argument to reach the public, and Mr. Bush added a new paragraph to his stump speech today to make that point.
"Have you heard this on television at night?" he asked at the Montgomery rally. "That unemployment claims have gone down to the lowest in two years? Have you heard that inflation is down, that interest rates are down, that total employment is 93 percent, inflation 2.5 to 3 percent, home mortgages are 8 percent?"
After the speech, Torie Clarke, the campaign spokeswoman, said: "We have to spend a lot of time from now on on the goals and objectives of a second term. Here are the No. 1 issues: jobs and the economy. Here's what George Bush would do; here's what Bill Clinton would do; you make the choice."
That argument is coupled with two new commercials that began appearing on television this week. The advertisements tout Mr. Bush's second-term economic agenda, his record on life-and-death issues of war and peace, and the value of experience in a President.
 
Ads Follow Attacks
 The ads follow weeks of televised attacks on Mr. Clinton's economic proposals and his trustworthiness. The campaign has not pressed the case for Mr. Bush's foreign accomplishments, the highlight of his first term, since the primaries last spring.
These days, Mr. Bush often closes his speech with a reminder that the cold war ended on his watch and a vow that he will spend a second term pressing for the same kinds of earth-shaking changes at home.
"People say, 'Well, why do you want to do this?' " he said today in Montgomery. " 'It's ugly out there. You're getting clobbered by the national media over and over again. Can't be any fun.' The answer is, something transcends your own personal well-being. And what transcends it for me is, we have literally changed the world."
Now, he added, "What I want to do through the programs I've touched on today is make life better and more challenging by creating more opportunity, in employment and education, for every young person here today."
 
Signs Energy Bill
 Later, in the southwest Louisiana hamlet of Maurice, Mr. Bush visited a gas drilling rig to sign energy-policy legislation that aides said would create 45,000 new jobs in 1993 alone.
The President briefly shelved the campaign rhetoric to praise two Democrats, Senator J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana and Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, for their work on the bill.
"It's not a Republican accomplishment or a Democratic accomplishment; it's an accomplishment for all America," Mr. Bush said, adding of Senator Johnston: "I wish the guy would see the light on the rest of the things."
The energy bill is a grab bag of incentives to explore for oil and gas, conserve energy and promote alternative power sources like methane and wind. But potentially the most sweeping measure, Bush aides said, would overhaul utility laws to force competition in the generating and selling of power.
That clause should cut the cost of electricity by $250 billion in the next 15 years, or about $750 per household, the White House said. A second important clause revises tax laws to encourage drilling for oil and gas, increasing production by the equivalent of 50,000 barrels of oil a day by 2000.
 
On the Offensive
 In recent days, as more television and print accounts have publicly suggested that Mr. Bush has little hope of staging a comeback, Ms. Clarke and other Bush aides have begun to take the offense, arguing against accepting the conventional wisdom and sometimes bluntly criticizing news accounts they believe are erroneous or biased.
Even the President's wife, Barbara, pressed the point in a Friday night appearance on the CNN program "Larry King Live." The news media, she said have "knocked us for a year."
"The day after the convention," she said, "The New York Times had -- 7 out of the 10 stories were negative about George. I mean, the day -- I find that hard to believe."
Today, Ms. Clarke said that a new CBS-New York Times poll, which shows that the gap between Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton has narrowed to about 5 percentage points, reflects the campaign's own conviction that the race is getting closer.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
For TV, Perot Spends Heavily on Wart Removal

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 24

 BODY:
The top-of-the-line makeover at the Neiman Marcus beauty salon in Dallas does not come cheap -- $200 for the full treatment, including haircut, facial, manicure and massage.
But that is loose change compared with the nearly $1.1 million that Ross Perot has spent in the last week to make over his political image. While remaining out of sight since Monday night's final debate, Mr. Perot has focused his television advertising campaign not on the economic issues he maintains are so vital but on a careful portrayal of his character and life story. 
 In the second round of his blitz of half-hour television appearances, Mr. Perot has thrown away his charts and graphs. Viewers have instead seen the aw-shucks billionaire providing sentimental reminiscences of his childhood and his heroics. As in most autobiographies, there are some omissions, including the accounts of investigations and autocratic business dealings that so angered Mr. Perot in the first phase of his campaign.
"What I am and what I'm being portrayed as is two different things," Mr. Perot said on the "Today" program on NBC several weeks ago. "I'll put my character up against anybody's if anybody will ever take an honest look at it."
 
Friendly Interviewing
 Because he apparently believes nobody will do so, Mr. Perot paid the networks more than $1 million to broadcast four half-hour programs about himself in the last eight days. The first two consisted of the kind of interview candidates dream of: one conducted by his own media consultant. On Friday night, members of Mr. Perot's family provided 30 minutes worth of testimonials. In tonight's installment, on CBS before the World Series, viewers saw "The Ross Perot Nobody Knows," a compilation of Mr. Perot's once anonymous acts of charity for soldiers from the Persian Gulf war, Dallas police officers, neighbors and employees.
Mr. Perot has spent another $940,000 for an hour on ABC on Monday night, but aides have not said how it will be used. He spent a stunning total of $23.6 million on advertising in the first two weeks of October and has said he will spend $60 million of his own money on his campaign. He may well spend more.
Mr. Perot's televised autobiography, which dwells heavily on his attendance at the United States Naval Academy and his service in the Navy, omitted any mention of his efforts to cut short his military service. While he spoke at length about the familial "three musketeers" spirit he engendered at his computer company, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, he did not discuss the company's policy against facial hair and its preference for married employees.
He did not address the heavy use of lobbying and hardball political tactics to win the government contracts that made the company a success. Nor did he mention his history of hiring private detectives to investigate business rivals, political figures and his own campaign volunteers.
 
Wall Street Left Out
 While Mr. Perot talked at length about the formation of E.D.S., he neglected to describe the end of his association with the company after it had been acquired by General Motors. Unable to influence the operation of the automobile giant to his satisfaction, Mr. Perot sold his shares for $700 million and walked away.
He also did not discuss his failed foray into Wall Street when a brokerage house he took over went bust.
If there is a recurring theme running through Mr. Perot's self-portrayals, it is the depiction of a self-effacing man who is unaffected by his vast wealth. Scattered throughout Friday night's segment were anecdotes about the 25-cent allowances given to his children and the Saturdays he spent mowing the lawn.
"To us it was a very normal American household," Mr. Perot's son, Ross Perot Jr., said.
For all of Mr. Perot's assertions that what separates him from President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton is his willingness to deal forthrightly with the country's problems, his economic proposals have received little mention in the advertising barrage.
Thus far, Mr. Perot has used only one of his seven purchases of large segments of television time to prescribe the bitter medicine he says is needed to reduce the Federal budget deficit. His plan includes tax increases on gasoline, reductions in an array of usually sacrosanct benefit programs, and across-the-board cuts in Government spending.
 
Usual Campaigning
 Those proposals also are not mentioned in the 60-second advertisements Mr. Perot has produced. Accompanied by images of rolling storm clouds or a pulsing electrocardiogram, these commercials create a sense of urgency about problems that Washington has ignored. But they do not deal with Mr. Perot's proposed solutions, arguing only that "it's time for a candidate who will get down to business."
His aides said today that they did not know whether Mr. Perot would speak in detail about his economic policies when he finally leaves the television studio to campaign on Sunday in Flemington, N.J., and Pittsburgh. He is scheduled to speak at the Flemington Fairgrounds at 1:30 P.M. and at Pittsburgh's David Lawrence Convention Center at 4:30 P.M. Other than rallies and news conferences after the three Presidential debates, the Sunday appearances will be Mr. Perot's first public events since he re-entered the race on Oct. 1.
To some observers, the Perot advertising strategy reinforces a view that he rejoined the race largely to rehabilitate his image. In the first phase of his campaign, Mr. Perot's reputation as a crafty businessman and can-do patriot was transformed in a few months. News reports began portraying a darker force and finally, at the end, Newsweek on its cover labeled him "The Quitter."
"It confirms the view of some people that this guy is on the biggest ego trip since Geraldo Rivera opened up Al Capone's vault," said Darrell West, a Brown University political scientist who studies campaign advertising. "It's all him. When he's asked about the issues, he waves a copy of his book and says, 'Buy this.' "
 
Controlling Message
 But other political scientists said the strategy shows that the man who prides himself on his unconventional candidacy understands the conventions of politics quite well. Few successful candidates, after all, publicize positions that might cost them votes, like raising gasoline taxes by 50 cents a gallon over five years.
By controlling his message and limiting his access to the media, the experts said, Mr. Perot has eliminated the potential for gaffes like his earlier reference to a meeting of blacks as "you people." By not engaging his opponents, he has manufactured an image of seriousness and statesmanship. By not campaigning, he has insured that most news reports of him will be about his advertising, allowing him, like the Wizard of Oz, to portray himself as he wishes.
"One thing that he has done very skillfully is take those info-mercials and turned them into news," said Daniel B. Payne, a Democratic media consultant in Boston. "He's getting a very tightly controlled message out there. Bush and Clinton are out on the trail and they don't have much control over the bites on the news."
Mr. Perot has no plans to join them, although he is scheduled to appear on Thursday night in one of his friendly environments, Larry King's television studio.
Because he is financing his own campaign, Mr. Perot does not have to worry about about the $65 million Federal spending limit imposed on Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton. And because the success of his campaign does not depend on victory, he has said he is not particularly obsessed with winning.
"He's playing for the future, making himself a force to be reckoned with by both parties," said Mr. Payne. "And he's becoming at least a very loud spectator on the sidelines in the next four years."

HEADLINE: Attacks on U.S. Aid Program Alarm Caribbean

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Whether they arrived 100 years ago or in 1980, Dominican economists say, foreign visitors to their country would have found a largely agricultural nation that lived almost entirely from its production of sugar, tobacco and coffee.
But in little more than a decade, the aggressive promotion of light assembly industries, strongly aided by American programs known as the Caribbean Basin Initiative, has completely changed the country's landscape, making manufacturing the largest sector of the economy. 
 Although the extent of the transformation varies, similar economic changes have been wrought throughout the region. For many countries, the United States initiative has been crucial in helping open American markets to their new industrial goods.
But governments in the region are growing nervous as criticism of the United States' efforts to foster industrial development and encourage trade with its poorer neighbors is voiced in the American Presidential campaign.
Everywhere in the Caribbean and Central America, governments have begun expressing concern that support for a longtime goal of United States foreign policy, fostering export-led growth, may be coming to an end.
While the domestic debate has focused on what Senator Al Gore called "using our tax dollars to subsidize the recruitment of U.S. companies to move overseas," leaders throughout the region have reacted with alarm to attacks on an arrangement they see as mutually beneficial.
"The Dominican Republic is probably the country that has benefited most, after the U.S., from C.B.I.," said Bernardo Vega, a former central bank director and economist in the Dominican Republic, where 142,000 people out of a population of nearly seven million are working in recently created assembly jobs. "If this kind of relationship were to end, it would completely destabilize our country."
For Mr. Vega, like many of his counterparts elsewhere in the region, the Caribbean Basin Initiative has been a mutual success because it has fostered growth in his country while allowing American producers of goods like textiles, shoes and simple electronics components to remain competitive with rivals in the Far East.
Under the initiative, formally introduced by the Reagan Administration in 1983, goods assembled in the region from American-made materials or parts, like cloth or electrical equipment, can be reimported into the United States under preferential tariffs.
Critics, among them Senator Gore, the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, and some American labor leaders, have said that the program causes the loss of jobs in the United States to low-wage competitors by providing technical support in setting up and marketing industrial parks abroad.
Officials in the Caribbean and Central America, however, contend that the United States trade surplus with the region has expanded since the Caribbean Basin Initiative began and that such criticisms disregard other benefits to the United States as well.
"Eighty percent of the textiles we produce in Jamaica are made from American cloth and thread," said Richard L. Bernal, Jamaica's Ambassador to Washington. "If we were to close down, the United States would still be importing similar goods from Asian producers, but they would have no American content at all."
In Central America, where long and costly civil wars recently ended, officials say they see a political risk for their countries should the United States stop encouraging the creation of new industries or restrict their access to the American market.
Countries like Costa Rica and Honduras have already seen as dramatic a transformation of their economic systems as the Dominican Republic. But others, particularly war-torn El Salvador and Nicaragua, are only now beginning to make a full-fledged push toward developing a new industrial base.
In El Salvador, the Government has projected that 50,000 new jobs will be created in export-oriented assembly industries over the next few years under its development program, which arose from the Caribbean Basin Initiative.

HEADLINE: Little-Remarked Item on Ballot Would Put Constitutional Cap on Spending

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 23

 BODY:
With surprisingly little fanfare, Connecticut residents will vote next month on a idea that has been taking hold across the nation: constitutional restrictions on government spending.
The measure, a Constitutional amendment known as Question 2, is supported by most Connecticut political and business leaders, who say that it will insure greater fiscal responsibility and that it is a necessary accompaniment to the passage last year of the state income tax. 
 "We see this as an indication of the voters' concerns about living within our means in Connecticut," said John Rathgeber, the executive vice president of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association.
 
Weicker's Criticisms
 But Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has criticized such "automatic pilot" spending restrictions as an easy way out for legislators unwilling to make difficult budget decisions. Many town and city officials, already reeling from cuts in state aid, fear that the cap could ultimately mean that the state would pass more costs on to them, forcing property-tax increases. Teachers and other public employees fear that the measure could limit their salaries and harm education and other social services.
"Putting on a blanket cap will intensify competition for dollars between human services, education and aid to cities, and would hurt poorest communities the most," said George Springer, president of the Connecticut Federation of Teachers.
The amendment was put on the ballot after it was passed overwhelmingly by both houses of the State Legislature.
It stipulates that general budget expenditures cannot grow faster than the higher amount of either the increase in the national consumer price index during the previous year or the average of the previous five years of personal income growth in Connecticut before inflation. The cap would exclude spending for debt service, court-ordered or federally mandated programs and aid to 11 cities and towns deemed "distressed municipalities" -- categories that now account for about one-fifth of the state's $8 billion annual budget.
 
11% Spending Growth in 1980's
 The impetus for the amendment was that "the state hasn't been doing the job controlling spending," said Michael Levin, the research director of the Connecticut Policy and Economic Council, a nonprofit research group. During the 1980's, the average yearly growth in state spending was almost 11 percent. If the limit had been in effect, growth would have been less in 6 of the 10 years, he said, and also more consistent, instead of soaring in the mid-1980's and being cut back in the early 1990's.
A statutory limit on spending growth, which took effect this year as a prelude to the proposed amendment, restricted the increase in expenditures in the 1993 fiscal year to 7 percent, based on the same formula of personal-income growth.
Even its backers acknowledge that the amendment is anything but ironclad. The legislature could sidestep its restrictions, for example, by "redefining what one means by general budget expenditures" or by declaring emergencies "for a lot of things we don't see as emergencies," Mr. Levin said.
Because the amendment grew out of the state's 1991 budget and tax reform bill, it has broad political support.
"There was a consensus last year that a two-sided approach to fiscal stability was needed," said Miles Rapoport, the assistant majority leader in the House of Representatives and a West Hartford Democrat. However, he added, "There are potential problems with the cap, which we'll need to debate in two or three years, when the cap becomes tougher."
 
Painful Spending Cuts
 The amendment could lead to painful spending cuts, he said, ranging from aid to towns and cities to programs that provide low-cost prescription drugs for the elderly and services for the mentally retarded.
But beyond such political battles is the question of whether the amendment will do more than create an illusion of fiscal responsibility.
In the approximately two dozen states that have enacted spending or tax limits since the late 1970's, the record has been mixed. A 1988 study by the National Association of State Budget Officers found that about half the states with spending caps had reduced spending as a proportion of state income during the 1980's, but that "relative to states without limitations, the differences are minor."
Governor Weicker, who has declined to comment specifically on the Connecticut ballot initiative, opposed the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law when he was in the United State Senate and has testified against a Federal balanced-budget amendment. The reason, said a spokeswoman, Avice Meehan, is that he "believes that elected officials ought to be accountable for the expenditure of taxpayer dollars rather than relying on a mathematical equation."

HEADLINE: Camden Braces for Mischief Night Fires

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMDEN, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Authorities have ordered a dusk-to-dawn curfew and assigned nearly the entire police force to duty on Friday, Oct. 30, hoping to avoid a repeat of last year when the traditional pre-Halloween hijinks of "Mischief Night" escalated into an arson spree.
But some residents and community leaders, wary of the plan's effectiveness, say the effort would be better spent on rehabilitating housing and providing more opportunities in Camden's neighborhoods -- not stricter security measures. 
 A year ago, a Mischief Night rampage that residents recall as "a night from hell" was blamed for more than 120 fires and led to scores of arrests. Most of those arrested were juveniles, but officials said later that it appeared that firebugs or professional arsonists might have taken advantage of the confusion.
"We definitely got a bum rap last year," said Thomas R. Knockhe, a board member of the North Camden Trust, an eight-year-old nonprofit group that rehabilitates abandoned housing. "But regardless of that, you have got to protect the city."
 
Modeled on Detroit's Plan
 The city's strategy for Mischief Night this year, known as the Camden Anti-Arson Plan, was drafted by City Hall, the Police and Fire departments, community leaders and the local prosecutor's office. It is modeled after a plan devised by officials in Detroit, where during the mid-1980's hundreds of fires were set on the annual Devil's Night on Oct. 30.
The plan, outlined by Mayor Aaron A. Thompson about a week ago, encourages youths to celebrate in the daytime or at supervised indoor events during the evening. It also encourages adults to set up neighborhood patrols, especially near abandoned property, to head off problems.
But the city intends to back up those efforts with a curfew from 6 P.M. Oct. 30 to 6 A.M. Oct. 31 for all Camden residents ages 5 to 17 unless they are with a parent or guardian.
The city normally has a 11 P.M. to 6 A.M. weekend curfew for children, and that curfew will resume on Halloween night, officials said.
In addition, virtually the entire 300-member police force has been assigned to patrol on Oct. 30.
 
Debate Over Strategy
 But the planned curfew and the increased police presence have heightened a debate that reaches beyond the Mischief Night strategy and to the direction of this city, the sixth largest in New Jersey.
"I'd rather all this strength and mobilization be channeled toward the rehabilitation of housing which wouldn't leave them vulnerable to being burned," said the Rev. Michael Doyle, an Irish-born priest who has been in Camden for the last 24 years.
With nearly half of its 87,462 residents receiving some sort of public assistance, Camden is the poorest urban area in New Jersey and one of the poorest cities in the nation.
Once a thriving industrial city that was home to shipyards and the Campbell Soup Company, Camden began its economic and social slide in the 1950's as white residents started moving to the suburbs. Between 1950 and 1980, the city lost nearly one-third of its population. Thousands of buildings were left vacant, and the closing of the shipyards and the Campbell plant hastened the slide.
 
From Soup to Fish
 In February, the state opened a $52 million aquarium complex on the Delaware River waterfront that officials hope will be the anchor of a revitalization plan for the city. But even the aquarium became caught up in the debate, with some community leaders criticizing city and state officials for not spending the money on Camden's neighborhoods.
There has been no organized opposition to the curfew plan, but critics argue that it will unfairly penalize the innocent. And Father Doyle worries that it could lead to conflicts.
"Forces are sort of poised against each other," he said. "I think the city might have overdone it."
Camden teachers have been encouraged to discuss Mischief Night, and class assignments for hundreds of schoolchildren last week included essays on last year's violence.
Automobile bumper stickers implore: "Do Camden Right -- Stop the Fires on Mischief Night."
Mr. Knockhe said his organization, North Camden Trust, had organized patrols to oversee abandoned buildings and some recently restored houses, including some renovated since last Halloween, in north Camden, the poorest part of the city and the site of most of last year's fires.
"I'm sure the curfew will be very difficult to enforce," Mr. Knockhe said. "The hard part about it is that it makes it look like young people are the problem. But if the young people aren't on the streets, it will help police concentrate on the adults who are and the professional arsonists and firebugs."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
For Those Not Satisfied With a 3-Man Race

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton and Ross Perot are not the only alternatives to George Bush at the polls this year. Ballots in many states will list an array of would-be presidents, including, for those who don't care, the Apathy Party candidate who promises not to steal for his first two years in office.
The choices also include a psychologist, a professor and an imprisoned felon. Almost two dozen Presidential candidates will appear on various ballots around the country, according to the Federal Election Commission. 
 The common thread, if any, is a desire to challenge "this idea of a two-party system," said Lenora B. Fulani, a New York psychotherapist who heads the New Alliance Party's ticket.
Ms. Fulani, on the ballot in 38 states and the District of Columbia, has raised $5 million for her campaign.
The Libertarian candidate, Andre Marrou, is on ballots in all 50 states and the District of Columbia and Guam -- a fact he cites when complaining about his exclusion from the Presidential debates. "If we could get the coverage you people in the press give to Ross Perot, then I stand a chance," he said.
Lyndon LaRouche, a perennial candidate who is on ballots in 17 states and the District of Columbia, is running his campaign from a Federal prison in Rochester, Minn., where he is serving 15 years for fraud.
"It's a terrible inconvenience," he said Mr. LaRouche, whose ticket is Independents for Economic Recovery.
Jim Boren, the Apathy Party candidate, who is on the ballot in Arkansas, pledges, "I will not steal for the first two years of my administration."
"I'm serious about what I'm trying to do," said Mr. Boren, a political science professor at Northeastern State University in Tahlequah, Okla. "I'm using humor and satire to parody the worst side of politics to try to get people involved."
Because of pending litigation, some candidates may yet be added to some ballots. Here are other candidates, their parties, and the number of states where they are on the ballot:
BRADFORD, Drew -- independent, one state.
BRISBEN, John Quinn -- Socialist Party, three states and District of Columbia.
DANIELS, Ron -- independent, eight states and District of Columbia.
DODGE, Earl F. -- Prohibition Party, three states.
EHLERS, Delbert L. -- independent, one state.
GRITZ, James (Bo) -- independent, 17 states.
HAGELIN, John -- Natural Law Party, 27 states and District of Columbia.
HALYARD, Helen -- Workers League Party, two states.
HEM, Eugene A. -- Third Party, one state.
HERER, Jack -- Grassroots Party, three states.
La RIVA, Gloria Estella -- Workers World Party, one state.
MASTERS, Isabelle -- Looking Back Group, one state.
PHILLIPS, Howard -- Taxpayers Party, 21 states.
SMITH, Robert J. -- American Party, one state.
WARREN, James Mac -- Socialist Workers Party, 13 states and District of Columbia.
YIAMOUYIANNIS, John -- independent, four states.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Pulse -- Illinois;
Bush's Chances Appear Less Than Slim in Illinois

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Illinois usually stays up late on Presidential election nights.
The count was close in this bellwether state in 1948, when it went for Harry S. Truman in the wee hours, and in 1960, when it gave John F. Kennedy the barest of majorities. It was close in three of the last four Presidential races. But not this year. Not unless a sudden shift from Gov. Bill Clinton toward Ross Perot, reported late this week by senior officials of both major parties, becomes a stampede. 
 "Clinton started strong and has stayed strong for a long time here," said Bill Daley, a Chicago banker who heads the Illinois Clinton-Gore campaign and who is the brother of Mayor Richard M. Daley. "City, small towns, suburbs, upstate, downstate, right across the board. But we're all a bit nervous about Perot these last few days, I'll tell you."
 
Bush Disappoints Republicans
 Republicans have been crushingly disappointed by President Bush's failure to take take strong measures to arrest his slide.
Representative Henry J. Hyde, a conservative from the Chicago suburbs with a flair for the dramatic, suggested to President Bush's counsel, C. Boyden Gray, that Mr. Bush carry a pocket calculator onto the set at one of the television debates, tally the cost of Mr. Clinton's proposed new programs and hand it to the Democratic nominee with the comment, "You're the Rhodes scholar, you make the numbers add up."
That suggestion went aglimmering, as did the clamor by other important Illinois Republicans for personnel changes -- replacing Vice President Dan Quayle with Gen. Colin L. Powell, for instance, or naming Jeanne J. Kirkpatrick to succeed James A. Baker 3d at the State Department -- to symbolize a fresh start by the Administration.
Newton N. Minow, the onetime chairman of the Federal Communications Commission who now teaches at Northwestern University and who heads the Annenberg Washington project on the news media, said that jamming all the debates into a short period "made it into a mini-series, attracted more attention and heightened the impact."
"I think there's a lot more interest in Perot than before, a lot less dismissing of him for having pulled out," Mr. Minow said. "The question is whether people will actually go for him in the booth, or whether they'll ultimately decide that's a wasted vote."
 
Big Gap in Poll
 In The Chicago Tribune's latest poll, published today but completed last Monday afternoon, before the final debate began, Mr. Clinton led President Bush by almost a 2-to-1 ratio, 47 percent to 25 percent, with Mr. Perot at 10 percent and 18 percent undecided. More than 1,000 voters were interviewed for the survey, and it had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus about three percentage points.
Republicans like Mike Lawrence, Gov. Jim Edgar's press secretary, readily acknowledge that Mr. Bush is well behind. The Governor, a moderate Republican, has campaigned staunchly for the President, and he "still thinks the state could be turned around," Mr. Lawrence said. Asked how good the chances of that happening were, Mr. Lawrence replied that he would rather not put words in the mouth of the Governor, who is resting briefly in Arizona from minor surgery.
Another top Republican, retreating behind the cloak of anonymity, said there was "no way in the world" for Mr. Bush to win here. He predicted the President would lose the state by at least 500,000 votes.
How did such a situation come to pass in a state like this? How has the campaign looked through experienced political eyes here?
Well, for one thing, Illinois has been trending Democratic lately, as first the downstate farmers and then the small-city manufacturers, like Caterpillar in Peoria, have faced hard times. Mr. Bush beat Michael S. Dukakis by only 95,000 votes in 1988, and since then things have got worse for the President.
 
A Stronger Democrat
 The Democratic nominee is stronger this time. Senator Paul Simon, who sought the Democratic Presidential nomination himself four years ago, paused at a farmhouse near Champaign yesterday to make that point. In 1988, he said, "we had an able guy who didn't like campaigning, but Bill Clinton enjoys mixing with people, and that comes across on television."
"The image is one of warmth," the Senator added. "Here's a man who really identifies with the ordinary guy who's in trouble."
There are lots of those now, even in Chicago, whose glistening Michigan Avenue skyscrapers bear witness to the city's status as one of the nation's big urban success stories of the last quarter-century. The city's employment rolls have grown, but the manufacturing sector, with its high-priced jobs, accounts for only 20 percent of the total, down from 30 percent a few years ago. New service jobs pay much less.
Mr. Bush has found it almost impossible to relate to voters who are apprehensive about their economic future, in the judgment of Chicagoans favorably disposed to the President and to his re-election.
 
'Going to Lose Badly'
 Jack Fuller, the editor of the Tribune, whose editorial page has endorsed Mr. Bush, said he was "convinced that history is going to judge the Bush Administration a success, on balance." But the President, Mr. Fuller asserted, "hasn't got the slightest talent for talking to ordinary people about their anxieties, and as a result his reputation has collapsed here, people are angry, and he's going to lose badly."
Illinois has not been as hard-hit as many other states by the recession of 1992. Mr. Lawrence, Governor Edgar's aide, says that "it's not a statistical issue this time, but an anecdotal issue."
"Among white-collar workers, whatever the numbers show," he said, "everyone knows someone who's been laid off or is on the verge of it. People in their 50's like me thought that with a college degree you had no worries. That was wrong, and these white-collar workers, mostly Republicans, tend to scream when they're hurt."
Beginning with his speech at the Republican convention in Houston, Mr. Edgar has tried to address the apprehensions of such people. With the end of the cold war, he said there, striving to link Mr. Bush's foreign-policy triumphs with the domestic agenda, "we have the chance to open a new era of economic growth, an age of expansion for our thousands upon thousands of manufacturing firms."
But others at that convention spoke with what Mr. Fuller, the editor, called "a snarling meanness that turned off lots of people." Carter Hendren, a top Republican legislative aide and electoral strategist, said the convention's concentration on so-called family values had produced "massive slippage among voters under 35."
"The young people are worried about jobs, and about health care, and about how they're going to send their kids to college," Mr. Hendren said. "They're not going to spend very much time worrying about what their neighbor around the corner does in his bedroom."
 
Alienating Some
 Representative Hyde, one of his party's most eloquent voices on Capitol Hill, said that Mr. Bush had disappointed his "anti-tax base" in the state by raising taxes, and had failed to exploit the abortion issue successfully despite his strong anti-abortion stance.
Because "his persona is so bland" and his economic program so weak, Mr. Hyde declared, the President has not scored on abortion as he should have with the Reagan Democrats, the largely Catholic, working-class voters who left their party to back the Californian.
At the same time, traditionally Republican middle-class suburbanites have rebelled against Mr. Bush's position on abortion, with the result that he has severe problems in both the blue-collar and the white-collar suburbs around Chicago, the so-called "collar counties" which any Republican nominee must carry handily to win.
Many older blue-collar voters, switched off by the President but not turned on by Mr. Clinton, seem to be toying with a vote for Mr. Perot, the in-out-in independent candidate. Polls here and elsewhere suggest that he benefited greatly from the TV debates.
Mr. Clinton will certainly benefit from a couple of local political developments. The Democratic party in Chicago is unified for the first time in two decades, with lake front reformers and old-school machine pols, blacks and whites, working together for the ticket, and the campaign of Carol Moseley Braun, bidding to become the first black woman ever to sit in the Senate, could well generate a big black turnout comparable to those for Harold Washington, the mayor who died in 1987.

HEADLINE: Florio's Naming of G.O.P. 'Jobs Czar' Wins Wide Praise in Trenton Truce

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
For the next year or so, he will be one of the most powerful members of Gov. Jim Florio's cabinet, overseeing a billion dollars worth of public and private projects in an effort to bring jobs to New Jersey.
What makes Robert E. Hughey's appointment particularly interesting is that the Democratic Governor has chosen a Republican to try to stimulate economic growth while Republicans and Democrats, locally and nationally, are blaming each other for the depressed state of the economy. 
In fact, three years ago Mr. Hughey was working to keep Mr. Florio out of the Governor's mansion. He was the manager of State Senator William L. Gormley's unsuccessful bid to be Republican candidate for governor.
Mr. Florio went on to win the general election, and Mr. Hughey returned to private life as an investment banker and planning consultant.
 
Instantly, 'the Jobs Czar'
 But this month, Mr. Hughey's career took another turn. Amid considerable bipartisan hoopla, the 49-year-old Mr. Hughey became Mr. Florio's Chief of Economic Recovery, a new, cabinet-level job that instantly became known as "the jobs czar."
In Trenton, where bipartisan cooperation is rare, the appointment was greeted like a coronation. Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, a fervent Republican who rarely praises anything done by the Democratic Governor, joined Mr. Florio at the announcement to say that "both Democrats and Republicans want to get New Jersey moving again and we are willing to do whatever it takes to do it."
"We are here together to show that the good of New Jersey always comes first," Mr. Haytaian said. "This cabinet-level positon will have real power and Bob Hughey will have the tools he needs to get the job done."
And Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, who is also a Republican, said, "I cannot think of any greater priority for this administration than the development of opportunities for business to flourish and jobs to be created."
 
Cutting Through Bickering
 Governor Florio said he hoped Mr. Hughey would use the new post to bring jobs to New Jersey, where the unemployment rate is nudging 10 percent. "We can't afford to tie up a single dollar in delays and red tape, and we can't afford to waste a single minute on political bickering."
In an interview this week, Mr. Hughey described his new role as that of "a super-coordinator," to make sure that all the pieces of job-producing projects, from publicly financed convention centers to private high-tech industry and everything in between, are in place, and if they are not, to put them in place.
The main duty of "the Chief," as Mr. Florio refers to Mr. Hughey, "will be to identify viable job-creating projects, identify resources that can be pooled for economic development, cut red tape for existing or proposed projects, and secure private-sector financing," the Governor's statement said.
How to do that, said Mr. Hughey in the interview just off the Governor's office -- he is still two weeks away from getting an office of his own, or a staff from other agencies -- exists only in outline.
 
'Help Find the Pieces'
 He said: "We are going to meet today, for example, with the state Chamber of Commerce and say what we have already said to the state department heads concerned with public projects, and that is if you have a project under way and if it is close to realization and you have everything in place to build the project, except for one or two things, then bring it to us and tell us about it, and we will help find the pieces."
He is also charged with looking at the projects of state and bistate authorities like the Turnpike Authority, N.J. Transit and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the New Jersey Building Authority, the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority and relatively more recent undertakings like the Urban Development Corporaton and the Urban Enterprise Zone Authority and projects to renew aging water, sewer and other parts of the urban infrastructure.
He will not create new projects, but help existing ones. "New Jersey already has an infrastructure trust program in place, not just for highways, but for water supplies and sewers," he said. "So unlike other states that are just getting under way on this sort of thing, we also have a broadly based funding power." New Jersey's taxes are supplemented by many public authorities that collect tolls, casino revenues and the like.
 
'A One-Year Coordinator'
 "So the next next logical step is how do we make them work together?" he continued. "Really what I am is a one-year coordinator; it is assumed that I will have it done in a year. All the authorities coordinated and the creations of jobs in a one-year period, when we most need them."
As an investment banker who is also an urban planner -- and as head of the New Jersey Environmental Protection Department for four years under Gov. Thomas H. Kean -- Mr. Hughey brings a resume to his job that Mr. Florio says is tailor made to negotiate credit lines for public and private projects and to balance environmental considerations with job creation.
"It is impossible not to be impressed with Bob Hughey," Mr. Florio said in an interview today. "I worked with him on environmental matters when I was in Congress and he has the skills and ablities I wanted, a balanced, no-nonsense ability to put the pieces together. It is the interaction among agencies that is important, cross-cutting across the agencies and the private sector."
But Mr. Florio said that no one should fear that one of his jobs would be to skirt environmental regulations. "Anyone who thinks you have to sacrifice the environment to create jobs is erroneous," he said. "I don't share that belief, and neither does Bob Hughey. No, no one is going to short-circuit environmental regulations. Most people sign onto the proposition that there should be a balance."
 
Jeep and Shirtsleeves
 Mr. Hughey has a reputation for informality -- he drove a Jeep to cabinet meetings at the Governor's mansion when he worked for Mr. Kean and often arrived in shirtsleeves -- as well as for an amiable but often blunt approach to problem solving.
With the New Jersey economy stagnant -- the loss of 330,000 jobs in the last three years has wiped out much of the gains in the '80's -- he says he will use the same approach in his new job, which pays $100,225, a cabinet salary.
There will be few meetings, he said, but a lot of faxes and telephone calls. "If I met with just the principal players, the authority heads and the cabinet officers, if I actually sat down and had a quality meeting with all those people and tried to understand what they were working on, that alone would wipe out a month and a half of this job, and I don't have time to do that, and I'm not going to," he said.
"But what we are going to do with everyone involved is say, 'What's close, what can be done now, and how can we do it?' Initially, people will think I am rude. I mean, I don't want to just have nice meetings."

HEADLINE: Lights to Return Along Rochester's Highways

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Oct. 24

 BODY:
The Monroe County executive thinks that $1.46 million is a small price to pay to lift people's spirits, even in tight-money times, especially if he can light up major roads as part of the bargain.
And so, the county bought the lights along its expressways and plans to turn them on next week, after more than nine months of darkness. 
 It's less a question of safety than of morale, said County Executive Robert L. King, who persuaded the county legislature to approve the purchase deal with Rochester Gas and Electric Company.
"Probably I was more concerned about the notion that the loss of the lights caused us to think of ourselves as a community in decline," he said. "It's hard to put your finger on it, but take someone who comes into this brightly lit new airport we have and then they go into this dark hole of Calcutta."
The lights were darkened except at expressway exits by Mr. King's predecessor, Thomas R. Frey, to save the county about $400,000 annually.
 
A Matter of Economics
 After the lights went out in January, radio talk shows were flooded with complaints from motorists, although the complaints subsided when summer brought more hours of daylight.
Specifically, what the county is buying for its $1.46 million is the fixtures of 5,000 lights -- bulbs, wiring and filament -- that sit atop poles that are owned by the state.
The county had been renting the lights, and paying for the power used, which cost $1.72 million in 1991. With the power turned off, the county will pay $1.32 million this year.
Mr. King insists that the purchase is cost-effective. By buying the lights, which will be paid for through 10-year bonds, the county will qualify for a discounted rate for power, he says. The package, including debt service and maintenance, will cost about $1.3 million annually, he said, meaning that in the short term the lights can be turned on for slightly less than the cost of keeping them off.
Calculating the cost of the lights to the county once the bonds are paid off is difficult because the county will be responsible for maintaining the lights.
Since taking office after defeating Mr. Frey, a Democrat, last fall, Mr. King, a Republican, has said that county faced a $42 million budget gap in a budget of $774 million. He successfully pushed for an increase in the county sales tax of one-half of one percentage point, to 3.5 percent from 3 percent, and he has called for another half-point increase in his 1993 budget.
But in the purchase of the lights, Mr. King says, "We're getting the best of both worlds. It's a win-win situation."
When Mr. Frey's administration decided to turn off the expressway lights, they cited studies that found that motorists actually had fewer accidents because they slowed down on darker roads.
Political opponents of Mr. King have criticized him for pushing through the light purchase before fulfilling the pledge he made when he took office to get more studies of the safety question.
But Mr. King said the real value of the lights was community spirit.
He said the darkened expressways gave the county a poor image, especially when combined with news of financial troubles for the Rochester Orchestra and the possibility that the city might lose its minor league baseball team.

HEADLINE: Very Private Candidate In a Very Public Race

SERIES: Connecticut's Senate campaign: First of two profiles.

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FARMINGTON, Conn.

 BODY:
Brook Johnson, with his jacket off and his gold horse cuff links gleaming, looked back over his shoulder in the car he uses for campaigning and did a cackling imitation of an old woman.
"Johnson wouldn't know -- he's a millionaire," Mr. Johnson crowed in a tone of scorn, mimicking the character in a radio commercial for Senator Christopher J. Dodd. That one ad, more than Mr. Dodd's more conventional attacks on Mr. Johnson's business career or the attacks on Mr. Johnson's motives in running for the Senate, hit home, he said. 
 Mr. Johnson is a millionaire who cringes at the very word. He clearly enjoys the trappings of wealth, from having his own polo mounts to his BMW to his homes in London and Florida. But the image he projects, in private and on the campaign trail as Mr. Dodd's Republican challenger, is less the genteel horse-country aristocrat than the flinty shop-floor scrapper made good, with all the resentments still rattling around inside him.
"Everything I have I earned," Mr. Johnson said in an interview. "And remember where Chris Dodd was. He was in Willimantic with his father, a United States Senator, and my Dad was working on the second shift at the American Thread Company in the same town."
 
Enigmatic Clues
 It is from such small moments that one gets a clue to the spirit and character of Mr. Johnson, who has never before run for public office, or for that matter been involved in politics at all. And clues, for the most part, are about all you get. Even his choice of political heroes offers little help in defining the man who wants to be Connecticut's next senator. They are, in Mr. Johnson's order: Winston Churchill, John F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan.
He climbed the corporate ladder in the rough and tumble world of textile manufacturing, "getting my hands dirty," as he puts it. He enlisted in the Army at the height of the Vietnam War in 1968.
Unknown only six months ago by Republican leaders even in his own hometown of Greenwich, he chose, for his first leap into public life, a statewide run against a two-term Senator from one of Connecticut's most prominent public families. Mr. Dodd's father was Thomas J. Dodd, who served in the Senate from 1959 to 1971.
It is a story that would seem made for politics, and yet Mr. Johnson refuses to discuss some things, like his private business, and dismisses other subjects, like his military service, as irrelevant. In a year in which the Presidential candidates have seemed at times obsessed with Vietnam-era Angst, Mr. Johnson simply waves off his own enlistment, saying "it was a long time ago."
 
Scorning Publicity
 And he has at times seemed as openly scornful of reporters and free publicity as he is of his millionaire image, failing to show up for interviews that might help flesh out his public persona, and meetings with editorial writers who will make recommendations to their readers about whom to vote for. The New Haven Register, for example, endorsed President Bush last Sunday -- presumably indicating fertile ground for a Republican Senate candidate -- but Mr. Johnson snubbed the paper on Monday.
The paper's editorial page editor, Charles P. Kochakian, said a campaign aide called five minutes before the 10:30 A.M. meeting to say Mr. Johnson could not make it. It was the second time, Mr. Kochakian said, that a meeting with Mr. Johnson had fallen through at the last minute.
"I've been covering politics for 20 years and I've never seen anything like it," said Steve Kotchko, news director for the Connecticut Radio Network. "Usually these guys are running to you."
Mr. Kotchko said he twice tried to get Mr. Johnson to appear on a 30-minute interview program that is distributed to more than 20 radio stations around the state. The candidate simply failed to show up the first time; the second time, after Mr. Kotchko said he had spent a day calling the campaign once every hour, an aide said the interview couldn't be arranged. Mr. Kotchko said this week he will have to explain to his listeners what happened, if only to avoid appearing biased because Mr. Dodd has been on the show and Mr. Johnson has not.
If time were on Mr. Johnson's side, such attitudes might be an asset, a sort of take-me-as-I-am anti-politician's bravado. But for a campaign that began from a standing start only six months ago, Mr. Johnson's scheduling troubles and sometimes abrasive manner have turned what would have been a fast-paced ride to Nov. 3 in the best of circumstances into what sometimes seems more like a runaway train.
"It hasn't been bumpy," said Richard Foley Jr., the State Republican Party chairman. "It's been a roller coaster."
 
Starting From Scratch
 Starting from scratch with a candidate not even known in his own party, Mr. Foley said, has required the campaign to build an organization, develop contacts and get Mr. Johnson and his ideas known, all at a full-tilt scramble; not to mention persuading people to vote for him. Mr. Foley said he expects that by Election Day at least 90 percent of voters will at least know who Mr. Johnson is, and that Mr. Johnson will pull off an upset victory and win. Time is the enemy, Mr. Foley said.
Time does not seem to be helping chip away Mr. Dodd's wide lead in the polls. According to a statewide poll by the University of Connecticut's Institute for Social Inquiry released on Friday, Mr. Dodd's lead held steady through the last few weeks. The poll said 51 percent of the 505 registered voters questioned said they planned to vote for Mr. Dodd, compared with 30 percent for Mr. Johnson, and 19 percent undecided. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percentage points. A poll earlier in the month showed Mr. Dodd with a 20-point lead.
But Mr. Johnson, who is 46 years old, said he is used to uphill fights. He grew up struggling, he said, partly because his family did not have a lot of money, and partly because his father apparently thought that struggle produced character. Born in Willimantic, a sagging old industrial town in eastern Connecticut that was once at the heart of the state's now moribund textile industry, he worked his way through college at North Carolina State University, where he graduated with a degree in textile engineering.
After the Army, where he served mostly in Europe, Mr. Johnson went back to school under the G.I. bill at the London School of Economics. His career since then, like his father's, has been entirely in textiles, mostly at Collins & Aikman, a Tennessee-based company where Mr. Johnson rose from sales trainee to division president in 15 years.
 
Unwelcome Questions
 Those are the years Mr. Johnson most likes to talk about, and those are years on which his television commercials are based, that his company, while he worked there, created thousands of manufacturing jobs. What happened after he and other executives bought Mr. Johnson's division and turned it into a private company in 1987 is private and the now-public candidate resents even being asked about it. It would help his competitors, he said.
He also does not like to be asked why, according to voting records in his home town of Greenwich, he showed so little interest in politics until this year, only voting twice in the last 10 elections. The demands of his business kept him out of town a lot, Mr. Johnson has said.
"The business world is one where you operate without public scrutiny on every decision, and where authority flows from the top down," said State Senator William H. Nickerson, a Republican from Greenwich who supports Mr. Johnson. In politics, Mr. Nickerson said, everything works by building consensus and almost every act is public. "I think he's made an extraordinary transition from those two different worlds," Mr. Nickerson said.
What Mr. Johnson does like to talk about is the Federal deficit. In attacking Mr. Dodd, he has said that term limits, a balanced budget amendment, and campaign spending limits intended to curtail the need for special-interest donations would all dovetail to help reduce the nation's $4 trillion debt, which Mr. Johnson argues could be erased entirely in six years.
Mr. Johnson and Mr. Dodd do agree on many issues. Both support abortion rights, although Mr. Johnson believes that parents or guardians of minors should be notified. Both oppose military intervention in the turmoil in central Europe. Both also favor overhauling the nation's legal system to cut down on lawsuits that raise medical malpractice insurance and clog the court system.
Such broad agreement doesn't help voters distinguish between the two men, and so probably only helps the better-known Mr. Dodd. But Mr. Johnson is still upbeat about what he has described from the beginning as his longshot chance of an upset victory.
If he loses, will he run again for another office? He's not sure. As his car rolled through the northwest Connecticut hills, Mr. Johnson paused and looked out the window.
"Whether or not I'll run for another office, or get involved as an individual, as a citizen trying to reform government, I want to do something," he said. "It's an obligation of all of us who aren't politicians to take our spot at the wheel."

Dodd, says his status as a millionaire would impede his ability to relate to the needs of his constituency. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Praise of More Retirement Coverage

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Pensions -- or Perks for the Affluent?" (Forum, Sept. 20), David Mermelstein and Norman Stein address an important issue. However, the picture is incomplete. 
 First is the problem of inadequate retirement-plan coverage. Only 43 percent of our nation's employees are covered under a private retirement plan, which creates serious problems as our population ages. Any effort to increase the number of employer-sponsored plans via pension simplification must be encouraged.
Employers choose retirement plans based on what makes economic sense for them and their employees. While 401(k) plans are very popular with employees, many employers find the existing pension rules to be both complex and expensive to comply with.
Under current 401(k) rules, contributions by higher-paid employees are "linked," partly, to those in the lower-paid group. The tests needed to prove the 401(k) plan is equitable to both groups can be quite expensive. One proposal in the urban aid tax bill (H.R. 11) would eliminate these tests if certain minimum employer contributions were made. This would simplify administration and reduce costs, encouraging more employers to sponsor 401(k) plans and providing larger benefits for most employees.
Professors Mermelstein and Stein assert that 401(k) plans primarily benefit higher-paid employees since lower-paid employees cannot afford to participate in them. Facts do not substantiate this statement. Our own customer data, along with other recent industry surveys, show that 70 percent of lower-paid employees currently make deferrals under 401(k) plans, where they are available.
The changes in H.R. 11 will simplify pension-plan administration and increase employee coverage. Any attempt to encourage employers to provide plans should be applauded, not castigated.
 
RAY S. CRABTREE
Des Moines, Iowa, Oct. 2
 
Ray S. Crabtree is a senior vice president with the Principal Financial Group.

HEADLINE: WORLD SERIES: NOTEBOOK;
Is a Worldly Series In Baseball's Future?

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 24

 BODY:
With a Canadian team in the World Series for the first time, there has been talk of a real world baseball championship beginning sometime in the next decade.
Not the amateur baseball championship or the Olympics, but an event featuring the top professionals competing for the United States, Japan, the Dominican Republic and other nations. 
 "We're probably talking about something that major league baseball takes an integral role in developing and organizing," Deputy Commissioner Steve Greenberg said.
 
 
Free-Market Pricing
 The closer you get to a seventh game in a World Series, the higher the prices scalpers charge for tickets.
For instance, take Game 6 between the Atlanta Braves and the Toronto Blue Jays.
When the teams played here in Games 1 and 2 last weekend, field-level seats were being scalped for up to $1,000. Now, with the Series back in Atlanta, the top price for the game on Saturday night reportedly jumped by 50 percent, to $1,500.
Georgia law forbids ticket scalping, but it doesn't extend to legal ticket brokers out of state. Those outlets are asking $250-$950 a seat. (AP)
 
 
Talk About a Package Deal
 One scalper here was offering more than just seats to the game, according to authorities.
The Atlanta police accused Robert Martin of offering an undercover agent a package of two upper-deck seats, enough marijuana for about eight joints and a hotel room with continental breakfast, all for $650.
Martin, 36 years old, was ordered released without bail pending a Nov. 5 hearing. (AP)
 
Baseball Money Talks Softly
 The Series is expected to pump about $40 million into Atlanta's economy. But when it comes to money makers, baseball takes a backseat to pro football.
A consensus of economists from Atlanta, Detroit, Los Angeles and Minneapolis polled by the Atlanta Journal and Constitution said the Super Bowl was the biggest money producer for a city, with expected returns from $125 million to $153 million.
"It's just a different demographic," said Jack Kyser, chief economist of the Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles County. "It's a corporate event. There's a lot of wining and dining. The Super Bowl type of person would be looking for an upscale hotel. And there's a lot of expense accounts."
Atlanta will soon get a chance to find out. The 1994 Super Bowl will be at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta. (AP)
 
Bullpen Blanks
 Toronto relievers have not allowed a run in 13 1/3 innings of the World Series. No team's relievers have ever finished a Series with more than 13 scoreless innings. . . . The Braves have made only one error in the first five games of the World Series. The record for the fewest errors in a six-game series is one and the record for a seven-game series is two.
 
The Cabrera Index
 President Bush, trailing solidly in the polls less than two weeks before Election Day, told Georgians during a campaign stop this week that the race to the White House wasn't over "until Cabrera swings."
Based on the first five games of the World Series, the Presidential race is over.
Francisco Cabrera, whose two-out, two-run, pinch-hit single against Pittsburgh in the final inning of the National League Championship Series pulled out the pennant for the Atlanta Braves, has not had a swing against Toronto. But then, if there's a seventh game Sunday night, and the Braves are down by a run in the bottom of the ninth with the bases loaded and two out. . . . .
 
Heavyweight Fan
 Among the 55,000 or so fans expected for Game 6 was heavyweight boxing champion Evander Holyfield, who was scheduled to take a break from training for his Nov. 13 title fight against Riddick Bowe to fly into Atlanta for the game. Holyfield, who is from Atlanta, is training in Houston. (AP)

HEADLINE: More on the Gas Tax, Con and Pro

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Raise the Gas Tax to Cut the Deficit" suggests just one more way to further destroy the United States economy. 
 Mr. Oppenheimer cites the high gasoline taxes in "Eastern Asia and in Western Europe" -- perhaps he would like to accelerate the decline in the United States standard of living to be on parity with the nations in "Eastern Asia and in Western Europe."
The "ten billion dollars" he anticipates from the first year of an increased gasoline tax will come from transporters of goods and of people, and will increase the cost of products at the retail level, cause tourism to suffer and cut purchasing power. This is not a way to stimulate a flagging economy! It is a way to further destroy it.
 
LEE S. DIMIN
Valley Stream, L.I., Oct. 8

HEADLINE: More on the Gas Tax, Con and Pro

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Raise the Gas Tax to Cut the Deficit" (Forum, Oct. 4) doesn't make any sense. Your writer, Ernest J. Oppenheimer, seems to believe that if we throw more money into the Federal pot, suddenly the Government will use the money efficiently, wisely and well. Any taxpayer with the ability to read a newspaper -- any newspaper -- realizes there is no basic good financial sense in government. That's why we have a huge deficit and we're going broke! 
 Mr. Oppenheimer points to Europe as an example of higher gas taxes. May I remind him that Europe is also in a very tough recession now? Whether it is due to its citizens being taxed to the maximum is difficult to say, but excessive taxes are not an encouragement to economic recovery. Ask Canadians shopping in Maine.
Dreamy idealism got the United States where it is today, Mr. Oppenheimer. A few realistic ideas would be more appropriate.
 
JACKIE GRIFFIN
Bangor, Me., Oct. 5
