HEADLINE: OCT, 18-24: Counterfeiters Prosper;
Law Fails To Protect And Curtail Migrants

BYLINE: Peter T. Kilborne

 BODY:
In 1986, Congress tried to curb illegal immigration, mostly from south of the border, with a law that granted amnesty to three million unauthorized laborers already here and that established sanctions for employers who hire unauthorized newcomers. Congress created a commission to assess the law.
After slowing for a few years, the flow of illegal immigrants appears to be climbing back to its mid-1980's levels, although no one knows the real numbers. Last week, the final draft of the commission's research showed that the Immigration Reform and Control Act has failed in just about every way feared or expected. 
 Farmers, who thought the law would dry up their labor supply, often turn workers away. The anticipated rise in wages and improved conditions from farmers competing for a shrinking supply of workers have not happened either. After accounting for inflation, the study says, migrant worker wages have fallen 2 percent.
The commission found that the law has been undermined by counterfeiters, who produce authentic-looking driver's licenses, Social Security cards or birth certificates for the workers. It suggested that fraud-resistant documents be developed.
But it says the best solution is to phase out Washington's "agricultural protection" that exempts most farms from benefits like overtime pay and unemployment insurance. The practice repels many American job-seekers. Removing it would encourage more to apply -- reducing jobs for illegal immigrants and their incentive to cross the border.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1729 words

HEADLINE: George Bush's Failure -- Bill Clinton's Promise

 BODY:
Paradoxically, this has turned out to be the most popular and least popular Presidential campaign in years. It's the most popular in the sense that a great many citizens are paying close attention. The debates, and political television generally, have been drawing big audiences, and voter registration is up almost everywhere.
It's the least popular campaign because the voters don't much care for the candidates. Even at this late stage in the campaign, only 4 out of 10 of each candidate's supporters strongly favor their man. Thus in 1992 the usual question -- Which candidate is best? --has changed to, Which candidate is disliked least? 
 Meanwhile, history and circumstance make this a pivotal election. It could mark a national turning point; a Democratic victory would bring undivided government to Washington. And it will certainly mark a global turning point: It is the first election since the end of the balance of terror.
President Bush has been a sensible steward of America's foreign interests. But now, with the cold war over, he seems completely stumped by the need for leadership to move the country out of economic stagnation and spiritual unease.
Ross Perot, self-made billionaire, charms voters by, as he might say, talking turkey. But he torpedoed his credibility in July by jumping his own ship for two months. For all his businesslike confidence, he seems bereft of the skills needed to manage the grinding collisions of political interests.
Bill Clinton, though highly regarded by other governors, has not previously been tested on the national stage. He has, when pressed, shown a discomfiting tendency to blur truthful clarity. But he, much more than his rivals, manifests qualities of leadership: intellect, years of immersion in government, the capacity to attract first-rate people -- and the perseverance that has carried him through a brutal campaign. These concrete characteristics equip him to be a good President. With his instinct for ordinary people's concerns and for social unity, he could be even better.
 
President Bush
 The President can rightly claim credit for substantial accomplishments, including domestic legislation like the Americans With Disabilities Act. His successes, however, have been mostly international.
In his finest hours, he orchestrated the remarkable Desert Storm coalition that triumphantly reversed Saddam Hussein's aggression against Kuwait. Though suspicion now swirls about previous relations with Iraq, Mr. Bush managed the enterprise with a virtuosity and resolution that make his domestic dissembling look all the sorrier.
He deserves unstinting credit for launching the Israeli-Arab peace talks. He had an important hand in Germany's unification. He has been a constructive if sometimes grudging force for the transformation of the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. His Administration worked capably to end violence in Central America.
Just a year ago, largely because of his diplomatic achievements, President Bush was overwhelmingly popular. People chuckled over his often wacky diction. ("We're enjoying sluggish times, and not enjoying them very much.") But now, many voters turn away impatiently, repelled by his contradictions.
In 1988 he proclaimed the seminal six words of his Presidency: "Read my lips: No new taxes." Yet in 1990, to avoid amputating great chunks of government, he repudiated that pledge in a budget agreement with Congress. Then last March he repudiated that, thus denying himself any plausible leadership path.
With such slow growth in this nearly stagnant economy, many Americans feel the pinch of tough times. Yet Mr. Bush has done little to show that he understands the pain or that he has a reasonable idea of how to respond. Even if his deepest instincts tell him that government should keep its clumsy hands off the economy, why not say so, as part of a cogent policy plan?
For a generation now, even Republican Presidents have accepted the idea that Washington should try programs to stimulate a flagging economy. All Mr. Bush offered were some timid little remedies in his State of the Union speech and some incoherent promises to the Republican Convention. Not till after Labor Day did he issue an "Agenda for American Renewal" -- about a year late.
If the President's economic management is thus exasperating, his positions on individual rights are often infuriating. In a climate that cries out for racial healing, he derided even a modest civil rights law. In the AIDS plague years, a time that cries out for somber sensitivity, he aligns himself with intolerant convention speakers eager to disparage, as Pat Robertson did with a sneer, ho-mo-sex-uals.
Bitter differences over abortion rights have divided the country for a generation. Mr. Bush has carried his right-to-life position to radical extremes, like his veto in June of a bill to permit use of fetal tissue transplants in research on Parkinson's disease.
Mr. Bush's high-level appointments have sometimes caused even loyal Republicans to wince, starting with his choice of Dan Quayle as Vice President. Mr. Quayle is not the featherweight he's often made out to be, but since when is mediocrity a standard of choice for a standby President?
The imminence of other Presidential appointments means this election will determine the future of two branches of government. Mr. Bush is determined to appoint justices who will push the Supreme Court hard to the right, well into the terms of several future Presidents. It's an alarming prospect considering Clarence Thomas, his latest nominee. Justice Thomas has shown himself to be so ideological that he attacks even conservative colleagues with slogans. Yet Mr. Bush voices pride in this appointment, and promises more like it.
George Bush is an admirable American -- war hero, entrepreneur, devoted father and grandfather, who has given thousands of endless days to public service. He has often been a prudent manager. None of that, however, makes him a good President. Lacking leadership, his capacity to govern has collapsed.
 
Ross Perot
 George Bush came to office with a superb public service resume; Ross Perot's governmental experience has been slight. Yet he possesses an important quality of leadership. He can sell himself and his ideas. He conveys inspirational appeal to many voters, radiating conviction with folksy force.
But the man who said in July that he could conquer the deficit without breaking a sweat undermined his budding support by suddenly dropping out of the race. Now he's back again, on the ballot in every state and promising to spend $60 million of his own money. But he further diminished his plausibility by choosing as his running mate retired Vice Adm. James Stockdale, an admirable officer but palpably unqualified Commander in Chief.
Mr. Perot has already won himself a reputation as national civics teacher, educating the public to the need for shared sacrifice. His testiness, however, shows how completely he lacks the give-and-take skills needed to make government work. His whimsical candidacy remains merely a refuge for romantic voters who wish politics could be as simple as business and who wish bitter differences could be resolved on command.
 
Governor Clinton
 In contrast to on-again, off-again Ross Perot, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas has distinguished himself by his tenacity. He needed it. Not well known when the campaign began, he was vulnerable to one controversy after another.
He has also shown another, less attractive characteristic, a propensity for evasive ambiguity when challenged, either on personal matters like the draft or on policy.
There is justice in what President Bush says of his position on the Mexican free-trade treaty: "You cannot come down on both sides of the issue and call it leadership." By endorsing the treaty, Mr. Clinton stands up admirably against provincial special pleaders in his own party; that makes it all the more dismaying when he attaches strings to the treaty that could strangle it.
Likewise, last week he rightly ridiculed Mr. Bush's "read my lips" pledge. But in the next breath he issued his own promise not to raise taxes on the middle class -- even if that meant suspending his own public investment program.
In general, however, Mr. Clinton has taken strong and consistent positions, often notably more moderate than those of traditional liberal Democrats. For instance, he says to deadbeat fathers who fail to pay child support: "Take responsibility for your children, or we will force you to do so." Note the words responsibility and force.
Governor Clinton's choice of Senator Al Gore as his running mate created a confident contrast with the unprepossessing Dan Quayle. Mr. Clinton is an unquestioned leader of education reform and an enthusiastic advocate of initiatives like the police corps, in which students can pay back college loans with service. He knows how much good can be done by ingenious programs like small community development banks.
Most important, he offers the public a coherent, visionary program to conquer stagnation. He identifies America's crucial need: a well-trained work force. Yes, he says, stimulate private investment, but also recognize the need for public investment in education, infrastructure, the environment.
Republican skeptics worry that "more public investment" would turn into, simply, more pork. They say his program does not add up, and they may be right. But so what? No October plan adds up in January; what counts is the vision it sets out. Mr. Clinton's vision inspires hope.
He speaks passionately and consistently for tolerance and racial unity. As he told the Democratic Convention, politicians have for too long said that "what's really wrong with America is the rest of us. Them. Them the minorities. Them the liberals. . . . There is no them; there's only us." He stirs the conscience when he says, "We need each other."
Governor Clinton's knowledge of government puts Ross Perot's oversimplifications to shame. The promise of his program makes George Bush's belated agenda look paltry. And Bill Clinton's devotion to social justice makes both his opponents sound like auditors. Voters rarely have perfect choices for President, but this year, in Bill Clinton, they have a clear one.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

LENGTH: 721 words

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Russia's Rumblings

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Are the Russians contriving their own new and bizarre brand of gothic democracy -- or could they be heading toward Yugoslav-style chaos and nationalistic authoritarianism? To experts, the answer is both.
With Americans and West Europeans looking inward, Russia has taken strange and ominous turns, and its foreign policy and domestic future may be hanging in the balance. 
 * The Russian Intelligence Service (successor to the infamous K.G.B.) admits to U.S. officials that Russian military intelligence is off on its own and setting record levels for spying, that is, recruiting agents and stealing industrial secrets. Not to worry, says the R.I.S., it's only military inertia.
* The largely defanged Russian military is making a play to share power. Military leaders insist on Russian troops staying put in their new sister republics -- like the Baltics, Moldova, Georgia and Tajikistan -- to protect Russian minorities. This forges a highly explosive nationalistic link between "endangered" Russians abroad and the army.
* The Russian military is also trying to hold on to weapons banned by treaty or commitments. Military leaders secretly continued to make biological weapons, violating treaty terms -- and lied about it to President Boris Yeltsin. When confronted with U.S. evidence, they confessed. They are also pressing their political superiors to keep certain missiles and missile silos. This would contradict Yeltsin's promises to the Bush Administration and the agitation is delaying a new nuclear arms treaty.
* Prime Minister Yegor Gaidar and Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev are sounding alarms about a "constitutional coup" by the conservative legislature to unseat Mr. Yeltsin and destroy reform efforts. Maybe they are simply appealing to their many friends in the West to save their jobs, which are in jeopardy. Or maybe they know what they are talking about.
* Mr. Yeltsin barely lifts a finger to prevent what he himself calls a potentially catastrophic constitutional confrontation in December. So, on Wednesday, the standing "small" legislature voted overwhelmingly to convene the full legislature on Dec. 1. That full body will have power equal to Mr. Yeltsin's and could conceivably shackle his authority. The President could pre-empt that move by staging a nationwide referendum to abolish the full legislature or to validate new elections.
Most experts do not think matters will come to such a pass. They reckon that these rumblings are birth pangs of Russian politics. They feel that both pro- and anti-Yeltsin forces fear unpredictable elections and a breakdown of order, and will find a power-sharing compromise.
But even if the experts are correct and a paper compromise can be hammered out, this will do nothing to halt political and economic deterioration.
Neither economic reformers nor the highly diverse center group called the Civic Union has a politically viable economic plan. All their schemes contain big holes and promise too much pain for too long to a cynical public. Pockets of economic success can be found, but the downward spiral continues. For Russia, a better standard of living stands a generation away -- if and only if leaders establish public confidence before pushing ahead with tough decisions. And no Russian leader is prepared to sound that trumpet of sacrifice. (Sound familiar?)
Nor have Western leaders told Moscow flatly that there will be no Western pot of gold. Thus, Russian leaders go on fantasizing about a Western rescue that will never come, and putting off the hard choices.
Russian economic miscalculations could be compounded by political miscalculations, if reformers and conservatives misread the West's recent inattention. Westerners' self-absorption does not mean they have lost interest in Russia or no longer realize the centrality of Russian stability to any new world order.
Soon, Western leaders have to rekindle the old signal fire. They must loudly reaffirm their commitment to Russian democracy and reform and unmistakably underline their opposition to constitutional coups. Russian coup plotters in August 1991 misunderstood Western unhappiness with Soviet chaos. The plotters actually believed the West wanted them to overthrow Mikhail Gorbachev. The West should leave no room for similar misconstructions in December.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Tax Cuts and Spending Hikes? No Way!

 BODY:
To the Editor:
How wrong can you get? "First, Fight the Slump" (editorial, Oct. 9) calls for "a menu of quick-hitting tax cuts and spending hikes" as the best remedy for today's sagging economy. 
 Of course, you contend that this grossly irresponsible course must be temporary. For 30 years in the Senate I heard this siren call. I'd expect it in a political body. But to hear it from The New York Times? Ouch!
As long as the Federal Government is running a deficit of $300 billion-plus, and rising -- year after year pushing up the national debt a third of a trillion dollars annually -- America will suffer increasing economic paralysis as the drain of rapidly increasing interest payments deprive the country of the investment in research, training and acquisition of machinery and equipment vital to the productivity this country must have to compete internationally.
The trouble is that our 2 percent to 3 percent economic growth rate is not the result of too little Federal Government stimulus. It is not as if a $500 billion or $600 billion annual deficit will push us out of our oh-so-slow economic growth rate.
Our problem is the size of the deficit. And you want to make it bigger! All in the name of temporary stimulation. You're calling for a guarantee of more drain on our shriveled household savings.
Do we need more investment in infrastructure and education? Yes indeed. But we need to reduce consumption at the same time to get it! Let's start with a 50-cent-a-gallon tax on gasoline to be promptly invested in highways, bridges and related infrastructure. Let's slap a tax on all kinds of consumption, as proposed by Senators Sam Nunn and Pete Domenici, and I mean very big taxes, big enough and progressive enough to steer Americans away from costly new cars and homes and encouraging -- O.K., forcing -- investment in high-tech business.
Let's recognize the truth in "No gain without pain." Let's subsidize directly and heavily the kind of technical training of our work force that the Labor Department tells us will be necessary if in the next 20 years we are to have a world-class work force.
A Labor Department study found that less than 3 percent of our young adults have the reading and math skills to cope with the high-technology economy we are about to confront.
Just any old "quick-hitting tax cuts and spending hikes" are politically tempting. They will guarantee a continued economic slump and a grim future for our world-leading economy. We can do better than that, a lot better!
 
WILLIAM PROXMIRE
Washington, Oct. 9, 1992
 
The writer was Senator from Wisconsin from 1957 to 1988.

HEADLINE: Tax Cuts and Spending Hikes? No Way!;
The Secret Budget

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Truth About the Deficit" (Op-Ed, Oct. 4) offers only a partial truth. Charles J. Zwick and Peter A. Lewis omit the fastest-growing segment of the Federal budget: so-called off-budget expenditures.
By 1984, off-budget expenditures were adding more than $100 million to the annual budget deficit, according to the National Center for Policy Analysis. Since then a proliferation of off-budget loan guarantees for farmers, students, homebuyers, shipbuilders, the flood insured, cable television companies and other industrial and small-business loans have further increased off-budget expenditures. 
 These off-budget expenditures have precisely the same economic consequences as on-budget expenditures. Whether a defaulted guaranteed loan is on or off budget, the taxpayers pay the bill. Until these off-budget expenditures are included in the deficit by our deceitful Congressmen, there can be no complete truth about the deficit.
 
C. W. GRIFFIN
Phoenix, Oct. 4, 1992

HEADLINE: U.S. SENATE RACE;
The Candidates on the Issues

 BODY:

ECONOMY AND TAXES
Robert Abrams, Democrat: Favors phased reduction in military spending to $145 billion in the year 2000, or roughly half the military spending forecast by the Bush Administration for that year. Would use part of the estimated $900 billion to $1 trillion savings for deficit reduction and part for investment in infrastructure, housing and schools. Favors tax credits of up to 20 percent for businesses and industries that invest in plant modernization or defense-industry conversion, and of up to 30 percent for research and development. Opposes any increase in personal taxes. 

Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican: Opposes any tax increases. Favors a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget. Has proposed a two-year freeze in Federal spending, except for Social Security. Favors tax credits for first-time home buyers, and restoring full deductibility for I.R.A. accounts. Wants private enterprise zones to help rebuild inner cities, and privatization of some Government services.

 HEALTH
 
 Abrams: Favors a national health insurance program, backed by Congressional Democrats, to provide benefits to all Americans, in place of more than 1,500 private insurance plans now in place. Says the national plan would be financed through a new payroll tax (in lieu of premiums employers now pay) higher corporate taxes, and higher taxes on alcohol and tobacco. Favors condom distribution in schools and needle exchanges to fight AIDS.

 D'Amato: Favors plans backed by Congressional Republicans to offer vouchers to poor families that could be used only to buy medical insurance, and tax deductions for families with incomes below $80,000, plus the deduction of medical insurance premiums for the self-employed. Supports changes in medical malpractice and laws to hold down medical costs. Opposes needle exchanges. Supports supervised condom distribution in schools as long as parents can elect that their children not participate.
 
THE MILITARY
 Abrams:
 Says military spending cuts of nearly $280 billion over the next five years should be used for "victory fund" to revitalize the economy. Proposes to reduce total troop strength to 1.1 million from 2.1 million, Army divisions to 7 from 18, Air Force fighter craft to 800 from 1,728. Also favors large cuts in strategic nuclear warheads.

 D'Amato: Favors cuts in military spending of $85 billion over the next five years, emphasizing troop reductions in Europe, leaving a total of about 100,000, fewer than the 150,000 the Bush Administration wants. This would comprise one heavy Army corps, six Air Force tactical wings and Navy headquarters and support units for the Sixth Fleet.

THE ENVIRONMENT
 
Abrams: Favors increased Federal support for recycling and the imposition of minimum standards for recycled content in packaging and paper. Supports Earth Summit limits on emission of greenhouse gases, and favors stricter energy efficiency standards for automobiles and appliances. Favors more stringent review of pesticides and stronger Federal open-space provisions and conservation incentives.

D'Amato: Has taken a grab-bag of positions on environmental issues. Has fought vigorously for mass transit money and stricter fuel emission standards, but voted against cleaning up contaminated Department of Energy nuclear waste centers. Has voted both for and against restoring United States financing to the United Nations Population Fund.

ABORTION
 
Abrams: Favors abortion rights and opposes restrictions like parental notification for teen-agers or 24-hour waiting periods. Supports Medicaid financing for abortions for poor women, though his office is required by law to defend a state law that provides money for prenatal care, but not abortions, for some women with incomes above the poverty level.

D'Amato: Opposes abortion, and has endorsed a proposed constitutional amendment holding that life begins at conception. In the past, he opposed abortion except to save the life of the mother, but now says he also favors exceptions in cases of rape and incest. Favors parental notification. Twice voted to uphold the gag rule prohibit federally financed family planning clinics from dispensing advice about abortions, but recently voted against it.

 CRIME:
 
Abrams: Opposes the death penalty, but supports an alternative statute that would mandate life in prison without parole for certain crimes, including murder. Supports stricter handgun controls and a ban on assault weapons. Favors increased Federal support for enforcement of state and local drug laws and for residential drug treatment programs.

D'Amato: Favors the death penalty for murder or contract killings ordered by drug lords. Has opposed some gun control laws, but voted for the Brady Bill to require a waiting period for handgun purchases nationwide. Sought to make street handgun slayings a Federal crime, punishable by death.

CIVIL RIGHTS
Abrams: Favors Federal legislation providing benefits to domestic partners regardless of sexual orientation. Favors Federal law to bar discrimination against homosexuals. Pledges to support new Federal laws to punish bias-motivated violence.

D'Amato: Cast a deciding vote to let stand President Bush's veto of the Civil Rights Act of 1990, arguing that the bill would lead employers to use quotas. Says the Federal Government should "do more" to protect the civil rights of all Americans, whatever their "predilection," but has not specified how.

EDUCATION
 
Abrams: Favors loan program to allow every American student to borrow up to $10,000 per year to finance college education, with the money repaid through future tax filings on a scale linked to income levels. Opposes prayer in schools, and tuition tax credits for private and parochial schools.

D'Amato: Favors tuition tax credits for private and parochial schools, and giving parents of public school students the right to select which school their children can attend. Supports voluntary prayer in the schools. Favors expanding existing loan programs for college students, and a new plan in which loans would be repaid on a sliding scale pegged to income.

FOREIGN AFFAIRS
 
Abrams: Says that the United States is "the world's only remaining superpower, but should not attempt to be the world's super-policeman." Says European allies should take lead in forging a peaceful solution in the former Yugoslav states. Refused to say unequivocally until the Persian Gulf War ended whether he favored that use of military force. Sharply criticized the Bush Administration for delaying loan guarantees to Israel.

D'Amato: Was a sharp early critic of Saddam Hussein and a proponent of the Persian Gulf War. An early supporter of independence for the Baltic states, and strong backer of Israel. Warns that despite the end of the cold war, "this is still a dangerous world." Supports coordinated United States-European action to provide cover for humanitarian relief in Bosnia.

A map on Sunday showing states with United States Senate races misstated the status of New Jersey. There is no Senate race in New Jersey this year.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Two on Base, One Out In Toronto

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
FOR ALL THE GOOD PRESS THIS city has received, it hasn't been much of a place for architecture. (It wasn't much of a place for baseball, either, once upon a time.) Toronto's glory was in its ability to make urbanity seem benign and welcoming, to make the very idea of downtown appealing -- a more important achievement, in some ways, than the creation of a bunch of prima donna buildings.
But as Toronto's baseball fortunes have changed, so, too, has its approach to building. This city now has three new buildings that stand on their own as works of architecture, buildings that would have a claim on our attention no matter where they had been put. One of these projects, the galleria at the recently finished BCE Place office complex in the downtown business district, is among the best public spaces conceived in the 1980's, and it is full of lessons for other cities. Another, Terminal 3 at the Lester B. Pearson International Airport, is the finest piece of airport architecture since the United Airlines terminal in Chicago. And the third, the downtown headquarters of the Canadian Broadcasting Company, is a garish monument to deconstructivism that proves that Toronto, for all its virtues, is not above the desperate search for trendiness that afflicted so much commercial architecture in the last decade. 
 The best first. BCE Place (for Bell Canada Enterprises) consists of a pair of sleek office towers in gray granite with sculptured tops that, taken by themselves, are respectable if hardly distinguished. What raises this project far above its peers is the collaboration between the architects, the New York office of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, with the Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava, who designed the remarkable galleria connecting the two towers.
Mr. Calatrava, who won the competition to design a biosphere for the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York, is a visionary architect, not the sort to make his daily bread in the service of real-estate developers. But here, working with Raul de Armas, the architect in charge of the project, Mr. Calatrava produced a stunning six-story, 380-foot-long structure of white-painted steel and glass, leaping skyward with graceful, yearning arches.
Mr. Calatrava and Mr. de Armas have done a gentle dance here -- or perhaps it is more of a hesitant conversation between two people who do not speak the same architectural language but sense they have something to say to each other. Both the galleria and the office towers bespeak a search for a balance between rationalism and romanticism. Plenty of other skyscrapers are products of the same quest -- but nowhere else has it yielded anything like this galleria, which is brilliantly balanced between expressing pure structure and romantic aspirations. Ultimately the galleria comes off as a very sensual, expressive space, at once delicate and strong.
The first temptation is to say that this arcade is what we would have gotten if Antonio Gaudi had been co-opted into partnering with some big-time commercial architect. The galleria is nothing if not Gaudi-esque. In truth, however, Gaudi would have been far more subversive than Mr. Calatrava has been, and would have done something more challenging, even outrageous. It doesn't detract from Mr. Calatrava's achievement to point out that he seems to have been a little too eager to please here. The result is a mood that is a bit more commercial than spiritual, as shown in compromises like the escalators to the below-ground retail concourse in the middle of the galleria, a gesture akin to putting a stairway down the center of a nave.
The new airport terminal, designed by Scott Associates of Toronto, is frankly commercial, but that is part of what makes it interesting. The Canadian Government, following a pattern used in many public projects (but not airports) in the United States, invited private developers to bid for the right to build and operate the terminal. That a high level of architectural seriousness was achieved here is all the more remarkable, then: this building was put up to make money, not to be a monument.
The terminal is long and sleek, with white metal and lots of glass, including a vaulted ceiling. The building has a certain kinship to Helmut Jahn's United Terminal in Chicago, with one essential difference: this one has a gentle curve to it, which makes it more enticing, for the curve subtly propels you through the high main hall. On balance this is a much softer, easier structure than the terminal in Chicago, its details less Teutonic, its overall mood less hard-edged. The Toronto airport proves that decent airport design is not impossible on a tight budget and, moreover, that warm high-tech is not an oxymoron.
If only the Canadian Broadcast Center proved anything so promising. This 10-story studio and office building, designed by John Burgee and Philip Johnson of New York along with Bregman & Hamann and Scott Associates of Toronto, is a boxy concrete grid into which have been shoved a couple of projecting glass boxes and a glass cylinder. A grid of red-painted metal intersects the larger concrete grid, making a sort of plaid pattern on the facade.
The building was created as a demonstration of the so-called deconstructivist style of architecture, a theoretical approach in which the goal is to present the building as an amalgam of competing elements rather than as a coherent whole. Mr. Johnson, whose role as a patron of new styles (and of the younger architects who help intitiate them) is well known, has done much to bring the more ambitious examples of deconstructivism to the public eye.
But whatever its virtues, the style has been so watered down here as to make this building almost indistinguishable from the average tarted-up modern office building of Toronto or any other city. The Canadian Broadcast Center comes off not as a serious essay in deconstructivism, but as a little bit of this and a little bit of that -- deconstructivism so diluted that it is hard to see how it differs from the decorative, know-nothing commercial style of Dallas freeway architecture.
Only the sprightly red grid distinguishes this building. Take it away and what have you got? A very ordinary building indeed. Now that may be a kind of virtue in that it says that these architects could do a lot with economy of detail. But is that high art? And does it justify the claims made for this building as an important work? The broadcast center, alas, seems less a building for the 90's than the last gasp of one of the major failings of the 1980's: the Put-a-Famous-Architect's-Name-on-Anything syndrome.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 8, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 25 about new buildings in Toronto referred incompletely the role of Bregman & Hamann Architects. In addition to being associate architects on the Canadian Broadcast Center, they were the co-architects (with Scott Associates) of the new airport terminal and the master planners and architects (along with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and Santiago Calatrava) for the BCE Place project and its galleria.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Behind the Scenes;
The Faces Behind the Face That Clinton's Smile Masks

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 23

 BODY:
On television, Bill Clinton radiates earnestness, empathy and polite deference, coming across as an odd hybrid of television evangelist and think-tank analyst. But in person, it is possible to see more: his commanding attitude and his supple political shape-shifting, his fascination with and yearning for the adulation he is getting, and his surliness and finger-wagging upbraidings when something does not go exactly as he likes.
After a rousing, celebrity-powered rally in the once-conservative stronghold of Orange County, Calif., on Thursday night, Mr. Clinton lost his temper with a Secret Service agent when a couple of autograph seekers evaded a rope line in the parking lot of the amphitheater and got to Mr. Clinton. 
 "This is not going to work if these people just walk up," he snapped at the agent, his body tense and his eyes hard. But as he started moving toward the crowd again, he transformed his face back into the political mask of the easy-going country boy and resumed his loose, unhurried gait.
 
Oxford and Dogpatch
 For all the years he has been in politics, George Bush is a transparent politician, easy to read through verbal cues and body language tics. Bill Clinton, on the other hand, is a more opaque and complicated subject, a curious and sometimes calculated blend of Oxford polish and Dogpatch raffishness, of idealism and expediency, elusiveness and ego.
At one moment, the 46-year-old Arkansas Governor will be biting his lower lip, Elvis-style, and beaming his "Aw, shucks, all this attention for me?" slack-jawed smile, assuring audiences that he does not want to be President for himself, since he has a good life in Arkansas, but only to help make America a better place for his 13-year-old daughter, Chelsea, and the sort of decent, working-class folks he knows in Arkansas.
At the next moment, he will show flashes of pride and temper natural in a man who sees, tantalizingly within reach, the prize he has been hungrily moving toward for decades. Mr. Clinton has done what it takes, from restyling his hair to confessing his sins to muting his wife, and he has the concentrated air of one who is not about to let it slip away now.
 
Nerves Getting Frayed
 With polls showing his lead dropping, he is relentlessly crossing the country, hoarsely selling himself as the hip, fresh, Kennedyesque alternative to a tired "ol' Bush," as he calls the President. This is a campaign on a fast and scary water slide to Nov. 3: the mood is, by turns, giddy, paranoid, snappish and smug.
The campaign's nervousness was reflected in the attempts of aides to chastise and argue with reporters who wrote that Mr. Clinton still has problems on the trust issue, as reflected by polls.
Because of the static about "character" questions that has surrounded his campaign, the portrait of Mr. Clinton has been a caricature of labels like "Slick Willie," draft-dodger and ladies' man. And because the candidate has been fashioning and refashioning his political image and message for so long, there is a packaged quality to his appearances that dims spontaneity and makes it difficult to discern the real Bill Clinton. It is hard to tell if the large crowds he is attracting love him or simply the idea of change.
He pays close attention to the smallest details of his image: His aides confided that when he started jogging with Senator Al Gore, he became self-conscious about the long, baggy shorts he was wearing to exercise, reminiscent of the ones worn by overweight boys at camp, and has been trying to go shorter himself, if not yet quite as short as his fitter running mate.
 
Eyes of the Predator
 Like Dan Quayle, Mr. Clinton comes across as one who has long been a golden boy. But unlike the Vice President, Mr. Clinton does not try to wing it and leave much of the tedious homework on issues to others.
At airports, he scans the scene with a predatory look, seeing if there are any potential voters to charm. He is so eager to work any rope line, offering a series of speech bites on education, health care and taxes, that reporters have taken to chanting, late at night in the fifth city of the day, "Get in the car, get in the car!"
Some aides suggest that the Clintons are still uncomfortable with their new level of rock-star-style celebrity, in which women scream as they once did for Frank Sinatra, hold up signs reading "Bill's a Babe" and "Blondes for Bill," and tell Mr. Clinton as they shake his hand, "You're so much more handsome in person."
But it only takes a few hours on the campaign to see that Mr. Clinton gets the same adrenaline charge from working yet another group of voters screaming "We love you Bill!" that George Bush did from traveling overseas to attend meetings of his cherished global club.
 
On the Charm Patrol
 The Democrat jokes about this phenomenon, portraying it as the flaw of a policy dweeb. "There are some detailed policy positions I haven't gone over yet," he mischievously told exhausted reporters late one night. "Maybe we could block out an hour later."
Although Mr. Clinton has spent a lot of time avoiding reporters, when he thought they would be asking critical questions, this week he was on charm patrol.
Flying from Orange County to Las Vegas for a rally at the University of Nevada, he changed into a white sweatshirt, black slacks and black loafers and walked back to the press section with baby steps, intoning in a deep voice, "Yes, we're going to take bold steps into the future."
Asked about his mother's taste for gambling, he said: "My mother was supposed to be in Vegas but she was summoned to Moscow. She was consulting with the right-wing bunch there on how to get rid of Yeltsin."
It was the Republicans who were supposed to have a closet-full of October surprises for the Democrats, but the surprises so far have been exploding cigars for President Bush on Iran, Iraq and the feuds in his own Administration. And Mr. Clinton is quick to turn each Republican embarrassment to his political advantage.
He ignores the occasional Bush signs -- "Have some more syrup on your waffles, Comrade," read one in Billings, Mont. -- and treats hecklers with amused contempt.
"Don't boo that poor boy," he told the crowd at the Orange County rally, when a lonely Republican called out from among the 24,000 Clintonistas. "Why are you giving him any attention at all? Blow it off. We won't have to put up with it much longer."
He tries to portray himself as the heir to both John F. Kennedy and Ronald Reagan. This week, he even began saluting his audiences, in the way Ronald Reagan, another President who never went to war, liked to do. He has promoted himself, as Mr. Reagan did when he vanquished Jimmy Carter and Walter F. Mondale, as the avatar of uplifting oratory and Western swagger.
He posed on a Harley-Davidson motorcycle in a biker's jacket at the Milwaukee airport; sat around in a white cowboy hat jawboning in a dusty auto parts store in Pueblo, Colo., with a bunch of Western governors in matching white hats, and strode on stage in Montana, Colorado and Wyoming to music such as "The Magnificent Seven," (also used for Marlboro commercial), "Ghost Riders in the Sky," and "How the West Was Won."
He talked tough about welfare and the death penalty and offered Reaganesque anecdotes about ordinary Americans who have told him of their problems. At a rally in Las Vegas on Friday, he even suggested that the economy could grow out of its crisis -- a favorite Reagan prescription.
 
Both Hip and Presidential
 He presents himself as young enough to be hip, yet old enough to be Presidential, even joking sometimes that he needs reading glasses to see his notes. Clinton aides carefully choose the music for his rallies -- from the Beatles' "Twist and Shout," "Revolution" and "Here Comes the Sun" to the Beach Boys' "Good Vibrations" -- to underscore the generational message.
At a Chicago rally on Tuesday, Mr. Clinton and Tipper Gore swayed to the beat and sang along when Michael Bolton crooned one of his pop love songs. While Mrs. Gore mouthed "I love it" and Mr. Clinton looked so moved he might cry, Hillary Clinton and Al Gore stood by stiffly, like two members of the high school math club straitlaced at a mixer.
After a rally at the University of Oregon, Mr. Clinton discussed "funkodelic" music with the Crazy 8's, a band from Portland, and borrowed a saxophone to play a few bars of "Take Five," the Dave Brubeck classic written by saxophonist Paul Desmond.
At the Orange County rally, Mr. Clinton acted shy as he joined Whoopi Goldberg and the singing nuns from her movie "Sister Act," in a rendition of the rock song, "Shout." While he wants to be seen as with-it, he does not want to get too wild, so he limited his participation to clapping and occasionally calling out "Shout."
But afterward on his plane, when reporters were tweaking him about not giving a more soulful performance, he tried to make up for it by describing the last time he saw James Brown in concert.
"I saw his show a year or two ago, and he was fat but he could still do it," Mr. Clinton said. "You know, he's got a big old pot belly now, and he can do the splits and go right down to the floor and come back up. It's amazing to see."

HEADLINE: 2 Run on Records in Silk Stocking District

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

 BODY:
City Councilwoman Carolyn B. Maloney was grumbling about her Congressional campaign's lack of money the other day when the 86th Street crosstown bus rolled up, bearing an enormous poster of her opponent, Representative Bill Green.
She stood there for a moment against the backdrop of Mr. Green's picture and noted, rather wistfully, that she can ill afford the $750 needed to buy such an advertisement. And then, as the bus rolled away, Ms. Maloney picked up her bag of leaflets ($8 for 100) and walked on to her next meet-and-greet stop, a street fair on Broadway. 
 Money is not the least of Ms. Maloney's obstacles in her campaign against Mr. Green, who has represented the wealthy 14th Congressional District for seven terms and staved off challenges by such rich and formidable Democratic opponents as Bella Abzug, Mark Green, Carter Burden and Andrew J. Stein. Ms. Maloney also has to contend with Mr. Green's reputation for being good natured, independent and progressive, a Republican even the district's Democrats -- who outnumber its Republicans 3 to 1 -- have been more than able to live with.
"Bill Green is extremely popular, and he matches the style of the district -- upscale, moderate, sensible," said Norman Adler, a political consultant not connected with the race who has worked for both parties. "He supports good causes. The constituents think he's a Democrat in sheep's clothing."
But Mr. Adler cautioned that in this most volatile of political years, not everything is certain. Among the things on Ms. Maloney's side, he and others say, are her sex and party in a year when women and Democrats are expected to do particularly well here and new boundaries that have inserted heavily Democratic chunks of Queens, Brooklyn and the Upper West Side into the district.
A third candidate, Abe Hirschfeld, running on an independent line, is not considered a major factor in the race.
Ms. Maloney, who is 44 years old and worked briefly as a public-school teacher, is best known on the City Council for her work investigating city contracts in sludge and other areas. As chairwoman of the committee on contracts, Ms. Maloney has helped set up computerized systems that can track information on contracts and vendors doing business with the city. "Some people find them boring, but contracts are a passion of my life," she said in an interview at a coffee shop on the Upper West Side, as her two young daughters sat drinking juice at a nearby table.
 
10 Years on Council
 The reputation she gained as dogged and hard working through 10 years in the City Council led many local Democrats to feel that if anyone could beat Mr. Green, it would be her.
"I believe this is a wonderful district for an assertive Democrat like Carolyn Maloney to run in," said Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President. "It's a district that has regularly kept alive the tradition of mixed representation, where people are willing to switch candidates based on their stand on the issues."
But Mr. Green, who has a considerable personal fortune, is a fixture in the Silk Stocking District, so named because it includes some of Manhattan's toniest areas. He argues that he is in a position to help the city as the only New York City Representative from either party on the House Appropriations Committee. And he enjoys riches far beyond the $70,000 Ms. Maloney has spent so far on the campaign. (She says she has about $10,000 on hand.) As of Sept. 30, Mr. Green had spent $466,550 and had an additional $427,533 on hand.
In this year when Republican candidates in far friendlier places are distancing themselves from their President and party, the Congressman boasts of his non-Republican stances on such issues as abortion -- he is for abortion rights -- the environment and gun control, and indeed he has been endorsed by groups like the Sierra Club and the National Abortion Rights Action League. He also proudly points to a 1991 study in Congressional Quarterly that shows he voted against President Bush 69 percent of the time that year, more frequently than any other House Republican.
"I feel my race stands apart from the top of the ticket," said Mr. Green, 62, tall, relaxed and looking preppily rumpled over a cup of coffee at an East Side diner on a recent morning. "The best the top of the ticket ever did in my district was when Ronald Reagan got 38 percent of the vote." That year, Mr. Green said, he himself got 56 percent of the vote.
 
Disputing Votes
 Conceding that he supports many of the same causes that she does, Ms. Maloney is nevertheless trying to chip away at Mr. Green's reputation by casting him as a typical Republican supporter of Reagan and Bush economics. "The biggest issue confronting this city is the economy and jobs," she said. "Bill Green voted consistently with the Reagan economic measures that have gutted the city."
To bolster that view, she includes with her campaign literature a list of Mr. Green's votes supporting various Republican economic bills. For example, she points out that in May of 1981 Mr. Green voted to enact President Reagan's first economic plan, which increased defense spending and included tax cuts for the rich. And in September 1991, Mr. Green voted against a plan to extend unemployment benefits, a plan that the Administration opposed but that a third of the Republicans in the House ended up supporting.
Mr. Green, who describes himself as being fiscally cautious, counters that she is misrepresenting his record by taking the votes out of context. As far as the first vote goes, he notes, he did support the 1981 Reagan budget. But he contends that it was only after many of the deepest cuts were taken out of the earlier version, changes he says were made because he and other dissenting Republicans pressed for them.
As far as the second vote, Mr. Green says, he did vote against the bill Ms. Maloney is referring to. But at the same time, his staff points out, he has voted to extend unemployment benefits six times in the last year. The reason he opposed the September bill, said Charlotte Feldman-Jacobs, his press secretary, was that it included no financing for the extension.
For his part, Mr. Green does not seem that worried about Ms. Maloney, though his campaign has taken to sending unflattering clippings about her in local newspapers to reporters. "She's been in the City Council for more than 10 years, but for 9 years they did very little except change the names of streets and playgrounds," he said. "Although I have no objection to the names they chose."
 
Unpredictable Year
 With a minuscule advertising budget -- she says she is trying to scrape together the $13,000 needed to send out a district-wide mailing -- Ms. Maloney spends much of her time shaking constituents' hands and mobilizing volunteers to pass out her literature. She is paying special attention to the new 20 percent of the district, in Greenpoint, Brooklyn; Astoria, Queens, and Roosevelt Island, which are thickly Democratic and where Mr. Green is not so well known.
The question now is, will Mr. Green's reputation on his home turf be enough to help him prevail if there is a landslide in the district for Clinton? "He's well-known as the New York City Republican, and the issue is whether in this time of change people want to stick with him," said Hank Morris, a Democratic political consultant not connected with the race. "He's always been a survivor, but this is the toughest political year to survive."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Out of China, a Boost for Hong Kong

BYLINE: By Sheryl WuDunn

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
ORDINARY Chinese must be wondering what could have happened in their country to have sent the Hong Kong stock market bouncing to new heights this week. For while their markets, in the cities of Shanghai and Shenzhen, were creeping downward, the Hong Kong market rose to a new record, mostly on the news from China.
The prime shaker in the Hong Kong exchange is not a central bank. It is a coterie of elderly men, most in their 80's, who rule China and who with a cough or a stumble can send the markets reeling. They essentially determine the pace of China's economic growth -- the direction is invariably up -- and therefore the action in Hong Kong. 
 Last week, the action was in the Hang Seng index, which surged to a peak of 6,329.12 on Thursday, dropped by 66.58 points on Friday to 6,262.54, but even so was up 277.21 points, or 4.6 percent, for the week.
Underlying the market's rise is a change in perceptions about Hong Kong's relations with China. For years, Hong Kong's proximity to China and its scheduled return to Chinese control in 1997 have provoked anxiety, dampening investor confidence and lowering price-earnings ratios in Hong Kong.
But these days, a growing number of investors see China as an opportunity, rather than a threat. They argue that Hong Kong companies are able to participate in one of the greatest economic booms anywhere, and that the boom will continue for many years.
"Hong Kong is always a proxy to China," said Wai-keung Wan, sales director at the Jardine Fleming brokerage house. "China is embarking on a long-term growth trend. In the 1990's, any country that can produce economic growth can reasonably command a premium. Therefore, people feel very positive about China."
Hong Kong's stock exchange, once a wayward cowboy market of which Americans were wary, has been rising on and off since the beginning of this year. A buying frenzy in Hong Kong seized investors last week because they thought China had cleared a number of political and economic uncertainties.
Investors were reassured by the new leadership team that the Communist Party announced a week ago, feeling that the seven members of the new Politburo Standing Committee are reform-oriented. In fact, the appointments were largely expected, but the market seized upon the news to leap ahead.
In the process, the market ignored some bad news: China's Communist leaders criticized and snubbed Hong Kong's new Governor, Christopher Patten, signalling that relations may become tougher between Hong Kong and China. Mr. Patten had come to China to discuss his proposals for broadening democracy in Hong Kong and for financing a $16 billion airport. "On the face of it, it was quite negative," said James K. Osborn, assistant director at Baring Securities (Hong Kong) Ltd. "But on sheer fact, it was not a worse surprise than what was expected."
On Friday, however, after Mr. Patten departed for Hong Kong, China said it would retaliate if Mr. Patten's proposals for democracy and the airport were implemented without Beijing's consent. China's comments are certain to influence the direction of the market next week. Disappointment with the trip -- coupled with profit-taking -- accounted for the market's fall on Friday.
The underlying reason for the Hong Kong market's euphoria recently has been the 14th Communist Party Congress, which culminated Monday with the announcement of the new leadership team. The congress declared that China would develop a "socialist market economy" with the emphasis on "market."
Moreover, China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, who is 88 years old and holds no posts, appeared on public television on Monday. Investors took that as good news -- dispelling fears that he was virtually on his death bed -- instead of focusing on the fact that his health seemed much worse than the last time he appeared on TV, in February.
Mr. Deng exerts the greatest influence in the country, and now he is determined to lock China onto a course of building a market economy. The congress hailed him and his commitment to economic reform.
The previous week also brought news that lifted the market. Chinese and American trade negotiators broke a stalemate in discussions over American exporters' access to the Chinese market. The result was that China agreed to import more American goods, thereby avoiding punitive duties on as much as $3.9 billion worth of Chinese exports to the United States.
Money has been pouring in these last couple of weeks from the United States, as well as from Asia, analysts said. Although trading is conducted in Hong Kong dollars, the currency is pegged at a rate of about 7.8 Hong Kong dollars to the United States dollar. "One beauty of the Hong Kong stock market is that it is really a U.S. dollar market because of the peg," said Allan Ng, a senior analyst at S. G. Warburg Securities (Far East) Ltd. "No matter what happens, there's not currency risk."
Many of Hong Kong's large companies have shed the undeserved fly-by-night reputation they had a decade ago. The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation recently acquired the British bank Midland Bank P.L.C. Among the major China plays in the market are Hopewell Holdings Ltd., a construction firm building a highway in China.
Not surprisingly, most of the buying focused on blue chip companies, such as the Hong Kong Bank, and on Cheung Kong, Hong Kong's largest conglomerate, run by its richest man, Li Ka-shing.

HEADLINE: USAir Pulling Out of Mercer

BYLINE: By BARBARA STURKEN

DATELINE: WEST TRENTON

 BODY:
ON a wet Friday afternoon at Mercer County Airport in September, passengers clutching rain-soaked tickets and bags hurried past a poster beckoning them to sunnier climes: "Fly USAir to Tampa -- only $349 for four days!" There was no hint that within a few days the airport's jet service, operated by USAir nonstop to its main hub at Pittsburgh three times daily, would be just a memory.
And last week, the Mercer County Executive's Office was notified that USAir plans to discontinue its daily propeller-plane flights to Baltimore and Washington National Airports, the only remaining scheduled service, by the end of the year. 
 The airline's actions represent a serious blow to the community's efforts to make Mercer Airport a viable alternative to the Newark and Philadelphia airports.
The service cutback also comes at a time when many industry analysts believe that secondary airports like Trenton's are poised to grow in importance as major airports become more and more crowded.
After the jet service was dropped, said William Mate, director of the Mercer County Division of Economic Development, "we were flooded with calls from people complaining that USAir was taking the service away just when it was becoming an integral part of our economy."
One disappointed passenger was Eileen Pogo, who lives a 10-minute drive away in Hamilton Square. "I don't understand why they are leaving," she said. She ticked off the advantages of Mercer over a big airport like Newark International, including free long-term parking and the speedy arrival of luggage after a plane lands.
Gloria Burke, a Trenton resident, echoed Ms. Pogo's concern. "It's a mess going to Newark or Philadelphia," she said.
Passengers to the Pittsburgh USAir hub could fly on from there to other parts of the country.
 
Need for 'Tough Choices'
 Susan Young, a spokeswoman for USAir, explained the removal of jet service in these terms: "All the carriers have lost a lot of money over the last year, and we have to make some tough choices. This service was simply not economically feasible." The flights, using 110-seat DC-9 aircraft, were often less than half full, she said, and the jet equipment could be used more profitably on another route.
Airport and county officials criticized the company's decision to drop the Pittsburgh route after 11 months as premature. "We feel they didn't give the service enough time," said Edward Meara, president of the Mercer County Chamber of Commerce.
He and other officials pointed to boarding figures showing that traffic had been steadily building each month as more local residents learned of the service. Total jet passengers grew from 2,867 in January to 4,101 in May and 5,029 in June, most of them business travelers.
In all, 22,313 people used the USAir jet service during the six months ending in June; an additional 7,249 passengers flew on USAir's commuter flights in the same period. In July, however, passenger jet traffic at Mercer dipped to 3,851.
Mercer officials also said that USAir had failed to give the service enough advertising support. "You can't get people on the planes unless they know about it," said John Maier, whose final day as manager of the airport happened to coincide with the end of the jet service.
The industry's cash crunch, however, has left airlines with fewer dollars to spend on the sort of promotional efforts that can build up a following for a new service like Mercer's.
 
Advertising Drops
 USAir at first backed its jet service with various promotions, offering travelers out of Mercer double miles in its frequent flier program through last April. But since then, local officials said, there has been little advertising.
The loss of the commuter flights, on top of the withdrawal of jet service, has further angered Mercer County officials. The 19-seat propeller planes, serving Baltimore and Washington, have been operated by Jet Express, USAir's subsidiary.
Kenneth Carlson, president of Jet Express, said last week in a notification to the Federal Department of Transportation that the company believed that the commuter service would be uneconomical without the ground-handling and other support that had been supplied as part of the jet service.
Lynda Brugno, director of the Mercer County Department of Transportation and Infrastructure, said: "It is a blow, and of course we are disappointed. We can only hope either that Jet Express will somehow stay or that we will get a replacement."
Mr. Mate said discussions were now under way with a Northwest Airlines commuter partner, Precision Airlines, to offer daily flights to Boston, where passengers could connect to flights to other points in the United States and to Europe and Canada. The airport would still like to attract a carrier that could offer access to the South and the West, he said.
 
Microcosm of Deregulation
 To some observers, the story of USAir's short-lived service at Mercer is a tale of airline deregulation in microcosm. "It's all about hubs and spokes, and we're a spoke," Mr. Maier said. In the aftermath of the deregulation of the industry in 1978, the major airlines established giant hubs in major cities that act like sorting centers, ferrying in passengers from scores of smaller cities and then shipping them out on flights to their ultimate destinations. At some hubs almost three-quarters of all passengers are simply there to change planes.
For a small airport like Mercer, achieving spoke status can be a boon for local customers, who can fly to virtually anywhere in the country with one stop at the hub city. USAir promoted the Mercer-to-Pittsburgh flights as an efficient way to reach 300 destinations as disparate as Bermuda, San Diego and Frankfurt.
Mercer is experiencing another side effect of deregulation: by and large, the Government no longer requires airlines to consider the needs of local communities when they enter or exit routes.
And since the airline business has posted staggering losses lately -- in the last two years USAir has lost more than $700 million -- companies tend to base decisions on where to position their jets on short-term financial considerations.
 
News From Taxi Driver
 When abandoning a community, airlines rarely consult with the local leaders who courted them in the first place. Mr. Maier said he had learned of the end of USAir's jet service by talking to a taxi driver.
"What we normally do is to notify our employees and then notify the airport," Agnes Huff, a USAir spokeswoman, said. She added that she did not know why that had not happened at Mercer.
Local officials say they tried several times to meet with top USAir executives, but with no success. Robert D. Prunetti, the Mercer County Executive, said he had written twice to Seth Schofield, the chairman of USAir, requesting a meeting to discuss the situation. Two weeks after the service was discontinued, he said, a company executive wrote to say that the decision was final.
A restoration of jet service by USAir or another major line is unlikely, Mr. Maier said. "With the economy in a recession, it just doesn't look good," he said.
The airport will thrive only with Government assistance, he said. The Federal Department of Transportation does supply some subsidies for commuter airline service at smaller airports that would otherwise have no scheduled airline service. With the withdrawal of Jet Express commuter flights, Mercer would be in that position.
 
Free Trade Zone Sought
 Meanwhile, Mercer has applied for Federal status as a free trade zone, so that cargo could be shipped to the airport and stored duty-free. If the airport became a hub for freight, officials said, more businesses would be attracted to the area, and passenger jet flights might return.
Mercer's location midway between the busy gateways of Newark and Philadelphia is at once an advantage and a drawback. The two international airports offer customers a large choice of airlines and flights, and are each about an hour's drive from Trenton. But large airports often subject travelers to a host of annoyances: clogged roadways around the terminals, long waits for luggage to arrive and steep parking fees.
At Newark, it costs $22 a day to leave a car for up to three days near the terminal; longer-term parking, at a distance from the terminal, costs $6 a day. And the air fares offered by USAir out of Mercer were competitive with prices from airlines serving Newark, Mr. Maier said.
When Mercer opened a modern terminal in 1976, it also expanded parking in the belief that this might lure more customers. Free overnight parking is available in a lot that can hold up to 100 cars. The lot is guarded 24 hours a day.
 
 
 
Corporate Jets, Too
 Mercer County Airport, which is on a 440-acre stretch of land off Scotch and Bear Tavern Roads in West Trenton, hums with activity.Scheduled air service is just one part of its total operations.
Ronson Aviation, which charters and services corporate jets, has a sizable presence. Nearby companies, including Johnson & Johnson and Bristol-Myers Squibb, keep corporate jets there. The National Guard has a base on the site. In all, more than 600 people work there.
The runway can handle jets of any size except jumbos. In recent months, President Bush, Vice President Dan Quayle and Senator Al Gore, the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, have all landed there. The control tower coordinates 150,000 to 175,000 takeoffs and landings a year. The flow of traffic has led some local residents to complain about jet noise.
Built by the Army Corps of Engineers in 1943, the airport was used as a base for Navy planes until 1952, when the Government deeded it over to the county, which now provides it with an annual operating budget of about $1 million. The Federal Aviation Administration chips in $300,000.
For many years, the airport was served by Allegheny Airlines. In 1979, Allegheny -- by then rechristened USAir -- abandoned Trenton for more profitable markets in the Sun Belt.
Jets returned to Mercer in 1984, when United Airlines came in with three daily flights to Chicago. But within two years United, too, had moved on. While United was at Trenton, arriving and departing passengers totaled 60,000 annually, setting a record for scheduled passengers at the airport.
It was only after intense lobbying by the community that USAir decided to give jet service at Mercer another chance last November. Local officials argued that the influx of companies into the Princeton corridor area might provide the extra traffic to make the service viable.

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 1; Column 5; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1810 words

HEADLINE: Downtown Mainstays Are Lost in the Shuffle

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
FOR many years, Society for Savings was a mainstay of downtown Hartford, but it will become "Bank of Boston-Connecticut operation." G. Fox, another Hartford tradition, is being closed, and its branch stores in the suburbs will become Filene's. Connecticut Bank and Trust has become Fleet Bank, and Connecticut General has become two anonymous initials in the insurance giant Cigna.
And there are indications that the trend toward closings and regional mergers and consolidations in business could continue. Analysts have been busy speculating on the implications of the Primerica Corporation purchasing a large share of the Travelers Corporation, the Hartford insurance giant. 
 The changes have prompted one banker to observe that perhaps the real growth industry in Connecticut is sign painting.
But some economists find the trend no laughing matter. There is concern that as Connecticut becomes home to regional offices, rather than headquarters offices, the state will suffer. "Chances are that sooner or later there will be a merger of functions, like the payroll department, to take advantage of economies of scale," said a finance professor at the University of Connecticut School of Business Administration, Dr. Lewis Mandell. "And those merged departments are generally going to be moved to the headquarters," Dr. Mandell predicted. "So if the headquarters are outside of Connecticut, Connecticut stands to lose jobs."
A professor of economics at Fairfield University and a manager for the New England Economic Project, Dr. Edward J. Deak, said he had mixed feelings about the trend.
"With a friendly takeover, typically the new combined company is going to be better capitalized and better managed, so the likelihood is that the firm will be around longer, which benefits the consumer," Dr. Deak said.
"On the other hand, though, when things start to go wrong and they start looking for divisions to close, there's not that much connection to the community if their headquarters aren't here," Dr. Deak said. "They're more inclined to shut down rather than tough things out."
 
Loss of Hometown Support
 Dr. Deak also said that hometown-based corporations tend to support more civic functions. "Customers are nationwide, and they're all going to be treated the same way," Dr. Deak said. "But if you're looking for United Way support, or money for the symphony, or uniforms for the Little League, they're going to help their home community first.
That's not to say that outside firms do not take part in those functions, Mr. Deak said. "But if you're based in Boston, you're not wedded to the fate of Bridgeport."
Communities can come to be identified with the companies headquartered in them. Willimantic had the American Thread Company, the successor to a company that started in the mid-19th century. The city painted bobbins on its police cars in honor of the thread mill, and it was widely known as "Thread City," until the mill closed in 1985.
And there are places where that kind of identification with a single company remain. In Killingly, for instance, the village of Rogers was renamed years ago in honor of the electronics company (the village used to be known as Goodyear, when a tire manufacturer had a plant in the community). Rogers supports many local causes -- it even pays the village's street light bill -- and its employees serve on many local boards and in civic organizations.
"We don't usually think about the benefits that accrue to us through our community activities," said the president of Rogers, Harry H. Birkenruth. "Being a good neighbor just seems like the right thing to do. I know that it's important to me to feel personally connected to the community where I live and work, and I suspect that most other Rogers employees would agree."
The closing of a business that has long been a part of the community can leave a void that takes years to fill -- as in Bridgeport where the closing of Read's department store left the downtown without a major retailer, said the vice president of the Bridgeport Regional Business Council, Carole B. Adzima.
 
End of Lunchtime Shopping Sprees
 "The impact has just been horrendous on downtown employees; if you needed something you could run over there on your lunch hour," Ms. Adzima said. "Now if you need something you wait until after work and you run to Trumbull or Fairfield."
Ms. Adzima said people tended to shop where they lived, and because so few people lived in downtown Bridgeport there was little reason to put any retail uses there.
By Jan. 1, Hartford will lose one of its downtown institutions as well, when G. Fox closes, and its suburban branches -- nine in Connecticut, two in Massachusetts, one in New York and one in Rhode Island -- will become part of the Filene's chain. Both chains are owned by the May Department Store Company in St. Louis.
A spokesman for the May company, James Abrams, said the issue of G. Fox being a locally based chain was one that weighed heavily in the decision-making process.
"We were very sensitive about it," Mr. Abrams said. "We studied it at length, realizing G. Fox is a very prestigious and historic name. But so is Filene's. Our desire is to operate a dominant, regional department store, and Filene's is in a lot of markets that G. Fox is not, and is more widely recognized."
 
The 'Name' Factor
 There was also a lot of consideration about what a takeover would mean at the former Connecticut Bank and Trust, now Fleet Bank, said its marketing director, John Parunak.
"We knew the value of the name of Connecticut Bank and Trust," Mr. Parunak said. "The name was as important to some customers as the service and convenience and the quality of products we were delivering."
Fleet took over C.B.T. in July 1991, and spent eight months doing various analyses, focus group studies and surveys to determine how to proceed.
"What we found out was that for most customers, as long as we didn't change their life, they didn't care what name we put over the door," Mr. Parunak said. At that point Fleet began the process of converting 600,000 C.B.T. accounts to Fleet accounts.
"There's always some fallout when you make changes," Mr. Parunak said. "But we see the last year as a success. There was no appreciable impact on our business. In fact, we've brought in many new customers."
The Connecticut General Insurance Company was taken over by the Philadelphia-based Insurance Company of North America (INA) a decade ago, but the combined company, known as Cigna and based in Philadelphia as well, never abandoned its roots.
"Connecticut General is still a name we very much use in the life insurance business, in the pension business, and in our group health plans," said an assistant vice president of Cigna, Rick Goulart.
 
Most AEffected Is Banking
 Mr. Goulart said the company treated all its customers the same, whether they lived in Pennsylvania, where the company is based, or in Connecticut, where it has almost 3,000 employees.
"But a company's name does make a difference to the community, and any major company is sensitive to how the company is viewed by the public," Mr. Goulart said. "Those factors weigh very heavily in a decision to move into a community, or in a decision to pull out."
Perhaps the Connecticut industry most affected by mergers and acquisitions has been banking, because of a listless economy and a sluggish real estate market. Out-of-state banks have taken over, or taken large shares of, several Connecticut banks.
"One of the reasons for a merger or takeover is operational efficiencies, so why would they leave redundant operations in Connecticut?" asked Dr. Mandell, a nationally recognized authority on banking. "Connecticut becomes kind of a branch office, a district headquarters."
Dr. Mandell said he once did a study for the Federal Comptroller of the Currency that looked at customer satisfaction in banking. The expectation was that the large, regional banks could provide better service.
"Contrary to the theory, the satisfaction was much higher where there were restrictions on expansion," Dr. Mandell said. "If it's a local bank, you're banking with a person who grew up with you, who lives in the same town, whose kids go to school with your kids.
"Now when you want a loan you fill out a form and some computer in another state makes the decision," Dr. Mandell said. "It can be very harmful, particularly for small business in Connecticut, because the decisions cannot take into account the character of the individual, something a personal banker would know."
 
Hartford Decline
 Dr. Mandell said he worried that the trend could accelerate in some cities. Hartford, for instance, has been so battered by the economy that it is declining in importance as a financial services center. Eventually some of the large law firms that serve those companies could disperse, the restaurants where those employees eat and the shopping centers where they shop could dry up, and cultural opportunities could disappear.
"What's the likelihood that a UTC is going to stay in Hartford?" Dr. Mandell said, referring to the huge conglomerate once known as United Technologies Corporation. "A few years ago, they were looking for a site to put up a new building. Now they're renewing their lease on the Gold Building on a short-term basis. And if they go, a lot of other companies could follow."

 
VANISHING INSTITUTIONS
 November 1981: Connecticut General Corporation and the INA Corporation, parent of the Insurance Company of North America, announced plans to merge, forming Cigna.
February 1987: D.M. Read, a Connecticut department store chain, and Jordan Marsh, based in Boston, were consolidated after their corporate parent, Allied Stores, was acquired by the Campeau Corporation.
November 1987: The Hartford National Bank, which merged with the Connecticut National Bank in 1982, approved a merger with the Shawmut Bank Corporation of Boston.
July 1991: Federal regulators arranged for the Fleet/ Norstar Financial Group to acquire the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company and the Bank of New England, which had merged in 1984 and were declared insolvent.
August 1991: Citytrust and the Mechanics and Farmers Savings Bank, both of Bridgeport, were declared insolvent by regulators and acquired by the Chase Manhattan Corporation.
June 1992: The Connecticut National Bank, the state's largest with 143 branches, announced that it would change its name to Shawmut Bank Connecticut in January.
September 1992: The Society for Savings, a Hartford-based savings bank, agreed to be acquired by the Bank of Boston.
September 1992: G. Fox & Company, Hartford's last downtown department store, said it would close early next year and 13 other Fox stores across the state would be renamed Filene's in February.
