SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 3; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1662 words

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: RICHARD A. DUFFEE;
He Inhales So Others Can Breathe Freely

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
RICHARD A. DUFFEE is a founder and an owner of Odor Science and Engineering in Bloomfield, an international consulting company that sniffs out trouble. He has spent 36 years tracking down the source of odors and helping companies and municipalities snuff them out.
In the field he works with plastic bags to collect air samples and a portable "scentometer," which is a device about the size of a portable cassette player -- except with nosephones instead of earphones -- to filter air and determine how much odor is present. In his laboratory he has machines that dilute air for measurement purposes and complex chemical analyzers that track specific compounds. 
 Mr. Duffee, 61 years old, has a degree in chemistry from Boston College and one in meteorology from the Pennsylvania State University. While working at Battelle Memorial Institute in Ohio he did graduate work in experimental psychology at Ohio State University. He worked for T.R.C. Environmental Services as chief scientist, before starting the consulting company, which is one of few in the nation, in 1987.
Odor Science and Engineering has annual revenues of $1.5 million, and 16 full- and part-time employees. Mr. Duffee, who has earned the nickname "Snuffee Duffee" (one of his partners gave him a "Golden Nose" plaque that hangs on his office wall), charges $175 an hour to detect, identify and trace the source of odors.
He was interviewed recently at his offices on Blue Hills Avenue in Bloomfield, having moved there in September from the company's original location on Fish Fry Road in Hartford, which he thought was an appropriate place to start an odor-consulting business. Here are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. How did you discover you had this unusual talent?
A. I don't think I can sniff out odors better than anyone else, I just have a good memory for odors. As a chemistry undergraduate student I found that once I smelled something I could recall what it was that smelled like that. I went through qualitative organic analysis largely on the basis of that. It really isn't that I'm super sensitive, although I am sensitive, but it was my memory for odors that was one of the first things that got me into the business. The other was wanting to use the training I had in chemistry and meteorology.
Q. Do you ruin many cars, clothes or furniture?
A. Not my own usually. I've had incidents where we've stunk up a hotel room. I had to pay for a hotel room for a week while it aired out because one of my people in New York State had taken some samples, had the bag in his room, and one of the bags leaked. We got some angry calls about that one. Clothes -- I've thrown away a lot of clothes and shoes because it's not worth trying to get the odor out. And we've turned in some rental cars that I probably wouldn't want to get into after we get through with them.
Q. Are there state or Federal regulations governing odor?
A. There are no Federal regulations on odor whatsoever. There are some at the state level. Some states, including Connecticut, allow seven times the threshold -- in other words, it takes seven volumes of odor-free air to dilute one volume of ambient air to its odor threshold.
Q. How difficult is it to track an odor?
A. That's not that difficult, necessarily. It's a combination of understanding the smell and its dispersion in the atmosphere -- that's where my meteorology training comes in. I start from the outside and move in toward the problem.
I remember one time going to a cellophane-rayon plant, and they put out large amounts of carbon disulfide and hydrogen sulfide. Hydrogen sulfide smells like rotten eggs and carbon disulfide has sort of a medicinal smell. People were sure it was the hydrogen sulfide they smelled. They were getting complaints 20 miles away. So I went 20 miles away and, sure enough, I smelled it, but it wasn't hydrogen sulfide. And it wasn't carbon disulfide.
So we began to analyze the components, separating them and we found out it was carbonile sulfide. The carbon disulfide was oxidizing in the atmosphere, and the carbonile sulfide was giving this burnt gunpowder smell. If they'd put controls on the hydrogen disulfide it wouldn't have done much.
Q. What can be done to control a specific odor once you have identified the cause?
A. Most odor-control techniques are broad scale. If you're going to use incineration you're going to get rid of all odors. If you're going to use carbon absorption, you're going to get rid of most odors. If you're going to use scrubbing, that gets more chemical specific. The ideal way to control odor though is, don't release it in the first place. If you can find the chemical in the process that's causing the problem, and you can replace it, you've solved the problem.
Q. How scientific is odor detection?
A. The sensation of odor has four properties, two we can measure. One we just described, and one is totally subjective. The one we described is what we call the odor character, it smells like a skunk, a lemon, or whatever.
There's the intensity: How strong is the odor? To do that we compare the odor with standardized concentrations of butanol, an alcohol with a slightly sweet, slightly rancid odor.
The other one that is used to quantify odor is what we call pervasiveness, or detectability. You measure that by determining how many volumes of clean air it takes to reduce that odor to its detection threshold, the point at which you can't smell it anymore.
The fourth property is called hedonic tone, the degree of pleasantness or unpleasantness. What you consider pleasant can be entirely different from what I do.
Q. What's the worst thing you've ever smelled?
A. Until last Easter it was a rendering plant in Iowa. It's the largest dead-stock plant in the world. All they do is process dead animals, mainly hogs. But 28 million pounds a year of dead animals, with a 250-mile collecting radius. The animal may be dead a day before it's found, and at 250 miles it may be on the truck six hours or more before it gets to the plant. The whole animal goes into a grinder, which can reduce a whole cow to one-inch cubes in about a minute.
They only had one of those grinding machines, and no spare parts, and the thing broke in July. I got there about the middle of August, and I stepped into the receiving area of the plant, and my eyes began to tear from the ammonia.
Last Easter, I was trying to sample a process that produces trimethylamine, which is essence of rotten fish. In strong concentrations it will burn and sting your eyes, it will choke you, because you can't breath. I figured I would bleed a little into a bag, but the pipe was under a lot more pressure than the gauge said, and the bag popped off, and I'm standing in a stream of pure trimethylamine. I'm trying to shut the valve, my eyes are streaming, and I thought I was going to die.
I got my samples, and I went back to the office, and my office manager said, "Oh, you reek. Get out of here." I went home, and my wife threw me out. A few days later, I'm at choir practice Saturday night, and something stinks. I look down and I'm wearing the shoes I wore that day! I had to put them outside.
Q. Are you concerned that high technology is going to replace the nose as the odor tracker?
A. Oh, we've got a long way to go before that happens. For 35 years we've been trying to develop an instrument that would measure odor like we measure light or sound. And we're not much closer now than we were when we started. We don't really understand in detail how we perceive odors, although we understand a lot better now than we did then.
Q. Is the odor-tracking business affected by the economy?
A. It's been affected. The beginning of this year was probably the slowest time we've had, although slow for us is not really slow. People are concerned about odor. They think if they smell something it's going to have an effect on their health. And I think people are less tolerant of odor than they used to be. I think about the mid-1970s, or even a little earlier, the Environmental Protection Agency was creating an awareness of the problem through the Clean Air Act and got people worried about the health effects of the environment. Since then our business has been very strong, it's never really had a down period.
Q. Who typically hires you?
A. Mostly it's an industrial firm that is alleged to be causing an odor problem, or over the last five years, waste-water treatment plants and composting operations operated by municipalities. But until recently it was almost all industrial customers. I do all of General Motors's work. The first study I ever did for General Motors was when they had a new truck plant. There were 128 stacks on this roof. Everybody at the plant thought it was emissions from the paint process, but it wasn't. It was coming from the primer. If I can identify the specific source, I can save the customer money.
Q. Have you ever been really stumped by an odor?
A. From time to time. There's an indoor air-quality problem up in Braintree, Mass. Twin office buildings, built about 1988, identical in every way. One of them, no problems. The other one, on the fourth floor, from the time people moved in, you've got a kind of a rancid odor. We were called in a few months ago to look at it, and we determined it has to be the air-conditioning system in that area. It's not the fresh air intakes. We've done biological work, but nothing there. Chemical evaluations, but nothing out of the ordinary chemically. But you sure can smell it.
What we've done is put in a carbon-absorption system, but that treats the symptoms, not the problems. We're darned if we can figure out what that odor is.
Q. What's your favorite smell?
A: Chocolate, I guess. But I've worked in areas where they are complaining about it, in Hershey, Pa., and San Francisco, near Ghiardelli's.

LENGTH: 4931 words

HEADLINE: Al Gore's Double Life

BYLINE: By Alex S. Jones; Alex S. Jones, who won a Pulitzer Prize for reporting in 1987, left The New York Times this month to begin work with his wife, Susan E. Tifft, on a biography of the Ochs-Sulzberger family.

 BODY:
On a balmy August night in Waco, Tex., as moths swarm around the floodlights above a sea of banner-waving Democrats, Al Gore is on a stem-winding, give-'em-hell roll. Standing in shirt sleeves on an improvised stage, Gore whips the assembled thousands hard as he charges the Bush Administration with ruining the economy. "What time is it?" he yells, echoing the rhetorical flourish he first used during his acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention. Waving his arms like an orchestra leader, he leads the crowd in a shouting, chanting denunciation of George Bush and Dan Quayle: "It's time for them to go!"
And then, after the slight pause of a speaker who knows how to connect with his audience, Gore moves to the meat of his message: "Do you have the courage to change?" he cries, punching the air as sweat pours off him. "You have to have the courage to change. You have to reach out for something different."
It is a good night for Gore, who seems entirely at home with this rural, blue-collar crowd. And yet, the next morning, a very different Gore is on display. Standing beside Bill Clinton at an impromptu news conference at a power station outside Waco, Gore looks wooden and startlingly aloof; his arms dangle awkwardly like a department store mannequin, and his demeanor is so icily serious that he could easily pass for a Secret Service agent. 
 When Gore's turn comes at the microphone, he seems a world away from the effortlessly eloquent and persuasive politician of last night's rally. His voice slows, as though he were speaking to an audience that was a little dim. His tone sounds preachy, ultra-earnest, like a man who wants desperately to be believed, but is not really sure how. "George Bush and Dan Quayle taking credit for a clean environment is like a weatherman taking credit for a sunny day and then looking for another four-year contract," he stiffly tells the campaign press corps, sounding more like a professor than a candidate on the stump.
After the news conference, several reporters can be heard muttering that, like a campaign version of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, it is hard to be sure which of the two Al Gores is going to appear: the relaxed, open, even fiery Gore, who has emerged in recent years, or the self-conscious, distant introvert who seems to live behind a Plexiglas shield that even close friends cannot fully penetrate.
It is oddly endearing for a politician of Gore's stature to be handicapped by what is, in part, a problem of communication. But, as Gore himself explains, on these stiff occasions he cannot hear the remoteness in his own voice; he is tone-deaf to his own flat notes. Perhaps it is because Gore has lived so many years inside his own head that he does not hear the music of speech the way more extroverted personalities, like Bill Clinton, Ronald Reagan and the majority of other politicians, do.
People who know Gore well almost always say the same thing in describing him: he is a lot more complicated than he seems. A straight arrow who, by his own admission, smoked marijuana for years, a deeply religious man who does not hesitate to go for the political jugular -- as he proved in his opening statement at the Vice-Presidential debate -- Gore is clearly a man of different parts. According to his wife, Tipper, who has a master's degree in psychology from George Peabody College in Nashville, Gore is, even now, as a candidate for high office, in the process of integrating the contradictory sides of his personality.
Out on the campaign trail, the personality switches can be jarring. For instance, riding on his campaign bus down a Texas highway, there is the Gore who does not hesitate to indulge his taste in cheerfully vulgar humor. "Look at this, Dad," says his 19-year-old daughter, Karenna, as she slaps a supermarket tabloid in front of her father. Gore glances at the tabloid and giggling like a high-school kid, gives a dramatic reading of the sad saga of "the gassy granny," a German grandmother who had been so embarrassed by a burst of flatulence in church that she jumped off a cliff.
But a few weeks later in Kennebunkport, Me., a different Gore shows up at a fund-raising event -- a distant, awkward candidate who gives a perfunctory speech and seems to wish he were elsewhere. "You could see the lips pursing," said Ralph Hall, executive editor of The York County Coast Star in Kennebunk and an old friend of Gore's.
GORE ALLOWS that he is sometimes out of sync with those around him. He says he is a man whose natural inclination is to deal with the world intellectually, who likes nothing better than to withdraw into himself and think his way through a problem. His reputation in Washington has been that of a technology and public-policy wonk. Now he is firmly pushing himself to become a more sentient being, a man not afraid to put his emotions in full public view.
Indeed, few other candidates for high office have gone so far as the 44-year-old Gore in placing their psyches on display. In his best-selling book, "Earth in the Balance: Ecology and the Human Spirit," the Senator describes having "to look inside myself and confront some difficult and painful questions about what I am really seeking in my own life, and why."
Gore had found in what he calls "the global environmental crisis" a metaphor for his own unrest, "an inner crisis that is," he writes, "for lack of a better word, spiritual." He browbeats himself equally for his failure to live an environmentally responsible life (e.g. using his car's chlorofluorocarbon-spewing air-conditioner on the way to make a speech about how CFC's should be banned) and for more personal failings ("my own tendency to put a finger to the political winds and proceed cautiously"). And he pledges that he will no longer be party to "the failures of candor, evasions of responsibility and timidity of vision that characterize too many of us in government."
But Gore is still clearly torn between his idealism and political pragmatism. During the campaign, Vice President Quayle, among others, has attacked him as an "environmental extremist." Gore says that he recants "not a single word" of his aggressive environmental program. But he also concedes that he has had to soft-pedal some environmental proposals, like his call for stringent fuel-efficiency standards, in places like Michigan. Gore says that while the environment is still the centerpiece of his personal campaign message, his larger objective is to do all he can to help Bill Clinton win the election.
"The pressures of a campaign are different from the pressures of serving in office," he says. "I have to admit that knowing what national campaigns are like, I might well have been more vulnerable to the timidity that these national campaigns demand of a candidate, but I like to think I would have written exactly the same book."
MANY AMERICANS, WHO HAD formed their dominant impressions of Gore during his disappointing run for the Presidency in 1988, were introduced to the other Gore in July at the convention. Speaking in front of projected images of his 9-year-old son, Albert 3d, he described the opening day of the baseball season in 1989, when he thought his son had been killed. "I want to tell you this straight from my heart," Gore said. "That experience changed me forever."
Outside Memorial Stadium in Baltimore after the game, Albert had darted in front of a car and been knocked 30 feet in the air, then dragged across the pavement for 20 feet more. By the time his father got to him, he was lying in a gutter without pulse or breath; his eyes were open in what Gore described in the speech as "the empty stare of death."
As Gore held his son, he was plunged into a grief so immeasurable and despairing as to be fathomable only to those who have lost a small child. More than three years after that afternoon, during an interview, he involuntarily flinches as though hit in the stomach upon hearing the story of another little boy who had not been so lucky as Albert, who has now fully recovered.
After the convention speech, some critics suggested Gore had traded on his son's pain and a private family issue to further his own political ambitions, especially when he compared the resurrection of the Democratic Party to the recovery of his wounded son. But the Gores remain unapologetic. "That happened to us, in public, and we dealt with it in public," Tipper Gore says. "We kept as much private as we could, but it's become a part of our lives, and it's part of who we are and very much a part of who Al is, and I think that it was courageous of him to reveal that. He's very much a different person in many ways because of that trauma, and if you want to know him, you have to know what happened."
Although Gore describes his son's accident as the catalyst, the ground had been well prepared for another side of his personality to emerge. In 1984, he had been cast into a depression by the death of his sister, Nancy, his only sibling, from lung cancer. Nancy, who was 10 years older, had been protective of him, and she had been heavily involved in his four Congressional campaigns, as well his successful run for the Senate in 1984 (she died without ever knowing he had won).
Four years later, Gore's dismal performance in the Presidential race came as a cruel shock to a man who had lived, by and large, a charmed life. With his clean-cut good looks, Harvard education and impressive pedigree as the son of a famous United States Senator, Gore had rarely encountered doors that were closed to him. "I had just lost a Presidential election, having given it everything that I had, and encountered the limits of my capacity to persuade people of policies I felt so deeply needed to be followed," he recalls.
After the voters spurned him, Gore had thrown himself with his usual obsessiveness into studying the environment, an issue he had become interested in soon after entering the House of Representatives. Soon he had resumed his normal frenetic pace of meetings, hearings, luncheons and preparations for another possible run for the Presidency.
But then came his son's accident. Immediately Gore canceled his entire calendar, and he and Tipper spent the next month at Albert's side at Johns Hopkins Children's Center in Baltimore. "All these things that had loomed so large, not only in my daily life, but in my whole set of priorities, all of a sudden didn't amount to a hill of beans," Gore says.
And surprisingly, Gore found himself a little less disconnected from the world. "There was an outpouring of empathy and compassion from people I didn't know, from people I did know but didn't really know -- people who ran the elevators at the Capitol and the subway car from the Senate Office Building to the Capitol, police officers, janitors, secretaries, staff in the Senate. People who I suddenly came to understand had, in many cases, gone through experiences worse than the one my family had gone through and were carrying these heavy burdens in their hearts, without giving any indication outwardly that I had picked up -- partly because I wasn't paying attention."
For a man who had always kept much of his emotional life tightly contained, the public suffering of his family became a release. For the first time, he allowed his feelings of vulnerability to come out, and, as he recounts it, the explorations of those feelings gradually expanded into reconsideration of his entire life. In the months that followed, Gore began work on "Earth in the Balance," writing it himself at night in his parents' Capitol Hill apartment.
In the summer of 1991, Gore announced that he would not enter the race for the Presidential nomination. "I would like to be President," he said in a statement, "but I am also a father, and I feel deeply about my responsibility to my children." While Gore insists that he was thinking solely of the needs of his family in the aftermath of his son's ordeal, skeptics contend that he may also have been thinking about President Bush's huge popularity from the gulf war. Around the same time, a number of Democrats considered leading candidates for the nomination, including Lloyd Bentsen, Richard Gephardt and Jay Rockefeller, had also decided not to run.
This May, Warren Christopher, a lawyer with long experience in Democratic politics who was heading up Clinton's Vice-Presidential search committee, met with Gore to sound him out about who he thought would be good for the ticket. "We talked for nearly an hour," Christopher recalls, and Gore spoke enthusiastically about a number of possible candidates. Christopher says that only in the last two or three minutes of the conversation did he ask about Gore's own interest. "It was a very guarded, reluctant response, and he said that was something he would have to think about for a long time," Christopher says. But Gore did not rule it out.
A month later, Christopher called Gore in Rio de Janeiro, where the Senator was issuing daily attacks at the Earth Summit on the Bush Administration's environmental policies. Christopher wanted to know if Gore would be willing to place his name on a short list for the nomination. Gore told him he would let him know the following day. As far as Gore was concerned, his son and entire family had healed considerably during the year he had spent not running for the Presidency. "I thought about it," Gore says, "and I reframed the question to take the personal ambition part out of it, because I didn't want to do it in that sense. I didn't expect it. I didn't seek it. When I said yes, the question to which I answered yes was, 'Were you willing to give your country a better chance to change?' -- not 'Do you want to run for Vice President?' "
And how would he respond to those who might roll their eyes at such high-mindedness?
"Well, I don't care," Gore replies without hesitation.
WHEN GORE'S FATHER, the 84-year-old former United States Senator Albert Gore Sr., learned that Bill Clinton had chosen his son to be the nominee for Vice President, he told a reporter, "We raised him for it." This is in part true. But Al Gore's upbringing -- and the expectations that came with it -- have also been an obstacle to his political achievements. Which may be why Gore resents the suggestion that he was ever put in early training for a political career.
"That's not true," Gore responds heatedly when confronted with his father's remark. "When I was growing up, I don't ever remember a time when either of my parents said: 'Don't you want to go into politics? Don't you think you would like to do this or that.' I don't ever remember a time."
Despite protestations that his childhood was normal, Gore seemed to grow up much faster than most of his peers. "When I talked with him, I almost had to look at him to see whether I was talking to a child or an adult," recalls Eleanor Smotherman, Gore's second-grade teacher in Carthage.
One reason for Gore's accelerated maturity may have been that throughout his childhood, he lived in two worlds that could hardly have been more different. As the son of a prominent senator, Gore spent half of each year in the Fairfax Hotel on Massachusetts Avenue in Washington. The Fairfax, now the Ritz-Carlton, was then mainly a residential hotel and was owned by a Gore relative. When Gore was growing up in the 50's, his father and mother, Pauline, were at the center of the capital's high society. Big things were expected of the elder Gore, who was a serious contender for the Democratic Vice-Presidential nomination in 1956.
During holidays and Congressional recesses in the summer, Senator and Mrs. Gore returned to Tennessee and, as an inseparable team, spent most of their time on an endless round of appearances, speeches and constituent fence-mending. Usually, young Al was left in the care of Alota and William Thompson, the tenant farmers who ran the Gores' spread outside Carthage, a small town about 50 miles east of Nashville. In stark contrast to the elegantly appointed Fairfax, the Thompson home had no indoor plumbing and was heated by a single coal-burning fireplace. Al shared a bed with the Thompsons' only child, Gordon.
At the age of 5, when he began living part time with the Thompsons, Gore adopted a pattern he would repeat, instinctively filling a void created by the many absences of his parents. The Thompsons, he found, offered the unconditional love his own parents did not provide. Alota, a nurse, became like a second mother to Al. "She loved him as much as she did me," recalls Gordon, who now lives just down the road from Gore's farm.
Gore, essentially, adopted the Thompsons as a second family, demanding to stay with them whenever his parents were not around. Their home became a kind of emotional citadel, a refuge from the larger world, where great expectations awaited him. Even then, he was entranced by politics. Gordon recalls his friend sitting transfixed in front of the television watching a political convention. "He was real interested in it, and he knew a lot about politics, even when he was small," he says.
When Gore was 13, he found a second surrogate family in the Carthage area. Donna Armistead, who was nearly 16, was the attractive, tomboyish sister of one of Gore's friends. Despite their age difference, Gore was bold enough to invite her to a drive-in movie. Double-dating with her brother, they talked all night in the back seat. The next day, he asked her to see no one else, and she agreed. Their relationship endured throughout Gore's high-school years and, as with the Thompsons, he effectively joined her church-going family.
"What he didn't get from his family he picked up from my own," recalls Armistead, who now works for a Nashville physician. "I guess he kind of got a nurturing that he was lacking."
After spending summers in Carthage with Donna and a group of buddies he'd worked with for years in the corn fields, he returned to Washington each fall to attend St. Albans, one of the nation's most exclusive schools. Armistead remembers that, throughout his high-school years, Gore usually wrote her twice each day and called every Saturday night at 7:30 from St. Albans.
But Gore kept the two worlds he occupied very much separate. Not once did he ever invite Donna Armistead to St. Albans. Indeed, Reed E. Hundt, one of Gore's friends at St. Albans, was not even aware of Armistead's existence. "I never knew about her," he said. And though he developed strong friendships with a tight-knit group his own age who lived near the Gore farm, he rarely talked to them of his Washington life.
At a party around the time of Gore's graduation from St. Albans, he met Mary Elizabeth Aitcheson, known since childhood as Tipper after a favorite nursery rhyme. Tipper, like Donna, was outgoing and warm, but as the private-school-educated granddaughter of a prominent banker, she traveled in a different world. After a few dates, Tipper and Al had already begun talking about how many children they would have. That summer Gore broke off his relationship with Armistead, who a year later burned hundreds of his letters on the eve of her wedding. Though Gore and Tipper did not marry until after college, they have been together ever since that summer 27 years ago.
Despite their apparently traditional marital roles, both Gore and Tipper describe their relationship as a partnership of equals. A child of divorce, Tipper says her broken home, and Gore's political one, made both of them eager for a more stable, conventional family life. She embraces motherhood, and her fierce protective instincts show themselves on the stump. For instance, when Hillary Clinton sagged after a woman reporter demanded to know how her daughter, Chelsea, felt about reports of her father's infidelity, Tipper almost threw her body in front of Hillary to rebuke the reporter for asking such an intrusive question.
Out on the campaign trail, Mrs. Gore is an outspoken feminist who resents being cast as a decorative political wife. A former professional press photographer, she takes pictures at every campaign stop, prompted by a desire to have something to do onstage besides smiling and waving. Indeed, she is one of her husband's closest political advisers.
Tipper Gore is probably best known for her 1987 book, "Raising PG Kids in an X-Rated Society." The book, a parental call to arms against violent and sexually explicit material in rock recordings, prescribes movielike ratings for the record industry. The response was furious. Tipper found herself under attack for advocating censorship -- a charge she denies. Because of the record-labeling campaign, Tipper's image as a prim bluestocking has been hard to live down. Many reporters covering the Gores are surprised to find her smart and tartly funny.
BY HIS OWN ADMISSION, Gore feels deeply ambivalent about the family he grew up in, a family he describes in his book as "determinedly political." His whole life, in fact, can be seen as a series of alternating steps toward and away from his parents -- and all they represented.
Although Gore bought the farm directly across the Caney Fork River from his parents' farm in Carthage, bringing his own children there summer after summer, he has carefully structured his own family to be different from the one in which he grew up. Unlike Gore's mother, who was out campaigning with her husband most of the time, Tipper Gore is only a part-time campaigner, putting her energies into being the mother of three girls and a boy: Karenna, 19, Kristin, 15, Sarah, 13, and Albert, now 10. And when Gore decided to run for his father's old Congressional seat for the first time, he forbade the elder Gore from making even one speech on his behalf.
Albert Gore Sr. was born on a farm near Carthage and lived as a boy on another farm in an area known as Possum Hollow. But after a youth of hardscrabble farming he elected to become a teacher. Eventually he became the Superintendent of Schools and entered politics. An ardent supporter of the New Deal, Gore served in the House from 1939 to 1953 and in the Senate from 1953 to 1970. By his own admission, Senator Gore was a strict disciplinarian with his son. "I was, I won't say stern, but I was an insistent taskmaster," the elder Gore recalls. "He worked and worked hard."
Pauline LaFon was the daughter of a West Tennessee merchant whose general store went bust in the Depression. She worked as a waitress at the Andrew Jackson Hotel coffee shop in Nashville to put herself through Vanderbilt Law School, where she was one of the first female graduates. After briefly practicing law, she married Albert Sr. in 1937. When her husband declared himself for Congress a year later, they left newborn daughter Nancy at home during the day and, in the start of a lifelong tradition, campaigned together.
Although Gore idolized his parents as a child, his prickliness about his father today is apparent. "Al has never wanted to be bossed by his father," says Pauline Gore, Mrs. Gore is sensitive to her son's feelings about being upstaged by his father. At the Democratic convention she had to restrain her husband, who had rushed up on stage after his son's acceptance speech, extending both arms in a gesture of triumph as though he himself had just gotten the Vice-Presidential nomination that had eluded him.
"Pauline pulled my coattail twice," says the elder Gore, "and one of my grandchildren whispered to me, 'Grandpa, I like your shyness.' "
The senior Gore remembers that even at an early age, his son was keenly interested in politics. Albert Sr. recalls a night when he and his wife were about to leave their Fairfax apartment for a formal White House reception. As the couple were leaving, their son, then about 10 years, called out: "Dad, save that outfit. I might need it someday."
But by the time he got to Harvard, Gore thought he would become a writer or, perhaps, a lawyer-journalist, like Fred Graham, who was a close friend of his sister Nancy. He spent one college summer as an office boy at The New York Times, and began returning less frequently to Carthage. He and Tipper, who also went to college in Boston, would talk about making movies, or living by the sea, where she would paint and he would write.
Like millions of those of their generation, the Gores both smoked marijuana. Indeed, during his Presidential bid, Gore announced that, as a college student, he began smoking marijuana, a practice he continued later in the Army and as a reporter at The Tennessean in Nashville. The pre-emptive confession was all but ignored.
Gore was also in sync with his generation in his opposition to the Vietnam war. Yet despite his beliefs, he elected to enlist in the Army after graduation from Harvard in 1969. He feared that avoiding the draft would hurt his father's prospects of being re-elected to the Senate. But he asserts that his main motivation was to insure that no boyhood friend of his from Carthage wound up going in his place.
The Senator's bitter defeat in 1970 was an acute disappointment for his son. Gore had campaigned tirelessly for his father, even posing in his Army uniform for a widely published photograph with Albert Sr. But in one of the first negative television campaigns, Albert Gore's Republican opponent, William E. Brock, was able to turn the tide with blistering attacks on the Senator's opposition to the war and school prayer. Election night, Pauline Gore recalls, was one of the few times she ever saw her son cry.
Two months after the election, Gore was sent to Vietnam, where, thanks to his writing talents, he landed a job as an Army journalist. Ralph Hall, another Army journalist, remembers long discussions with Gore about the war. "We were basically conscientious objectors while in the Army," he says. "But we felt the military was an obligation, even though we disagreed with what was going on."
Gore returned from Vietnam utterly disillusioned with the political process that had engendered the war. "He was more restless," Tipper recalls. He took graduate courses in religion at Vanderbilt to have a place to think through the questions that Vietnam had raised. "I think it was a purification," Tipper says.
He had decided he no longer had any interest in conventional politics. When his parents tried to coax him into attending Democratic Party functions, he declined. While studying religion, he also worked as a reporter at The Tennessean in Nashville. In 1974, he entered Vanderbilt Law School, but continued writing for the newspaper.
Gore had always said his primary reason for getting into journalism was to change things. But he gradually began to believe that real power would come only through holding political office. When John Seigen thaler, The Tennessean's publisher and a major force in state Democratic politics, told Gore the Carthage Congressional seat was up for grabs, he was interested. "It just came home to me that if I was ever going to do it, now was the time," Gore recalls. "Not 10 years from now. Not one week from now. Now." He hung up the phone, turned to Tipper and said, "I think I'm going to run for Congress." And then he immediately dropped to the floor and began doing push-ups to get in shape for the race.
Even Gore's critics acknowledge that he has been, over the last 16 years -- four terms in the House and eightyears in the Senate -- one of the hardest-working people on Capitol Hill. Gore has never forgotten the charge that one reason his father lost was that he suffered from "Potomac Fever," had lost touch with the people he represented. Gore learned that lesson well, and has tried to return to Tennessee most weekends to hold town meetings. (Since 1976, Gore has presided over more than 2,000 such meetings.) "He was a better listener than I was," his father says.
In Washington, Gore proved to be a man in a hurry to attain a position of influence and was soon holding hearings, mostly on toxic waste and other environmental issues. As a former reporter, he had a sharp sense of what made a story, and he got more than his share of headlines, which prompted some resentment in the clubby atmosphere of Congress.
When a group of powerful Democratic fund-raisers urged him to run for the Presidency in 1988, he decided to do it. Today Gore contends that a big part of his motivation for making that race was simply raw ambition for higher office. When he was lambasted in the press for his wooden delivery and tendency to keep his distance from other people, he was hurt and perplexed. His defeat --he withdrew from the race after losing badly in the New York primary -- stunned him.
In this new period of self-examination following his son's accident and the writing of his book, Gore asserts that he has liberated himself from the burdens of the past. He says he is now free to be totally himself -- perhaps an overly optimistic assessment for a professional politician, especially for a front-running candidate for Vice President of the United States. Vice Presidents, after all, are expected to support the policies of their bosses under all circumstances, and Clinton has not embraced all of Gore's environmental positions.
But Gore says one reason he put his environmental ideas -- and his pledge to fight for them -- in black and white was to make sure that he would be embarrassed if he slipped back into overcautiousness. "That's growth," he says. "That's a good thing to do. And if that makes it harder for me to be hypocritical in the future, that's fine."

HEADLINE: The Chat of the Chattering Classes

BYLINE: By Joel Conarroe; Joel Conarroe, the author of books about American literature and editor of "Six American Poets," is president of the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation and chairman of the National Book Awards.

 BODY:

DOCTOR CRIMINALE
By Malcolm Bradbury.
344 pp. New York:
Viking. $22. 
 "IN the happening of fire, ask for helps the fireman at the window. Do not evacuate in the lift."
No writer takes more delight than does Malcolm Bradbury in fractured language of any sort. Hence this notice, which the narrator of "Doctor Criminale" spots in a Viennese hotel room. In the author's earlier novel "Rates of Exchange," a linguist named Petworth travels to the Soviet Union, where he is addressed variously as "Pitwit," "Petwurt" and "Pervert," where everyone he meets butchers one language or another ("Oh my English, I wish it was gooder") and where Russian speech is hilariously reduced to a series of made-up words, as in "Burs'ii Proly'anii" (Government bank) or "Prif'sorii Universitayii."
In that 1983 novel (nominated for the Booker Prize), which manages to be funny, gloomy, shrewd and silly all at once, the British Mr. Bradbury also has some good-natured fun at our expense. When Petworth reveals that he has traveled in the States, he is bombarded with questions: "Do they have topless seminars now in the university, the topless physics, the topless mathematics? How is your ego and your id?" Now, a long decade later, seminars are more likely to be canonless than topless, but the irrepressible Mr. Bradbury -- a professor of American studies at the University of East Anglia -- introduces other of our more typical cultural phenomena, with names like Madonna, Schwarzenegger and Quayle. "Doctor Criminale" takes place during a period in which George Bush, not Ronald Reagan, presides over "the golf courses and budget deficits of the United States," a time in which New York has become "the Beirut of the Western world. The streets are filled with gangs and terrorists, the women rage with anger, everyone lives for themselves."
In the course of the narrative this sardonic observer of human foibles casts a cold eye on a number of cultures, including that of Yugoslavia, which is now "not a country, by the way, just lines on the wrong map." The Belgian people go about "their usual lives: eating chocolates, crashing their fine cars and wondering whether Belgium [is] really a country at all." As for French icons, Guy de Maupassant so hated M. Eiffel's controversial erection that he "always dined . . . in its restaurant, because it was the only place in Paris you couldn't see the tower from." Thanks to "the Great Thatcherite Economic Miracle," Britain is "enjoying a deep recession." And in Italy, "when you are an hour late, you are already half an hour early." These and more.
But lest I give the impression that Mr. Bradbury's ambitious novel is a compendium of one- and two-liners, let me hasten to stress that "Doctor Criminale" is an earnest attempt to illuminate the extraordinary historical complexities associated with glasnost and with the difficult emergence of a brand-new Euro-world. The work is structured around the quest, by a young British journalist (or "journo") named Francis Jay, for the truth about an internationally celebrated man of letters, Bazlo Criminale, a walking web of contradictions who embodies key aspects of contemporary history.
The novel opens with a wickedly funny set piece about the Booker Prize ceremonies, at which the finalists are "presented with a leatherbound copy of what proved to be their own books; they looked at them in dismay, having presumably read them already." Despite making a fool of himself at the event, Jay is signed up to do research on Criminale for a television profile, and thus begin his travels to various academic conventions, including the Lausanne International Congress on Erotics in Post-Modern Photography, in search of information about his shadowy subject.
Like Petworth, Francis Jay is an unlikely hero, a tabula rasa with a passport, who acquires wisdom and understanding only gradually in the course of his search, which becomes ineluctably a search for himself. Criminale, for his part, is a charismatic intellectual acrobat with a gift for dignifying any occasion, the Great Thinker of the Age of Glasnost, "a master of the conference lapel badge, a virtuoso of the plenary address." A friend of Kurt Waldheim's with the added dubious distinctions of having advised Walter Ulbricht on human rights and Nicolae Ceausescu on architecture, he is known as "the man who has single-handedly reinvigorated philosophy by writing its epitaph."
With his head in the sky and his feet in the mire, Criminale is, like Paul de Man, a subtle thinker and a flawed human being, a creature of political deceits and betrayals who has learned to swim with the flow and whose history, as a result, is one of contradictions and deceptions. As our narrator, aided by several erotically compliant women, stalks this curious prey, he discovers much to admire and much to disdain, and it is a measure of Mr. Bradbury's artistry that the reader is made to share these responses as the crafty philosopher gradually emerges from the page.
Jay also discovers, with absolute certainty, that things are seldom what they seem and that "the real truth is always a little bit round the corner." His tireless search for this truth -- and for understanding of his own elusive self -- is brilliantly expressed. The book suffers from a talky passage or two, especially in its middle chapters, but it is never less than impressive in its willingness to raise disturbing questions. This is a playful, smart and entertaining work of art with deadly serious underpinnings.
Among the places Jay's researches take him is the Villa Barolo on Lake Cano, run by the Magno Foundation -- clearly the Bellagio Study and Conference Center on Lake Como, administered by the Rockefeller Foundation -- a place where, in Mr. Bradbury's words, "the modern scholar, coming on a Guggenheim or a MacArthur 'Genius' grant, got everything: power showers and jacuzzis, electronic typewriters and computer interfaces, fax facilities to keep inspiration in close contact with the office or home."
Admirers of another fine British novelist-critic will remember that some of the most seductive pages of David Lodge's "Small World" are also set at what is clearly Bellagio. If Mr. Lodge, justly celebrated for deflating academic pretensions and satirizing international congresses, is the laureate of the airlines, Mr. Bradbury is clearly logging some frequent flier miles of his own, and his take on wide-ranging gatherings of self-important pedants, though less consistently genial than his compatriot's, is no less memorable.
Here he is, for example, on a representative convention address "on all those things that cheer thinking spirits up these days -- the end of humanism, the death of the subject, the loss of the great meta-narratives, the disappearance of the self in the age of universal simulacra, the depthlessness of history, the slippage of the referent, the culture of pastiche, the departure of reality, and so on."
Introducing Barolo-Bellagio is possibly Mr. Bradbury's way of tipping his hat to a fellow writer who got there first. Also Lodgian is his introduction of "a very rich Marxist" who analyzes "such things as the films of David Lynch or the rise of the miniskirt," obviously a colleague of the Milanese professor in "Small World" whose Marxist convictions in no way inhibit her indulgence in la dolce vita. Like "Doctor Criminale," too, "Small World" involves a quest, featuring an Irish poet who flies from conference to conference in pursuit of a maddeningly evasive prey.
Mr. Bradbury also pays implicit homage to a writer who has had a major influence on his linguistic pyrotechnics. One of the nubile women who accompany Jay on his travels is named Ildiko Hazy, a fictional sister to Dolores Haze, a k a Lolita. Other characters have inventive monikers as well -- Otto Codicil, Sandor Hollo, Massimo Monza and the Misses Belli and Uccello, not to mention Bazlo Criminale himself. It is mainly in such wordplay that the author's debt to "Vladimir Nabokov -- God bless him" is apparent, as in a reference to "the chattering classes, who chatted the chat the chattering classes like to chatter when they are just chatting." Sprayed with Egoiste in a departure lounge, Jay responds, "If Chanel want to sell perfumes in airports, why don't they make one called Terminal Depression?" The book is full, too, of little multilingual jokes: "Lavinia took me by the hand, to the strains of 'La ci darem la mano.' "
Clever names and Mozartian allusions aren't necessarily designed to win over readers addicted to easy listenin'. Mr. Bradbury obviously intends his ironic observations to be savored by a fairly sophisticated audience. It's not everyone who will stay the course with a work that introduces such questions as "whether Nietzsche's umbrella was, as Derrida argued, a hermeneutic device, or whether it was a thing that stopped him getting wet when it rained." For readers who like this sort of literate prose, though, "Doctor Criminale" offers a nourishing feast. It is greatly to Mr. Bradbury's credit that a work showing how skim milk tends to masquerade as cream is itself the real thing, creme de la creme de la creme.
 

 
BAD EGGHEADS
 Whence came Dr. Bazlo Criminale? Malcolm Bradbury, his creator, attests to a longstanding interest in the idea of the "tainted intellectual," the person who stands for contemporary thought but possesses some flaw in his history. "We've had many such figures," he said, "from Heidegger to Paul de Man. I am interested in such people and in how their situations arose in the first place. We very often approach them innocently and assume their integrity is easily come by." His enigmatic character's origins may well fuel international literary parlor games.
In a telephone interview from his farm in Norfolk, England (he claims to be one of very few British novelists to own a combine harvester), Mr. Bradbury continued: "The book is simultaneously a comedy and a serious comment on an ethical and political situation. I've tried to mix two voices, really. One matter is the comedy which produces the story of the innocent young man amidst difficult things which he cannot understand; the other is the story of a man who has been struggling through history and who has committed certain moral crimes but at the same time emerges with, I hope, a certain dignity."
The name Criminale, the author confides, "first caught my eye on a storefront in northern Italy, and it seemed exactly right. The idea had come before and arose from other things, from men like Brecht and Lukacs, the Hungarian philosopher. I've traveled a lot in Eastern Europe and began to realize that a certain kind of intellectual or philosopher succeeded in these Communist cultures only if he had also been extremely cunning as well."
Mr. Bradbury, who is 60 years old, believes that the young man in the novel "must come to some sort of understanding that the generation before him is actually mired in history. In the contemporary view of morality and identity," he said, "without a strong sense of self you have no ethical center for your life, and it's very difficult to stand up to history." -- LYNN KARPEN

HEADLINE: All About/Sports Stadiums;
It's Boom Time for the Playing Fields Across the Country

BYLINE: By STEVEN J. VIUKER; Steven J. Viuker, a freelancer in New York, writes about the business of sports.

 BODY:
So maybe consumers are not buying a whole lot of cars. And, yes, businesses have cut back on first-class airline tickets and four-star lunches. But there is at least one area of conspicuous spending in these recessionary times: sports stadiums.
Domes, parks, yards and coliseums (few seem to be called stadiums or arenas anymore) are being built or remodeled across North America at a pace not seen in two decades. 
 Among the cities with new stadiums just opened or in the works are Atlanta, Baltimore, Cleveland, San Antonio and San Jose. In New York, Madison Square Garden recently completed a $200 million face lift.
These stadiums are put together in far different ways than their elder counterparts. Many are being financed through partnerships of local governments, sports teams and private corporations. Sometimes money comes from lotteries, instead of the usual bond issues and tax increases.
They also have many more luxurious corporate boxes and other amenities nestled inside. And several are being built in downtown areas, not in the suburbs miles away.
 
Building a Complex
Financing Through Partnerships
 The recent success of two downtown stadiums -- Camden Yards in Baltimore, which opened in April at a cost of $104.5 million, and the $500 million Skydome in Toronto, which opened in September 1989 -- seem to have inspired other cities.
"Toronto built Skydome," said Bill Dorsey, publisher of Skybox magazine, a sports business publication based in Cincinnati. "The Blue Jays became winners and almost four million fans paid to see them. Suddenly, Toronto was on the major league map."
Especially in prosperous times, cities were happy to bear all the costs of construction and upkeep of stadiums. Small and medium-size cities built stadiums to attract teams, seeking the big-city aura conferred by a major-league franchise.
Those expectations still often prevail, of course, though sometimes a field of dreams can turn into a house of nightmare. That seems to be the case with the Suncoast Dome in St. Petersburg, Fla. Opened in January 1991 at a cost of $140 million, the Suncoast is usually dark, save for an occasional concert or hockey game. Debt has risen to $262 million from $116 million because the city has failed to get a major league franchise it thought the stadium would be sure to attract.
So far, Suncoast has been used mainly as a threat by teams like the Chicago White Sox and San Francisco Giants seeking new stadiums or more favorable treatment.
Not so in Baltimore, where the Orioles had played in Memorial Stadium, in a suburb, since 1954. "The move to Camden Yards has increased attendance and allowed the fans to enjoy the city," said Jon Miller, an announcer for the Orioles and for the ESPN cable sports channel. "They'll arrive at the park, either by car or train, have dinner and then go to the game."
Cleveland is hoping to go Baltimore one better with its ambitious Gateway Complex. The $362 million project will have a 21,000-seat arena for basketball and musical shows and a 42,500-seat football stadium. Both are scheduled to open in 1994.
City officials say Gateway, a 50-50 public-private venture, will be the linchpin for the revitalization of downtown Cleveland. The city managed to persuade the Gund brothers, owners of the Cavaliers basketball team, to abandon suburban Richfield Coliseum, which they own, for the new downtown arena.
Even financially strapped cities no longer must concede losing a franchise.
"As with Baltimore, Cleveland and the new Georgia Dome," said Mitchell Ziets of Public Financial Management, a financial consulting firm based in Philadelphia, "new stadiums can be built largely with money from a dedicated revenue stream." That might take the form of a special lottery, equity from corporations or leases on luxury suites, in the place of bonds and taxes.
While the average fan may grouse about the corporate elite sitting in their air-conditioned boxes with television sets and private bars, they might as well get used to it, said Mr. Dorsey, whose Skybox magazine is distributed in luxury suites.
"It is those luxury seats that help pay the salaries of the players, keep seat prices lower and indeed help to build the facility," he said.
With its recent makeover, Madison Square Garden, which is owned by Paramount Communications, yanked out many lower-priced seats and replaced them with luxury boxes. At $140,000 to $190,000 a year, those 88 skyboxes will open the spigot of lease revenue to $15 million a year, from $2 million before.
The Georgia Dome in Atlanta is paying off its construction debt partly with revenues from more than 200 luxury suites located on three levels around the football stadium. The suites, ranging in price from $20,000 to $120,000 a year, have been snapped up by Coca-Cola and other corporations.
A suite's appointments make leasing one to watch a basketball game seem akin to chartering a yacht just to go fishing. Seating up to 20 people, the boxes are crammed with a bar, carpeting, mirrored walls, TV's, refrigerator, bathroom, closet, telephone and a lot more. When hot dogs just won't do, full-course meals can be catered.
 
Leasing Luxury
The Comfort of the Suites
 Companies that lease suites have access to additional services, like a concierge and business center with office equipment and meeting rooms. Some of the lease payments and other costs are tax deductible as business expenses.
Those kinds of features appealed to Tom O'Donnell, chief executive of McDonald Company Securities in Cleveland. His company has signed 10-year leases for boxes in both the Gateway arena and football stadium.
"Ours is a relationship business," Mr. O'Donnell said, "and a loge is a great way to entertain our clients. Our company now is just minutes away from the downtown complex. I believe these luxury suites will eventually be the hottest ticket in town."
Emerging as a leader in providing financing for the new stadiums is the San Francisco branch of Fuji Bank Ltd. Its sport finance group, started in 1988, has been involved in the Arco arena in Sacramento, Calif., America West arena in Phoenix, Gateway Complex in Cleveland, Kiel Center in St. Louis and Tampa Coliseum in Florida.
Working with the bank, Prudential Insurance Company has underwritten some of the arenas as well.
Fuji executives say they have eagerly backed private investments in sports arenas because they saw an opportunity to make money as public tax support diminished. They also say they like the idea of the new sources of profit available to team owners from luxury boxes and even restaurants and hotels built as part of a sports complex.
One of the nation's largest design firms, Ellerbe Becket Inc., of Kansas City, Mo., worked on many of the new projects, as has the Turner Construction Company of New York.
Ernst & Young, through its sports and entertainment group, has been kept busy conducting feasibility studies for cities and investors considering new stadiums.
But not everyone thinks the new wave of fancy arenas is all for the better. "Can you tell me," said Stan Fischler, a sports historian and author, "that the new Madison Square Garden equals the old in terms of charm and intimacy? Or that you can duplicate a Chicago Stadium or Montreal Forum?"
Nostalgia aside, a theory is rising about a correlation between improved team performance and a new stadium. Toronto, after all, did make it to its first World Series this month. But that's another story.

 
 
ROOTING FOR A HOME TOWN
 Now more than ever, team owners fret over their profit percentages as much as their winning percentages. Those who think they are not getting their fair share of revenue, often threaten to move to a more financially accommodating city.
And when teams consider a change in venue, their home towns start worrying. That was the case with Arlington, Tex., when the Texas Rangers baseball team contemplated moving in 1989. While the city was studying the feasibility of building a new stadium, a group of investors tried to move the team to the Dallas-Fort Worth area, about an hour's drive away.
At stake: $100 million or so that the Rangers brought yearly to Arlington's economy.
After a lot of give and take, the Rangers announced that they could not bear the thought of leaving their beloved Arlington and made a 40-year commitment to stay.
For its part, Arlington promised to build a $165 million sports complex with a 50,000-seat open stadium, to be completed in 1994. The stadium will be linked to the adjacent Six Flags amusement park.
The Rangers are providing 75 acres of land, the city is providing 8 acres.
To enhance profits, the Rangers will get a share of revenue from luxury box leases, in addition to the usual ticket and concession sales.
For the pleasure of keeping their big-league baseball team, even if they never go to a single game, Arlington residents will see their sales tax rise by half a cent.
Jerry Gorman, national director of Ernst & Young's sports consulting practice, said the three legs of the Arlington Stadium deal -- the franchise, the local government and the public -- was the pattern for future stadium financing.

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Hopkinton, R.I.;
Work to Start On Golf Resort

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Abbott

 BODY:
WITH hopes of turning this rural town of 6,900 residents into a golf resort that will attract thousands of tourists, a development partnership plans to break ground next month on a $7.5 million, 18-hole golf course.
Brae Bern Limited Partnership also plans to build a 200-room hotel, a conference center and 165 units of housing around the golf course, according to Hal Henry, Brae Bern's general partner. The project is backed by the State of Rhode Island, which is providing the developers with loan guarantees. 
 "The concept is, let's build a quality golf course in Rhode Island with an eye toward creating another Hilton Head," Mr. Henry said, referring to the resort island in South Carolina. New England has some 4.5 million golfers and Rhode Island has no destination golf resort, Mr. Henry said.
The course, not yet named, will be just off Interstate 95, Mr. Henry said, "We are a 75-minute drive for 7.5 million people and a tank of gas away for 25 million."
Designed by Philip Wogan of Topsfield, Mass., the course is being built by Corcoran & Jennison Builders of Braintree, Mass. It should be ready for play by the spring of 1994, Mr. Henry said.
Brae Bern Limited Partnership is contributing $2 million to the project. The remaining $5.5 million will be raised through the sale of bonds, Mr. Henry said. The state has agreed to guarantee $5 million of the built-out project.
"Without the state's guarantee, I don't think we could have put the financing deal together," Mr. Henry said.
The cost of the entire development, including the hotel, conference center and housing, is expected to reach $55 million. Mr. Henry said another marketing study suggested he should hold off on the rest of the project until he developed a market for the golf course and until the economy improved. But the opening in February of a casino in Ledyard, Conn., six miles from the project site, which is drawing 15,000 people a day, has persuaded him to move ahead with the rest of the project now. Mr. Henry said he was talking to major hotel chains about a possible joint venture and hopes to announce a groundbreaking on the hotel sometime next year.
State officials said the Hopkinton development fits neatly into their plans to help tourism industry, the state's third largest after health care and jewelry manufacturing.
The 43-square-mile Hopkinton borders Connecticut on the west and is about 15 miles inland from Rhode Island's beaches in the area of Rhode Island known as South County. Interstate 95 cuts through the center of the town, which has a handful of businesses employing more than 100 people, but is primarily residential.

HEADLINE: As G.M. Tries to Outrun Past, Critics Ask: Who's in Charge?

BYLINE: By LEONARD M. APCAR

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest manufacturer, was once renowned for its profitability and vitality. Now it is paralyzed by a crisis that has engulfed the very top of its management.
In the last week, General Motors employees and stockholders have awakened to headlines predicting that Robert C. Stempel, the affable, methodical chairman and chief executive, is on the verge of being pushed out by G.M. directors. That has not happened to a ranking G.M. executive since William Crapo Durant, the company's president and one of its founders, was forced out in the 1920's. 
 The board apparently believes that Mr. Stempel has moved too slowly to halt one of the most pronounced deteriorations of a business in American history. Frustrated over a gusher of red ink still flowing after three years, a faction of outsiders on G.M.'s board wants faster action against the auto maker's enormous bureaucracy and feisty union, as well as improvements on the bottom line.
The possibility of an executive-suite bloodletting is almost unheard of at stately, colorless G.M. For generations, a preordained succession of men have presided at headquarters in Detroit, in a corner office at the end of a long, usually deserted, always silent hallway, sealed off by guarded doors. Now, employees of all stripes are confused about who is in command.
"I had dinner last night with two G.M. engineers who can't get a decision from superiors on 1996 and 1997 models they're developing," said David E. Davis, the editor of Automobile magazine. "The executives are not communicating to the troops."
During a meeting of executives on Friday, G.M. employees were passing handwritten notes to each other: "Is Stempel out?" or "Is Smale taking over?" a reference to John G. Smale, the taciturn former chairman of Procter & Gamble who is a director of G.M. Mr. Smale, chairman of the board's executive committee, led a management shake-up seven months ago that ousted G.M.'s president and stripped some powers from Mr. Stempel.
At the end of last week, dealers, suppliers and stockholders were pressing the company for answers, but G.M. has said little. After stomping out earlier rumors on Wall Street and in Detroit of a possible bankruptcy, talk that G.M. brushed aside as "irresponsible," Mr. Smale issued a brief statement last week. Its tone was ominous for Mr. Stempel, who is 59 years old and was hospitalized briefly this month for high blood pressure. Mr. Smale said the board had not taken any action but "continues to reflect on the wisest course for assuring the most effective leadership for the corporation."
G.M.'s turmoil comes at an enormously sensitive time. Mr. Stempel, who has been chairman for 27 months, has been trying to give birth to "a new G.M.," bent on turning out higher-quality, distinctive cars and trucks at a cost that is competitive with the company's more efficient rivals. The goal is to make money no matter what size the market is or what market share G.M. can hold. That represents a departure from the previous goal, elusive for a decade, of trying to win back some of the 10 percentage points of market share G.M. lost to Toyota, Honda and other other foreign car makers, as well as to its Detroit competitors.
To make money, G.M. must trim its capacity, eliminate overlapping functions in plants and offices and spend heavily to restyle its cars to move beyond the series of look-alike models it offered in the 80's. It also has to seriously consider whether it needs all its car and truck marketing divisions: Cadillac, Buick, Oldsmobile, Pontiac, Chevrolet, Saturn and GMC Truck. On top of all that, the company needs to develop a culture that not only listens to the market of auto buyers but acts quickly to meet demands and anticipate new ones.
In that climate, executive drift may be disastrous, for G.M. no longer has the financial cushion that insulated it from previous mistakes.
"This is a company that has had one strikeout after another," said Maryann Keller, a stock analyst with Furman, Selz Inc. in New York.
 
A Need to Shrink While Still Investing
 What G.M. did not do -- but Ford and Chrysler did -- was face reality and learn to live with many fewer plants. Although G.M. closed 30 plants in the 80's, mostly antiquated ones, it also opened 9 new factories and modernized 19 others. The mighty company believed "closing factories is an incredible sign of weakness," Ms. Keller said.
What is painfully clear now to both Mr. Stempel and the board is that G.M. is at a crossroads: it can either lose further ground to aggressive rivals or brake its slide and begin making and selling cars profitably.
Both sides agree that G.M. has to shrink even as it is reinvesting in new cars. Where they differ is over approach.
Mr. Stempel, a patient engineer who will take the time to diagram his answers to questions about fine points of automotive engineering, said he learned too well that the upheavals brought on by reorganizations ordered by his predecessor, Roger B. Smith, hurt the corporation, costing sales and profits. That round of change, which began in 1984, took three times longer than planned and consolidated engineering, manufacturing and design. G.M. has since undone that reorganization, and on Friday it announced yet another round, which merged six car engineering groups into four.
To outsiders, the changes wrought by Mr. Smith hardly seemed revolutionary. But inside, it "was an emotional thing to do at the time," said Robert D. Burger, a now retired G.M. executive who ran Chevrolet in the 80's. "People who had worked at G.M. for many years weren't used to change." In the shake-up's early going, some engineers did not know who their boss was or even where they had a desk and a phone.
When Mr. Stempel took over, which happened to be the day after Iraq invaded Kuwait, he vowed, "I am not going to take G.M. apart again."
But he has announced the elimination of 74,000 jobs and 21 plant closings by the end of 1995, moves that would cut capacity by 20 percent. Although G.M. has said that some aspects of the plan will happen sooner, Mr. Stempel still has not identified a third of the 21 plants he intends to padlock. G.M. says those plans will be made by December, a full year after Mr. Stempel signaled his intentions.
"I don't know why they are taking so long to do what they have to do," said Douglas Fraser, the retired president of the United Automobile Workers union and a former director at the Chrysler Corporation.
At first, Mr. Stempel, who earned $1 million in salary last year, moved decisively. In his first six months, he cut G.M.'s stock dividend in half, canceled executive bonuses and consolidated engine and transmission operations into a single division.
He also placed a $3.35 billion bet that was a catastrophe. The amount reflects the money set aside to pay laid off workers. In 1990, Mr. Stempel signed a three-year U.A.W. agreement that paid union members nearly full wages even when they were not working. In return, Mr. Stempel got the freedom to close plants and shrink production to the point that G.M. could be humming at 100 percent capacity when the market picked up.
But the nation dug in for a prolonged recession, and car sales sagged. The result: Mr. Stempel is paying thousands of workers to stay home. At its worst last year, G.M. was losing $500 million a month in North America.
 
An Entrenched Tendency To Move Only Slowly
 Nor did Mr. Stempel's strategy buy labor peace. When G.M. tried to eliminate 240 tool-and-die-making jobs in Lordstown, Ohio, in August, the union struck and shut 14 assembly plants, idling more than 40,000 workers. The strike was settled only after G.M. agreed to defer the job cuts for a short time.
Now, the G.M. board may be reaching the conclusion that Mr. Stempel, himself a 34-year G.M. employee, cannot break free from the go-slow tendency that has been the bane of G.M.'s culture. And while Mr. Stempel may be the best engineer to run a prosperous G.M., he may be the wrong man now.
Ross Perot, who clashed with General Motors after it purchased his computer services company in the mid-80's, summed up the G.M. culture: "I come from an environment that if you see a snake you kill it. At G.M., if you see a snake, the first thing you do is go hire a consultant on snakes. Then you get a committee on snakes, and then you discuss it for a couple of years. The most likely course of action is nothing. You figure, the snake hasn't bitten anybody yet, so you just let him crawl around on the factory floor."
G.M. long believed in its heart that American fascination with small, foreign cars was whimsy. Deep down, Americans really wanted roomy Chevys, Buicks and Cadillacs. Better mileage was on the way, and once Detroit had it, sales would come.
No one believed that more than Roger B. Smith, who became G.M. chairman in 1981. He earmarked $40 billion -- roughly the same amount that the Federal Government is spending on the ambitious space-station program -- for new plants and automation. The figure helped bring G.M.'s total capital spending for the 1980's to $76 billion. Although it was having a bad patch -- 1980 was G.M.'s first annual loss in modern times -- Mr. Smith believed that G.M. was entitled to a 45 percent share of the American car market and needed modern assembly capacity to meet it.
He spent heavily on robots to paint cars and install windshields, intending to use automation to replace as many union workers as possible. He poured millions of dollars into technology and christened the Saturn Corporation in 1983 with a mandate to seek "start-to-finish innovation."
It took years to figure out what worked. At first, the robots painted themselves and dropped windshields onto the front seats. And only now, nine years after Saturn was announced, has it turned out to be a G.M. bright spot, luring young customers and helping cut the average age of G.M. buyers from the current level of 47 years. But Saturn is a more modest undertaking than originally planned and will take far longer to recoup the $3.5 billion G.M. has sunk into it.
For a while in the 80's, when the economy was growing and car sales were strong, G.M.'s huge profits, totaling nearly $28 billion from 1983 to 1989, masked many of its ailments. The biggest one was that G.M.'s costs were too high. The Japanese were building cars in the United States with nonunion workers, and they were importing full-sized, more profitable models that ate into G.M.'s bread and butter, the family sedan.
Mr. Burger, the former Chevrolet chief, attributed G.M.'s declining market share in the 1980's to "the increased pressure of the imports coming into the middle of the market that G.M. had owned for many years, and not only coming in with cars that were as good, but maybe sometimes better."
"Most importantly," he said of the foreign competition, "they had a cost advantage because we were so big, with so many people."
 
Chasing Competitors And Racing the Clock
 In April, after G.M. reported a $4.45 billion loss for 1991, the largest for any American corporation ever, G.M.'s board ordered Mr. Stempel to demote his president, Lloyd E. Reuss, and replace him with John F. (Jack) Smith Jr., who had led a turnaround of G.M.'s European operation. Mr. Smith is focusing on the North American operations by moving faster on plant closings, executive consolidations and price concessions from suppliers.
"There is a change that has gone on," said James Harbour, a Troy, Mich., manufacturing expert. "But if you think you're going to see it overnight, forget it."
In a recent study, Mr. Harbour calculated that it costs G.M. $795 more to build a car than is spent by the Ford Motor Company, which is the most efficient producer among the Big Three. That figure translates into a $4-billion-a-year disadvantage for G.M., nearly equal to its net loss last year.
To pare those costs, General Motors is trying to develop cars faster by creating teams of engineers, designers and marketing experts to sidestep the traditional bureaucratic obstacles that slow development. G.M. used to take five years to develop a car. Some 1990 and 1991 models took an average of 34 months -- an improvement, but still slower than Toyota, which has been known to spin out a new model in slightly more than two years.
G.M.'s target is $2 billion in savings this year and $5 billion annually by 1995. Meanwhile, the company wants "double digit" price cuts from suppliers and is trying to reduce the endless variations of components. One example: G.M., in its various models, uses five different kinds of brackets to support engine radiators.
But all of this will take time, and time may have run out for Mr. Stempel. The company's board meets next Monday in Manhattan at the G.M. Building, on Fifth Avenue at East 58th Street.
In Detroit, meanwhile, G.M. workers are aghast at the board's treatment of Mr. Stempel, especially in light of the progress he has made. "There is a lot of pain and agony," said a G.M. executive who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "There is a lot of love for Bob Stempel. For the first time in a long time, we thought they were starting to turn the big sucker around. Their time just ran out."
