HEADLINE: Research Questions Effectiveness Of Most School-Choice Programs

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
Allowing parents to choose their children's schools may be the hottest idea in American education, but a new flood of research argues that such "choice" programs alone will not help schools and, in some cases, can actually hurt them.
A report to be made public today by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, a leading educational research group, is the latest of several to argue that choice primarily benefits children of better-educated parents, does not necessarily improve student performance, requires additional money and, without certain safeguards, may actually widen the gap between rich and poor school districts. 
 Choice programs in various forms have swept the country in the last few years. Many communities allow students to choose any school within a district. In 13 states -- Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Idaho, Iowa, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Nebraska, Oregon, Utah and Washington -- students may cross district lines, taking their share of state and local money with them. A dozen other states are actively considering such measures.
 
Milwaukee Voucher Plan
 Only Milwaukee actually allows private schools to compete for students, paying public money for a small number of poor students to attend private schools. Thirteen states are debating a similar plan, and Colorado has a voucher proposal on the November ballot.
The new studies come after three years of intensive lobbying by supporters of the voucher plan, including President Bush, conservative research groups and the two scholars whose 1989 book helped ignite the current debate. These supporters maintain that only competition from private or parochial schools will force complacent public school monopolies to improve.
The Carnegie report, which is based on a yearlong study, was criticized by advocates of choice programs on the ground that it underestimates the potential of such programs and had played down public support for the idea.
 
'Self-Satisfied Establishment'
 Lamar Alexander, the Secretary of Education, said, "Only a very self-satisfied establishment could so easily dismiss so many parents' wishes."
The Carnegie report recommends that rather than relying on choice alone, educators concentrate on improving all public schools and combating the poor health conditions and violence that impede many children's performance in school. Fair choice programs would pay for students' transportation, give parents enough information about schools and compensate for wide gaps in spending between rich and poor school districts. School improvement teams could visit failing schools with the power to remove principals and invest more money so that failing schools could improve rather than shut down.
But critics of public schools like John E. Chubb and Terry M. Moe, who ignited the choice debate in their book, "Politics, Markets and America's Schools" (Brookings Institution, 1989), say public schools have resisted such changes precisely because they face no real consequences for failing to act.
When researchers contend that poor children with less well-educated parents would lose under choice programs, Mr. Chubb replies that these children would have a better chance with choice than they do now, stuck in the nation's worst schools.
But the Carnegie report and a number of other studies have found that in general, parents who take advantage of choice programs are better educated or more confident, raising the possibility that children of troubled families may lose in an educational free market and end up stuck in the worst schools.
Surveys of families in choice programs in Montclair, N.J., and Milwaukee, as well as research by Amy Stuart Wells of the University of California at Los Angeles and a recent study of choice programs in Scotland, all found that better-educated parents usually participated in choice programs or used more sources of information to decide which school was best.
The Carnegie researchers, who surveyed more than 1,000 parents, visited choice programs across the country and compiled other studies, present the most adverse criticism of statewide choice programs.
In Massachusetts, with school spending already battered by the recession, a choice program has caused fiscal havoc, the Carnegie report says. It cites the case of Brockton, a financially troubled city, and its suburban neighbor, Avon, which spends twice the amount of money per pupil as Brockton and could easily lure students away. During the first year of choice, the report says, 135 Brockton students transferred to Avon, taking with them nearly $1 million in state aid.
Under Massachusetts law, Brockton also had to pay Avon the difference between the two districts' spending to match Avon's higher per-pupil spending. While Avon hired a new guidance counselor and paid for a new roof, Brockton had to lay off teachers and pack 40 students to a class.
Massachusetts has since amended its law to avoid such stark problems, but it still does not pay for transportation, which means that poor students may be unable to choose schools far away from their homes.
 
Some Bright Spots Found
 The Carnegie researchers pointed to some bright spots, like rural schools in Minnesota that attract students by creating innovative programs. But overall, the report said, no statewide program had demonstrated a clear link between choice and improving student achievement, partly because several studies show that most parents chose schools not for academic reasons, but because they were close to home.
The researchers found that less than 2 percent of students actually took advantage of statewide programs and that none of the programs met what they said were essential preconditions: paying transportation, providing parents enough information or compensating for the gaps in spending between rich and poor school districts. "By these yardsticks, we conclude that responsible and effective statewide school choice does not exist in America today," the report said.
Choice programs within one school district have been the most successful in improving student achievement, the report concludes. Parents and students in all choice programs are happy with them, the report says, but it emphasizes that students' freedom to choose schools was just one factor in this success. The nation's three most celebrated examples of choice programs -- those in New York City's East Harlem district, in Cambridge, Mass., and in Montclair -- have higher scores and more motivated students.
But these districts also spent a great deal of money on innovative programs, attracted generous Federal grants, offered parents considerable guidance and information on how to choose schools and gave teachers power to create their own schools. The report also says that 1992 test results show that some of East Harlem's gains have eroded, partly because of budget cuts.
 
Milwaukee Problems Cited
 The Carnegie report also criticizes Milwaukee's two-year experiment with vouchers. The program has had some problems -- a private school closed abruptly in the middle of its first year, stranding 63 children. There have been high and unexplained attrition rates. Test scores have not risen.
But most parents say they are delighted with the program, and its defenders note that it would be unusual to see changes in test scores after only two years.
The Carnegie report also found that most parents oppose vouchers by a 2-to-1 margin. But the Gallup Poll has indicated that there is substantial public support for vouchers. Much depends on how the questions are worded.
Other researchers are attacking Mr. Chubb's and Mr. Moe's argument that the best schools are those that have the least amount of bureaucratic oversight, and that competition will thus improve all schools.
Two researchers who have been sympathetic to choice programs, Valerie E. Lee of the University of Michigan and Anthony S. Bryk of the University of Chicago, said that Mr. Chubb and Mr. Moe made several technical decisions in the way they compiled their statistics that skewed their data, exaggerated the effect of autonomy on schools and minimized the effect of teaching methods or course requirements on student achievement.
Mr. Moe did not return messages left at his office requesting comment on these studies, and Mr. Chubb's secretary said he was out of town.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Despite Perot Surge, Clinton Keeps Sights on Bush

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STERLING HEIGHTS, Mich., Oct. 25

 BODY:
Spending an entire day in this swing state, Gov. Bill Clinton delivered a focused and concerted attack on President Bush today and called the Presidential race "a battle for the spirit of America."
Mr. Bush, he suggested, has abandoned average working people, has taken refuge in the White House and has used the power of the Presidency to help his "political cronies" and to nurture "a collection of the same old fears" that have divided the nation.
 
A Spot Above the Fray
 "We only have to put up with this, if you're willing to fight for change, for nine more days," Mr. Clinton said at a fall harvest festival in Saginaw.
The sharpened attack left little doubt that the Democrats would treat the President as their primary enemy as shifting polls in a handful of crucial states illustrate just how many voters are still making up their minds. 
 Taking advantage of a strategy that worked well for him when Mr. Bush and Ross Perot were sparring last June, Mr. Clinton ridiculed both his opponents, saying they were preoccupied with investigating each other rather than with the future of Americans, and he claimed a spot for himself above the fray.
"Now, it turns out today, Mr. Perot is accusing Mr. Bush of investigating his children," Mr. Clinton said, referring to the Texas businessman's accusations on the CBS news program "60 Minutes" tonight. "So now we've got this bizarre situation where Bush and Perot have accused each other of investigating each other's children. Let me tell you something. I want to investigate your children -- their problems, their promise and their future."
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, picking up on Mr. Clinton's theme at a rally in a high school stadium here tonight, said Republican economic strategies have benefited only the wealthy. "They'll take care of themselves," he said. "They will not take care of the rest of us."
This was the first time Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Clinton have campaigned together, but aides to the New York Governor said that Mr. Cuomo has given 81 interviews that were broadcast in 22 states on Mr. Clinton's behalf,
"America's getting lucky again," Mr. Cuomo said. "When we need one most in this country, a champion steps forward. And one has stepped forward again."
 
Jumps on New Allegations
 During his campaigning today, Mr. Clinton also repeatedly drew attention to the recent spate of news articles about the possible involvement of Mr. Bush and his chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, in illegal dealings with Iran and Iraq. By combining the latest allegations with his customary recitation of Republican shortcomings on jobs and the economy, Mr. Clinton sought to make a sweeping indictment of the Bush Administration's actions as well as of its intentions.
"If I worked at it 18 hours a day, I couldn't cost you as many jobs as he has in the last four years," he said. "Because I could not go to sleep at night with the kind of policy that they have visited on the American people.
"I do not promise to be a perfect President," Mr. Clinton said. "If you elect me, I'll make mistakes, but unlike the guy who's in there today, from Day One, I'll get up every day, go in to work and try to get something done."
Mr. Clinton launched no such specific attack on Mr. Perot or his proposals. Instead, he used a classic Clinton campaign tactic -- appropriating elements of his opponent's most effective pitch -- to tell voters he is on their side against the Washington insiders who he said have claimed the White House.
"I'll wake up every day in that White House with the idea that it's not my house," he said, sounding for all the world like a less twangy Mr. Perot. "It's your house. And I am nothing more than a temporary tenant and your chief hired hand, and that if it hadn't been for you I wouldn't be there."
 
Sights Remain Fixed on Bush
 Mr. Clinton has faced down his electoral foes in a similar manner before, dispensing with threats from Senators Tom Harkin, Bob Kerrey and Paul E. Tsongas with the same sort of rhetorical technique. He uses some of their words in his stump speech today.
But today's assault was conducted with a twist. Working to make sure that the President always remains his primary target, he used Mr. Perot's language to bolster his attack on Mr. Bush.
"How in the world can these people be talking about this when the state of Michigan lost 125,000 manufacturing jobs since Bush has been President, when this country's lost 1.4 million manufacturing jobs, when most Americans are working harder for lower wages than they were making 10 years ago, including most of the people in this audience today?" he asked. "How can they be talking about each other when they ought to be talking about you and your future?"
Because of Mr. Perot, the contest in Michigan has tightened considerably. Polls show Mr. Clinton's lead over Mr. Bush at about 10 percentage points, half of what it was before the debates.
Mr. Clinton has responded by campaigning here aggressively. He flew into Grand Rapids on Saturday night, on to Saginaw and to this Detroit suburb today. He is scheduled to return to the state again on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Baker, Telling Iraqis of Loan Aid, Asked Help on Palestinian Talks

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d sent a message to Iraq in November 1989 telling the Iraqis that the United States had just approved new grain credits and seeking Baghdad's influence in persuading Palestinians to take part in peace talks with Israel, a newly declassified document shows.
Although the message from Mr. Baker, now the White House chief of staff, does not explicitly link the farm loan credits to Iraq's intervention with the Palestinians, it provides the clearest evidence so far that the United States wanted something in return for the guarantees. 
 The message was sent to Iraq's Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, on Nov. 9, 1989, nine months before Iraq invaded Kuwait. A copy of the message was released along with many other documents on Friday night by the Senate Agriculture Committee, which is investigating reported abuses in the farm credit program.
Some members of Congress have charged that the Iraqis diverted the grain for money and weapons, and that the Bush Administration generally sought to curry favor with President Saddam Hussein before the Iraqi invasion. The question has become an issue in the Presidential election.
 
Wide Opposition to Iraqi Aid
 The Bush Administration has repeatedly denied that there was any evidence of such a grain diversion and justified its decision to extend the farm credits as a way to try to moderate President Hussein's behavior through economic and political incentives.
The decision to proceed with the farm credits was made despite opposition from the Treasury Department, the Federal Reserve, the Office of Management and Budget and Federal prosecutors in Atlanta who were investigating a multibillion-dollar loan fraud involving the Atlanta branch of an Italian bank and Iraq.
In another document released by the committee, the Federal prosecutor in charge of the bank case wrote in an internal memo in July stating that Iraq had misused the farm program and that the Agriculture Department knew it but ignored it.
The July 16, 1992, memo by the prosecutor, Gail McKenzie, sharply criticizes the Department for ignoring evidence of the abuses in a meeting with other Government agencies held just before the Administration agreed to proceed with the first $500 million of the $1 billion in credits to Iraq.
 
The Urgency of Peace Talks
 Mr. Baker's request to the Iraqis for help with the Palestinians partly explains why he became personally involved in lobbying for the farm program. Determined to make progress on his peace plan, Mr. Baker at one point, according to previous press reports, telephoned Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter to press the case for the grain credits.
In the message to Iraq, which was sent by Mr. Baker for delivery by the United States Ambassador in Baghdad, April C. Glaspie, Mr. Baker said he was "pleased to be able to inform" Mr. Aziz that an Agriculture Department team would soon arrive in Baghdad to negotiate new credits under terms that "we believe will be acceptable to you."
The message, sent a month after Mr. Aziz and Mr. Baker met in Washington, said the decision on the grain credits "reflects the importance we attach to our relationship with Iraq."
Then Mr. Baker quickly turned to the peace talks. "We are at a critical point in our diplomacy," Mr. Baker said. "The Government of Egypt is working closely with Palestinians to respond positively to our five-point framework, enabling us to get an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue launched. It would be useful if you could weigh in with them and urge them to give a positive response to Egypt's suggestions."
Mr. Baker had broached the subject of Iraqi support for the Egyptian peace plan at his meeting with Mr. Aziz on Oct. 6. But at that meeting, according to the minutes, Mr. Aziz remained noncommittal, telling Mr. Baker, it was "Iraqi policy to refrain from public statements on the peace process."
Ms. McKenzie's memo gives a detailed description of her concerns about the grain program, which she had voiced in a conversation with two senior Agriculture Department officials on Oct. 11, 1989. Other documents indicate that Ms. McKenzie and other members of her team had warned against giving Iraq new credits.
Ms. McKenzie wrote in the memo that she told the two officials that there were strong indications that Iraq was bartering or diverting food bought through the credit program, because the country was buying more food than "could reasonably be consumed in Iraq." She noted that the Agriculture Department's monitoring system traced food shipments only as far as Jordan and Turkey, not as far as Iraq.
At the time of her meeting, Federal prosecutors in Atlanta and other United States Government officials were suspicious that Iraq was diverting either the loan money or the food into weapons purchases, although the allegations have never been proved.
 
Kickbacks to Iraqis Reported
 Ms. McKenzie's memo was apparently written as a protective measure to exonerate her and her team of any wrongdoing in their handling of the bank fraud. Ms. McKenzie said in the memo that it was written after she learned that Congress was investigating her briefings to Agriculture Department officials.
The prosecutors had also uncovered evidence that Iraq had demanded bribes from American exporters participating in the program. In her memo, Ms. McKenzie described how the Iraqis paid inflated prices for goods backed by the aid program in order to include kickbacks and freight charges in violation of the program's regulations. Even after the Agriculture Department "advised Iraq to cease such demands for payments," she wrote, the Iraqis continued to demand kickbacks.
Many of the loans guaranteed by the United States grain program were extended by the Atlanta branch of the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, the Italian bank that Ms. McKenzie's office was investigating.
She noted that Iraq was using other loans from the bank to buy militarily useful equipment, including machines useful in both ballistic missile and nuclear weapons programs. She also said Iraqis "may be" using profits from the bank fraud scheme and from kickbacks in military projects.

HEADLINE: Rabin Reiterates That Israel Will Not Yield All of Golan

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin told his Cabinet emphatically today that Israel would not fully pull back from the Golan Heights even though it has raised the possibility of withdrawal in its peace negotiations with Syria.
His affirmation of Israel's position came just before a fresh spurt of violence left six Israeli soldiers dead, including five killed in southern Lebanon when Islamic guerrillas blew up their tank. It was the largest one-day death toll the Israeli Army suffered there in two years. 
 In addition, a soldier was killed by an Arab gunman, described as a militant Islamic fundamentalist, who fired a machine gun at an army post in the West Bank city of Hebron. Hours later, hundreds of armed Jewish settlers from Hebron went to Jerusalem to demand the Prime Minister's resignation. They tried unsuccessfully to storm a hotel where he was holding a reception.
On the question of the Golan Heights, Mr. Rabin was said to be angered by press reports here that he was ready to discuss a complete Israeli withdrawal, and he insisted at his Cabinet's weekly meeting that he had nothing of the sort in mind.
 
Only Part
 Later, other officials said that when Israeli negotiators used the word "withdrawal" last week -- for the first time in their discussions with Syria -- it meant that Israel was willing to yield only some Golan territory and to redraw boundaries. Giving up the Golan entirely, as Syria demands for full peace and security arrangements, is out of the question, they said.
The Israeli offer, said Health Minister Chaim Ramon, who is close to the Prime Minister, involves "territorial changes on the Golan Heights, and not to leave the Golan Heights."
Nothing has been mentioned, other officials said, about what might happen to the three dozen Jewish settlements built there since the Golan was captured in the 1967 Middle East War.
The possibility that some settlements might be dismantled has generated protests, including one by several dozen settlers who camped today outside the Prime Minister's office during the meeting. They used loudspeakers to replay a campaign speech by Mr. Rabin, in which he said that Israel would be abandoning its security if it came down from the Golan Heights.
Before the weekend, Mr. Rabin described his offer of a partial withdrawal from the Golan as a test of Syria's readiness for peace. "If Syria rejects this," he told Israel television, "I will at least feel I did what is expected of a Prime Minister to take advantage of the chance for peace, to say I did everything to reach peace."
Israel's affirmation of its position, the gulf between Syria and Israel, the approaching Presidential elections in the United States and the latest violence are almost certain to affect the progress of peace talks in Washington. If nothing else, the violence is likely to reinforce Israel's argument that it must maintain its southern Lebanon buffer zone because the Syrian-dominated Lebanese Government has shown that it cannot control fighters from the pro-Iranian Party of God.
 
Convoy Bombed
 According to reports from Lebanon, the Israeli soldiers were killed when a roadside bomb planted by Party of God guerrillas exploded as their convoy passed just inside the Lebanese buffer zone. One soldier was killed immediately, four died later of their wounds, and five were less seriously wounded.
Reuters reported from Lebanon that Israeli artillery responded by pounding Party of God strongholds in the Bekaa region, north of the border zone.
The Hebron attack occurred near the Cave of Machpela, burial site of Old Testament figures. According to the Israeli Army, a Palestinian gunman let loose a burst of automatic fire at a military checkpoint, killing one soldier and lightly wounding another.
The slain man was identified as First Sgt. Shmuel Garish, a 32-year-old reservist from Rishon Lezion, near Tel Aviv. Brig. Gen. Moshe Yaalon, the army's West Bank commander, said that the Islamic fundamentalist group Hamas had claimed responsibility and that the purpose of the shooting was to disrupt peace talks.
Besides the round under way in Washington -- consisting of direct discussions between Israel and Syria, Jordan, Lebanon and the Palestinians -- negotiations began today on another track in The Hague. These are part of "multilateral" talks that involve some 35 countries on broad issues affecting the entire Middle East: arms control, economic development, refugee problems, water resources and the environment.
The "multilaterals" are supposed to complement and bolster the "bilateral" negotiations in Washington, but diplomats here caution that unless there is movement in the face-to-face talks, the region-wide discussions will remain little more than a sideshow.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
General Motors, once renowned for its profitability and vitality, is paralyzed by a crisis in its top management fed by predictions that Robert C. Stempel, the chairman, is on the verge of being pushed out by G.M. directors tired of the auto maker's gushing red ink. At a company that for generations had a well-defined system of succession, the situation has left employees confused about who is in command. [Page A1.] Whatever happens when the board meets next Monday, it seems clear that 11 outside directors are broadcasting a message that G.M. is not changing fast enough. [D5.]
A squabble between the chairman of the nation's largest bank, Citicorp, and the chief executive of a much smaller company highlights the debate over how stock options should be valued. [D2.]
 
The Economy
The gross domestic product figures to be published tomorrow -- one week before Election Day -- may give President Bush a final chance to contend that the economy has finally begun to emerge from its limbo. [D1.] 
 Orders for American-made machine tools jumped 16 percent in September from levels of a year earlier, reflecting heavy ordering last month at an industry trade show held every two years. [D1.]
Hard economic times are forcing changes on Rodeo Drive, the fashionable retail strip of Beverly Hills, Calif., where it is possible to spend $15,000 for a handbag. [D1.] At least one business is thriving: the Beverly Loan Company, the city's best-known pawnshop. [D3.]
 
International
Europe will eventually have a telecommunications market nearly as competitive as that of the United States, according to the chief executive of Belgium's telephone company. [D7.]
The Sunday Telegraph of Britain reported that the president of the European Community had a secret understanding with Bill Clinton to delay a world trade agreement until after the Presidential election. Mr. Clinton and his aides denied the report. [A14.]
 
The Media Business
American Express's dismissal of Chiat/Day/Mojo as the ad agency for its charge cards followed months of speculation that Chiat's position was deteriorating because its initial campaign had drawn mixed reviews. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D1.]
Americans watching Presidential debates and registering to vote in record numbers are buying masses of books about the candidates, the deficit, environmental problems and the way Government doesn't always work. Esther B. Fein: Publishing. [D8.]
The intense interest in this year's Presidential elections and the impulse toward cause-related advertising has resulted in a bumper crop of "get out the vote" messages. [D8.]
This year's hottest magazines appear to be Men's Journal and Sportsman, which feature articles like cave-diving in the Yucatan and dog sledding in the Arctic Circle. [D8.]
Audiences for syndicated shows are slumping badly despite Bill Cosby's "You Bet Your Life," the most eagerly anticipated syndicated series in years. [D8.]
 
Today's Columns
The stocks of cellular telephone companies in California plunged last week after a ruling by state regulators aimed at increasing competition there. Market Place. [D6.]
The aftermath of Canada's constitutional referendum could foretell events in the American bond market after the Presidential election. Jonathan Fuerbringer: Credit Markets. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Millionaire and Comptroller Square Off

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Oct. 25

 BODY:
As youngsters picked out Halloween masks at a shopping mall here and prepared their tricks or treats, candidates in Long Island's newly redrawn Third Congressional District sought out voters, conjuring up frightening images of their opponents.
"He's a zealot and an extremist on the abortion issue," said Stephen A. Orlins, a Democrat and self-made millionaire, pulling out all stops in describing his Republican opponent, Peter T. King, who is now Nassau County Comptroller. "He's out of touch with reality and has used his position to block a woman's right to choose." 
 Mr. King, a Catholic, says he has developed his own personal views against abortion and is not necessarily guided by the church's teachings. He called Mr. Orlins "a carpetbagger" who has lived in Manhattan for the last several years and who rented a house in Manhasset "only just this summer so he could make his first run for public office."
"He's got the money so the Democrats are willing to help him buy a seat in Congress," Mr. King said, although acknowledging that members of the House do not have to live within the district they represent.
 
A Party Loyalist
 The bitter race began when Representative Norman F. Lent, a Republican, surprised party leaders by announcing earlier this year that he was giving up his seat after 22 years in Congress. Republicans, anxious to hold onto a district that covers the central part of Nassau County, quickly chose Mr. King, a 48-year-old party loyalist who is well known among voters.
The Democrats picked Mr. Orlins, a 42-year-old political newcomer who has spent most of the last two decades building a brokerage business, which he sold to Shearson Lehman in 1985. After the sale, he served as president of the Asian division of the brokerage concern for three years and lived in Hong Kong.
He returned to the United States in 1990 and is now a consultant to American Express.
"I grew up in Nassau County," said Mr. Orlins, angered by Mr. King's assertion that he is an outsider. "In 1950, my family moved to Roslyn, where I went to nursery school, elementary school and high school.
"My values were formed in this district," Mr. Orlins added. "Since then I've lived all over the world and had a wealth of experiences that can now benefit the people of the district. I've built a business, as opposed to someone who has lived on the county and town payroll for the last 17 years."
 
'A Big Difference'
 Mr. King, who is married and has a son, Sean, 22, and a daughter, Erin, 18, speaks proudly of his service in public office, saying he has a "proven record" with the voters in Nassau County.
"Orlins was never around," he said. "There's a big difference between making millions for yourself and fighting for other people, putting your reputation and career on the line."
Mr. King, a Seaford resident, was a Hempstead Councilman from 1978 to 1981 and has been the Nassau Comptroller since then. The public has long identified him with the anti-abortion issue, and he has taken part in demonstrations organized by the Roman Catholic Diocese at Rockville Centre. But he denied Mr. Orlins's charge that he had "ever blocked entrances to abortion clinics or in any way broken the law."
Mr. King said he was "especially angered by an Orlins campaign advertisement in which a husband is informed by a hospital spokesman that his wife has been raped and is pregnant and that Peter King won't let her get an abortion."
"That ad really scrapes the bottom of the barrel," Mr. King said. "It's as if I were to run an ad saying that a father and mother had just learned that their teen-aged daughter might seek an abortion but that Steve Orlins would not let them find out."
Mr. Orlins said Mr. King "had every right to have his own opinion on the abortion issue."
"That's what democracy is all about," he said, "but when he calls for a constitutional amendment to ban abortion, he's subjecting every woman in this country to his own views over their right of choice."
 
Economic Issues
 Both candidates insist the economy is the major issue in the campaign. Mr. Orlins, however, is trying to portray his opponent as an an entrenched government bureaucrat, an assertion that Mr. King bristles at.
For instance, Mr. King says he "blew the whistle" on Nassau County's fiscal crisis in February 1991, "long before anyone else spoke out." This year the county has a $130 million gap in its $2 billion budget, and fighting between the Republicans and Democrats on the county's Board of Supervisors has stalled action on the deficit.
Mr. Orlins, for his part, argues that since Mr. King, as Comptroller, sits on the board, "he's part of the problem, rather than a part of the solution."
 
Other Candidates
 Two other candidates in the race are expected to draw some votes equally from Mr. King and Mr. Orlins. Louis P. Roccanova, 27, of North Massapequa, is running on the Right-to-Life Party ticket and may take votes away from Mr. King, while Ben-Zion J. Heyman, 59, of East Rockaway, is on the Liberal Party line, and may draw votes from Mr. Orlins.
There are 150,000 registered Republicans in the district, 87,000 Democrats and 60,000 independents. The district stretches along the South Shore from East Rockaway through Long Beach, Merrick, Bellmore, Seaford, Massapequa, Farmingdale and Hicksville and north through Locust Valley, Brookville, Glen Cove and Glenwood Landing on the North Shore.
Mr. King, who says his political role model is Jack F. Kemp, the Federal Housing Secretary, said he would support the balanced-budget amendment and vouchers allowing students to attend the public or private school of their choice. On health care, he supports allowing small businesses to deduct 100 percent of employee medical insurance premiums and improving medical malpractice tort procedures.
A graduate of Notre Dame University Law School, Mr. King opposes gun control but says he would support a mandatory 10-year minimum sentence for any crime committed with a firearm.
 
Harvard Law Graduate
 Mr. Orlins, who is married and has three daughters, Eliza, 9, Sabrina, 5, and Emily, 4, is a graduate of Harvard Law School. He said he opposes the balanced-budget amendment, which he calls a false mechanism to solve the country's fiscal problems. On health care, he said employers should either help provide health insurance for employees or pay into a government health-care program.
On the gun-control issue, Mr. Orlins favors passage of the Brady bill, with its mandatory waiting period for handgun purchases, and he is against providing school vouchers.
Representative Lent, 61, of Baldwin, has served in what was the old Fourth Congressional District since 1970, when he defeated Allard K. Lowenstein, a Democrat, by 9,300 votes. Many political observers say the vote in the King-Orlins contest could be even closer.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

NEW YORK CITY
 
MORE QUESTIONS IN DANIELS CASE
On a day of confusing signals in the controversy surrounding Randy Daniels, a Harlem rally in his support was abruptly canceled yesterday, and an adviser said Mr. Daniels was being pressured by City Hall to step down as a deputy mayor. At the same time, Mr. Daniels's lawyer announced that a multimillion-dollar libel suit would be filed this week against the woman who has accused him of sexual harassment. A1.
 
THE MAN IN THE EYE OF THE STORM
More than a dozen friends and colleagues of Randy Daniels who were interviewed in the last several days said they found it difficult to reconcile the accusations by Barbara Wood, a television reporter who worked briefly for Mr. Daniels in the office of City Council President Andrew J. Stein, with the man they know as a devout husband and father and a consummate gentleman. B3.
 
ANITA HILL REVISITED
Anita F. Hill lost her battle against Clarence Thomas a year ago, but the eerily similar sexual harassment charges that erupted in New York City last week demonstrate that she won a lasting moral victory. More Americans are infused with an acute sensitivity that no longer reflexively gives a man the benefit of the doubt. And that, part of Anita Hill's legacy, has been the heart of Randy Daniels's problem. Metro Matters, B3.
 
RAISING MORALE AMONG POLICE
Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said he met twice last week -- his first full week on the job -- with the leadership of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to explore ways to increase morale in the department. Mr. Kelly said he had met with Phil Caruso, president of the police union, and members of the executive board, "to identify some of the core morale issues that we can work cooperatively on." B3.
 
ONE LANDLORD'S STRUGGLES
As a private landlord renting to poor and nearly poor New Yorkers in a troubled neighborhood in Harlem, Harley Brooke-Hitching, is either a crucial provider of low-cost housing or a slumlord, depending on one's point of view. In either case, her risky real-estate speculation may yet prove her undoing. Strictly Business, B2.
 
REGION
 
D'AMATO RAISES ABRAMS SPECTER
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato is out to scare New York. Stalking senior citizens' homes, veterans' posts and defense industry plants all across the state like a bespectacled King Kong, the Republican incumbent is trying to spread terror, panic or even just a twinge of anxiety about the economic plans of his opponent, Bob Abrams. Mr. D'Amato has made his opponent's call for universal health insurance and major defense cuts the cornerstone of his campaign. And Mr. Abrams, the Attorney General, has been reduced to pleading that the Senator is distorting his views. B4.
 
BITTER L.I. CONGRESSIONAL RACE

B6.
 
A QUIET LEGACY OF CHARITY
DeWitt Wallace and Lila Acheson Wallace, who founded Reader's Digest, protected their privacy zealously, discouraged would-be biographers, left no diaries and destroyed their personal correspondence. When they died, he in 1981 at age 91 and she in 1984 at 94, their wills left no instructions about how their money should be used for philanthropy. But they had created two funds and seven organizations that will give away $150 million yearly. Those funds are only a part, albeit the largest part, of the Wallaces' charitable legacy. B6.

HEADLINE: D'Amato Sows Worry to Reap Votes

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato is out to scare New York. Stalking senior citizens' homes, veterans' posts and defense industry plants all across the state like a bespectacled King Kong, the Republican incumbent is trying to spread terror, panic or even just a twinge of anxiety about his opponent's economic plans.
"Bob Abrams is going to double your Medicare payments" he tells a cluster of wide-eyed elderly voters at an old-age home in Buffalo. He warned veterans at an American Legion post in Syracuse that Mr. Abrams would eliminate all veterans' benefits and shut down their V.A. hospitals. "It will be the end," he said ominously. "There would be no more veterans' benefits." 
 At Grumman headquarters in Bethpage, L.I., where almost half the staff has been laid off since 1986, his message was starker still. "Four hundred thousand jobs, we would lose, if he has his way, right here in New York," he shouted. Pointing at a huddle of assembled employees, he added, "If he gets elected, will these people have jobs?
Seeking a third term in the middle of a recession, Mr. D'Amato rarely talks on the stump about his own economic agenda. Instead, he has made his opponent's call for universal health insurance and major defense cuts the cornerstone of his campaign. In two or three, and sometimes four, appearances a day, staged for newspapers and television stations all across the state, he tells voters over and over that Mr. Abrams's proposals will raise taxes, cut benefits and cause massive layoffs.
Mr. Abrams, the Attorney General, has been reduced to pleading that the Senator is distorting his views.
 
Hyperbolic Math
 And while Mr. D'Amato has distanced himself from George Bush (his supporters have begun distributing "Clinton-D'Amato" buttons), his apocalytic warnings echo the President's. Like Mr. Bush, Mr. D'Amato says the Democratic candidate will raise taxes. Like Mr. Bush, Mr. D'Amato argues that while the economy is bad, it will grow much, much worse if his opponent is elected. And like Mr. Bush, he has questioned his rival's honor. Only Mr. D'Amato's style is different. On the stump, he is Joe Pesci in a pin-stripe suit: brash, guttural and relentless.
He has locked onto Mr. Abrams's on-again-off-again embrace of the Russo bill, a universal health care proposal made by Congressman Martin A. Russo, Democrat of Illinois. Mr. Abrams endorsed the plan last spring, but has since said he does not favor its financing mechanisms, which include higher personal taxes.
The Senator gleefully ignores Mr. Abrams's demurrals, insisting, "You can't have it both ways." Mr. D'Amato says flatly that Mr. Abrams "will cost New Yorkers at least 200,000 jobs and raise taxes on everybody."
Sometimes, even the Senator's math verges on the hyperbolic. When he tells some audiences that Mr. Abrams intends to "double" elderly people's Medicare payments, he is referring to an estimate that the Russo bill would require a 38 percent increase.
Mr. D'Amato assured employees at Grumman headquarters on Long Island that Mr. Abrams's call for a 50 percent cut in military spending would eliminate 400,000 defense-related jobs in New York. The D'Amato campaign calculates that there are 400,000 defense-related jobs in the state. "We assume everyone will lose their jobs," is how Kirill Goncharenko, an issues adviser to Mr. D'Amato, explained the Senator's figure.
 
'Little Guy' in Loafers
 His speeches are short, punchy and visceral. (He snaps at aides who hand him "boring" talking points.) Though he wears Hermes ties and tasseled loafers, Mr. D'Amato talks in the class-conscious code of "we" and "they," casting himself as the champion of the "little guy" fighting the establishment. He told members of Local 1087 of the Glaziers Union in Manhattan that he was "fighting the powers that be" in Washington.
And at large rally of conservative Jewish supporters in Borough Park in Brooklyn yesterday, Mr. D'Amato stood on a truckbed surrounded by rabbis and shouted that Mr. Abrams "is buried over there with an ultra-liberal elitist establishment that doesn't know what our people have to do to survive."
He frequently mentions his differences with the Bush Administration, saying he opposed Saddam Hussein long before Mr. Bush did. He brags that he did not vote in favor of the 1990 tax bill. Trying to cast Mr. Abrams as "hopelessly liberal" and on the far-left of the Democratic Party, Mr. D'Amato says he and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas support the death penalty and welfare reform, but that Mr. Abrams does not.
Mr. D'Amato, who was chastised by the Senate ethics committee for "improper and inappropriate" misuse of his office after a long investigation, seldom mentions the many charges of ethical misconduct that have been levied against him. He leaves that to his television ads, which lobbed a pre-emptive strike against Mr. Abrams on the issue of ethics by attacking the Attorney General's practice of taking contributions from people who do business with his office.
Occasionally, when addressing a particularly supportive crowd, like the Orthodox Jews in Borough Park, Mr. D'Amato lets some of his bitterness over his tarnished reputation slip through. He blames his enemies for his troubles.
 
Abhorring a Vacuum
 He alluded yesterday to the multiple allegations, saying that "people on both sides of the aisle have said to me, 'Alfonse, we're for you, and what has been done is wrong.' " He continued, "What Bob Abrams and his claque have done, or are attempting to do," he paused, and added, "and The Village Voice, and Mark Green, is absolutely wrong." Mr. Green, the Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, opposed Mr. D'Amato in the 1986 Senate election and raised some of the charges that were investigated by the Senate ethics committee.
Off the podium, Mr. D'Amato rails against his critics in the kind of language not often heard in the Senate cloak room.
Among even his ardent supporters, Mr. D'Amato inspires affection more than awe. His manner is playful, sometimes childish, usually on the far side of propriety. And when he gives a speech, Mr. D'Amato works even the smallest rooms with rib-digging affability, hugging supporters, and punching old friends in the arm. "Howyadoin, big guy," is his standard greeting for a stranger.
The Senator, like nature, hates a vacuum. While campaigning, he feels compelled to make antic conversation with everyone, even protesters. He could not ignore a small, fervent group of broom-wielding "Dump D'Amato" protesters in Astoria, Queens, this month. As they chanted, "hey, hey, ho, ho, Al D'Amato has got to go," Mr. D'Amato sidled up to them and, with a schoolyard smirk, began waving his hands like a conductor leading an orchestra. Unamused, the protesters chased him to his waiting car, chanting even louder.
In his speeches, Mr. D'Amato focuses on what he calls Mr. Abrams's "tax and spend" proposals and rarely speaks in specifics of his own economic plans. Mr. D'Amato says that Mr. Abrams wants to spend an additional $500 billion on health care. He says that he agrees that the national health-care system needs reform, but only through cost containment, more managed care centers and tax incentives for the uninsured.
He omits the fact that his health care proposal, the Chafee bill, is basically the same as Mr. Bush's. Asked what his proposals would cost, Mr. D'Amato shrugged and said he didn't know. The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, who was traveling with him, supplied the answer: $100 billion.
Mr. D'Amato does address social issues. He almost always brings up crime, telling voters that he supports the death penalty for drug kingpins and that he sponsored legislation to impose mandatory sentences on criminals who use a gun when committing a crime. "Use a gun, you're away," he says, addressing imaginary street punks. "You're going to jail, gone. Kill somebody, you're gettin' the death penalty."
And ever since Mr. Abrams called him a "fascist," Mr. D'Amato has not missed an opportunity to stoke Italian-American resentment by repeating the insult -- and enlarging upon it.
"I'm not going to get into the area that is most painful to me these recent days," he told 150 members of the Hudson Valley chapter of American Ex-POWs, several days after the incident. Then, he promptly did. "But let me tell you something: I do resent being called a fascist. It's wrong. It has no place in the political system." His voice quivering with indignation, he added, "To raise the specter of Goebbels, that infamous Nazi, as he has done, is wrong."
Lately, he has added the specter of Bella Abzug and Gloria Steinem to his recitation, saying that Mr. Abrams "stood by and laughed" as the two feminists called Mr. D'Amato a "Nazi" at a recent rally.
Mr. D'Amato does not hold many public rallies -- he says they are inefficient. His appearances, which are almost always followed by a private fund-raising event, are before small groups and rarely last more than 10 minutes. They mainly serve as backdrops for news conferences with local television, radio and newspaper reporters.
Sometimes, the pretext vanishes altogether. An appearance billed by Mr. D'Amato's campaign as a visit to the Buffalo Chamber of Commerce last Wednesday turned out to be a visit to the front door of the chamber of commerce; Mr. D'Amato stood in front of the entrance in the Statler Towers and told Buffalo reporters that his opponent would wreak "economic devastation" on New York.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Off the Trail -- Visits With Americans;
Odd Source Of Comfort For Feminist

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Male curmudgeonliness would seem to offer scant comfort to Pat Blumenthal, a 36-year-old feminist, working mother and field organizer in the politics of abortion rights, where absorbing accusations of woman's self-villainy is a part of the job.
But, to her delight, a colleague with a VCR saved for her the most unexpected sound bite in long years of her campaign issue, a terse, snappish statement of exasperation at all the moralistic combat over abortion uttered by one of the most patriarchal-looking of sources, James B. Stockdale, Ross Perot's running mate. 
 "I believe a woman owns her own body and what she does with it is her own business, period," he grumbled in the Vice-Presidential debate, glowering about as manfully as any man on either side the issue, his shock of white hair punctuating the replay memorably for Ms. Blumenthal.
She missed the live debate in which the retired admiral broke through his befuddlement at public speaking to spit out his position favoring a woman's right to choice on abortion. That night, Ms. Blumenthal, state director here of the National Abortion Rights Action League, was busy overseeing phone banks, mailings, campaign volunteers and Election Day logistics plans, the pick-and-shovel tasks of field work that underpin, in this state alone, dozens of contests in which the pro's and cons of abortion are a critical issue.
 
The Message and the Medium
 "I loved it," she said of Mr. Stockdale's position. "He stripped away all the language of both sides that was simplistic. It took someone like him to do that; for a woman to get up and say it would not have the same effect."
This was a statement of special bias for her because normally, Ms. Blumenthal says, she is weary of the public oratory on both sides of the issue and prefers backstage organizing to dramatic exhortations. She has spent half her life on some painstaking, mundane organizing of community groups, working here on such issues as utility rates, a neighborhood's fight to keep its grocery store, the right to relocation for public housing residents and senior citizens' need for a pressure group.
In the abortion controversy, Ms. Blumenthal exemplifies the dual political levels and looks of the issue in a year when attention is on the Presidency. On the national front, the issue is being heard less than in previous campaigns as the economy dominates voters' concerns and President Bush finds less advantage in raising it in the face of polls showing increasing support for abortion rights.
But here in Colorado, one of the abortion-rights movement's earliest bastions of relatively liberal acceptance, the issue's importance is mushrooming in the face of the Supreme Court's increasingly nip-and-tuck defenses of a woman's abortion rights. The statehouse politics of the issue are growing across the nation following the Court's rulings liberalizing the states' authority to try to qualify those rights.
 
Rising to Political Challenge
 In the last three years, the Court's wavering has helped the Abortion Rights Action League's membership and activities boom as women who thought the issue was settled in 1973 decided they must step into the public realm to learn grass-roots politics and bolster sympathetic politicians.
"Three years ago when I'd call people, they'd say, 'If you call my office, don't say who you're with,' " Ms. Blumenthal recalled. "And they were absolutely afraid of our bumper stickers. Now they're all over the place and I hear people proudly talking about having brought up the issue at the office."
No less impressive, however, Ms. Blumenthal is still reeling from the shock of last spring when the Christian Coalition and other fundamentalist political action groups quietly mounted what proved to be a highly effective blitz of the state's normally sparsely attended caucus system. They elected cadres of anti-abortion delegates who engaged in a flurry of unexpected primary fights over the issue in both parties.
So as a result of both growing support and growing challenge, the Colorado Abortion Rights Action League, which was involved in only one state legislative contest two years ago, is using extensive phone banks, television advertizing and volunteer help to focus this fall on 10 races that Ms. Blumenthal has judged most winnable. Her group's endorsement was sought by dozens of state candidates and granted to 48 of them, including 16 who are in head-to-head fights with anti-abortion candidates.
 
Vows to Emulate Enemies
 "It was hard, it was humbling, and it was a warning," Ms. Blumenthal conceded about the caucus lesson dealt by the opposition, whose political savvy she admires and is vowing to emulate in preparing her own caucus blitz in the next round of state legislative elections.
This year, the national office of National Abortion Rights Action League has sent two extra workers into the state to run a high-profile special expenditure campaign on behalf of Representative Ben Nighthorse Campbell, a Democrat who is running for the Senate against former State Senator Terry Considine. This is attracting national attention, but Ms. Blumenthal says her local staff of five faces a much longer haul on the less-noticed, no-less-important state level of the issue.
"It doesn't go away here," she said, sounding like a precinct captain in the trenches. "We're tougher and we're more political, but if we want to be viable we have to show that not only are we pro-choice, but we are electorally capable of producing."

Stockdale, Ross Perot's running mate, when he unequivocally defended abortion rights in the Vice-Presidential debate. Ms. Blumenthal spoke to her staff in Denver. (Michael Lewis for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Housing Lottery in a Bastion of Affluence

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 21

 BODY:
After six years of married life, two children, and a career path that had taken them to Newburgh and Syracuse, Gwen and Tom Pileski returned to their birthplace here a year ago and are still reeling from the shock.
For families like the Pileskis, she a 29-year-old nurse and he a 33-year-old corrections officer, this Long Island township ranks among the nation's least likely places to find affordable housing. With its manicured hedgerows and storybook estates, "even a rat trap costs more than we can afford," Mrs. Pileski said. 
 But for a select few, that will soon change.
In a government-subsidized housing program aimed squarely at the middle class, Southampton plans to build 30 houses, each on its own half-acre wooded lot adjoining a wilderness area, and each to be sold by lottery for less than $100,000.
"It's a long shot," said Mrs. Pileski, "but you don't pass up a chance like this."
 
Middle-Class Exodus
 Even before it was announced this week, rumors about the Southampton project had prompted more than 300 families, including the Pileskis, to seek applications for the lottery.
Now that it is official, the project's sponsors are bracing for an even bigger deluge of applicants seeking a piece of the fashionable Hamptons.
"Affordable housing is critical to us," said Fred Thiele, a 39-year-old native of Southampton and the town's Supervisor, who says that most of his contemporaries who grew up here have left, mainly because of housing costs.
"The perception of Southampton is one of glitz and wealth during the summer months," Mr. Thiele said. "But we have a lot of year-round residents who are struggling."
The affordable-housing program here is far from the first in the region. The programs have their roots in a broad national recognition, beginning in the 1980's, that lower-cost housing is needed not only for the poor, but also for the middle-income families of teachers, nurses, postal workers, plumbers and shopkeepers, people who have vital roles in the community but who cannot afford to live in the most affluent areas.
Most efforts have focused on the big cities. The New York City Housing Partnership, an eight-year-old group that uses state subsidies and inexpensive city-owned land, has built more than 7,000 homes, most of them attached town houses or multifamily buildings, and sold them for an average price of just over $75,000.
The Town of East Hampton, encompassing the lush summer resort areas at the eastern end of Long Island, has also been in the forefront of the push for affordable housing. It has built and sold more than 150 single-family homes since 1987, all on half-acre lots, for prices averaging under $80,000.
Still, "most of the suburbs have lagged behind," said Kathy Wilde, president of the New York City group. She estimated that an assortment of affordable-housing programs, involving government and private groups, has so far managed to build fewer than 2,000 homes in the New York suburbs of northern New Jersey, Westchester County, Fairfield County and on Long Island.
The homes planned here, and those already built in East Hampton, are unlikely to provide a useful model, because few communities have enough vacant land to set aside large lots for new homes. In most cases, experts say, making homes affordable means building them in dense clusters on small parcels of land.
The site to be developed here is hardly the most prestigious in Southampton, a township that includes some of the most affluent summer resorts in the Northeast, from Westhampton Beach to Bridgehampton
The 15-acre plot where the new homes are to be located is in East Quogue, just down a forested lane from the Montauk Highway, and next to a mobile home park.
 
3 Rms, Barrens Vu
 Still, even by the lofty standards of the Hamptons, the buyers of Southampton's affordable homes are certain to have attractive real estate. The site adjoins the Long Island Pine Barrens, a vast undeveloped tract along the geographical spine of the Island, and architectural plans dictate that each of the homes be built in a saltbox or cape style that conforms to the 17th- and 18th-century legacy of the area. Ten of the houses are to have two bedrooms, and 20 will have three bedrooms. Most will have two bathrooms, and will have a one-car garage and kitchen appliances, but basements are offered only as an option at added cost to the buyers.
The town, which is working with the Long Island Housing Partnership, was able to obtain the land in part because of the region's soft real estate market. The land had been owned by a major developer, Patrick Malloy 3d, who was unable to obtain zoning changes that he sought during the mid-1980's to build luxury homes. He then donated the site to Southampton in 1990 after the market for expensive homes had evaporated.
With free land, Southampton obtained subsidies from New York State, which maintains a large pool of affordable-housing grants. Each house completed in the project is to receive $25,000 in state subsidies.
With most of the financial details worked out, "marketing is going to be the easy part," said Jim Morgo, president of the Long Island Housing Partnership, which has hired architects and builders, and will act as developer. "There is going to be enormous demand."
 
Several Restrictions
 Southampton officials have not set a date for the lottery, but it will be before the end of the year. Construction is expected to begin in the spring, they said, and the houses will be completed by the end of October 1993.
To qualify for the homes, buyers must have household incomes below the median for Long Island, which is $55,000 a year for a family of four. They must also be first-time home buyers, and promise to remain in the homes for at least 10 years.
Anyone who buys one of the homes and sells it in less than 10 years will be required to pay back part of the $25,000 in state subsidies that have been granted for the home.
For those who live outside Southampton Township, the project offers little chance for a housing windfall. Although precise rules of the lottery have not yet been determined, town officials said they plan to give preference to Southampton residents, and might even give the highest priority to families who already live in East Quogue.
 
Cramped Living Conditions
 Among those who have already asked for applications are Janet DiBari, a 32-year-old nurse, and her husband, Nicholas, a 29-year-old maintenance worker.
Mrs. DiBari, who grew up in Southampton, said that remaining here with her family has been a financial struggle. Although the DiBaris have looked for homes they could afford, she said the closest thing they had seen was an old, dilapidated hulk priced at $125,000. That house would have required another $125,000 in repairs to make it habitable, she said.
For now, the DiBaris and their 2-year-old daughter, Christina, live in a cramped three-room cottage they rent from her parents, and talk constantly about whether it might make more economic sense to leave Southampton.
But that would all change if they win the Southampton affordable-housing lottery.
"There are only 30 houses, but our chances are as good an anybody's," Mr. DiBari said. "We are going for it."

HEADLINE: Sanford Renews Tough Senate Race

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 24

 BODY:
Senator Terry Sanford, at 75 the grand old man of North Carolina politics, returned to the campaign trail today after two weeks in the hospital to have a heart valve replaced.
He spoke briefly, saying it "sure is good to be back home" where his political career began, and introduced Senator Al Gore, the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, who told a roaring crowd, "We need Terry Sanford back in the Senate to help bring change." 
 But whether the Senate's oldest freshman will win a second term seems more in doubt than any other statewide race here, including the Democratic Presidential effort. Senator Sanford, who campaigns on a record that dates back beyond his governorship in the early 1960's, faces a stiff challenge from a former friend, Lauch (pronounced LOCK) Faircloth.
In the two weeks the Senator was hospitalized, momentum in the race shifted to Mr. Faircloth, whose campaign has hammered the incumbent with harsh television advertisements.
 
Ex-Democratic Fund-Raiser
 The challenger is a 64-year-old businessman and farmer who has never held elective office but has raised money for the Democrats and was appointed tp high-level jobs by various governors, including Mr. Sanford.
In September, a month before his hospitalization and before the television barrage began, Mr. Sanford held a big lead and said in an interview that the race "looks too good to be true."
It was.
Democrats say their polling shows Mr. Sanford was barely ahead on Thursday, when he left the hospital, although he has gained a bit since. On the same day Mr. Faircloth told Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate minority leader, that "we're a little ahead and gaining."
Carter Wrenn, executive director of the National Congressional Club, a political action committee that has helped Senator Jesse Helms and other North Carolina conservatives, said Friday that the race was within two or three percentage points either way.
Mr. Sanford predicted victory at a peppery news conference in Raleigh on Friday. He said his campaign had lagged in his absence, but added: "I've got time to catch up. I've got the energy to catch up. I've got friends to help me catch up."
 
Aspects of a Blood Feud
 He will need them all in what looks like a blood feud. While neither candidate discusses it, political insiders say the friendship broke up six years ago when Mr. Sanford, after a lifetime in North Carolina politics, decided to run for the Senate seat that had been held by James T. Broyhill, a Republican Congressman who was appointed to fill a vacancy caused by the death of John East. Mr. Faircloth, then a Democrat, felt it was his turn.
Mr. Faircloth became a Republican in February 1991, after Mr. Sanford voted against United States military action in the Persian Gulf. While that vote has not figured in this campaign yet, at the time it seemed like a great risk for a Southern Democrat.
Mr. Faircloth makes brief speeches before friendly audiences. He usually keeps attacks on his rival under wraps, although today in Asheville he called Mr. Sanford "controlled, bought and owned by the labor unions."
But Mr. Faircloth's real campaigning is done on television. And it is almost unceasingly negative. He portrays Mr. Sanford as a "big-spending Washington politician" and "too liberal." And, to play on the age and health issue, Mr. Sanford's pictures make him look old and feeble.
 
Against Kennedy and Welfare
 Much of the advertising campaign looks like golden oldies from the Congressional Club. Mr. Faircloth is running against Senator Edward M. Kennedy and welfare, just the way Senator Helms and other Carolina politicians have before.
Mr. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who is a totem of liberal evil here, is presented as the beneficiary of a Sanford vote for a highway bill that included a tunnel in Boston. Welfare, a traditional way of raising racial issues in Carolina politics, is brought in by ads portraying Mr. Sanford as a patron of welfare recipients.
Mr. Sanford, whose fund-raising efforts lagged when he was hospitalized, is on television, too, denigrating Mr. Faircloth's character, saying he conducted private business on the state payroll and labeling him a "front man for the Congressional Club."
At the news conference on Friday Mr. Sanford said he would get back out on the trail right away and campaign on issues like the economy and education. And he seemed ready for a scrape, grimacing as he said his foe's "youthful conduct" might become an issue and ridiculing arguments by Mr. Faircloth and Jack Hawke, the 51-year-old Republican state chairman, that his health and age made it doubtful he could complete another term.
The Senator took out an old-fashioned ear trumpet, saying Mr. Faircloth needed it because he wore a hearing aid. And he added that even though "I won't promise to go to Jack Hawke's funeral, I'll at least send a message."
He is getting a lot of help. Four Democratic Senators, though not Mr. Kennedy, have campaigned here for him. North Carolina Democrats are even more active. Former Gov. Jim Hunt, who is favored to win his old job back, campaigns for Mr. Sanford at every stop. And Johnsie Setzer, a fund-raiser, said she had spent today on the phone, urging freinds to help him.
Mr. Hunt said of the Senate race: "We can win it, but we've got to pull out all the stops. I'm pushing Terry everywhere. A lot of these people are not for him, but I'm pushing him."

Momentum in his re-election race shifted to his opponent during the hospitalization; Lauch Faircloth is challenging Senator Terry Sanford. (Photographs by Duane Hall for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Wallace Journal;
A Town Loses Jobs, Then Celebrates

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALLACE, La.

 BODY:
There was a celebration here recently for an occasion that would have caused despair in many other places: the cancellation of plans for a new industrial plant and its promise of hundreds of jobs.
The jobs, about 1,000 of them full time and 800 temporary, would have come with a $700 million wood pulp and rayon plant that the Formosa Plastics Corporation, which is based in Taiwan, planned to build here. 
 For decades Wallace, a mostly black rural village halfway between Baton Rouge and New Orleans, was ignored. But as the economy sagged and politicians sought foreign investment, a 1,740-acre plantation here was chosen by Formosa as the site of what would have been the world's largest wood pulp and rayon plant.
The plans were canceled in early October after bitter opposition by a coalition of environmentalists, preservationists and black residents here. They said they favor jobs but not more industrial pollution and damage to what is left of plantation country.
"My fight was not against jobs," Wilfred M. Greene, a 70-year-old retired school principal, said at the coalition's jambalaya and beer party at the Friends of Charity Hall here on Oct. 16. "My fight was against equating your life with jobs. That's wrong."
A Formosa official says the company canceled the project because the Environmental Protection Agency required a statement on the plant's effect on the environment, delaying construction, and because of a lawsuit filed by the owner of a neighboring plantation, Evergreen.
But the coalition had a part in it, too. For three years its members lobbied, nagged the environmental agency and gathered statistics on the plant's potential emissions.
"The plant would have discharged 16 billion gallons of waste water each year into the Mississippi River, which is the drinking water supply for more than a million people downstream in the New Orleans area," said William Fontenot, a state environmental specialist. "And the company would have needed about 8,000 tons of hardwood every day."
The coalition knows that the issue is a microcosm of a war that Louisiana now faces: jobs versus costs to the environment. And that war is being fought here in St. John the Baptist Parish, which straddles the Mississippi. The East Bank drew the heavy industry. Wallace, on the West Bank, was left with a view of smokestacks spewing clouds of steam into the air.
Not everyone is happy with the coalition's victory. Prof. Loren Scott of Louisiana State University calls the cancellation "a very big hit" to the state. The plant's economic effect, he said, would have been considerable.
High school dropouts could once find work at oil and chemical companies fairly easily. But in the last 11 years, 52,000 jobs were lost in the oil industry, and 3,500 jobs were lost in the chemical industry.
There have been changes in technology, too. "Plants have become more automated," Professor Scott said, "and now require fewer people with better skills."
The parish had already begun remedial high school education to prepare residents for jobs in the Formosa plant. Delton Arceneaux, the parish's director of economic development, said more than 1,000 people showed up recently to apply for a test to determine whether they met the minimum level of skills required for a job at the plant. That, he said, "shows you how hungry people are."
Parish records show that of 150 applicants who were tested, two-thirds scored below the 10th-grade level in reading and mathematics.
Next door to the party, Jessie Allen, who owns Allen's Bridge View Grocery and Deli, said: "I see nothing to celebrate. They're celebrating that young people are not going to get jobs. Formosa was to many of the people here a dream come true."
As for pollution, she said: "We've put up with pollution from plants that are already here. People here work in grain elevators and chemical plants. Anywhere, when you get out of bed in the morning you step into danger."
At the party Mr. Greene, the retired school principal, recalled the Formosa officials who tried to buy the riverfront land owned by his family since 1874. "They came in like carpetbaggers with bags of money," he said. "I had reached the point where I was willing to lose my property in the defense of it."

HEADLINE: Flap Over Value of Stock Options

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
John S. Reed is not a man too many people pick fights with. As the chairman of Citicorp, the country's largest bank, Mr. Reed is one of the nation's most powerful bankers and a prominent member of the Business Roundtable, an influential group of chief executives. So why is Gary L. Roubos, the chief executive of a much smaller company, calling Mr. Reed an ostrich?
The squabble involves how stock options are valued on a company's books. Last week, the Securities and Exchange Commission ruled that companies had to provide, in their reports to shareholders, some value for the stock options granted to executives. 
 But it stopped short of forcing companies to deduct that value from their earnings as they would other business expenses. That unpleasant task now falls to the Financial Accounting Standards Board in Norwalk, Conn., which makes accounting rules for the private sector.
 
 
Question of Cost
 Most chief executives clearly prefer the current rules, which allow companies to hand out as many stock options as they like without reducing their net earnings. Changing the rules, they feel, would only spotlight big pay packages and make some boards more reluctant to approve the deals.
The Business Roundtable is campaigning to convince the rule makers that options have no real cost, or at least that the cost cannot be measured reliably. But Mr. Roubos, chairman of the Dover Corporation, a New York-based manufacturing company with $2.2 billion in sales last year, thinks the group's view is dead wrong.
Though Mr. Roubos declined to be interviewed, Dover confirmed that he had sent a letter on July 2 stating his views on the subject to the Business Roundtable's policy committee and to Mr. Reed, who is the group's top policy maker on accounting issues.
 
 
Public Attention
 "It is ostrich-like to pretend that a stock option has no value at the time of grant," Mr. Roubos wrote jointly with his company's vice president for finance, John F. McNiff. "Corporate America undermines its credibility by trying to maintain this obvious fiction at a time when the spotlight of public, regulatory, and Congressional attention is focused on it."
Mr. Roubos's letter expresses a view already shared by many economists, accountants, politicians and shareholders, all of whom would like to see options treated on the books like all other major forms of compensation -- as an expense. But Mr. Roubos is the first chief executive to make the case.
Because stock options typically give executives the right to buy stock at a fixed price at any time for 10 years, the letter concedes that experts may disagree on the award's exact value on the day it is granted. But the letter asserts that an estimate, however rough, would be better than no number at all.
The letter also hints that continued inaction on the issue could jeopardize the tax deduction that companies take for the estimated cost of options when they are exercised.
 
 
'Ahead of Our Critics'
 "Pretending that option grants, however useful or appropriate, are somehow 'free' will increase the likelihood of our having to live with some other ideas becoming the rule," the letter states. It notes several proposals in Washington concerning executive pay issues, such as letting shareholders determine executive pay levels and placing limits on how much compensation expense companies can deduct from their taxes, an idea Gov. Bill Clinton has embraced.
"For once, let's get out ahead of our critics -- especially on a technical point where they are so obviously correct," the letter concludes.
A spokesman for the Business Roundtable said the letter was "the only one I'm aware of that took that position" and that it did not alter the group's view on the subject.
"The question of valuation is one that we've looked at, and certainly there are a number of experts who agree with us that it's a tricky thing to do with any kind of real accuracy," the spokesman said.
Analysts who follow Dover are not surprised by the letter. They note that Dover's management has always been candid about everything from cash flow to year-to-year performance in its shareholders reports. And Mr. Roubos can take the position he has, they say, because his company can afford it.
 
 
Modest Options
 Dover, which makes elevators and other industrial products, has made tens of millions of dollars every year since Mr. Roubos took charge in 1981. Still, the company has used options modestly. Last year, Mr. Roubos received cash compensation of $765,000, a $39,875 long-term bonus, plus 19,110 options, a benefit that consultants value at about $266,000. The entire employee group, including Mr. Roubos, received options valued at about $2.9 million.
If the company had to reduce its earnings by the estimated value of its stock options, the result would be only a slight dent in the $204.1 million in pretax earnings the company had last year.
Like Mr. Roubos, Mr. Reed has not been among the largest receivers of stock options. Last year, Citicorp awarded him a $1.2 million salary, plus 300,000 options valued at about $687,420. It gave another $11.1 million of options to its other employees. But since Citicorp's earnings tend to be erratic, a charge against earnings for the value of the options could be more noticeable to shareholders.
