HEADLINE: Hard Times, Even on Rodeo Drive

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Oct. 25

 BODY:
In a memorable scene from the movie "Pretty Woman," a prostitute played by Julia Roberts goes into a boutique on Rodeo Drive here only to be turned away by snooty sales clerks who say they have nothing in her size.
For years, snobbery has been a hallmark of this city of wealth and glamour, movie stars and entertainment honchos, where it is possible to spend $20,000 for a watch, $6,000 for a suit with 14-karat gold pinstriping or $15,000 for a handbag of rare leather. 
 But business and community leaders here say that in these hard economic times even Beverly Hills can no longer afford to be so exclusive. A sharp decline in sales of luxury items, a glut of commercial real estate and a dearth of tourists in the last two years are changing its retail landscape.
 
'Open Arms' Policies
 To attract a broader customer base, even at the risk of bringing in buyers previously deemed to lack the right "look," retailers have adopted "open arms" policies, training their staffs to be less discriminating and to push low-ticket as hard as high-ticket items.
To fill vacancies that began to appear for the first time two years ago, the city is bringing in retailers that previously would not have met its snob quotient like Guess Jeans and Banana Republic. "These new stores will bring in more excitement and a broader spectrum of customers," said Donald Tronstein, who owns three buildings that house 11 shops on Rodeo Drive. "We are cultivating people who will graduate to the couture line in a few years."
Not everyone seems as captivated by the notion.
Asked if they welcomed moderately priced retailers like Guess, which plans to open a 7,000-square-foot-store at 411 Rodeo Drive at month's end, most shop owners on the drive declined to comment. But an owner of a women's boutique several doors from the new Guess shop said: "What can you do? It's a sign of the times. I'm just thankful it's Guess and not the Gap. That would be horrendous."
Yet more midline merchandise may be on the way. The chamber and the city are trying to promote Beverly Hills as an "outdoor shopping mall" with something for everyone. As part of that effort, the city is helping retailers negotiate lower rents and eliminate red tape. In the past, many businesses avoided a Beverly Hills address because of the exorbitant rents and the bureaucratic morass they met in obtaining a license to operate a new enterprise.
 
'Warmer and Friendlier'
 "We are a warmer and friendlier society," said Bill Boyd, executive director of the Beverly Hills Chamber of Commerce. "We want people to come here and spend $10 to $10,000."
There are four main shopping fares here. Rodeo Drive, the most celebrated, is known mostly for its high-priced boutiques; Wilshire Boulevard, for its expensive department stores; Beverly Boulevard, for its basic American merchandise, and Robertson Boulevard, for its broad mix of shops.
But in recent years, all these addresses have faced increased competition from new malls like the Beverly Center and the West Side Pavilion. Meanwhile, a persistent recession and the riots in Los Angeles have greatly reduced the number of tourists to the area. In addition, it is now de rigueur for the rich to dress more modestly.
Many stores are trying to offset declines in sales by pushing moderately priced merchandise. "Instead of selling a lot of $700 jean jackets," Mr. Boyd said, "some stores are selling dozens of signature T-shirts to people who can't afford to buy but are browsing and want to take something home from Beverly Hills."
Carroll & Company, a men's store that has been on Rodeo Drive for 42 years and caters to the business establishment, is now offering a moderately priced line of contemporary clothing for younger men, called John Carroll, named for the son of the owner, Robert Carroll.
 
Attracting Younger Customers
 "For decades we catered to the successful businessman," John Carroll said, "but that customer base is now shrinking and we have had to adjust to attract the younger man who can't afford $1,500 for a suit or $1,000 for a sweater."
Donald M. Tallarico, who owns Tallarico jewelers on Rodeo Drive, where a typical piece of jewelry costs about $20,000, said his sales were off by 30 percent in the last year mainly because of a shift in spending patterns by the rich to more conservative items. For example, instead of buying a showy $50,000 platinum bracelet suitable for parties, customers are more likely to buy a more versatile gold and diamond piece for $25,000, he said.
The jeweler said that some days more than 20 people wandered into the store and other days no one called. "Our sales people are not walking around with their noses in the air, I can tell you that," Mr. Tallarico said. "When business walks through that door, we grab it. But you know you have to be pretty confident in your taste to walk in a store of this nature," referring to the shop's bright white carpet, which he said many people found intimidating.
Winnie Schweitzer owns three Rodeo Drive designer stores, Krizia, Ungaro and Gianfranco Ferre. Her sales, which come mainly from a wealthy foreign clientele, have dropped 30 percent in the last year because of the recession and the decline in tourism, especially from Japan. "It's a big change," she said. "Over all, business is much tougher and we would welcome new business from right here at home."
 
Holding Their Own
 Some shop owners say that business has never been better and that they have always treated all customers well. Lois Petren, a marketing representative for the Polo Store on Rodeo, said that sales were up and that high-priced items continued to move. "People are not intimidated in our store, and that's why we continue to have good traffic," Ms. Petren said. "We work very hard to make everyone feel important. It's a very traditional, old world approach to retailing, and it works."
Despite a big drop in tourism here, some shop owners say they are holding their own because they have a strong local customer base. "The key to success on this street is not to rely on the casual customer or tourist," said Francine Bardo, managing director of the House of Hermes. "We are more community oriented, and our longtime customers keep coming back."
But the recession has clearly forced some Beverly Hills businesses to close. Beverly Hills had a surplus of commercial space for the first time two years ago when there was 1.7 million square feet of vacant space, or a 26.2 percent vacancy rate in July 1990. That has declined to 1.1 million square feet, or a 17.3 percent vacancy rate as of July 1992, mainly because of the city's effort to woo new businesses, according to the city's Chamber of Commerce.
City officials have been actively recruiting new businesses, especially entertainment companies, law firms and banking concerns. Playboy Enterprises, ICM International, Chase Manhattan and United Talent Agencies recently opened offices here.
"The biggest negative we have working against us is that people believe they can't shop or operate a business in Beverly Hills," said Mark Scott, the city manager. "They think that it's just too expensive. But people are starting to realize that rents have gone down and that has brought in new types of business and perhaps a new approach."

HEADLINE: The Economy's Final Report Card Before Election

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Voters may react mainly to what happens to jobs and wallets. Economists respond to other measures, including the broadest and most revealing indicator of economic performance, which comes each quarter when the Commerce Department adds up the dollar value of all goods and services produced on American soil.
With publication of that figure, the gross domestic product, on Tuesday -- a week before Election Day -- President Bush may get one final chance to contend that the economy has finally begun to emerge from the rare limbo between recession and recovery in which it has hovered since mid-1991. 
 Many recent major indicators -- the balance of trade and industrial production, for instance, have been downbeat, although Mr. Bush has complained that not enough attention had been paid to several positive signs, including low inflation and a drop in the weekly number of new claims for unemployment benefits.
 
Employment and Unemployment
 Mr. Bush told a campaign rally on Saturday, for example, that the news media were not announcing that the employment rate was 93 percent. In the latest monthly figures, the Labor Department reported that the unemployment rate was 7.5 percent -- which is what most of the news media reported -- while 57,000 nonfarm payroll jobs had been lost, a number that economists look at more closely than the unemployment rate.
On balance, the recent economic news has prompted widespread trimming of expectations for the July-September quarter.
Many private analysts now expect the gross domestic product to rise at an annual rate of less than 1.5 percent, the pace recorded in the spring. On the other hand, given the economic and methodological uncertainties, growth might be significantly higher.
"A number above 2 would be great for the President," acknowledged Laurence H. Meyer, a man with ties to the Clinton campaign who heads a consulting firm in St. Louis bearing his name. "Two and a half would be a tremendous boost."
But the most likely cause of such a figure would be a surge in inventories, and that would be a mixed economic blessing at best, many economists say. They tend to view higher inventories more as the result of involuntary buildups of unsold material than of newly optimistic retailers intentionally stocking more goods.
And even the a strong G.D.P. report would not necessarily translate into votes, asserted Neil S. Newhouse, a partner in Public Opinion Strategies, a Virginia firm that polls on behalf of Republicans. "The only mileage you can make is if it reinforces what Americans already feel," Mr. Newhouse said. "In the absence of other positive signs it's probably too late to have a significant impact on the election."
Another report to be released on Tuesday will come from the the Conference Board, a business research group based in New York that surveys consumer confidence each month, and here there is little expectation of signficant improvement. The consumer sector has been one of the few to show a bit of spark lately, at least in part involving replacement of hurricane losses, but September's third straight monthly decline in confidence, to 56.4, suggests this may not be sustained.
No matter how high the third-quarter G.D.P., moreover, it will not inspire the country's designated arbiter of business cycles -- the dating committee of the National Bureau of Economic Research -- to announce the formal end to the lingering recession that began in July 1990. For one thing, such a call so close to Election Day would probably be politically explosive, even though the chief arbiter, Robert Hall, a Stanford economics professor, has insisted that the election would not prevent such a call if the evidence demanded it. But the committee's own benchmarks, more diverse than just the G.D.P., still do not justify it.
A sixth straight quarter of economic expansion, even if token expansion, might seem evidence enough to pronounce the recession over. If two quarterly contractions in a row constitute recession, as popular shorthand has it, then why shouldn't 18 months of uninterrupted expansion bring recession to an end?
Indeed, Tuesday's report of a sixth straight expanding quarter will almost certainly show the economy finally surpassing the level of the second quarter of 1990. In other words, it will have regained all the ground lost during its three negative quarters -- the final one in 1990 and the first two in 1991.
 
Small Quarterly Gains
 But the quarterly gains so far have averaged only 1.6 percent a year, barely one-quarter of the first-year average for postwar recoveries and only half the pace needed to keep unemployment from rising.
The seven members of the dating committee, all academicians, use far more than than the G.D.P. to determine economic peaks and troughs. These are implied in the National Bureau's formal definition of recession: "a recurring period of decline in total output, income, employment and trade, usually lasting from six months to a year and marked by widespread contractions in many sectors of the economy."
Specifically, the committee monitors industrial production, nonfarm payrolls, factory and trade sales, and personal income excluding transfer payments like Social Security benefits, crop subsidies and interest on Treasury securities. It also gives some weight to the G.D.P. Of the five indicators, three remain below pre-recession levels.
Still, formal determination of the end of the longest of the nation's nine postwar recessions may not be far off. In an interview today, Professor Hall allowed that it "could be before" early 1993. Tuesday's report, he said, is likely to "begin to set the stage."
Nevertheless, 17 months have elapsed since May 1991, the month many analysts think will be designated as the recession's end, suggesting unusual caution by the committee. It took nine months, until April 1991, to announce the onset of the latest recession, and only six months and eight months, respectively, to call the beginning and end of the sharper recession of 1981-1982.
 
Factors Hampering Recovery
 "I assume they don't want to have to say down the road that they were wrong," said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
Some of the more obvious factors preventing brisk recovery are heavy debt burdens, decreased prices of real estate and other tangible assets, a shrinking military contracting industry and reticence by banks to lend money to human customers when an exceptionally steep yield curve -- longer-term interest rates much higher than short ones -- provides almost irresistible returns for risk-free loans to the Government.
But economists seem inclined to reject the notion that months of political speeches about a poor economy, even when misrepresented and for a time unchallenged by a Bush Administration fearful of being deemed out of touch, do much to damage consumer or business psyches.
"This may not have helped any, but it's not clear it hurt," commented Donna Zerwitz, spokeswoman for the National Bureau. She said this was because sentiment, which on the Conference Board's gauge hit a 17-year low of 47.3 in February, had dropped so far before the campaign started.
One of the more sober views of the upcoming G.D.P. figures is that of Michael P. Niemira, economist at Mitsubishi Bank in New York. He predicts a 2 percent rate of growth for the third quarter, a bit less than before the latest trade figures were released, but says that "arithmetic" will make the gain appear much better than it is.
Consumption will prove unsustainable, he said, while a boost from inventories will "evaporate" in the fourth quarter. Periods like this, when recovery is just under way and lowered interest rates help release some pent-up demand, Mr. Niemira added, usually show the best growth of the business cycle. If the best is already at hand, he mused, the future could be grim indeed.

HEADLINE: STRICTLY BUSINESS;
A Lament of One Landlord: From Riches to Rags

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
It is a typical day at Equities Ltd., the 11 tenement buildings in East Harlem that Harley Brooke-Hitching so loftily named when she bought them.
A pregnant woman, homeless until now, sits with the office manager doing paperwork that will enable her to get city subsidies to live in one of Ms. Brooke-Hitching's 180 apartments. The woman is thrilled that she won't have to give birth in a shelter. 
 Ms. Brooke-Hitching pats her softly on the shoulder as she steps outside into the ceaseless salsa beat of the barrio. This slight, 40-something, redheaded woman seems an unlikely candidate for her chosen vocation: as a private landlord renting to poor and nearly poor New Yorkers in a troubled neighborhood, she is either a crucial provider of low-cost housing or a slumlord, depending on one's point of view. In either case, her risky real-estate speculation may yet prove her undoing.
Her father was a British aristocrat, her mother from Oklahoma, where she was born. She grew up on both sides of the Atlantic, was a high-school cheerleader in Oklahoma City and studied art at the Sorbonne. Early jobs included setting up an exclusive club for well-heeled visitors to London and opening an Amsterdam office for Sotheby's.
After a short marriage to an international banker, she stayed on in Bangkok and became a large and successful dealer in Asian art. She raised her son, Matthew, now 18, as a single mother, came to New York in 1980 and proceeded to make a small killing on co-op conversions.
She is the founding chairwoman of City Harvest, a charity distributing surplus food to the needy. She carries a licensed handgun.
Ms. Brooke-Hitching, who lives in an airy Upper East Side apartment that opens into a 37-foot-long greenhouse, came north to Harlem in 1985 to profit from the soaring real-estate market. She reasoned that you could multiply your fun by buying more for less in a marginal neighborhood. She bought her buildings one by one, flipping a couple of early ones -- industry jargon for immediately selling a newly purchased property -- as if to prove her intuition.
Then things got tough. Part of it is the drugs and the crime that seem only to worsen. Mute testimony occupies a dish on her desk: it is full of spent shells she collected in and around her buildings.
The value of her 11 buildings rose by 1989 to $4.5 million from the $3.1 million she paid for them, but it has surely fallen since. Today, she says she would be very lucky to get back the purchase price.
A bigger problem looms. Costs have skyrocketed -- from taxes to water and sewage fees to oil costs -- and relief is nowhere in sight. And like many owners, she paid too much. Perhaps most ominously, she signed personally for a number of loans.
It is scant wonder Ms. Brooke-Hitching lies awake nights worrying that her entire $3.5 million investment -- including $1.1 million in cash -- will be lost.
 
A Worry for Tenants, Too
 The stakes may be higher still for the more than 600 people she houses in apartments that fetch from $79 a month for a rent-controlled one-bedroom to $720 for a newly renovated three-bedroom.
Her little real-estate empire, with its cab drivers who sleep in shifts and aromas bespeaking faraway places, is made up of the kind of dwellings familiar to millions of New Yorkers.
She greets a hairdresser from the Ivory Coast who has lived in an Equities apartment for two years and is frequently frightened in this often cold city. She again unsuccessfully tries to persuade some tenants from Mexico, new arrivals, that they could sell more flowers if they arranged them more smartly.
She stops at the apartment of Ndao Daouda, who came to America from Senegal in 1984 with $47 and now peddles T-shirts and socks on East 116th Street. Mr. Daouda is the one who visits her when one of her many Senegalese tenants has a complaint or can't pay rent on time. "When we talk together, we understand each other," said the man Ms. Brooke-Hitching calls "the diplomat."
 
Major Source of Housing
 It is impossible to overstate the importance of this type of privately owned housing in New York City's struggling neighborhoods. Over the last decade, the million immigrants to this region have settled mainly in places like this. So will the million more expected this decade.
Of the million welfare recipients in New York City, many also end up in such housing. So, too, do the working poor. One of Ms. Brooke-Hitching's tenants is a Mexican man who commutes to Brooklyn to work 12 hours a day in a Korean grocery.
The Citizens Housing and Planning Council calculates that there are 350,000 units of private housing in areas of New York City with a poverty rate over 25 percent. At least twice as many people live in such private housing as in projects run by the Housing Authority.
The true number is obscured by the doubling and tripling up of families in apartments. This is a direct result of the impossible cost of living in New York City: the median rent of a two-bedroom apartment is $600 -- about twice welfare's housing allowance for a family of three, and far beyond the reach of most immigrants.
"Literally half the people who live in this city don't earn what it takes to pay for housing here," said Kathryn Wylde, senior vice president of the New York City Housing Partnership.
So they make do. They combine welfare, jobs in the underground economy, whatever. And they find apartments like those offered by Ms. Brooke-Hitching.
 
Not the Ritz
 To be sure, the accommodations in some such buildings are shameful. Repairs are infrequent, heat and hot water chancy at best. Some landlords physically threaten tenants and illegally enter their apartments, Ms. Brooke-Hitching said.
The problem is that poor New Yorkers desperately need somewhere to live, and landlords who cater to them claim to be an endangered species. Though it is the same complaint some have been making since time immemorial, the case is gathering weight.
"Private property owners have never faced the steepness of the hill they've got in front of them right now," said John Gilbert, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, composed of 25,000 landlords. Under the rent-stabilization process, the city and state regulate the rent of about 60 percent of the city's rental housing.
Mr. Gilbert said 16 percent of all apartment buildings in the city are so pressed they are a year or more behind in property taxes.
The rapidly rising cost of water and sewer fees -- up 169 percent since 1987 -- is generating the most pain. And water fees have increased ten-fold and more for some buildings where water meters have been installed, as they must be in all buildings by 1997. Under rent regulations, these charges cannot be automatically passed on to tenants.
The Citizens Housing and Planning Council, which analyzes housing issues from a public-interest perspective, warns that 50,000 units of private rent-regulated housing are in "immediate jeopardy of lapsing into abandonment or city ownership."
Joseph B. Rose, executive director of the council, said, "We're on the brink of a precipice."
 
More Problems Loom
 Ms. Brooke-Hitching feels she might already be falling off a cliff. To be sure, some would say she speculated and lost, and that's part of the game.
But whether or not the injury is deserved, Ms. Brooke-Hitching complains that it is accompanied by much insult. Her scars range from routinely losing on her many trips to Housing Court -- a result, she says, of a pro-tenant bias there.
There is also the upcoming problem of stricter city standards on lead paint. Generations of paint cake the walls of the buildings and could be a huge expense to remove. Recycling garbage also proved difficult during a pilot program due to what Ms. Brooke-Hitching characterizes as tenant uncooperativeness. She paid many fines.
"Around here an environmental issue is not having your kid shot," she said.
On the plus side, Ms. Brooke-Hitching has paid for most major capital improvements, including new boilers, plumbing, windows and doors. Though it took two and a half years of waiting and a lawsuit against the city, she was allowed to raise rents 6 percent. The wait hurt her tenants perhaps as much as it did her: the rent increase was retroactive, leaving them owing large back-rent bills. What might have been another plus, lower interest rates, has not helped as much as it might have, as only 1 of her 11 mortgages is variable.
So the bills pile up. She owes $50,000 to an oil company and $60,000 in back taxes. The city has notified her that it will seize one building, the one more than a year behind in taxes, if she does not pay up.
She dimly remembers how she felt at the beginning, before a drug dealer gave her a black eye, before the girlfriend of a disheveled addict accused her of paying the man for sex. Before she risked losing her entire savings.
"I was so confident and optimistic," Harley Brooke-Hitching recalled. "I was fearless."
And now? "I feel like a rat in a cage."

She spoke as her work crew repaired one of her 180 apartments in East Harlem. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Up 16% After Industry's Trade Show

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Orders for American-made machine tools jumped 16 percent in September from levels a year earlier, the Association for Manufacturing Technology reported yesterday.
The association said the increase reflected heavy ordering last month at an industry trade show that is held every two years. 
 The association, based in McLean, Va., valued September's orders at $283.8 million.
September sales were up 77.1 percent from August, the largest month-to-month increase in two decades. Machine tool orders, which often swing widely from month to month, are one measure of industrial production and capital spending by manufacturers. The statistic combines figures for orders of metal-cutting and metal-forming machines used to produce goods from refrigerators and cookware to automobiles and aircraft.
"The trade show had a lot to do with the jump," said James Paper, an analyst with Kirkpatrick Pettis, a regional brokerage firm in Omaha. Mr. Paper said the increase might also reflect some optimism that Gov. Bill Clinton would win the presidential race, and that a Clinton Administration would grant investment tax credits.
Albert W. Moore, the industry association's president, said many association members postpone purchases until the International Manufacturing Technology Show in Chicago in early September every other year. "It's one-stop shopping," he said.
As a result, many orders were probably placed in September that would have otherwise been made in the final quarter. "Due to the deepening decline in export orders, it is unlikely that the industry will post a fourth quarter equal to the $798 million posted in 1991," Mr. Moore said.
Through September, export orders were down 32.8 percent from the previous year.
With so many caveats, analysts said yesterday that the September figures shed little light on the economy's health.
Even so, the last time the industry association reported such a strong month-to-month gain was from November to December 1970, when orders climbed 79 percent, according to Patrick McGibbon, director of statistics at the industry association.
So far this year, machines tool orders have totaled $1.92 billion, a 3.9 percent increase over the comparable period last year.
Of the $283.85 million in total September orders, $53.05 million were sold for export and $230.8 million were placed by American companies.

HEADLINE: China Reacts To Trade Pact

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 25

 BODY:
China will step up trade activities in Canada, the United States and Mexico to minimize the effects of the North American Free Trade Agreement on Chinese businesses, a top trade official here says.
Wang Zhiquan, a leading member of the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations and Trade, was quoted in today's Business Weekly newspaper as saying the agreement's lower tariffs could increase Mexico's exports of low-cost goods to the United States and Canada at the expense of China. 
 China sold $19 billion worth of goods to the United States last year, representing a quarter of its exports.
Mr. Wang, deputy director of the ministry's department on American affairs, told the paper that to maintain market share after 1994, when tariffs start to drop, China should increase export credits to buyers of Chinese machinery and electronics, set up trade distribution centers and encourage its enterprises to start joint ventures in North America.
The Business Weekly reported that China had set up a number of Mexican enterprises in hopes of getting around tariff and quota barriers set up by the agreement.
It said the Ministry of Textiles was hoping by the end of the year to sign a joint venture contract with Always Best of Los Angeles to build a mill to make T-shirts and underwear in Hermosillo in northwestern Mexico with a $500,000 investment.

HEADLINE: A Pawnshop to the Rich: Business Is Picking Up

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Oct. 25

 BODY:
The chic boutiques and high-priced department stores here may be emptier today than they have been in the past, but at least one business is thriving in this stubborn recession: the Beverly Loan Company. It is perhaps this city's best-known pawnshop, at least to some.
With credit tight and unemployment high, more people are turning to pawnbrokers for short-term loans to tide them over. 
 But if you are looking to pawn a color television or electric guitar, Beverly Loan is not the place to go. Catering mostly to well-to-do residents of Beverly Hills and the west side of Los Angeles, this pawnbroker deals almost exclusively in expensive jewelry or precious metals, like the Rolex watch and other jewels that an auto dealer recently pawned to get $10,000 to make his payroll. Or the diamond and gold jewelry that a Beverly Hills woman pawned for $8,000, which she needed to pay her bill at Chanel. She wanted to buy a new dress there but had exceeded her credit limit.
The number of loans the shop is making has been increasing in the recession. "It's quick, fast and fairly painless," said Jean Zimmelman, who runs the 54-year-old company with her sister Helaine. "People love the confidentiality. They don't want their bankers or friends to know they are down on their luck. We are not interested in a credit history because the loan is based solely on collateral."
Beverly Loan is one of the few pawnbrokers in the country that makes loans of more than $10,000. One famous customer was the sister of King Farouk of Egypt, who in 1972 pawned her mother's royal jewels for $369,000 after she was disowned for marrying a commoner.
Recently, the pawnbroker has started accepting fine pieces of art as collateral, but "only the contemporary stuff that I like," Jean Zimmelman said. A woman recently pawned an Andy Warhol for $1,500 to pay for her wedding. A man brought in a Keith Haring to get $3,000 to buy a car.
Unlike rates in the banking industry, pawnshop rates are regulated by the state, but loans of more than $2,500 are set by the pawnshop based on the value of the collateral. Beverly, which says it has a 20 percent foreclosure rate, generally charges about 4 percent a month for loans exceeding $2,500. In California, the term of a pawn loan is five months.
"This is a glitzy town and some people feel they have to maintain a life style no matter what. Others just need the money to survive," Jean Zimmelman said. "We don't ask any questions. We are here to make life easier."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
American Express in Ad Shift

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
The American Express Company has dismissed Chiat/Day/Mojo from creating and producing sales pitches for its charge cards, less than a year after it awarded the New York advertising agency the $60 million account.
The decision, made late Thursday, followed months of intense speculation that Chiat's hold on the prestigious account was loosening because its initial campaign had drawn mixed to negative reviews and was perceived as failing to help reverse the company's sagging share of the charge card market. 
 Chiat won the account away from Ogilvy & Mather, which had handled the American Express card for 29 years, in an intensely fought competition, and its ads were a sharp departure from Ogilvy's "Membership has its privileges" campaign, which featured celebrities like Ella Fitzgerald, Tom Seaver and Paul Newman in warmly emotional settings.
 
Pressured by the Recession
 This second change of agencies at American Express is yet another sign of how some large marketers have responded to sagging sales during the nation's economic slump. Fruit of the Loom, Mastercard, Miller Brewing and Subaru of America have also changed advertising agencies in recent months.
But clearly these changes do not always produce the desired effect.
"There's tremendous risk when you change," said Philip W. Sawyer, editor of Starch Tested Copy, a publication from Starch INRA Hooper in Mamaroneck, N.Y., which measures consumer response to print ads. "There's the potential for breakthroughs and also the potential for failure."
In a Starch test this summer, magazine readers preferred the Ogilvy New York campaigns to Chiat's, which presented oversized green and gold charge cards as consumer icons.
 
 
'A Tough Decision'
 A spokeswoman for American Express in New York called the dismissal "a tough decision," adding that Chiat/Day/Mojo had "done some very fine work."
The decision does not mean, however, that American Express will return the account to Ogilvy New York. Instead, the spokeswoman said, the financial-services giant will undertake "a whole re-examination of how we do things." That could involve introducing a global campaign and restructuring its accounts worldwide, now handled by various advertising and direct-marketing agencies.
Among the shops involved, the spokeswoman listed Chiat/Day/ Mojo, which continues to handle the gold charge card account in Britain; Ogilvy New York; McCann-Erickson, which works for American Express in Japan; Wunderman Worldwide, and Young & Rubicam, Wunderman's parent.
In the meantime, the spokeswoman said, American Express will expand nationally a test campaign Ogilvy introduced on Aug. 30, consisting of television commercials that paint flattering portraits of restaurateurs and merchants who accept American Express cards. The commercials, which have been running in Atlanta, Los Angeles and New York, were aimed primarily at rebuilding relationships with service establishments that had complained that the company's fees were too high.
Ogilvy New York created the test campaign because the less glamorous service establishment account remained with it after the charge-card assignment was shifted to Chiat/ Day/Mojo.
The American Express spokeswoman said the financial-services company had been so "delighted with the response" to the test "that we decided we didn't want to have two campaigns on the air at once."
That spelled doom for Chiat/Day/ Mojo, which had been working on a second phase of its campaign, scheduled to be introduced on Nov. 11, that was intended to be as warm and fuzzy as anything Ogilvy New York could produce. The spokeswoman praised those commercials but said the test demonstrated that Ogilvy New York's campaign spoke to consumers as well as to store and restaurant owners.
"We're delighted," said Rochelle Lazarus, president of Ogilvy New York. "We set out to do a campaign that celebrated American Express's relationship with the service establishments, and they felt it had legs, that it did a lot for the brand and reminded everyone what American Express was all about."
For Chiat/Day/Mojo -- which had re-established its New York office with a skein of impressive account victories like American Express's after a year during which it lost a staggering $100 million in billings -- it was the second time in two months the agency lost an American Express account. In August, Shearson Lehman Brothers, which is owned by American Express, began a review on its estimated $20 million account, and it excluded Chiat/Day/Mojo.
"I have to review my own performance, as well as what we're doing there, because we're obviously not doing something right," said Jay Chiat, chairman and chief executive at Chiat/Day/Mojo. While layoffs are now likely, he said, "more than that, what we have to do is sit down and re-evaluate the New York office."
Mr. Chiat disputed the criticism of the work his agency created, but the campaign was widely criticized as too cool, too assertive and too reliant on images of carefree, free-spending consumers that evoked the 1980's. Critics even complained that the new theme -- "The card. The American Express card." -- was too aloof.
Chiat/Day/Mojo had modified the campaign in recent months, adding some warmer elements that were particularly evident in low-key commercials pegged to the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona. The changes followed the return to American Express of Aldo Papone, the retired chairman and chief executive of the American Express Travel Related Services Company, under whose aegis Ogilvy New York had emphasized emotional content in its work. He has been consulting there, with the title of senior adviser, since April.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
As Canada Bonds Go, So May U.S. Market

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The reaction in the Canadian bond market to the results of a referendum today on whether to confer special constitutional status on French-speaking Quebec could be a harbinger of what is going to happen in the American bond market a week from now.
A relief rally in Canadian bond prices, brought on as the uncertainty caused by the referendum lifts, could be a preview of a similar rally in the United States after the Presidential election returns are in and uncertainty disappears. And if there is not a rally, at least the downward pressure on prices of the last several weeks may subside. 
 "We've seen this before," said Sherry Cooper, the chief economist at Burns Fry Ltd. in Toronto. "The best foreign-exchange rallies and the best bond rallies we have in Canada are the ones that follow these kinds of crises."
Many analysts of the Canadian bond market are betting that regardless of the outcome of the vote (recent polls forecast a "no" vote on special status), the short end of the market from Treasury bills to five-year notes should get the most benefit from the rally.
 
Relief From Uncertainty
 There is no complex economic analysis behind this prediction. It is just a recognition that the sharp fall of the Canadian bond market since early September has already accounted for more than a "no" vote, and that the relief from the uncertainty about the outcome of the referendum will provide a lift.
Sound familiar? The American bond market has also swooned lately, in part, traders say, because of the uncertainty over the Presidential election and fear over the costs of an economic stimulus program proposed by Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the candidate who has been leading in the polls.
The Federal Reserve's decision in early October not to cut short-term interest rates below the current 3 percent also helped send the shorter end of the market tumbling. And there is the perennial fear of traders of having to swallow the huge amounts of notes and bonds from new Treasury auctions. The two-year and five-year note auctions are this week, and the big quarterly sale of 30-year bonds and 3- and 10-year notes come just after the Presidential election.
In this atmosphere, the yield on the 30-year bond has soared from 7.31 percent at the beginning of October to 7.63 Friday. At the same time, the discount rates on three-month Treasury bills have jumped from 2.58 percent to 2.93 percent Friday.
But by the end of last week, many analysts had concluded that investors and traders had sold off more than they needed to. "I suspect the market is a little too bearish on Clinton's proposals," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
 
Bond Yield Jumped
 In Canada, concern over a possible negative vote in the referendum began to grow in early September. The yield on the 30-year Canadian bond was 8.07 percent on Sept. 4, jumped to 8.63 percent on Oct. 19, and was at 8.58 percent on Friday. The rate on three-month Canadian Treasury bills moved from 4.56 percent on Sept. 8 to 7.9 percent on Oct. 5, and was 7.1 percent Friday.
Even though yields in Canada have fallen a little in the last several days, the differential between the yields on Canadian bills, notes and bonds and their American counterparts is still quite large. To market watchers, this means there is room for the differential to narrow to where it was just two months ago. And that means a potential for profit as prices rise as yields fall.
For example, the differential, or spread, on three-month bills was as wide as 523 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, on Oct. 2. It has narrowed somewhat, to more than 400 basis points now, but it was only 150 points before concern over the referendum arose.
The spread for 30-year Canadian bonds had jumped to 110 basis points in October, from 71 points in early September, and was down to 94 basis points on Friday. That still leaves some room for improvement, but there is less opportunity than with shorter maturities. The bond has recovered more than the shorter maturities, in part because short-term interest rates had to be pushed higher to defend the falling Canadian dollar.
 
Good Fundamentals
 Beyond the post-referendum relief factor, Canadian bonds, notes and bills, like those in the United States, have economic fundamentals to support their prices and lower their yields once political uncertainties are dispensed with.
Inflation in Canada is down to 1.3 percent over the last 12 months, lower than in the United States. And economic growth is no better, or even less than in the United States, with the unemployment rate in September at 11.4 percent. These fundamentals are the real underpinnings of the forecasts of yields falling.
"If the referendum is rejected, Canada will still be there," said Anita M. Lauria, an analyst who follows the Canadian bond market at Salomon Brothers. "And people will be able to focus on the economic fundamentals."
The one caveat is the Canadian dollar, which has fallen 4 percent against the American dollar since early September. The outlook is a little less clear there, although some analysts expect the Canadian currency to strengthen against the American dollar after the referendum. If this happens, it could add to the earnings of American investors in Canadian securities when the securities are sold and the proceeds translated into American dollars.
But because a rejection of the referendum could further weaken the already unpopular Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, it is hard to figure if the Canadian dollar will rebound as much as the bond market. In addition, to get the economy going, short-term interest rates will have to come down more, also undermining the Canadian dollar.
"There is that element on the currency side," said Patrick Paradiso, a vice president at Deutsche Bank Capital in New York, "that people need to be aware of."

HEADLINE: The Talk of Hollywood;
Director Who Blends Action With a Bit of Art

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 25

 BODY:
So "Under Siege," the new action adventure starring Steven Seagal, is not exactly high brow. The film, about nuclear terrorists aboard a Navy battleship, won't rival "Howards End" for Academy Award nominations. The art house set, who prefer Ingmar Bergman and Akira Kurosawa, won't even blink at it. But the movie, along with "The Last of the Mohicans," is the major success of the autumn, and has been No. 1 at the box office for the past three weeks. Even serious film critics admit that "Under Siege" is perhaps the best popcorn film in years. And a darkly funny, if violent, one.
Andrew Davis, the 45-year-old director, and a politically involved former cinematographer from Chicago, said with a smile: "The film is more complicated and interesting than people anticipate. It tries to raise some provocative issues about nuclear weapons. Look, if you do an intellectual movie that 20 people on the West Side of Manhattan see, you're not exactly reaching a lot of people." 
 In the film, Mr. Seagal plays a Navy cook, and highly decorated former SEAL in trouble with the brass, who takes charge of the crew against a bunch of murderous military specialists who have plotted to hijack the ship and steal its nuclear arsenal. Also on the ship is a Playboy Playmate (played by Erika Eleniak) with, of all things, pacifist leanings. But that's another story. The film's screenplay was by J. F. Lawton, who wrote "Pretty Woman."
Mr. Davis was shrewd enough to surround Mr. Seagal, who is known far more for his grunting martial arts than his acting skill, with two dazzling character actors, Tommy Lee Jones and Gary Busey. The two just about steal the film as over-the-top, and funny, bad guys.
(Mr. Seagal came to stardom the old-fashioned way. Like Lana Turner. According to legend, Miss Turner was discovered by a talent scout at a soda counter. Mr. Seagal was discovered by one of his martial arts students, Michael Ovitz, the chairman of Creative Artists Agency.)
Mr. Davis said the success of the film had just about transformed his career. In Hollywood Mr. Davis has gained a reputation as a highly successful action director; his movies include "The Package," a 1989 thriller, starring Gene Hackman and Mr. Jones; "Above the Law," which marked Mr. Seagal's feature debut in 1988, and the Chuck Norris film "Code of Silence," in 1985.
Mr. Davis said sardonically: "Things have changed a lot for me in the last few weeks. It's all about money. Isn't it wonderful? Great movie makers come through Hollywood all the time but if you don't make money on your movies -- and especially if you're a woman -- forget it. A man can fail five times. A woman fails once. That's it."
 
Longing for Something New
 Mr. Davis, who lives in Santa Barbara with his wife, Adriana, and two young children, said his next films would probably go far beyond the action genre: he yearns to direct a comedy or a drama or even a musical.
Mr. Davis began his career working as an assistant cameraman to Haskell Wexler on "Medium Cool," the 1969 classic about the turbulent 1968 Democratic convention in Chicago. (He said, "I loaded cameras during the riots.)
Mr. Davis's roots -- and many of his friends -- are in Chicago. He has a degree in journalism from the University of Illinois in Champaign-Urbana, and still has fantasies about being an investigative reporter. His father, Nate Davis, is a well-known stage actor in Chicago.
Mr. Davis's acclaimed first independent film, "Stony Island," in 1979, which brought him to Hollywood, was a semiautobiographical musical about jazz musicians on the South Side of Chicago. He then spent several years directing a number of quickie exploitation films because he was broke. The Norris film "Code of Silence" turned Mr. Davis into an action director.
"I got pegged as this action guy -- this guy who could do great stunts," he said.
 
Echoes of a Classic
 Mr. Davis takes his film making seriously: the scenes in "Under Siege" in the Pentagon war room are designed to resemble a similar backdrop in Stanley Kubrick's 1964 classic, "Dr. Strangelove." And he insists that each of his films has a broader theme: the movies have dealt with police cover-ups ("Code of Silence,") and an assassination plot by Soviet and American military dissidents against Mikhail S. Gorbachev ("The Silence").
Although Mr. Davis says that critics too often condescend to action films, he acknowledges that many of these films are terrible.
"The basic underpinnings don't have any soul or value," he said. "They're totally incredible so you don't believe them. They're dumb stories. People are unbelievable."
"People want to see action," he said. "Life is boring for a lot of people and they want to be excited. But if you make these you've got to like the people in it. You've got to have some irreverent humor. Audiences want to cheer for the good guys and hiss the bad guys, and really love the hissing."
"Look, it's so dark out there for a lot of people," said Mr. Davis. "You want to give people some hope without turning it into a diatribe. Every successful action movie has a guy who's a nobody, who gets messed up by the big guys in the system and then comes back and does right. It's Robin Hood. It's hope for the little guy. That's what it's all about. "
 
Too Sad to Sell
 If "Under Siege," is pure escapism, "American Heart" is the reverse. It is bleak, unfunny and sad, and as a result is facing enormous difficulties.
Jeff Bridges, the movie actor, is one of the producers with Rosilyn Heller and Neil Koenigsberg. Mr. Bridges is also the film's star and its guiding force.
"Most of the major studios don't want to touch it, but why the independents have turned it down is a big mystery to me," said Mr. Bridges in a telephone interview. "It's distressful. Everyone's so reticent. It just doesn't fit into a neat category."
The low-budget film, directed by Martin Bell, a British documentary film maker, with a screenplay by Peter Silverman, a television writer, deals with an ex-convict, played by Mr. Bridges, who reluctantly allows his desperately lonely 15-year-old son, played by Edward Furlong, to live with him. The film takes place in Seattle's underside. Also involved in the movie as associate producer is Mary Ellen Park, a well-known photographer who is married to Mr. Bell.
In traditional Hollywood style, one company, which was set to distribute the movie, went bankrupt. The movie was then placed in limbo. Mr. Bridges and his partners have failed to find a company to release the film. One main reason, they say, is because the current bleak economic mood in the nation leaves audiences craving for escapist films like "The Last of the Mohicans" and "Under Siege." Preview audiences have generally responded positively to the movie.
Mr. Bridges said: "I knew this film would be a tough sell, but nothing like this. Nothing quite like this."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Andrew Davis, director of the new action adventure "Under Siege." (Eduardo Citrinblum for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Diversity in the Fastest Growing U.S. Minority

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Latinos
A Biography of the People
By Earl Shorris
520 pages. W. W. Norton. $25.
Earl Shorris's "Latinos: A Biography of the People" is a large baggy book that strives to give readers a sense of the diversity and complexity of the fastest growing United States minority, which comprises Mexican-Americans, Cuban-Americans, Puerto Ricans, Dominicans and immigrants from Central and South America. 
 Explaining his terminology, Mr. Shorris, a contributing editor of Harper's Magazine, writes: "I have chosen to use Latino/Latina for linguistic rather than political, geographic or economic reasons: Latino has gender, which is Spanish, as opposed to Hispanic, which follows English rules. Although the linguistic connection to culture in the group name may eventually be killed, I choose not to be among the assassins."
Mr. Shorris succeeds in introducing us to what he considers a misunderstood and downtrodden people. Typical of his perceptions is this description of the dominant culture in Hispanic history: "It must be remembered that there are two Spains: the Spain of the Inquisition and that of Miguel Cervantes, the inventor of Don Quixote, a Spain of certainty and irony, of paranoia and hope, of death and laughter." Armed with a quiver full of such paradoxes, he is able to interrogate the diverse representatives of his broad subject, the Mexicans of Texas and California, the Puerto Ricans of New York City and their home island in the Caribbean and the Cubans of Miami.
Unhappily, Mr. Shorris has also shackled himself. One difficulty with "Latinos" is that the subject is a little too diverse for untroubled digestion. As Mr. Shorris is the first to point out, Latin Americans "are not one nationality, one culture, but many." As a people often said to have died twice -- once at the hands of the conquering Spaniards, later as a result of more subtle white oppression -- Latin Americans have suffered a variety of histories, even to a point where the parts that make up their whole often practice forms of racism against one another. As Mr. Shorris observes of the Latin encounter with American culture: "All the rules and none of the rules apply to Latinos." So the organization of this history is necessarily lumpy and discursive.
More vexing still is the difficulty of seeing what Mr. Shorris is ultimately driving at. He insists more than once that Nathan Glazer and Daniel Patrick Moynihan were wrong in their book "Beyond the Melting Pot" to conclude that all immigrant experiences were essentially the same and that American culture was tending toward homogeneity. Is this meant to imply that the extreme difficulties that Latins are encountering in their struggle to succeed will ultimately prove insoluble? Or is Mr. Shorris arguing that America must radically change its ways to fit this huge and growing minority? His answer is not by any means clear.
He also faults Mr. Glazer and Mr. Moynihan for introducing "the concept that later came to be known as 'blaming the victim' " and for suggesting, in Mr. Shorris's words, that "blacks were the exception to the pattern, and Latinos were probably going to be an exception too." Although Mr. Shorris doesn't spell out what he means here, the implication is that blacks and Latins were accused of suffering from handicaps that made it impossible for them to follow the paradigm of immigration, integration and assimilation.
Much of Mr. Shorris's book is devoted to defining superficial perceptions of those supposed Latin handicaps, then probing deep into their past to explain the far more complicated truth behind them. For example, Mr. Shorris mentions the perception of Mexican immigrants as lazy, but he points out that behind this appearance are the complex truths that can be summed up in the single word "aguantar," which translates into "to bear," "to endure" or "to put up with," but which "came to mean enduring one's fate bravely and with a certain style," a stoicism now misperceived as laziness.
Elsewhere, Mr. Shorris says that many Puerto Ricans who were asked "to define their essence in a word" gave the answer "partying." He is quick to add that this aptitude has more to do with despair than happiness and that such despair has roots in Puerto Rico's history of being conquered and occupied. But it's a risky game the author is playing here. As he himself warns, "The difference between stereotypes and cultural distinctions is sometimes very subtle."
Again one has to wonder what point Mr. Shorris is driving at. Is it that because of their tragic histories Latin people will require extraordinary help in their quest to be assimilated into American culture? Or is it that they are so separated from the mainstream immigrant experience and so handicapped by their history that Americans will have to undergo a deep change to accommodate them? Is he possibly even suggesting that the dominant culture of America should prepare to submit to Latin Americans? The answer is not clear, not even in Mr. Shorris's argument for bilingual education, which leaves us to wonder if he expects Spanish to become our permanent second language.
Nor is his entreaty for cultural diversity buttressed by his statement that he alone among all candidates was the only qualified person to write "Latinos." Shouldn't a Latin American have written this book? someone asks Mr. Shorris, a Spanish Jew who grew up among Mexican-Americans in El Paso, Tex., in an interview that accompanies the book's publicity material. Absolutely, he replies, but the only qualified Latin he knows of died some 20 years ago. This recalls Dorothy Parker's famous response when asked why she had failed to write some piece for a new magazine she was working for. "Someone was using the pencil," she explained.
Taken with half a grain of salt, "Latinos" remains an informative survey of certain struggling Americans with tangled historical roots in common. Best of all, perhaps, the book indicates where future explorations of this subject may occur. As a section on Latin arts seems to promise, there are now young Hispanic writers maturing who will be fully able to tell such deeper stories.

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
New York, More Than Show Biz

 BODY:
New Yorkers know there is plenty to cheer about in their city: ethnic and cultural diversity, first-rate theater, world-class museums, restaurants, literati, designers, scholars and other professionals. But outsiders often overlook these assets, pointing instead to violent crime, filthy streets, political turmoil and the overall hassle factor.
That's why Fortune magazine's fourth annual survey of America's best cities for business is gratifying. Despite the problems and unrelenting negative publicity, the city came in fifth -- behind Seattle, Houston, San Francisco and Atlanta, but in front of Raleigh, Denver, Boston and about 50 other major cities. 
 The corporate chief executives who participated in the survey ranked New York low on manufacturing competitiveness and social conflict but extremely high on the presence of international opportunities and transportation facilities.
They also pointed to New York City's astonishing array of financial wizards, lawyers, ad agencies and, well, deal-makers.
As American business is increasingly forced to reach abroad for business, New York increasingly becomes the best place to call home. It also doesn't hurt, according to Fortune, that late-working C.E.O.'s can also reach out for "sushi or deli or Chinese at 2 A.M."

HEADLINE: For Congress From Connecticut

 BODY:
Connecticut needs strong hands in Congress to help it through the double downer of a sluggish economy and shrinking defense budgets. Five of its six representatives meet that test.
Here are choices in three races: 
 Third District (New Haven area): First-term Democrat Rosa DeLauro is re-matched against Tom Scott, a militantly conservative former state senator she narrowly defeated in 1990.
Representative DeLauro has spent the two years usefully, applying her considerable energy to economic programs and post-cold war conversion, particularly for small businesses. Mr. Scott has spent the time obstructively, fomenting public opposition to the state income tax.
 With two candidates who disagree on virtually everything, voters have a clear choice. We like Ms. DeLauro.
Fourth District (Fairfield County): Republican Representative Christopher Shays is challenged by Democrat David Shropfer, a marketing consultant, and Al Smith, a lawyer who was the Democratic candidate last time and is now endorsed by Gov. Lowell Weicker's fledgling A Connecticut Party. Both challengers are competent, but neither warrants unseating Mr. Shays.
An independent Republican who votes against the President almost as much as with him, Mr. Shays is stubborn about holding down spending, unless there's money to cover it. Unlike the President, he is willing to raise taxes.
Mr. Shays was Republican point man on cable TV regulation -- a bill he has pushed for three years, and the only one enacted over a Bush veto. Admirably, he also co-sponsors a bill to make members of Congress subject to the health, safety and employment laws from which they now exempt themselves. He rates re-election.
Fifth District (Danbury, Waterbury, Meriden): Representative Gary Franks, first elected in 1990, is the only black Republican in Congress. He had a unique opportunity to shine -- and failed. His voting record seems blindly pro-business. His attention to constituent concerns has been haphazard, and he has mismanaged his staff.
Of the two challengers for the Franks seat, we favor Democrat James Lawlor, a soft-spoken probate judge. As counsel to local development efforts, he's been a leader in creating jobs -- a critical asset in the long-depressed Naugatuck Valley.
State Representative Lynn Taborsak, a scrappy liberal Democrat who lost the party's endorsement to Mr. Lawlor, is running on the A Connecticut Party line. It would be unfortunate if she split the Democratic vote enough to re-elect Mr. Franks.
In the other races, as in past years, we favor the incumbents, all of whom have served with distinction -- Democrats Barbara Kennelly of Hartford and Sam Gejdenson in the eastern part of the state, and Republican Nancy Johnson in the northwest. Mr. Gejdenson rates a special nod this time for his hard work on campaign finance reform.
On ballot issues: Question 1, on absentee voter registration, would open the way for more people to vote. Vote yes. Question 2, on capping the state budget, invites evasive fiscal gimmickry. Vote no.

LENGTH: 425 words

HEADLINE: An Urban Aid Bill That Doesn't

 BODY:
After the Los Angeles riots in April, Congress vowed swift relief. This month it finally passed an urban aid bill. Only it doesn't provide much urban aid. And what it does provide -- tax breaks for yacht buyers, real estate investors and wealthy savers -- is irresponsible, opening up gaping holes in future budgets.
President Bush, boxed in by election-year pledges, threatens to veto the bill because it would raise some taxes even as it cuts others. That's an absurd reason, but a serendipitous outcome. 
 Congress, at the urging of the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, and the Senate Finance Committee chairman, Lloyd Bentsen, has delayed forwarding the bill to the President to push the deadline for a veto beyond Nov. 3. That way Mr. Bush could change his mind and sign the bill after the election. Mr. Mitchell is fighting on behalf of subsidies to ship builders in his home state of Maine, Mr. Bentsen on behalf of wealthy families saving for retirement.
No one concerned about cities would fight nearly as hard. The bill, costing $27 billion over five years, spends only about $7 billion on cities. The rest is frittered away in tax breaks for tuxedo rentals, college football games, restaurants and so on.
The original centerpiece was to be enterprise zones -- blighted areas to which employers would be drawn by tax breaks and regulatory relief. But that calls for a carefully targeted experiment that would pile up tax breaks, infrastructure investments and support services in a few urban zones. Instead, the bill would spread a few billion dollars thinly over 50 zones, half of them rural.
The next Congress can salvage the bill by concentrating aid on a dozen urban zones. It could also preserve support for distressed families and a permanent extension of the low-income housing tax credit, which attracts private investors to inner-city housing.
What should never resurface are budget-busting tax breaks. The bill would grant corporations automatic write-offs for purchases of intangible assets like customer lists and subsidize retirement savings for high-income families. Neither provision is unreasonable had Congress paid for them. But Congress wasn't willing. It offset these permanent tax cuts with temporary tax hikes, a gimmick to satisfy the budget law while running up deficits in the future.
What started as a response to a human disaster -- the Los Angeles riots -- now threatens to become a financial fiasco. The best outcome is a veto, sadly leaving America's inner cities more time to rot.

HEADLINE: For U.S., a New Day's Dawning in East Asia

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Cold War's Over and It's Time to Rebuild" (letters, Oct. 6) addresses problems and opportunities in a reduced demand for military hardware, personnel and bases. The time is also ripe to revamp United States relations with East Asia. Our leaders seem at a loss how to respond to the pressures of East Asia's peoples and centers of power. The challenges of communications technology alone stagger the imagination. 
 Despite the lessons of the 20th century and a geographical setting that places the United States strategically between Europe and Asia, no American leaders have stepped forward to articulate the significance of transformations in Asia-Pacific relations.
Foremost, for example, the United States ought to encourage Japan to join in forging a commitment based on renewed mutual respect to spurn the pitfalls and one-sided attitudes that induced them half a century ago to wage bitter warfare against each other. An identical plea for hardheaded peacemaking could also be addressed to improving relations between the United States and China.
For Japan we ought to consider:
(1) Phasing out in a limited number of years United States responsibility for Japan's security, with Tokyo step by step assuming the burdens of self-defense; (2) support for Japan, and Germany, to gain permanent Security Council seats, obtaining greater strength for global peacekeeping needs; (3) educating Americans better, students and adults alike, about the Janapese, Chinese, Koreans, Filipinos and all East Asians, and (4) devising a national economic philosophy to foster the wealth of all nations, to encourage support for the interests of consumers, as well as producers, as an integral element of competition, and to discourage the harmful practice of bashing others to override one's own deficiencies.
Whoever wins the November election, the time has come for a fresh start in United States relations with East Asia.
 
ARTHUR P. DUDDEN
Bryn Mawr, Pa., Oct. 9, 1992
 
The writer is author of "The American Pacific From the Old China Trade to the Present" (1992).

HEADLINE: With Eye on Economy, 12 States to Pick Chiefs

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

 BODY:
From tiny Rhode Island to the Big Sky country of Montana, the 12 states electing governors next week share not just the unpredictable dynamic of politics in a Presidential year, but budget woes and an electorate uneasy about the economy.
States that had never before given a second thought to initiating income or sales taxes are debating when and how to start them. At the same time, they are looking to the nightmarish experience of California, where some say high taxes and regulation may have played a part in the state's fiscal collapse. 
 "We can't allow ourselves to fall into the mess that California has fallen into," said Ken Eikenberry, the Republican candidate for governor in Washington State, in a refrain spoken this year by many other candidates to lead their states.
State budgets nearly everywhere are reeling from the recession, but hardly anybody is willing to talk about new taxes to balance budgets. As a result, there is much talk about cutting expenses and creating more jobs in the private sector.
 
Bucking a Trend
 One notable exception to the "no new taxes" talk is Deborah (Arnie) Arnesen, the Democratic nominee for governor of New Hampshire, where candidates traditionally take a pledge not to raise taxes. Ms. Arnesen, a 38-year-old state representative, has advocated a state income tax, with three-quarters of the proceeds going to local governments for property-tax relief. (Her Republican opponent, Steven Merrill, a former state attorney general, has taken the pledge against new taxes.)
Ms. Arnesen's candidacy is notable in another respect: if elected, she would be the first female governor of New Hampshire. But this year, that is not so unusual. More women are running for Congress than ever, and they have a chance of winning the governor's mansion in three states: New Hampshire, Montana and Rhode Island.
In many states, the Democratic candidates for governor are clinging as closely as they can to Gov. Bill Clinton's coattails. The Democrats hope to put at least two new states in their column, Delaware and North Carolina, while Republicans say their best outcome would be to break even. Of the dozen races this year, five are in states the Democrats control and seven are in Republican hands. There are now 28 Democratic governors, 20 Republicans and 2 independents.
Based on state polls and interviews in the states electing governors this year, Democrats think they will win in Delaware, Rhode Island, North Carolina, Indiana, Vermont and West Virginia. Republicans predict a solid victory in just one state, Utah, with Washington and New Hampshire leaning their way. Missouri, North Dakota and Montana are rated tossups.
 
Washington Race Tightens
 Washington, with a seat that opened up when the popular two-term Democratic Governor, Booth Gardner, decided not to seek a third term, was thought about a month ago to be solidly in Republican hands. But Mike Lowry, a Democratic former Congressman who has twice failed in runs for the Senate, has had a surge in recent polls.
Long associated with his party's liberal wing, he has broadened his appeals this year by bringing voices from business to his campaign.
Mr. Lowry has refused to accept campaign contributions of more than $1,500 and has pledged not to run any negative advertisements. But he was helped considerably this week when a newspaper reported that a supporter of the Republican nominee, Mr. Eikenberry, tried to solicit a $50,000 campaign contribution from a University of Washington regent, in return for new term on the board. Mr. Eikenberry said the story was "a lie."
Negative advertising has not been restrained in Montana, where the Republican State Attorney General, Marc Racicot (pronounced ROS-ko) and Dorothy Bradley, an eight-term state representative, are in an extremely tight race.
Ms. Bradley began the campaign by riding around parts of the state on horseback. Similar to Governor Clinton, she put out a brochure touting her People First economic platform. But a series of negative advertisements and debates have reduced her lead enough to make the race nearly even.
Mr. Racicot's supporters circulated a flier that noted that Ms. Bradley was divorced, had no children, no military experience and spent some years right after college restoring pottery in Germany. By contrast, the brochure noted, Mr. Racicot was a married father of five who was a captain in the Army.
In the Montana of old, Ms. Bradley's private life might have been a significant factor in a statewide race, but the state has changed considerably in the last decade. "There's been such a demographic shift in Montana over the last 10 years that I don't think anyone really cares if she's divorced and doesn't have any children," said John Heynemann, a spokesman for Ms. Bradley.
The race has since focused on such issues as imposing a sales tax and how to protect the foundering cattle industry.
 
Focus on Farm Economy
 One state to the east, North Dakota, has also featured a rather nasty personal fight, where the two-term Democratic Governor, George A. Sinner, is stepping down. Attorney General Nicholas Spaeth, the Democrat, has made a campaign issue of his opponent's sometime residence in New York.
Mr. Spaeth accused the Republican, Ed Schafer, of not living in North Dakota for the last five years, a requirement for being elected governor. But Mr. Schafer, a businessman who is the former president of the company that manufactures detergent products like Mr. Bubbles and Snowy Bleach, countered with an income tax form that he said proved his residency.
"We think its's backfired on the Democrats," said Ed Roby, communications director for the Republican nominee.
Both candidates have promoted visions of keeping jobs and people from leaving North Dakota. More than 50,000 people moved out of the state in the last eight years, leaving it with a population of just over 600,000. Pointing to recent personal ventures like an aquaculture project that raises tropical fish using indoor pools, Mr. Schafer has campaigned as a business-minded leader with creative solutions to bring jobs to North Dakota. His opponent has focused his program on finding broader markets for the state's farm products.
Two Midwestern states, Indiana and Missouri, are leaning Democratic. Polls in Missouri last month put Lieut. Gov. Mel Carnahan, a Democrat, up by 10 points over State Attorney General Bill Webster. Gov. Evan Bayh of Indiana, elected in 1988 at the age of 32, has proved to be popular in a state that usually leans Republican. He won by only a 53-to-47-percent margin in 1988, but has registered a lead of better than 2 to 1 over the State Attorney General, Linley Pearson, in recent state polls.
The Republicans also appear to be in trouble in the six races for governor in the East. B. Gary Scott, a real estate executive, was once thought to be ahead of his Democratic opponent in Delaware, United States Representative Thomas R. Carper. But in the last few weeks, political experts have given a slight advantage to Mr. Carper. The state had been ruled for two terms by Gov. Michael N. Castle, a Republican.
In Rhode Island, the Republican, Elizabeth Leonard, has been trying to use the recession and Rhode Island's banking crisis to unseat Gov. Bruce Sundlun, a Democrat. A car dealer, Ms. Leonard has been billed by the Republican Governors' Association as the "perfect outsider," in this year of anti-incumbency sentiment.
She has railed against corruption in state government, but her inexperience has apparently hurt her. A Brown University poll a month ago had Governor Sundlun ahead by 16 points.
Recent polls in North Carolina give Jim Hunt, a former governor, a wide lead in his attempt to win back the governor's mansion as he challenges Jim Gardner, a Republican who is lieutenant governor. Mr. Hunt, who lost in a bid to unseat Senator Jesse Helms in 1984, has worked in business and as a cattle rancher in recent years.
He is campaigning this year on a platform to raise educational standards in North Carolina. The state has been smarting over a loss of jobs, particularly a recent desision by BMW to locate a plant in South Carolina.
 A map showing the parties for all 50 incumbent governors shaded two states incorrectly. The Governor of Louisiana is a Democrat; the Governor of Mississippi is a Republican.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing;
The Voters Choose to Read, And Political Books Flourish

BYLINE: By Esther B. Fein

 BODY:
FOUR years ago, The New York Times nonfiction paperback best-seller list the week before the Presidential election was a typical grab bag: inspirational messages, a book about a cat, a murder case, and memoirs about a traumatic childhood and a rock and roll groupie.
Two books on the hard-cover list gave only a hint that a campaign was under way: an account of Ronald Reagan's second Presidential term and a prescription for what the American people and Government should do in the face of a predicted depression in 1990. 
 But behold the pre-election book buyers of 1992: Americans who are watching Presidential and Vice Presidential debates and registering to vote in record numbers are also buying masses of books about the programs of Presidential candidates, about the deficit and environmental problems, and about the way Government doesn't always work.
 
An Unlikely Scenario
 Publishers and booksellers who are enjoying the windfall from these sales chuckle at the unlikely scenario. Imagine a writer submitting a book proposal about the debt crisis and swearing it will become a best seller? It might be worthy, but a reading public that reaches for homilies and thigh exercises would never go for it.
Surprise. It's the No. 12 book on the hard-cover nonfiction list, "Bankruptcy 1995: The Coming Collapse of America and How to Stop It" (Little, Brown), by Harry E. Figgie Jr., a former Reagan adviser, with Gerald J. Swanson.
"We didn't expect these political books to do quite as well as they have, but people are really interested in the political process this year despite the fact that everyone predicted there would be all this apathy," said Bruce Dasse, divisional merchandise manager for Waldenbooks, whose responsibilities include books about history, biography and political science. "What we're discovering is that people want substance. People aren't interested in the personalities so much as the issues."
The best-seller list reflects that interest. On the hard-cover nonfiction side, in addition to "Bankruptcy 1995," is "Earth in the Balance" (Houghton Mifflin), by Senator Al Gore, the Democratic Vice Presidential candidate's book about the environment, which will hit the No. 3 spot on Sunday. And No. 8 is "Truman" (Simon & Schuster), David McCullough's biography of the former president whose name has been invoked so often in this campaign, he seems almost contemporary.
The paperback nonfiction list shows an even sharper interest in politics and government. In the No. 1 slot is "United We Stand" (Hyperion) by Ross Perot, the independent candidate's program for rebuilding America. The No. 2 book is "Putting People First" (Times Books/Random House), by Gov. Bill Clinton and Senator Gore, the Democratic candidates' program for changing America.
Next on the list is "America: What Went Wrong?" (Andrews & McMeel), by Donald L. Barlett and James B. Steele, an analysis of how the practices of Wall Street and Washington have benefited only a few Americans. And at No. 5 is "The Government Racket" (Bantam), by Martin L. Gross, examples of Washington waste with suggestions for curbing it.
Some of the books were commissioned before publishers had any clue that this election would spur such interest. Others were rushed into print to take advantage of the political mood, to educate and, yes, concede the publishers, to make money.
The popular books are mostly slim and fairly inexpensive, with all the paperbacks selling for less than $10. Booksellers say the length and the price have helped attract customers. People feel they can learn more about the issues without committing a lot of time and money.
Charles E. Hayward, president of Little, Brown, described the books as "almost like manifestoes." He and others in publishing said readers clearly were interested in "digestible" political books, ones that concentrated on a single issue or that boiled down the essence of several important issues.
 
Reflecting Public Opinion
 Not everyone agrees that this is a healthy trend. "The good news is that people are buying political books," said David Rosenthal, executive editor of the Random House adult trade division. "The bad news is that these are the printed equivalent of sound bites. The information is written, packaged and printed in a way that is disturbingly similar to TV."
One noteworthy observation about the top-selling books is that none of them is about the Republican candidates, except by implication the ones that criticize the current state of Government affairs. Even the political books that are not on best-seller lists but that are enjoying respectable sales in the stores are favorable profiles of Mr. Clinton or Mr. Perot or satirical looks at President Bush and Vice President Quayle.
The books reflect the public opinion polls and the sentiments of many people in the publishing industry, said Steven Schragis, publisher of the Carol Publishing Group. The company's Birch Lane Press currently has two biographies on the market, one of Mr. Clinton and one of Mr. Perot. It also has a novel about an idiot who becomes Vice President.
"The books I publish absolutely reflect my political inclinations," Mr. Schragis said. "But based on the best-seller lists, I would say it's the public's inclinations, too."
