HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Clinton Presents Hard Line To Bring In North Carolina

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WILSON, N.C., Oct. 26

 BODY:
Appearing in a televised question-and-answer session with a small group of North Carolinians today, Bill Clinton and his running mate, Al Gore, worked to win over the state's independent, essentially conservative voters.
The strategy played out in an exchange with a young man named Shawn Searcy on "CBS This Morning." Mr. Searcy voiced an objection to excessive Government largess toward the poor. He said he believed that "if you don't work, you don't eat." 
 Mr. Clinton replied: "I agree with you. If people don't work, if they can work, they shouldn't eat."
For Mr. Clinton, eight days from Election Day, the votes of people like Mr. Searcy, who once supported George Bush or may yet support Ross Perot, hold the key to victory.
 
Overcoming Distrust
 To reach them, and to overcome their ingrained distrust of Democrats, Mr. Clinton sounded today, as he has more often in these last days of the race, a theme heavy with values.
"We're going to empower people to take control of their own lives, then hold them accountable for doing so," Mr. Clinton said in a speech at Elon College, just outside Burlington, in central North Carolina.
"Moving people from welfare to work by investing in their education, then requiring them to work, enforcing child-support enforcement orders toughly so you can't cross the state line and beat your child support bill, giving people the opportunity to get an education but requiring them to give something back to their country, dealing with first-time nonviolent offenders by giving them a chance to be in community boot camps, where they can do work, learn discipline, have education, and gain control of their lives."
 
Beyond Liberalism
 The themes of the day are not new to Mr. Clinton's campaign; all year he had positioned himself as a Democrat willing to go beyond the boundaries of traditional liberalism.
Rather, the distinction is one of impetus. In recent days, Mr. Clinton has taken to emphasizing themes of personal responsibility at every speech, stringing together his views on issues like crime, welfare and the family into a riff that serves to position Mr. Clinton as the sort of Democrat a socially conservative voter could support.
A Clinton campaign official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the campaign's strategy was to ratchet up emphasis on these themes over a period of days, allowing them to eventually occupy a central position in Mr. Clinton's stump speech without effecting what would seem a radical change.
 
Largest Caravan Yet
 In their eighth and final bus trip of the 1992 campaign, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore led the largest, and most unwieldy caravan yet -- more than 200 people in 16 buses and a dozen or so cars, vans and motorcycles -- lumbering along back roads from the hills and oak forests of the western Piedmont to the pine trees and tobacco fields of the eastern coastal plain.
Mr. Perot's impressive performances in the Presidential debates and his huge purchases of television advertising time had in the past week or so cost Mr. Clinton a good measure of the independent voters, causing the Democrat to lose more than six points to Mr. Perot in national preference polls.
But today, with Mr. Perot railing against media-G.O.P. conspiracies for the second day in a row and Bush Administration spokesman Marlin Fitzwater calling Mr. Perot "a crazy man," and a "paranoid person," many in the Clinton and Gore campaigns believe Mr. Perot has topped out, and will shortly begin, by the display of his temperament, to drive away voters, who would go in large measure to Mr. Clinton.
"It sounds like Perot and Bush are doing everything we need them to do, and all we have to do is stand by and watch it," said Robert Squier, a Washington-based political consultant who advises Mr. Gore. "If you want a perfect scenario for the last week, this is it. Perot is attacking Bush and Bush is attacking Perot, and our guys are up there talking about fixing the economy and getting this country moving in the right direction again."
 
Watching From a Distance
 Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore did allow themselves to address the matter a few times, but carefully, and with the air more of a dispassionate observer than an interested party.
On "CBS This Morning," Mr. Clinton said Mr. Bush's strategy lay in the hope "that the anti-Bush vote will be divided and he can sneak up through the middle," adding that "this fight that Perot and Bush are in right now may make that more difficult."
At a rally that drew 15,000 people to fill a grass amphitheater at the North Carolina Central University in Durham, Mr. Clinton acted somewhat in the manner of a tolerant adult watching a pair of squabbling adolescents, as he spoke of his adversaries.
"Mr. Bush and Mr. Perot have called each other names for months because Mr. Bush thought Mr. Perot hired people to investigate his children, and now Mr. Perot says Mr. Bush hired people to look into his children," he said. "It looks to me like what they ought to be doing is what I've been doing; I'm looking into your children, and their future, and their promise."
Mr. Gore was more political in his remarks, and came closer to expressing the joyous wonderment the Democrats are feeling as they regard Mr. Bush and Mr. Perot from a safe distance.
 
'Talking About What Matters'
 "The other candidates for the Presidency have both been accusing each other of the most remarkable things today," he told a crowd in the town of Wilson. He pointed his two forefingers at each other, and added "Both sides been pointing at each other and shooting each other in the foot, and Bill and I've just been sitting by watching it. We're out here where the rubber meets the road, talking to the people and talking about the future of America."
A Democratic victory in North Carolina, both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore reminded their audiences several times, could be the key to the election. For weeks Mr. Clinton has been consistently leading Mr. Bush in polls of North Carolina voters, leading Democrats here to hope for their first Presidential victory since 1976, when Jimmy Carter carried the state.
The belief that this year's contest is going to be close is reflected in the high interest in the race. Of the state's nearly four million registered voters, 71 percent are expected to vote this year, compared with 64 percent in 1988, when Mr. Bush carried the state with 58 percent of the vote.
The day finally ended at 11 P.M. in the small coastal plain town of Wilson, with Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore both clearly exhausted, barely able to get through their stump speeches before a crowd that drifted away even as the candidates began to speak.
Mr. Clinton, his voice hoarse and tired, ended with an exhortation that was almost a plea: "Every time when the chips were down, Americans have gotten up to bat, and hit a home run on the question of whether they have the courage to change. Don't let them take your courage away from you in the last week."

HEADLINE: Industry Fights Massachusetts Plan on Recycling

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WATERTOWN, Mass., Oct. 21

 BODY:
Now that recycling has became popular, many consumers here neatly sort their paper, glass, plastics and other material and feel they have done their part to save the environment. But the sorted trash still ends up in incinerators and landfills, environmentalists say, because there is no market for the material.
Environmentalists are trying to change that with a ballot referendum, sponsored by Gov. William F. Weld, one that advocates and opponents agree would be the most sweeping recycling and repackaging measure in the country. 
 But the proposal, which would encourage less elaborate packaging or and the use of recycled material, has raised a cry of alarm -- and $5 million for a counter-campaign -- from out-of-state manufacturers of chemical, paper and consumer products.
"Recycling is not when some consumer puts newspapers at the curb," said Amy Perry, an organizer for the Massachusetts Public Interest Research Group and the campaign's chief spokeswoman. "It's when someone makes it into a cereal box."
But the people who sell cereal boxes say they are horrified. "This is the dictionary definition of draconian, a bad idea whose time has not yet come," said Jeffrey Nedelman, vice president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America. "This proposal in Massachusetts is the most sweeping, most regressive solid waste proposal we have encountered anywhere, period. Most people think all of the crazy ideas come out of California, but even the Californians haven't touched this one."
Moreover, Mr. Nedelman's group fears that California and other states will follow suit if the ballot initiative here is successful.
The Massachusetts proposition, which would take effect in 1996, gives manufacturers five ways to comply with the proposed regulations:
*Reducing the volume of packaging by 25 percent every five years.
*Making a package designed to be reused five times or more.
*Making the package with a recycled material content of 25 percent (rising to 35 percent in 1999 and 50 percent in 2002).
*Making the package from materials that will be recycled at a rate of 25 percent (and 35 percent in 1999 and 50 percent in 2002).
*Using a package whose material was recycled at a rate of 50 percent in Massachusetts the previous year.
Proponents say that some materials, like the plastic used for soda bottles, already comply. Opponents say that some of the options are so unrealistic as to be useless, like making a food container that will be re-used five times. And some manufacturers say materials like polystyrene, better known as Styrofoam, and plastic films used for food packaging could never comply.
Ms. Perry said that the initiative does not discriminate against plastics as a group, but may favor some plastics over others. That raises the prospect of sharp swings in the prices of the raw materials of plastics.
The proposal is intended to extend the life of landfills as well as reduce the use of virgin materials in packaging. Ms. Perry said it would reduce the more than 6.8 million tons of waste that goes to landfills and incinerators each year by 1 million tons; opponents dispute the figure.
In a debate here this evening, one of dozens that have been held around the state, Ms. Perry and Stephen Allen, who is a spokesman for a manufacturers' group that opposes the referendum, disagreed over the cost of the initiative to consumers. A study performed for the Responsible Waste Management and Jobs Committee, an industry group, estimated that the initiative would affect $39 billion worth of goods, 50,000 products in all, and would add $190 million to $840 million to the cost of consumer products. The likely result, said the study, would be a burden of $230 annually per household. Mr. Allen said the measure would leave 90 percent of wastes untouched.
But Ms. Perry said that the study overestimated the cost by assuming the need to repackage some items that are already in compliance, like soda bottles. And she noted that the initiative already has the support of some businesses as well as the Republican Governor, who has made a television commercial saying the proposal is "pro environment and pro business."
Paul Denning, a member of the Watertown Council, which has unanimously endorsed the initiative, said his town is capable of collecting all kinds of materials, but "it's very frustrating because there are no end-markets."
Steven E. Kilberg, the plant manager of the Sweetheart Cup Company in the Boston suburb of Somerville, who was also at the debate, who said recycling polystyrene was impractical, and that his company would probably stop selling its products in Massachusetts.
Ms. Perry responded: "If the Massachusetts public wants toothpaste, there's going to be someone to do it. If Crest decides it doesn't want to, then Colgate will benefit."
Others are not sure the rest of the world will bother. Hope Tsacoyeanes, executive vice president of the Watertown Chamber of Commerce, cited an oft-used statistic here, that 80 percent of what Massachusetts consumes is packaged in another state or country. She said some consumers will pay dearly for the rules that manufacturers will have to meet.
"Massachusetts has this zeal to be first," said Ms. Tsacoyeanes. "Why us, why not the whole country? It's obviously something that's needed, but why punish a failing economy?"
Christopher P. Flynn, president of Massachusetts Food Association, said in an interview, "it doesn't follow that if you have mandates that you pick out of the sky, that all of a sudden, infrastructure will develop." His group complains that the bill does not pay for new recycling centers that would help packagers comply with the law..
The backers say that until the last few weeks polls showed a overwhelming majority of voters favored the referendum, but now the measure's supporters are contending with a blitz of advertising by the other side. The supporters have no television or radio budget, but have persuaded a few stations to run counter-ads, including one narrated by the Governor, as a matter of fairness.
As opponents have said that some products will be unavailable in Massachusetts if the question is approved by voters, supporters have resorted to ridicule in response. In one radio ad, a voice that sounds like it comes from a stuffed shirt intones that the referendum "will end life on this planet as we know it."
"We'll be starving, naked cave persons," the advertisement says.
The Public Interest Research Group, continuing this theme, has put posters on college campuses to drum up support that say, "Buy Naked, Vote Naked."

HEADLINE: Bush or Clinton, Europe Expects No Shift in Foreign Policy

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The idea that Gov. Bill Clinton might be elected President next week seems to cause little aprehension among Western European leaders. Most are more worried about their own political survival.
"We all become a little conservative as we grow older, so there's a tendency to think that things will go better with the person you know," Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain said in an interview in Madrid the other day. 
 "I have had a very comfortable, intense and fruitful relationship with President Bush," he said. "I think the United States has an international dimension which appears little in the campaigns. But whoever sits in the White House has no choice but to assume it."
And, Mr. Gonzalez added, "the U.S. has to recover economically to reassume its international responsibilities."
Mr. Clinton's campaign has made much the same argument. And according to officials in Bonn, London and Rome, government leaders, to the extent that they think about the election at all, take about the same view as Mr. Gonzalez: they do not expect major changes in foreign policy if Mr. Clinton is elected.
 
Mitterrand Is Mum
 In France, President Francois Mitterrand's aides have given no hint of his preference.
Mr. Mitterrand is balking at making some concessions in agricultural policy demanded by the United States as a condition for a new global trade agreement. But his motivation is believed to lie mainly in French domestic politics: He needs the support of French farmers to hold onto his own job.
French officials have been saying recently that no trade agreement is possible before the United States elections, but that probably reflects a desire by Mr. Mitterrand's Socialist Party to put off any deal until after the French legislative elections in March, political observers in Paris say.
David Aaron, a deputy national security adviser in the Carter Administration, went to Paris this month to assure French officials that continuity in American policy would be assured if there was a change of administrations.
The Paris daily Le Monde said Mr. Aaron had also told the French that Mr. Clinton's attitude toward the NATO alliance would be less rigid and "dogmatic" than the Bush Administration's. When he was Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d took an extremely negative view of French-German plans to build a "Eurocorps" as the kernel of a European Community defense force that could act independently of NATO.
In Germany, some politicians close to Chancellor Helmut Kohl say they would not be disturbed by a change in administrations, and would welcome it if Mr. Clinton appointed Representative Les Aspin as Secretary of State or Senator Sam Nunn as Secretary of Defense (though Mr. Clinton has not said he would do that). Both men are well known and widely respected as "moderate Democrats," a senior German politician said.
"Clinton has made clear he would continue the basic policy," a German foreign policy official added. "Whether there are 50,000 American troops more or less doesn't make much difference now that the cold war is over."
Mr. Clinton recently suggested that he might continue troop withdrawals even after United States forces in Europe reached the floor of 150,000 that Mr. Bush set for 1995.
Some German officials have less than fond memories of the last Democratic Administration, under President Carter, but these seem to have faded. Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel, according to those close to him, knows Anthony Lake, one of Mr. Clinton's campaign foreign policy aides, from his days in the State Department.
The German Foreign Ministry's political director, Jurgen Chrobog, made a point of conferring with Mr. Lake in New York during the United Nations General Assembly last month, officials here say.
The influential weekly German news magazine Der Spiegel even suggested in a recent issue that Chancellor Helmut Kohl actually wanted Mr. Clinton to win, a view that Mr. Kohl's close aides dispute. "The Chancellor will always be grateful to President Bush for his role in making German reunification possible," one said.
European news organizations have provided extensive coverage of the campaign. Le Monde has used the occasion to run a series on the decline of America as a world power, emphasizing all the social and economic problems Mr. Clinton has brought up to argue that it is time for a change.
"Whistlestop Bush is dogged by farce," The Sunday Times reported last weekend in London, where the President's friend, Prime Minister John Major, is on the ropes only six months after winning an election.
It isn't all that certain, some British officials say, that Mr. Major will still be holding his own job next January, but if he is, they say, he will undoubtedly prefer to continue building on the close relationship he established with Mr. Bush over the war in the Persian Gulf.
But the British are also prepared for a different outcome. "I would undoubtedly be in favor of a continuation of the Republican Administration," said Peter Temple-Morris, a lawmaker from Mr. Major's Conservative Party, but "I'd say a Clinton Presidency is very likely."
"People here are quite reassured about Clinton," Mr. Temple-Morris said. "He's an Oxford man, a gentleman from the South, just the sort of American the British often take to."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Finance;
Perot Leads in $40 Million TV Ad Blitz

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Led by Ross Perot, the Presidential candidates are engaged in the costliest advertising blitz of any general election campaign. Already, they have poured more than $40 million into network television alone, and they expect to spend millions more by next Tuesday.
That figure represents only a portion of the spending on broadcast commercials because the campaigns are also spending large amounts in local markets and on radio stations. 
 The surge in advertising budgets is driven in large part by Mr. Perot, who is spending far more than any previous independent candidate. In the first two weeks of this month, after he got back in the race, Mr. Perot dipped into his personal fortune, spending $26 million, almost exclusively on ads, including network, radio and local television. That was more than double what either President Bush or Gov. Bill Clinton had spent, according to the Federal Election Commission.
Today in Dallas, Mr. Perot's campaign unveiled nine new commercials, a departure in that they feature the candidate himself instead of a rolling text.
The Perot campaign has been distinctive for its half-hour or hourlong programs devoted to issues like the deficit or to Mr. Perot's biography. The eighth such "infomercial" was broadcast tonight.
Unlike the major party candidates, who each received $55 million in Federal subsidies for the general election by agreeing not to accept private donations, Mr. Perot can spend as much of his own fortune as he wants on his independent effort. He has said he expects to spend more than $60 million.
Political commercials will be virtually inescapable in this final stretch; all three campaigns have purchased time on mystery programs, football games, comedies and more. Network advertising executives said they had never expected the campaigns to buy so much air time this year.
A survey today of advertising purchases on ABC, CBS and NBC found that Mr. Perot had spent $19.8 million on network commercials, the most of the three candidates. He was followed by Mr. Bush, who had spent $17.5 million, and Mr. Clinton, $5.4 million.
 
Windfall for ABC TV
 "It's a huge difference from '88," said Stephen Battaglio, manager of media relations for ABC. "And our sales department has been expecting more buys in the final week."
To date, the Presidential campaigns and the Democratic Party have purchased $22 million in advertising on ABC, Mr. Battaglio said, far more than on the other networks. "I guess it's because we tend to reach a younger viewer who is less likely to watch news programming," he said.
Though the Perot and Bush campaigns have by no means held back on their network advertising in recent weeks, they like the Clinton campaign, are planning blitzes for the final week. On CBS, for example, the Clinton campaign has paid for nearly $1 million worth of time for ads that have yet to run.
Each of the three campaigns is expected to broadcast 30-minute appeals the night before the election, which ABC said it would cost the campaigns another $472,500.
 
Some Targeted Ads
 The network figures do not tell the full story. The Clinton campaign is expected to spend as much as the Bush campaign, but it is concentrating on local markets in crucial states, a tactic pioneered in earlier campaigns by Republicans. The Democrats say that targeting their advertising is more efficient because the campaign does not spend money on states where Mr. Clinton has either a comfortable lead or no chance of winning.
By contrast, the Bush campaign, which has found itself behind Mr. Clinton across the country, has emphasized national buys. But it, too, has purchased time in some targeted states, as has Mr. Perot, despite his preference for national commercials. The campaigns have refused to say exactly how much they are spending in local television markets.
In addition to the advertising purchased by the campaigns, other groups are buying air time to help particular candidates. Democratic Party officials say they expect to spent as much as $12 million on generic advertising that does not mention their candidates by name. Much of that will be spent in the final days of the campaign. On ABC alone, the Democrats have bought $1.7 million worth of time.
The more than $40 million spent on network advertising thus far is already a record; in 1988 the campaigns spent $38.5 million on network advertising in the general election, according to the Television Bureau of Advertising, a trade group.
Harold Simpson, a vice president of the bureau, said Mr. Perot's aggressive advertising efforts have helped spur Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton to compete. "Both parties," he said, "are pulling out all the stops at the national, regional and local levels."
Mr. Simpson said the bureau projected that candidates for national and local offices this election will spend more than $300 million on advertising, compared with nearly $230 million in 1988.
To fill half of the hour he purchased on ABC tonight, Mr. Perot broadcast a new presentation about building businesses and creating jobs, the central effort the Texas entrepreneur says he would bring to the White House.
But rather than giving an academic discourse on national tax and investment policy, Mr. Perot provided a Dale Carnegie-style lecture about his basic business principles.
"Listen, listen, listen to your customer," he said.
"Keep titles in the background. Keep performance in the foreground."
"If you have a corporate politician, fire him."
Mr. Perot suggested that his experience in building a large data-processing corporation was more applicable to the country's economic problems than his opponents' familiarity with fiscal policy.
"Economists base everything on theory," he said. "What we need is people with practical experience in business who know how to do this."
And when asked by his interviewer, actually his media consultant, how small new companies should compete with larger established ones, Mr. Perot gave a response that seemed intended as a metaphor for his campaign. "They will dismiss you as a loony for showing up and they will go into cardiac arrest when you win," he said.
The Perot campaign announced today that it had purchased time for still more "infomercials": 30 minutes on CBS on Wednesday night; 30 minutes on ABC and 60 minutes on NBC on Sunday night; and 30 minutes on all three networks on Monday night, the eve of the election.
Sharon Holman, Mr. Perot's press secretary, said she had high hopes for the new ads. "Probably, at least in my own opinion, there's nothing more powerful than Ross Perot looking right in the camera and talking to you," she said. "That's the reason for part of the success of the infomercials, and I think part of the success of the debates as well."

HEADLINE: Santo Domingo Journal;
Shepherds, or Wolves? Whatever, Flocks Grow

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Re public

 BODY:
To believe Pope John Paul II, Bienvenido Alvarez-Vega is one of the Protestant "rapacious wolves" who are increasingly stealing Latin Americans from the Roman Catholic flock.
After the Pope used that phrase in a speech to a meeting here of Latin American bishops in mid-October, Mr. Alvarez talked about religion in his roomy office at the Santo Domingo daily paper El Siglo. 
 Wearing a pink shirt and casual slacks, Mr. Alvarez did not look either rapacious or wolflike. But as an articulate, university-educated Pentecostal Christian who directs one of the Dominican Republic's major newspapers, he certainly represents the dramatic progress of evangelical Protestantism in lands that have been historically Catholic.
Adherents of Protestant evangelical or Pentecostal churches, often with roots in the United States like Mr. Alvarez's Assemblies of God or the Church of God based in Cleveland, Tenn., are estimated at 18 to 21 percent of the population in Brazil, 16 percent in Chile and 20 percent in El Salvador. Estimates for Guatemala range from 18 to 33 percent. The estimate for Latin American generally is 6 to 7 percent.
 
A Topic for the Bishops
 This growth, a major item on the agenda of the Latin American Episcopal Conference meeting here in October, has been bitterly attacked by many Catholic leaders. They have portrayed what they call "sects" as everything from Communist infiltrators to agents of Yankee capitalism, the Pentagon and the Central Intelligence Agency.
One passage of the Pope's official text echoed this vision of a well-orchestrated, well-financed religious invasion by outsiders: "We must not underestimate a certain strategy whose objective is to weaken the links that unite the countries of Latin America and in this way erode the strength born of unity. Important economic resources are allocated toward this goal, to finance proselytizing campaigns aimed at destroying Catholic unity."
But Mr. Alvarez said the Pope's speech actually represented a moderation of the Catholic attitude. The Pope, Mr. Alvarez noted, had also attributed the success of Protestant groups to shortcomings in the Catholic church's own pastoral efforts, including the shortage of priests.
Protestantism in the Dominican Republic has actually lagged behind that in other nations, although the ranks of evangelical and Pentecostal Christians here have included Cabinet ministers and a presidential candidate, Mr. Alvarez said.
Most of the growth, now encompassing about half a million of the nation's 11 million people, was occurring among the poor. The new Protestant groups are egalitarian, he said, breaking social barriers and sharing power in the congregations in a way that Catholicism did not.
"Anyone can talk, sing or give testimony," Mr. Alvarez said. "The service is spontaneous and indigenous," with local songs and rhythms.
Asked whether his Protestant faith made him feel like an outsider to Latin American culture, Mr. Alvarez said, "Exactly the opposite."
Mr. Alvarez grew up in a Catholic home in La Romana, a sugar town with a large number of English and American residents and "a lot of Protestant influences," he said. He joined the Assemblies of God at 12. When he went to the Autonomous University of Santo Domingo to study communications, he joined an evangelical group affiliated with Intra-Varsity Christian Fellowship.
"My origins were Pentecostal," he said. "But I received my most solid formation in traditional Protestantism -- Lutheranism and Calvinism but with a Latin American perspective." He met his wife, a member of the Free Methodist Church, through the Intra-Varsity Christian Fellowship.
"Nobody has made a greater effort to have a Latin American theology than evangelicals," he said, and before Catholics "we had the liturgy in our own languages."
The fact that evangelical services were in Spanish was one of the things that attracted the Rev. Kerry Gonzalez when he was a boy in Cuba. Today he and his wife, Ethel, a native of Kansas, are missionaries with the Assemblies of God at the Trinity Evangelical Church in Santo Domingo.
Mrs. Gonzalez took leave of an evening Bible lesson, led by a 34-year-old former drug addict who once lived in New York, to explain that the church began in the 1970's in a carport and then moved into rented halls. It now meets in a simple but spacious concrete building seating 300. It runs a dispensary with five doctors and a school attended by 1,000 children in two shifts daily.
Mrs. Gonzalez said that only the salaries of her and her husband came from the Assemblies of God in the United States. The Santo Domingo church also welcomes gifts for schoolbooks, medical supplies and other specific items from North American friends and local congregations. But most of the church's funds are raised from its Dominican members, she said.
While the Bible lesson went from plodding repetition to a shouting, singing crescendo, Mr. Gonzalez spoke of his disappointment with the Pope's words. "He has come from Poland and gone through persecution," the 60-year-old minister said, "Anyone who has gone through that should have a better sense of religious freedom."
At the offices of El Siglo, Mr. Alvarez acknowledged that in some countries the evangelical churches, which "often think more of heaven than of earth," he said, had been favored by military leaders and conservative forces as a counterweight to grass-roots protests backed by Catholic groups. But he warned that with the Catholic Church still enjoying special privileges in many Latin American countries, the conflict with Protestants was apt to intensify as the latter grew more numerous.
Mr. Alvarez criticized his fellow evangelicals, most of whom, he said, do not recognize Catholics as genuine Christians. "I think that's a tragedy," he said. "It shows a spiritual arrogance, a sense of having a monopoly on the truth which is not real.
"I think there are important differences of theology and liturgy, but what unites us is bigger than what separates us, and both paths are sincere searches for God."

SECTION: Section A; Page 21; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Issues -- Unanswered Questions;
Bush, Clinton and Perot Demonstrate How to Let the Worst Go Unspoken

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
At the beginning of the Presidential debate last Monday night, with 90 million Americans looking on, Gov. Bill Clinton was asked a straightforward question: How can voters believe that he can pay for all his campaign promises so painlessly?
It was an appropriate question. The Democratic Presidential nominee promises to create jobs, reduce the budget deficit, cut taxes of the middle class, reform welfare, provide universal medical insurance, guarantee college educations for everyone qualified and spend $20 billion a year more on new public works projects. 
 To pay for all that, he proposes little beyond higher taxes on the very wealthy and foreign corporations and modest additional cuts in military spending.
 
Shift Into Cruising Gear
 But it also was a question Mr. Clinton has fielded time and again this year before smaller audiences. So in the debate, he shifted into his familiar cruising gear. He responded that middle-class Americans were overtaxed. He decried "trickle-down" and "tax-and-spend" economics. He said the country could "increase investment and reduce the deficit at the same time."
Once again, he did not answer the question.
Throughout the campaign, Mr. Clinton, President Bush and Ross Perot have ducked a variety of questions -- or managed to avoid discussing certain difficult topics altogether. The matter of how they would pay for their campaign promises is foremost. But they have also dodged such issues as urban decay, homelessness and bank failures.
 
$250 Billion in Lost Revenue
 Mr. Bush is no more precise about how the country could afford the pinata filled with the tax cuts he favors: an across-the-board reduction by one percentage point in tax rates, increased personal exemptions for families with children, credits and deductions to help families pay for medical insurance, a cut in the capital gains tax rate, new tax breaks for investments in plants, machinery and real estate, tax credits for first-time homebuyers, more generous tax treatment of individual retirement accounts, lower small-business taxes and writeoffs for businesses that give workers time off in family emergencies. All together, these tax measures could cost the Government $250 billion or more in lost revenue over the next five years.
The President said last Monday night, as he has throughout the campaign, that he intended "to get the deficit down by controlling the growth of mandatory spending." Just what is this mandatory spending he wants to control, and how does he propose to control it? Mr. Bush never says.
Mr. Perot has made deficit reduction the focal point of his campaign, and he talks often about "fair, shared sacrifice." But even his ledger is heavy on the side of promises and light on the side of pain.
Tom Stacy, a law professor at De Paul University in Chicago who has scrutinized Mr. Perot's policy proposals, puts the matter this way: "Perot is not very different from the stereotypical politician from whom he tries to distance himself. He, too, promises that we can have our cake and eat it too. We can balance the budget while having everything else we want: economic growth, universal health care, better schools and safer streets."
 
The Deficit
Doubtful Figures For Many Plans
 The budget deficit -- the difference between what the Government spends and the revenue it takes in -- is expected to be nearly $350 billion in this fiscal year, by far the highest in the nation's history. All the candidates talk about reducing it.
Mr. Perot says he would eliminate it entirely in six years. Mr. Bush says he would lower the deficit by two-thirds at least, and Mr. Clinton promises to cut it in half during the next four years.
Almost without exception, independent experts who have studied these proposals say that the candidates' figures do not stand up to scrutiny.
"Clinton's plan just doesn't add up, and Bush hasn't proposed anything specific," said Stanley E. Collender, a specialist in the Federal budget at Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm. The Perot proposals, Mr. Collender added, have little meaning unless the independent candidate explains how he would reduce the Government's spending on Medicare and Medicaid, which will continue to mushroom if the law is not changed.
In fact, the biggest problem with all of their plans is that the three candidates want to overhaul the nation's medical care system to make health insurance much more widely available, but none have suggested realistically how this could be financed.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush suggest it could be done by controlling medical costs in one way or another. Mr. Bush talks about somehow restraining malpractice lawsuits. Mr. Clinton has said he wants a Federal board to set prices. But the authorities doubt any of this would be sufficient, and say universal medical insurance could cost the Government as much as $20 billion a year.
Mr. Perot is even more vague. In the debate Monday night, here is how he described what he would do about the problem: "We've got plans lying all over the place in Washington. Nobody ever implements them. Now I'm back to square one. If you want to stop talking about it and do it, then I'll go up there, and we'll get it done."
Beyond the cost of medical care, the higher taxes Mr. Clinton proposes for the wealthy would be offset by the tax cuts for the middle class. Many tax analysts say Mr. Clinton's plan to tighten enforcement of tax laws affecting foreign corporations doing business in the United States would raise nowhere near the $45 billion over four years that he forecasts.
And while Mr. Clinton would reduce military spending by a total of $38 billion below current plans for the next five years, that would not begin to pay for $220 billion in new spending for new transportation, communications and environmental cleanup projects, research and development of new technology, education and job training.
Mr. Clinton's deficit reduction is based largely on his forecast that the economy will be stronger in the next few years than most economists are predicting.
Furthermore, his balance sheet shows the Government saving billions of dollars through such vague steps as revising the Defense Department inventory system, "management reform" in the savings and loan bailout and a 3 percent cut in "administrative waste." This sounds suspiciously like Ronald Reagan's unfulfilled pledge to eliminate the Government's "waste, fraud and abuse."
Mr. Bush's principal deficit-cutting proposal is to put a cap on the growth of what he calls "mandatory spending," what used to be called "entitlements." The President would allow these programs, under which benefits are paid automatically to everyone who is eligible, to grow no faster than the increase in the eligible population and the general rate of inflation. But since medical prices are rising far faster than the general rate of inflation, this means Mr. Bush will have to accept deep cuts in Government spending for Medicare and Medicaid, although he never says that.
This year the Government will spend $750 billion, about half the total budget, on these mandatory programs. About 40 percent of these funds will go for Social Security, which the President says he will not touch.
Most of the other programs, including welfare, food stamps and pensions for veterans and retired Government employees, already rise no faster than the rate of inflation and the increase in the number of people eligible. In fact, welfare benefits, adjusted for inflation, are now much lower than they were a decade ago.
The only places left for substantial cuts are Medicare and Medicaid, which are the fastest growing expenses in the budget next to interest on the national debt. Together, they will cost about $225 billion this year.
These programs are very popular, the foundation of the safety net for the elderly. Medicare provides health insurance for everyone 65 years of age and older. Medicaid is often thought of as the health insurance program for the poor, but three-quarters of Medicaid money goes for nursing home care.
If Mr. Bush has any real plan to limit Medicare and Medicaid spending, he has never let on during his nearly four years in office.
Mr. Perot says he would raise the gasoline tax by 10 cents a gallon each year for five years. The revenue, however, would go for public works projects, not for deficit reduction.
He does propose some other specific tax increases and spending reductions. But 20 percent of his deficit reduction would come from lower Medicare and Medicaid spending, and he has never said how he could deliver that.
 
Urban Blight
Little Discussion And Few Proposals
 Listening to the candidates, it is as if Los Angeles never burned last spring, as if homeless people are not sleeping on the grates in every city in America. There is little sense on the campaign trail that America is more than one big middle class with everyone equally imperiled by the economic downturn. And there is little recognition that a stronger economy might not be enough to solve some people's miseries.
"There has been remarkably little discussion of urban blight, given that the Los Angeles riots occurred in the middle of the political year," said Theda Skocpol, a Harvard sociologist who is writing a history of American social policy.
The candidates are avoiding the issue partly because the problems are immune to simple, inexpensive solutions, and are so laced with the explosive topic of race that they do not lend themselves to ordinary political discourse. But Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton also have their own, purely political reasons for shying away from the issue of poverty.
The President and his closest advisers believe that an aggressive antipoverty agenda like the one sought by his Housing Secretary, Jack F. Kemp, would raise expectations that could not be met and help mobilize constituencies that typically vote Democratic.
 
Fighting an Old Image
 Meanwhile, Mr. Clinton is trying to shed the image, used to advantage by Mr. Reagan, that Democrats are the party of poor people and members of minority groups, at the expense of the broad middle class.
In part, Governor Clinton is siding with those who believe that social policies limited to the poor, like welfare, will always be politically weak, since most Americans do not qualify for them. In this view, it is better to design programs like Social Security or universal medical insurance that help the poor but have the political support of the middle class.
Of course, the consequence of such a policy is that the nation ends up spending scarce resources on wealthy retired people and others who do not need them.
On the matter of homelessness, Secretary Kemp promised shortly after taking office at the beginning of the Bush Administration to make it one of his chief concerns. But generally, promises to make unused Federal property available to the homeless and to make special efforts to get Social Security benefits to homeless people who are mentally disabled have not been fulfilled.
In July, Mr. Clinton suggested that the Reagan and Bush Administrations were partly responsible for the growth in the number of homeless people. "Due to enormous cuts in Federal housing assistance in the Reagan-Bush era," Mr. Clinton said, "we suffer from a huge shortage of affordable housing, our pubic housing stock has deteriorated and homelessness has exploded."
But neither then nor at any other time in the campaign has Mr. Clinton said exactly what he would do about the problem.
 
The Banks
Hardly a Word As Crisis Looms
 In the Presidential campaign four years ago, Mr. Bush and Michael S. Dukakis ignored the collapsing savings and loan industry, which turned out to be the worst debacle in public finance since the Depression, one that will eventually cost the taxpayers as much as $500 billion. It turned out to be the first big issue Mr. Bush had to tackle once he was in the White House.
Once again, the situation is hardly being discussed. And when it does come up the candidates tend toward demagoguery. For example, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Perot have both accused the President of willingly spending billions on the savings and loan bailout while refusing to spend money on other problems.
But Mr. Bush has little choice. The money is being used to pay off depositors who had Government-insured accounts in savings institutions that failed. The Government cannot ignore those obligations any more than it could refuse to pay interest to holders of Government bonds.
The next administration will be confronted early on with the need to seek tens of billions of dollars of new taxpayer money to continue the savings and loan bailout. In addition, a new law that takes effect in December will require Government regulators to seize many troubled banks at a time when the bank insurance fund is already $5.5 billion in the red. The Office of Management and Budget has predicted that the insurance fund could face losses as high as $72 billion through 1995.
 
The Bailout Continues
 Both Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton have talked vaguely of the need to relax regulations over the banks to encourage more lending and stimulate the economy. But neither man has forthrightly said that the savings and loan bailout is still far from over, and that it may require $80 billion more to be completed.
Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who heads the House Banking Committee, said Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush had "trivialized the banking crisis by saying it does not exist."
The candidates are avoiding the issue largely because they see no benefit in bearing bad news. Both parties are to blame for the savings and loan and banking messes, and the issues are so technical and complicated that discussing them is hardly a sure way to win votes.

HEADLINE: SHAKE-UP AT G.M.;
STEMPEL QUITS JOB AS TOP G.M. OFFICER IN RIFT WITH BOARD

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Robert C. Stempel resigned today as chairman and chief executive of the General Motors Corporation amid speculation about his imminent dismissal and the failure of the board of the world's largest manufacturer to give him a public vote of confidence.
Mr. Stempel's departure, the culmination of several days of reports of a widening rift between him and the board, represented a bitter realization that the apparent campaign against him and his record left him powerless to steer the huge, deeply troubled car-making empire. 
 Over the 27 months of his tenure, the company reported two years of losses, including the largest annual loss ever by an American company. And while he had moved to stem the flow of red ink, the nation's No. 1 auto maker is headed for another year of losses, thanks to the highest costs in the industry, a sluggish car market and G.M.'s inability to capture a thicker slice of the market with improved cars and trucks. Some say that given the state of the economy, Mr. Stempel never really had a chance to turn the company's fortunes around.
 
Possible Successor
 G.M.'s board accepted Mr. Stempel's resignation but asked him to remain until it named a successor, an action that is expected soon, or certainly after a board meeting scheduled for New York next Monday. One widely believed sequence is that the board will ask John G. Smale, the 65-year-old retired chairman of the Procter & Gamble Company and a G.M. board member who led a management shake-up seven months ago, to assume the chairmanship for an interim period.
No matter who takes over, G.M.'s new chairman will essentially be locked into drastic cost-cutting dictated both by G.M.'s past slowness to respond to competitive pressures and by the weak economy. [Page D6.]
As part of the shake-up, it is believed that Mr. Stempel's chief executive's duties will be assumed by John F. (Jack) Smith Jr., 54, the G.M. president who was installed at the board's direction last April. Mr. Smith, who has 31 years with G.M. and is credited with turning around the auto maker's European operations in the 1980's, is focusing on the company's money-losing North American operations.
If Mr. Smith were to become chief, the board's clear mandate would be to take whatever action he thought necessary to quickly stanch financial losses, which might mean further elimination of jobs, more plant closings, sale of nonessential subsidiaries, executive dismissals and, perhaps, renegotiating the auto maker's labor agreement with the United Automobile Workers union.
"At this point, the board has no justification for not letting Smith forge his own course," said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, a professor of business at Emory University who specializes in corporate leadership. "People in G.M. will be reluctant to act if they think he doesn't have the board's confidence."
 
Wall Street Reaction
 Mr. Stempel's resignation came early in the day, before trading of G.M. shares began on the New York Stock Exchange. By the end of the day, G.M. shares were the most active, closing up 62.5 cents each, to $34.125. Since word of Mr. Stempel's possible ouster first circulated, investors had been bidding up G.M. shares aggressively.
In tendering his resignation, Mr. Stempel agreed to stay on until the board selected a successor. But in a statement, he pointedly added, "I could not in good conscience continue to watch the effects of rumors and speculation that have undermined and slowed the efforts of G.M. people to make this a stronger, more efficient, effective organization."
Mr. Smale issued a separate statement as chairman of the board's executive committee, in which he said the board "will announce our management changes as soon as practicable."
If Mr. Smale, an outsider, does take over, it would fulfill what many experts in corporate governance have been urging for hidebound American corporations: the breakup of the clubby atmosphere in corporate board rooms, where top executives rarely face tough grading of their performance and directors rarely take direct action.
 
Shivers in Detroit
 The events of the last two weeks, portending more painful retrenchment, have struck deeply at the pride of G.M. executives and workers, and sent shivers throughout Detroit.
Within hours of the announcement, chief executives of the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation issued sympathetic farewells to Mr. Stempel, a well-regarded automotive engineer who, like all of his predecessors, had been carefully groomed for the G.M. chairmanship for more than a decade.
While Mr. Stempel might have been a perfect chief executive in good times, he was a product of the G.M. system and was ill-suited to break the culture that had for years worked against the company in a generation of rapid change and global competition.
"A certain esprit may have been shattered at G.M., and I don't think that's bad," said Elmer W. Johnson, a former G.M. executive who is a partner with the law firm of Kirkland & Ellis in Chicago. "A new chief executive will have an opportunity to build a culture that is more in tune with the times."
The United Automobile Workers union, reacting to Mr. Stempel's resignation, jabbed at what it described as G.M. directors' "tactics of management by rumor, news leak and innuendo."
The U.A.W., which represents 308,000 G.M. hourly workers in the United States and has endorsed Gov. Bill Clinton for the Presidency, imparted a political flavor to its statement, calling Mr. Stempel a "victim" of misguided "White House policies that have relentlessly tightened a noose around our nation's domestic auto producers."
 
Tough Bargaining Ahead
 Hourly workers are only too aware that the dire financial conditions leading to Mr. Stempel's exit might result in tough bargaining soon over the most generous pay and job security benefits in American industry. In any case, bargaining for a new long-term labor agreement is only about nine months away.
Mr. Stempel's resignation capped a tumultuous period of news leaks and rumors -- and G.M. denials -- that he was on the way out. It also was a trying month for him personally. On the day The Washington Post reported that he might be dismissed if he did not toughen his stance against the union, Mr. Stempel collapsed at a meeting in Washington and was hospitalized there for two days suffering from high blood pressure.
Over Labor Day weekend, G.M. settled a damaging U.A.W. strike that exploded into 14 plant closings after the union protested management's attempt to phase out 240 parts-making jobs.
Since 1986, when G.M. directors voted to buy Ross Perot's G.M. stock for $750 million and force the Texas billionaire out of the company, G.M. directors have been taking a more active and visible role in management, under the urging and guidance of Ira Millstein, a senior partner of Weil, Gotshal & Manges in New York. Mr. Millstein declined to discuss the board's actions.
Mr. Perot's fight was largely with the leadership style and strategies of Mr. Stempel's predecessor, Roger B. Smith, whose unwillingness to cut unused capacity was at the heart of Mr. Stempel's problems.
 
Assessing the Blame
 Carl Sewell, a Cadillac dealer in Dallas, echoed the views of many G.M. executives and managers reacting to Mr. Stempel's resignation when he said Mr. Smith deserved "much more blame than Bob Stempel." Mr. Smith remains a G.M. director, though not in the group of 11 who are active in governance.
But another expert in corporate governance, who spoke on condition of anonymity said: "Bob can't get off free. He was at Roger Smith's side for most of the 1980's; he agreed with everything Roger did." Before becoming chairman in 1990, Mr. Stempel was president and chief operating officer and held several other important jobs.
Mr. Sonnenfeld, the Emory professor, while praising directors for acting, said: "It should have been 10 years ago. The band-aid being pulled off so slowly only has heightened the level of anxiety. Uncertainty is worse than decisive, traumatic action."
But last Thursday evening, only hours after Mr. Smale signaled the board's loss of confidence in the G.M. chairman, Mr. Stempel still felt confident enough to preside at a retirement dinner for Charles Jordan, the auto maker's styling chief. As executives dined in a paneled third-floor dining room of the venerable Detroit Club, Mr. Stempel assured colleagues the newspaper reports of his departure were nothing but rumors.
"He seemed O.K. to me," said a G.M. executive who spoke on condition of anonymity. "He said everything was going to be all right."
In accordance with longstanding G.M. ritual, Mr. Jordan received an inscribed silver platter, which retired G.M. officers refer to as their "pickle dish," and the 50 or so officers watched a 12-minute film of Mr. Jordan's life prepared by G.M. video technicians.
 
Eyes on the Chairman
 From the corners of many eyes, officers were watching Mr. Stempel. Hurt and disappointed because G.M. directors -- who possessed little or no direct automotive experience -- had emasculated their leader, they may have wondered if he could win back his power by proving there was no way to speed changes already underway. "I thought he just might tough it out," said one middle manager on Sunday night.
But by the weekend, Mr. Stempel had concluded that the lack of confidence from the board, as well as G.M.'s mounting financial woes and the deepening anxiety that he might not be able to restructure quickly enough to prevent a cash crisis, was too much to bear.

LENGTH: 1049 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush, Sounding Like His Rivals, Tones Down His Attacks, Briefly

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 26

 BODY:
President Bush set aside his unremitting assault on Gov. Bill Clinton for a few hours this morning to make a final attempt to address the currents of discontent in 1992.
He painted himself as a "conservative activist" combining the most popular attributes of Ross Perot and Mr. Clinton. But by midafternoon in Albuquerque, Mr. Bush was back on the full-throated attack, talking about his opponents' "crazy ideas" and directing the ire of his supporters at the press while his advisers tried to come to grips with a rapidly changing political landscape. 
 Mr. Bush's attacks on Mr. Clinton had helped produce the shift in public opinion polls that the Republicans had been seeking for weeks. But to the dismay of the Bush camp, it succeeded only in pushing Mr. Perot up and did nothing to improve the President's own standing.
 
Forget the Stand-In
 Midway through a Rocky Mountain campaign swing dominated by the urgent need to come to grips with that situation, Mr. Bush went to Denver this morning to appear before a conference of Ace Hardware store owners and deliver a domestic policy speech that had been planned for his chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d. But White House strategists concluded that having Mr. Baker speak for Mr. Bush there would only add to the notion that Mr. Bush was weak on domestic policy.
The talk turned into an unlikely mixture of the President's own proposals, including the line-item veto and a balanced-budget amendment, Perot-like calls for a joining of forces to break Washington's gridlock and compassionate talk of lifting up future generations that was reminiscent of Mr. Clinton's own oratory.
 
A Promise on Deadlines
 Mr. Bush said he would work with newly elected members of Congress to produce a bipartisan package of economic measures, which he did not spell out but would clearly be based on his own ideas, before a second inauguration on Jan. 20. He said he would create two new teams, one to shepherd his programs through Congress and another to prepare military plants for conversion to civilian production.
Mr. Bush, who has come under fire from within his own party for setting political deadlines and letting them pass almost unnoticed, vowed that a second term would be different. "We'll set deadlines for decisions and we'll meet them," he said.
Mr. Bush's remarks were based on a calculation by his advisers that Mr. Perot is about to slide in the polls and that Mr. Bush must therefore do something to stop Mr. Perot's supporters from backing Mr. Clinton.
"A lot of Perot's supporters are not going to pull his lever in the voting booth," a Bush campaign official said today. "They're going to vote for one of the other two candidates and we have to give them a reason to make that George Bush. That requires a positive message, not just attacks."
But Mr. Perot's accusations on Sunday of Republican dirty tricks only served to complicate things. Bush aides went into a state of alarm today as attention turned equally to a hotly worded retort by Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, who called Mr. Perot "crazy" and "paranoid."
 
Borrowed Themes
 In trying to reach out to Perot backers in Denver this morning, Mr. Bush seemed to appropriate ideas from each of his rivals: Mr. Clinton's cultivated image of compassion and change, and Mr. Perot's themes of efficiency and can-do American capitalism.
"The real choice is not between activism and passivity," Mr. Bush said. "The real choice is between a liberal activist Government that seeks to impose solutions on individuals, families and the private sector, and a conservative activist Government that gives individuals, families and businesses the means to make their own choices through competition and economic opportunity."
In outlining his "vision for America," Mr. Bush seemed to dwell primarily on the past, giving himself credit for ending the cold war and denouncing Mr. Clinton as a "tax and spend" Democrat.
It was only when he sought to portray himself as a man of action that Mr. Bush offered new themes that some of his advisers and other Republicans had been trying to inject into his speeches for months.
"As the support for Ross Perot has made clear, there is a strong desire for a new coalition in America -- to overcome gridlock, to get the job done," Mr. Bush said.
To address the need to convert military plants to civilian uses, Mr. Bush said: "Immediately following the election, I will assemble a defense conversion council. And it will include every necessary Cabinet agency and work closely with key members of the United States Congress."
Mr. Bush, in a distinctly Clinton-like turn of phrase, also said he would create "a fund for future generations" that would provide seed money to use weapons-making technology for peaceful ends.
Noting that scores of new members of Congress will be elected in November, the President said, "I plan to use the time from Nov. 4 through convening of the new Congress to meet with all the new members of Congress, regardless of party and to shape a legislative package in a way that will guarantee swift passage."
Mr. Bush did not offer any details of what he meant by a legislative package.
Mr. Bush, who has made character the centerpiece of his attack on Mr. Clinton, said in Denver that the choice of a President in 1992 came down to "ideas, action, character." He talked of his anguish over the decision to send Americans into war with Iraq.
"When you enter that voting booth," he said, "ask yourself three common-sense questions: Who has the right vision for America's future? Who can get us from here to there? And which character has the character? And who would you trust with your family or with the United States of America in a crisis?"
But by the time he arrived in Albuquerque, Mr. Bush was back to ridiculing Mr. Clinton, using a comment in which the Democrat confused a Patriot anti-missile weapon with a cruise missile to suggest that he knew nothing about military affairs. "He was the guy who said the Patriot missile was the one that goes down chimneys," Mr. Bush said. "Governor, that is Santa Claus."
With a sneer, he added: "I mean, come on. This guy wants to be Commander in Chief and he doesn't know the difference between a Patriot and Santa Claus."

HEADLINE: Connecticut Senate Candidates Debate (Politely)

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 26

 BODY:
Connecticut's Senate candidates, who have attacked and ridiculed each other in television commercials in recent weeks, were absolute gentlemen tonight in a muted, polite debate before a statewide television audience.
The Democratic incumbent, Christopher J. Dodd, and the Republican challenger, Brook Johnson, did disagree on some issues -- notably how and which types of capital gains taxes might best be cut to stimulate the economy, and whether a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution would really help reduce the nation's budget deficit. Mr. Dodd called the amendment idea a gimmick; Mr. Johnson said it would force lawmakers to focus on the task of budget cutting. 
 But if viewers had expected fireworks in the last of three debates for the candidates, they were disappointed. The tone of the hour, which was sponsored by the League of Women Voters and the New London Day newspaper, was often downright respectful.
Mr. Johnson's recent television commercial, for example, portrays Mr. Dodd as a globe-trotting politician who cannot be bothered with the problems of Connecticut, illustrating the point by showing Mr. Dodd's picture superimposed underneath series of different silly hats and native head-dresses from around the world. But in the debate, Mr. Johnson actually praised Mr. Dodd for his efforts to help save defense jobs in Connecticut -- a major issue especially in this corner of the state -- and skipped opportunities to draw blood.
"You're a little more macro in the way you look at it, I'm a little more micro -- now that doesn't mean you're wrong and I'm right," said Mr. Johnson, a businessman making his first run for office, in one typical exchange about taxes and economic policy.
Mr. Dodd, who is seeking his third six-year term in the Senate, needled Mr. Johnson several times about investing capital from his textile business in Canada instead of the United States, and pointed out several times to the audience that Mr. Johnson had not really answered a question put to the candidates by a panel of journalists. But he stopped short of the pointed questioning that characterized their last debate last week -- about Mr. Johnson's business record, his lack of public experience, and his failure to vote in many elections.
Their most substantive exchange came over a question about taxes. Mr. Johnson said he favored reducing the capital-gains taxes on profits from the sale of stock or real-estate, for example, if the asset is held for a certain length of time.
Mr. Dodd said he wanted a targeted capital gains tax cut that would give tax breaks to developing companies, which would create jobs in the future. Mr. Johnson's plan, Mr. Dodd charged, would simply transfer more of the nation's wealth to the rich.
"This is exactly how we got into the mess, with that mentality and those ideas that created the leveraged buy outs and the acquisitions and the mergers -- the predators that destroyed, in my view, a good part of our economy in the 1980's," Mr. Dodd said.
Mr. Johnson disagreed, saying his plan would free capital for investment and job-creation, but would not enrich short-term speculators.
"There's no clearer choice for the state of Connecticut than between Chris Dodd and myself," Mr. Johnson said later in the debate. "I am an outsider with no political background and no political experience -- Chris is definitely a political insider with a lot of political background and political experience."
The real problem of Washington, Mr. Johnson said, is that people fight too much over politics.
"What has to happen in this next term in Washington, whether I'm there or you're there, is that there has to be some burying of the hatchet, because the only ones with their heads on the chopping block are we the American taxpayers," he said.

HEADLINE: Budget Surplus Is Projected By Analysts In New York

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 26

 BODY:
New York State's leaders, who for the last four years faced massive midyear budget deficits that spurred bitter political fights and painful spending cuts, announced today that they were facing something all but forgotten in the Capitol: a budget surplus.
The surplus, while negligible in size, nonetheless indicates that the state's $30.9 billion budget is in balance. That alone suggests a significant turnaround not only in the state government's financial condition, but also in the way it approaches budgeting. 
 Last year at this time, state officials said there was a $689 million deficit. The announcement was followed by months of budget battles that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said kept him on the sidelines of the Presidential campaign and that caused a damaging cut in the state's credit rating.
 
Cautious Revenue Forecasts
 Today's report, from the state Division of the Budget, could be the first step in a lengthy process aimed at restoring the state's credit rating, which sank earlier this year to the lowest of any state in the nation. Massachusetts, which previously held that dubious distinction but was forced to grapple with its budget problems earlier than New York, got such a boost this summer.
The small surplus of $21 million was tied not so much to any fundamental recovery in New York's economy, but to cautious revenue forecasts built into last spring's budget agreement and an economy that has not grown significantly worse since then, budget analysts said.
Today's announcement from the budget division, which is overseen by Governor Cuomo, came barely a week before all 211 state legislative seats are up for election. But the budget report was required by law to be made before this Friday, which marks the official midpoint of the state fiscal year.
Mr. Cuomo is not on the ballot, and if anything, the news would appear to be most beneficial to his Republican adversaries, who are facing a tough battle in their bid to maintain control of the state Senate. The Democrats have an all but unshakable hold on the Assembly.
Last year, at the height of the budget battles, Mr. Cuomo accused the Republicans of driving the state to the brink of financial ruin, and pledged that he would remind the voters of their alleged transgressions this fall. But Mr. Cuomo was mostly smiles when he appeared with the Republican Senate leader, Ralph J. Marino, this afternoon at a bill-signing ceremony.
 
'Going to Get Killed'
 The Governor, Mr. Marino and Democratic lawmakers ratified a "memorandum of understanding" for how they planned to spend the money from the $800 million economic-development bond act, if voters give their approval to it next Tuesday.
Last December, after the State Senate refused to go along with the Governor's plan for a multiyear solution to the state's budget ills, a furious Mr. Cuomo said of Mr. Marino and his Republican colleagues: "They're going to get killed when they are revealed to the world. They are going to get badly burned." Mr. Marino himself is now facing a bruising re-election battle.
But today, asked whether he wished to reiterate such comments, Mr. Cuomo simply said voters should "remember what the Republicans did, they should remember what the Democrats did.
"They should punish the bad guys and support the good guys," he said. Asked just who the "bad guys" were, the Governor waved the question off.
 
Warning: It's an Estimate
 The surplus revealed today is so relatively tiny that there is no chance that the Governor and legislative leaders will return here to fight over how to divvy it up, just as they fought in past years over how to close the deficit. They will, however, return to fight: a special session is expected to be held in December to grapple with a separate, contentious budget issue of how to finance various transportation programs, including a capital plan for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
In fact, budget analysts warned today that the figure was only an estimate of where the state would wind up at the end of the fiscal year next March, and that the budget could fall out of balance.
And Mr. Cuomo, speaking to reporters at the Capitol, said that it would be "very tough" to put together next year's budget, due April 1.
"We're $21 million ahead and believe me, that's glorious considering where we've been in recent years," he said. "But next year is going to be very, very difficult."
In recent years, when the midyear deficits have ranged to as high as $1 billion, the Governor and the legislative leaders have had to eliminate thousands of state jobs, cut aid that had been previously pledged to local governments and school districts and pare social services like Medicaid.
At times they also fought, as they did last year, to a standoff over where to make additional cuts and wound up borrowing money to keep the budget legally balanced. That only worsened the problems in the next fiscal year.
This time around, the projected surplus appears to eliminate the prospect of such cuts or of any mid-year tax increases for New Yorkers. But an analyst at the Citizens Budget Commission, one of the best-known private groups that monitors the state's fiscal practices, warned that today's announcement did not guarantee that the surplus would be there at the end of the year.
"It's heartening to see that the receipts seem to be on target, but of course, the revenues could change, the economic picture could change," said the analyst, Cynthia Green. She also said that state leaders would have to avoid any temptation to increase spending before the fiscal year ends March 31. "What's critical is to stick to this plan not just for six months, but for the full 12 months," she said.
There was no expectation here that today's word would lead to any immediate upgrade of the state's credit rating, which could lower the costs of borrowing money and save the state taxpayers millions of dollars.
George W. Leung, the vice president and managing director for state debt ratings at Moody's Investors Service, said it was clearly "good news" that, for the first time in five years, there appeared to be no mid-year deficit.
But, he said, several additional steps toward "structural reform," including cuts that would recur in future years, would likely be necessary before a credit upgrading would be addressed. Even Mr. Cuomo said he did not expect any re-evaluation from the raters, at the earliest, until after the state's 1993-94 budget was put together next spring.
