HEADLINE: Abrams-D'Amato Race Becomes a Family Affair

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
The New York Senate campaign has just entered a new arena of ruthless, cutthroat competition.
It pits the Matriarch against the Modern American Wife, Mama vs. Ms. And it uses a gauzy new feel-good ad as an insidious weapon in an increasingly negative campaign. 
 Attorney General Robert Abrams may have started it by showcasing his family at every opportunity. But now Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has retaliated by going nuclear.
"I'm very much surprised at Abrams talking the way he has," Antoinette D'Amato, 77 years old, said sternly in Buffalo, referring to Mr. Abrams's one-time use of the word "fascist" to refer to Mr. D'Amato. She shook her head sorrowfully. "Does he talk that way at home?" she added. "He has really, really insulted us."
This is not Family Feud. It is war. From the start, Mr. Abrams has been behaving like a contender for a Father of the Year award, persistently taking his two daughters out to campaign at his side. Last Sunday, he took his 6-year-old daughter, Becky, campaigning, perching her up on a long table on the stage during a meeting of the Jewish Electrical Welfare Club in Flushing, Queens. Father fussed dotingly over her coat buttons and hat. Daughter chewed at a bagel.
 
And Now, the Loyal Daughter
 Meanwhile, Mr. Abrams's bright, articulate wife, Diane, a lawyer, frequently travels upstate to campaign on his behalf on women's issues, particularly abortion.
But now Mr. D'Amato, who is separated from his wife and has four grown children, has taken the battle of the family albums to new heights.
Mr. D'Amato's mother and his daughter Lisa Murphy, 30, began a two-day, seven-city media tour yesterday to defend his honor and lacerate his opponent. It is Lisa who is featured in the latest D'Amato campaign commercial, mistily saying how "proud" she is of "my dad." But her grandmother is the star of the D'Amato family road show, commenting acerbically on everything from pasta to Presidential politics.
"You mean to tell me with all that power and money, he's afraid of anybody?" Mrs. D'Amato said of Ross Perot's contention that fear of Republican "dirty tricks" drove him to quit the Presidential race. "Aw, c'mon."
This is not the first time Mr. D'Amato has come up with a good-ad/bad-ad media strategy. In 1980, Mr. D'Amato appalled many New York Republicans when he ran ads during the primary that focused, rather brutally, on Senator Jacob K. Javits's ill health. Later, in the general election, Mr. D'Amato softened his image with ads that featured his mother, holding grocery bags, complaining about inflation and bragging about "my son, Alfonse." (Like another well-known Italian-American, the film maker Martin Scorsese, Mr. D'Amato likes to give cameo roles to his funny, outspoken mother.)
She campaigned for him in 1980 and again in 1986, handing out her personal Italian cookbook, "Recipes for the Forgotten Middle-Class." "Lisa is continuing the family tradition that Mama started in 1980," said Zenia Mucha, the Senator's spokeswoman. "He credited Mama with getting him elected. Now Lisa is bringing across the message that her father, the Senator, has always been there for the people of the state of New York."
This year, in a Senate contest that is routinely referred to as the nastiest in the nation, the Senator seems to be relying once again on his family to help paint him in homey, rosy hues.
"Proud" is the first word uttered by his daughter in the latest D'Amato ad, a softly lit 30-second commercial that could pass for a holiday season Hallmark ad. "That's how I feel about Al D'Amato," she says straight into the camera, while seated at a piano topped with framed photographs of her children. "He was the first Italian-American elected to the Senate from New York." As lilting piano music plays softly in the background, she adds: "Al D'Amato is always there to help. But then, I'm partial. You see, Al D'Amato is my father."
The Abrams campaign, which has been struggling to keep up with Mr. D'Amato's carpet-bombing negative ad campaign, seemed taken aback by this latest surprise sally into the Mary Poppins positive. Timothy Gilles asked a reporter to read the text of Lisa Murphy's ad, then remained silent for several moments. "I'll have to call you back in five minutes," he said.
Five minutes later, Mr. Gilles made the following statement. "It sounds like a nice, warm, positive spot. And it marks the first time since Sept. 15 that Al D'Amato has done anything other than sling mud, lies and distortion at Bob Abrams."
He added that the impetus for the ad must have been that "he's run out of lies." But he would not say if the Abrams campaign would respond in kind to Mr. D'Amato's family ads. "It is our policy not to preview our media strategy," he said.
Off-screen and on the stump, both Lisa Murphy and her grandmother are ferocious in defending Mr. D'Amato's reputation. "Al was very upset," his mother said, referring to the Senate Ethics Committee investigation that criticized him for "improper and inappropriate" use of his office. "What they put him though is unconscionable. Where is the money? He's an honest person," she said insistently. "If he wasn't, he'd be a millionaire."
Ms. Murphy said she had agreed to film the commercial because "it's very important that people understand that Al D'Amato is a politician -- he's a career politician -- but he also has children, parents, people who care about him, especially when he is maligned in the media."
 
Following the Democrats
 The idea to add his daughter to his arsenal came during the primary, Ms. Murphy said. The entire D'Amato family watched the debates between the three Democratic candidates, and noticed how much attention Mr. Abrams's photogenic family received. "We watched carefully," Ms. Murphy said. "When it was over, immediately, his children ran up on stage. Of course the media focused on him and his children."
She added that in the second debate, she noticed that two of Mr. Abrams's rivals, Elizabeth Holtzman and Geraldine A. Ferraro, made a point of having family members rush to their side.
And when Mr. Abrams and Mr. D'Amato had their first television debate last month, Lisa Murphy skipped a cousin's wedding to be at her father's side, with her three children in tow. Mr. Abrams did not bring his family. "He must have presumed that my father, who is separated and doesn't have young children, wouldn't bring his family to the debate," she said. "That's probably why he didn't bring his family to the debate." She paused, and with her father's keen competitive zest, added, "I'm sure he regrets it."
Prodded by her grandmother, she added, "Oh, yeah, and we wanted to be there for moral support, as well."

HEADLINE: Space Station, Promised for '92, Is Still Mostly on Drawing Board

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

DATELINE: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.

 BODY:
THIS is the year the space station was to begin flying as an orbital outpost for American astronauts, opening a new era of exploration in time for the 500th anniversary of Columbus's arrival in the New World.
NASA laid out the plan in 1984, saying the venture would cost $8 billion and take eight years. 
 But as of today, with that sum expended, there is no station in orbit, little hardware ready for flight and few chances that the 350-foot-long outpost will be completed before the century's end, if then.
Moreover, the nation's space shuttles, which were to be lofting station parts and supplies by now, are beginning to fly half empty for want of payloads.
What does exist, scattered across the back roads of America, are down-to-earth leviathans like the $500 million structure being erected here at the Kennedy Space Center. It is the biggest construction job at the spaceport since the Apollo program to reach the Moon.
Surrounded by a dense growth of palm, pine and palmetto, the six-story structure is the size of two football fields and is envisioned as a high-technology workshop for 1,500 experts preparing station gear for space. It will be ready in 1994.
Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration say the Kennedy building and its cousins in places like Cleveland, Houston and Huntsville, Ala., are the concrete basis of big dreams. Buildings tend to be further along than flight hardware, they say, because budget turmoil and years of Congressional meddling have forced repeated redesigns of the outpost, often restricting progress to the mundane.
But the sites do at times suggest the triumph of bricks and mortar over higher pursuits. In one case, a building was erected in 1987 for testing a space-station component that was later eliminated as the design of the outpost evolved.
If nothing else, the earthbound side of the station saga helps explain where the $8 billion has gone and why the station's estimated price has climbed to between $30 billion and $40 billion. It also hints at the political momentum that can carry a big science project forward long after the motivating spark has gone away.
The orbiting outpost was proposed in 1984 by President Ronald Reagan, who was dazzled by its commercial promise and the vision of astronauts permanently based hundreds of miles above Earth. "We can follow our dreams to distant stars," he said in unveiling the plan, "living and working in space for peaceful, economic and scientific gain."
After the speech, Congress embraced the idea and NASA's eight-year, $8 billion plan. "The benefits to the human race are only beginning to be imagined," said Senator Slade Gorton, chairman of the Senate space subcommittee. And he praised the goal of deploying the station in 1992, calling it "an appropriate celebration for the 500th anniversary of the arrival in America by Columbus."
Over the next few years two things conspired to slow the plan, and at times nearly to kill it. One was the mushrooming of the modest station idea to embrace the needs of new users, contractors and political allies. Added to Mr. Reagan's commercial aims were plans for an observatory, an Earth-observation post, a fuel depot, a satellite service station and a base for planetary exploration.
The station was to be all things to all people. But the price mushroomed as well, prompting a vicious cycle of fund shortages, delays, cost increases and design revisions meant to trim the bloated station back to a reasonable size.
 
A Change in Plans
 Throughout this turmoil, the earthly infrastructure of the station grew steadily. The buildings tended to be large, following the most optimistic projections of their usefulness. At NASA's Lewis center in Cleveland, work began in 1987 on a six-story building to test 60-foot solar collectors whose high temperatures would power turbines to make electricity. The building opened in 1989. But by 1990, the collectors had been scrapped as too advanced and demanding. Instead, the designers decided to use passive solar cells on the orbiting outpost.
John Kobak, Lewis's director of station work, said the building had now been adapted for use as a manufacturing center. He also said Lewis had built a mission-control center for 36 technicians who would monitor the electrical systems of the station.
"We're the only center that didn't have a facility like that," he said, noting that NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville and the Johnson Space Center in Houston both had ground-control centers to govern various aspects of the station's flight.
At Johnson, work is nearly finished on three new station buildings, including a main mission control center that is to house four mainframe computers, 90 computerized work stations and 300 personnel. The other buildings are a training site for astronauts where on-board station jobs will be simulated and a center in which techniques will be practiced for astronauts to assemble the station structure in space.
Officials at Johnson also want, but have yet to receive approval for, a large new indoor swimming pool in which astronauts would practice station assembly techniques in the next-best-thing to weightlessness. The pool would be 202 feet long, 102 feet wide and 40 feet deep.
The biggest of all station buildings is at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, not far from the pounding surf and the dense jungle typical of the area. This is where all the station hardware is to come together before being carried into space on 18 shuttle flights. This is where gear is to be rigorously tested to make sure it works and fitted together in an effort to make sure that the myriad parts of the 350-foot-long structure were designed correctly.
"Our goal is to find any goofs before we get on orbit," said Dick Lyon, head of Kennedy's space station work.
Also on the agenda are plans for feeding the 1,500 workers at the Kennedy site in a large cafeteria being built next door, and giving the public a glimpse of station processing through a viewing gallery. Up to 300 tourists at a time will be able to watch through bulletproof glass.
 
Construction at Site
 Today the site is a blur of cranes, trucks, dust, hardhats, building materials and the emerging giant, which looms over the nearby jungle like a creature from outer space. It is about 60 percent complete.
Its interior is a maze of steel girders that outline what will be laboratories and supply rooms. At the rear, things open up into a cavernous six-story hangar where station parts are to be checked out. The area, 105 feet wide and 440 feet long, is big enough to simultaneously process hardware for eight station-building flights. Each site for payload processing is about 45 feet by 90 feet, surrounding a cargo space that corresponds to the shuttle's 15-by-60 foot payload bay.
It is easy to get a false impression of the cost of the Kennedy structure. A NASA publication, "Space Station Freedom Media Handbook," a 102-page guide to the orbiting outpost, dated May 1992, says the bill will be "approximately $72 million."
 
1996 Launching Target
 But Mr. Lyon, a genial, balding man with an easy smile who has worked at the Florida spaceport since the Apollo program, says that figure is only for bricks and mortar. Equipping the site with cranes, computers, test stands, forklifts, nitrogen and helium outlets and the piles of complex gear needed to check out station hardware will cost $375 million more. The total, he said, will be roughly $500 million.
Mr. Lyon said that by early 1996 the structures and their equipment would be ready to support the first planned launchings that year of shuttles carrying station parts into space.
If Gov. Bill Clinton becomes President and decides to work more closely on the station effort with the Russians, as he has vowed to do, the sprawling site here, like its sister in Cleveland, might become instantly obsolete. Many experts have proposed, and NASA is now studying, having the Russians loft the station on big rockets from central Asia.
But Mr. Lyon said it would make more sense to bring Russian rockets here and fire them from adapted seaside launching pads, and to process their payloads here as well.
 
Vow to Cancel Station
 If Ross Perot becomes President and cancels the station, as he has vowed to do, since he considers it an unaffordable extravagance, the building would still undoubtedly find uses. Mr. Lyon said it was built with flexibility in mind, its high bay having mobile work stations that could be adapted to projects other than the envisioned orbiting outpost for the nation's astronaut corps.
"Even if the station went away, we wanted to be able to process payloads," Mr. Lyon said. "We didn't want a white elephant."

HEADLINE: With Cold War Over, Scientists Are Turning To 'Greener' Pastures

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
DR. WILLIAM DANNEVIK, Dr. John Ambrosiano and Dr. Mike Wehner are physicists who used to work on nuclear weapons at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California. They have now switched their skills to the task of making better forecasts about global warming.
Dr. Henry W. Kendall, a 1990 winner of the Nobel Prize in Physics and a longtime anti-nuclear activist, has taken a leave from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to learn more about human impact on the global environment. His goal is to galvanize the scientific community in the cause of environmental protection. 
 With the cold war over, many scientists are converting both their professional skills and their activist convictions from national security and nuclear weapons to other issues, particularly the environment. This intellectual shift is driven variously by principle, by a growing interest in the environment among younger scientists, by the hunger for new challeges and -- not least -- by the search for new sources of financial support.
The change comes at a time when the Pentagon is opening up intelligence files to scientists in search of environmental data and when the environment bids to achieve equal billing with national security and economics on the international agenda, as demonstrated by forums like the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro last June.
 
From 'Star Wars' to Global Warming
 Since just after World War II, national security has been a driving force behind American science, the main wellspring of money, the main attracter of talent in many important fields and the main lightning rod for scientists concerned about public issues.
But now, said Dr. Sidney Drell of Stanford University, "I see more young scientists who are informing themselves and working with environmental issues, and being more attracted to that and less attracted to the traditional bombs and arms-control issues."
"Being an old warhorse, I still stay with arms issues," said Dr. Drell, one of a group of arms experts who actively opposed the Reagan Administration's "Star Wars" missile-defense plan. "I would be very unhappy if I found everyone was abandoning ship," given the dangers of nuclear proliferation. "But among my colleagues, particularly the younger ones, the interest is certainly shifting."
In one sign of the times, Dr. Drell added his signature to those of more than 750 scientists who subscribed to a 1990 appeal, organized by the Union of Concerned Scientists, to prevent global warming. "I rarely sign general statements," he said, "but you can see I thought it was important."
Dr. Kendall believes that human activities "are undermining the life-support capacity of the most important global support systems we have." In line with this thinking, the Union of Concerned Scientists has sharply shifted its emphasis. Three years ago more than three-quarters of its budget went to arms control or national security issues; now about three-quarters is focused on climate change and related issues, said Howard Ris, the executive director.
 
Skepticism and Diversity
 As with nuclear arms, scientists are divided on environmental issues. Some, for example, believe that fears about global warming are overblown.
One prominent doubter is Dr. Robert Jastrow, director of the Mount Wilson Observatory in California and an outspoken promoter of the Star Wars concept in the mid-80's. His skepticism on global warming is often expressed through the George C. Marshall Institute in Washington, of which he is president, and it carried weight with the Bush Administration when John H. Sununu, formerly the President's chief of staff, controlled White House debate on the issue.
Concerns other than the environment -- health and economic competitiveness, for instance -- are also vying for the attention of scientists shifting from the cold war agenda.
Lawrence Livermore and Los Alamos, two premier national laboratories that are citadels of nuclear weaponry, have put more emphasis on a wide range of other activities as the nuclear enterprise shrinks. Both are pursuing diverse lines of research, from computer and software development to materials, lasers and sensors, from chaos theory to biomedical projects. Together with Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, they have become major centers of research on mapping the human genetic structure. But the environment and related energy questions stand out, if only because of their prominence as public policy issues.
At Livermore, Dr. Dannevik, Dr. Ambrosiano and Dr. Wehner still write computer codes for mathematical models. Once the models simulated nuclear explosions; now they simulate the workings of the earth's climate.
As a Department of Energy installation, Livermore has been trying for some time, as Dr. Dannevik put it, "to develop a next generation of the climate simulation model" in the hope of making better policy decisions on national energy strategy. "The new ingredient," he said, "is the involvement of former weapons and code developers in the area."
The three physicists, whose ages range from 35 to 44, see their new pursuit as a natural magnet. "It's what people generally call a grand challenge," said Dr. Ambrosiano.
For Dr. Wehner, the switch has been "like going back to school -- I've had to learn very basic science that normally you'd take as an undergraduate." But he said the transition had been eased by a remarkable similarity between nuclear physics and atmospheric physics: both are complex systems that involve radiation transfer, the flow of gases and fluid dynamics, and both are approached through similar mathematical formulations.
Given the existence of nuclear weapons elsewhere in the world, those who build bombs often see them as a force for stability and peace. "I share that view," said Dr. Ambrosiano, adding that he saw both his past and present pursuits as constructive.
And Dr. Wehner said, "I certainly don't regard myself as a peace dividend or as some bomber-turned-green." Climate modeling is appealing, he went on, simply because "it's extremely interesting and it's a very current and relevant interest."
Similarly, some computer modelers at Los Alamos who used to work on weapons are now working full time on improving models of the workings of the ocean as part of the global climate system. Like Livermore, Los Alamos has diversified its efforts into a variety of fields, like clean energy use.
At the national laboratories, said Dr. Lou Rosocho, deputy leader of Los Alamos's advanced laser and systems technology group, "there was a whole culture based on the cold war."
"A lot of people sold their services to the weapons program to do interesting science," he went on. With the winding down of the cold war, the culture was left "wondering just what the hell it was going to do." Out of this identity crisis is emerging a new set of missions in the national interest, he said.
When Dr. Rosocho joined Los Alamos in 1981 with a private-industry background in developing technologies for clean air and water, he thought he could promote those technologies. "But I discovered very abruptly that no one was interested," he said. "If you had an idea about Star Wars, you got an enthusiastic reception."
So he went to work trying to help use laser beams to initiate a fusion reaction. A decade later, he works on ways of cleaning up air and water and says that "we've been making significant inroads" on that enterprise.
"I've come full circle," he said, "and the realization of the need for many of these environmental technologies is here."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
The Game Looks to Foreign Fields

BYLINE: By Claire Smith

 BODY:
A major league all-star team with representatives from the World Series champion Toronto Blue Jays and the National League champion Atlanta Braves leaves for Japan today. That is yet another sign that baseball, willingly or not, has embarked on an off season in which it will meet its future on many levels.
For the Japanese baseball powers did not even wait for the Toronto Blue Jays to win the first World Series played somewhere other than on American soil before expressing a desire to make this truly a world championship. 
 That shouldn't be considered so alien a notion. "It's something our international partnership has talked about," the deputy baseball commissioner, Steve Greenberg, said. "I'd like to think that in the next decade we'd have some sort of international play. I'm not talking about mid-summer at the Olympics, or an international World Series, but some sort of international play. I know that the Japanese professional baseball leagues would be keenly interested."
So even while baseball looks at the effect of sagging ratings and growing disenchantment among fans at home, it is gearing up for a mission many of its officials insist predated the initiatives abroad by the National Basketball Association and the National Football League.
The effort is being marshaled by the Major League Baseball International Partnership, a conglomerate of corporate and baseball interests marketing the sport abroad.
That organization, born during the commissionership of Fay Vincent, oversaw the broadcasting of the just-completed World Series to more than 70 nations around the world, in eight different languages. It is, baseball spokesmen vow, only the beginning. The next Series will be translated for the first time ever into Mandarin, another symbolic indication that even China's great walls can be crossed by baseballs carried on satellite beams.
It is just another indication that baseball, America's grand old game, is caught in the jet stream of change. And the World Series played partly on soil outside the United States was not the first indication, any more than it will be the last.
Earlier this summer, major league owners were dragged kicking and sometimes screaming into the realities of the day when they reversed field and allowed interests other than those born in North America to purchase part of a major league franchise. And Greenberg has talked of the possibility of sending a kind of kiddie Dream Team to the Olympics, perhaps as soon as 1996 in Atlanta, as baseball contemplates seeking permission for its top minor league prospects to participate.
The move onto the international stage would be fitting considering the sport has for years benefited from a sort of baseball brain drain, culling talents from Canada, Mexico, the Caribbean and South and Central America. The Blue Jays, a Canadian team, had a roster dotted with players from the Dominican Republic and Jamaica as well as Americans from Oklahoma, Minnesota, Puerto Rico and the like.
In fact, the only common citizenship major league players have any longer is that they belong to the Major League Baseball Players Association, a nation, rich and successful, unto itself. And it is that nation-empire that baseball will concentrate on first, before visions of international series, or Olympic participation occupy the minds of baseball's powers. Or so baseball's lords will insist now that the first season, played on the field, has given away to a second and more intricate one that will be played in board rooms.
Putting championships back together will be easy compared to the work ahead.
Major league owners, faced with putting their house in order in wake of a summer of discontent and rebellion, know they must either make peace with their player-millionaires or break the union they so often target but fail to hit.
Management officials must also redefine the very nature of the game's government in the wake of Vincent's forced resignation almost two months ago. The new world vision of a commissionership, of central baseball, of the owners' role in issues, has yet to be revealed. Hints at realignments, new tiers of playoffs, a move toward cable television and away from over-the-air broadcasts are also ideas that have been voiced, but not implemented.
Also, until vision is restored to the game, all talk of signals being beamed to China, Taiwan or Brazil begs the issue of importance if the game is still at a loss to explain if anyone is willing to pay the tab for those radio and television signals from the United States.
Owners, adept at giving dismal forecasts, insist there won't be networks lining up to do so. ESPN has already pulled out of its commitment, deciding not to exercise a $250 million cable contract option covering 1994-95. The golden goose, which laid a $1.499 billion four-year television-rights egg on baseball in 1990, will be gone by 1993, chased off by the recession and poor ratings. Or so the owners insist.
So players brace, wondering how the dire premonitions will affect their future, as free agents plan to hit a market they are hearing no longer exists. Owners of small-market teams wonder how devastating a winter it will be if big-market clubs boost the market once more with $6 million and $7 million player contracts.
It is a fluid time. Just how much so, to what end and within what boundaries no one will know for quite some time.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
New Ways to Help Injured Workers

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
HEALTH insurers and health maintenance organizations are jumping into the rapidly growing worker's compensation market, angling for a share of the $70 billion a year that employers spend to cover job-related injuries and illnesses. The insurers offer networks of physicians who typically accept preset fees and abide by rules that encourage workers to return to work as soon as possible.
The growing interest in managing worker's compensation follows a surge in medical expenditures, which now are 50 percent of worker's compensation costs, up from 20 percent in the 1970's. The other big cost is injury-related loss of earnings or impaired ability to work. According to some experts, worker's compensation costs will soar to $120 billion by 1995. 
 Worker's compensation insurers say their costs have also been swelled by claims for off-the-job injuries as employers have cut back on general health benefits. And they suggest that workers in some recession-buffeted industries may even become accident prone on the eve of losing their jobs, in a desperate reach for a substitute for wages.
A survey of 716 employers by the Towers Perrin consulting and actuarial firm found that 63 percent would prefer to combine worker's compensation with conventional health benefits in 24-hour coverage, on and off the job.
Even so, Jerry Miccolis, a Towers Perrin vice president, said most employers have been slow to act. They see worker's compensation as a legal obligation, which must be kept in check by safety programs. Health care, by contrast, is seen as a benefit voluntarily provided to employees. Also, injured workers cannot be forced to choose a doctor from a network of physicians in most states. Only about 20 states allow employers to control the choice of physicians to treat work-related cases.
But cost pressures are sweeping away the barriers. Roanoke County, Va., for example, buys 24-hour coverage for 2,000 school and county employees from Consolidated Risk Management Services, a for-profit unit of Virginia Blue Cross and Blue Shield. "We eliminate duplication of payments," said Bob Jernigan, Roanoke's risk manager. He added that doctors used to charge 25 percent more for an office visit in worker's compensation cases. Eliminating such extra charges saved the county $12,000 last year, he said.
"If you have a serious injury," he added, "Blue Cross provides a medical management team." They check on patients before authorizing admission to hospitals and make sure their treatment is appropriate, he said. "With worker's compensation, you normally don't get that."
California recently authorized a three-year experiment to encourage health maintenance organizations to provide doctors for job-related injuries. The measure was sponsored by Kaiser Permanente, the country's largest H.M.O. Kaiser already offers worker's compensation coverage in Oregon.
Eleven Blue Cross and Blue Shield associations across the country also have networks of worker's compensation physicians; 30 more Blue Cross plans are seriously considering the field.
The Liberty Mutual Insurance Company, the largest worker's compensation insurer, and Kaiser are also jointly marketing some general health-care products, with an eye to possibly combining forces in worker's compensation as well.
On its own, Liberty Mutual offers worker's compensation physician networks in 35 states. And the FHP International Corporation, an investor-owned H.M.O. based in Fountain Valley, Calif., is providing worker's compensation for 60 employers.
Many insurers also provide consultants to help employers avert expensive accidents in the first place. Robert Randell, a consultant with the Travelers Corporation's cost reduction unit, tries to get employers involved in dealing with workplace injuries. "They can personally deliver the injured person to the doctor," he said. "They can maintain active contact with injured employees to get them back to work."
Working with Mr. Randell, Larry Teafatiller, general manager of a Target Stores distribution center in Southern California, is ordering new machines to assist loading operations, to cut down on manual lifting that is blamed for back injuries.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, which has been on guard against injuries since the company's founders began making gunpowder in the early 19th century, insists that "all injuries can be prevented," said Dr. Bruce W. Karrh, the chemical company's vice president of integrated health care. Du Pont said its rate of injuries per hours worked is only 2 percent of the rate for all American industries. As a result, Dr. Karrh said that Du Pont averages less than $4 million a year in worker's compensation expenses. Some large employers spend hundreds of millions.

HEADLINE: Administration Denies Delaying Bank Action

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The Bush Administration and banking regulators today denied charges that they had postponed closing ailing banks so as to push bad economic news until after Election Day.
At an unusual Congressional hearing just eight days before the polls open, the officials also defended their predictions that about 100 banks will be closed next year and criticized a recent study suggesting that up to 1,000 institutions would need to be closed in the coming years. 
 Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, convened the hearing after some Democrats and the independent Presidential candidate Ross Perot warned of a "December surprise."
 
 
New Law
 They have said there may be widespread bank closings when a new Federal banking law, takes effect Dec. 19. It will require regulators to intervene at ailing banks with very low ratios of equity of assets -- either by closing them or taking other corrective action.
But waiting until then not only hides the bad news from the voters, the critics maintain, but it may also worsen the problem as the ailing banks continue to pile up losses and increase the ultimate costs to the taxpayer.
Mr. Riegle portrayed today's event as a factual review of the banking industry's health. "Some say that the industry is healing itself -- others say that it's on the brink of a major crisis," Mr. Riegle said.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady suggested the hearing was politically motivated, and criticized the Senator for holding the hearing after Congress had adjourned. "He has had countless opportunities to provide genuine reform instead of holding a vacuous hearing the week prior to a Presidential election," Mr. Brady said in a statement distributed by a Treasury official to reporters and lobbyists at the hearing.
No Republican senators showed up for the hearing, nor did any of Mr. Riegle's Democratic colleagues.
In October of last year, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation predicted that bank closings this year would cover institutions with $80 billion in assets. But so far this year, institutions with only $29 billion in assets have been closed.
Andrew C. Hove Jr., the acting chairman of the F.D.I.C., said his agency was being unfairly penalized for its candor in issuing an estimate a year ago. "Our grim projections of last year have not been realized, but the casualty list is still extremely high," Mr. Hove added.
Mr. Hove said that low interest rates had helped many banks, and that further failures by the end of December would increase the total value of assets in closed institutions to $40 billion this year.
Federal regulators have been very sensitive about suggestions that they have delayed or underestimated the cost of helping insolvent banks because the opening stages of the savings and loan crisis were marked by delays and underestimates.
Mr. Hove said that the Dec. 19 law would accelerate the closing of some institutions but would not cause a significant increase in the overall number of closings.
John P. LaWare, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, and Stephen R. Steinbrink, who is the acting Comptroller of the Currency and is a Treasury official, also defended the Government's handling of ailing banks.
But Mr. LaWare did warn that banks were issuing many home equity loans that might not be repaid because of high unemployment. That may also weaken real estate markets, creating inadequate collateral for mortgages and the home equity loans, he said.
Mr. Reigle has been trying to stake out a strong position on financial regulation since his reputation was damaged by a Senate Ethics Committee rebuke for intervening with regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr., whose savings and loan subsequently collapsed at enormous cost to taxpayers.

HEADLINE: SHAKE-UP AT G.M.: The Economy's Seat on the Board;
Any G.M. Strategy Will Be Dictated by the Weak U.S. Market

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
No matter who takes over at General Motors as Robert C. Stempel's replacement, or how good he is, the new chairman will be locked into a corporate strategy even before he takes command -- a strategy dictated by the nation's weak economy.
Simply stated, G.M. waited too long for ballooning sales to save the day. Americans are buying cars and trucks at an annual rate of barely 13 million a year, far from the 15 million in the late 1980's had created enough demand to mask G.M.'s numerous inefficiencies. And sales are likely to remain weak for months to come. 
 The alternative turnaround strategy would have been to rapidly develop new models popular enough to win away customers in the important middle market -- now dominated by the Ford Taurus and the Honda Accord.
But developing new models takes time, and this at the moment is out of stock. "There is no longer enough time for General Motors to turn its situation around without layoffs and downsizing," said Robert L. Crandall, a senior fellow and auto industry expert at the Brookings Institution.
 
 
A Leaner Company
 All that's really left as an immediate strategy, then, is to cut costs, to create a leaner, smaller company.
New-model cars or a smaller company -- or a combination of the two -- are, of course, strategic alternatives open to any new management team. "The two are inextricably intertwined and should be carried out together," David Healy, an auto analyst at S. G. Warburg & Company, said.
But since Mr. Stempel failed to make headway on either count after he became chairman in 1990, downsizing has now become inevitable.
"The priority is to stop the financial bleeding," said Harley Shaiken, a labor economist and auto industry expert at the University of California at San Diego. "The second task is to rebuild the corporation. The problem is that measures that stop the financial bleeding, like confrontations with the United Auto Workers over layoffs, could also destroy the corporation."
G.M. will probably have to lay off 85,000 blue and white collar workers, or 23 percent of its 370,000 employees in North America, and shut four more of its 40 assembly plants, along with 15 or more parts operations, Mr. Healy estimated. Mr. Stempel's failure to move quickly toward these goals was decisive in bringing about his resignation.
The odds are that John G. Smale, a former chairman of Procter & Gamble and the G.M. director who led the revolt against Mr. Stempel, is likely to be the first to undertake this task, replacing Mr. Stempel as chairman for two years or so, analysts say. But given his background at Procter & Gamble, a consumer products company, he would probably be better at the less pressing goal at G.M. -- stirring consumer interest in new auto models.
John F. Smith Jr., who became G.M. president after turning around the company's troubled European operations, seems likely to become the chief executive under Mr. Smale -- bringing to the task the necessary experience at cutting costs and introducing other efficiencies. William E. Hoglund, G.M.'s chief financial officer, is another candidate for a top slot, particularly if Mr. Smale's tenure is brief.
Rarely has an outsider moved into the top slot at an American auto manufacturing company, following the example of Stanley Gault, who retired as chairman of Rubbermaid Inc. and then became chairman of Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, where he engineered a turnaround.
"There is a line of thought that says it is very hard for an insider at G.M. to affect change because he has too many loyalties and is himself a captive of the company's traditions and bureaucracy," Malcolm Salter, a Harvard Business School professor and auto industry specialist, said. "But G.M. has tried to bring in outsiders as top executives in recent years, and they have failed. And to some extent, Jack Smith plays the role of an outsider, arriving from Europe, bent on efficiency and standing apart from the people in Detroit."
 
 
Ross Perot's Charges
 Among the outsiders, Ross Perot became G.M.'s largest shareholder after selling his company, Electronic Data Systems, to G.M. But his attacks on G.M.'s inefficiencies in the mid 1980's failed to win support for change among G.M.'s board members and Mr. Perot finally sold back his shares to G.M. and resigned as a director. "G.M. has failed to tap the resources of its people," Mr. Perot charged at the time.
Whoever the next leader, the obstacles at G.M. are enormous. Cutting costs appears to be a short-term necessity, unless a revival of the national economy provides some relief, but cost-cutting alone won't return even a smaller G.M. to prosperity. What's more, playing off one plant against another, keeping open the plants whose workers grant the most concessions, is likely to result in morale-sapping frictions with the United Auto Workers.
"The root cause of the problem is lack of product," said Donald F. Ephlin, now retired after years as vice president of the United Auto Workers in charge of negotiations with G.M. "They have done a good job with Cadillac, but their mid-sized products are their bread and butter. And the Pontiac Grand Prix, the Chevrolet Lumina and the Oldsmobile Cutlass are failing. General Motors is paying a penalty for failing to compete hard with other companies more used to scratching for a living."
Without the efficiencies that come from greater sales volume -- in effect, more cars produced for each worker -- the company's average costs, according to one recent study, are $795 a car greater than those of Ford and Chrysler, which went through modernization programs a decade ago, reducing their labor forces and reorganizing production so that factory floor workers took on more responsibility for quality and efficiency.
Now G.M. must carry out that task at a moment when the world marketplace is flooded with auto production capacity. "There are more new entrants than exits in the auto business," Mr. Salter said. "The Koreans, the Indonesians and others enter, and no one seems to go out of business."
In the United States alone, new Japanese-owned auto factories have added nearly two million vehicles to the nation's capacity to manufacture cars over the last decade.
Perhaps the greatest burden is G.M.'s size. Even after downsizing, it is likely to remain the world's largest auto and truck maker, along with Toyota in Japan.
"G.M. for decades led the industry, not only because it was big, but because it defined the trends," Mr. Shaiken said. "If you are defining trends and setting the pace for new models, your size and production volume give you the advantage in the marketplace. But in the 1980's, first the Japanese and then Ford with the Taurus, took over the leadership in trends, and G.M.'s size became an albatross. When someone else sets the trend, you have to switch to get back into step, and size made switching difficult for G.M."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Boeing Profit Down 9% as Orders Slide

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
The Boeing Company reported yesterday that its earnings had fallen 9 percent in the third quarter, primarily because of a decrease in commercial jet deliveries.
Net income for the Seattle-based aerospace company totaled $364 million, or $1.07 a share, down from $401 million, or $1.17 a share, a year earlier. Sales fell 10 percent, to $6.90 billion, from $7.66 billion in the third quarter of 1991. Boeing projected that its total sales for 1992 would be in the $30 billion range. 
 Boeing's earnings were at the low end of analysts' estimates, and the company's shares fell $1 yesterday, to close at $35.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Frank Shrontz, Boeing's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement that the weak global economy was continuing to depress parts of the airline industry. As a result, some airlines have asked to delay aircraft orders and options. But some of the deferred deliveries have been offset by new orders and requests by other customers to accelerate deliveries, Mr. Shrontz said.
"The trend remains a downward tilt," said Howard A. Rubel, an analyst with C. J. Lawrence, a securities concern. He said business cycles in the aircraft industry were too long "to expect big changes overnight." Mr. Rubel noted that while Boeing's operating profit margins were off a little because of the lower volume of production, it had been able to offset that by continuing to reduce costs.
Announced commercial orders during the third quarter totaled 47 aircraft, valued at $2.1 billion, including a Southwest Airlines order for 34 737's. The figures represent a decrease from 62 aircraft, valued at $4.9 billion, in last year's third quarter.

HEADLINE: Dow Surges 36.47 Points On Earnings Reports

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stocks posted solid gains yesterday as upbeat corporate earnings captured the market's attention despite investors' caution ahead of the Nov. 3 Presidential election.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 36.47 points to end at 3,244.11. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was moderate at 188.1 million shares, compared with 199.1 million on Friday. Advancing issues led those declining by 1,087 to 709. 
 The market was also bolstered by gains in some leadership stocks like Philip Morris, Merck and Procter & Gamble.
"Maybe there's a bit of relief that this earnings period wasn't a horror show," a trader said.
The Dow transportation index, continuing a spate of recent gains, shot up 23.17 points, to 1,356.34. The index is considered a barometer of the economy, and analysts said its performance has been a prop for the overall market.
"The transports have been acting very well," said Ron Doran, director of institutional trading at C. L. King.
Still, uncertainty about the election continued to dog the market.
"There seems to be a little bit of feeling this may turn out to be a horse race," Mr. Doran said. Over the last few weeks, investors have seemed to be betting on a victory by Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democrat of Arkansas who still holds a lead in opinion polls over President Bush and Ross Perot. But some of the latest polls show Mr. Clinton's lead narrowing.
The Nasdaq index trailed the Dow, gaining 1.62 points, to 598.92. Secondary issues had been outperforming the blue-chip stocks in the last week as investors searched for higher- growth companies.
"Today is more of a Dow market," said Marshall Acuff, a portfolio strategist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. "You've got buyers under the market, and when they see it doesn't fade, they are in there."
John Blair at County NatWest said some buying by program traders contributed to the gains.
"I think anybody that wanted to make a big bet on the election probably has made it, and people are a little bit anxious about what Perot means," he said, referring to Ross Perot's recent gains in the polls.
Procter & Gamble was among the bigger blue-chips reporting unexpectedly strong operating earnings, although the consumer-products giant's net income was down because of a $200 million charge. P.&G.'s shares gained 2 1/2, to 53 1/2.
General Motors added 5/8, to 34 1/8, and the issue was the most active on the Big Board. Philip Morris rose 1 1/8, to 75 5/8, and Merck gained 1 7/8, to 43.
British Steel slipped 1 5/8, to 8 3/4. The stock was the biggest percentage loser on the Big Board, with a 15.6 percent drop. The company said it would cut production in line with a further fall in demand.
Shares of U.S. Healthcare slumped 6 3/8, to 43 3/8. While its third-quarter profits were within expectations, analysts said results showed higher expenses and lower margins.
Other health-care companies that lost ground included Foundation Health, down 2 5/8, to 39 1/4; United Health, off 2 3/4, to 50 7/8, and Pacificare, off 2, to 42 1/4.
Among the stocks in the Dow transportation average, Federal Express was up 2 1/8, to 45; AMR gained 1 5/8, to 64 3/8, Consolidated Rail was up 1 3/8, 43 1/8, and Norfolk Southern was up 1 3/4, to 62.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 4.07, to 418.17. The American Stock Exchange market-value index gained 1.92, to 376.16.
The New York Stock Exchange's composite index of all listed common stocks rose 1.95, to 229.78. The average share gained 28 cents.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Florida Paper Tests Service: Information by '511' Number

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
In a potentially significant action, utility regulators in Florida are letting a newspaper use an easy-to-remember "511" telephone number so its readers can call for faxes and other information about news and sports reports and advertisements.
The Florida Public Service Commission voted last week to let The Palm Beach Post, part of the Cox Newspaper chain in Atlanta, offer the service temporarily in West Palm Beach. The commission typically allows such experiments for two years but can withdraw permission at any time, especially if the Federal Communications Commission makes a conflicting ruling. 
 If the decision is made final and spreads to other states, "511" service would give the newspaper industry a valuable marketing tool. For example, readers could dial a newspaper's "511" number and get the fax of the transcript of a Presidential debate, late-breaking scores or the nearest location of a department store.
 
Easier to Remember
 Three-digit numbers, like 411 for directory assistance, are more valuable to companies than similar "976" and "900" seven-digit numbers because they are easier to remember. Moreover, callers are billed through the monthly local telephone bill, rather than separate bills.
In addition, "511" numbers are free from the taint in the public mind of association with the steep charges and unsavory reputation of the sexually explicit "970" and "976" adult phone lines. The fee for "511" numbers would also typically be a flat fee of 50 cents or less a call, instead of $1 or more a minute.
"This decision," said James T. McKnight, vice president-telecommunications for Cox Newspapers, "gives newspapers a chance to compete with the telephone business on a more equal footing."
Newspapers have been locked in an increasingly bitter battle with the telephone industry over electronic information services. They fear that phone companies may offer audio and video services, including help-wanted notices and real estate placements, that may prove to be more attractive than classified ads.
Classifieds are especially important to newspapers because the recession has hurt display advertising, which usually is taken out by department stores and other troubled retailing industries.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Profit Down but Sales Up at P.& G.

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Procter & Gamble Company, the maker of Ivory Soap and Tide detergent, said yesterday that its net income had fallen 19.6 percent in its fiscal first quarter, which ended Sept. 30, as a result of an extraordinary charge, but that revenue had risen 9.3 percent.
The consumer products giant said it had earned $431 million, or 60 cents a share, down from $536 million, or 76 cents a share, a year earlier. 
 But P.& G. said the drop in earnings stemmed from a decision last month to set aside a reserve of $200 million to cover the cost of winding down its Citrus Hill orange juice business. Excluding the charge, it said, third-quarter earnings would have jumped 18 percent, to $631 million.
 
Revenue Sets a Record
 The Cincinnati-based company said its revenue had risen to a record $7.88 billion, from $7.21 billion a year earlier. The chairman, Edwin L. Artzt, characterized the earnings as "a good start to the new fiscal year."
The company cited rising international sales, lower costs and higher profit margins in the United States and favorable exchange rates for the strong earnings report.
Wall Street analysts and stock market investors were more interested in the company's operating performance than in the one-time charge, and applauded Procter & Gamble's results.
The company's shares gained $2.50 yesterday, to close at $53.50, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
"Sales were a little lower than expected, but the surprise was in P.& G.'s operating margins, which were up in the United States even though unit sales were down," said Alice Beebe Longley, a vice president in equity research at Donaldson Lufkin Jenrette. "This is evidence of ongoing improvement in profitability due to cost cutting."
Andrew Shore, a first vice president at Paine Webber Inc., said the report was "good news and bad news."
"The good news is that the company's pricing policy is looking like it is driving down costs," Mr. Shore said. "The bad news is that unit sales in the United States were weaker than expected. But the company is clearly setting the stage for substantial earnings leverage when volume begins to improve."
To lessen its dependence on turns in the American economy, Procter & Gamble has expanded aggressively overseas during the last several years, buying up competitors and pushing its own product lines. The effort is paying off.
In the quarter, international sales rose by 9 percent, excluding acquisitions, while domestic sales dipped by 6 percent.
During its 1993 fiscal year, international sales are likely to exceed domestic revenue, said Deepak Raj, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company.
"Last year domestic sales represented about 52 percent of the total," Mr. Raj said. "We estimate that in the current fiscal year international sales will be $17 billion versus $15 billion in the United States."
In large part, expanding sales in Europe, the Far East and Latin America represent a doubling of foreign investment over the last three years, Mr. Raj said, to the point where international assets now total more than $10 billion.
"Despite that investment spending, they have been able to hold international profit margins and grow unit volume sales very aggressively," he said. "P.& G. sells high-quality products, and the world is trading up."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Some Gains, Especially Against Pound

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar edged higher yesterday against most major currencies, led by a gain of nearly 4 cents against the British pound.
Dollar dealers said that the currency remained within a fairly narrow range in domestic trading and that activity was relatively subdued. 
 Its biggest move was against the British pound, which fell to $1.5852 in New York from $1.6225 late Friday. In London, sterling dropped to $1.5855 from $1.6165 late Friday.
Dealers in London cited fears that there could be another national election if Prime Minister John Major failed to persuade Parliament to ratify a European union treaty. Mr. Major's office has refused to confirm or deny British news reports that he will quit and call an election if he loses a vote on Nov. 4 at the start of a new debate on the treaty.
Walter Simon, vice president of foreign exchange at the New York office of Bank Julius Baer, said dollar traders expected interest rates to fall in Britain, a development that would discourage foreign investment in the pound.
He said there had been speculation that the steel industry might lay off workers in Britain, just as the Government-owned coal company there is doing.
"If all these people are coming out of work, that is not a place where people are interested in being," Mr. Simon said.
Overall, Mr. Simon said, traders in the United States generally tested the upper and lower ranges that the dollar set in overseas dealings.
"It was a technical trading day," he said.
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose to 121.62 Japanese yen from 121.20 yen at Friday's close. In London, the dollar was quoted at 121.97 yen. The dollar finished at 121.85 yen in New York, up from 121.60 yen late Friday.
Dollar rates as of 4 P.M. in New York compared with late rates Friday included: 1.5305 German marks, up from 1.5275; 1.3645 Swiss francs, up from 1.3630; 5.1900 French francs, up from 5.1800; 1,320.5 Italian lire, down from 1,340.5, and 1.24375 Canadian dollars, down from 1.24675.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.5390 German marks, up from 1.5305; 1.3680 Swiss francs, up from 1.3635.

HEADLINE: Resales Off For Homes

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes in September edged lower from August levels, the National Association of Realtors said today, though the selling rate was up 5.1 percent from September 1991.
The trade group said sales last month were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.28 million, up from 3.12 million units a year ago, but almost 1 percent below August's revised rate of 3.31 million units. 
 Interest rates for 30-year conventional fixed-rated mortgages averaged 7.92 percent last month, the lowest monthly average since June 1973. In September 1991, the rate was 9.01 percent.
The national median price for an existing home in September was $103,200, a 2.9 percent increase over the September 1991 price of $100,300, the real estate group said.
The Northeast showed the biggest increase. The region's seasonally adjusted sales rate was 530,000 units, up 1.9 percent from August's 520,000. The median price for a single-family home in the region was $137,000, down five-tenths of 1 percent from September 1991.
The South also showed a gain, posting a rate of 1.21 million units, up eight-tenths of 1 percent from the previous month's 1.2 million. The median price was unchanged at $91,700.
The biggest regional decrease was in the West, where the rate dropped 5.6 percent from August's 710,000, to 670,000 units. But the median price edged up to $145,200 from $144,200 a year earlier.
The sales rate also slipped in the Midwest to 870,000 units, down 1.1 percent from 880,000 in August.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Prices Show Gains On Reports of Asian Buying

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Copper futures rallied yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, making a comeback from Friday's selloff on news of Asian buying overnight.
On other markets, grains and soybeans were lower, energy products mostly rose and livestock and pork were mostly higher. 
 Copper futures recovered all of Friday's losses, which occurred on news of rising Comex and London Metal Exchange warehouse stocks. The market gained strength on news that China has entered the market, said Bernard Savaiko, an analyst at PaineWebber Inc.
Mr. Savaiko said that although the world economy was weak, the demand for copper was holding up well. He said China's entry into the market could signal added strength.
Copper for delivery in November settled 1 cent higher at 99.55 cents a pound.
 
Pressure on Grains and Soybeans
 Grain and soybean futures were lower in quiet trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, with corn futures hitting new contract lows as the pace of the Midwest corn harvest picks up.
Soybean futures were mostly lower, with the market reacting to the dry, warm weekend, which aided harvesting. Also hurting soybeans was the lack of a resolution to the American-European soybean subsidy dispute, analysts said.
Wheat futures felt pressure as the market showed disappointment over the Agriculture Department's failure to reach agreement over the purchase of 500,000 metric tons of soft red winter wheat by Russia.
December wheat settled 1 1/2 cents lower at $3.44 1/4 a bushel; December corn was 1 1/4 cents lower at $2.05 1/2 a bushel; December oats were 2 1/4 cents lower at $1.32 3/4 a bushel and November soybeans were 2 1/2 cents lower at $5.41 3/4 a bushel.
Energy futures settled mostly higher in quiet trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. December light crude oil was 8 cents higher at $21.27 cents a barrel; November heating oil was 0.05 cent higher at 61.85 cents a gallon; November unleaded gasoline was 0.41 cent higher at 59.30 cents a gallon; December natural gas was 7 cents lower at $2.277 per 1,000 cubic feet.
Cattle futures were higher and pork futures mixed on trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. December live cattle were 0.72 cent higher at 74.47 cents a pound; December live hogs were 0.03 cent lower at 43.92 cents a pound and February frozen pork bellies were 0.12 cent lower at 42.60 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: Big Winner From Plunge In Sterling

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The Hungarian-American financier George Soros made a profit of almost $1 billion during last month's devaluation of the British pound by betting heavily that the currency would collapse despite Government assurances to the contrary.
In an interview reported today in the Times of London, Mr. Soros said he had borrowed heavily to take his stand against the pound because he was confident the German Bundesbank wanted devaluations in Britain and Italy, but not in France. 
 In the weeks leading up to Sept. 16, known as Black Wednesday in Britain, Mr. Soros sold pounds, betting $10 billion that Prime Minister John Major would fail to keep the currency above its floor in Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism.
He won, and Mr. Major lost. The onslaught by currency speculators forced Mr. Major to pull the pound out of the European Community's system for regulating the value of the community's national currencies. The pound was subsequently devalued by 12 percent.
"We must have been the biggest single factor in the market in the days before the E.R.M. fell apart," The Times quoted Mr. Soros as saying. "Our total position by Black Wednesday had to be worth almost $10 billion."
The depth of the British recession made Mr. Major's commitment to keep the pound at 2.95 German marks untenable, he said.
Mr. Soros was identified over the weekend in the United States and Britain as the man who made a billion out of the pound's collapse. "A billion is about right as an estimate of the profit, though dollars, not pounds," he said.
The profit was not his personal gain but that of the $4 billion Quantum Fund and three smaller offshoots he manages.

HEADLINE: Uncovered Short Sales Rise Again on the Nasdaq

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The number of over-the-counter shares sold short and not yet covered rose between mid-September and mid-October, the ninth straight monthly increase, the National Association of Securities dealers said yesterday.
The latest monthly figures reflect trades that took place on the Nasdaq system as of Oct. 7 and settled as of Oct 15. These uncovered short positions are a widely watched gauge of investor sentiment, since they reflect the activities of a large contingent of professional sellers who specialize in ferreting out overvalued companies. 
 By borrowing the stocks of those companies and selling them at high prices, the investors are betting that prices will fall, thereby enabling the short-sellers to buy the shares back cheaply and pocket the difference.
As in the previous month, the mid-September through mid-October period was a difficult one for short-sellers, because Nasdaq's broad market averages moved higher, not lower. And much of the rise has taken place since the beginning of the month.
"Short-sellers started the month in pretty good shape, up about 2 percent to 3 percent," said Harry Strunk, a Palm Beach, Fla., investment consultant who tracks professional short-sellers. "But since early October, they are down about 3 percent on average."
Despite the rise in broad over-the-counter averages, nervousness about the Nov. 3 Presidential election led to a 4.9 percent increase in outstanding short interest on the Nasdaq, to 462.7 million shares, from 440.7 million shares in September.
"These over-the-counter stocks have been pretty strong of late," said one professional short-seller, who asked not to be identified, "and the higher the price goes, the greater the chance that they will be shorted. But the economy seems to be picking up a notch, which makes me wonder if the increase in short interest is justified."
Short interest in the 2,670 over-the-counter issues traded on Nasdaq's National Market System amounted to 438.8 million shares during the period, up from 416.2 million shares from mid-August to mid-September.
Meanwhile, short interest in 971 small-capitalization Nasdaq issues aggregated 23.9 million shares, down slightly from the 24.5 million shares traded in the previous month.
As a result of a sharp increase in overall trading volume after the normally slow August-September month, short interest recorded through mid-October represents 2.82 days average daily Nasdaq National Market System volume, compared with 3.43 days for the period ended mid-September

PUB-DATE: October 27, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 23; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 664 words

HEADLINE: The Elvis Strategy

BYLINE: By Greil Marcus; Greil Marcus is author of "Dead Elvis: A Chronicle of a Cultural Obsession."

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif.

 BODY:
In no Presidential year has Elvis Presley been so inseparable from the action as in 1992.
Soon after the New Hampshire primary, the news media noted an odd phenomenon: interest in the Postal Service's Elvis-stamp election seemed to outstrip public concern for the primaries themselves. The intensity of the national joke-cum-struggle over the choice between the old and young Elvis revealed, among other things, a profound dissatisfaction with the candidates actually on view. The stamp election was more fun, and perhaps more meaningful, than the real one. Thus when Ross Perot emerged to fill the void Elvis's ghost had revealed, Mr. Perot was not only himself -- steely-eyed Mr. Fixit -- he was also the weirdest Elvis stand-in anyone had ever seen. 
 The weirdest, but not, in this political year, the most eager. Bill Clinton, a lifelong Elvis fan, won that prize. The press corps secretly called him "Elvis" -- "Elvis with a calculator" was one of the better variations. But by the end of the primary season, a wan version of the King's lazy grin seemed nearly all the candidate had left. When Governor Clinton sang a verse of "Don't Be Cruel" in a CNN interview, it sounded like a loser's plea.
Then came the great shift. Ross Perot decided not to run, George Bush went nowhere and Bill Clinton surged. In July, "Elvis Aron Presley" was listed in the party literature as the "Entertainment Coordinator" of the Democratic Convention. Al Gore told the convention it had always been his dream to come "to Madison Square Garden and be the warm-up act for Elvis."
The President's attacks were couched in bizarre Elvisisms: the Governor was on all sides of every issue. "He's been spotted in more places than Elvis Presley," Mr. Bush complained. "I guess you'd say his plan really is 'Elvis Economics,' " he continued: "America will be checking into the 'Heartbreak Hotel.' "
Despite Bill Clinton's growing lead, the President persisted into the fall. "I finally figured out why [Clinton] compares himself to Elvis," he said. "The minute he has to take a stand on something, he starts wiggling."
The tone was sour, like 1950's bluenoses sniffing at "Elvis the Pelvis." You could almost hear Elvis objecting. (He hated the word "wiggle.") Even Mr. Clinton finally felt free to join the conversation. "I don't think Bush would have liked Elvis very much," he said.
It was a charge the President couldn't pork rind, and it raised the question of why he would risk alienating working-class white Southerners with remarks that disparaged a cultural hero.
The simple answer is this: slap Elvis on anything and you'll be noticed. Elvis in a speech is a guaranteed sound bite on the evening news. But if Elvis is a hook, he -- or it -- is also a hook lodged in millions of hearts. You're guaranteed a response when you pull the Elvis cord, but there's no guarantee what the response will be.
For Mr. Bush, the invocation backfired. For Russell Feingold, the Democratic senatorial candidate in Wisconsin, it was a charm. The candidate's primary victory was due in large part to a TV ad featuring an Enquirer-style "Elvis Endorses Feingold" story. Last week in Milwaukee, Mr. Clinton endorsed Mr. Feingold, saying: "The real reason that I so deeply, deeply support him is that Elvis supports him."
And for Bill Clinton, Elvis clearly helped. After the primaries, when he had fallen drastically behind Mr. Bush and Mr. Perot, he took his saxophone onto "The Arsenio Hall Show" and blew "Heartbreak Hotel." That moment may have turned the race around. Mr. Clinton stepped forward as if to say: All right. Who cares. Let's rip it up.
For the first time in the campaign Bill Clinton was more Elvis than calculator. The spirit of freedom in Elvis's best music is a freedom of self-discovery -- and that night Bill Clinton accepted the gift. Playing the old song as best he could, he was more fan than star, more himself than Elvis, but perhaps just Elvis enough.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Clinton, Gazing Beyond Nov. 3, Outlines Vision

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAFAYETTE, La., Oct. 27

 BODY:
As his opponents continued to squabble, Gov. Bill Clinton sought higher ground for his campaign today, describing in sweeping terms the tone and priorities he would bring to the White House.
"The important thing is, what are we going to do after the election," he said in Augusta, Ga., on the first stop of a Southern swing. "Because after the election, there'll be no charges to answer, nobody to make fun of, only the American people, their problems and their promise out there. 
 "And the issue is, what are we going to do to move our country forward and lift our country up," Mr. Clinton said. "That is why I got into this race."
 
Out of the Cross-Fire
 The tone of Mr. Clinton's remarks, which came on a day that he was taking his campaign to the formerly Republican bastions of Georgia, Florida and Louisiana, reflected his strategists' view that he needed to distance himself from the cross-fire between President Bush and Ross Perot.
"I did not enter this race for President to run my opponents down," he said at rallies in Augusta and Tampa. "I entered this race to lift the American people up."
Mr. Clinton has been wary of seeming to claim the Presidential mantle prematurely, and with his speech today he undertook the difficult task of casting himself as the best choice without seeming to overreach. In what amounted to a balancing act, he mixed attacks on Mr. Bush with optimistic descriptions of how a Democratic Administration would bring about authentic change.
 
The First Priorities
 Mr. Clinton said his first priorities as President would be ending trickle-down economics, reining in health- care costs and pushing through legislation on tuition aid, job leaves for workers' family emergencies, toughened child-support regulations and community "boot camps" for first-time criminal offenders.
He said the ideas he was proposing would not be cost free, and he voiced some caution as he presented sweeping plans that he asserted would change the way business was done in Washington.
In describing the outlines of a new Administration, Mr. Clinton reiterated much of what he has described in policy speeches all year.
By turning his sights beyond next week's general election, Mr. Clinton was reaching for a message that had enough energy to carry his candidacy through the final week but was at the same time free of risks.
 
6 States in 2 Days
 In the next two days, he will have chances to deliver the message to voters in Houston; Jackson, Miss.; Louisville; Toledo, Ohio; Detroit, and Secaucus, N.J.
Moreover, his campaign began broadcasting a new television commercial that set a similar tone, pointing to the business executives and scholars who had endorsed him and his proposals.
As Mr. Clinton outlined his programs today, focusing heavily on domestic concerns and making virtually no reference to foreign policy, he also contrasted his plan with the record of President Bush.
"This is an Administration divided against itself with no firm convictions, in total disarray," he said at an afternoon rally in downtown Tampa, Fla. "Can you believe what's going on in Washington? It's sort of like reading the comic strips on the front page every day now."
Ross Perot's independent candidacy received scarcely a mention from Mr. Clinton in his speeches, and his aides said they plan for it to stay this way.
"While the other candidates are tearing each other down, he wants to spell out in clear terms his plan to lift the country up," said Bruce Reed, Mr. Clinton's policy director. "When voters go into polls next Tuesday, he wants them to know that America is going to change in real, concrete ways if they cast votes for him."
 
Meets Cuban Leader
 At each rally today, Mr. Clinton's supporters broke into chants of "One more week!" The chanting, which Mr. Clinton encouraged, also served to drown out the cries of the pockets of Bush-Quayle protesters who show up at every Clinton event.
He denied that he was campaigning a region that was strongly for Mr. Bush in 1988 simple to keep his opponent off balance. "I'm trying to win the South," he said.
To that end, Mr. Clinton met briefly with the Cuban exile leader Jorge Mas Canosa and with Representative Dante B. Fascell, Democrat of Florida, chairman of the House Foreign Relations Committee, at the Tampa International Airport.
Mr. Clinton said he and Mr. Mas had not discussed politics but had talked about Mr. Clinton's support of the Cuban-American Democracy Bill, which tightens the United States's economic embargo against Cuba. Mr. Bush signed the legislation last week, and Mr. Mas said he would vote for Mr. Bush. Mr. Mas is chairman of the influential Cuban American National Foundation, a 54,000-member lobbying group. Cuban-Americans have voted overwhelmingly Republican in the past.
Mr. Clinton is hoping for victories in several Southern states next week. It would be especially damaging for Mr. Bush if he lost in Florida and Texas, where Mr. Clinton will visit Wednesday.
This year's election, he said, in his policy address today, will be a referendum on Americans' willingness to change the course of their futures by being "more than spectators" in the political process.
 
'My Fellow Americans'
 "This year, when the history of this election is written, it will not be about politics and manipulation," Mr. Clinton said. "It will be about how the American people took charge of their future again."
Mr. Clinton, who has recently begun addressing his supporters as "my fellow Americans," is making an especially energetic pitch in Florida, where Democratic officials crowded onto the stage to be seen with him today.
"Four years ago, Florida gave George Bush an enormous majority, more than than 60 perent of the vote," Mr. Clinton said. "Since then, unemployment has gone up, airline companies based in Florida have been bankrupted, the elderly people have seen no attempt to control health-care costs, and every attempt to do it has been by cutting Medicare to those least able to pay.
"The economy of Florida is in a shambles, and yet they say if there's one big state in America that we can depend upon, its Florida -- they're just knee-jerk and vote Republican," Mr. Clinton said, prompting boos from his Democratic loyalists.
Lieut. Gov. Buddy McKay, the chairman of the Florida Democratic Party, said the presence of so many elected officials eager to bask in the free exposure drawn by a Presidential frontrunner, was proof of how well Mr. Clinton was doing here.
"We all know he is coattails," he said.
