HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Uses Latest Economic Figure to Support His Assertion of a Recovery

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KETTERING, Ohio, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Searching for ways to undermine Gov. Bill Clinton's appeal to recession-weary voters, President Bush today eagerly seized on an increase in economic growth to proclaim that the American economy is growing and "will lead the world to recovery."
Mr. Bush spent most of the day steering away for from the feud that erupted over the weekend with Ross Perot over campaign dirty tricks, although he did keep the dispute alive early in day when he referred to Mr. Perot's accusations as "crazy" on national television. 
 Instead, the President kept his fire trained on his Democratic opponent as he campaigned through economically troubled areas where he is trailing badly in public opinion polls.
Mr. Bush suggested that the 2.7 percent increase in the gross domestic product announced today undermined Mr. Clinton's campaign of change, and he presented the news as evidence to allay voters' doubts about his own economic stewardship.
"Two-point-seven percent is darn good growth and it pulls the rug out from under Mr. Clinton, who's telling everybody how horrible everything is," Mr. Bush said in a televised session with voters that was broadcast across Kentucky this afternoon.
"We have now had six straight quarters of growth in the United States," he said. "And yet the Democrats keep telling us that everything is going to hell. And they're wrong. They are wrong."
 
Bush Predicts Recovery
 At Paducah Community College in Paducah, Ky., addressing more than 10,000 cheering and flag-waving supporters at his largest and most enthusiastic rally in days, Mr. Bush shouted, "We're moving and we're going to lead the world to recovery."
By this evening, Mr. Bush, making a final push that will focus on the Midwest for the next few days, including a train trip through Wisconsin on Saturday, had warmed to his attack on Mr. Clinton's favorite theme.
"Change. Change. Change. Change. Change," he chanted derisively at a rally here.
The President pointedly avoided referring to other, less heartening statistics published today, including the smallest increase in wages in five years and the lowest level of consumer confidence in eight months.
He stayed away from other bad news, trying to get past his feud with Ross Perot over the independent's accusations of Republican "dirty tricks." Mr. Bush said he thought the episode was "strange," but his aides have concluded that Mr. Perot's charges hurt the Republican campaign, and the President clearly did not want to talk about them anymore.
Rather, for Mr. Bush, as he stumped through a spectacular day in autumn-painted districts in Iowa, Kentucky and Ohio, it was time to search for good news and for silver linings.
He trumpeted the economic figures at each stop. He invited a reporter from USA Today aboard Air Force One for his first interview with a nationally circulated newspaper in four months after hearing that the newspaper had a poll showing the race tightening.
And in an interview from Des Moines on NBC's "Today" program, Mr. Bush seemed confident, almost serene. When his interviewer noted that polls still gave Mr. Clinton a substantial lead, Mr. Bush said, "Well, that might be right, see, but I think that's no hill for a climber, at the end here."
After refusing at first to respond to a series of questions about whether he ever thought about losing, Mr. Bush offered this almost wistful discussion of the benefits of retiring from the White House:
"Some day I won't be President, and that day doesn't worry me one single bit. I'm going to get big into the grandchild business. I'm going to get big in the golf business. I'm going to tell my handlers, who will be gone, they'll be vanished, don't worry about it. If I want to be out on a boat, whether there's a war on or something else, I know what I'm doing, and forget about it all."
Not wanting to leave anyone with the impression that he was anything but confident about his re-election, Mr. Bush added hastily, "But that's going to be five years from now, not one."
In his quest to provide reasons why voters should re-elect him, Mr. Bush also suggested, in the familiar rambling way that often reveals much about his mood, that as a lame duck, he could operate without thought to politics.
"I will be re-elected and not have any politics on the horizon -- no more -- no more campaigns, no more debates, thank God," he said as he began his day in Des Moines by taking questions from a screened group of supporters.
The questioning was so gentle and so evidently orchestrated by local political aides that Mr. Bush seemed to grow embarrassed.
When a teen-ager asked him how Arkansas ranked in various economic areas, Mr. Bush said: "Hey, good question. That's what we call a -- we call that -- in the World Series every once in a while you see the seams on it when it comes over the plate, the slow ball -- you know what I mean."
Mr. Bush combined the more upbeat tone of his remarks with a continuation of his increasingly peppery attack on Mr. Clinton.
Asked in Des Moines how Mr. Clinton could execute his plans to raise taxes on the most wealthy Americans and significantly increase Government spending, Mr. Bush retorted, "We don't have anybody dumb enough to figure it out."
He assailed Mr. Clinton as lacking any experience on foreign policy. Referring to his family's dog, Mr. Bush said, "Clinton and Gore, they've got about as much foreign policy experience as Millie, put together."
The Bush campaign prepared to broadcast a new 30-second advertisement on Wednesday that may be its toughest attack yet on Mr. Clinton's record as Governor of Arkansas. With black-and-white photographs of stormy weather in the background, the announcer says, "In his 12 years as Governor, Bill Clinton has doubled his state's debt, doubled government spending and signed the largest tax increase in his state's history."
Faced with the success of Mr. Perot's 30- and 60-minute paid political programs, the Bush campaign today began broadcasting a series of two-minute television commercials. The first shows the President speaking to a group of people about the tough decisions he makes as commander in chief.
 
Issue of Character
 While making no direct reference to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Bush raises the issue of character. "All of you know that the Presidency is the most serious job in the world," he tells the group. "And we simply cannot put America's future at risk with a person who is wrong for the job, and with policies that are wrong for America."
Appearing on the NBC program "Today" this morning from Des Moines, Mr. Bush joined in the attack on Mr. Perot that had been begun by his staff, but in a more restrained manner.
Asked about Mr. Perot's accusations of dirty tricks, Mr. Bush said, "I agree that this recent incident is crazy."
He declined to say whether Mr. Perot's contentions were evidence of a temperament inappropriate for the Presidency. "I'm not here to characterize Ross Perot," he said, adding: "I want to concentrate on Governor Clinton. I believe that's the main opponent. I'm not going to stand out here, waste my time analyzing this problem."

LENGTH: 1102 words

HEADLINE: Perot Spending More on Ads Than Any Candidate Before

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
Since re-entering the Presidential race at the beginning of the month, Ross Perot has embarked on what is likely to prove to be, week by week, the most expensive political advertising campaign in the history of the country.
In the first two weeks of this month, Mr. Perot spent $24 million on commercials. According to campaign disclosures received Monday by the Federal Election Commission, he spent almost $10.8 million over the next 10days. On Monday night alone, he spent almost $1 million for an hourlong paid program on ABC. 
 If Mr. Perot's advertising budget were annualized, it would exceed that of companies like Chrysler and RJR Nabisco.
But as other independently wealthy Presidential candidates have proved, outspending one's opponents, and even outspending big, multinational corporations, is not necessarily the most effective way to get to the Oval Office. And ever since Sunday night, when Mr. Perot told "60 Minutes" on CBS that he had dropped out of the race because of tips that Republican "dirty tricksters" were planning to disrupt his daughter's wedding, the news about Mr. Perot has provided a distinctly unflattering contrast to his advertising.
Now the main question seems to be which media image will prevail: the Ross Perot of the news stories ("Paranoid!" "Loony!"), or the Ross Perot of the advertisements (down-to-earth, sober, pragmatic).
 
Rule of Advertising
 "The rule is your advertising and your free media have to get out a coordinated message," said Darrell West, a professor of political science at Brown University. "That's not happening with Ross Perot. The problem is the interpretation that went out on the news is this guy is paranoid."
Aides to both Gov. Bill Clinton and President Bush were visibly relieved when Mr. Perot began to make news that conflicted with his high-rolling ad campaign. But both sides also said it would be foolhardy to underestimate the influence of tens of millions of dollars worth of advertising in the last days of the campaign.
"I think his advertising will have an impact," said Sig Rogich, head of the Bush ad campaign. "Plus, I happen to think his ads are pretty good."
While they are trying to sort out the impact of Mr. Perot's unusual accusations and the Bush campaign's denials, and are relying on polls that still suggest a race in flux, both the President and the Arkansas Governor seem to be having trouble settling on an end-game ad strategy.
The Bush campaign has produced a new two-minute ad that focuses on the President's qualifications, but has also produced a new ad attacking Mr. Clinton's record in Arkansas. The Clinton campaign, in the meantime, is planning a new ad in which Nobel Prize-winning economists praise the Governor's economic plans.
Because it often takes a few days for the latest news to be felt in the polls, it is still too early to tell which image of Mr. Perot is winning. But both Democratic and Republican campaign officials say their latest tracking polls suggest that support for Mr. Perot, who had been gaining about a point a day since the last Presidential debate, on Oct. 19, seems to have leveled off.
For his part, though, Mr. Perot is pouring money into his campaign at an unprecedented rate. Last Wednesday alone, Mr. Perot added $4.5 million to his campaign treasury and the next day he added another $2.85 million.
Responding to a question this morning on the NBC program "Today," Mr. Bush said he found it "a little bizarre" how much Mr. Perot was spending on his campaign."
The President added: "But put it this way. Don't worry about him. He's got plenty left."
Probably the most extraordinary aspect of Mr. Perot's advertising campaign has been his half-hour paid programs, which have consistently drawn the kind of audiences that would make many sit-com producers jealous. On Monday, Mr. Perot's hour-long presentation on ABC, which included a half hour conversation with his family that had run once before, attracted 12 million viewers. This was significantly fewer than CBS's "Evening Shade" and NBC's "Fresh Prince of Bel Air" at the same time, but enough to confound many analysts.
Between now and Election day, Mr. Perot has purchased seven more half-hours of network time, at a cost of several million dollars.
At the same time, though, the unconventional independent candidate has also been spending heavily on highly conventional 30- and 60-second commercials. And in addition to buying commercial time on the networks, he has recently begun more selective local television and radio buys.
Much of Mr. Perot's local advertising is in California, where Mr. Clinton enjoys a wide lead in the polls and where neither the Bush campaign nor the Clinton campaign is on the air. In Los Angeles, for instance, Mr. Perot is spending at least $750,000 on local television, according the figures obtained from the three network affiliates there In San Diego and San Francisco, he is spending another $600,000 on television.
In New York City, in contrast, he is spending much less. Two of the network affiliates and Channel 5, the local Fox station, reported that he had purchased about $180,000 in ad time, compared with Mr. Clinton, who had purchased $2 million worth of time on the three stations and Mr. Bush who had purchased slightly over $1 million. While New York State is considered by most analysts to be in Mr. Clinton's column, the Bush campaign considers itself competitive in New Jersey and Connecticut, in the same television market.
Mr. Perot's latest advertisements are clearly aimed at countering the perception that a vote for him would be a wasted vote. In the ads, Mr. Perot inverts the concept and urges voters not to waste their votes on the two major parties.
In one radio ad, for example, Mr. Perot talks about one of his favorite subjects, former government officials who lobby for foreign countries, then an announcer says, "This is no time to waste our vote on politics as usual." In another radio commercial, he lists statistics about crime, job losses and growth in the national debt -- all for one day. Again the announcer says, "This is no time to waste our vote."
In a new television ad, Mr. Perot warns voters against listening to the press and the major parties. "The closer we get to the election, the more people will be telling you how to vote," he says. "The press. The polls. The parties. They're all counting your vote before you even leave your house on Nov. 3. I'm not going to tell you how to vote. That's wrong. But you ought to vote for what you believe in, and you know that's right."

HEADLINE: Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky Journal;
Russia Permits Just a Peek at Nature in the Raw

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PETROPAVLOVSK-KAMCHATSKY, Russia

 BODY:
Ever since Czar Aleksandr II sold Alaska to the Americans, Kamchatka has been Russia's easternmost frontier -- a peninsula roughly the size of Montana, with snow-tipped volcanoes, sputtering geysers and miles of untouched birch forests that turn amber in the fading light of autumn.
Here, nine time zones away from Moscow, nature is still undefeated, in contrast to the rest of Russia, where the environment was regularly sacrificed to the reckless god of industrial development. On Kamchatka, the rivers are still clean enough for freshwater crayfish and spawning salmon, while in winter the snow in its volcanic craters is so white that local people describe it as almost blue. 
 In the Soviet era, Kamchatka's pristine beauty was kept off limits by a military that jealously guarded its strategic location on the northern Pacific. Foreigners were barred, and even Soviet citizens had to get special permission to travel here.
"Kamchatka is still terra incognita for the rest of the world," said Sergei A. Alekseyev, director of the Kronotsky Nature Reserve, in the heart of Kamchatka. Besides 22 volcanoes and a population of bears, sables, otters, sea eagles and white falcons, the reserve boasts a Valley of Geysers, where underground thermal springs come burbling and gushing out of the rocks like potions from a mad chemist's laboratory.
In the last year, Kamchatka has opened itself up to outsiders, joining in the nationwide scramble for a magic formula that will lure foreign investment without any sacrifice of local interests. For better or for worse, all that Kamchatka really has to offer is what nature gave it. The trick, local people say, is not to abuse this gift.
 
A Hardship Post
 But the pressure is on. The local government has already opened bidding to develop the mining of gold, while the peninsula's west coast is dotted with oil wells that were drilled to see whether the rich finds off Sakhalin Island extend eastward into the Sea of Okhotsk.
These are difficult times for the 370,000 people on Kamchatka, of whom 250,000 live in the city of Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky, an old and dingy military and fishing port that until recently could not receive foreign ships. Workers here still get special bonuses for living in a hardship region. But these benefits, which can increase salaries by 80 to 160 percent, are being whittled away by Russia's roaring inflation rate, made worse here by the high cost of transport.
At the Kronotsky Reserve, Mr. Alekseyev is making do with one-half of the 7.5 million rubles promised him this year by the central Government in Moscow, even as he struggles to pay the 50,000-rubles-an-hour bill for the helicopters that bring his staff of 40 rangers and 13 researchers in and out of the wilderness.
To make ends meet, Mr. Alekseyev has given approval for a form of "eco-tourism" on the Kronotsky domain. For a share of the profits, the reserve has given an exclusive contract to a local company, Sogzhoy, which offers helicopter tours to the Valley of the Geysers three times a week, available to customers with dollars at $250 for a round trip.
This year, about 2,000 people were flown in and out of the Valley of Geysers, the limit considered manageable by environmentalists here and in Moscow. To handle the tourists, a wooden walkway was built around the valley's rim for prime viewing of the geysers, the biggest of which spouts 191-degree water 131 feet in the air every eight hours.
But that is it: Kronotsky may stoop to tourism, but Mr. Alekseyev has vowed never to allow refreshment stands, postcard vendors or the kind of backpacking trekkers that throng America's national parks.
"We absolutely need to keep some places on the planet untouched, so they can serve as a benchmark for natural preservation," he said. "But the situation is such today that we have to find a compromise."
In his quest for the balance between nature's needs and human curiosity, Mr. Alekseyev has been in contact with experts at Yellowstone National Park, the only place in the world that has more geysers than Kamchatka.
The Kronotsky reserve dates from 1802, when czarist authorities barred sable-hunters from the region. From 1964 to 1976, the reserve was opened to visiting dignitaries and high-ranking Soviet officials, and to geologists who came in search of oil reserves. They found oil and left, but in the process tore up miles of delicate permafrost, or tundra, that has yet to fully recover.
Given the vast amount of wilderness available in the rest of Kamchatka, the Kronotsky reserve is not likely now to be on any prospectors' maps. In fact, in Moscow, the Ministry of the Environment is now trying to include the region on the international register of wilderness reserves, as a kind of safeguard against future meddling.
But Mr. Alekseyev worries now not just about the nature preserve, but about Kamchatka as a whole.
"There are still people who think of this as a huge country with unlimited resources, even though we have already seen much of Russia turned into an ecological desert," he said. "They say they want to develop with clean technology, but there is evidence of what miners do. Look at Alaska, look at Colorado."

In the last year, Kamchatka has opened itself up to outsiders, joining in the nationwide scramble for a magic formula that will lure foreign investment. (Otto Pohl for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: From Warm Letters to Cold Warring, Romance Fades

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 21

 BODY:
With flowers in hand, Donald Davis, a 54-year-old Orange County truck driver, went to the airport last month to meet his fiancee.
It was the first time he had set eyes on Natalya Sadchikova, a 42-year-old woman he had seen in a catalogue of prospective mail-order brides from the former Soviet Union -- the dreamy, downtrodden Natasha whose poetic letters had charmed him during their two-year correspondence. They shook hands and he brought her home, along with her 3-year-old daughter, Alina. 
 A month later, Ms. Sadchikova and her daughter are in a Newburgh homeless shelter. Mr. Davis seems to be in shock.
"It was a complete disaster, not a minor but a major disaster," said Mr. Davis -- one of the few points on which he and Ms. Sadchikova are in agreement.
 
A Growing Marriage Market
 Since the collapse of the former Soviet Union, thousands of Russian women like Ms. Sadchikova have added their names to the rosters of a growing number of marriage brokers, who they hope will find them American husbands.
Immigration and State Department officials who have noted the recent influx said they have no numbers, but lawyers, social workers and travel agents say as many as 100 Russian women have come to New York to marry their pen pals in the last year.
"There are more and more coming in through the bridal agencies that have mushroomed," said Olga Roussanow, senior counselor for immigration benefits at the Tolstoy Foundation in Manhattan. "It's very risky," she said, but because of the economic hardships that draw a number of the women here, "these people are not afraid."
Ms. Roussanow said many were eventually sent back to Russia after culture clashes that end in romantic fiascos -- which would be an understated description of the short-lived relationship between Ms. Sadchikova and Mr. Davis.
 
'Like a Little Puppy'
 By his account, her daughter kept him up nights crying and lost severaltreasured possessions, including a Rolex watch the little girl had adopted as a toy. His intended, he said, complained constantly about American food, grew suspicious when he took a shower before going to work, and became enraged when he talked on the telephone with his 87-year-old mother, who had been hit by a bus.
He claims that Ms. Sadchikova pretended to be pregnant with his child -- before he broke the news that he'd had a vasectomy. And he says she propositioned his 27-year-old son.
Ms. Sadchikova denies most of Mr. Davis's account; she says her daughter does cry a lot. She maintains that the relationship failed for far less dramatic reasons: because Mr. Davis was impatient with her child, with her faulty English and with the fact that she had to have everything explained to her.
"I think we are like a little puppy you see on the street," she said. "You say, 'Oh, poor little puppy, no one loves him. I take him home.' Then in home he makes wet on the floor, he wants food and play, and you put the puppy back in the street."
She fled from Mr. Davis's home in Washingtonville to the shelter here, she said, to avoid being deposited on the streets of Brighton Beach in Brooklyn, where many Russian immigrants live. Mr. Davis said he planned to take her to Brighton Beach only because she had asked him to.
Before the outbreak of their own personal cold war -- that is, before they ever met -- both had been full of hope that they might build a new life together.
"He write, 'I love you, I need you.' They were good letters," she said. "I'm romantic; I dreamed to look at the world and he write me about nature, about his love to his sons, about traveling. I think this man must be good."
She was thinking, too, about finding a way out of her hometown of Vladivostok, on Russia's East Coast on the Sea of Japan, where a crumbling economy had made life difficult and where work as a freelance photographer was increasingly hard to find. Her husband of 15 years, who could not have children, she said, had divorced her after she decided to have another man's child.
And she was more than ready for a fresh start. "Every marriage is like a song," she said. "You sing it and it's finished. You begin another song." Not long after Alina was born, she sent her picture to Scanna International, a pioneer in the matchmaking industry, which set up an office in Vladivostok in 1989.
 
$10 an Address
 A Scanna representative in Pittsford, N.Y., where the company is based, said Russian women have become the mainstay of its business in the years since the former Soviet Union liberalized its immigration policies. About 5,000 American men are looking for Russian brides through Scanna alone, according to the representative, who claims that the agency has listings for 20,000 Russian women.
Other bridal agencies that once dealt primarily with Asian women have shifted their focus to Russia, and a number of new agencies have opened, advertising in publications like The Russian Daily and The Village Voice.
Every two weeks, Scanna publishes a catalogue that sells for $5 and includes the photographs and brief biographies of 200 new women. The address of a woman in the catalogue costs an additional $10 -- or $7 each with the purchase of 10 or more.
After two failed marriages, Mr. Davis said he turned to the catalogue as a way of placing a kind of international personal ad. And the idea of rescuing a woman from hardship appealed to Mr. Davis, who describes himself as the kind of person who can't pass a guy with a sign that says "Will Work for Food" without stopping to help.
"You start out with the fantasy that you might meet someone," he said. Soon, he began writing Ms. Sadchikova. He was captivated by the lyrical, philosophical turns in the broken syntax of her letters and moved to compassion by her stories of deprivation in Russia. "Once she wrote me, 'Have you ever looked into the eyes of a genius and wondered what was in his mind?' " he said. "To me she was a very sensitive person."
She also sent him another picture of herself. "It is not so good looking," she said. "I want him to see the truth."
Unlike most Scanna clients, Mr. Davis ignored the advice of the agency, which strongly recommends that prospective bridegrooms travel to Russia to spend extended vacations with their correspondents before bringing them to this country.
To get what is known as a fiancee visa, which gives the immigrant 90 days to marry or leave the country, the couple must have already met. But to get a six-month visitor's visa, like Ms. Sadchikova's, an applicant must have only an invitation -- and convincing proof that she plans to return to Russia.
Most couples work with an immigration lawyer like Larry Holmes of San Diego, who for the last 18 months has specialized in bringing Russian brides to this country through several agencies -- and he insists that in most cases the matches have produced happy marriages.
"My clients all tell me the same thing," he said. "They think American women are spoiled and Russian women aren't. They're the more old-fashioned type of girls."
Mr. Holmes, who is careful to say that this is not his personal opinion, said: "They all tell me that they are sick and tired of the princess attitude of American women."
But some men like Mr. Davis prefer to close the deal themselves.
Last summer, Mr. Davis sent Ms. Sadchikova the invitation.
Almost immediately after posting the invitation, he said, he began to get cold feet. But when he received a telegram that Ms. Sadchikova was already in Moscow with the visitor's visa in hand, he sent two plane tickets, costing $780, to her and her daughter.
And he would now gladly pay for two return tickets, he said. But Ms. Sadchikova has another five months before her visa expires and plans to spend that time trying to find another way to stay here.
Despite recent events, "I am like Alyssa in country magic" in the United States, she said, referring perhaps to Alice in Wonderland. "Maybe I find another husband."

Ms. Sadchikova is one of nearly 100 Russian women who came to New York to marry pen pals in the last year. Her marriage plans, like many arranged by brokers, have changed because of cultural clashes. HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Independent;
Perot Aides Try to End Story But President Keeps It Alive

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Ross Perot's top campaign aides tried diligently today to put an end to stories about his unsubtantiated accusations of Republican dirty tricks, but President Bush kept the story alive by calling Mr. Perot's charges "crazy" and "strange."
At a news briefing at Perot headquarters here, Sharon Holman, Mr. Perot's press secretary, dismissed questions about his accusations as "yesterday's story" and said the independent candidate for President wanted to get back to the issues. 
 But Mr. Bush, picking up where his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, left off on Monday, expressed amazement in an interview on the NBC News program "Today" about the accusations.
Asked whether he agreed with Mr. Fitzwater's characterization of Mr. Perot as "a paranoid person who has delusions," Mr. Bush replied, "I agree that this recent incident is crazy."
He added: "I mean, an allegation that we would wittingly or in any other way try to break up a man's daughter's wedding, particularly not even in the Presidential race at that time. What in the world would be the reason for that?"
 
Denver Rally Planned
 Unlike Monday, when Mr. Perot repeated his accusations after showing up unexpectedly at a morning news briefing conducted by his aides, he remained secluded today. But the Dallas billionaire plans to appear at a rally in Denver on Wednesday evening, Ron Ellsworth, his Colorado campaign chairman, said. Recent polls have shown Colorado to be Mr. Perot's strongest state.
The trip will be only the second day of public campaigning for Mr. Perot since he re-entered the Presidential race on Oct. 1. Ms. Holman said she expected him to campaign this weekend but did not say where.
Mr. Perot also agreed today to be interviewed on Thursday by the ABC News correspondent Sam Donaldson for "Prime Time Live." Mr. Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton are taping separate interviews for the show. Mr. Perot will also appear on CNN's "Larry King Live" on Thursday night and has purchased seven 30-minute time slots on the networks between tonight and Monday night, the eve of the election.
Since rejoining the race Mr. Perot has spent more than $1.4 million a day, almost all of it on television advertising, according to Federal financial disclosure reports made public on Monday. He spent $10.8 million from Oct. 15 to Oct. 26, bringing his total to $37 million since he announced his candidacy 26 days earlier, and to $57 million for the year. Those numbers shatter previous records for expenditures by an independent Presidential candidate.
In Mr. Perot's absence, his aides made it clear they wanted the story about his accusations of Republican dirty tricks to go away. They say his improved standing in public opinion polls is the reason for the continuing questioning of his credibility.
Orson G. Swindle 3d, the director of United We Stand, America, Mr. Perot's political organization, told reporters: "We're trying to stop talking about it. If you'll cooperate, we'll quit talking about it."
 
Conventional News Reporting
 But questions about Mr. Perot's accusations dominated today's news briefing at the Perot campaign headquarters. And because even an unconventional campaign cannot escape the conventional practices of news reporting, the issue of Mr. Perot's credibility is not likely to die unless he provides backing for his charges.
Mr. Perot said in interviews with The Boston Herald, the CBS News program "60 Minutes" and at rallies last Sunday that he dropped out of the Presidential race in July because he had learned of a Republican plan to smear his daughter Carolyn by making public a doctored photograph depicting her in a lewd manner. He also charged that the Republicans planned to disrupt her wedding on Aug. 23 and that there was a plan to wiretap his phones.
He offered no evidence, although several Perot associates have said he spoke to them of his fears before he dropped out on July 16. When reporters asked him on Monday for help in substantiating his claims, he replied, "I'm sick and tired of you all questioning my integrity without any basis for it."
It was too early to tell from public opinion polls whether Mr. Perot's accusations were helping his campaign or hurting it. If voters believe Mr. Perot, his explanation could soften one of his enduring liabilities -- his decision to drop out of the race. But if they believe he has made reckless charges it could feed the perception of some that he is ill-suited for the Presidency.
 
Bush in Unlikely Position
 While more restrained than Mr. Fitzwater, the President did his best today to feed that perception. But it placed him in the unlikely position of having to attack a candidate who only three days ago seemed to be helping him by taking votes from Mr. Clinton.
"I will confess to you, strange, strange," Mr. Bush said in commenting on Mr. Perot's charges. He noted that Mr. Perot had said he accepted White House denials, but added, "I think I am glad that he has said there's nothing to it, but that's after airing it to how many million viewers?"
Mr. Perot also was attacked on the issues today, this time by aides to Mr. Clinton who characterized his proposals for hefty increases in gasoline taxes and Medicare premiums as regressive.
Gene Sperling, Mr. Clinton's economic policy director, said the campaign had conducted an analysis of Mr. Perot's economic plan showing that working-poor families and elderly couples would pay more in taxes as a percentage of their income than would middle-class families. Mr. Sperling also said the average millionaire would get a tax break because Mr. Perot's proposal to raise income tax rates for top earners would be more than offset by his proposed cut in the capital gains tax.
 
Stockdale on Antiwar Protests
 "What people should find most disappointing about this," Mr. Sperling said in a telephone interview, "is that Mr. Perot's thesis has been that if it's fair, people will share."
Meanwhile, Mr. Perot's running mate, James B. Stockdale, a retired Navy admiral and former prisoner of war in Vietnam, took a swipe at Mr. Clinton. In an interview published today in The Idaho Statesman in Boise, Mr. Stockdale asserted that Mr. Clinton's participation in antiwar protests while he was a student in England raised questions about his qualifications to be Commander in Chief.
"Those comrades of mine that died, the extra 10, 15, 20 thousand, that blood is on your hands, you war protesters," Mr. Stockdale told the newspaper. "Every time in prison we would hear that they had one of these big galas of the sort that Clinton was arranging here and there in the world, 'Huh,' we'd say. 'Another year in this place. We're not going to get out of here until we bomb Hanoi.' And they couldn't do that until they beat that opposition down."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Politcal Pulse -- Michigan;
Michigan Figures to Be, as Usual, Unpredictable

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Michigan has a certain affinity for the political outsider. In recent years such diverse figures as George C. Wallace, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Edmund G. Brown Jr. and Pat Robertson have made strong showings in caucuses or primaries here.
It is a state of great political volatility. Two years ago, for example, former Gov. James J. Blanchard seemed to be cruising toward re-election. On the Thursday before Election Day, he led in one poll by 55 percent to 35 percent. Five days later, he lost. 
 "Voters here are more alienated from government and the political establishment than most," Mr. Blanchard said this week. "They've lost jobs or lost income. They are highly tax-sensitive and economy-sensitive, and they are worried sick about the future."
 
'Gold Out of Straw'
 So it is not too surprising that this swing state is one of the places where Ross Perot has gained ground dramatically in the last two weeks on Gov. Bill Clinton. Nor is it surprising that Mr. Clinton and President Bush, both of whom campaigned here on Sunday, are planning to return on Thursday for one more shot at Michigan's 18 electoral votes.
It is a fierce, unpredictable struggle. Suggesting that anything is possible, Mayor Coleman A. Young of Detroit, a Democrat, calls this "the year when politicians make gold out of straw."
For Mr. Bush, re-election seems highly improbable without a victory here. Trailing badly in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Illinois and California, he needs every big state he can get. But the Perot surge so far has helped the President only indirectly, at least according to the public opinion polls; his standing has not budged as Mr. Clinton's has headed south.
In a poll conducted by The Detroit Free Press and WXYZ, a Detroit television station, from Oct. 3 to Oct. 7, Governor Clinton led Mr. Bush 50 percent to 31 percent, with 8 percent for Mr. Perot and 11 percent undecided. Two weeks later, after the debates, a poll taken on Oct. 20 and 21 showed the Arkansas Governor down to 41 percent, the President still at 31 and Mr. Perot at 19, with 9 percent undecided. About 625 likely voters were interviewed for each survey, and the margin of sampling error in each was plus or minus four percentage points.
 
Engler Is Optimistic
 Gov. John Engler, the man who ousted Mr. Blanchard, said in an interview today that the Republicans' private polls showed more movement toward Mr. Bush, especially when a tough test was applied to weed out unlikely voters.
"The party's phone calls have ticked sharply upwards, we're running out of yard signs and you can feel the enthusiasm, which wasn't there 10 days ago," the Governor said. "I think it will be within 100,000 votes, one way or another, and it will depend on who does the best job on turnout."
But David Rohde, a professor of political science at Michigan State University, reads the polls differently.
"Obviously, there is a substantial number of voters who are anti-Bush but not very pro-Clinton, and they have been flopping back and forth between Clinton and Perot for much of the last six months," he said. "For them the economy is the most important issue, and they are angry at both parties, fearful of higher taxes, worried about the debt. George Bush is largely irrelevant in this. What has happened is that the anti-Bush people have found a newly viable alternative.
"It's very hard to believe, after all this time, that those people are going to vote for the President, so the question becomes: Can Perot keep going up, to the point where he splits the anti-Bush vote with Clinton and lets the President pull out a narrow win?"
Professor Rohde thinks not, especially after Mr. Perot's accusations on Sunday that the Republicans plotted to disrupt his daughter's wedding.
Richard Posthumus, the leader of the Republican majority in the State Senate, agrees that Mr. Perot is not likely to go beyond 15 to 20 percent of the vote here. But he still sees some benefit for Mr. Bush in the Perot surge.
"Perot is getting the kind of people, blue-collar people, who might have gone for Ronald Reagan but won't go for George Bush because they feel betrayed on the tax pledge and on the economy generally," he said. "These people are not philosophically in tune with Clinton, and Perot gives them a vehicle.
"So what does that do for Bush? Well, it slows down the Clinton-is-inevitable stuff. It makes people think again. And maybe it gives Bush some more time to work on the undecided 10 percent."
Steven J. Rosenstone of the University of Michigan, a leading academic specialist in third-party and independent movements, is not nearly so sure that Mr. Perot has yet reached his peak in this state.
"If I had to bet, I would say Perot couldn't go much farther," Professor Rosenstone said. "But I wouldn't bet a lot. What's different about him is that he has $60 million to spend. George Wallace in 1972 spoke to far more visceral issues in places like Macomb County than Perot does, but he couldn't match the major-party candidates on TV the last week, and he fell back at the end.
"Perot can go with them, dollar for dollar, and he's also more savvy than Wallace and others in dealing early with the argument that a vote for him is wasted."
The final Presidential debate, held Oct. 19 at Michigan State University, apparently propelled Mr. Perot's spurt in the state.
Frank Garrison, the head of the Michigan A.F.L.-C.I.O., said that "a fair number of our guys like him because he's self-made and kind of macho." In addition, he said, Mr. Perot's opposition to the President's proposed free-trade agreement with Mexico, to which Mr. Clinton has given qualified support, has played a role in the Perot boom.
"For the trade union movement it's a matter of survival to win this one," Mr. Garrison said, adding that his organization was "draining its funds" in an effort on Mr. Clinton's behalf that is more intensive than any since 1960.
 
Loss of Manufacturing Jobs
 A state tabulation shows that Michigan has lost 85,000 manufacturing jobs in the last four years, and the announced closing of the big General Motors plant at Willow Run will cost another 6,000 jobs. Other major plant closures are said to be pending.
Mr. Perot's stature as a champion of American manufacturing was damaged over the weekend when The Flint Journal, the daily newspaper in a prototypical car-making town, published a headline that said, "Perot -- Billionaire, Presidential Candidate, Volvo, Mercedes Owner." The small print said he also drives an Oldsmobile.
A late development that could help Mr. Bush, Governor Engler said, is the resignation, announced Monday, of Robert C. Stempel as chairman of General Motors, although the recession certainly contributed to his demise.
"If you think the way to fix General Motors' problems is to raise taxes and impose more stringent regulation, the way Bill Clinton wants to, then I think you're pretty crazy," Mr. Engler said.
According to Hugh McDiarmid, political columnist at The Detroit Free Press, Mr. Perot's strongest support in Michigan comes from men, young people 18 to 34 years of age and independents. Other surveys indicate that he is strongest in the Detroit surburbs, particularly the blue-collar areas where Reagan Democrats are concentrated.
 
'Enamored of the Messenger'
 In Macomb County, north of Detroit, which may be the nation's most closely studied electoral unit, Mr. Perot is on the march among voters who split in recent decades with the Democrats on racial and cultural issues but had seemed ready to "come home" with Governor Clinton. Leo R. Lalonde, the county Democratic chairman, said the Texas billionaire was now taking about a quarter of the vote there.
"A lot of people are enamored of the messenger," said Mr. Lalonde. "I'm just hoping that they'll leave him in droves when they come to grips with his tax plans and see how nutty the guy is."
But Clinton supporters here seem unsure, exactly, about how to cope with Mr. Perot and halt their candidate's slippage.
"Clearly, in Michigan a vote for Ross Perot is a vote for George Bush," said former Governor Blanchard, who was one of Mr. Clinton's earliest and most fervent backers. "But I'm not about to start saying that on the stump until Little Rock says to. I'm trying hard to be part of a national effort, not some local free-lance."


GRAPHIC: The fastest-growing Midwestern state between 1940 and 1965, Michigan has become one of the nation's most economically troubled. Although its politics have grown volatile in the years of adjustment to a contracting auto industry, only one of the 18 Congressional incumbents, Bob Carr, the Sixth District Democrat, is thought to be in trouble this year. In the Eleventh District, Robert W. Davis is retiring, and a fellow Republican, Philip Ruppe, seems like to win the seat.

HEADLINE: In the Battle Over Riverside South, the City Could Be the Winner

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
When the New York City Council considers Riverside South, Donald J. Trump's 57-acre mixed-use development project, on the Upper West Side, what is at stake is more than Mr. Trump's ambitions for the site. The project is an opportunity to look toward broader urban policy issues.
What if the tables were turned in the review process? What if this fiercely contested site, the target of heated debate for more than a generation, were given the opportunity to express its opinion about the way we plan and build cities? How would it rate us? 
 Not highly, in the opinion of a planning commissioner, Ronald Shiffman. On Monday, when Mr. Shiffman joined his fellow commissioners in approving Mr. Trump's plan for Riverside South, he praised the design, the civic groups who sponsored it, even the West Side residents who opposed it. But Mr. Shiffman also spoke pointedly of "the planning vacuum that unfortunately exists in New York City." The civic organizations, he said, had accomplished "what the city should have done years ago -- plan in the public interest."
Indeed, what is called for now is a shift in scrutiny: from Riverside South to city, state and Federal policies that govern urban development.
 
Focus for Debate
 "Riverside South is a partial glimpse of a public world at a time when there isn't a public world," said Linda Davidoff, chairman of the Parks Council, one of the private civic groups that joined with Mr. Trump almost two years ago to rework his earlier schemes for "Television City" and "Trump City." Ms. Davidoff's assessment is remarkably astute.
To judge Riverside South properly is to expose the vacuum that occupies the place where the public sector ought to be. This could turn out to be Riverside South's greatest contribution to New York.
Builders have had designs on the site for 30 years. Four of the designs were initiated by Mr. Trump. The West Side community, meanwhile, has pursued its own design: a well-organized, impassioned opposition that has helped to stall development. Still, the site, the former Penn Central railyards, has not stood totally idle. It has provided the focus for continuing public debate on virtually every issue of major importance to cities today. Urban design. Sustainable growth. Density. Affordable housing. Parks and public spaces. Transportation, sewage and other elements of urban infrastructure.
 
Collaboration and Hope
 Mr. Trump's agreement to join with the civic groups held out the hope that, at last, a developer would pay serious attention to these issues; that all those voices would be translated into urban design. The plan, prepared by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, with the architect Paul Willen, has made good on that promise.
A model of contextual design, Mr. Trump's plan promotes public access to the waterfront and to a new 21.5-acre public park on the site, which stretches along the Hudson River from 59th to 72d Streets.
 
Concessions to Public Desires
 The city's public review process, which began last May, has again provided an opportunity to air the issues. On each, Mr. Trump has made significant concessions to public desires: Sharply reduced density; a commitment to provide 20 percent below-market-rate housing, of which 12 percent will be subsidized by the developer if public money is not forthcoming, and redesign of the park by Thomas Balsley with a focus on recreation. Ten million dollars toward the renovation of the 72d Street subway station.
Each of his concessions has improved the project. They affirm the effectiveness of the public review process. And yet, somehow, the victory feels hollow. Each concession on Mr. Trump's part has pointed toward a far more intractable problem: the erosion of the public realm that has steadily worsened over the years.
What does it say about the state of urban policy that it takes such an enormous project -- virtually a small city -- to fix up one subway station? What does it say when it takes a luxury housing developer to create affordable housing?
 
Catalyst for Change
 It says this is a time when the vision and support required to build and maintain cities are at a historically low ebb. It is painful to talk about affordable housing when the prevailing will has been to dismantle public housing programs rather than to reinforce them. It is difficult to reckon with public transportation when there is insufficient will to divert government money from highways to mass transit.
Riverside South could help to change this. The project's size, long the focus of public opposition, could now prove to be its major asset. A project this big forces us to grasp that if, in one sense, the system worked with Riverside South, in a larger sense, a new system is needed.
Up to now, the debate on the Penn Yards site has pointed inward, applying pressure on Mr. Trump and his associates to improve the project's civic dimension. The pressure has been applied with success. But the real success will come with a broader debate: when the pressure that has been focused on these 57 acres is channeled toward each level of city, state and Federal government. It is at these levels that fundamental changes will be found in the way cities are perceived, designed, built and managed.

HEADLINE: Defending State's Jobs Is Priority, Dodd Maintains

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 27

 BODY:
Senator Christopher J. Dodd told labor and business groups today that his priority in a new term would be defending Connecticut jobs while working to restart the national economy.
Mr. Dodd, a Democrat seeking a third term, sharply criticized the Bush Administration for offering aid and trade concessions to Russia, China and Mexico while not acting to end the recession at home. 
 "I'm not going to sit here and tell you that Bill Clinton has a silver bullet that's going to solve all problems," Mr. Dodd told a meeting of union shop stewards in New Haven. "But I am going to tell you that Bill Clinton is going to have an agenda that puts America first."
President Bush twice vetoed the extension of unemployment benefits because of their cost, while asking for $12 billion in economic aid for the former Soviet Union, he said. "What many people in this state are asking is, 'How about an economic plan for the United States of America?" Mr. Dodd said. "We're not going to be any good to anybody unless we strengthen our own economy."
Later, at a Greater Norwalk Chamber of Commerce luncheon, Mr. Dodd said the Government must free tight lending policies that are preventing companies from obtaining working capital, and encourage investment in new manufacturing with tax credits and a capital-gains tax cut for specific industries.
He warned that Connecticut's delegation faces a hard fight defending the state's interests in the next Congress, when the expiration of the 1990 budget agreement will allow legislators to cut money from military spending and apply it to domestic programs. The debate over national health insurance is also of vital concern to the state's insurance industry.
"This state will be under tremendous pressure," Mr. Dodd told the chamber. "I promise there will be legislation by Jan. 3 aiming at us."
In both appearances today, Mr. Dodd focused on the economy while strongly advocating legislation supporting families and children.
Repeating a standard Dodd phrase, "the best social program ever invented is a job," he called for personal responsibility. "I don't say people have a right to engage in illegal or improper behavior because they don't have a job," he said. But he said the country must do more to create jobs, educate the children who will grow up to take them, and provide health care for everyone.
"My God, what kind of country are we living in," he said, "if you're a criminal and you have a right to a lawyer, but if you're sick you don't have a right to a doctor?"
 
Medicare and Medicaid Cuts
 Giving credit to Ross Perot, Mr. Dodd said he felt people were willing to talk seriously about the economic issues facing the country.
"My sense is people are saying, 'I want this to be a stronger country,' " he said. "People are saying, 'I'm willing to take a hit, as long as it's fair.' "
As he did in a series of debates with Mr. Johnson, Mr. Dodd said today that he would support cutting spending in two entitlement programs, Medicare and Medicaid.
He said that Medicare, the medical program for the elderly, should be subject to an income test so the country does not pay health insurance for the wealthy.
He also criticized the growing practice of elderly people giving their assets to relatives so Medicaid, the health-insurance program for the poor, will pay their nursing-home costs. "That is fraud," he said.

HEADLINE: Hard-Fought Race for Congress

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 26

 BODY:
For voters in the Fourth Congressional District in western Nassau County, one of the major issues this political season may come down to a question of definitions: what is an insider, what is an outsider and which would you rather send to Congress?
Both of the leading candidates, David A. Levy, a Nassau Republican strategist, and Phil Schiliro, a Democrat and veteran Congressional aide, are running their first campaigns for national office. Their backgrounds reflect the different paths to power for professional politicians in the 1990's. 
 Each has portrayed his opponent as the kind of political insider Nassau voters should avoid. Mr. Levy, with no Washington experience, is a product of the county's Republican Party organization, which many deride as a political machine. And Mr. Schiliro, with extensive experience in the Democratic establishment in Washington, has spent almost all his adult life living outside the district he now hopes to represent.
In Nassau County, long a bastion of Republican dominance, Mr. Schiliro has emerged as a scrappy challenger. He announced his candidacy earlier this year after the boundaries of the Fourth District were changed to include much of what had been the Fifth District, and Raymond J. McGrath, a Republican who had represented the Fifth District for five terms, said he would not run again.
Even with its new boundaries, the Fourth District remains a Republican stronghold. Registration figures show that the district has 147,000 Republicans, 87,000 Democrats and 52,000 independents.
Mr. Schiliro, a 36-year-old lawyer and native of Baldwin, L.I., has spent more than a decade honing his skills as a policy analyst and political adviser to Democrats in Congress.
He has taken a leave from his $100,000-a-year job as the top aide to Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat and chairman of the House Health and Environment Subcommittee. He has worked extensively on issues involving national policy on health care and the environment and now has the financial backing of several political action committees that share his interests.
But since leaving Long Island in 1978 to attend Lewis and Clark Law School in Oregon, he has never lived in the district he hopes to represent.
"He is passing through," said Mr. Levy, a member of the Hempstead Town Board and a veteran of Republican politics in the county. Other Republican Party loyalists here call Mr. Schiliro a "carpetbagger."
"No doubt Phil Schiliro is well-connected in the Washington establishment," Mr. Levy said. "But that estabishment is what we need to change."
No one could accuse Mr. Levy, 38, of straying far from Nassau County or its deeply entrenched Republican organization. Mr. Levy, a lawyer and former radio reporter, has been on the payroll of the county's Republican committee since 1984.
Mr. Levy makes $53,000 a year as a staff strategist and spokesman for the Nassau County Republican Committee. That is in addition to his $45,000 annual salary as a member of the Hemptstead Town Board.
"I have been in contact, day and night, with the people of this district," Mr. Levy said. "They know what they are getting when they vote for me."
 
'Political Viability'
 Still, it is precisely Mr. Levy's allegiance to the Nassau County Republican organization that Mr. Schiliro has attacked most vigorously. "He is a product of a machine that has ruined government in Nassau County," Mr. Schiliro said. "I've been fighting for things I believe in, and he has been trying to maintain political viability."
In a campaign with little radio and television advertising, both candidates have relied on direct mail and newspaper advertisements, as well as frequent visits to railroad stations and other personal appearances.
Mr. Schiliro's campaign has been far better financed, largely from sources outside the district. Mr. Waxman, the candidate's employer and mentor, has publicly requested that a host of political action groups, whose political interests are allied to health and environmental policy, send their checks to the Schiliro campaign.
Among the contributors to Mr. Schiliro are the Pro-Choice Political Action Committee, which supports abortion rights, the Kids Political Action Committee, which advocates greater Federal spending for children's health care, and the Sierra Club, the environmental group.
As of Oct. 14, disclosure forms submitted by the two candidates show campaign contributions of $257,500 to Mr. Schiliro, and $85,300 to Mr. Levy.
The candidates' positions on many issues are consistent with those of their parties but reflect the moderating influences of a wealthy, well-educated constituency. The district has traditionally voted for Republican candidates but has proved itself more liberal than the Republican Party mainstream on some social issues.
On abortion rights, Mr. Levy differs with many Republican candidates elsewhere by supporting unrestricted abortion during the first trimester of pregnancy. He opposes attempts to prohibit family planning clinics that receive Federal support from mentioning abortion. But he also opposes the use of Medicaid funds for abortion.
Mr. Shiliro, describing himself as ardently "pro-choice," supports the use of Medicaid funds for abortions.
He has courted backing from women, obtaining endorsements from Representative Patricia Schroeder, the Colorado Democrat; Barbara Boxer, Democratic candidate for the Senate from California, and others. He has also made Long Island's high incidence of breast cancer a cornerstone of his campaign and has called for liberalized Medicare rules to permit more frequent mammograms.
Mr. Levy says he too would support any increased commitment of Federal money for breast-cancer research and patient testing. But he says the economy is the top issue.
 
Economic Issues
 Perhaps more than in any recent election, economic issues -- the recession, wide job losses and the fiscal problems facing Nassau County -- seem to be on the minds of voters.
While neither candidate said he could provide quick fixes for Nassau, both said their national economic proposals would benefit workers here.
Mr. Levy, endorsing an amalgam of proposals made by President Bush and by Ross Perot, said his priorities include a reduction in capital-gains taxes and creating a $5,000 income-tax credit for first-time home buyers.
The economic incentives proposed by Mr. Schiliro are closer to those proposed by Gov. Bill Clinton. Mr. Schiliro said he supports more Federal investment in roads, bridges, mass transit and schools, increased Federal spending to help defense industry companies convert to making peacetime products, and new Federal programs to retrain workers.

HEADLINE: Abrams Tries to Tailor a Message for All Venues, Audiences and Moods

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
Ever the nervous student, Robert Abrams scanned a yellow legal pad moments before addressing a group of about 30 Democratic Party faithful on a recent afternoon. Scribbled at the top, a timeless reminder: "Say nice things about the party."
Great idea.
He did. Everyone clapped. On to the next stop. 
 Sometimes using charts and graphs, the New York State Attorney General stands before the cameras, his smudged glasses shining, his hands waving and his Bronx-tinged voice spinning tales of woe about Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's voting record, the state's poor economy and the many scandals that have swirled in the Senator's wake. Stop after stop, the words repeat in an endless loop, tailored to fit the venue, the audience and the mood.
 
The Standard Fare
 For weeks, his standard fare has droned on without providing him with an increase in the polls. Day after day, racing from one unlikely locale to another, Mr. Abrams pounds away, telling older people that their needs should be met, Jews that Israel is important, blacks that civil rights matter and hospital administrators that health care in New York is in a state of crisis. His messages are well framed and well meant.
 
Hitting His Stride
 He repeatedly attacks Mr. D'Amato's involvement in everything from lost Housing and Urban Development grants to lost jobs, the high cost of health insurance and threats to abortion rights. But as he moves toward the final stretch, he may have begun to hit his stride. Sunday, standing first before Local 3 of the Jewish Electrical Welfare Club in Flushing, Queens, and later before about 1,000 congregants at the First Baptist Church in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, Mr. Abrams suddenly hit a groove, winning passionate applause from audiences hungry for change in Washington and better prospects for their future.
At the Baptist church, he spoke of his fight against housing discrimination and his deeply held belief in civil rights. He condemned Mr. D'Amato for casting "the decisive vote" against the 1992 civil rights act and almost brought the congregation to its feet when he promised to "pay Al D'Amato back Nov. 3."
Even when he ran through his customary litany of the 500,000 jobs lost in New York State, the $117 billion sent to Washington never to return, and his complaint that New Yorkers have suffered from deep cuts in education, health care and other essentials, he seemed almost spontaneous.
"We've got news for this administration," he said, his voice rolling over a carpet of bowed and nodding heads. "They have turned their backs on us over these last 12 years and we are going to turn our backs on them this Nov. 3."
In closing, he leaned on his only laugh line. "Al D'Amato says he's bringing home the bacon," he said in a voice that tends to rise and fall like the tides. "But we know that's a lot of ba-low-ney! New York is hurting! New York is in pain! New York has lost more jobs than any state in the nation under the Bush-Quayle-D'Amato years."
Invariably, he invokes the Clinton-Gore-Abrams spirit, then goes a little glassy-eyed as he casts his mind forward to a hypothetical future and its "first 100 days." He can taste it.
 
Fund-Raising Troubles
 Now, caught in a tight race against an aggressive opponent, Mr. Abrams is finding that his predictability may have hurt, and that his overwhelming need to spend time out of the limelight raising money has left him in front, but only slightly so.
Faced with money problems and the need to whirl and counterpunch with every fresh attack staged by his deft, high-spending opponent, Mr. Abrams's own race still has far to go to reach victory. His latest move has been to release a harsh advertisement attacking Mr. D'Amato with the frequency and some of the same ferocity that has been turned on him. That may move him away from a once-a-day stealth campaign that has worried his supporters and left the incumbent Senator grabbing most of the attention.
Even when Mr. Abrams has taken to the stump, one tends to wonder where in the world did everybody else go? Unless his campaign staff hitches his wagon to someone else's, he usually holds forth before several dozen potential supporters, a supportive United States Senator (if he's lucky -- two) or simply a couple of rumpled television and newspaper reporters who peer at him against a backdrop full of supposed symbolic impact. At those stagy news conferences, Mr. Abrams's tones roll like those of a new-age preacher stuck with out-of-date oratory.
Those appearances, intended to reach the masses via the few, have often been obscured by both bad luck and poor preparation. Monday, at a news conference held to decry New York's crumbling infrastructure and Senator D'Amato's supposed disregard for New York state, Mr. Abrams stood with Senator Bill Bradley near Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and 42d Street. The roar of adjacent traffic nearly drowned out their statements. But a more incredible detail was purely visual. The stretch of highway that Mr. Abrams's advance team picked looked freshly painted and remarkably secure.
 
His Worst Moment
 There have been other pratfalls. At a stop in Cortland on Oct. 11, one supposed supporter conceded that he came only because his boss told him the Attorney General "needed warm bodies."
But the worst moment may have come last week when Mr. Abrams stood outside Bellevue Hospital Center flanked by Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa and Harris Wofford of Pennsylvania. As the men tried to talk about the urgent need for a national health insurance program they were repeatedly interrupted by a man shouting: "Help for the homeless!" Reporters, meanwhile, could not help noting the pervasive stench of urine and that the three politicians were huddled beneath a sign pointing to the hospital's psychiatric ward.
Mr. D'Amato's team, meanwhile, has pressed every advantage. During a campaign swing upstate several weeks ago, the Senator's supporters heckled an Abrams rally and managed to so thoroughly unnerve the Attorney General that he later called the Senator a "fascist," a term he afterward attributed to anger. Days later, he apologized. Now, Senator D'Amato's allies have a new technique. They sometimes appear early at Mr. Abrams's news conferences and hand out counter-spin photocopies that undercut the Attorney General's statements.
Once past such technical and human glitches, Mr. Abrams lays out rehearsed speech chunks that are more compelling in the abstract than in person. Even his supporters lament that while they admire his stand and his record on such issues as national health care, job protection and abortion rights, his style is something short of galvanizing. His wife, Diane, is considered a more compelling speaker on abortion, though Mr. Abrams has been an aggressive defendant of abortion rights throughout his long public career.
Day by day his staff has usually seemed unsure of what was coming. A charitable assessment would be that the campaign is fluid and always ready to react. Some leading New York politicians say, instead, that it is floundering. "I don't know," said the assistant to one visiting senator. "It just seems, well, disjointed."
 
A Slow Start
 Ethan Geto, Mr. Abrams's campaign director, admits to a slow start. "We decided to take the pain in the first couple of weeks," he said, explaining that there was neither the time nor the money to get the campaign message out more broadly. Other campaign staffers complain that some events Mr. Abrams has attended simply turned out to be smaller or less dynamic than they had hoped. For the most part, though, the result has been rather like a concert in an empty hall.
Pinned by the need to raise money and thwarted by the fickleness of news, the race for the Senate is the furthest Mr. Abrams has ever moved from his roots as a young candidate for the State Legislature who stood outside Bronx subway stations shouting out his name and grabbing the hands of anyone who passed. But some of that spirit lingers.
Even through the rain and the stench, the hecklers and the drone of traffic, Mr. Abrams mostly keeps his calm. Bounding out of a rented car, he extends one hand for a handshake, the other for a pat on the back. "Hey!" he booms. "Bob Abrams. Help me out! Your vote is my luck."
Some people take his hand and return his pat on the back with words of encouragement and the promise of a vote. Others sometimes take a moment to criticize him for the negativity of the primary and the mudslinging of recent weeks.
The comments freeze his smile. "Hey," he shrugged uncomfortably when challenged during a "drop and stop" in Brooklyn. "When you're attacked, you have to defend yourself."
At those moments, his smile fades and he flushes from the collar of his shirt to the top of his head. Then he looks around for a friendlier face and moves, magnetized, toward the potential of another Democratic lever dropping. Urged on in his bumpy race, his smile breaks out again and sometimes he almost looks happy.

HEADLINE: Far From the Governor's Office, but Not From Politics

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADISON, N.J.

 BODY:
With handicapping for a Democratic Presidential cabinet already under way, a name that pops up on some lists belongs to a Republican, Thomas H. Kean.
Mr. Kean, the former Governor of New Jersey and now president of Drew University, also happens to be chairman of President Bush's re-election effort in New Jersey, but some analysts think he could become Secretary of Education if his old buddy, Gov. Bill Clinton, is elected President. 
 His inclusion on such lists attests to Mr. Kean's reputation as an educational innovator. Under him, New Jersey became the first state to allow professionals without the usual certification to become public school teachers. It also attests to his unusual ability to handle issues without necessarily bowing to partisan politics.
At the same time his continued involvement with the world of politics, even while serving as president of a liberal arts college, makes some of his faculty and students uneasy. Many people on campus are asking whether Drew is merely a way station on Mr. Kean's path to higher political office.
"We have no delusions about Kean giving up his political life for that of a university administrator," said a recent editorial in The Acorn, the weekly student newspaper, "but we would like to think that during his tenure here, however brief, Kean would act more like a president, and less like a governor."
 
No 'Political Eunuch'
 Typically, Mr. Kean says he understands those concerns but will go his own way and take the consequences. "You can't expect someone to become a political eunuch just because he's president of a university," he said on a recent walk across the leafy Drew campus in Madison. "You've got to take on controversy from time to time. You've got to do things that people disagree with."
To most college presidents, partisan politics is laced with trouble; someone not as affable in character or moderate in politics as Mr. Kean might not be able to pull off such a double role. But three years ago Drew's trustees took a chance on him, hoping his record of education reforms, and his large circle of friends, would help revive the 125-year-old university, which has 2,100 students on its campus, about 20 miles from Newark.
By most counts, Mr. Kean has given Drew a higher profile. Applications, student test scores and overall donations are up.
"He's great for us because of the p.r. factor," said Thomas G. Ward, a senior political science major from Parsippany who is enrolled in Mr. Kean's seminar, titled "Governing a State."
 
Kean's 'Terrific Drawback'
 Before Drew appointed him its 10th president, Mr. Kean, who is 57 years old, had no experience running a university. He has a bachelor's degree in history from Princeton and a master's degree in history and education from Columbia, but no Ph.D.; his teaching experience amounts to the two and a half years he taught history at St. Mark's Preparatory School in Southborough, Mass., where he had been a student.
"His lack of qualifications and experience as a scholar has been a terrific drawback," said Rosalind S. Seneca, a professor of economics at Drew and one of Mr. Kean's most ardent critics. "He wants to run the university as though it were a corporation or a political organization. He sees everything in terms of constituencies and wants to maintain control."
But in his penny loafers and blue blazer, Mr. Kean looks the part of a college president. And his resume includes 10 years as a legislator and eight years as chief executive of one of the nation's most complicated states.
During that time education was one of his chief concerns. Along with Governor Clinton, he was one of the prime movers at the National Governors' Association's Conference on Education in 1989.
Among Mr. Kean's most significant educational innovations in New Jersey was the alternate route program, which makes it possible for any college graduate to become a public school teacher, bypassing standard teacher's certification requirements. New Jersey also issued its first state report cards for school districts during his administration, adopted statewide proficiency standards for students and substantially raised starting salaries for teachers.
Mr. Kean said many of the principles he followed in Trenton apply to running a university.
"Someone asked me the other day to compare the two jobs, and I said that they are basically the same thing," Mr. Kean said. "I still have to deal with constituency groups with a lot of their own interests, and I'm still working with a whole bunch of people I can't fire."
Because he can appeal to people across the spectrum, Mr. Kean has become a valuable adviser to President Bush. Last summer, Mr. Bush invited Mr. Kean to a lunch at the White House with Secretary of Education Lamar Alexander, who is also a former governor and university president; Benno C. Schmidt Jr., who had just quit as president of Yale to start a national system of private schools for Whittle Communications, and Christopher Whittle, that company's president.
Mr. Kean said Mr. Bush was worried that the Whittle effort would interfere with the Government's New American Schools Development Corporation, a school reform effort that Mr. Kean heads. Mr. Kean said that what the Whittle group was proposing were "models for what might be done with less money to educate kids better."
"If they're able to do that, a lot of public schools, in order to compete, would start making some of these changes also," he said.
 
Changes at Drew
 After he left the Governor's office, Mr. Kean said, he had offers from a number of universities but picked the $125,000-a-year position at Drew because, he said, he wanted to establish a national model of higher education and felt he could have more influence in less time at a small institution. Drew is also a 20-minute drive from his home.
He wasted no time making his mark. He replaced most of the university's top officials and brought in several from state government.
Soon after Mr. Kean arrived donors gave the university $2 million, which he used to start a scholarship program for minority students. He also revived an idea he had embraced while Governor: He has made teaching count for half of promotion decisions and started a $10,000 annual teaching award -- one of the largest in the country -- that is Drew's version of a master teacher program.
His first battle over budget cuts, in 1990, was stormy, with students and faculty members picketing outside President's Hall. "People didn't have very much confidence in him," said Gabriel K. O'Hare, a senior from Claremont, Calif., who is president of Drew's Student Government Association.
That confrontation taught Mr. Kean a little about university politics and the value of building a consensus. He named students and faculty to budget committees and made Drew one of the first universities in the nation to put its proposed budget on a computerized electronic mail network, accessible to all.
Almost from the day Mr. Kean arrived at Drew, there have been rumors he will leave to run for United States Senate, or for governor again. He is said to have turned down appointments in the Bush Administration, and now he is amused by talk of his part in a Clinton cabinet.
"I have never made a commitment that I won't go someplace else at some point," he said. He said he's been offered positions in both the public and private sectors. The answer, he said, is always the same.
"What I tell them is that I have an obligation here and I'm enjoying myself," leaving anything more unsaid.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas H. Kean, the former governor of New Jersey, straddles two worlds, one old and the other new. From his President's office at Drew University in Madison, N.J., he finds that politics still makes a claim on his time. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)
