HEADLINE: Mayoralty Of Elizabeth Is Entering A New Era

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 27

 BODY:
It's hard for J. Christian Bollwage, a Democratic councilman since 1983, to see how he could lose the campaign to be this city's next mayor. Even his sole rival seems inclined to agree.
"I now know what it's like to be David fighting Goliath," said the Republican candidate, James W. Dembeck. "The G.O.P. has no money. When they asked me to run, I was under the impression that they had leadership, organization and money. It's really a biweekly kaffeeklatsch." 
 Make no mistake: Mr. Dembeck, a 62-year-old former planning board chairman who unsuccessfully sought a council seat in 1959 and the mayoralty in 1976, is still very much engaged. He attends rallies and community meetings, though his work as an accident investigator prevents him from spending much time going door to door. His platform calls for term limits on all elected officials, more efficiency in city departments, new downtown development and a crackdown on crime and drugs.
 
Big Edge for Democrats
 But the reality is this: Elizabeth has 21,000 registered Democrats, 3,500 Republicans and 13,000 independents, and the 38-year-old Mr. Bollwage (pronounced BOWL-wage) has the momentum, the money and the new-found political clout to do some of the things that Mr. Dembeck can only talk about. In June the councilman defeated Mayor Thomas G. Dunn in a primary election that ended Mr. Dunn's 27-year grip on City Hall and left Mr. Bollwage the undisputed party leader and front-runner for the $61,000-a-year post.
Mayor Dunn has stayed out of the campaign. "I made it very plain that if Bollwage wanted my support, I'd be willing to give it to him, but only upon invitation," Mr. Dunn said. "For some strange reason he has continued his attacks on me after the primary, so evidently he is not going to ask for my support. I don't want to go where I'm not wanted."
Ordinarily, the novelty of a campaign without Mr. Dunn would have been more noticeable. But for the first time in 200 years, the city is without its main source of local news, The Daily Journal, which closed in January, its local advertising base gone. Both candidates say the loss has made it tougher for them to get their message to the city's 110,000 residents. They have relied instead on a weekly newspaper, The City News, and debates on a local cable television station, the second of which will air on Wednesday night.
Next Tuesday's outcome aside, the candidates generally agree that Elizabeth, the state's fourth-largest city, needs an overhaul. They also agree that crime and drugs are problems that must be tackled strenuously, though they differ on how to staff the police department and how much to spend. Mayor Dunn, they say, overstayed his welcome, having failed to involve waves of new immigrants, many of them Hispanic, in his government -- a government that did not seize opportunities for seed money and renewal in the late 1980's.
 
Post-Election Plans
 Now, with a clear field and the likely company of at least seven allies on the the nine-member City Council, Mr. Bollwage has begun to outline his post-election plans.
In a program he calls "Neighborhoods for the 90's," Mr. Bollwage says he hopes to create from existing city agencies a new Neighborhood Services Department as a kind of SWAT team for renewal.
"We would have the police move into the four or five areas in the city where there are open-air drug markets, remove the dealers or push them elsewhere," he said. "But we wouldn't stop there."
Mr. Bollwage envisions sending social workers, teachers, builders and a permanent police presence to each of these neighborhoods in an attempt to restore confidence, commerce and social stability. He hopes to add 10 officers to the force in each of the next four years.
 
Downtown Development
 He also wants to begin the long-stalled effort to revitalize a three-acre chunk of downtown Elizabeth, which has been little more than a parking lot for 20 years. The Council has approved a plan for commercial and residential development, but it will be up to the new administration to see it through as well as to try to reap more revenue from the city's seaport, particularly from land owned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
Mr. Dembeck believes a Bollwage mayoralty will be profligate with tax dollars, and on a political level he is incensed by Mr. Bollwage's apparent assumption that the mayoralty is already his.
"He's part of the problem," said Mr. Dembeck. "He's been part of the administration for years, and all of a sudden he's asking people, 'What's the problem?' "
Mr. Bollwage, who has worked in sales, marketing and public relations, rejects the criticism. He said he looked forward to "talking about the positives of this city in a global market."

HEADLINE: Sauce Makers Smile At the Rage for Pasta

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
AMERICANS eat more than four billion pounds of pasta a year. And they're not eating it plain.
Despite the nostalgic image of Grandma in her apron tending a pot of simmering sauce for hours, what's sauce for pasta nowadays usually comes in a jar. Since the pasta industry is still ballooning, with annual consumption having doubled since 1975, it continues to pull the sauce business along with it. Supermarkets and groceries are scrambling to find enough shelves for all the sauces. 
 "In the past a meal of pasta was considered Italian, but now it's become American," said John Gennari, the marketing manager for Ragu Foods, which was started in a Rochester kitchen in 1937 by two Italian immigrants, Giovanni and Assunta Cantisano.
Ragu became the first nationally distributed brand of pasta sauce after it was acquired by Chesebrough-Pond's in 1969. Now a subsidiary of the multinational giant Unilever, it has a 40 percent share of the market, making it the leading brand. Its closest competitor is Prego, made by the Campbell Soup Company, with a 26 percent share.
After they sold Ragu, the Cantisanos did not retire from the spaghetti-sauce business. They now make Francesco Rinaldi products in Rochester, and their son, Ralph, is the company's chairman.
Starting in the mid-1970's, sales of pasta sauces grew by about 20 percent a year, creating what is now a $1.2 billion industry. While annual increases have dropped to the single digits for most big commercial brands, the growth is expected to continue. The producers of pasta sauce, both large and small, happily continue to increase their orders for tomato paste or canned California tomatoes from year to year.
Mr. Gennari said more new pasta sauces have been introduced this year than in any of the 14 previous years he has been in the business. "Many of them are by significant companies," he said, citing Hunt, which has expanded its line of sauces, and Campbell, which introduced the Healthy Request line of canned sauces this year. Del Monte Foods, the country's leading vegetable processor, is about to come out with a line of pasta sauces.
At the same time, there still seems to be room for fledgling companies with humble beginnings and a family recipe, like the Cantisanos of Ragu. For example, in 1985 Frank Dell'Amore could no longer keep up with customers' requests to buy the homemade tomato sauce that he was serving in his pizzeria, Filomena's, in Burlington, Vt. So he began commercially bottling the sauce, which is based on his grandmother's recipe.
In the last year Dell'Amore Enterprises has sold $300,000 worth of sauce in jars bearing a wistful photograph of Mr. Dell'Amore's grandmother, Filomena d'Agosto, when she was 19 years old. Those sales were 30 percent higher than the previous year and meant peeling more than 300 pounds of garlic a month by hand. The distribution area of the sauce has expanded from the Burlington area to the entire Northeast and beyond.
Because it takes time to peel garlic and cook tomatoes, many people prefer opening a jar of prepared sauce to starting from scratch. Even though Campbell reported that 60 percent of the time, consumers add ingredients instead of using the sauce direct from the jar, it takes less time to add some seasonings than to cook a pot of tomatoes, even canned ones.
Convenience aside, it does not require a Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science or a Nobel Prize in Medicine to understand that pasta topped with sauce provides, at modest expense, a filling meal that is longer on carbohydrates than fat. Consumers have long known that spaghetti with tomato sauce is one of the cheapest mealtime options. Lately, they have also realized it's healthy.
While many commercial pasta sauces derive around 50 percent of their calories from fat, once the portion of pasta is factored in, the total drops to 25 percent or less. "Last year we reduced the oil so that only 30 percent of the calories in Prego sauces come from fat," said Marsha Cade, the director of corporate communications for Campbell. "And we are looking at even lower levels with any new products we introduce." Mr. Gennari said Ragu's research showed that about 19 percent of consumers want a sauce that specifically addresses health concerns.
In style and flavor, the pasta sauces lining store shelves these days offer something for everyone. And just as the almost endless growth of pasta flavors shows no sign of winding down, there is no indication that the saturation point has been reached when it comes to sauce flavors.
Routine tomato, meat and mushroom sauces have been joined by garden vegetable, pesto, walnut, creamy Alfredo, four-cheese, puttanesca, roasted pepper and primavera, to name a few. Ragu alone has two dozen flavors grouped in six different styles, with more to come.
Until the 1980's, commercial spaghetti sauces were smooth, with a uniform texture usually made by diluting tomato paste with water. But then they began appearing in a chunkier style, with pieces of whole tomato. The smooth consistency more closely imitated sauce that had simmered for hours, while the chunky style seemed fresher. Extra-thick is another variety of sauce now on the market.
Celebrities including Paul Newman, Frank Sinatra and Tommy Lasorda also have their faces on jars of spaghetti sauce.
In recent years some companies, like Progresso, have added lines of more expensive sauces with distinctive ingredients and stylish packaging to complement the standard, old-fashioned kind. The Classico brand, packed in canning jars and now sold nationally by Borden, is another example of fancier pasta sauce.
Most of the old-fashioned commercial pasta sauces are sweetened, usually with corn syrup, to mellow the often harsh or bitter flavor of tomato paste. With the current trend toward a fresher style using whole tomatoes, many brands have now eliminated the sweeteners.
In a sampling of sauces in just one category -- marinara -- the range of flavors and the variety of ingredients were astonishing. The sampling encompassed 16 brands, covering many of the biggest producers and some small ones. Although many sauces labeled tomato or tomato and garlic are essentially the same as the marinara sauces, these were not included.
The term marinara has undergone an evolution. In Italian it simply means "of the sea," or fisherman style. In fact, the authoritative Italian cookbooks, by writers like Giuliano Bugialli and Marcella Hazan, don't even mention marinara sauce.
In his book "Eat Right, Eat Well, the Italian Way" (Alfred A. Knopf, 1985), Edward Giobbi included a recipe for marinara sauce made with tomatoes, basil, garlic, carrots, onion and oil. "I have never seen this sauce printed in an Italian cookbook," he said.
As they are understood today, marinara sauces are tomato-based and meatless. "In talking with members of my family, it seems that Italian immigrants began using the term marinara to describe a sauce that was meatless, to serve on Fridays, but not necessarily with fish in it," Mr. Dell'Amore said. "In the old days it may have been the sauce that people cooked clams or squid in, and some people also put anchovies in it."
Contadina, the leading maker of refrigerated sauce, has anchovies in its marinara sauce. "It's of the sea," said Dawn Caldwell, the brand manager. "Ours is the most authentic marinara sauce."
But authenticity may be beside the point, now that manufacturers of salsas, salad dressings and Asian seasonings have gone into the pasta-sauce business. Roasted chili, Southwestern black bean, creole, Thai peanut and other non-Italian sauces are now appearing.
If pasta consumption increases in this country as much as expected by the end of the decade -- something like 50 percent -- it seems that the sauce makers will keep right in step. As long as they keep peeling that garlic.
Not All Sauces Grow in Cans
 
Marinara Sauce
Adapted from "We Called It Macaroni" by Nancy Verde Barr (Alfred A. Knopf, 1990)
Total time: 50 minutes
 
 1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil
2 small cloves garlic, minced
4 1/2 cups peeled, seeded and chopped fresh plum tomatoes, or drained canned plum tomatoes
Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
2 tablespoons minced fresh basil.
 1. Gently heat the oil and garlic in a heavy saucepan and cook just until the garlic is golden. Remove from heat.
2. Chop the tomatoes very fine by hand, or in a food processor or a blender. Add them to the pan and season with salt and pepper. Simmer about 30 minutes, until the sauce is reduced somewhat and the oil separates from the tomatoes. The sauce should be thick enough to hold its shape on a spoon.
3. Stir in the basil, check seasonings, and cook 5 minutes longer.
Yield: 3 1/2 cups (about 6 servings).
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 115 calories, 10 grams fat, no cholesterol, 25 milligrams sodium (before salting), 2 grams protein, 8 grams carbohydrate.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
The Private Budget Deficit of America's Families

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:
The Forgotten Americans
By John E. Schwarz and Thomas J. Volgy
219 pages. W. W. Norton. $19.95.
Right up to the eve of the Presidential election, the key word in the campaign has been jobs: keeping them and creating them. But something much deeper runs through "The Forgotten Americans," a timely book that goes to the heart of the changing work ethos in the United States. Its important revelations promise to challenge the conscience of Washington for a very long time. 
 In "The Forgotten Americans," John E. Schwarz and Thomas J. Volgy, political science professors at the University of Arizona, follow the trailblazing path of Michael Harrington's "Other America," a book that helped to spur the war against poverty during the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations. In that landmark study, Mr. Harrington wrote: "The other America, the America of poverty, is hidden today in a way that it never was before. Its millions are socially invisible to the rest of us."
While not as hortatory as the Harrington book, "The Forgotten Americans" is even more telling three decades later because it includes members of the middle class as well as the recognizable poor. For what Professors Schwarz and Volgy emphasize in their book is that "America may not be the land of opportunity it claims to be, not even for people who are diligent, responsible workers."
Something's amiss in the American dream, the authors say, when tens of millions of people work hard, sometimes hold down two jobs, put in long hours of overtime (wives as well as husbands in many two-income families), yet cannot afford the basic necessities of food, housing, clothing and medical care. Taking the family out to dinner? Going to the movies? These are luxuries possible a few times a year, if at all.
The real people whose lives are described through interviews in "The Forgotten Americans" don't sound as if they are much concerned about the Federal deficit. They leave the impression that the billion-dollar numbers are for the big boys in government to worry about. What's foremost on their minds is their own home deficit.
In addition to case histories that help to humanize "The Forgotten Americans," Professors Schwarz and Volgy (a former Mayor of Tucson, Ariz.) support their findings with statistics drawn from census figures, tax records, nutrition information from the Agriculture Department, employment records from the Labor Department, and housing and education surveys by government and industry. The hard numbers in "The Forgotten Americans" add up to a devastating portrait: of families outwardly prosperous -- owning a car, a small house or apartment, a television set, electrical appliances -- but below the surface, struggling to keep up with the Joneses, who are broke, too.
The authors cite the Federal Government's conflicting figures. The poverty line for a family of four is $13,360 a year according to the Census Bureau and $15,323 a year according to the Department of Labor. But just to cover bare necessities, a truer figure for the family's annual budget is $20,700, and even that doesn't provide for a decent level of existence. Nearly 30 million people fall into the authors' description of Americans who have been left behind by the faltering economy. Some are now categorized as the "new poor": middle-class citizens who have lost their jobs and must turn to charity for food, clothing and housing.
Whether a family is ranked as poor or lower middle class, what is it like to live on a minimal budget?
The authors say: "Members of families existing on the economy budget never go out to eat, for it is not included in the food budget; they never go out to a movie, concert or ball game or indeed to any public or private establishment that charges admission, for there is no entertainment budget; they have no cable television, for the same reason; they never purchase alcohol or cigarettes; never take a vacation or holiday that involves any motel or hotel or, again, any meals out." And, of course, there's no leeway to buy books, including this one that explains their plight.
"The Forgotten Americans" is better at clarifying the problems of the visible and invisible poor than at providing strong solutions. That puts the authors in the same boat as the Presidential candidates. Nevertheless, Professors Schwarz and Volgy do offer some specifics: A moderate increase in the minimum wage (from $4.25 to $4.85 an hour), coupled with some type of income supplement; an expansion of special tax credits for fully employed workers, and affordable health insurance for workers who don't have any.
The book's main achievement is to show that it is possible for tens of millions of Americans to believe in the work ethic, do their best on the job and still not quite make it in the land of opportunity. In this respect, the conclusions in "The Forgotten Americans" fly in the face of those who have cosmeticized the true state of the economy during the Presidential campaign.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Skandia Reinsurance Cuts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The troubled reinsurer Skandia American Reinsurance Corporation is redirecting its business focus and will cut its premium volume in certain areas, moves that are likely to result in layoffs.
Skandia, the eighth-largest reinsurer in the nation and a unit of Sweden's Skandia Group Insurance Company, said on Monday that its parent company's capital position had been eroded by "economic turmoil in Europe and Scandinavia with increased interest rates, declining real estate values and ailing stock markets." 
 The company said it would focus on casualty treaty and casualty facultative business. Treaty reinsurance involves covering multiple risks within one category, like fire coverage. Facultative reinsurance involves covering a single risk or event, like the Super Bowl.
Rumors have been circulating for weeks that Skandia, which employs about 350 people in the United States, would announce layoffs. A Skandia spokeswoman, Susan Young, said the "implication is that the organization will be tailored to meet the reduced level of volume."
She said the company is still "formulating its implementation plans."
Last week the company rejected a $500 million takeover bid from John Head & Partners, a New York-based investment partnership. Skandia gave no reason for turning down the bid.

HEADLINE: Business Technology;
Seeking Concrete's Cause of Death

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 22

 BODY:
Mauro J. Scali stared suspiciously at the image on his video screen. It looked like a well-marbled block of pate, but was actually a magnified view of a concrete sample sawed a few days earlier from a defective slab outside a warehouse in Virginia.
"I'd rather not say exactly where," said Mr. Scali, whose work as a coroner of concrete requires considerable discretion -- and the occasional legal deposition. He would not identify the client, either, but his samples usually come from the ready-mix supplier or the contractor, often arriving by overnight mail and sometimes by anxious courier. 
 Whether this sample would lead to a lawsuit was not clear, but it was obvious to Mr. Scali why the top half-inch of concrete had begun peeling off soon after the concrete was poured, leaving a rough surface. No bubbles were visible in the uppermost layer, he said, a clue that workmen had troweled the upper surface too early, before it had time to partly set, making it weaker.
 
 
New Focus on What's Underfoot
 As a topic, concrete may seem as pedestrian as the sidewalks underfoot. But the technology is gaining new attention in light of the public-policy focus on infrastructure, which in many cases is no more than a fancy term for concrete.
Mr. Scali, who runs part of a concrete-analysis laboratory here operated by W. R. Grace & Company, is a petrographer, a profession that derives its name from the Greek roots for "rock" and "record." His work seems far removed from the messy world of concrete, a business in which the product moves from big, messy plants into big, messy trucks and then to big, messy construction sites.
Far from the madding slop, Mr. Scali's labors are clean and precise, employing tools like electron microscopes, computer-driven infrared spectrometers, and even equipment for preparing concrete specimens half the thickness of a human hair, for examination under a microscope. There are also experiments with unexpected materials, from corn syrup and soaps to plastics.
Concrete -- whose basic ingredients are cement, sand, gravel and water -- is a material seldom noted for innovation. The industry is understandably conservative, because whatever errors it makes are literally set in stone, causing problems for years. But it is the job of Mr. Scali, along with others in the lab, to try out new formulas developed by the company's researchers. It is also his duty to conduct post-mortems on concrete that has met a premature demise.
In seeking the cause of the fault in the Virginia slab, Mr. Scali noted that the workers might have had a legitimate excuse. The lower portion of the sample showed excessive air bubbles, and when concrete is made with too much air, it bleeds out excess water only very slowly and can cause the surface to begin drying too soon. When the surface of the slab dried early, because of retarded bleeding, the workers probably concluded that it was ready to be troweled -- creating the fatal flaw.
W. R. Grace is one of two big concerns in the concrete additive business; the other is Master Builders Inc. of Cleveland, a subsidiary of Sandoz Chemical Ltd. A number of companies play smaller roles.
In public works, like roads and bridges, the biggest issue is corrosion, not of the concrete, but of the steel reinforcing bar, an essential ingredient that has vastly increased the usefulness of concrete.
The problem is that even well-mixed, well-poured concrete is porous. Road salt, which came into widespread use in the early 1960's, gradually sinks in, as does sea water in coastal locations. When salt corrodes steel, the rust that results occupies four times the volume of the steel it replaces, and breaks the surrounding concrete.
Road salt has been in wide use since the early 1960's, but there is no consensus yet on the antidote. Grace's approach, which it has been testing since the 1970's, is a calcium nitrite solution that it makes and that is added to concrete as it is made. The additive helps keep a patina of oxidized material on the steel-reinforcing bar that prevents deeper corrosion. Testing formulations, Grace keeps hundreds of bars, each in a concrete cylinder, soaking in warm basins of salty water for years.
The laboratory here tortures concrete in other ways, in chambers that alternately freeze and thaw the concrete in damp conditions, and others in which workers try to set concrete at 20 or 100 degrees Fahrenheit, at varying levels of humidity. The building, incongruously, is faced in corrugated steel; executives said Grace preferred to spend its money on personnel and equipment than on fancy quarters for petrography and testing.
 
 
Coating Bars With Epoxy
 Additives like those made by Grace and Sandoz are not the most frequently used technique in the struggle against corrosion. The leading approach, one favored by the steel industry, is to coat the reinforcing bars with epoxy. But Grace and other proponents of additives say that installing such bars without damaging the epoxy, by nicking the coating or bending the bars, is impossible.
But the epoxy proponents have an advantage, acknowledged Thomas G. Weil, a product manager at Grace. "It's very simple," he said. "You can see it. There it is." In contrast, anti-corrosion additives do not change the appearance of concrete. Design engineers make the decision, he said, and most of them have had no chemistry lessons since college.
The Concrete Reinforcing Steel Institute, a trade association in Schaumburg, Ill., recently hired a consultant to prepare a report showing the superiority of epoxy, then sued him in Federal court when his report said that the epoxy could not protect the reinforcing bars for as long as it was supposed to.
The two methods are not mutually exclusive. John Mullarky, first vice president of the National Ready-Mixed Concrete Association, said many builders use epoxy on the reinforcing bars and add anticorrosives to the concrete. "We have a lot of belt-and-suspenders people in the industry," he said. "They'll do everything."
 
 
Stronger and Denser
 Another approach to slowing corrosion is to make the concrete denser, a technique that also makes concrete stronger. Grace is one of several manufacturers of additives to do so, changing the way concrete has historically been mixed.
The chemical reaction by which concrete forms, absorbing hydrogen and forming very strong crystals, requires 30 pounds of water per 100 pounds of cement, but typically much more is added, to assure that all of the cement comes in contact with water, and to keep the concrete soft long enough to spread it into the forms. The problem is that when the concrete is hard, some of the extra water, called water of convenience, remains, and as it dries it leaves voids.
Grace and others make additives to facilitate mixing, so that the water-to-cement level can be closer to the optimum. They also use additives to retard the hardening process. These include corn syrup and molasses.
But this still leaves a substantial amount of empty space in the concrete. In concrete used outdoors, some empty space is essential, to leave voids that ice will fill as it expands from water. But it makes the concrete too weak to be a replacement for structural steel. So users of concrete have turned to other additives, like silica. Grace makes one that is 100 times smaller than concrete grains, to fill up the space between the grains.
 
 
Concrete Skeleton
 As a result, newer buildings have been constructed using concrete with a strength of 20,000 pounds a square inch; the typical compression strength a decade ago was 5,000 pounds a square inch. Turner Construction built a 56-story office building, 2 Union Square in Seattle, using such concrete, substituting steel-reinforced concrete for a steel skeleton. The project manager, Marvin D. Doster, said that still stronger concretes are on the horizon.
Mr. Mullarky, of the ready-mixed concrete association, said the competition with steel in the construction business is muted now because the recession has so curtailed new building. But progress in concrete, he said, "has already driven the steel industry to talk about making stronger steel."
Mr. Scali, for his part, said his lab's goal was to make concrete long-lasting and predictable, so people will think better of it -- "if they think of it at all."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Has Mixed Session, Interrupting Recent Rally

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against major currencies yesterday in a pause in its upward climb of recent days.
Gold fell. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery dropped $3.70 an ounce, to $337.40. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $337.25, down $3.25 from Monday. 
 Andrew Hodge, a vice president at Bank Brussels Lambert, said the dollar's climb was stopped temporarily because "it's had about all the run it could take."
"It's played itself out on a temporary basis," Mr. Hodge added. "It's going to go higher, but not today."
He said the dollar did not react to economic news reported during the trading day. The Conference Board's consumer confidence index fell to an eight-month low in October and the gross domestic product showed a stronger-than-expected 2.7 percent growth rate in the July-September quarter.
"The market couldn't do anything with that today," Mr. Hodge said, adding that the dollar's slide against the German mark was a correction "that was more than warranted."
"We just had a countertrend the day before we resume the climb in the dollar," he said.
In New York, the dollar rose to a closing 122.15 Japanese yen, up from 121.85 late Monday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 122.28 Japanese yen from 121.62 yen at Monday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 122.45 yen.
The British pound fell in New York to $1.5775 from $1.5842 late Monday. In London, it fell to $1.5845 from $1.5855 late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Monday, included 1.5285 German marks, down from 1.5305; 1.3595 Swiss francs, down from 1.3645; 5.1860 French francs, down from 5.1900; 1,327 Italian lire, up from 1,320.5, and 1.23605 Canadian dollars, down from 1.24375.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Xerox Reports 3d-Period Net Advanced 12%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 27

 BODY:
The Xerox Corporation reported that third-quarter net income rose 12 percent on sales of new products, including the Docutech Publishing Series and a color copier.
Net income at the business-machines and financial-services company climbed to $135 million, or $1.18 a share, from $121 million, or $1.06 a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue rose 4.9 percent, to $4.49 billion from $4.28 billion. 
 Xerox's profits lagged behind the mean estimate of $1.35 a share in a Zacks Investment Research survey of seven analysts. Its stock fell $2.25 yesterday, to $76, in New York Stock Exchange composite trading.
 
Focusing Financial Services
 Paul Allaire, chairman and chief executive, said Xerox's document-processing strategy and product-introduction schedule met with "excellent customer reception" despite difficult economic conditions in the United States, Europe, Japan and Brazil.
Mr. Allaire also said the company continued to narrow the focus of its financial services businesses; in those lines, quarterly earnings climbed to $7 million from $4 million. The efforts include an extensive restructuring at Crum & Forster, a property-casualty insurance unit.
In line with the restructuring, Xerox posted $444 million in capital gains during the quarter, as Crum & Forster shortened the duration of its fixed-income securities to minimize rate fluctuations on invested assets. The gains were offset by provisions of an equal amount to strengthen the balance sheet for future restructuring actions.
Crum & Forster is looking at ways to restructure its operations and will make additional provisions during the fourth quarter, Xerox said. The amount has not been determined.
In the last two years, Crum & Forster sold a specialty personal lines underwriter and withdrew from standard personal property and casualty insurance lines as it began to concentrate on more profitable lines and geographic segments, Xerox said. The insurer also reduced staff 30 percent.
Crum & Forster reported $30 million in pretax losses from Hurricanes Andrew and Iniki.
Asset management and investment banking continued to benefit from strong markets, higher mutual fund fees and capital gains at Xerox Life, the company said. In Xerox's document-processing business, third-quarter profit increased to $128 million from $117 million, as revenue rose to $3.6 billion from $3.3 billion.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
BMW Puts Account In Review

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
BMW of North America Inc. said yesterday that it would place its account in review. The account, estimated at $80 million to $85 million, has been at Ammirati & Puris Inc. in New York a month shy of 18 years.
The unexpected disclosure was followed by one just as startling: Although BMW asked Ammirati to participate in the review, the agency, which created the "Ultimate driving machine" identity for the German maker of luxury cars, declined. 
 The twin surprises typify current turmoil between car makers and their agencies as the weak economy and intensifying competition roil relationships. Even General Motors, which has not dismissed an agency since the Eisenhower Administration, has its Oldsmobile account in review; in that instance, the incumbent, Leo Burnett U.S.A. in Chicago, decided to participate.
BMW becomes the sixth auto maker to place an account in review in the last 18 months, even though, unlike the other five, its sales have been rising, up 27 percent for the first nine months. Four of those reviews -- American Isuzu, Jaguar Cars, Mercedes-Benz of North America and Subaru of America -- ended with longtime shops dismissed.
That tumult is a primary reason Ammirati, which is known for stylishly understated campaigns for clients including Nikon, RCA and United Parcel Service, chose not to participate in the review on what has been its largest account. With so much automotive business in flux, the agency believes it can snare another account more easily than go through the arduous process of trying to keep a restless client.
"It's part of the BMW philosophy to constantly challenge ourselves to do better," Victor H. Doolan, executive vice president of sales and marketing at BMW in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., said in an interview yesterday.
"Perhaps that's what other large car companies should have done," he added, "like one in the news today" -- an allusion to G. M.
Yet the review is puzzling because BMW's sales gains so far this year have been among the most robust of any auto maker. BMW has even moved ahead of archrival Mercedes-Benz for the first time in American unit sales, 49,203 to 47,648 for the nine months.
Also, BMW's advertising, which has carried the "Ultimate driving machine" theme for nearly two decades, is among the best known in the automotive category. During the 1980's, campaigns played on the desire of free-spending young professionals, who coined the affectionate nickname "Beemer" for the marque, to buy cars emphasizing sporty performance over plush comfort. More recently, concerns that BMW was being perceived as a so-called yuppie-mobile led Ammirati to present it as an automobile for drivers who want to emphasize handling and control.
The risk, of course, is that changing agencies could prove disruptive. Mr. Doolan called it a risk worth taking because "the time is opportune to look at what's in the market and where to take BMW in the future."
"BMW always takes the view that we should never be complacent with our success," he added. And while BMW was "very sad to hear" that Ammirati withdrew from the review, he continued, "that's life; that's their prerogative."
Martin Puris, president and chief executive at Ammirati, was clearly eager to suggest that the arrival in March of Mr. Doolan, a former president of BMW's Canadian operations, precipitated the review.
"When a new sales and marketing executive comes in," Mr. Puris said, "he's a new client; you've got to win him over."
"But the first inkling we had of any difficulty," he added, was when Mr. Doolan visited Ammirati's office Monday to disclose the review.
"It was an absolute, total blindsiding," he continued. "The way in which it was done was as much a convincer as anything else that we didn't want anything to do with the review."
But Mr. Doolan said, "I don't think it has anything to do with my arrival." He added that "this decision was taken by BMW, not by myself." He called the review part of a worldwide re-examination of all operations by BMW's Stuttgart-based parent.
Mr. Puris, who is also chairman and chief executive at the November Company, the agency handling President Bush's re-election campaign advertising, was surprisingly chipper considering the departure of so significant an account.
"We have a rather good reputation in the automobile business," he explained, "and I wouldn't be surprised if we had the opportunity to handle another piece of business, whether it's now or next month or a year from now." He said the agency would "keep the BMW team together for the foreseeable future" and try to avoid laying off anyone who has worked on the account.
His equanimity also stemmed from an estimated $120 million in new billings recently awarded to Ammirati by Mastercard International and Compaq Computer, bringing the agency's total billings, including BMW, to an estimated $320 million.
Morgan, Anderson & Company, the consultant BMW hired for advice on its review, also consulted on the Mastercard and Compaq reviews.
Mr. Doolan declined to identify the 30 or more agencies that would be invited to participate in the review. He said he hoped to narrow them to four or five finalists by Dec. 15 and name a new agency by the end of January.
Participants are expected to include small to midsized, creatively focused agencies without automotive accounts. Many are also likely to be involved in the Oldsmobile review, like Deutsch Inc. and Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor in New York; Tatham Euro RSCG in Chicago, and W.B. Doner & Company in Southfield, Mich., and Baltimore.
Two other likely contenders are the previous agencies of two other European luxury cars: McCaffrey & McCall in New York, which lost Mercedes-Benz to Scali, McCabe, Sloves, and Geer, DuBois in New York, which lost Jaguar to Ogilvy & Mather New York.
Another likely candidate is Lord, Dentsu & Partners in Los Angeles and New York, which was rocked by the stunning disclosure Monday that the Mazda Motor Corporation was scrapping plans to introduce a luxury line called Amati. Lord, Dentsu was awarded Amati's account in January after a five-month review involving four other agencies.
And two finalists in a review for a newly formed metropolitan New York BMW dealer association might also participate in the corporate BMW review. They are Ally & Gargano and Cox Landey & Partners, both in New York.

HEADLINE: Mixed Yields for C.D.'s and Money Funds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit were mixed in the week that ends today.
Analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor, a Florida-based interest rate publication, said that while money market accounts slipped again, yields on certificates of deposit, particularly six-month C.D.'s, were up nationwide. Robert K. Heady, the publisher of the rate publication, said that not since April 1990 had the yield on a six-month certificate risen as much as 4 basis points on The Monitor's index of 20 major banks nationwide. 
 "What we're now seeing is a mild upturn in short-term C.D. yields following last week's stall in the down slide," Mr. Heady said. "Chalk it up to the Clinton factor as the market anticipates his election and the coming increase in Government spending to reignite the economy, which will put upward pressure on interest rates."
A victory for President Bush would mean less of a rate rise because his spending programs would be more modest, Mr. Heady added.
"And if you remove the election from the equation altogether, rates would move lower simply on the market's attitute on the economy," Mr. Heady said.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Monday, average discount rates rose for the third consecutive week. The auction is often regarded as a reliable barometer of how banks could set deposit rates in the weeks ahead.
The average rate at auction for a three-month bill this week rose 3 basis points, to 2.97 percent, while the six-month bill rose 12 basis points, to 3.22 percent.
The combined New York area average for yields in the latest week was narrowly down, as the average money market account dropped 2 basis points, to 2.79 percent, and a three-month certificate of deposit slipped one basis point, to 2.85 percent. The yield on a six-month C.D. was unchanged at 3.01 percent.
Yields at commercial banks were mostly up, with a money market account unchanged at 2.63 percent, while a three-month certificate rose one basis point, to 2.77 percent, and six-month certificates gained 2 basis points, to 2.91 percent.
The largest yield adjustments this week were made at Anchor Savings, which reduced its money market account by 26 basis points, to 2.76 percent, and its three-month C.D. dropped by 16 basis points, to 2.89 percent. Key Bank, on the other hand, raised its six-month C.D. 30 basis points, to 3.14 percent.
Outside the New York market, yields at 20 large banks surveyed were mixed, with the average money market account down a basis point, to 2.68 percent, and a six-month C.D. up 4 basis points, to 2.91 percent.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Dips Again

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Consumer confidence dropped in October for the fourth straight month, a private business group said yesterday, indicating that Americans are still deeply worried about the course of the economy.
Consumer confidence is now at its lowest point since February. Gains that occurred in the spring and summer have been erased as the economy has only slowly gained steam. 
 The Conference Board, a private business group based in New York, said its index of consumer confidence fell to 53 in October from 57.3 in September. The index uses a base of 100 in 1985.
 
Deferring Big Purchases
 The board found that one in three households surveyed said they had been significantly affected by the recession. The group surveys 5,000 households each month.
One in four said someone in their household had been unemployed in the last year. Of those who found new work, well over half took positions that paid less than their previous jobs, the conference board said.
Consumer opinions are a crucial component of the economy, for pessimism tends to cause people to keep a lid on spending. In the survey, 43 percent of consumers said they had put off a big purchase because of the economy.
In the survey, consumers continued to view the economy in a negative light. Fewer than one in 10 respondents said current business conditions were good; more than 4 in 10 said they were bad.
Consumers were especially worried about job prospects in the slow-growing economy. Only 5 percent of respondents said jobs were "plentiful," while almost 50 percent said they were "hard to get."
 
More Are Pessimistic
 Respondents were also more pessimistic about the coming six months than they were in September, the board said. Only 13 percent expect more jobs to be available six months from now, with nearly twice that level predicting fewer available jobs.
Only 16 percent expect business conditions to be "better" six months from now, fewer than in the prior survey.
The 4.3 point decline in the index in October was the largest since July, when the index dropped 11.4 points, to 61.2 from 72.6 in June.

HEADLINE: For Congress From New York

 BODY:
New York has more unpredictable Congressional contests this year because of redistricting. Here are recommendations in some contested races in New York City and in districts that include city and suburban neighborhoods.
Fifth District (Queens, Nassau and Suffolk): Gary Ackerman, a Democrat, is running for a sixth term in a reapportioned district that now stretches into Long Island, well beyond his old Queens base. Mr. Ackerman worked effectively on famine relief and the plight of Ethiopian Jews, but his record is otherwise unremarkable. 
 His Republican opponent, the Suffolk County legislator Allan Binder, is a former Congressional aide who theorizes naively about complex matters like health care and the economy. Yet Mr. Binder has no patience for Congressional perks that infuriate voters, and has been a more thoughtful lawmaker than his rhetoric would suggest.
In a close call, we endorse Mr. Binder for the promise he offers of energetic representation.
13th District (Staten Island and Brooklyn): Susan Molinari's first-term performance has been disappointing, particularly on local issues. She is ambivalent on the issue of Staten Island's secession, a destructive concept, and her immoderate speech during the raucous police demonstration at City Hall last month showed poor judgment. In Washington, however, she remains a valuable commodity -- a moderate Republican who supports abortion rights.
Her opponent, Sal Albanese, is one of the City Council's brightest members, but his maverick style would likely weaken his effectiveness. We endorse Ms. Molinari with the hope that in the future she will provide a voice as constructive at home as it can be in Washington.
14th District (Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn): Bill Green, who has long represented what is still the core of this district -- Manhattan's East Side -- is a Republican member of the Appropriations Committee, where he can push for New York's needs.
His industrious opponent, City Councilwoman Carolyn Maloney, has made a useful contribution by focusing on important issues like campaign finance reform and improving contract procedures. But Mr. Green has earned another term.
18th District (Westchester, the Bronx and Queens): The Democratic incumbent, Nita Lowey, faces a challenge from the Republican candidate she defeated four years ago, Joseph DioGuardi. We support Ms. Lowey, a hard-working lawmaker who has emphasized education and environmental issues. Mr. DioGuardi, an accountant, can point to few notable accomplishments during his two terms in Congress and accepts the designation of the one-issue Right to Life Party.

HEADLINE: Coming Soon: The Vietnam Peace

 BODY:
Confronted with evidence that its secret archives could shed light on the fate of Americans missing since the Vietnam War, Hanoi has finally opened those records. The Bush Administration can best reciprocate with two overdue steps of its own: Lift the U.S. veto on international bank lending to Vietnam, and establish diplomatic ties.
America's punitive policies toward Vietnam have done little to advance U.S. interests. Successive Administrations barred Americans from most commerce with Hanoi and pressed allies for similar restrictions. This boycott isolated Vietnam from the democratic ferment fostered by foreign trade and investment in Eastern Europe and China. 
 Hanoi blames America for this isolation. But Hanoi's own perverse behavior is as much to blame. Vietnam might have achieved normalization in the Carter years. Instead it demanded billions in reconstruction aid, not acknowledging its own brazen violations of the Paris peace agreements. Although Hanoi can claim some justification for invading Pol Pot's Cambodia in 1978, it can claim none for a 10-year occupation. And its long insistence that it was fully cooperating in the search for missing Americans now stands exposed as a lie.
Still, if Hanoi opens its archives the case for ending the boycott is strong. Vietnam now welcomes foreign investment and private entrepreneurship. It makes no sense to undermine those reforms by blocking World Bank loans, or to handicap U.S. businesses interested in this new market.
The case for diplomatic ties is also compelling. New political and economic channels can increase opportunities for raising issues that concern Americans. If both sides pursue this opening, the much-delayed Vietnam peace may finally be at hand.

HEADLINE: The G.O.P. Won the Cold War? Ridiculous.

BYLINE: By George F. Kennan; George F. Kennan, professor emeritus at the Institute for Advanced Study, is author of the forthcoming "Around the Cragged Hill: A Personal and Political Philosophy."

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
The claim heard in campaign rhetoric that the United States under Republican Party leadership "won the cold war" is intrinsically silly.
The suggestion that any Administration had the power to influence decisively the course of a tremendous domestic political upheaval in another great country on another side of the globe is simply childish. No great country has that sort of influence on the internal developments of any other one. 
 As early as the late 1940's, some of us living in Russia saw that the regime was becoming dangerously remote from the concerns and hopes of the Russian people. The original ideological and emotional motivation of Russian Communism had worn itself out and become lost in the exertions of the great war. And there was already apparent a growing generational gap in the regime.
These thoughts found a place in my so-called X article in Foreign Affairs in 1947, from which the policy of containment is widely seen to have originated. This perception was even more clearly expressed in a letter from Moscow written in 1952, when I was Ambassador there, to H. Freeman Matthews, a senior State Department official, excerpts from which also have been widely published. There were some of us to whom it was clear, even at that early date, that the regime as we had known it would not last for all time. We could not know when or how it would be changed; we knew only that change was inevitable and impending.
By the time Stalin died, in 1953, even many Communist Party members had come to see his dictatorship as grotesque, dangerous and unnecessary, and there was a general impression that far-reaching changes were in order.
Nikita Khrushchev took the leadership in the resulting liberalizing tendencies. He was in his crude way a firm Communist, but he was not wholly unopen to reasonable argument. His personality offered the greatest hope for internal political liberalization and relaxation of international tensions.
The downing of the U-2 spy plane in 1960, more than anything else, put an end to this hope. The episode humiliated Khrushchev and discredited his relatively moderate policies. It forced him to fall back, for the defense of his own political position, on a more strongly belligerent anti-American tone of public utterance.
The U-2 episode was the clearest example of that primacy of military over political policy that soon was to become an outstanding feature of American cold war policy. The extreme militarization of American discussion and policy, as promoted by hard-line circles over the ensuing 25 years, consistently strengthened comparable hard-liners in the Soviet Union.
The more America's political leaders were seen in Moscow as committed to an ultimate military rather than political resolution of Soviet-American tensions, the greater was the tendency in Moscow to tighten the controls by both party and police, and the greater the braking effect on all liberalizing tendencies in the regime. Thus the general effect of cold war extremism was to delay rather than hasten the great change that overtook the Soviet Union at the end of the 1980's.
What did the greatest damage was not our military preparations themselves, some of which (not all) were prudent and justifiable. It was rather the unnecessarily belligerent and threatening tone in which many of them were publicly carried forward. For this, both Democrats and Republicans have a share of the blame.
Nobody -- no country, no party, no person -- "won" the cold war. It was a long and costly political rivalry, fueled on both sides by unreal and exaggerated estimates of the intentions and strength of the other party. It greatly overstrained the economic resources of both countries, leaving both, by the end of the 1980's, confronted with heavy financial, social and, in the case of the Russians, political problems that neither had anticipated and for which neither was fully prepared.
The fact that in Russia's case these changes were long desired on principle by most of us does not alter the fact that they came -- far too precipitately -- upon a population little prepared for them, thus creating new problems of the greatest seriousness for Russia, its neighbors and the rest of us, problems to which, as yet, none of us have found effective answers.
All these developments should be seen as part of the price we are paying for the cold war. As in most great international conflicts, it is a price to be paid by both sides. That the conflict should now be formally ended is a fit occasion for satisfaction but also for sober re-examination of the part we took in its origin and long continuation. It is not a fit occasion for pretending that the end of it was a great triumph for anyone, and particularly not one for which any American political party could properly claim principal credit.

HEADLINE: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT A RATE OF 2.7% DURING 3D QUARTER

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
The economy grew at a surprisingly brisk pace of 2.7 percent in the July-September period, the Commerce Department reported today. This was the sixth consecutive quarterly advance in gross domestic product, the most comprehensive measure of economic activity within American borders.
The dollar value of the output surpassed the pre-recession peak registered in the 1990 second quarter. 
 President Bush and other Republicans immediately seized on the figures, which are the final important set of numbers to be published before Election Day, to contend that the economy was shaking off its lethargy and that the United States would "lead the world to recovery."
"We have now had six straight quarters of growth in the United States," Mr. Bush said as he campaigned through Iowa, Kentucky and Ohio. "And yet the Democrats keep telling us that everything is going to hell. And they're wrong." [Page A16.]
 
 
Less Optimistic View
 Democrats offered a far less optimistic view. Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said Mr. Bush's reaction was "another example of a failed President grasping at straws."
And specialists working in the campaign of Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic nominee, noted that growth in the last six quarters had averaged 1.8 percent -- less than one-third the rate for comparable periods in the other eight postwar recoveries. They said the third-quarter advance could not be sustained.
The conventional view of campaign strategists and political scientists is that voters' perceptions of the state of the economy are formed and change slowly and that it is too late for new economic data to alter the way people will vote next week. Some Republican economists acknowledged as much when asked about today's output figures.
 
Central Issue
 Yet this year's campaign has changed course so many times and President Bush's handling of the economy is such a central issue that the political effect of the figures cannot be gauged with much confidence.
The G.D.P. data, moreover, were blunted by a separate report from the Conference Board, a corporate group, showing that consumer confidence fell in October for the fourth consecutive month. With a reading of 53, the index is now at its weakest level since February, which was the lowest point since the onset of recession in July 1990.
And other recent economic soundings have been decidedly mixed. A drop in first-time claims for jobless benefits to the lowest level in more than two years raised hopes last week that the job market had finally begun to improve, and retail sales have also ticked up recently. But the nation's trade deficit, reflecting economic slowdowns abroad, soared to $9 billion in September and industrial output has fallen two months in a row.
The National Bureau of Economic Research, the nation's business-cycle arbiter, has yet to formally declare the recession's end -- although most economists believe this occurred sometime in mid-1991.
While economists in general are inclined to favor Republicans -- though there are prominent exceptions -- most tended to agree with the Clinton forces today that the overall third-quarter G.D.P. results were not as strong as the 2.7 percent rate of expansion implied.
"This number is quite decent if it was sustainable," Dave Orr, chief economist for the First Union National Bank in Charlotte, said. "But it's not."
He and others cited in particular a sizable 3.4 percent rate of increase in what consumers spent on personal consumption, much of this on clothing, furniture and other household equipment and medical care. This was in contrast with a rate of decline of one-tenth of 1 percent for the second quarter.
But the figures also indicated that consumers were forced to draw down their savings to make these purchases since disposable personal income -- running at an annual rate of $3.6 trillion -- edged up a negligible $400 million and, on a per capita basis, no doubt fell.
The savings rate, meanwhile, dropped to 4.5 percent from 5.3 percent in the spring quarter, the Commerce Department's report showed.
Another significant source of numerical strength was a surge of 6.9 percent in the pace of Federal military spending. This was seen as an aberration since the preceding four quarters all showed big declines, averaging 8.8 percent.
No one interviewed today suggested that these or any of the other numbers in the report were "cooked" for political purposes, though one said the spending itself could possibly have been timed for maximum effect. Since these figures reflect actual delivery of goods, they were not affected by various military contracts the Administration announced recently to considerable campaign fanfare.
Economists skeptical about the sustainability of this summer's G.D.P. pace also pointed to a further buildup in business inventories, which rose at a $14.7 billion rate in the third quarter after an increase of $7.8 billion in the spring.
Inventories are subject to differing interpretations -- increases could result both from a buyers' strike or aggressive stocking by optimistic merchants -- but most analysts thought the third-quarter buildup was involuntary. Newly produced goods contribute to G.D.P. even if they languish on retail or wholesale shelves, but their existence also tends to retard future production.
Under Secretary of Commerce J. Antonio Villamil, however, said that the inventory-sales ratio remains low, "suggesting that additional increases in demand will be met primarily by production gains rather than inventory liquidation."
Business increased its investment in equipment, the report also showed, though this was said to consist mainly of computers and was not broadly based. And the international trade sector continued to drag down performance, with the department estimating a September deficit $200 million higher than August's $9 billion. Some considered this projection overly optimistic in light of significant weakening of foreign economies.
"There's really nothing here I'm impressed with," Lincoln F. Anderson, chief economist for Fidelity Management and Research in Boston said. "We won't get anywhere near 2.7 in the fourth quarter."
But there was one element in today's report, inflation, that was unambiguously good -- except that it was aided by a weak economy. As measured by the fixed-weight index, which assumes that the composition of output does not vary, inflation retreated to a 2.4 percent rate during the summer from 3.2 percent in the spring.
In a separate report today, the Labor Department said its Employment Cost Index rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter, slightly less than in the four preceding quarters during which increases were either eight-tenths or nine-tenths of 1 percent.
Increases in wages and salaries decelerated to four-tenths of 1 percent from six-tenths of 1 percent, while benefit costs rose 1.5 percent after rising 1.1 percent in the second quarter.
The rise in G.D.P. -- the total value of the nation's output of goods and services, minus income from abroad -- was the fourth biggest of Mr. Bush's Presidency and nearly twice as big as the analysts' consensus. On the other hand, as the Clinton camp noted, it was only half the normal pace of the early stages of typical recoveries and short of the 3 percent pace considered necessary to push down the unemployment rate.
"Half the surge in demand came from people dipping into their savings," Gene Sperling, economic policy director for the Clinton campaign, said. "How encouraging is that?"

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Allied-Signal Has a Profit of $149 Million

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 27

 BODY:
Allied-Signal Inc. posted a profit for the third quarter, as the company's reorganization continued to pay off.
Allied-Signal, one of the nation's largest automotive and aerospace companies, said its net income was $149 million, or 99 cents a share. In the third quarter of 1991, the company took a charge against earnings of $661 million to cover restructuring and other costs and reported a loss for that quarter of $540 million.
Revenue for the most recent quarter edged up just 2 percent, to $2.94 billion, from $2.88 billion a year earlier.
"Our continued productivity gains, reduced cycle times and improved working capital turns have resulted in higher margins for our businesses despite slow growth in our global markets," Lawrence Bossidy, chairman and chief executive, said. 
 The results show the effects of a restructuring announced a year ago that analysts hailed as a necessary step toward reining in a company whose profits had been diluted by high costs and investment in research that took years to add to the bottom line.
"I'm really astonished at how well the company's done despite the recession," Michael Lauer, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company, said.
Mr. Bossidy said 1992 earnings are expected to exceed previous forecasts of $3.60 to $3.85 a share, and some analysts recently raised their expectations to nearly $3.90 a share.
Profit margins grew by nearly half in the third quarter, to 7.1 percent from 5.1 percent, as net income in the automotive segment nearly doubled. Sales gains in automotive and engineered businesses were tempered by declines in military equipment and aviation, the company said.
In New York Stock Exchange trading today, Allied-Signal's stock slipped 62.5 cents a share, to $56.375.
Last October, Allied-Signal announced plans to lay off 14,000 employees, or 14 percent of its work force; close 10 plants; sell eight business units, and consolidate operations -- at a cost of $880 million before taxes.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
RJR Nabisco's Profit Rises 48% on Foreign Sales Strength

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation reported a sharp 48 percent increase yesterday in third-quarter net income, helped in large part by strong foreign food and tobacco sales.
The consumer products giant, whose brands include Camel and Winston cigarettes, Oreo cookies and Planters peanuts, said its earnings had risen to $182 million, or 13 cents a share, from $123 million, or 7 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago. 
 Revenue totaled $4.02 billion, up 7 percent from $3.76 billion in last year's third quarter.
 
Retiring High-Interest Debt
 The earnings reported yesterday included a $70 million after-tax charge tied to the cost of repurchasing and retiring $511 million worth of high-interest debt. Without the one-time charge, RJR said it would have reported net income of $252 million.
A number of analysts said the results were slightly better than expected, but the reaction among investors was fairly tepid: the price of RJR's shares rose by only 12.5 cents a share, to $8.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.
"Shares have been soft, trading in sympathy with Philip Morris and American Brands," Jennifer M. Coury, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, wrote in a a report to clients. "We would be buyers of RJR Nabisco at these levels."
In the tobacco segment of RJR's business, responsible for three-quarters of the company's profits, analysts said they were pleased with the strong performance of RJR's cigarette brands in foreign markets. At home, a big jump in sales of cheaper private-label brands helped to offset slumping demand for the better-known and more expensive Camel, Winston and Salem cigarettes.
RJR's worldwide tobacco sales amounted to $2.33 billion in the third quarter, up 7 percent from a year ago, with most of the growth coming from abroad.
International net tobacco sales rose more than 14 percent during the quarter, to $736 million. Domestically, net sales rose a more modest 4.6 percent, to $1.59 billion. Meanwhile, the number of cigarettes sold in the United States rose 6 percent.
"The company did a fantastic job of increasing domestic cigarette volume, due in large part to a very sharp increase in private-label sales, which were up fourfold from a year ago,"said Roy Burry, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company.
RJR's food businesses reported net sales of $1.69 billion, up 6 percent from the third quarter of 1991.
In a statement, the company said sales growth was strong in Latin America and modest in North America, "where the weak economy continued to restrain consumer spending."
The statement elaborated at some length on the company's continued efforts to pare its debt burden, which stood at $29.6 billion in February 1989 after the company was purchased by Kohlberg Kravis & Roberts.
During the quarter, RJR repurchased $100 million of 15 percent payment-in-kind debentures due in 2001, $44 million of its 17 3/8 percent senior converting debentures due 2009, $263 million of its 15 percent subordinated discount debentures due 2001 and $105 million of other debentures.
"We continued to take advantage of favorable market conditions in the quarter to replace high-cost debt with lower-cost debt," Louis V. Gerstner, Jr., RJR's chairman and chief executive, said in the release. "The refinancing of $2.8 billion that we have completed since the beginning of this year will produce significant interest savings for the company."
In the last three years, RJR has lopped off $15 billion worth of debt, largely by selling assets and buying back outstanding debt.
"Right now, their job first and foremost is to strengthen the balance sheet, and they are doing a great job of that," said Emanuel Goldman, an analyst at Paine Webber. "The recession is having an impact on industry after industry, and for now they just have to make it through a difficult period. We like the stock, and rate it attractive."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The economy grew at a surprisingly brisk pace of 2.7 percent in the July-September period and surpassed its pre-recession peak for the first time. Republicans seized on the figures, contending that the economy was shaking off its prolonged lethargy, but Democrats offered a less optimistic view. [Page A1.]
Consumer confidence dropped in October for the fourth straight month, indicating that Americans are still deeply worried about the course of the economy. [D2.] 
 Records of New Medico Health Care were seized by the F.B.I. in an investigation of alleged health care fraud. [D3.]

HEADLINE: Study Finds Mortgage Bias

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Mortgage applications from black and Hispanic borrowers are still rejected roughly twice as often as applications from whites and Asians, the Federal Reserve said today in its second annual report on lending discrimination.
Because of rising delinquency rates linked to the recession, lenders in 1991 denied a greater percentage of mortgage applications for all racial and ethnic groups than in 1990, the Federal Reserve said. But differences in rejection rates across groups appeared roughly the same, it said. 
 In 1991, lenders rejected 37.6 percent of the applications for conventional mortgages from blacks, 26.6 percent from Hispanics, 15 percent from Asian-Americans and 17.3 percent from whites.
A year earlier, the rejection rates were 33.6 percent for blacks, 21.4 percent for Hispanics, 12.8 percent for Asians and 14.2 percent for whites.
The agency said that some -- but not all -- of the discrepancy can be explained by income differences among the groups. However, disparities still were present when the applications were grouped by income.
For instance, among high-income applicants, the rejection rates were 9.7 percent for whites, 13.6 percent for Asians, 19.8 percent for Hispanics and 23.2 percent for blacks.

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: Esther B. Fein

 BODY:
Printing Madonna
When Beacon Press tried recently to hire R. R. Donnelley & Sons, one of the country's largest printers, to print one of its books, "Gay Ideas: Outing and Other Controversies," by Richard Mohr, a professor of philosophy at the University of Illinois, the publishing house was turned down.
Too controversial, Beacon editors were told. Too sexually explicit. 
 A Donnelley vice president, Bill Flavell, defended the decision in an interview with National Public Radio in September, saying, "It is fairly standard that there are certain types of materials that Donnelley chooses not to get involved with, and that could be anything from seditious material to certain types of very sexually explicit material, for reasons primarily due to our employees' feelings about dealing with this type of material."
This month, a book printed by Donnelley is the hottest selling book in the country. It is Madonna's "Sex" (Warner Books), which features the now much discussed photos of her in a compromising position with a dog, sandwiched naked between an array of people and with a knife held to her crotch by a bald, tattooed lesbian.
 
Here's the Reason
 Defending the company's decision to print the Madonna book, Donnelley's vice president for corporate relations, James M. Ratcliffe, told The Boston Globe, "We can't reject work just because people might find it controversial."
Wendy Strothman, the director of Beacon, found Donnelley's sudden turnaround hypocritical and a sign of a general reluctance on the part of printers to deal with books on gay sexual themes when the job isn't lucrative enough to be worth the potential criticism from employees and from other customers.
Donnelley has turned down other books on gay topics. In 1984 a company representative told Alyson Publications that it would not print "I Once Had a Master," a collection of short stories by John Preston, because of the book's gay content. Last year, Alyson was rejected again by Donnelley when the publisher tried to hire the printer to produce "Gay Sex: A Manual for Men Who Love Men," because it was too sexually explicit.
"It looks as if they have a conveniently flexible set of guidelines for accepting or rejecting books," Ms. Strothman of Beacon Press said. "It is ridiculous that Donnelley would find Madonna's work more acceptable than Mohr's thoughtful, creative essays. What we are witnessing is blatant homophobia."
 
Looking for Uniformity
 Gerald Butler, the president of Donnelley's book division, said that Mr. Ratcliffe's statement -- that the company does not reject projects because others might find them controversial -- was the official company position, but he refused to answer any questions about the company's decision to accept the Madonna book while rejecting other books for their sexual explicitness.
Mr. Ratcliffe conceded that the company had "not been entirely consistent and we've taken perhaps an ad hoc approach." He said the company was trying to make its standards "more uniform and less contradictory."
Despite the enormous publicity that has surrounded "Sex" since the photos were still being shot, Mr. Ratcliffe at first said Donnelley "had no idea how big the sales for the book" would be when it agreed to take on the project and he denied financial considerations were a factor.
 
Well, It Is a Lot of Books
 People involved with the Madonna book and with books Donnelley has rejected said they thought the size of the "Sex" print run, well over 500,000 copies, had to have influenced the printer's decision to take on the project.
"Maybe when it's 500,000-plus copies it's different," said Laurence J. Kirshbaum, the president of Warner Books. "It's hard to turn down that kind of business in this economy."
Mr. Ratcliffe finally did modify his position. "We're obviously not in the business," he said, "of turning down good business."
 
Lucrative Republishing
 Executives at the Book-of-the-Month Club realized 10 years ago that they had an ideal setup for a new venture. Instead of buying the rights from publishers to sell club editions of books, they wondered, why not publish books on their own, or in joint projects with the publishers? They had easy access to an audience, the 2.7 million club members who regularly buy about 17 million books a year through the catalogues of the company's three largest clubs -- Book-of-the-Month, Quality Paperback and History -- and they had access to printers, who put out the clubs' selected titles.
They began with reprints of classics, like "All the King's Men," by Robert Penn Warren (in 1982 it sold 9,500 copies), "Berlin Diary," by William Shirer (a 1987 offer that sold 8,500 copies) and the Revised English Bible (a 1989 main selection that sold more than 80,000 copies). They then started doing anthologies, like the World Treasury of Modern Religious Thought, a joint venture with Little, Brown & Company that was a Book-of-the-Month Club main selection in 1990 and sold more than 100,000 copies. In June, the club had success with a six-volume set of Mark Twain classics, so far selling more than 20,000 sets.
Next month the three clubs will offer the company's most ambitious self-publishing project thus far, one that was born out of carefully studying the clubs' extensive data base that tracks reader preferences.
What the company learned, said Alice van Straalen, the director of the book development department, was that its customers liked religious books, reference books and anthologies, and were willing to pay fairly high prices for such works. And so the company came up with "Sacred Writings," a seven-volume set of the world's major religious texts, edited by Jaroslav Pelikan, a professor of history at Yale University; the set will cost $75 in hard cover and $50 in paperback.
The six texts included are: the Tanakh, the 24 books of the Hebrew Bible; the New Testament, along with the Old Testament Apocrypha; the Koran; the Analects, the reputed sayings and conversations of Confucius, containing the central principles of his teachings; the Rig Veda, the oldest and most important text of Vedic Hinduism, made up of a collection of 1,028 hymns, and the Dhammapada, a book of the Buddhist canons.
There is also a companion book by Mr. Pelikan, "On Searching the Scriptures: Your Own or Someone Else's," introducing readers to each text.
In a show of confidence in the project, the company had a first printing of 25,000 copies, a large run given the set's steep price.
"We saw a tremendous appetite," said Ms. van Straalen, "and we created something to fill it."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Oil Prices Decline Sharply Ahead of Inventory Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Energy futures plunged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders acted ahead of the release of American Petroleum Institute inventory data.
On other markets, coffee gained, and grain, soybeans, livestock and meat were mixed. 
 Energy futures traded higher at the opening in buying influenced by Monday's strong close. But buyers disappeared and traders reasserted the trend downward.
Crude oil prices moved to their lowest levels since August on accurate expectations that the Petroleum Institute numbers, released after the close of trading yesterday, would show an increase in crude oil and distillate stocks, said Thomas Blakeslee, an analyst with the Pegasus Econometric Group.
Besides confirming those higher supplies, the institute's figures showed a surprising increase in refinery operations. Unleaded gasoline supplies fell slightly.
Also weighing on energy futures was the increased production by OPEC nations, Mr. Blakeslee said. "It is apparent OPEC production is exceeding 25 million barrels a day, well above the quota," he added.
Gasoline prices were strong amid perceptions of tight supplies and the likelihood that refiners would reduce gasoline runs because of the seasonal switch to heating oil production.
Light crude oil for December delivery was 25 cents lower, at $21.02 a barrel; November heating oil was 0.2 cent lower, at 61.65 cents a gallon; November unleaded gasoline was 0.6 cent higher, at 59.90 cents a gallon, and December natural gas was 1.8 cents lower, at $2.295 per 1,000 cubic feet.
Coffee futures remained firm on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York as Colombia left the market and there was a lack of selling by other coffee producers, including Brazil.
Buying sent coffee futures 1.80 cents a pound higher before investors took profits later in the session. December coffee settled 0.70 cent higher, at 66.55 cents a pound.
Grain and soybean futures were higher on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Corn futures, despite pressure from reports of an excellent harvests, got a lift from news that the Agriculture Department planned to buy a million metric tons of corn and give it to republics of the former Soviet Union.
Wheat futures gained on a report that Russia had made another bid for wheat under the export subsidy program. The department has rejected past bids from Russia on the ground that they did not match prices offered by other nations.
Soybean futures were mostly higher on news that the United States and the European Community would resume talks to reach an agreement on trade tariffs.
Livestock and meat futures were mixed in trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk
