HEADLINE: Poll Finds D'Amato and Abrams Virtually Even in Senate Contest

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
A week before Election Day, the New York Senate race is a tossup between Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and State Attorney General Robert Abrams, even as Mr. Abrams's fellow Democrat, Bill Clinton, retains a double-digit lead over President Bush in the state, according to a new statewide New York Times poll.
After six weeks of rancorous campaigning, Mr. Abrams leads Mr. D'Amato among registered voters by just 3 percentage points, 38 percent to 35 percent -- or within the survey's margin of sampling error. Nearly one-quarter of voters said they were still undecided, an unusually high percentage this late in a race, and an apparent sign of wide dissatisfaction with both candidates.
When undecided voters were pressed to say which way they were leaning, the contest became a virtual draw, with 42 percent saying they favored Mr. Abrams to 41 percent for Mr. D'Amato. Mr. Abrams leads only in New York City, while the Senator holds a slight edge upstate and a double-digit lead in the suburbs on Long Island and in the Hudson Valley.
 
Clinton Shows Strength
 The tight Senate race stands in stark contrast to the Presidential contest, in which the survey -- conducted Saturday through Monday -- showed Mr. Clinton leading Mr. Bush 45 percent to 28 percent in the state, with 15 percent supporting the independent candidacy of Ross Perot. That contrast is an apparent testament to the effectiveness of Mr. D'Amato's relentless television advertising attacks on Mr. Abrams, who had led him in most polls over the last several months. 
 It may also be a legacy of the bitter Democratic primary, which ended with one of Mr. Abrams's rivals, Geraldine A. Ferraro, so angry that she refused to endorse him. One-third of those who said they voted for her in the primary now back Mr. D'Amato, while another fifth are undecided.
The closeness of the race was reflected in a new level of intensity in the campaign yesterday, as each candidate issued fresh ads attacking the other's integrity. Mr. Abrams's camp -- which says it has been outgunned five to one in television ads in the race -- said it would at last come close to meeting Mr. D'Amato's spending in the air war in these final frantic days.
The new ads were unequivocally harsh. Mr. Abrams's cites a pending Federal investigation into whether Mr. D'Amato tried to influence the grand jury testimony of a former Federal housing official concerning Mr. D'Amato's role in the awarding of Federal contracts. It ends with a narrator intoning: "The same old story, the same old Al. Doesn't New York deserve better? Isn't it time for a change?"
The new D'Amato ad accuses Mr. Abrams of planning to raise taxes, and twits him for repeated late payments of property taxes on his Dutchess County home -- for which Mr. Abrams has paid penalties. "It says it exactly," Mr. D'Amato said at a news conference to preview the ad. "He's going to raise taxes on everyone else and he has trouble paying his own."
Both campaigns and state party officials said The Times poll reflected their own sense of a tight race, and it included bad news for both candidates, as well as hints of how either could win. In addition to the high proportion of undecided voters, about one-quarter of each man's supporters said they might change their minds.
"That's where the race is -- dead even," said the state Democratic chairman, John A. Marino, who is striving to guard against complacency in the presidential race and hoping a large Democratic turnout helps Mr. Abrams. "I hope this serves as a warning to Democrats that we're this close to sending Al D'Amato back to the United States Senate -- for six years."
 
Clinton's Loose Coattails
 But even a heavy Democratic turnout is no guarantee of help for Mr. Abrams, since about one in five voters who said they were Democrats said they also intend to vote for Mr. D'Amato. About one-fifth of Clinton voters also said they plan to vote for Mr. D'Amato.
Moreover, the electorate expressed little enthusiasm for either Mr. Abrams or Mr. D'Amato. Each candidate was viewed unfavorably by about one-third of those surveyed, while just one in four viewed Mr. D'Amato favorably and only one in five had a favorable opinion of Mr. Abrams, a popular four-term attorney general who has been the state's record vote-getter. Among undecided voters, only 1 percent viewed Mr. D'Amato favorably, and only 2 percent viewed Mr. Abrams favorably.
Mr. D'Amato's attacks on Mr. Abrams as a "hopelessly liberal" tax and spender who takes campaign contributions from people doing business with his office appear to have helped dent the Attorney General's image, already battered the rough Democratic primary, in which Mr. Abrams repeatedly questioned the ethics and family finances of Ms. Ferraro.
More than a third of voters said they do not believe Mr. Abrams has the honesty or integrity they want in a senator, while just under half expressed the same view about Mr. D'Amato, who has weathered years of inquiries into his ethical conduct.
Voters were almost exactly evenly divided on who would do a better job of handling what they viewed as the problem they most wanted their next senator to tackle, which they overwhelmingly identified as the economy and unemployment. About one-third said either man would do equally well. The telephone survey of 1,213 registered voters has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
On the issues, each candidate could claim strengths. Voters expressed wide support for abortion rights, which Mr. Abrams backs, and also for the death penalty, which Mr. D'Amato favors. But neither issue was near the top of the voters' list, which was dominated by the economy, followed by taxes, the deficit, education, health care, homelessness and crime.
In yet another sign of the closeness of the race, voters were evenly split on some issues that sharply divide the candidates. For example, nearly half the respondents said they favored keeping military spending about the same, while the other half favored cutting it. Mr. Abrams and Mr. D'Amato have argued bitterly over Mr. Abrams's calls for deep cuts in military spending, which Mr. D'Amato says would throw hundreds of thousands out of work.
Mr. Abrams's campaign director, Ethan Geto, acknowledged that his campaign had faced big obstacles, but said he was confident that the Attorney General's final million-dollar-plus advertising push in the coming week would make it more competitive. The centerpiece of his ad campaign is a 30-second commercial in which Mr. Abrams looks into the camera and talks about his support for abortion rights and a national health insurance program -- a program that two-thirds of voters in the poll said they favor in concept.
"We think we're gonna get close enough in striking distance with our slingshot that our pebble is going to hit Goliath in the right place," he said.
But Kieran Mahoney, Mr. D'Amato's campaign manager, repeated his contention that Mr. Abrams's plan would lead to higher taxes -- which Mr. Abrams acknowledges, though he disputes Mr. D'Amato's assertion that personal income taxes would rise. Mr. Mahoney said New Yorkers recognized that, and were wary of Mr. Abrams as a result.
"Abrams started out with a 15-point lead, and it's now basically a dead heat and we have the momentum and we're going to win," he said, adding, "All things considered, we out-campaigned the opponent."
In a striking mark of the prevalence of television advertising as the main electioneering vehicle in modern statewide campaigns, more than half the respondents said they had seen commercials for each candidate in the last week, while only one-quarter said they had seen in either one in person or interviewed on a news program or in a debate.
When voters in the survey were asked who they expected to win, regardless of their own preferences, 44 percent picked Mr. D'Amato, to 36 percent for Mr. Abrams. Such questions are sometimes a sign of prevailing attitudes and the sense of momentum in a campaign.
Mr. D'Amato has sought to rally Italian-American voters, the state's single largest bloc, to his side, by repeatedly attacking Mr. Abrams for calling him a "fascist" after being heckled by D'Amato protesters, and by attacking Mr. Abrams's criticism of Ms. Ferraro during the primary. Nearly half the voters who identified themselves as Italian said they backed the Senator, compared with about 30 percent for Mr. Abrams.
 
How the Polls Were Done
 The latest nationwide New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 20-23 with 1,854 adults around the continental United States. Of those polled, 1,467 said they were registered voters.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers.
In addition, The New York Times conducted a separate poll throughout New York State on Saturday through Monday with 1,599 adults. Of those polled, 1,213 said they were registered voters. The sample of New York telephone numbers was provided by Survey Sampling Inc. of Fairfield, Conn. Respondents were interviewed in English or Spanish.
For both polls, one adult within each household was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent. The results of each poll have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines at the residence, as well as to adjust for variations relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
According to statistical theory, in 19 of 20 cases, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all registered voters in the respective population.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for registered voters in New York City it is plus or minus 5 percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Oil Prices Decline Sharply Ahead of Inventory Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Energy futures plunged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders acted ahead of the release of American Petroleum Institute inventory data.
On other markets, coffee gained, and grain, soybeans, livestock and meat were mixed. 
 Energy futures traded higher at the opening in buying influenced by Monday's strong close. But buyers disappeared and traders reasserted the trend downward.
Crude oil prices moved to their lowest levels since August on accurate expectations that the Petroleum Institute numbers, released after the close of trading yesterday, would show an increase in crude oil and distillate stocks, said Thomas Blakeslee, an analyst with the Pegasus Econometric Group.
Besides confirming those higher supplies, the institute's figures showed a surprising increase in refinery operations. Unleaded gasoline supplies fell slightly.
Also weighing on energy futures was the increased production by OPEC nations, Mr. Blakeslee said. "It is apparent OPEC production is exceeding 25 million barrels a day, well above the quota," he added.
Gasoline prices were strong amid perceptions of tight supplies and the likelihood that refiners would reduce gasoline runs because of the seasonal switch to heating oil production.
Light crude oil for December delivery was 25 cents lower, at $21.02 a barrel; November heating oil was 0.2 cent lower, at 61.65 cents a gallon; November unleaded gasoline was 0.6 cent higher, at 59.90 cents a gallon, and December natural gas was 1.8 cents lower, at $2.295 per 1,000 cubic feet.
Coffee futures remained firm on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York as Colombia left the market and there was a lack of selling by other coffee producers, including Brazil.
Buying sent coffee futures 1.80 cents a pound higher before investors took profits later in the session. December coffee settled 0.70 cent higher, at 66.55 cents a pound.
Grain and soybean futures were higher on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Corn futures, despite pressure from reports of an excellent harvests, got a lift from news that the Agriculture Department planned to buy a million metric tons of corn and give it to republics of the former Soviet Union.
Wheat futures gained on a report that Russia had made another bid for wheat under the export subsidy program. The department has rejected past bids from Russia on the ground that they did not match prices offered by other nations.
Soybean futures were mostly higher on news that the United States and the European Community would resume talks to reach an agreement on trade tariffs.
Livestock and meat futures were mixed in trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

AFRICAN DUST SPREADS WESTWARD
The hot October winds scoop the thin topsoil up from Africa, swirl the dust high into the sky and drive it west for thousands of miles. Scientists tracking the dust say it is a boon for the Atlantic food chain and for soil and vegetation in the Americas. A1

THE GROWING SCOPE OF AIDS
Under the new definition, the number of new AIDS cases reported each year is expected to nearly double, bringing with it a two-edged sword. States will be eligible for more Federal funds than are now distributed on the basis of reported cases. But agencies and clinics will face higher costs and heavier workloads. A1
 
DEAD ENDS FOR DRUG SALES

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN SPENDING IN CONGRESS RACES SOARS TO NEW HIGH

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Congressional campaign spending has soared to record levels this year as far more lawmakers than usual face tough fights to hold on to their seats, Federal Election Commission records show.
The trend is apparent in races for both chambers but is especially obvious in campaigns for the House. In past years incumbency has almost guaranteed re-election for House members, but in 1992, voter hostility, aroused in part by some lawmakers' abuse of checking-account privileges at the House Bank, has frequently made it an obstacle. 
 In addition, many House members are spending more trying to appeal to substantial numbers of new voters because of redistricting.
 
Hurt by Recession
 The increase in spending has not been matched by an increase in fund raising, largely because political action committees, which dole out money on behalf of industries, trade associations, unions and ideological groups, have given only a little more than in past years. The committees, which have often been accused of having an excessive influence on Congressional races, say the recession has left them short of money.
The average House incumbent spent $292,949 in the 21 months ending Sept. 30, up 27 percent from the same period two years earlier. The average for Senate incumbents, which is not comparable to 1989-1990 spending because different states are involved, is $2,351,205.
"We've never had to raise so much money and work so hard," said Representative Thomas J. Downey, a Long Island Democrat who has spent $794,789 seeking his 10th term, "because of the natural vulnerability we all feel."
 
Spending Outpaces New Money
 A New York Times computer analysis of reports filed with the election commission showed that incumbents' average spending has risen much faster than their fund raising, and that overall fund raising has risen faster than contributions by political action committees. The incumbents' overall fund raising increased 12 percent, to $363,189, while their contributions from PAC's grew by 7 percent, to $164,575.
Because spending grew faster than receipts, the average incumbent had $153,274 on hand after 21 months, down 16 percent from two years ago.
To avoid distortions caused by an occasional candidate with vast resources, like Michael Huffington, a California Republican who has spent $4,070,908, on a House race, the Times analysis used medians. The median is the point at which half the candidates in a group spent more and half spent less. Mr. Huffington, who is mostly using his own money, is spending more than 174 other major party candidates in open House seats. The median is $175,588.
Candidates in open seats, where neither has the advantages of incumbency, often have the stiffest competition. Democrats held an edge in this category, with the average candidate having raised $225,324 and spent $185,789. Republicans had raised an average of $173,170 and spent $132,188.
The difference was accounted for largely by political action committees. The average Democrat had raised $59,313 from such committees to the typical Republican's $6,850. While the PAC's see no reason to stir up the Democrats -- who control both House of Congress -- by contributing to Republican challengers, they do give to incumbents. The median in money raised from PAC's for a Republican incumbent was $141,385; for Democrats it was $187,850.
 
Hurdle for Challengers
 But challengers are generally in dire financial straits. The average challenger has raised only $42,807, with some $1,100 of it from political action committees, spent $34,076 and had $5,397 on hand Oct. 1.
Even so, 31 challengers had raised at least $200,000, the threshold described by Gary Jacobson, a professor of political science at the University of California at San Diego, as "enough to get the message out" and make a race competitive. Twenty of them are Republicans; 11 are Democrats.
Three challengers have actually raised more than the incumbent they are facing. Susan Stokes, a Kentucky Republican, has outraised Representative Ron Mazzoli, by $244,919 to 168,325. But she was aided by the incumbent's unilateral fiscal disarmament; he is among 12 incumbents taking no contributions from PAC's, and he limits individual donations to $100. The legal maximum contribution for an individual is $1,000.
 
Trying to Come Back
 The other two House challengers who have outraised incumbents are Gwen Margolis, a Florida Democrat, and Beau Boulter, a Texas Republican seeking to regain the seat he gave up for a Senate attempt in 1988.
Ms. Margolis is challenging Representative Clay Shaw and has outraised him, $573,033 to $430,095. But she had to spend heavily in a primary, and he led her in cash on hand, $419,247 to $110,221.
Mr. Boulter has raised $286,589, to $285,451 for Representative Bill Sarpalius, who got 60 percent of his money, or $170,619, from PAC's. Mr. Boulter got only 2 percent, or $6,735, from them.
In only two Senate races did the challenger raise more money than the incumbent. In California, Dianne Feinstein, the Democrat, had taken in $7,132,821, compared to $6,283,709 for Senator John Seymour. And in North Carolina, Lauch Faircloth, the Republican, had $2,042,555 to Senator Terry Sanford's $1,879,983.
 
The Money Race
 Those totals placed them third and fourth among Senate candidates, trailing Representative Barbara Boxer, a California Democrat running for an open seat, who had $8,836,194, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York. Mr. D'Amato reported receipts of $8,154,347.
Ms. Boxer's opponent, Bruce Herschensohn, had raised $5,475,537. Mr. D'Amato's challenger, Attorney General Robert Abrams, had receipts of $5,231,170.
Fifteen Senate candidates, all incumbents, had raise more than $1 million from PAC's, led by Mr. Seymour with $1,274,103. Ms. Feinstein's $696,027 led all challengers. Ms. Boxer's $700,281 led all those in open seats.
Two other Senate races showed close fund-raising duels. Senator John Glenn of Ohio, a Democrat, had outraised his challenger, Lieut. Gov. Mike DeWine, by $2,752,425 to $2,355,665. But Mr. Glenn, who has been raising money for years, had $709,858 on hand and Mr. DeWine had only $56,720.
In New Hampshire, Gov. Judd Gregg, the Republican candidate, had brought in $910,591, to $834,910, for his Democratic opponent in the Senate race, John Rauh. But Mr. Gregg had $177,388 left at the beginning of the month to Mr. Rauh's $22,242.
The median spending by Senate incumbents at this point in 1990 was $1,956,009, much lower than this year, in part because there were no contests in either of the nation's two most populous and expensive states, California and New York. In 1988, the median spending at this point by Senate incumbents was $2,380,568, around this year's level.
None of this year's Senate races will break the Senate spending record of $25.8 million set in 1984 by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina and his unsuccessful Democratic challenger, James B. Hunt. Nonetheless, the two Senate contests in California have already produced nearly $27 million in spending in 21 months, just by the four candidates who made it to the general election.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Voters;
Michigan Thinks, Rethinks and Thinks Again

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 28

 BODY:
As if flicking channels on the TV set, voters here have been switching from Presidential candidate to candidate to candidate, hoping to find true love but instead finding the political equivalent of one-night stands.
To be sure, in this western Michigan city that gave the world Gerald R. Ford, there are plenty of die-hard Republicans who started out as fans of George Bush and who will stay with him to the end, though even many of them have flirted with Ross Perot. But more voters than not have been loyal to no one. 
 It is common to find people here who have changed their minds three and four times since February and even since the debates this month -- most because of Ross Perot, with whom voters have what can only be called a love-hate relationship.
Based on conversations with some 75 voters over the last three days, Bill Clinton seems to hold the slightest of leads here, with Mr. Perot a distant third, drawing votes from President Bush and especially Mr. Clinton.
In interviews at midday on Monday, most people said they believed Mr. Perot's accusations, first made the day before, that Republicans had tried to orchestrate dirty tricks against him. But by late Tuesday afternoon, after television and newspaper commentators had weighed in with assessments that Mr. Perot was lying or paranoid, the mood on the streets had shifted, with people splitting 50-50 on whether he was being truthful.
"I voted for Bush last time and I was going to stay with him," said Joni Wagner, 32 years old, who works for the Travelers Life Insurance Company. "Then I decided Bush wasn't doing enough about the economy, so I went to Perot. When he dropped out, I switched to Clinton, though I'm afraid he's going to spend and spend. I thought Perot was terrific in the debates, so I'm back with him."
Ms. Wagner, like the others interviewed on Monday, said she believed Mr. Perot's accusations. But 34-year-old Laurie Pawlowski, like half the others who were interviewed Tuesday afternoon, did not.
"I'll tell you, it's a stopper," Ms. Pawlowski, an insurance cost-control manager who is voting for Mr. Clinton, said of the Perot accusations. "Something's wrong with him. He's paranoid."
Dawn Stickler, 58, a claims manager at the same company, agreed. " 'Paranoid' is the word," she said. "I started out for Bush, but when I first listened to Perot, I thought he was doing real well. Then kablooey! He drops out, and you're back to square one. Now Perot is out of the question. He's flaky. This latest stuff is part of a pattern."
"Maybe Bush has learned his lesson on the economy," Ms. Stickler continued. "We don't know what Clinton will do. He may make things worse. I'm leaning to Bush. I don't think he'll hurt the economy more than he has. Clinton might."
 
Who Are You Supporting Now?
 That is what constitutes a political endorsement these days. In the interviews here and in similar conversations over the last three weeks in Albuquerque, N.M., and St. Louis, few people offered rousing support for their picks for President. In fact, most were almost sheepish in talking about their candidate, spending much of the conversation shaking their heads as they listed his faults. It seems that the most common expression in America these days is: "the lesser of three evils."
Therein lies what seems to be the reason for the fickle electorate. With party loyalty a thing of the past and with people voting not out of passion but out of defense -- to keep the damage to a minimum -- it all makes for paper-thin support.
"They all have problems, so you go with the guy who is the lesser of three evils," said Bill Baier, 40, sitting at a lunch table of mostly claim managers at a medical insurance company. He will vote for Mr. Bush.
"You don't know what to believe," Mr. Baier went on. "Did somebody really do such and such? Was there really a letter? Did somebody try to do something to somebody's kid? I blame the media for the confusion. This stuff keeps coming at you and you don't know. You think Perot might be good, but then you're told he has no foreign policy experience. The media tears them all down, so nobody looks good. So you don't really vote for anyone. All you're left with is: Who will do the least damage? Bush is no genius. But I least I know him."
This city of 190,000 people, which has not suffered anywhere near the economic losses of the motor cities of eastern Michigan, used to be sure-fire Republican. But that has been changing over the last 25 years. Mr. Bush carried the city in the 1988 Presidential election, but not by an overwhelming margin -- 54 percent of the vote to 45 percent for the Democrat, Michael S. Dukakis. The city's newspaper, The Grand Rapids Press, has endorsed Mr. Clinton, the second time in a hundred years it has endorsed a Democrat. (The last time was in 1980.)
That the area is up for grabs in this election is made clear by the repeated treks here by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush. The Democrat was in town just last Saturday. The Republican is due Thursday. Statewide polls show Mr. Clinton's lead in Michigan falling from 50 percent to 41 percent since the debates, with Mr. Perot rising to 19 percent from 8 percent. Mr. Bush has stayed at 30 percent. That ranking seems in line with what is happening in Grand Rapids, although Mr. Clinton's lead seems much tighter here.
 
'I'm Back With Ross'
 "I voted for Bush last time," said Ray Fisher, a 34-year-old body shop manager who had dropped by the makeshift Perot headquarters here to pick up a lawn sign. "I started toward Clinton. But I liked Perot's toughness. When he dropped out, I went back to Clinton. But he and Bush are the same -- finger-pointers. Now I'm back with Ross."
As for whether he believes Mr. Perot's accusations of dirty tricks, Mr. Fisher said, "They're probably true." And as for any anger at Mr. Perot for pulling out of the race, he added, "I see it as a wise move to take the attacks off of him."
But other onetime Perot supporters are not so forgiving. It is clear that for all the millions he may spend on television advertisements, Mr. Perot cannot overcome their anger at his betraying them. And while many people say they like his ideas, they say they cannot envision him as President because of what they see as his dictatorial ways, his strange personality and ultimately his untrustworthiness.
"I was on board with Perot," said the Rev. Ulysses Hines, 66, pastor of a black church, the Church of the Living God. "But when he dropped out, that was it. You can't trust him. I like his ideas, but you can't trust the man." Mr. Hines's car now has a Clinton-Gore bumper sticker.
Throughout the last two weeks, the religious right has been pressing hard here in radio talk shows and radio advertisements, and a number of voters said that as a result they had joined the swelling ranks of the great vote-switchers.
"I was all set for Clinton until I heard he wanted to put gays and lesbians in the military; that soured me on him," said Jerry Tappin, 55, a boiler operator who will now vote for Mr. Perot and who refused to believe that the Texas businessman also supports allowing homosexuals in the millitary.
For Brian Terrell, a 24-year-old duct cleaner, the revelation came during a Monday morning radio talk show. "I was leaning toward Perot," he said. "But I heard he supported abortion. Now I'll stay with Bush."
With Election Day less than a week away, few people seem to be genuinely undecided. They may profess to be undecided at first, and that is what they may tell the poll takers, but after a little wheedling and cajoling, they usually fess up.
"I really haven't decided," said Brian Jackson, a 40-year-old accountant.
Oh, come now, Mr. Jackson. You know.
"Well, I'm leaning toward Clinton," he confessed. "But don't let that get out. My neighbors are all Republican."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Steps Up Attacks on Democrat's Character

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 28

 BODY:
After a brief attempt to turn his campaign to his own vision for the country, President Bush crisscrossed Ohio today, buoyed by a belief that the Republican attack on Gov. Bill Clinton's character is working, and campaigning on a single theme: trust.
Waving his arms in triumph at new public opinion polls and trumpeting the recent signs of economic growth, Mr. Bush campaigned through a crescendo of rallies in Lima, Toledo, Strongsville and Columbus that ended with a blizzard of red, white and blue confetti and balloons here this evening. 
 He grew more boisterous with each event, cheerfully revising his epithet for Senator Al Gore, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, from "Ozone Man" to a simple "Ozone" by the time he arrived here. As his attack on Mr. Clinton mounted and the crowd shouted louder and louder for him to "give 'em hell," Mr. Bush flashed his off-center grin and told them to be patient because "I haven't attacked the media yet."
Mr. Bush tried out a new closing line for his speech here but was so excited that he could not seem to form the words. Trying to say he would do his "level best to lead this country to new heights," Mr. Bush ended up proclaiming something like "new husskites." Undaunted, he waved and left the stage.
 
Surge of Exuberance
 Much of Mr. Bush's exuberance seemed to spring from two new "tracking polls," including one by the Gallup Organization that suggested the race was tightening drastically. But the real situation remained unsettled, as the other showed no real change in the contest between Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton. A tracking poll involves daily interviewing over an extended period of time with results for two-day periods combined and released.
Along the trail today, Mr. Bush mentioned a host of opponents besides Mr. Clinton: Jimmy Carter, the "talking heads" in Washington, prison inmates in Arkansas, the national teachers' union, "environmental extremists," trial lawyers and "the gridlock guys," as Mr. Bush was referring to members of Congress today.
But Mr. Bush, whose strategy for months has been to get within a few points of Mr. Clinton and then close the gap by proclaiming that he is the more trustworthy, saved his strongest fire for Mr. Clinton's draft record and his assertion that the Democratic nominee is trying to "be all things to all people."
 
More Trustworthy Babysitter
 In a state where he is behind but must win, Mr. Bush stood at every stop in front of a sign announcing that this city "trusts Bush." He asked voters whom they trust to run the military, to keep taxes low, to hold families together and to uphold the nation's morals. At one point the actor Bruce Willis, who introduced Mr. Bush at two stops, even said that Mr. Bush would make a more trustworthy babysitter.
The President, who has tried to paint Mr. Clinton as a waffler, said, "You can't have a lot of but's sitting there at the Oval Office."
While Mr. Bush campaigned, his staff began running two new commercials driving home the chosen theme for the final days. The ads showed people on the streets of Cincinnati questioning Mr. Clinton's honesty. One said, "I think he's full of hot air." Another said: "He dodged the draft. He can't be straight on anything."
In case the point was still unclear, Mr. Bush spelled it out explicitly in Strongsville, a town near Cleveland, where more than 10,000 people gathered across from Town Hall to cheer the President on. "I tell you what's going to decide this election: it's going to be character and trust," he said.
 
Comeback Strategy
 Campaign aides acknowledged that Mr. Bush was still struggling on the electoral map. The Bush camp is ceding important states, like California, New York and Illinois, to Mr. Clinton and is building a strategy based on regaining enough strength to hold Texas, Florida and the rest of the South, and come back in states like Ohio, Michigan, Missouri and Wisconsin. Mr. Bush's travel schedule for the coming days reflects that: Michigan and Missouri in the next two days and a train ride through Wisconsin on Saturday.
Mr. Bush's problems were evident tonight during an hourlong question-and-answer session with voters and broadcasters who grilled him on everything from his economic policies to race relations and even foreign affairs. Mr. Bush seemed to grow testy at times, and at one point, waving his arms vaguely, he blamed the women's movement for the furor over the nomination of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court.
But for public consumption, everything about the day was intended to convey the sense that the comeback Mr. Bush has been predicting has already started. Behind the scenes, Bush aides organized large crowds, filling them with schoolchildren and, here, with five marching bands, to increase the noise level.
 
Help From Hollywood
 On stage, the President produced movie stars to help build crowds. Mr. Willis called Mr. Bush the man who ended the cold war. "Like all people here in Toledo, Ohio," he said at the first rally of the day, "I grew up under threat of nuclear attack."
Heckled by Clinton supporters in Strongsville, Mr. Bush did not lose his temper as he has at other moments in recent weeks. Instead, he shot back: "These guys feel it slipping away from them. They know we're moving. They know we're moving forward. I feel sorry for them."
On the tarmac beneath the wings of Mr. Bush's Boeing 747, Air Force One, members of the Oak Ridge Boys, a country-western band that often travels with the President, mingled with reporters talking of a new optimism in the crowds.
 
'A Sorry Record'
 As the President tries to chip away at public confidence in Mr. Clinton, he is keeping the Democrat's draft record and antiwar activities in Europe in the 1960's as his central theme.
But dusting off an attack that he used with great effect against Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in 1988, Mr. Bush is also devoting much time to asserting that Mr. Clinton could not be trusted to run the country because he has had a "sorry record" as Governor of Arkansas for 12 years.
"Governor Clinton better clean up his mess in Arkansas before fooling around with the United States of America," he said.

A1); President Bush acknowledging supporters at the end of a rally yesterday in Columbus, Ohio. (pg. A24) (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Water-Project Spending Falls Short for 2d Time

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
For the second year in a row the Dinkins administration has not spent all of the money it could have for repairs of the city's water mains, sewers, treatment plants and other environmental projects.
The Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, Albert F. Appleton, who last December said he hoped to meet his capital-spending goals for this year, said yesterday that there were good explanations for why he did not spend the money allotted to his agency in the city budget, including that most projects cost less than expected. 
 But the City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, criticized the department, contending that the department's failure to let $680 million in contracts, almost half of the money authorized for the rebuilding effort, meant that the city could not take full advantage of the strong competition for construction work during the recession and the resulting cheaper prices.
The budget approved in June 1991 authorized $1.55 billion for water and waste projects for the fiscal year that ended June 30 of this year. But the department let contracts totaling only $868 million, Ms. Holtzman said in a letter sent Monday to Mayor David N. Dinkins.
By the Comptroller's standard, the department let contracts for only 56 percent of the $1.55 billion. Other city agencies, on average, let contracts worth 73 percent of their spending plans, during the fiscal year that ended in June, Ms. Holtzman said.
Ms. Holtzman also said the department's underspending prevented the city from creating as many construction jobs as it could have if the $1.55 billion had been spent. The city does not actually lose any money because construction projects are financed through the sale of bonds.
 
Earlier Criticism
 Last year, the department was criticized because its failure to let $600 million in contracts for construction and repairs caused the city's program to upgrade water mains and sewers to fall sharply behind schedule. Mr. Appleton asserted that his agency had in fact turned around its construction program in the last year, in large part because of the attention focused on problems the previous year, in which the department fell behind schedule. Mr. Appleton said the department's building effort accomplished more in the last 12 months than ever before.
He said it was true that his agency had awarded contracts worth less than the amount authorized by the city. But he said that Ms. Holtzman failed, in her analysis, to take into account legitimate reasons why his construction plan was reduced during the year.
He said that the authorized spending approved in any city budget is always adjusted to account for changes in plans and in economic and construction conditions.
In the city's capital budget approved in June 1991, the Department of Environmental Protection was authorized to let contracts worth as much as $1.55 billion during the fiscal year. In September 1991, when some city agencies revised their spending plans, Mr. Appleton's department stuck to the $1.55 billion estimate.
 
Plant Cited
 In January 1992, Mr. Appleton said, the department sharply reduced the overall spending plan to $792 million. Among the reasons, he said, was the removal from the plan of a proposal to rebuild the Newtown Creek sewage-treatment plant in Brooklyn -- a project estimated to cost nearly $300 million.
He said that the only way his agency could have performed appreciably better would have been to proceed with its flawed design for rebuilding the Newtown Creek sewage-treatment plant. And that, Mr. Appleton said, would have made no sense.
The agency also estimated that it would save, during the 12 months of the fiscal year, about $175 million because so many projects were being bid at prices well below what had been anticipated, Mr. Appleton said. That estimated savings, which was realized because competition among contractors drove down bids during the recession, was applied toward a reduction in the overall construction-spending plan.
Projects amounting to an additional $80 million were also removed from the department's list for a variety of reasons, Mr. Appleton said. Among them, he said, was that the department tries to time some water-main projects to coincide with street rebuildings by the city's Department of Transportation, so that streets are torn up only once.
Mr. Appleton's department also moved forward an additional $69 million in projects that had been planned for the current fiscal year, which ends in June 1993, because of the favorable economic climate for construction.
As a result, the department's final goal, a slight modification of the one set in January, called for the agency to let contracts valued at $847 million during the fiscal year that ended last June, Mr. Appleton said.
By the end of June, the department had let $868 million in contracts, and department officials boasted that they had managed to exceed their authorized spending.
But Ms. Holtzman argued that the officials could make that claim only because they had lowered their spending goal by nearly half during the year.
Mr. Appleton said he objected to her suggestion that his department had lowered its spending goal to make itself look good. "The most pernicious thing about this letter is the suggestion that the change from September to January was done deliberately because we were not going to meet our target," Mr. Appleton said of Ms. Holtzman's letter to the Mayor.
He contended that, by adding the $175 million saved because of lower-than-expected construction bids to the $868 million in contracts that were let, spending for the fiscal year exceeded $1 billion. "We had far and away the best construction year in D.E.P.'s history," he said.

HEADLINE: Albania Is Less Violent; Still, Its Economy Festers

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Albania, racked by violent public disorders both before and after democratic elections in March, appears to have halted what was widely perceived as a gradual descent toward anarchy, a senior official of the Tirana Government and American diplomats say.
While bands of robbers still roam the countryside, the recently reorganized police forces have managed to isolate them, using vehicles and communications equipment acquired from Italy, said Bashkim Kopliku, the Minister of the Interior, who is visiting the United States. In an interview, Mr. Kopliku said "public order is not quite good, but it is better." 
 Last winter, a wave of looting swept Albania as hungry villagers sought to augment their meager food supplies. Warehouses were plundered in Kavaje, Durres, Pogradec, Librazhd, Cepan and Lushnje. Then and later, armed gangs robbed citizens and foreigners in Tirana, the capital, and other cities.
Over the summer, the Albanian police were reorganized, including a purge of nearly a third of the 2,600 officers who had served the former Communist Government, Mr. Kopliku said. In the battle against crime, draconian measures were sometimes taken. In June, when two brothers were apprehended after they robbed a family of five of the equivalent of $50 and bludgeoned them to death, they were publicly hanged in Tirana.
Mr. Kopliku, who is also a deputy prime minister, said that under a new law the police can now frisk people on the street for weapons and will begin investigating crimes on the spot instead of leaving that task to special commissions, as was the Communist practice.
The economy of Europe's poorest country remains in bad straits, Mr. Kopliku said, with many industrial plants working at only 5 percent of capacity and unemployment widespread. But agriculture has picked up as a result of privatization of 90 percent of what had been collectivized property during 46 years of Communist rule, according to Mr. Kopliku and to a State Department official.
After a slow start in 1991, United States economic assistance for Albania has picked up. A total of $83 million has been sent so far this year. Among the many aid projects is a shipment of $15 million worth of cotton for milling in a factory outside Berat. This will provide employment for about 15,000 Albanians for the next five months, an Administration official said.
Since Albania began to shed its Stalinist system nearly two years ago, the country has received "next to nothing" in terms of foreign investment, he said. But during a visit to Tirana earlier this month, Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said he saw no serious obstacles to Albanian compliance with the fund's recommendations for economic change.
The political scene under President Sali Berisha, who won overwhelming endorsement in the March elections, has become "tense" as factions in his party vie for power in Parliament, the State Department official said.
One faction is headed by Gramoz Pashko, an economist and a co-founder of the governing Democratic Party with Dr. Berisha. Mr. Pashko and several other members of Parliament this month formed a new party named the Democratic Alliance, in opposition to what they call the "autocratic rule" of Dr. Berisha.

HEADLINE: Venezuela Stable, but Fragile, Since Coup Attempt

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Nine months after an army coup attempt nearly toppled civilian democracy here, Venezuela's paradox endures: Latin America's most muscular economic growth in a country suffering from political jitters.
On the economic side, Venezuela, rich with oil, is still the star of the Americas. 
 Undimmed by the coup attempt, the economy grew by 8.5 percent in the first half of this year, down only slightly from the gain of 10.4 percent in 1991. During the first half of this year, a record $555 million in foreign investment flooded in, four times the level of the corresponding period last year.
"The real surprise is how well the economy has stood up," said Michael M. Skol, the United States Ambassador here. "All the time new companies are coming in. During the last six quarters, Venezuela essentially had the fastest growth rates in the world."
 
A Symbolically Important Trip
 On the political side, President Carlos Andres Perez has weathered bitter opposition in congress, in the streets and in the barracks. A wide range of politicians interviewed here this month predicted that Mr. Perez, whose 70th birthday is Oct. 27, will serve out the last 15 months of his five-year term.
In one sign of stability, Mr. Perez flew this month to Germany for Willy Brandt's funeral. It was the first time the President had been able to leave his country since rebellious Army units tried to kill him on his return from a European trip last February.
"Despite the Feb. 4 uprising, the military's conduct has been in support of the democratic process," the President said in an interview in his palace office, which is still scarred by bullet holes from the coup attempt. "The street protests are being coordinated by small groups who have no support in the neighborhoods."
But scattered terrorist incidents, continued unrest among Army officers and widespread popular antipathy to Mr. Perez make for a tense political climate in Venezuela, which is the second-largest source of oil imports for the United States, after Saudi Arabia.
 
Out of Sight but Not Out of Mind
 Almost weekly, newspapers carry reports of military plots, real or imagined. Though he is still behind bars, the leader of the uprising in February, Lieut. Col. Hugo Chavez Frias, continues to rank as Venezuela's most popular political figure in public opinion polls. (President Perez and his Government regularly get disapproval ratings of 75 percent.)
Nerve-racking incidents abound.
Although the colonel's popularity has ebbed, his image was emblazoned on banners carried earlier this month by hundreds of student protesters here. "CAP out!" the students chanted, referring to the President by his initials.
In the last month, an "anti-corruption commando" shot and wounded a labor leader who had been released on bail on corruption charges and threw a hand grenade in the garden of Blanca Ibinez Lusinchi, the wife of Mr. Perez' predecessor, Jaime Lusinchi. Mrs. Lusinchi, who fled Venezuela to avoid embezzlement charges, won political asylum in Costa Rica last month.
On Oct. 12, the President's bodyguard shot and killed two inebriated Guajiro Indians who were about to crash their pickup truck into a bus carrying the President. In a measure of the nation's jitters, many Venezuelans believed it was an assassination attempt; the bolivar, the nation's currency, promptly lost 6 percent of its value against the dollar.
"It's another example of the Government's lack of credibility," admitted Angel Zambrano, the Information Minister, when asked about his failure to quell the assassination rumor.
 
Apathy Is a Strong Opponent
 Although Mr. Perez promised "big changes" after the coup attempt, Venezuela's political parties remain autocratic and detached from the citizenry, and virtually no one has been jailed for corruption, a problem that scores high among complaints here. While unemployment has dipped in recent months, inflation this year is expected to be about 40 percent, double the Government's target.
The President's political position is particularly fragile in Caracas, a sprawling city of migrants that is home to a quarter of Venezuela's 20 million people. In the last election here, a mayoral contest in December 1989, only 27 percent of eligible voters cast ballots; even fewer are registered as members of political parties.
In February 1989, the alienation was shown in riots after Mr. Perez announced reductions in subsidies for food and gasoline. About 300 people were killed by army troops, a police action that left many officers bitter.
Defenders of civilian rule hope the political calendar will channel frustration to the ballot boxes. Last summer, Mr. Perez narrowly beat back two congressional attempts to cut short his term. With presidential elections scheduled for December 1993, candidacies are already taking shape.
 
Big Names on the Sidelines
 The nation's two most popular figures do not seem likely to win.
Colonel Frias, a nationalist with hazy economic views, is expected to sit out the vote in jail. He now awaits a court-martial on charges of leading the rebellion, which left dozens dead.
Another military uprising is "highly probable," Colonel Frias predicted in a statement smuggled out of jail in August. But Government officials believe the military unrest has been defused through salary increases, changes in command, housing loans, scholarships for overseas study, the strengthening of military intelligence and the appointment of a general to the post of Foreign Minister.
In a series of blunt statements here, visiting Bush Administration officials have warned that a coup would provoke chaos in relations with the United States, the largest single market for Venezuela's oil exports.
Support for Rafael Caldera, a populist who served as President 20 years ago, is not expected to endure: in Venezuela, where half the population is under 30, it seems doubtful that voters will elect a 77-year-old who first ran for President when Harry Truman was in the White House.
Mr. Caldera, who boasts that his ideas on state leadership of the economy have changed little since the late 1950's, seems out of step with trends to liberalize the state-dominated economy. By the end of Mr. Perez's term, the Government plans to privatize about 60 state-owned companies and to open sectors of the state-dominated oil industry to foreign investment.
Indeed, surveys of investor confidence indicate that business people do not believe that the political tension is strong enough to negate the geological fact that Venezuela enjoys the world's largest proven oil reserves outside the Persian Gulf.

HEADLINE: U.S. Funding Gap Widens

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
The gap between Federal spending and revenues widened to a record $290.2 billion in the year ended Sept. 30, the Government said today.
The deficit surpassed by 7.7 percent the previous record of $269.5 billion, reached in fiscal 1991. David Munro of High Frequency Economics, a New York-based consultant, said the first order of business for the new Congress probably would not be a fiscal stimulus package. 
 Rather, it probably will be a measure raising the national debt ceiling from $4.145 trillion, which is likely to be reached during the middle of the January-March quarter.
As high as the 1992 deficit was, it still amounted to far less than the Bush Administration's January forecast of $399.7 billion and was below its mid-July prediction of $333.5 billion.
Economists attributed the better-than-expected performance to a delay in spending on bank and savings institution failures. In the spring, the House voted down a bill that would have authorized the continued operation of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which handles failed savings and loans.
In fiscal 1992, government spending totaled $1.38 trillion and accounted for 23.6 percent of the entire economy. Revenues amounted to $1.09 trillion.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Candidate Perot Might Learn From Strategist Perot

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Looking at the way he has planned his campaign, almost any candidate would long to have Ross Perot as a campaign manager. But few handlers would like to have him as a candidate.
As a tactician, Mr. Perot has devised a campaign strategy that focuses a strong, clear message on the economy and using his vast financial resources to get that message out through paid advertising. At the same time he has minimized his weaknesses, limiting time on the stump where he can be a rambling, awkward speaker and, for the most part, keeping away from reporters who tend to draw out his white-hot temper. 
 As a candidate, however, he ignited a distracting controversy with accusations that Republican operatives sought to besmirch his daughter Carolyn and disrupt her wedding.
In addition, he has allowed himself to become the flame that attracts the likes of Scott Barnes, a proponent of unsubstantiated tales of worldwide conspiracies, who drew Mr. Perot into an unseemly attempt to entrap a top Texas Republican.
 
Erring With Flair
 Indeed, at times there seems to be two Ross Perots.
"He's a good strategist and tactician," said Frank I. Luntz, a poll taker who worked for Mr. Perot in the first phase of his campaign. "He's got about a 90 percent success rate. The best political strategists have about a 70 percent success rate. But the problem is that the 1 in 10 mistake is usually big."
Even associates of Mr. Perot acknowledge that his interview on "60 Minutes," where he made the assertions of Republican "dirty tricks," and his surprise appearance at a news conference here on Monday, where he repeated the accusations, were errors that a smart campaign manager would not have allowed to occur.
Yet it is difficult to separate Ross Perot the campaign manager from Ross Perot the candidate. Moreover, even when Mr. Perot had veteran political strategists like Edward J. Rollins and Hamilton Jordan advising him, the strong-willed billionaire did not listen to them.
 
Sure-Footed Ad Campaign
 When Mr. Perot got back into the race, many political professionals felt that without seasoned political strategists to advise him, he would fall flat on his face. He did not.
In the 28 days since his return Mr. Perot has done a masterly job in rehabilitating his image and clawing his way back into the Presidential race. His commercials have created enough of a sense of urgency over the national debt to make a vote for an independent candidate seem perhaps the only way to avert a crisis. His half-hour programs on the economy, complete with charts, seem authentic and appealing to voters weary of the mudslinging of the other candidates.
He injected himself into the three Presidential debates, where he seemed a refreshingly unrehearsed alternative to President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton. And he has spent $34.8 million on advertising, broadcasting many of his commercials during sports events like the World Series and Monday Night Football. These shows not only have high ratings, but their audience is primarily men, a group more receptive to Mr. Perot's can-do image.
"During the month of October, he moved from 7 percent to 20 percent in the polls, and his negatives continued to fall," Mr. Luntz said. "That's the biggest run in such a short time that any independent candidate has ever had."
But Mr. Perot the tactician, has, at times, been tripped up by Mr. Perot the candidate. His biggest mistake may have occurred over the weekend, when he publicly asserted that the Republicans were plotting against his daughter and planning to wiretap his telephones.
 
Distracting From Message
 The story about his daughter, for which he has yet to offer any proof, may have helped him with some voters by banishing the image of Mr. Perot as a quitter who abruptly left the race in July because he could not take the heat. Here is a man, some voters may reason, who was willing to give up his goal to protect his family.
But by not coming forward with corroboration from a credible source, Mr. Perot not only risks his own veracity, he reinforces the image of a man willing to make seemingly wild accusations on the slimmest of evidence.
Mr. Perot's involvement in an undercover operation to offer stolen information to Jim Oberwetter, head of the Bush campaign in Texas, also creates an image of a man who would stop at nothing to destroy a political rival. "He talks about his family," an indignant Mr. Oberwetter said today. "I have one, too. And my three daughters don't want to see their daddy in jail."
The charges and countercharges have also shifted the focus of the Dallas billionaire's campaign away from his core economic message. In recent days Mr. Perot's aides have vainly tried to turn news stories back to the issues. Nonetheless, his rise in the polls appears to have stalled.
Ross Perot the strategist seems to have gauged well the public mood. He has discerned that many voters have become fed up with the usual brand of incumbents and blow-dried candidates. Even as he obfuscates, he has created an aura of himself as a straight-shooter who speaks his mind. But as a candidate, he doesn't seem to know, or seems incapable of knowing when to stop.
"It has a lot to do with when he uses his head or uses his heart," said Mr. Luntz. "When Ross Perot uses his head, he's unbeatable. He's focused, straightforward and compelling. When he uses his heart, sometimes his emotions get carried away."

HEADLINE: Florio Offers Plan to Pay Health Costs

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTH BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 28

 BODY:
Facing a 30-day deadline for changing the way New Jersey pays for its uninsured residents' health coverage, Gov. Jim Florio today proposed subsidizing private health-care groups like health maintenance organizations to cover those residents.
But Mr. Florio left it to legislators to find a way to pay for the new coverage. New Jersey's present method of financing health care for the uninsured -- a surcharge on the insurance bills of those who can afford to pay -- has been struck down by the courts, and the Governor and legislative leaders have agreed to end it by Nov. 30. 
 Mr. Florio said his plan would enable thousands of uninsured New Jersey residents to buy insurance while reducing the cost of providing health services.
 
Cheaper Family Coverage
 His plan would cover the costs of preventive care items like immunizations, as well as primary care expenses like doctor's visits and tests, hospitalization and prescriptions. Mr. Florio wants working families who are squeezed out of the health insurance market by premiums up of to $6,000 a year to be able to obtain coverage from a state-sponsored system for $1,260 a year.
"Our exclusive reliance on hospitals as the health care provider for people without insurance is bad medicine and bad economics," Mr. Florio told a symposium of the New Jersey Public Health Association here. "We can't solve our health-care crisis just by pouring money into a broken system. Money spent on prevention and keeping well is a much better investment than money spent the way we spend it now."
Mr. Florio wants to borrow a page from the system Hawaii has been using for 20 years, which provides coverage for 98 percent of all state residents. But Hawaii can require businesses to cover employees because its law was enacted before a more restrictive Federal statute.
Mr. Florio said many elements of his proposed plan, known as New Jersey Shield, still must be worked out. But he said he wants to shift away from an exclusive reliance on hospitals as the health care providers for the uninsured to a new system that assigns such residents to a "primary care giver." That could be a local physician or a community health center.
 
Emphasis on Prevention
 "It will be a managed-care system where the emphasis will be on prevention and primary care, not a system that waits for an emergency," he said.
The new system, Mr. Florio said, would not replace the private health insurance market, Medicaid or Medicare, but "will complete the health-care umbrella" for working people and those temporarily without jobs. He said it would bridge the gap between what they can afford and what a good managed-care program costs. He said the state would not get into the insurance business itself, but would contract with existing providers of managed care.
Under New Jersey Shield, "gatekeepers" would guard against unnecessary tests or treatment. Insurers would be chosen by bid through the state, with three or four options available to patients in each county.
Subsidies would be provided on a sliding scale to uninsured workers, people who are temporarily unemployed and those in part-time or seasonal jobs.
For example, a family of four making $33,500 a year would pay $105 a month, with the state paying the remainder of whatever the cost turns out to be. Those making above 300 percent of the Federal poverty level, or $40,020 for a family of four, would not be eligible for subsidies. They could still buy into the plan at full price.
To pay for the plan, Mr. Florio said he would sign any revenue-raising measure passed by the State House "within reason," as long as it also included two reforms he wants -- a requirement that all insurance companies insure everyone who asks for coverage, and that rates be fixed so that everyone pays the same premium, regardless of age, gender, residence or past medical history.
Mr. Florio, a Democrat, said "it would be folly" for the Republican-controlled legislature to send him a revenue-raising measure without the reforms he asked for, since they would reduce the cost of insurance.
 
Concern in the State House
 Brenda Bacon, Chief of Management and Planning for the Governor, said the reforms could cut the number of uninsured residents from 800,000 to between 400,000 and 500,000. She said the cost of subsidizing their managed care under Mr. Florio's plan would be about $450 million, or about $300 million less than the present system.
Donald Sica, the executive director of the General Assembly said he did not know whether New Jersey could emulate Hawaii's system. "But even if it should work, and we haven't been told enough to make a judgment," he said, "it wouldn't begin until Jan. 1, 1994, and has nothing to do with our immediate problem" of replacing the hospital surcharge.
A standard benefits package under the proposed system would include preventive care -- immunizations and screenings, for example -- with no co-payments or deductible; primary care -- prenatal care, physical exams, well-child care, family planning and diagnostic tests -- with no deductible, no co-payments for the first two visits and $5 payments for subsequent visits; emergency room visits with a $25 co-payment; prescription drugs with a $3 co-payment, and hospitalization with a $200 deductible and a 20 percent co-payment up to $1,000 limit for those below 250 percent of the poverty level and up to $5,000 for everyone else.
Marvin Rubin, the president of the New Jersey Public Health Association, called the Governor's program a good start toward reform, but added: "I personally feel we have to go further." Dr. Rubin said he favored a single-payer system for all health care services, but said that is probably not politically feasible.

HEADLINE: Durable-Goods Orders Fall As Personal Incomes Climb

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Issuing the latest in a series of inconclusive economic reports, the Commerce Department said today that new orders for durable manufactured goods eased four-tenths of 1 percent in September, while personal incomes climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Economists cautioned against taking either report at face value, saying the orders were stronger than they appeared, while the income figures were weaker. The reports followed Tuesday's report that the economy expanded at a 2.7 percent annual pace in the summer quarter, compared with 1.5 percent in the spring, a pace analysts considered unsustainable. 
 The decline in orders, a widely followed but volatile indicator of future factory activity, was the third in a row. Such a string of declines has not occurred since the first quarter of 1991, when the economy was clearly in recession.
Nonetheless, economists were mildly heartened today to see that orders rose five-tenths of 1 percent when military goods are excluded and jumped 4.1 percent for nonmilitary capital goods, a gauge of business investment. Moreover, shipments of durable goods, defined as those intended to last at least three years, rose 1.4 percent, reversing a two-month decline.
"Over all I'd say it's a weakish report, but there were some positives," said Ian Borsook, an economist for Merrill Lynch & Company.
At the same time, analysts continued to be disturbed by a persistent erosion in unfilled orders, the backlogs that sustain current operations. These fell 1.3 percent last month, the 13th straight decline, to the lowest overall level since December 1988. Backlogs also fell nine-tenths of 1 percent with military business excluded.
"The divergent components of the orders data indicate pockets of strength and weakness, and in this respect only further cloud an economic situation that was already murky," said Gordon Richards, economist for the National Association of Manufacturers. He predicted "continued stagnation" in the current quarter "as consumption slows down again."
The main contributor to the $500 million order decline, to $118.9 billion, was an 8.4 percent drop for aircraft and other transportation equipment. The smaller primary metals sector slumped 10.2 percent, the biggest loss since March 1989. Military orders dropped 15.7 percent, to $5.4 billion, the report also showed.
Partly offsetting these, however, were a 5.6 percent gain for electrical machinery and a 2.3 percent gain for non-electrical machinery.
 
Distorted by Weather
 Today's income and spending figures were distorted by the weather, which obscured what economists said was essential flatness. The Department said the rebound in personal income from the effects of Hurricane Andrew, which hit Florida and Louisiana in August, more than offset declines attributed to Hurricane Iniki, which hit Hawaii in September.
This produced the seven-tenths of 1 percent increase in incomes, to an annual rate of $5.08 trillion, the biggest advance since December. Consumer spending climbed by the same percentage, to $4.12 trillion, the biggest rise since January. Both income and spending eased two-tenths of 1 percent in August.
Among the hurricanes' effects for which the Department made adjustments were the loss of rental and proprietors' income from uninsured losses to homes and businesses, wages lost from work disruptions and losses from crop damage. September's rise in income also benefited from subsidy payments to farmers.
Without the hurricane-related adjustments and the subsidy payments, personal income edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in September, compared with a six-tenths of 1 percent increase in August, the Department said.
Both income and spending last month, after hurricane adjustment "were weak, even though at first glance the data appear strong," declared Marilyn Schaja, an economist for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "Wage and salary income actually fell."
The seven-tenths of 1 percent rise in consumer spending resulted from a 1.2 percent increase for services -- 57 percent of the total -- a nine-tenths of 1 percent increase for durable goods and a two-tenths of 1 percent decline for nondurables.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail;
And What of the Also-Rans? Most Act Like Good Sports

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr.

 BODY:
Before the 1992 campaign finally ends, here's a catch-up on what's doing with the candidates who got left in the dust of the spring primaries and caucuses:
Most are being good political sports and working for their party's nominee. But not all. 
 On the Republican side, Patrick J. Buchanan, the hard-right commentator, has spent most of the last two months on the road, telling crowds that he and President Bush still have their differences but that the President is nevertheless the best bet for conservatives -- until 1996.
Among the Democrats trampled by Gov. Bill Clinton on his way to Madison Square Garden, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia is working black voters for Mr. Clinton in key states like Michigan and Florida. Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa is working liberal Democrats, especially big labor in the Middle West. And Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska is mostly working to send more Democrats to the Senate, although he throws in a pitch for Mr. Clinton at the end of each appearance.
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts is out there saying he supports Mr. Clinton. But mostly he talks about the failure of both Mr. Clinton and President Bush to come up with an economic plan that suits his bite-the-bullet philosophy.
And then there's former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California.
He's still out there, too, campaigning to the beat of his own drum, still warning that special interests are taking over America. He says he'll vote Democratic on Nov. 3, but hardly ever mentions Mr. Clinton's name.
Why? "He hasn't asked for my help," he explains.
 
If It's Tuesday, It Must Be Heaven
 This is the point in Presidential campaigns when candidates begin to slip, exhausted, into a political twilight zone in which days and states and towns and airports and crowds become one big jumble.
Proof?
On Tuesday, President Bush flew into Kentucky, one of three states on his schedule that day, for a rally at Paducah Community College. Some 15,000 people were there to greet him. It went like this:
President: "Let me just say at the outset, I'm very pleased to be here -- and then back again -- back for me in this great part of. . .of. . ."
Crowd: "Kentucky!"
President: "I was going to say, of western Kentucky. It makes you agree with the guy who said, 'Heaven is a Kentucky kind of place.' "
 
Clinton Is Spurned By Arkansas Daily
 In the race for newspaper endorsements:
The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette, the largest daily in Governor Clinton's home state, says it will maintain its tradition of not endorsing Presidential candidates, even a home-grown candidate. Never a great Clinton fan, the paper said in an editorial published yesterday:
"Bill Clinton is a master politician, but what principles, if any, inform his politics? Who knows? And if we don't know, how can we recommend him to America as a leader?"
On the other hand, the Governor has won the endorsement of The Phillipian, the student newspaper at Phillips Academy, the Massachusetts prep school that President Bush attended.
Mr. Bush did win, with reservations, an endorsement from The New York Post, which cited in an editorial today his "acute understanding of how the world works."
 
On Long Shots And Dark Horses
 There are polls. And then there is Ladbrokes.
The London betting house, self-proclaimed "World's Largest Bookmaker," has just changed the odds on the Bush-Clinton-Perot race. Those on the President have been cut from 3-to-1 to 5-to-2, while those on Mr. Clinton have gone from 1-to-6 to 1-to-4. Mr. Perot remains at 20-to-1.

HEADLINE: Dow Advances 15.67 in Broad-Based Rally

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks closed higher yesterday, buoyed by bargain hunting, but trading remained cautious ahead of the Presidential election.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 15.67, to close at 3,251.40. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 203.9 million shares, compared with 201.7 million on Tuesday. In the broad market, gainers pulled ahead of declining issues 1,016 to 732. 
 Investors tended to focus on companies reporting quarterly results, and some bought in anticipation of a stronger market next week because of the election.
Big names, including International Business Machines, General Motors, Ford and McDonnell Douglas were featured stocks.
Secondary stocks had a strong day, with the Nasdaq index ending up 4.44 points, at 601.39.
Two economic reports offered mixed news. Durable-goods orders for September fell four-tenths of 1 percent, but both personal income and consumption rose seven-tenths of 1 percent.
In general, analysts said they sensed a better tone to the economy, a factor that should bode well for the stock market.
"There is some evidence the economy is doing better," said Gerald Simmons at Interstate/Johnson Lane. "I think that's reflected in the fact we are holding here pretty well."
After the close of stock trading, Cable News Network said President Bush has pulled nearly even with Gov. Bill Clinton in a new poll.
Philip Orlando, equity portfolio manager at Unity Management, said very selective buying was helping to buoy stocks. "You see the market drifting, with individual stocks reacting to specific announcements."
He noted that Monsanto gained 1, to 55, after news that it would repurchase some of its stock, while Du Pont was up5/8, to 48 7/8, after releasing good earnings.
Shares of Life Re Corporation, a new issue, surged to 24 7/8, up from its offering price of 22 a share. The company is a Connecticut-based reinsurance company.
Genzyme Corporation sank 3 5/8, to 39 3/8. It reported third-quarter profits that were below expectations. Smith Barney lowered its earnings estimates on the company for 1992 through 1995.
General Motors continued its losses, dropping 1, to 31 3/8; worries that it may cut its dividend have plagued the stock. Ford slipped 1 3/4, to 38 1/8, after posting a 43-cent-a-share loss in the third quarter.
I.B.M. rebounded slightly, gaining 1 3/8, to 67 1/8.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 1.64, to 420.13. The American Stock Exchange index gained 2.35, to 379.00.

HEADLINE: Nicaraguan Chief Warns General

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 28

 BODY:
President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro threatened today to dismiss her military chief, Gen. Humberto Ortega Saavedra, after he declared his intention to lead the Nicaraguan Army until 1997.
Mrs. Chamorro accused General Ortega -- brother of the former Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega Saavedra, a leader of the rival Sandinistas -- of overstepping his authority and said he could be removed from his job "tomorrow, day after tomorrow or at any moment" on her decision. 
 "Mr. Ortega can say what he wants," Mrs. Chamorro said. "But I want to make clear that he cannot be there until 1997. He can't say that, because he is only the head of the army and the one who makes the decisions here is me."
General Ortega declared on Tuesday that he would resist attempts by critics to replace him and that he intended to remain head of the army until 1997, when a "professionalization" campaign would be completed.
He also said he would not permit the military, which once had 100,000 troops but now has only 18,500, to be further reduced.
Critics here and elsewhere, especially Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, have called for General Ortega to step down because of his ties to the leftist Sandinista Government led by his brother. Mr. Helms asserts that General Ortega's presence gives the Sandinistas too much power and has prevented Government reforms. The conservative Senator's ability to hold up United States financial aid to Nicaragua prompted Mrs. Chamorro to visit Europe to ask for money to help ease her country's growing economic problems.
