HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Advertisements;
Volleys of Data Replace Blatant Attacks of 1988

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
In a striking and unnoticed departure from the more blatant attack commercials that ruled in 1988, the Presidential campaigns this year are loading their advertisements with statistics and attribution in more subtle efforts to stretch the truth.
The advertising this year is just as tough, but it seeks to appear more credible by giving the impression that it depends on documentation and third-party sources. Instead of having the candidate or the announcer launch a direct assault, many ads are no nonsense and even dull, quoting newspapers and ordinary-looking citizens. 
 Several ads were deliberately made to look amateurish, with hand-held cameras and images out of focus, to fight any impression of slickness. Candidates have also sought to suggest they have substantive programs when they do not by closing their ads with '800' numbers people can call to get copies of their issue blueprints.
 
Longer and More Detailed
 In another effort to give the impression the candidates are long on substance, the campaigns have produced longer-running ads. Ross Perot has drawn large audiences with his 30- and 60-minute "infomercials," which may have led President Bush's campaign this week to begin broadcasting two-minute commercials.
"The obsession in ads this year is crystal-clear messages on both sides," said Henry Sheinkopf, a veteran Democratic consultant. "People want real information because they don't trust us. They don't trust the system. The ads are information laden."
Frank Greer, who produces Gov. Bill Clinton's advertising, said, "We've got a whole team of people we call the fact checkers. There's a new standard for honesty."
But as Kathleen Hall Jamieson, dean of the Annenberg School of Communication at the University of Pennsylvania, noted, raw facts do not always make for honest advertising. "This is the year," she said, "in which form is being confused with substance, and the candidates are getting away with it."
While there have been few blatant inaccuracies, many ads this year go out of their way to convey believability even as they sometimes play with the facts.
 
Citing News Media
 The Clinton and Bush campaigns have both turned to Time Magazine for credibility in their commercials. As the names of economists who back the Governor's fiscal remedies scroll on the screen, a Clinton ad unveiled today also states that an independent panel convened by Time concluded that he has the best economic solutions. The Bush campaign turned to Time for one of the harshest ads of the season: With foreboding background music, the ad featured a cover of the magazine that had an ominous-looking photo negative of Mr. Clinton with the headline, "Why Voters Don't Trust Clinton."
These are some other examples:
*A Bush commercial features working-class people saying how much more in taxes they would have to pay if Mr. Clinton becomes President. The ad invited viewers to identify with the people making the charges because they were portrayed as ordinary citizens. And although it makes several disputed assumptions about the Democrat's economic plan, it cannot be branded clearly false because it is hard to refute a projection about the future.
*A Clinton commercial shows clips of Mr. Bush making rosy pronouncements about the economy, while an announcer tells viewers how each of Mr. Bush's predictions did not come true. The facts are correct, but they do not always support the conclusion because they are taken out of context. The ad is made to appear credible by mimicking a news broadcast; the announcer has a neutral voice and the facts are attributed on the screen.
*A Perot commercial features sentences that crawl across the screen to suggest substance, and that the Texas billionaire has the know-how to reduce the national debt. But nowhere does the ad say how Mr. Perot would grapple with the deficit, nor does it mention his controversial prescription of higher taxes and cuts in entitlement programs.
 
Ads Getting More Scrutiny
 The campaigns are working so hard to sell credibility because they perceive that the public regards political ads as dishonest and nasty. The campaigns also are mindful that the press has been analyzing commercials with intensified vigilance this year. (The Bush campaign today showered reporters with 35 pages of documentation to back up its latest ad bashing Mr. Clinton; the Clinton campaign retaliated with a seven-page rebuttal.)
As John Carroll, a Boston ad consultant and public radio commentator put it, "Statistics can lie, but from a perception standpoint, it goes down better with the public if you have attribution."
Nevertheless, the latest New York Times/CBS Poll shows that the public is still deeply skeptical of political commercials. In the survey, based on nationwide interviews with 1,467 registered voters from Oct. 20 to Oct. 23, about 7 out of 10 voters said they had seen political commercials in the previous week.
But only 18 percent said the Clinton ads were "almost all truthful," and 19 percent said the Bush ads were. Though most voters doubted Mr. Perot's ads as well, they were viewed as more credible. Thirty-seven percent said the Perot ads were "almost all truthful." The poll has a sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Mr. Perot's ads may seem more credible because they are the most straightforward, and they refrain from attacks. But some analysts say it is because Mr. Perot has been brushed off as having little chance to win and thus has not been subjected to prolonged, critical press coverage or to sustained attacks from Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton.
"The one person whose advertising has had the greatest likelihood of impact is Perot," Ms. Jamieson said. Until his accusations this week of "dirty tricks" by Republicans, she said, Mr. Perot's "claims were left unchallenged, so there was no conflicting information in the news environment that questioned the guy with a pointer and all the statistics in his ads."
While it is difficult at this stage to determine what ads have been most effective, this much seems clear: with candidates' faces plastered all over the talks shows and with a public that distrusts commercials, paid political advertising has played a secondary role in shaping the campaign dialogue.
"Because there is so much accessibility in the news area of media," said Sig Rogich, who directs the Bush campaign's advertising effort, "if you see any surge for the President, I think it comes directly from the President, and the ads take a second seat."
That has not stopped the campaigns from pouring every cent they can -- probably as much as $100 million in all before the general election is over -- into selling their candidates.
The Times/CBS News poll shows that the commercials this season have reinforced peoples' attitudes about candidates but have done little to sway their votes. Forty-one percent of the voters said the ads had made them more confident that they had chosen the right candidate.
But fifty-five percent said the Bush ads would have no effect on their vote; 52 percent said the Clinton ads would have no effect, and 49 percent said that of the Perot ads.
Dean Alger, a political science professor at Moorhead State University in Minnesota, said the public distrust was evident again and again recently when undecided voters were asked to view the latest ads in the Presidential race.
In a typical response to ads of all three candidates, one viewer concluded after watching an ad portraying Mr. Clinton as a successful Governor: "The ad was impressive if the facts were accurate." Then, after watching a Clinton commercial that attacked Mr. Bush, he wrote, "The second ad was too negative, tearing down other candidate rather than telling about himself."

LENGTH: 1595 words

HEADLINE: Silicon Valley Takes a Partisan Leap of Faith

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Two months ago, a roomful of the nation's top high-technology executives met for dinner at the ranch of Apple Computer's chairman, John Sculley, to discuss something most of these lifelong Republicans never thought they would: supporting a Democrat, Gov. Bill Clinton, in the Presidential election.
Over poached salmon at Mr. Sculley's 15-acre spread in Woodside, Calif., the executives expressed a general frustration with the economic policies of President Bush and ultimately agreed to endorse Mr. Clinton. Though perhaps somewhat skeptical that any politician would make good on campaign promises, many were impressed that Mr. Clinton had held private meetings with them to help formulate a national technology policy. Many of them also believed his pledge to promote the resulting plan: form a partnership between business and the Federal Government to revive the economy and make critical industries, particularly in high technology, more competitive. 
 "I am still a Republican but I am voting for Bill Clinton because I don't believe America's industries can survive four more years of President Bush," Mr. Sculley said in an interview. "Clinton asked us to develop a technology policy for him, and that was refreshing, because he not only embraced a lot of the ideas we put forth but we believe he really plans to implement them."
Mr. Clinton has made high technology a core of his campaign to "get America growing again," and he has used that platform to cultivate important executives who not only would help with fund-raising but would enhance his credibility on economic and business issues.
Mr. Clinton has frequently cited such support on the campaign trail and referred to it several times during the Presidential debates. Last month, the Clinton camp made public a list of about 400 corporate executives who have endorsed the Democratic ticket of Mr. Clinton and Senator Al Gore. About 10 percent of these executives manage high-tech companies, and many of them supported Mr. Bush in the last election.
"Our primary objective was to show the American public that if long-term, tough-minded, Republican business leaders would go against their norm and go with Clinton, then there's no way he's a traditional tax-and-spend Democrat," said Ellis Mottur, director of business and high-tech constituencies for the Clinton campaign. "We figured that an endorsement by respected chief executives, whose judgment people trust, would give us that extra level of credibility, and we feel we have succeeded."
Bush's High-Tech Roster
The high-tech endorsements would seem to have put President Bush on the defensive. In mid-October, the Bush campaign released its own list of about 75 high-tech industry leaders who it said have endorsed the President's re-election. But the Bush response on high-tech was hastily arranged and not well coordinated, officials with the President's campaign acknowledge privately.
The Bush list includes such high-tech luminaries as Robert E. Allen, chief executive of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company; John F. Akers, chief executive of the International Business Machines Corporation, and John F. Welch Jr., chief executive of the General Electric Corporation.
In a round of telephone calls to nearly half the executives on the list, most would not come to the phone to discuss their endorsement. In fact, some of their spokesmen said the Bush list had come as a surprise to their bosses.
In some instances, top senior executives who have come out for Governor Clinton find themselves at odds with executives within their companies who support Mr. Bush. For example, John A. Young, president and chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, who has voted Republican his entire adult life, has said he endorsed Mr. Clinton because he believes the Governor "understands business and technology and the need for a motivated, highly skilled work force."
But David Packard, the company's chairman, favors Mr. Bush, saying in a statement: "Clinton talks about the future, but his ideas come from the past -- and his tax proposals will kill America's technology companies."
Mr. Young is chairman of an independent research group called the Council on Competitiveness, which has made recommendations to the Bush Administration over the years, without much result. Mr. Packard, in a recent interview, offered a possible explanation of why Mr. Young would support the Democratic candidate: if Mr. Clinton is elected, Mr. Young would have a chance at becoming head of the Commerce Department.
But Mr. Young would not be interviewed, and a Hewlett-Packard official, Robert C. Kirkwood, said, "Mr. Young is not in the business of accepting positions he has not been offered."
Meanwhile, in more than two dozen interviews with top business leaders who have come out in support of Governor Clinton, most of the executives said they believed he offered the greatest hope for economic change, particularly in working with the Democratic-controlled Congress.
"Candidates promise a lot of things when they are campaigning, so I guess we are taking a huge risk with Bill Clinton," said the chair-man of the Compaq Computer Corporation, Ben Rosen, who has voted for Republicans for the last 20 years. "But when you look at getting legislation passed that will stimulate the economy," he said, "Clinton has a much better chance of getting it through Congress than Bush."
The executives backing Mr. Clinton said that judging by the nation's persistent recession and sagging competitiveness, Mr. Bush is a failed chief executive who in their view has no plan or vision for reversing the country's economic downturn. And they said they were deeply troubled by the strong right-wing sentiments expressed at the Republican convention.
Economic dissatisfaction is perhaps felt most strongly in the high-tech industries, which have lost market share to foreign competitors inareas like computer chips and consumer electronics. High-tech executives say they are angry at the Bush Administration for not vigorously enforcing trade laws penalizing foreign companies that sell products below cost in this country and for refusing on ideological grounds to help American industry become more competitive with foreign rivals that receive assistance from their governments.
"Almost all of us in the high-tech area have faced intense competition from foreign firms, and the only way we can respond is for business and government to work together the way they do overseas," said Paul A. Allaire, chief executive of the Xerox Corporation. "Bill Clinton has indicated his willingness to do this, where Bush has not."
Jerry K. Pearlman, chairman and chief executive of the Zenith Electronics Corporation, the only American-owned maker of television sets, said he was supporting Mr. Clinton because he believes the Governor will aggressively enforce trade laws that prohibit dumping by foreign competitors.
"We have been jerked around by the Reagan and Bush Administrations for too long," Mr. Pearlman said. "Our industry has been devastated by dumped products from abroad because they refused to enforce the laws. If you ignore the laws because the State Department or Treasury or Defense says don't pick on our friends, then that's forcing business to go to the plate with both hands tied behind your back."
At the heart of Mr. Clinton's national technology policy, forged with the help of industry leaders, is the belief that the Federal Government must play a larger role in shaping industries and markets because most foreign countries now help their businesses to compete more effectively. To achieve that goal, Mr. Clinton proposes a variety of programs, including tax cuts for start-up companies and tax credits to prod existing companies to pursue target technologies and to offset research and development costs.
The policy calls for investing in so-called "21st-century infrastructure," like a high-speed data highway that would enable companies to collaborate on research and design and help doctors across the country to share medical expertise. The Clinton plan also includes skills training for all American workers and a shift from military research and development to civilian programs.
"The nice thing about these policies is that they are not only good for our industries but the nation as a whole because of their long-term impact." said Dick Brass, president of the Oracle Data Publishing unit of the software company Oracle Systems. Mr. Brass helped draft the technology policy and persuade executives to support Mr. Clinton.
 
Free-Market Critics
 But critics of the Clinton plan say that attempts by a centralized bureaucracy to manage industries ultimately fail because government is untrustworthy and inefficient. They support a free-market approach, leaving companies to their own devices and their own best instincts.
"This partnership idea is pretty fuzzy, and I'm not sure that the answer to our success is to imitate Europe and Japan," said James A. Abrahamson, who is chairman of Oracle Systems and has endorsed Mr. Bush. "Let the market decide, not people with bureaucratic judgment."
Jeremy Shane, deputy issues adviser for the Bush campaign, said the President believed that the Federal Government should support only very expensive basic research, like supercomputing, leaving development of specific technologies to the free market.
Mr. Shane attributed Mr. Clinton's inroads among high-tech executives to the deteriorating California economy and to the Governor's adept presentation.

LENGTH: 1143 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Profile;
Divining Clinton's Gut-Level Strategy

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
When the subject turned to the talking heads on television who were proclaiming the Presidential race over as soon as the debates were, James Carville narrowed his eyes into angry little slits. He grabbed the basketball sitting near his desk at the center of the Clinton campaign "war room," clutched it with both hands like a man planning to do violence to a ripe melon, and started to sputter.
"I'm mortified, mortified, mortified, mortified," said Mr. Carville, the Clinton campaign's chief strategist, diviner and spiritual center. "It just drives me crazy. Every piece of hot air, pontifical wisdom that's come out over the past year has been wrong. I'm not nervous. It's more like gripping fear." 
 Mr. Carville, whose reaction reflected both his political instincts and his superstitions, has seen his anxiety inch up as the race has tightened. But it is not just because the stakes are enormous for his candidate. If Mr. Clinton is elected Nov. 3, perhaps the only thing more remarkable than his rise from little-known Arkansas Governor to President will be Mr. Carville's rise from a struggling, third-tier political consultant a few years back to the nation's hottest political strategist.
 
Honed Attack in Pennsylvania
 Democrats and Republicans alike say the Presidential campaign was defined by last year's Pennsylvania Senate campaign, when Mr. Carville brought Harris Wofford to victory from a 47-point deficit against former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh in a race that depicted Mr. Thornburgh's ties to the Bush Administration as evidence of an out-of-touch creature of Washington. Mr. Carville went directly from there to the fledgling Clinton campaign.
Mr. Carville prudently disclaimed any pivotal personal role, but added: "The Wofford race is to this year's cycle in politics sort of what John the Baptist was to Christianity."
Whether the Presidential race will follow the Wofford script now seems open to question. But at least two things are clear about the 48-year-old Mr. Carville.
The first is that, as Lee Atwater once did for the Republicans, Mr. Carville has tapped into the gut of the electorate better than anyone else this year. The second is that beneath the wild-man image is a shrewd, sophisticated marketer who has crafted a deceptively rough-hewn image for himself as skillfully as he runs campaigns.
"Do I think I'm Chauncey the Gardener? No," said Mr. Carville, whose demonic smile, personal eccentricities and much-publicized romance with the Bush campaign spokeswoman, Mary Matalin, have made him a political celebrity. "But the idea that I'm a half-quart low has always worked to my advantage, has always kept the opposition just a little bit off guard, so I've never done much to contradict it."
Still, Mr. Carville's core can be discerned from the pictures of Louisiana's populist dynamo brothers Huey P. and Earl K. Long hanging from the blinds just above the 11 jars of Chef Dan's barbecue sauce stacked neatly on his desk.
"Our national pastime isn't baseball; it's politics," said Gus Weill, the dean of Louisiana political consultants, who gave Mr. Carville his start. "Where every little boy in other states wants to be Joe Dimaggio or Willie Mays, here he wants to Huey Long."
In truth, a decadelong recession and last year's Russian roulette Governor's race between Gov. Buddy Roemer, Edwin W. Edwards and David Duke, the former Klansman, have taken much of the fun out of Louisiana politics. But the response-a-minute, gut-level politics and theatrical blend of artifice and reality that define Louisiana politics define Mr. Carville as well.
His political career began in his teens as a bit player for raffish Louisiana politicians like Price LeBlanc, A.K.A. "The Tradin' Country Boy," a car dealer and unsuccessful state legislative candidate who ran under the Elvis-inspired slogan, "I want you, I need you, and I'll fight for you."
Mr. Carville stumbled through Louisiana State University in seven years, interrupted by a stint in the Marines, graduated from law school, and halfheartedly practiced law before hooking up with Mr. Weill in 1980.
He went out on his own in 1982, skating on the edge of oblivion until engineering a comeback victory for Robert Casey in his 1986 race for Pennsylvania Governor against William Scranton.
After the Wofford race, he was courted by most of the Democratic Presidential candidates and settled on Mr. Clinton, because, he says, he liked him.
"When I pick a candidate I've got to live in the same foxhole with him for a year," he said. "You've got to smell their breath a lot."
No one suggests Mr. Carville alone has shaped the hydra-headed Clinton campaign. And even his contributions can be hard to separate from his partner Paul Begala, who plays the benign Dr. Jekyll to Mr. Carville's Mr. Hyde.
But it is clear Mr. Carville has guided the Clinton campaign in two main ways: first by sharpening the campaign's strategy of immediate response to any charges; second by focusing the campaign's message and making sure it stays focused. With Mr. Clinton's advantage dwindling, however, he could face criticism that the tight focus turned into sitting on a lead.
Mr. Carville, like most of his peers, is not given to lofty philosophizing about what he does.
"I'm the tail," he said. "The candidate's the dog."
But he said he thinks, win or lose, this year's election will have a beneficial effect on politics.
"I think when it's written about, this is going to be a kind of campaign that's signaled not just a change in the way we govern, but in the way we run for office," he said. "I think campaigns are going to be a lot more information driven, and people are going to be dealing more directly with voters."
As for Mr. Carville's own future, three questions loom.
QUESTION #1 What will he do next? Having already said he would not want to live in a country that would employ him in Government, he plans to contemplate nature, lecture, cook and work for the re-election of Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey. He and some friends speculate, only half in jest, about teaching at L.S.U.
QUESTION #2 When the race ends, will he and Mary Matalin ride off into the sunset? Since Dr. Joyce Brothers has already stated that the relationship can work, he says he thinks it can too. So does his mother, Miss Nippy Carville, author of a Cajun cookbook. "She's beautiful, lovely, intelligent," she said of Ms. Matalin.
QUESTION #3 What will his pre-election superstition be? During the Wofford race, Mr. Carville wore the same underwear (washed at night, he now claims) during the campaign's final week rather than break up favorable campaign karma. This time, he is still searching. "I've gotten up on the other side of bed, worn my clothes inside out, but nothing has sort of struck me yet," he said warily. "You can't force it."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Gain on a Presidential Poll

BYLINE: JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Like a sailboat picking up a sudden gust, the bond market got a second wind just before trading finished in New York yesterday. The late action left the market a little higher on the day, with the price of the 30-year bond up 3/32 , to yield 7.6 percent, down from 7.61 percent Tuesday.
The late finish was powered by the results of a new Cable News Network poll which showed that the Presidential race had narrowed to 40 percent for Gov. Bill Clinton and 38 percent for President Bush. With a margin of error of three points, some traders saw the Democrat's lead, which was in double digits just days ago, evaporating. 
 While not the only factor moving the market this month, the uncertainty surrounding the Presidential election has played a role in the decline in prices and in yesterday's smart rally.
For bond traders, whether they are politically conservative or not, change is unsettling because of the uncertainty it creates. So some would see a Bush victory, for the short run, as a plus. And with Mr. Bush less likely to push for a major economic stimulus program, bond traders would be able to heave another sigh of relief.
 
Hard to Read
 But the reaction to the poll is still hard to read. Trading was thin yesterday because many big players have decided to stay out of the market until after the election, and in thin trading any move the market makes is exaggerated.
A rumor about the CNN poll -- that President Bush was in the lead -- had played a role earlier in the day, pushing bond and note prices higher after lunch and after the results of the Treasury's five-year note auction were announced. The auction, under a new single-price system being tested by the Treasury, seemed to go well, so that also helped the market.
But just before 3 P.M., about two hours before trading in New York winds down, the market appeared to lose all its momentum, giving up all its gains for the day and dropping below Tuesday's levels.
There was no news to account for the quick, across-the-board price decline. Instead, the market ran into what traders call technical levels and investors and dealers began selling when the price of the 30-year bond could not break through these ceilings.
Also, traders said at the time that the Tuesday rally and two days of Treasury auctions may have left dealers with a few more securities than made them comfortable ahead of the Presidential election.
Technical levels are the work of analysts who methodically plot every price move of a security and use the patterns that emerge to judge the direction of the market. These charts, when the market is moving up, produce what traders call resistance levels. And when the market is going down they are support levels.
 
 
Futures Contract
 Because these charts are followed closely by many dealers and investors they are used to make buy and sell decisions. The technical levels that were watched yesterday were on the futures contract for the 30-year bond. This contract, which is an agreement to buy or sell the 30-year bond at a set price in the future, trades on the Chicago Board of Trade. According to traders, the important price level was 103 7/32 .
What happened was this: The price of the 30-year bond futures contract began to rise on the poll rumor and the auction results, very quickly moving from just a tick under 103 to 103 8/32 .
But when the price inched over 103 7/32 , traders said there were sell orders waiting. Some selling came from big funds that speculate in the market. Other orders were from some investors who decided to take their profits here in case that level could not be breeched.
The market fell back on this selling but then rebounded again to pass just through 103 7/32 . Then there was more selling and suddenly there was no more buying. Traders in Chicago apparently decided for the moment, at least, that the resistance level could not be broken.
If that is the case, the theory says sell and that they did. Between about 2:15 and 3 P.M., when the Chicago market closes, the price of the bond fell from 103 8/32 to close at 102 21/32 , a drop of more than half a point.
The fall in Chicago, as often happens, washed over into the cash bond market in New York, pulling prices on bonds and notes and pushing up the discount rates on Treasury bills.
The yield on the five-year note that was auctioned yesterday jumped from 5.8 percent in the pre-auction, or when-issued, market to 5.85 percent around 3 P.M., reflecting a quick drop in the note's price. But the extra lift from the CNN poll, which was released around 4:30 P.M., brought the yield back down to 5.8 percent by the close of trading.
In the auction, in which all the notes are awarded at the same yield, the yield was 5.84 percent, far above the 5.54 percent at the September auction, which is a reflection of how much the market has fallen because of the election, the selling ahead of Treasury auctions and the Federal Reserve's decision in early October not to cut short-term interest rates a notch below the current 3 percent level.
Following are the results of the Treasury auction of five-year notes yesterday:

HEADLINE: In Suburbs, Vexation On Senate Candidates

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CROTON, N.Y., Oct. 27

 BODY:
It is possible to find people who say they are strongly for Alfonse M. D'Amato, or strongly for Robert Abrams. It's possible -- but it's much easier to find people like Mike Matzkin, who was asked today if he had made up his mind about the senatorial election.
"I've made up my mind that they're both idiots," snapped Mr. Matzkin, a camera company executive, as he stepped off a commuter train here. "You can feel free to quote me on that. What are they going to do, sue me?" 
 Mr. Matzkin's wife, Bea, who was at the station to meet him, was somewhat more diplomatic, but just as unhappy with the choices. She recoils at Senator D'Amato's opposition to abortion, but was also troubled when Mr. Abrams, the state Attorney General, called Mr. D'Amato a fascist. "A Senator should be able to control himself," she sighed.
With less than a week to go before New Yorkers give one of these men a six-year term in Washington, there is a remarkable sense of vexation and uncertainty among voters. And nowhere is the discontent more obvious than here in New York's suburbs, which many analysts describe as the race's crucial battleground.
 
Looking Elsewhere for Dignity
 It is, of course, a commonplace of this year's politics that voters say they are unhappy with the choices, or intend to pick the lesser of evils. But in this Senate race, routinely referred to as the nastiest in the nation, that sense of disgust is palpable. By contrast, many voters said they have struggled over whom to vote for in the Presidential race precisely because they do see something good in each man.
The unease is also reflected in a New York Times poll taken over the weekend in which 27 percent of voters described themselves as either undecided or abstaining in the Senate race -- compared with just 11 percent who gave a similar characterization of their feelings about the Presidential campaign.
The large number of undecided and unenthusiastic voters means the outcome of the election is unusually dependent on what happens in these final days of the campaign. The bright spot in this for Mr. Abrams, who has been badly outspent up to now, is that his strategy has focused on saturating the television airwaves with commercials in the final days. But many voters say that whatever decision they come to on Tuesday they already know all they need to know. So these weary voters may no longer be watching. Indeed, many said they would ignore the final debate on Sunday.
 
Look the Same, Act the Same
 In interviews in eight different communities on Long Island and in Westchester and Rockland Counties, many voters insist that they are so tired of the cacophony of this campaign, and of negative advertising, that they are ignoring the commercials altogether.
"To be honest with you, it's all starting to blur in my mind," said Brian Sheridan, a 35-year-old graphic designer from New Rochelle. "These guys even look very similar after awhile. You get confused. Their message is negative, and mentally you just start to turn it off."
Even the decided voters are angry. In Scarsdale, as sidewalk strollers looked at Halloween window decorations painted by village schoolchildren, Anna Decker said she was definitely voting against Mr. D'Amato. But as her three children started squabbling among themselves, she said of the television ads, "You just tune them out. It's like listening to my kids call each other names."
 
Media Faulted
 And on Long Island, Stephen R. Wiist, a librarian from Syosset, said he was thinking about skipping the Senate race altogether. "If I had my druthers, I might just vote for Perot and walk away. It's a real protest vote."
Some people blamed the news coverage more than they blamed the candidates themselves for the ugly tone of the Senate campaign. "The media has a lot of negative influence," said Ellyn Cioni of Smithtown, L.I.
Morton Mecklowsky, a 60-year-old community college professor of mathematics and philosophy from Stony Brook, L.I., said he was angered that, in his view, the media had portrayed Mr. Abrams and Mr. D'Amato in an equally negative light. "D'Amato is a gutter politician," he said. "Abrams is a decent human being."
Still, the prevailing attitude seemed to be more of a pox-on-both-their-houses variety. What makes that general contempt all the more surprising is that this is an election where voters do face a remarkable set of distinctions between the two candidates that could help them make up their mind.
 
Issues Define Candidates
 Mr. Abrams strongly favors abortion rights, is against the death penalty, wants massive defense cuts and a universal health-care program. Mr. D'Amato is anti-abortion, pro-death penalty, says the defense cuts would throw tens of thousands of New Yorkers out of work, and says the Abrams health plan would result in steep tax increases.
And even though many voters now seem fixated on what they view as each candidate's personal shortcomings, or say they are so perturbed at the campaign that they are not sure how the two men differ, it could well be these differences on the issues that determine their choice in the end.
There is some evidence that that is already happening, and probably the strongest drawing card for Mr. Abrams is his support of abortion rights. "I'm voting for Abrams because he's pro-choice," said Laura S. Obadiah, 26, a law student from Williston Park, L.I. "I'm not crazy about Abrams. I'm not really excited about voting for him but I feel like I have to because of this one issue."
But there are also plenty of single-issue voters whose opposition to abortion will make them side with Mr. D'Amato, even as they express reservations about his character.
Patricia Ramirez, 30, a nurse from Commack, L.I., said her past work at an abortion clinic had turned her into a staunchly "pro-life" voter who would back Mr. D'Amato. She objected to one television commercial by Mr. Abrams that emphasized his pro-choice position. "He just doesn't really know about it firsthand," she said. "He didn't see the women, the little girls really, who treated abortions like birth control."
 
Differing Perceptions
 Many other voters said they were far more concerned about the economy, but that does not mean that the interviews yielded any sense of consensus about who was the preferable candidate. Mr. Abrams, and the Democrats in general, tend to be seen as more likely to work for health care or to provide quicker relief from the ravages of the recession; but Mr. D'Amato and the Republicans are seen as better at holding the line on spending and tax increases.
"I think Abrams is the kind of guy who's going to be more personally interested in poor people," said Courtney Parchment, 19, a college student from Yonkers who is voting in his first election. "I think he'll help the homeless more often."
In any event, it is certain that neither candidate is seen as a leading spokesman for his cause. For instance, John Kallir of Scarsdale, owner of a Manhattan gallery, said of Mr. Abrams: "He's not a terribly interesting speaker. He's solemn and a little boring."
And Virginia Garbarini of New Rochelle, who was out shopping today with her daughter, Cathy Kostiw, said her fascination with Ross Perot only magnified her disappointment with the Senate race.
"Perot captures you," she said. "It's like he walks into the living room with you. She said she watched all 30 minutes of one of his recent program-length campaign ads. Asked if she felt the same way about Mr. Abrams or Mr. D'Amato, her daughter broke in as Mrs. Garbarini nodded, "Oh please. It's just political rhetoric from them."
If the uncertainty of the campaign could be captured in microcosm, it might have been done so by Jules Stern and Charles Siegel, registered Democrats, retirees and longtime friends, as they emerged from the Department of Motor Vehicles office in Yonkers.
"D'Amato's got more backbone than Abrams, Charlie," said Mr. Stern. "I'll say that for him." While Mr. Stern said he never really liked Mr. D'Amato ever since he ran over Jacob Javits in a brutal Republican primary in 1980, he said he was planning to vote for the Senator this time.
Mr. Siegel shook his head no. "He may be an advocate for New York, but he's too much of a wheeler-dealer for me," he said of Mr. D'Amato. "And he's been in there supporting the Bush program. Abrams, at least he's a change. He's a fresh face."
And if the attitudes could be summed up in a single response, perhaps it was the one from Alice Reynolds, a Bronxville homemaker who said she is seriously thinking of skipping over the Senate race when she went to the ballot box. "I think the problem for me is not that I don't know enough about this race. I think I know too much about the candidates."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Illinois;
Senate Race Tightens Amid Dispute Over Ethics

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 28

 BODY:
The bitter, bruising, potentially historic Senate race between Carol Moseley Braun and Richard S. Williamson is winding toward its final days with a fifth of the voters undecided and the once rabid heroine-worship of Ms. Braun appearing to have cooled.
In polls taken for The Chicago Tribune, Ms. Braun's lead has fallen from 34 percentage points in mid-September to 18 points this week, eroded by accusations that she avoided paying the Government for her mother's Medicaid bills, a steady drone of attacks on her ethics by Mr. Williamson and the appearance that she has coasted on her celebrity. 
 A newer poll, of 1,121 registered voters by the University of Illinois, put her lead at just 11 percentage points, with 28 percent undecided. Both polls had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Ms. Braun, who upset Senator Alan J. Dixon in the Democratic primary after his support of Clarence Thomas for the Supreme Court, is still favored to become the first black woman in the United States Senate.
 
Tighter Race Possible
 But the race could be closer than the numbers suggest because, when it comes to black candidates, some white voters have tended to tell poll takers one thing and do another in the voting booth. Harold Washington, the late Mayor of Chicago, and Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia and other black front-runners reliant on white votes watched solid leads in the polls translate to dead heats on Election Day.
"This is a state with a very checkered history," said Dianne Pinderhughes, a political science professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana. "It split on the Civil War. There is a very small percentage of black residents south of the Cook County area. It's been very difficult to determine whether one can trust those high numbers."
In a state where blacks make up only 15 percent of the vote, Ms. Braun has waged a determinedly nonracial campaign, spending more time in white subdivisions in the suburbs than black two-flats in Chicago, talking about women's rights more than civil rights.
But not without risk. It is not certain whether her investment will pay off, whether Republican women who crossed party lines to cast protest votes for her in the primary will stick with her in the general election.
Political professionals also say that white skeptics will seize on a news report that Ms. Braun may have mishandled a $28,750 inheritance check signed over to her by her mother, Edna Moseley. Because the candidate's mother, a nursing home resident, receives Medicaid, Mrs. Moseley is required to report such income to the state. Mrs. Moseley says she did report the money, but the state has found no record of it. Critics say Ms. Braun, a lawyer, should have made sure her mother had reported the money.
"Serious questions have been raised about her, and a lot of them will bail out," said Bruce DuMont, a Chicago political analyst who is host of a national radio program, "Inside Politics." "She has given them an excuse."
Moreover, in the final days of the campaign, excitement is muted in the black electorate, the group considered the most loyal to Ms. Braun and therefore the one more easily taken for granted.
In some black Chicago neighborhoods, there is no clue that Illinois could be on the verge of making history. There are few yard signs or bumper stickers on many blocks, and the talk is more about Michael Jordan's gambling debts or police raids at the Cabrini-Green housing project than about Carol Moseley Braun.
"There just isn't any enthusiasm," said Lu Palmer, a longtime black community advocate who was a member of her steering committee. "It's just not there. Those that vote will vote overwhelmingly for her. The question is will they turn out?"
After being what Mr. Palmer called "almost invisible" in black neighborhoods, Ms. Braun is trying to rouse black voters in campaign swings this week.
Her tightrope walk between the races is evidence of the Faustian calculus that black crossover politicians have to use to keep blacks in their corner while not turning off whites. In effect, she has had to choose which parts of herself to market.
"In this campaign, Carol Moseley Braun being a woman is far more important than her being black," Mr. DuMont said.
Ms. Braun says she feels her responsibility is to the entire state. "If this campaign is about anything, it is that the people in this state can get beyond race," she said in an interview.
Because Ms. Braun took only 38 percent of the Democratic vote in the three-way primary, her goal has been to win over the mostly white, fairly conservative Dixon Democrats who voted against her in the primary. "She has a lot of ground to make up," Professor Pinderhughes said. "The black vote and the Democratic vote will not deliver her."
But Conrad Worrill, chairman of the Black United Front, a black advocacy group, who is a professor of history at Northeastern Illinois University, said, "We're hoping this tactic of appealing to voters throughout the state at the expense of firing up the black mass electorate doesn't backfire on the campaign."
What has kept Ms. Braun's campaign going is an extraordinary personal magnetism, adoring crowds of mostly white, mostly female voter-fans, lots of money, much of it from supporters outside Illinois, and the rarely spoken but always understood chance that she could make history by integrating the Senate.
She has raised $5 million, more than twice as much money as Mr. Williamson has, and began the last week of the campaign with $1 million.
While there appears to have been a slight drop in support from Republican women since the Medicaid furor emerged several weeks ago, Ms. Braun is counting on women like Anne Wray, a suburban independent, to carry her over the top.
Standing outside a campaign stop in Kane County, waiting for Ms. Braun to arrive, Mrs. Wray said, "We don't need another condescending white male in the Senate."
Over all, Ms. Braun's campaign has been a safe and cautious one, where she talks in broad generalities about things like a woman's right to abortion and increasing the Federal role in financing public education. In campaign appearances and advertisements, including three new television commercials this week, she has tried to link Mr. Williamson to trickle-down economics and to the Reagan and Bush Administrations in which he served in the early and mid-1980's.
Mr. Williamson, a lawyer, has painted Ms. Braun as a tax-and-spend liberal with what he has called "reckless" ideas, like universal health care, accused her of cronyism and shoddy management as Cook County Recorder of Deeds and tried to connect her to controversial black politicians like Representative Gus Savage, an Illinois Democrat.
As Mr. Williamson has struggled for name recognition, Ms. Braun has taken time from the campaign to pose for magazines like Vogue and Essence.
Her national fame and the attention paid to her possible place in world encyclopedias has obscured the campaign, many say. The Chicago Tribune chose not to endorse either candidate. In an editorial endorsing Ms. Braun with "misgivings," The Chicago Sun-Times said, "The purpose of this election is to choose a Senator, not commit a historic act."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Rising Cuban-American Leader: Statesman to Some, Bully to Others

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Jorge Mas Canosa and his bodyguards travel around town in a bulletproof Mercedes-Benz because he fears Fidel Castro may try to assassinate him. President Bush singles him out for praise when he speaks of how "the Cuban community has energized Miami," while Bill Clinton courts his support in hopes of winning Cuban-American votes. And world leaders like Boris Yeltsin have been his guests here.
By just about any standard, no Cuban-American is more influential than Mr. Mas. Through the Cuban American National Foundation, the group he helped to found 11 years ago as a source of political support for the Reagan Administration, Mr. Mas has become the most visible member of the Cuban-American community and one of the most effective power brokers in Washington for his cause, the fall of the Castro regime. 
 On Friday, Mr. Mas, who became an American citizen just a decade ago, stood only inches from Mr. Bush as the President signed the Cuban Democracy Act. The new law, one of Mr. Mas's greatest triumphs, takes several proposals that the lobbying group has long argued will hasten the downfall of Mr. Castro and makes them official American policy.
 
Talking to Bush and Clinton
 Then, on Tuesday, Mr. Mas flew to Tampa to meet with Mr. Clinton, whom he praised for his deep-seated commitment to "the ideals of freedom, respect for human rights and self-determination for Cuba." Mr. Mas said he had told the Democratic nominee that "your support was crucial" to passage of the law and that Cuban-Americans, nearly 90 percent of whom voted for Mr. Bush in 1988, "need not fear a Bill Clinton Administration."
But people in Miami who have disagreed with Mr. Mas's program, or who have questioned his motives, assert that he has another, much less statesman-like side. To his critics, he is "Senor Mas y Mas," Spanish for "Mr. More and More," a vindictive power broker with an explosive temper who uses his ever-increasing influence and wealth to persecute those who disagree him.
"Any person who questions this man and this organization risks his career and his standing in this community," said Xiomara Almaguer, a Cuban-American psychologist who is co-founder of a new group called the Cuban-American Defense League.
 
Feud With Newspaper
 Executives at The Miami Herald, with which Mr. Mas has a long feud, say, for instance, that he recently told them he hired a detective to investigate them, because he was apprehensive about an article the newspaper was preparing.
CANF, as the group is known, has also said it will press libel charges against the authors of a Public Broadcasting Service documentary and a study by the human-rights group Americas Watch, both of which raise questions about Mr. Mas and his activities.
And in an incident that quickly became part of Miami's folklore, Mr. Mas once challenged a Dade County commissioner, Joe Carrollo, to a duel. Mr. Carrollo's offense had been to torpedo a $130 million real estate deal in which Mr. Mas and some prominent Republicans were partners.
"I am going to prove to the Cubans that you are a clown and a coward," Mr. Mas vowed during a radio broadcast. "Your bullying in Miami has ended because you have met a man with a capital M, a very big M." Mr. Carrollo defused the situation by picking water pistols.
 
Criticism About Zeal
 Mr. Mas's critics here and in Washington say that in his zeal to bring about Mr. Castro's downfall, he is forcing the United States into a restrictive policy just when flexibility is required. Many of these critics, who include former directors of the foundation, also question whether Mr. Mas's efforts are intended to benefit Cubans or to carve out a political and economic role for himself.
In many respects, Mr. Mas, who declined to be interviewed for this article, exemplifies the classic American immigrant success story. The son of a Cuban Army veterinarian, he arrived here 32 years ago as a penniless refugee and worked as a stevedore, shoe salesman and milkman before buying a struggling construction business and accumulating a fortune he has estimated at more than $9 million.
Today, Mr. Mas and his wife Irma live in a $700,000 house in the same Miami suburb as Jeb Bush, a son of the President and one of Mr. Mas's political allies. Mr. Mas's construction company, Church & Tower, has contracts with Southern Bell and Dade County, and Mr. Mas is often seen at sports and charity events in the company of the city's political and business elite.
 
More Cuban Than American
 But by his own admission, Mr. Mas, who is 53 years old, regards himself as more Cuban than American at heart and prefers to do things in what he regards as the proper Cuban way. He is familiar with the subtleties of politics in Washington, but he shows even more gusto for the personal attacks, vendettas and general fractiousness long associated with Caribbean politics.
"It is important to remember that the leaders of the Cuban-American community participate in American politics but are not of American politics," said Congressman Robert Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat who sponsored the Cuban Democracy Act. "They are fighting for a revolution to reclaim their country, so both their tactics and their style can appear to be out of balance with American politics."
The hard line Mr. Mas takes toward the Castro regime is encoded in the Cuban Democracy Act, which extends the United States economic embargo that began when the Cuban leader took power 32 years ago and which imposes penalties on foreign subsidiaries of American companies trading with Cuba. After Mr. Castro's fall, a decision to end the embargo and to grant aid to any successor government would be conditioned on holding free and democratic multiparty elections.
Those issues are very much of concern to Mr. Mas these days. The Cuban American National Foundation has already drawn up a new constitution and an economic recovery plan for Cuba, and some of his followers have begun greeting him as "Senor Presidente" as he strolls the Cuban-American neighborhood Little Havana.
In public, Mr. Mas has always danced away from suggestions that he has any ambition to succeed Mr. Castro, offering only ambiguous replies to questions about his role in a post-Communist Cuba. But privately, according to people who know him well, he has been much less coy.
Indeed, opponents of the Cuban Democracy Act argue that it advances Mr. Mas's dream more than the interests of the United States. Whatever its merits, the legislation is testimony to the clout that Mr. Mas and the foundation wield in Washington. Since the founding of the group, its directors and the political action committee they control, the Free Cuba PAC Inc., have donated more than $1 million directly to candidates for the Presidency, Senate and House and helped to raise even more through their sponsorship of fund-raising dinners.
 
Single-Minded Standard
 "Our philosophy is that we contribute to those who are friends of the Cuban cause and to those who are opposing enemies of the Cuban cause," Francisco J. Hernandez, the foundation's president, said. "We do not care if they are Democrats or Republicans, liberals or conservatives."
Over 12 years, Mr. Mas has contributed $216,000 to national political candidates, more than any other Hispanic individual in the United States, according to a recent study conducted by Hispanic Business magazine. He is also among the most familiar presences on Capitol Hill, testifying before Congressional committees and dropping in at the offices of members of Congress.
 
Foundation Expands Turf
 Mr. Mas attained that influence as head of the foundation, which is mainly a lobbying group but which has expanded its activity in recent years. Mr. Mas is now head of the Presidential Advisory Board on Cuba Broadcasting, which oversees Radio and Television Marti. The two outlets are branches of the United States Information Agency that provide Cuba's 11 million people with programming intended to challenge Mr. Castro's monopoly on information, and both have covered Mr. Mas's activities extensively.
The foundation also runs a resettlement program for Cuban refugees in a highly unusual arrangement that includes Federal support and financing. In addition, it has served as a conduit for more than $780,000 in grants from the National Endowment for Democracy to Cuban human-rights groups allied to the foundation.
Both the refugee program and Mr. Mas's involvement in Radio and Television Marti are cited by his critics as examples of a conflict of interest and of unwarranted government favoritism. "Who ever heard of a political party, which is what the Foundation really is, being allowed to run a refugee program?" asked Ramon Cernuda, a Miami publisher who is the American representative of several Cuban dissident groups. "How many hats can they wear?"
If in Washington Mr. Mas is the amiable but persistent lobbyist, in Miami he prefers to act the part of the caudillo, the traditional Latin American strongman who brooks no opposition.
"The man has become a Godfather," Mr. Cernuda said. "You need his blessing to get things done, because he has built a power machine."

HEADLINE: GOVERNORS REPORT GRIM FISCAL STATUS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Despite three years of budget cuts and tax increases, states' finances are still in turmoil as a result of the nation's weak economy, the National Governors' Association said today.
"States are under phenomenal fiscal pressure," said Raymond C. Scheppach, executive director of the association. 
 At the end of the fiscal year 1992, states together had an estimated surplus of $825 million, representing three-tenths of 1 percent of total state spending, the governors reported.
The year-end balance, as a proportion of state spending, is an important indicator of states' economic health, and it is now at the lowest level in at least 15 years. Even at the depth of the 1982-83 recession, surpluses exceeded the amounts states now have on hand or expect to have at the end of 1993, the governors' association said in its semiannual "Fiscal Survey of States."
 
Economic Growth Vital
 State officials say that the health of the national economy is far more important than any Federal aid program in determining the condition of state finances. Economic growth leads to increases in personal and corporate income, consumer spending and state revenue.
Total state spending rose 5.1 percent in the fiscal year 1992, and is expected to increase just 2.4 percent in 1993. That is far below the average increase of 8 percent a year in the 1980's.
"Even if we get an economic recovery, the states' financial situation will not improve dramatically," said Mr. Scheppach. With prison overcrowding and soaring Medicaid costs, demands on state treasuries are increasing. But state revenue as a share of state output is declining. States often tax service industries less heavily than manufacturing, and the service industries account for most of the nation's economic growth, Mr. Scheppach said.
Medicaid, the Federal-state health care program for low-income people, now accounts for 15 percent of the states' spending and will account for 28 percent in 1995, the governors estimate. Medicaid is the most rapidly growing item in most state budgets.
 
29 States Raising Taxes
 The sluggish economy continues to plague state revenue collections. Thirty-one states report that their collections for the fiscal year 1992 fell short of the estimates used in preparing the year's budget. Twenty-nine states have raised taxes for 1993.
The Federal fiscal year ends on Sept. 30. In most states, the fiscal year ends on June 30.
The Bush Administration reported today that the Federal budget deficit set a record, $290.2 billion in the fiscal year 1992, which ended four weeks ago. Most states must balance their budgets, but the Federal Government spent $5 for every $4 it collected in revenue. Federal spending totaled $1,381.9 billion in 1992. Total receipts were $1,091.7 billion.
Federal spending grew faster than the economy. Outlays by the Federal Government were equivalent to 23.6 percent of the gross domestic product in the last fiscal year, the highest proportion since 1985. The Federal budget deficit was equivalent to 4.9 percent of the gross domestic product, the highest level since 1986.
 
Reason for Lower Deficit
 The deficit in 1992 was far below the $399 billion estimated by President Bush last January. The Treasury Department said most of the discrepancy occurred because Congress did not provide as much money as Mr. Bush wanted to protect depositors at insolvent savings and loan associations. The money needed to meet those commitments will increase Federal spending and the budget deficit in the future, Administration officials said.
The Federal data confirm the governors' observations about the growth of Medicaid. Federal spending for Medicaid rose 28 percent in 1991, to $52.5 billion, then rose 29 percent in 1992, to $67.8 billion. State spending for Medicaid has increased at a similar pace.
To control other outlays, state officials have adopted various techniques: eliminating programs, consolidating agencies, freezing spending or hiring, delaying payments. But these techniques generally do not produce enough savings to balance state budgets, so governors must search for ways of permanently reducing state obligations, Mr. Scheppach said.
For example, he said, 11 states cut or eliminated benefits under a state welfare program known as general assistance.
 
State Payrolls Down 2%
 Many states are also cutting their payrolls. The number of full-time state employees, 2.3 million, will decline nearly 2 percent by the end of 1993, the governors' association said. New Jersey, Michigan and Massachusetts have "the most significant declines" in state employment, it said. Twenty-one states reported that the number of state jobs would decline from 1991 to 1993.
About one-third of the states are giving no pay increases to their employees in 1993. Eighteen states have changed employee benefits, often shifting costs for health insurance to state workers.
With revenue falling short of projections, 35 states cut overall spending below the levels initially approved in their 1992 budgets. Such cuts are sometimes made unilaterally by the governors. In other cases, a special session of the state legislature is required.

HEADLINE: SENECA JOURNAL;
Sovereignty And Casino Beckon To a Tribe

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: IRVING N.Y.

 BODY:
AT one entrance to the Cattaraugus Indian Reservation, someone has covered the green highway sign with a banner proclaiming: "Aboriginal Seneka Territory."
At the opposite end, outside the Seneca Hawk truck stop, another sign advertises "Goulash" and urges "Vote for Barry Nov. 3."
The balance between cultural and economic survival can be an awkward one on this Seneca Indian reservation, particularly at election time. Members of the legally sovereign Seneca Nation will vote on Tuesday to fill 37 offices, including president, clerk and half the 16-member Tribal Council. 
 The three presidential candidates promise economic development while defending the tribe against an ever-encroaching white world. They vow to keep state tax collectors away from Indian businesses selling gasoline and cigarettes to outsiders on the Senecas' Cattaraugus and Allegany reservations, the two largest in the state.
But none of the candidates will speak in more than general terms about casino gambling, an issue that some believe is the most crucial one facing the 6,350 members of the tribe, nearly half of whom live outside the reservations in western New York and northwestern Pennsylvania.
 
Vote-Buying Outlawed
 Complicating things is a political tradition that would make Boss Tweed proud. This election will be the first in generations where vote-buying will be illegal, though it is uncertain that the law, which was passed by the Tribal Council in August, will be enforced.
"They don't come up to you and say they're buying the vote," said Barry J. White, a Seneca who lectures in the Native American studies program at the State University at Buffalo. "They say, 'Go over to this place; there's food and refreshments there.' Then party workers will solicit you."
Many Senecas say that when their ancestors formed an elected government in the 1840's, they simply did too good a job of copying the American political system. And even opponents of vote-buying are uncomfortable with public criticism.
"What I don't want to see is the impression that the Seneca Nation doesn't know how to operate and is corrupt," Mr. White said.
Nevertheless, one of the three presidential candidates, J. C. Seneca, is making election reform an issue. Another candidate, Emery H. Williams, said he would abide by the new law. The third candidate, Barry Snyder Sr., takes no position on the new law.
"The election's not here yet," he said. "So I don't know what's going to happen this time."
 
'They're All Crooked'
 With crucial issues facing them, many Senecas have become cynical about their politicians.
"They're all crooked," said Janice E. Skutt, 34 years old, who was shopping on Saturday at the Wolf's Run gasoline station and convenience store on the Cattaraugus reservation. She said she took $100 for her vote a couple of elections ago. "After I was paid, I said, 'I just sold myself for $100,' " she recalled.
Mrs. Skutt said she feared losing her cleaning job at the Seneca health clinic for publicly criticizing the tribal government, but she said she felt strongly about problems on the reservation that needed more attention.
According to the 1990 Census, the reservation poverty rate is more than 27 percent. The rate for Cattaraugus County, which borders the Seneca lands, is 8.6 percent. Unemployment is chronically high, nearly triple the Cattaraugus County rate, according to the Census.
The candidates are well aware of the discontent.
"Why don't we smile anymore?" Mr. Snyder asked at a campaign forum last week. "We are a proud nation."
Mr. Snyder, 52, wants to see more Indian businesses on the reservations.
 
Issue of Taxes
 The reservations are already galvanized by the issue, following a July court ruling that the state may collect sales and excise taxes on fuel and tobacco sold by Senecas to non-Indians. For several days, angry Senecas confronted the state police and temporarily shut down the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway and Route 17 on the reservations. The State Court of Appeals is expected to decide soon whether it will hear the case.
"The ripple effect of this election will mean whether we have casino gambling," Mr. White said.
The candidates decline to discuss the issue in detail, saying there are no formal proposals on the table. But Mr. Snyder and Mr. Seneca refuse to rule it out, and while Mr. Williams's party is against it, he said he did not feel strongly either way.
Mr. White agrees that the Seneca reservations need to focus on economic development, but he said gambling could further threaten Seneca culture.
"We're in a transition very much like we were when we started fur trading with the Europeans," he said. "It's a whole new level of thinking, a whole new level of economics. And people are hungry for that. That's why I would rather have them think deeper about the implications of economic development."

Corruption is a main issue in the campaign. Barry Snyder Sr., center, is one of the three candidates running for president. (Mickey Osterreicher for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Battle for Senate Is Feeling Impact of Presidential Race

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Prospects for a Clinton landslide in New York have helped unite typically fractious Democrats, who are working for the kind of big margin that would send Republican Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato back to Long Island and many of them to Washington.
Their coordinated campaign, which is culminating in a 100,000-phone-calls-a-night blitz, is aimed in particular at fighting complacency and luring those Democrats who have long supported Mr. D'Amato over to back his opponent in the Senate race, State Attorney General Robert Abrams. 
 Given the projected margins in the Presidential race, Republicans are becoming increasingly preoccupied with preserving their State Senate majority and in protecting the United States Senate seat that the party has held for nearly a half-century.
 
'The $64,000 Question'
 The chief imponderable of the campaign appears to be not whether Gov. Bill Clinton will carry New York, but by how much. Will his shirttails be long enough for other Democratic challengers -- especially Mr. Abrams -- to get a grip? "That's the $64,000 question," said Tony Marsh, Mr. D'Amato's media adviser.
The Democrats say they are telephoning as many as 100,000 prospective voters a night to promote the Democratic ticket, usually mentioning the party's candidates for President and Vice President, Mr. Abrams and local candidates by name. John A. Marino, the Democratic state chairman, who is heading the Democrats' coordinated campaign for the national ticket and for state and local offices, said volunteers calling from thousands of phones across the state expect to reach 4 million New Yorkers in all -- 2 million of them during the four days starting Saturday.
Republicans, maintaining that President Bush remains a "viable" candidate, said they mailed out a million forms to reach potential absentee voters. Also, Republican workers are phoning tens of thousands of prospective voters, but not as many as the Democrats.
Regardless of whether Mr. Clinton redeems his remark that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo would make a good Supreme Court justice, other New Yorkers working in the Clinton campaign are in line to go to Washington if he is elected.
 
Shifted to Washington
 Right after the Democratic National Convention, Harold M. Ickes, the lawyer who engineered Mr. Clinton's victory in the New York Presidential primary last April, shifted to Washington as deputy chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
Deborah Sale, an Arkansas native who was chief of staff to Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine of New York, is working out of the national campaign headquarters in Little Rock. So is Susan Thomases, a New York lawyer who is the campaign scheduling director, and Maria Echaveste and Karen Adler, two New Yorkers who served as liaisons to Hispanic and Jewish voters during the primary and are now performing similar roles in the national campaign. Ms. Echaveste is a former chairwoman of the New York City Board of Elections.
A number of New Yorkers who have been campaign economic advisers, fund-raisers or both -- among them three investment bankers, Roger Altman, vice chairman of the Blackstone Group; Felix G. Rohatyn of Lazard Freres, and Robert Rubin of Goldman, Sachs -- are also seen as candidates for major economic posts.
Geraldine A. Ferraro, the former Congresswoman from Queens who has been campaigning vigorously for the Clinton-Gore ticket since she lost the Democratic primary for United States Senate, has said she would not seek elective office again but expressed interest in an appointive post.
 
Contributions to Campaign
 Sarah Kovner, a veteran of Democratic politics, and Paul Carey, son of former Gov. Hugh L. Carey, have been with Mr. Clinton from the beginning. Others singled out by Kevin L. Thurm, the Clinton campaign director in New York, for their contributions to the campaign include Hulbert H. James, a veteran of political campaigns and voter registration drives, who has been Mayor David N. Dinkins's director of African-American-Caribbean affairs; Joseph Ithier, chief of staff to Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx; Carol Hamilton, the Clinton campaign press secretary in New York, and Bruce Nyman, the Supervisor for Long Beach, L.I.
Two signals suggest that an upset is not anticipated: New York has barely been on either candidate's itinerary this fall; also, neither campaign is investing heavily in television advertising in New York and most of what is being spent in New York is aimed at viewers in the overlapping New Jersey media market. Most national campaign money allocated to New York is funneled through Mr. Marino's operation.
New York Republicans are stoically plumping for Mr. Bush despite his slump in the polls. This week, Jonathan Bush, the President's brother, stumped in several cities upstate. "I would like to see the poll numbers a little bit different," William D. Powers, the Republican state chairman, said, "but we still think it's viable."
 
Only One Element
 But the Presidential campaign is only one element in a strategy that includes galvanizing Republicans for the high-stakes 1994 gubernatorial campaign, which could revive the sagging fortunes of a state party that last elected a governor in 1970.
The Bush campaign in New York is largely being run by Mr. Powers and by Thomas F. Doherty, a Westchester County employee and Tuckahoe village board member. The state campaign chairman is former State Senator H. Douglas Barclay.
Republican officials say they mailed a million applications for absentee ballots to party members along with the slate of candidates from President on down. Mr. Powers and Mr. Doherty said only one candidate did not want his name included, Representative Bill Green, whose reconfigured district spreads from Manhattan's East Side into Brooklyn and Queens and includes more Democrats than Republicans.
After the election, Mr. Marino's deputy, Bill Lynch, a former deputy mayor to Mayor Dinkins, is expected to become Mr. Dinkins's campaign manager -- a job in which having a direct pipeline to the White House can be a considerable political plus.
Mr. Lynch was responsible for coordinating a registration drive that enrolled record numbers of new voters and that in Nassau County signed up more new Democratic voters than Republicans -- perhaps for the first time in a bastion of suburban Republicanism. Now, Mr. Lynch's job is to generate a large turnout to make the state safe for Mr. Clinton.
"We're trying to make it a sweep," he said.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "POLITICS: On Clinton's New York Campaign Team"
 
HAROLD M. ICKES
 
Son of Franklin D. Roosevelt's Interior Secretary, Mr. Ickes is a 52-year-old labor lawyer who has been active in Democratic campaigns in New York for decades --fighting the good fight but not accustomed to winning. Modest, volatile, tireless and a tough negotiator, he has known Mr. Clinton for 20 years since the anti-war movement and was recruited last year to manage the New York campaign. He also managed the national convention for Mr. Clinton and emerged, as the candidate's man in New York.
 
JOHN A. MARINO
 
Installed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo as Democratic State Chairman, Mr. Marino was the state's regional transportation director for New York CIty before shifting to full-time political posts. Mr. Marino, who is 44 years old, is intensely loyal to Mr. Cuomo. Last year, he helped prepare the foundation for a Cuomo presidential campaign that never materialized, but rebounded to run the coordinated campaign on behalf of the national ticket and state and local candidates.
 
KEVIN L. THURM
 
Mr. Thurm, an affable 31-year-old lawyer, and George Stephanopoulos, the Clinton campaign's national communications director, were fellow Rhodes scholars. He has worked in other campaigns, but never directed one state-wide, as he is doing now in New York since he was enlisted by Mr. Stephanopoulos a year ago. He practices constitutional and commercial law between campaigns, but has been working full-time for Mr. Clinton all year. He paused only briefly when, four days after the Democratic national convention, his wife gave birth to a son.
