HEADLINE: A New House District Could Make History

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNION CITY, N.J., Oct. 28

 BODY:
The new 13th Congressional District here may very well enter the history books on Tuesday as the first in New Jersey to send a Hispanic-American representative to Washington.
The Democrat on the ticket, in a district where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans by as much as six to one, is already the subject of talk about the influence that he would carry as one of the few Hispanic-Americans in the national political arena at a time when they represent the nation's fastest-growing ethnic group. 
 Even before he announced he would run, Robert Menendez, a Cuban-American who is a State Senator as well as Union City's Mayor, was considered by his party as the natural heir to the retiring seven-term incumbent, Frank Guarini.
Still, both Mr. Menendez and his Republican opponent, Fred J. Theemling Jr., a Hudson County lawyer who has never held elective office, are loath to say the election is a foregone conclusion.
Although he captured 68 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary, Mr. Menendez has been careful not to take the numbers for granted, even in a district that cuts a swath through four counties in areas that have traditionally been Democratic turf: Essex, Union, Hudson and Middlesex. In an interview, he pointed out that while the district's population is 43 percent Hispanic, Hispanic residents represent only slightly more than 20 percent of the registered voters. And while he is serving his second term as the popular Mayor of New Jersey's most densely populated city, he believes he is still an unknown quantity in parts of the new district.
 
'Make Up Their Own Minds'
 "I hate when people say that of course I'm going to win big," Mr. Menendez said. "Voters make up their own minds."
The district, which was drawn after New Jersey lost one House seat as a result of the 1990 Census, was created to increase Hispanic representation. It snakes from the northern tip of North Bergen in Hudson County, covers parts of New Jersey's largest cities, including one-third of Newark and more than half of Jersey City, and reaches to Perth Amboy in Middlesex County.
Mr. Menendez, whose campaign is aimed at appealing to blue-collar and middle-class concerns like jobs and health care costs, has campaigned since the primary with the anxious energy of an underdog, putting in 18-hour days to reach voters in areas where he believes his name carries little cachet. Before it is all over, he expects to have spent about $200,000 on the campaign. That is half what he spent on the primary but still far more than his opponent, who will spend about $11,000.
 
Blaming the Legislature
 Despite his tiny treasury, Mr. Theemling, born in Texas and raised in Hudson County, said he believed he still had a chance. He has already lost two campaigns, to Mr. Guarini in 1988 and 1990, getting about 31 percent of the vote in each race. But the 48-year-old candidate, a former assistant Hudson County prosecutor, said things might be different this time because Mr. Menendez is a member of the State Legislature, which many voters hold responsible for the state's ailing economy.
"Everyone I speak to -- Republican, Independent and Democrat -- is blaming the State Legislature for playing politics with our lives," he said. "Bob Menendez has been a State Senator and Assembly member. There is an anti-incumbency feeling out there and Bob is as good as the incumbent in this race."
But Mr. Menendez could hardly be called a Washington insider. While his political resume stretches back 18 years, when he was elected to the Union City School Board at age 20, his first entry into statewide politics came in 1987, when he was elected to the Assembly. He was in his second term in the Assembly when he was appointed to fill a vacant seat in the Senate in March 1991 and elected to the Senate last November.
Born in New York City, he was raised in Hudson County by parents who emigrated first to Puerto Rico, then to the United States, before Fidel Castro's rise to power. Many of his relatives remained in Cuba.
Mr. Menendez, like virtually everyone seeking office these days, bristles at the label of "insider." But he is part of Hudson County's powerful Democratic establishment. And his political allies outside the area include Jorge Mas Canosa, a Miami millionaire who heads one of the most powerful lobbying groups in the country, the Cuban American National Foundation. Mr. Mas Canosa's organization, which is devoted to devising a capitalistic plan for a post-Castro Cuba, is one of Mr. Menendez's largest campaign contributors.
 
Menendez and Clinton
 Three weekly Spanish-language newspapers in Hudson County have embraced Mr. Menendez's Congressional race, emphasizing his importance to the area's Spanish-speakers. The district's Spanish-speaking immigrants come from 21 different countries, but Mr. Menendez's base of support comes from Cuban-Americans, who number about 44,000. He is so popular with Cuban voters, who traditionally vote Republican, that Mr. Menendez voices cautious hope that he will be able to deliver their votes to the Democratic Presidential ticket.
"I've never had a Democrat to work with the way I do with Governor Clinton," he said. For instance, he said, Bill Clinton spoke out before President Bush did in support of a bill sponsored by the Ninth District's Democratic Congressman, Robert G. Torricelli, that would, among other things, tighten an embargo against Cuba.
"In fact, Clinton forced Bush's hand by doing so," Mr. Menendez said. "And he is not seen as a traditional liberal by a lot of the Republicans, which is a plus."
But Mr. Theemling, who says he has received enthusiastic receptions in the district's Spanish-speaking communities, said he did not think Hispanic voters would automatically pull the Democratic lever in the voting booth.
Like Mr. Menendez, he has endorsed Mr. Torricelli's bill, and like Mr. Menendez, his campaign speeches focus on creating jobs and bolstering the economy. Mr. Theemling's ideas include urban enterprise zones and tax credits to corporations for each new employee as well as increasing taxes on corporations that lay off workers to help profits. Mr. Menendez has focused on tax incentives in areas of high unemployment for new businesses and for research and development, as well as improved job training programs.
Mr. Theemling also favors President Bush's school choice plan, which would give parents the choice of sending their child to private or public school.
"I think it's a Hispanic issue because immigrants who come here often send their children to parochial schools and are often interested in attending schools with job programs that will get them out into the work force as fast as possible," he said.
Mr. Menendez, whose son and daughter, ages 7 and 9, attend public schools, has taken pains to emphasize an agenda that he says encompasses the concerns of everyone in the district.
"It is true that while becoming the first Hispanic-American member of Congress from the state would put a spotlight on my concerns for this particular group, it is the same as being the first Hispanic Senator in the State Legislature or the only Hispanic State Assemblyman," he said. "There are concerns we have that benefit all groups."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Democrats: Alarming Words for the Elderly

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

 BODY:
The Democratic National Committee yesterday began broadcasting two 30-second commercials, one on Medicare and one on "tough times" for middle-class families. Because they are paid for by the Democratic Party, these advertisements do not mention any candidates by name.
 
ON THE SCREEN: Opens with these words in white on black background: "Before you vote, remember the record," in white on black background, followed by a series of black and white photographs of elderly people. Closes with "The New Democrats. Social Security. Quality Affordable Health Care."
 
SCRIPT: Narrator: "Before you vote, remember the record. Every year for the past 12 years, the Republicans tried to cut Medicare. And in nine of those years they've done it. And this year, they've proposed a plan that could lower benefits for nearly 30 million older Americans and virtually eliminate compensation for over one million disabled veterans. Medicare cuts. Health-care crisis. The worst economic record since the Great Depression. Senior citizens know better than anyone, it's time for a change. And that's what the new Democrats are fighting for. Social security and quality health care."
 
ACCURACY: Republicans have for 12 years said they wanted to cut the rate of growth in Medicare, but not actually reduce the benefits. There have been Republican efforts to cut payments to doctors and hospitals, though not beneficiaries. It is true that the economy has grown more slowly during Bush's Presidency than in any other four-year term since Herbert Hoover's. But the recession in the early 1980's was much more severe than the one during the Bush years.
 
SCORECARD: This ad features a familiar scare tactic of the Democrats: playing up to senior citizens' fears that their Social Security will be cut. It has long been a sure-fire issue for the Democrats, though it is doubtful that Congress would ever approve a cut in entitlements.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Anheuser's Earnings Rise 8.5%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28

 BODY:
The Anheuser-Busch Companies reported an 8.5 percent increase in earnings for the third quarter today, citing higher profitability in the beer and entertainment businesses and lower financing costs.
The company said earnings for the quarter were $318 million, or $1.11 a share, up from $293 million, or $1.01 a share, a year ago. Sales for the quarter rose 4.4 percent to $3.54 billion from $3.39 billion a year ago. 
 The stock closed today on the New York Stock Exchange at $54.625, up $1.
The company said sales to wholesalers were a record 23.2 million barrels during the quarter, up from 23.1 million barrels last year.
Beer Institute figures showed that Anheuser-Busch beer volume sales accounted for about 44 percent of all brewing industry sales, including imports.
"Anheuser-Busch's gains, built from the largest volume base in the industry, have come despite the lingering effect of the 1991 Federal excise tax increase, the second-coldest summer in two decades and continued weak economic conditions in key selling areas, such as the Northeast and California," said August A. Busch 3d, president and board chairman.

HEADLINE: Ford Registers a Loss for the Third Quarter

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 28

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company, hurt by weak automotive volume in North America and Britain, reported today that it lost $158.9 million in the third quarter, narrowing from a loss of $574.4 million in same 1991 period.
Harold A. Poling, chairman and chief executive, singled out "instability in European currency markets" that "has led to lower sales in most of Ford's European markets, and will continue to affect the operating environment for the near term." 
 Ford had said losses could continue in the fourth quarter if the economy does not strengthen. In a prepared statement, Mr. Poling said the rest of the year and all of 1993 would be "challenging."
 
 
Stock Advances
 In trading today on the New York Stock Exchange, Ford's share price dropped $1.75, to $38.125.
Last week the Chrysler Corporation posted a $182 million third-quarter profit; the General Motors Corporation is expected to announce a third-quarter loss of up to $850 million Thursday morning.
David McCammon, Ford's vice president for finance, extended a compliment to Chrysler: "I have to give them a lot of credit. They had a better production situation in trucks than we did during the quarter."
Mr. McCammon, though declining to predict automotive sales for next year, said Ford was looking for steady but slow economic growth, reaching the 3.5 percent level next year. He conceded that Ford may be benefiting slightly from consumer unease over the corporate upheaval at G.M.
Ford's revenue for the quarter rose 10.5 percent to $23.33 billion from $21.12 billion.
For the nine months, Ford earned $681.4 million, or $1.10 a share, on revenue of $74.73 billion, compared with a loss of $1.78 billion on revenue of $66.3 billion a year earlier.
Ford's results were within the range predicted by most analysts. "If there was a surprise it was that Ford's profit margins in its automotive business deteriorated, principally because of European currency fluctuations and the costs of launching new models," Wendy Needham, automotive analyst for Smith Barney in New York, said. Ford recently introduced the 1993 Ford Probe, Ford Ranger pickup and Mercury Villager mini-van. It plans to introduce the Lincoln Mark VIII on Dec. 26.
Ford's worldwide automotive operations lost $464 million in the quarter, compared with $751 million a year earlier; automotive operations in the United States accounted for $153 million of the loss, compared with $197 million a year earlier.
Incentives to retail buyers averaged $1,050 a vehicle in the third quarter, up from $900 in the second quarter, largely because the third quarter is the "cleanup" quarter for remaining 1992 models.
 
 
Financial Services
 Ford's financial services, with fewer credit losses and better interest margins, posted a record $305 million third-quarter profit, up from $128 million last year.
With a strong balance sheet and a big increase in its American market share, Ford is well positioned for strong earnings if overall automotive demand increases -- unless economic conditions worsen in Britain, analysts say.
Ford's overall share of the car and light-truck market in the United States was 24.5 percent for the first nine months of the year, a level not reached since 1989. It compares with a 20.3 percent share a decade ago. A percentage point of market share is equal to sales of 130,000 to 150,000 vehicles, depending on the size of the market.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Carrying Sushi to Osaka Proves an Unpopular Plan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 28

 BODY:
A widely publicized plan by a Japanese restaurant chain to import frozen sushi from the United States again faces an uncertain future -- not because of opposition by Japan's Government to rice imports but because of a fight within the company.
Fujio Matsumoto, the president of the Sushi Boy chain, has quit the company, as has Haruhiko Saito, another executive behind the plan to import the sushi. Sushi Boy's remaining management is reviewing whether importing American sushi makes economic sense, said Jun Nakamura, a spokesman for the company. 
 The Osaka-based chain's plan drew international attention because it tested the boundaries of Japan's ban on imported rice. Earlier this month, however, the Japanese Government decided that sushi, which is a slab of raw fish on top of a chunk of rice, could be allowed in because it is a processed food, not rice itself.
 
Protests and Lawsuits
 Some agricultural groups have protested the plan and right-wing groups have hurled insults at the restaurants from loudspeaker trucks, Mr. Nakamura said.
He added that even before the sushi plan came to the public's attention, Mr. Matsumoto had a falling-out with three other large shareholders. In August, the company, apparently acting on orders from the three shareholders, filed lawsuits against Mr. Matsumoto and Mr. Saito. Mr. Nakamura said he could not discuss the charges in the suits but said they were not directly related to the import plan.
In addition, Mr. Saito, who owns the factory in Escondido, Calif., in which the sushi was to have been made, is on trial in district court in Kobe on charges he tried to evade duties on beef he imported from the United States.
 
New Company to Pursue Plan
 Mr. Matsumoto, in an interview, said he and Mr. Saito quit because the other shareholders were not enthusiastic about the import plan. He and Mr. Saito have formed a new company, named Rice Power, to import the sushi from the California factory and to distribute it to supermarkets. He characterized the Government charges against Mr. Saito as a mere dispute over the valuation of the imported beef.
As president of Sushi Boy, Mr. Matsumoto said the American sushi would be far less expensive because it could use California rice, which is a fifth or less the cost of Japanese rice, and because the sushi would be mass-produced rather than made by hand.
But Mr. Nakamura of Sushi Boy said the rice constitutes only a small fraction of the cost of the sushi, so using American rice does not cut overall costs much, especially once transportation is figured in. And the savings from mass production can be achieved equally well by using a Japanese factory, he said.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Funds Are Up But Taxable Yields Decline

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Money market fund yields were mixed in the seven-day period ended yesterday, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report survey of more than 862 tax-exempt and taxable funds.
The rise in tax-exempt yields this week, a contrast to last week's drop, came as no surprise to IBC/Donoghue's analysts. They noted that the municipal bond market was stabilizing, since the heavy issuance of debt had abated, allowing investor demand to catch up to supply. The oversupply had exerted upward pressure on yields. 
 Assets of tax-exempt money funds decreased by $137 million for the week, dropping the total assets to $96.8 billion, with the average number of days left to maturity of securities held in fund portfolios down one, to 65, Donoghue's analysts said.
The seven-day average compounded tax-exempt yield rose to 2.18 percent, up from 2.15 percent last week, with the simple yield up a like amount, to 2.16 percent. The 30-day average, which still reflects previous yield declines, is 2.36 percent for the compounded and 2.33 percent for the simple yield, both off 11 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Not factoring in state taxes, the data mean that the taxable equivalent of the seven-day compounded yield was about 3.03 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket and about 3.16 percent for investors in the 31 percent tax bracket.
Of the tax-exempt funds surveyed with assets greater than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue's said the Dreyfus Basic Municipal Money Market fund was the best performer with a yield of 2.90 percent.
 
Taxable Yield: 2.78%
 Among taxable money market funds, yields dipped about 5 basis points, while total assets dropped by $2.5 billion, to $491.2 billion. Of that total, institutional money fund assets lost $3.3 billion, to $170.8 billion, while the public funds gained $800 million, to a total of $320.4 billion.
The average seven-day compounded yield for a taxable money market fund was 2.78 percent, down from 2.83 percent last week and the simple yield was off 5 basis points to 2.74 percent. For the 30-day period, the average compounded yield is 2.83 percent and the simple yield is 2.79 percent, both down 3 basis points.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in portfolios rose by one, to 65, with the Standby Reserve Fund, distributed by Cowen & Company in New York, the top performer among general purpose funds with a yield of 3.78 percent. For government-only funds with assets under $100 million United Services Government Securities Savings fund, distributed by United Services in San Antonio was tops again at 3.97 percent.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donoghue's, said he did not expect yields to move sharply, because recent economic news had taken the pressure off the Federal Reserve to ease rates over the short term.
Elsewhere, the average yield on a bank money market account fell to 2.79 percent this week, from 2.80 percent last week.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Lumber Prices Soar on Talk Of Small Timber Harvest

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Lumber futures rose the daily limit of $5 per thousand board feet yesterday amid speculation of a smaller-than-expected timber harvest.
Logging restrictions in forest lands of the Pacific Northwest and a cutback in production at smaller mills touched off a seasonal price rally for lumber. 
 In other markets, copper, platinum and sugar closed higher, while energy futures settled mixed.
The lumber industry sees the end of October as a seasonal low point for lumber prices, according to Curt Cunningham, president of Pacific Futures Trading in Seattle. In a typical year, a rally begins in late October and extends to February or March.
"I would expect a significantly larger rally this season," said Mr. Cunningham, who added that tight supplies, coupled with strong Japanese demand could possibly extend this rally into April.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, November lumber futures closed on the highs of the day at $225 per thousand board feet, and January lumber ended at $226.60.
 
Strike Threat Stirs Copper Sales
A potential strike by 19,600 union workers at one of the largest copper mines in Chile reignited nervous buying of copper futures on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
December copper settled up 0.70 cent at 101.20 cents a pound, despite a Commerce Department report that orders for durable goods fell four-tenths of 1 percent in September. Copper is a component of many durable goods.
Another important durable good, platinum, closed on a firmer note at the New York Mercantile Exchange. Perceptions that supplies were tightening persisted, prompting the January contract to close with a gain of $2.20 at $356 an ounce.
Indications that thesugar cane crop in South Africa would be smaller than expected because of a drought helped support world sugar prices. March sugar rose 0.17 cent, to 8.81 cents a pound.
December crude oil settled 10 cents higher at $21.12 a barrel on the New York Merc, while November heating oil lost 0.25 cent, to 61.40 cents a gallon, after the American Petroleum Institute reported a 1.76 million increase in barrels in storage. November unleaded fell 0.25 cent, to 59.65 cents a gallon, at the close.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up on Expectations Of Declining Rates Abroad

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar continued its steady advance yesterday, settling higher across the board on world currency markets.
Gold prices settled mostly higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $339.40 an ounce, up $2 from Tuesday. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $338.85, up $1.60. 
 Analysts said the dollar continued to test the upward limits of its recent trading range, briefly piercing an important technical barrier against the German mark before retreating and settling firmly above a critical level of 123 Japanese yen.
Concerns that Japanese and some European central banks will be forced to lower interest rates helped the dollar. Lower interest rates abroad make American securities more attractive to investors, increasing their need for dollars.
 
Help From the Bank of England
 The dollar received more help later in the day after Robin Leigh-Pemberton, the governor of the Bank of England, said he did not see inflation building in the British economy. "The prospect is for lower interest rates there," said Randolph Donney, director of research at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
Separately, Mr. Donney said there was little reaction to Government reports showing that factory orders fell in September while personal income rose.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 122.05 yen, down 0.23 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 122.55 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 123.18 yen, up from 122.15 yen.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.5745 from $1.5845 late Tuesday. In New York, it cost $1.5735 to buy one pound, down from Tuesday's $1.5775.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates included: 1.5455 German marks, up from 1.5285; 1.3745 Swiss francs, up from 1.3595; 5.2470 French francs, up from 5.1860; 1,331.00 Italian lire, up from 1,327.00, and 1.2378 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2361.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5405 German marks, up from 1.5315; 1.3715 Swiss francs, up from 1.3620; 5.2265 French francs, up from 5.1955; 1.7350 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7255; 1,331.75 Italian lire, up from 1,331.00, and 1.2400 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2381.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $338.55 an ounce from $338.15 Tuesday.
Silver also gained ground. On the Comex, silver for current delivery settled at $3.757 an ounce, up from $3.739 Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Water, Water Everywhere . . .

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
A GLANCE at the big water projects bill on President Bush's desk might leave the impression of pork as usual: choice morsels include everything from $20 million to clean up an abandoned mine in Leadville, Colo., to an $85 million write-off for aqueducts to green the lawns of Phoenix.
But this is no ordinary exercise in pre-election benevolence. For the centerpiece of the legislation is a radical change in the way subsidized Federal water would be distributed to Californians -- one that would put the environment's interests ahead of agriculture, while creating a free market for water that would almost inevitably mean a lot more for parched cities and a little less for irrigation. 
 A Presidential signature on the bill would infuriate California farmers, who talk loudly and carry big wallets. Vetoing it, however, or letting it die this Saturday, would undermine candidate Bush's popularity in must-win Western states.
A veto, moreover, would dismay the pragmatic environmentalists who have been the President's sometime allies. "This is as close to free market environmentalism as one can expect in the real world," said Tom Graff, senior attorney for the Environmental Defense Fund.
One-fifth of the water used by Californians is drawn from the north and stored in a giant plumbing system built by Uncle Sam in the 1940's. And virtually all of it is used to make the desert bloom with everything from cotton to kiwis.
The catch -- well, one catch -- is that the farmers are charged just a fraction of the cost of this Central Valley Project. Bill Bradley of New Jersey, a leading Senate critic of the arrangement, estimates that Washington picks up 95 percent of the tab in the most generous of the water contracts.
For decades, opponents of the water subsidies, mostly urban Democrats, were brushed aside by politically savvy farmers. But rapidly growing cities have increasingly been puckered by periodic droughts. And environmentalists have increasingly become aware that water diverted to farms means double trouble, disrupting rivers that shelter wildlife and leaching chemicals into delicate ecologies.
Economists added fuel to their ire, pointing out that subsidies discouraged water-saving irrigation, while encouraging the cultivation of low-value grasses for cattle food along with what the Economist magazine once called "monsoon crops."
The Environmental Defense Fund has brokered deals in which urbanites paid for agricultural conservation and split the benefits with the farmers. But to the surprise of almost everyone, the breakthrough came in Congress.
Led by Senator Bradley and by Representative George Miller, a senior California Democrat with a suburban Bay Area constituency, Congress linked coveted Western water projects to changes in Central Valley pricing and allocation. Under the bill, the first 800,000 acre-feet -- roughly the amount consumed by a million suburban families -- would be dedicated to keeping wetlands wet.
Farmers would be allowed to renew their contracts for the other seven million acre-feet usually available. And they would be able to sell the water to urban water districts for whatever price the market would bear. But to induce conservation, they would be charged sharply higher prices for the last 20 percent of the water delivered. And a separate fee would finance a $50 million a year program to mitigate environmental damage.
The farmers and their important friends are furious. Senator John Seymour, the California Republican who faces an uphill battle against Diane Feinstein, bitterly fought the provisions and even tied up the Senate for a day by requiring a word-for-word reading of the 396-page bill. And earlier this month, Pete Wilson, the Republican Governor of California, wrote that its passage would be "a vicious economic blow to California."
Mr. Graff thinks the farmers are overreacting. He notes that they have long been at risk of losing some of their water by action in the courts, where environmental claims are being taken more seriously.
Nor is it clear that the new system would really disrupt agribusiness. Tom Jensen, the head of the Grand Canyon Trust who served as counsel to the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, believes that virtually all farmers should be able to cope simply by switching away from alfalfa, rice and cotton.
During the California primary, President Bush vowed to veto the Bradley-Miller bill. But it is very popular in other states where Mr. Bush is running close races with Bill Clinton. And free market types on the President's policy staff are making no secret of their enthusiasm for the bill's water-trading provisions.
Moreover, if the President is tempted to sign, he will have a good excuse. The bill is softer on farmers than the draft he criticized last May. Indeed, while the final version does exact a price, it insures their privileged access to Federal water for decades to come.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Assessing the Candidates' Health-Care Ideas

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
If, with so few days left before you have to pull the lever, the differences between the Republican and Democratic proposals for health care still seem fuzzy, you could do worse than tune into tonight's edition of "The Health Quarterly" at 10 P.M. on Channel 13.
Roger Mudd visits families caught in what he calls "the great American health-care squeeze." All are worried about the loss of health insurance, a condition that afflicts 37 million people, most of whom make too much money to qualify for Federal help but too little to buy insurance on their own. 
 After laying out the plans put forward by President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton, Mr. Mudd asks for assessments by two health-care analysts: Uwe Reinhardt, a professor of political economy at Princeton University, and Stuart Altman, who was a health-care adviser to Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford.
Both express skepticism that the Bush plan to give vouchers to low-income families can do the job. Mr. Reinhardt says he doubts that the maximum credit of $3,750 would enable most people to buy adequate insurance.
But he also says the Clinton plan, which would create pools of private insurers to offer group insurance to employers at lower costs, has not been spelled out sufficiently to permit an analysis of the figures. Moreover, as he sees it, compelling a business to offer health insurance is a way of using it as a tax collector for Washington. He concludes, "If both camps tell you they don't have to raise taxes to fund this, both are telling you a fib."
As for the promises of both candidates to contain ever-rising medical costs, Mr. Altman sees more hope in the Clinton plan than in the Bush plan, but he adds that the controls could mean limitations on certain kinds of care: "You might have to wait for a while." He gives the Clinton plan a B+ and the Bush plan a C.
Mr. Reinhardt gives both a sardonic A+: "They tell you very little, they leave things very vague and they play to an electorate that cannot stand the truth." For those who can stand the truth, tonight's program offers more of it than the candidates have.

HEADLINE: WHERE TO FIND IT

BYLINE: By Terry Trucco

 BODY:
"ALL people are not perfect," said W. Burdette Hunton, strolling past a row of dress forms made by his concern, the Wolf Form Company, in Englewood, N.J. Most of the forms were, in fact, a perfect women's size 8, which clothing manufacturers favor for sample garments. But there was also a custom-made women's size 16, with inches added to waist and bust; a child's form with a removable head, and a generous men's size 50, ordered by an opera company.
People with polished skills and pattern-perfect measurements seldom have problems fitting garments. But for most stitchers, a clothing form can be a vital tool, particularly if it is customized. Fitting problems are often eliminated by using a form, and for sophisticated methods of clothing construction, like French draping, a form is a necessity. 
 A custom form is also helpful when the sewer is shaping clothes to disguise a sloping shoulder, a raised hip or other minor imperfections.
The recession and sky-high clothing prices have contributed to a small boom in home sewing after years of decline. "Some people also find it satisfying to make their own clothes," said Bruno Ferri, the president of Wolf Form.
Wolf, which dates from the early 1900's, creates garment forms primarily for designers, clothing manufacturers and fashion schools. But the company sells directly to individuals as well, and it accepts custom orders. Clients can stop by for a fitting or can fill out a detailed measurement form, available by mail. Forms start at $450.
A Wolf form gets its shape from a sturdy papier-mache core made from molds. Cores are padded with cotton stock, covered with cream-colored Irish linen and placed on adjustable metal rods. The company has more than 1,200 molds in stock and makes new ones when needed. Sizes and shapes change, after all. "When I started here in 1931, a women's size 10 was a 34 1/2-inch bust, 24 1/2-inch waist, 34 1/2-inch hip," Mr. Hunton said. Today a size 8 is even larger than a size 10, measuring 36 inches, 26 inches, 38 inches.
WOLF FORM COMPANY , 17 Van Nos trand Avenue, Englewood, N.J. 07631; (201) 567-6556 or (212) 255-4508.
 
Make That 'Fashion Forms'
 "The word 'dress form' makes you think of something Grandma had in the attic," said LaVina Scott, a fashion design instructor for 25 years. So when Mrs. Scott invented a do-it-yourself method for making dress forms in 1968, she decided to call them fashion forms. In 1975 she published a book, "Sew Clothes to You," with step-by-step instructions ($24.95, available by mail). Based in Stockton, Calif., she now travels widely, giving seminars on making fashion forms.
"The idea was to make a form that fit the body perfectly," Mrs. Scott said. "A form that duplicates you offers proficiency in fitting, draping and pattern alteration." She also wanted a lightweight form that the stitcher could plunge pins into with ease. Her solution was to make a papier-mache model of the sewer's body and fill it with liquid polyurethane, then pad and cover the form.
Forms take 40 to 80 hours to make. "And you need someone to help you put the papier-mache on yourself," Mrs. Scott said. She suggests that the form be made on a day when the sewer is at a slightly heavier weight than average, since it is easier to fit fabric snugly.
Mrs. Scott also offers a three-hour video on French draping with a fashion form ($49.99 through December, $79.99 thereafter).
LAVINA SCOTT , 875 West Sonoma Avenue, Stockton, Calif. 95204;  (209) 463-3989.
 
Forms by Mail
 "It's so much easier to sew with a dress form," said Alan Wootton, the sales manager of the National Thread and Supply Corporation, a 44-year-old mail-order company specializing in sewing supplies. National offers several dress forms, all currently under $150. The biggest seller is the Dritz "My Double," a flexible plastic shell covered with a blue-gray nylon knitted material ($119.95). Small wheels at the neck, bust, waist and hips adjust each measurement. A free catalogue is available.
NATIONAL THREAD AND SUPPLY CORPORATION , 695 Red Oak Road, Stockbridge, Ga. 30281; (800) 331-7600.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 234 words

HEADLINE: Gross National Letdown

 BODY:
President Bush smiled when he learned this week that economic growth during the third quarter reached a surprising 2.7 percent, almost twice the previous rate. But his smile shouldn't be broad. The new figure almost certainly exaggerates the health of the economy, which continues to creep along at a painfully slow pace.
Even the 2.7 figure is half the normal rate of recovery and not enough to bring down unemployment. And there are plenty of reasons to question whether the third-quarter pace will continue. Part of the uptick was due to an aberrant surge in defense spending, another part to consumers drawing down savings at an unsustainable rate. And the figure may well be revised downward once the Commerce Department checks its technical procedures for handling inflation. 
 So after scouring the new data, what picture emerges? The economy is growing, but barely. Unemployment isn't likely to fall very much. Wages will probably continue to stagnate.
The picture isn't alarming, but neither is it encouraging. Unless the fourth quarter produces dramatic improvement, the first order of business for the new Congress will be to stimulate the economy with a package of temporary tax cuts and accelerated infrastructure investment. The package will have to be big enough to matter, but self- liquidating so that Wall Street need not fear a substantial increase in the Federal debt.

LENGTH: 469 words

HEADLINE: For Congress From the Suburbs

 BODY:
Some of the more provocative Congressional contests this year are in New York City's suburbs. Here are our recommendations in some key contested races, based on interviews and an analysis of candidates' records.
 Second District (Suffolk County): It's disappointing that Representative Tom Downey, who went to Washington in 1975 as a young Democratic reformer, has let power go to his head. He still bristles at criticism of a 1990 junket to Barbados, where he and other lawmakers mixed with lobbyists who had business before their committee. Even so, on many domestic issues and especially child care and welfare, Mr. Downey continues to provide an unusually knowledgeable voice. 
 His Republican opponent, Rick Lazio, is an engaging Suffolk County legislator who clearly has a future in politics, but we endorse Mr. Downey for his mastery of substantive issues.
Third District (Nassau): This lively race pits Nassau County Comptroller Peter King, the Republican candidate, against the Democrat Steve Orlins, a businessman making his first try at elective office. Still supportive of failed Reagan-Bush economic policies and zealously opposed to abortion rights, Mr. King has misused his office by auditing abortion clinics. Though he sounded belated alarms, he also has to bear some responsibility for Nassau's shaky finances.
It's unfortunate that Mr. Orlins opposes any new tax increases, but we endorse him as the better bet to provide responsible representation.
Fourth District (Nassau): Voters would be well served by either candidate -- David Levy, a Hempstead Town Councilman, or Philip Schiliro, a Democrat and a top aide to Representative Henry Waxman of California.
Mr. Levy, a moderate Republican closely tied to the party machine, emphasizes the need to reduce the deficit and energize the economy. Mr. Schiliro focuses on environmental issues, reflecting his key role in shaping the landmark Clean Air Act. Both support abortion rights, though Mr. Levy would impose restrictions. Because of his Congressional experience, we favor Mr. Schiliro.
 19th District (Putnam and parts of Westchester, Orange and Dutchess counties): Voters in this revamped district have a choice between two well-qualified candidates. The veteran Hamilton Fish Jr., a Republican, has provided diligent leadership while his opponent, Neil McCarthy, a Democrat, is an impressively knowledgeable lawyer.
Mr. Fish's opposition to abortion rights is troubling, especially since he bases his position on a tortured and fragile legal argument. Still, it is difficult to reject a Congressman who has compiled such an admirably strong and progressive record on other issues, especially in the area of civil rights. We urge Mr. McCarthy to try again, but support Mr. Fish's bid for a 13th term.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 365 words

HEADLINE: Water to the Rich Shouldn't Be World Preservation Ethic

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Slaking California's Thirst" (editorial, Oct. 13), in which you commend a bill approved by Congress that says "water developed with Federal funds is a commodity no different from food and fuel that can be bought and sold within reasonable limits to the highest bidder": 
 Years of drought and economic depression are very poor excuses to extend the failed theory that water is a commodity, managed by market pressures and sold to the highest bidder. In Colorado, water all runs toward money, instead of downhill. East Slope cities divert most of their water from the West Slope of the Rockies, because they bought the right to do so. The result: megapopulations and megapollution in their part of the state. The natural alternative is a larger number of smaller cities downstream, all across the state. Much better for the human and natural environment, too.
The West Slope had an oil shale boom a few years ago; the oil companies bought water rights from ranches all over the drainage, then went out of business. The result? Dry, sagebrush-covered land replaced grassy grazing land. Plus a large pool of "water rights" for sale to the highest bidder, probably San Diego. Water for Colorado ranching generally drains slowly back into the rivers for use again downstream, but water for cities just disappears from here. Agriculture can never be the highest bidder for water.
The last 50 years haven't done anything except increase the size of the desert cities and their greed for water. Why expect anything different in the next 50 years? You state: "time enough to discover new ways to avoid waste." Yes, but human nature dictates eleventh-hour emergency measures only. Let this be the eleventh hour; deal with it now. If the will is there, there are other ways to achieve the good ends you cite, like guaranteeing enough water in streams and wildlife habitats to restore fisheries and other natural areas.
"Water limits population" sounds a better ethic for preservation of the world than does water to the rich. If there isn't enough water for additional desert-city growth, well, that's life. Literally.
 
LINDA JOHNSON
Basalt, Colo., Oct. 14, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 603 words

HEADLINE: Perot Plan Prescribes an Economic Disaster

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Mr. Perot Presents Some Beef" (editorial, Oct. 19), you let Ross Perot off much too easy.
Mr. Perot's "beef" is spoiled and lacking in nutritional content. His television tables and charts, along with his book, are full of more obfuscations, inconsistencies and inaccuracies than you mention and, more fundamentally, lack understanding of how a modern economy functions. 
 You write that Mr. Perot presents "a damning indictment of how America's $4 trillion debt has inhibited productive investment and burdened future generations." Notwithstanding that the debt held by the public, that is, outside the Government itself, is $3 trillion, not $4 trillion, where did Mr. Perot explain how the debt inhibited investment and burdened future generations? It certainly is not in his oft-repeated one-liner that "we are spending our children's money."
As any economist can tell you -- or might have told him -- the issue is not using up people's money; money can always be printed. It is what we do to enlarge and use our resources of labor and capital productively.
The high-minded seminar with which you credit Mr. Perot was not high-minded at all, but a pandering to popular misunderstanding. A truly high-minded seminar would have explained that the real issues about debt and deficits relate to how they affect purchasing power, output and employment now, and how they affect our investment in the future. It would also have explained that Mr. Perot, or any business accountant, would hardly tolerate in his business the way our Federal deficits are calculated, failing to separate capital or investment spending from the current account.
Mr. Perot charges others with plans for which the numbers do not add up. My reading of his book and his not-too-clear television presentation of tables and charts is that a major part of budget balancing would come from increased taxes on gasoline, which he also pledges to use to rebuild our highways! I am all in favor of this, but one can't use the same tax dollars to reduce the deficit and to build roads! Economists have a phrase for that: double-counting.
But most fundamentally, Mr. Perot's plan of drastic tax increases and expenditure cuts would be a disaster for the economy in the short term, depriving us of billions of dollars of needed purchasing power over a period when none but the most sluggish recovery, if any, is in sight. And over the long term, Mr. Perot's single-minded focus on eliminating the budget deficit, as it is miscalculated, would prevent us from making the public and private investment in infrastructure, education, research and new technology on which our future depends. All of that has nothing to do with spending our children's money.
George Bush has presented no responsible fiscal plan, and his campaign has offered a variety of dubious tax cuts to be matched by unspecified decreases in "spending." Bill Clinton presents numbers that are hardly "wildly optimistic" and do add up, at least as well as any forecasts of an uncertain future can.
Governor Clinton too would reduce the deficit, somewhat more than in the forecasts of the Bush Administration's budgets, but he would do it in the one way that would help the economy and not wreck it.
That is, by increasing employment and income, so that less money will have to go out in unemployment benefits and welfare payments and more will go to the Government in higher tax revenues out of the higher incomes, with no general increase in tax rates.
 
ROBERT EISNER
Professor of Economics
Northwestern University
Evanston, Ill., Oct. 21, 1992

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Voting Trigger

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Perhaps you, too, have had a rough time this year deciding which candidate you are less against. Here is how one Undecided Voter reached a decision: I searched for my key trigger.
Each voter has an array of triggers inside his mind: these range from taxes (higher under Clinton) to concern for human rights (lower under Bush); from government domination of the economy (worse with Clinton) to government intrusion into private lives (worse with Bush). 
 The character trigger? My instinct is not to trust Clinton, whose campaign has achieved a Dewey-eyed smugness, but I have learned from hard experience not to trust Bush. (Perotnoia is not an option.)
My own key trigger this year, which is probably not most people's, is bunkerism -- a corrosive penchant for secrecy, compounded by ethical blindness to conflict of interest. A generation ago, I saw that arrogance of insiderdom destroy an Administration and many people's lives; that's why the need for Washington glasnost seizes me now.
As a test, I submitted a question to Bill Clinton last month about more open government: Did he support extension of the Freedom of Information Act, which permits citizen and press access to unclassified papers in executive departments, to cover Congress and the White House?
On any other subject, I would get a call back from Clinton aide George Stephanopoulos the same day; but on this, silence. After weeks of pestering came this fudge: "I support principles of FOIA. . . . Having said that, I have not studied the particular policy questions raised by extending FOIA to Congress and the White House." Having ducked, Mr. Clinton added soothingly: "As President, I would look at this issue with a strong preference for public disclosure. . . ."
He would sell dangerous F-15's to Saudi Arabia and keep open unnecessary defense installations to pick up a few votes, but on a matter that might open up closed-door political operations in the White House -- thereby keeping them clean -- Bill Clinton and his policy wonks were too busy to study the policy question. That puts those few of us whose votes are triggered by excessive secrecy between Little Rock and a hard place.
The hard place is George Bush's refusal to permit independent investigation of obstruction of justice within his Justice Department. He has just personally and publicly joined Attorney General William Barr, his former C.I.A. aide, in the Iraqgate cover-up.
Asked yesterday by Charles Gibson of ABC's "Good Morning America" about accusations in this space, Mr. Bush replied: "He's making charges that are not true. . . . The Justice Department had 40 lawyers that are nonpolitical. And they looked at these charges out of the partisan House [Judiciary] Committee and they said there isn't anything here. Forty that are nonpolitical wrote a 97-page report."
The President is associating himself with the unsigned apologia for nonfeasance attached to his Attorney General's rejection of the House's first call for independent counsel. The "career prosecutors" so often cited therein, whom Mr. Bush misidentifies as 40 "nonpolitical" lawyers, are mainly his political appointees. Most of these whitewashers serve at his pleasure and their jobs depend on his re-election.
The real career prosecutors at Justice include many who have been on the phone to me to express their disgust at the 97-page Barr apologia -- a document already exposed as misleadingly inadequate by the recent C.I.A.-F.B.I. accusations. These veteran straight arrows will not risk retaliation by volunteering evidence to their political boss's patsy prosecutor -- but will testify about their superiors' wrongful interference when a grand jury is convened by a court-appointed independent counsel.
Now to my voting trigger. Mr. Clinton's reluctance to stand foursquare against unnecessary secrecy is troubling, but Mr. Bush's embrace yesterday of a document that may figure in a criminal conspiracy is far worse: his encouragement of Barr's stonewalling places the Iraqgate scandal in the Oval Office.
New York Times columnists traditionally do not endorse any candidate, and I'm for traditional values. But any reader who cannot figure out against whom this lifelong Republican is voting this year isn't trying.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
